superEntry.entry:
alphabetical letter S *
The fourteenth letter of the alphabet; called SaAdN. It is one of the letters termed mahomuwsap [or nonvocal, i. e. pronounced with the breath only, without the voice]; and of the letters termed A^asaliy~ap, as also z and s, because proceeding from the tip of the tongue; (TA;) and is one of the letters termed musotaEoliyap, which are obstacles to A_imaAlap: (M in art. Swd:) it is not conjoined with s, nor with z, [nor, as some say, with j, (see A_ij~aASN,)] in any Arabic word. (TA. [See also art. Swd.]) It is a radical, and a substitute; not an augmentative. (M in art. Swd.) It is sometimes substituted for s; and, as MF observes, what Ibn-Umm-Kásim says appears to mean that this substitution is allowable unrestrictedly; but Ibn-Málik, in the Tes-heel, makes it subject to conditions, saying that it is allowable accord. to a certain dial. when the s is followed by g or x or q or T, even when separated therefrom by a letter or by two letters: MF says that the dial. above mentioned is that of Benu-l-'Ambar, accord. to Sb and others; who give as exs. Sagiba for sagiba, and Saxira for saxira, and SaqabN for saqabN, and SaTaEa for saTaEa. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [As a numeral, S denotes Ninety.]

1 Say^iba raA^osuhu *
1. Say^iba raA^osuhu His head abounded with Suw^aAb [or nits]; (S, M, K;) as also ASA^b↓. (S, K.) Say^iba mina Al$~araAbi, (M, K,) aor.
SaAa^a
, (K,) inf. n. SaA^obN, (M,) He was, or became, satisfied, and filled, with drink: (M, K:) or Say^iba [alone] he drank much water. (S.)

4 A^aSoAa^a
4: see the preceding paragraph.

Suw^obapN *
Suw^obapN A granary, or granaries, (A^anobaAr,) of wheat (TaEaAm). (K.) ― -b2- And A place where dates are dried: so in the dial. of the people of El-Felj. (TA in art. HDr.)

Suw^aAbN *
Suw^aAbN: see the next paragraph, in three places.

Suw^aAbN *
Suw^aAbN, (S, K,) vulgarly pronounced SuwaAbap, without., (MF, TA,) A nit; i. e. an egg of a louse; (S, K;) and an egg of a flea; (K;) but accord. to some, not applied to the latter unless tropically: (MF, TA:) accord. to IDrst, a young louse: (TA:) or the eggs of the flea and of the louse; as also Suw^aAbN↓: (M:) [or,] accord. to the S and K, Suw^aAbN↓ and Siy^obaAnN, (TA,) the latter of which is vulgarly pronounced SiybaAn, without ', (MF, TA,) are pls. of Suw^aAbapN; but the former of them is a coll. gen. n., of which Suw^aAbapN is the n. un.: (TA:) Yaakoob has erroneously asserted that one should not say Siy^obaAnN. (M, TA.) ― -b2- Suw^aAbN↓ is also sometimes applied to (assumed tropical:) The small pieces of gold that are taken forth from the dust, or earth, of the mine. (IDrst, TA.) In the following verse, cited by IAar,
Hay~aA yaA rab~i A^awojidoniY Suw^aAbFA↓
famaA A^araY AlT~ay~aAra yugoniY $ay~aA
the poet means, [O my Lord,] cause me to find gold like Suw^aAb [or nits], whole, or sound, not broken into minute parts; [for I see not the Tay~aAr to stand in any stead; $ay~aA being for $ayoy^FA;] by the Ty~Ar meaning the minutest pieces of gold that the wind blows away. (M, L, TA.) ― -b3- And [the pl.] Siy^obaAnN signifies [also] (assumed tropical:) Hoar-frost formed into grains like small pearls. (A'Obeyd, L, TA.) [And drops of fine rain are said to be likened to Siy^obaAn: see Ham p. 796. See also SabiY~N (in art. Sbw), last sentence.]

miSoA^abN *
miSoA^abN A man who drinks much water: (S:) or who satisfies and fills himself with drink. (K.)

1 Say^ika *
1. Say^ika, aor.
SaAa^a
, (AZ, S, O, K,) inf. n. SaA^akN, (AZ, S, O,) He (a man, AZ, S, O) sweated so that there arose from him a fetid odour, (AZ, S, O, K,) from *afar [app. as meaning stench of the arm-pit], or otherwise. (AZ, S, O.) ― -b2- And, said of blood, It congealed. (O, K.) ― -b3- And Say^ika bihi It (a thing, TA) stuck, or clave, to him. (K, TA.) Hence, accord. to the 'Eyn, SaAka, used in this sense in a verse of El-Aashà: (TA:) or this belongs to art. Syk, (S and O in that art.,) agreeably with the opinion of ISd. (TA in that art.)

3 Zal~a yuSaAy^ikuniY muno*u Alyawomi *
3. Zal~a yuSaAy^ikuniY muno*u Alyawomi He has continued vying with me, or contending with me for superiority, or striving to surpass me, in strength, or power, or force, (yu$aAd~uniY,) all this day. (O, K, * TA.) [And so yuSaAyikuniY, mentioned in the TA in art. Swk; but app. belonging to art. Syk.]

Say^ikN *
Say^ikN A strong man. (O, K.)

SaA^okapN *
SaA^okapN The odour, (K, TA,) i. e. altered odour, (TA,) of a piece of wood when it has become moist. (K, TA.) [And probably The altered colour and odour of rain-water trickling from trees: see what follows.]

SaAy^ikN *
SaAy^ikN, applied to rain trickling from trees, [app. a possessive epithet, meaning *uw SaA^okapK,] Altered in colour and odour. (TA in art. Hlb.)

1 SaA^aY *
1. SaA^aY, (S, M, K,) aor. yaSoy^iY, (M,) like SaEaY aor. yaSoEiY, (S, [in one of my copies of the S yaSoEaY, which is wrong, or, accord. to the TA, both are correct, and in the K the pret. is said to be like saEaY, which implies that the aor. is like yasoEaY,]) inf. n. Say^iY~N (S, M, K) and Siy^iY~N (Ks, M, K, TA) and Suy^iY~N, (Ks, K, TA,) said of a young bird and the like, (S, K,) of a bird and of a young bird (M) and of a rat or mouse (S, M) and of a jerboa (S) and of a cat and of a dog (M) and of a pig and of an elephant, (S, M,) It uttered a cry, or sound; (S, M, K;) as also taSaA='aY↓: (M, K:) and accord. to Fr, one says also of the scorpion, taSiYo'u and taSoy^iY. (S.) It is said in a prov., talodagu AlEaqorabu wataSoy^iY or wataSiYo'u, (As, S, Meyd,) this latter verb being formed by transposition, (Meyd,) i. e. The scorpion stings while uttering a cry; (S, Meyd;) the w being a denotative of state: (As, S:) applied to him who does wrong in the guise of him who complains of wrongdoing. (Meyd.) And one says also, jaA='a bimaA SaA^aY waSamata, (S, K,) and bimaA SaA='a waSamata (IAar, S, TA,) SaA='a being formed by tranposition from SaA^aY, (S,) He brought what was vocal and what was mute; (S, K;) such as slaves and beasts, and clothes and silver; (As, TA;) or sheep or goats, and camels, and gold and silver; (IAar, TA;) meaning he brought much property: and this is likewise a prov. (S.)

4 A^aSoA^ayotuhu *
4. A^aSoA^ayotuhu I made it (i. e. a young bird &c.) to utter a cry, or sound. (M, K. [See 1.])

6 taSaA~a^a
6: see the first paragraph above.

Say^iY~N *
Say^iY~N, of the measure faEiylN, (TA, [originally an inf. n., written in a copy of the M Siy^oYN, but the
former is evidently the right,]) The bitch: so called because of her cry. (TA.)

1 Sab~a *
1. Sab~a, (S, M, Msb, K, &, c.,) aor.
Sabu3a
, inf. n. Sab~N, (M, Msb,) He poured out, or forth (S, M, Msb, K) water (S, M, Msb) and the like. (M.) One says, Sababotu lifulaAnK maA='F fiY AlqadaHi liya$orabahu [I poured out for such a one water into the drinkingcup that he might drink it]. (TA. [See also 8.]) ― -b2- Hence [(assumed tropical:) He paid down a price, or sum of money:] it is said in a trad., A_ino A^aHab~a A^aholuka A^ano waAHidapF A^aSab~a lahumo vamanaka Sub~apF↓, meaning [(assumed tropical:) If thy family like that I should pay down to them thy price] at once, or at one time. (L, TA.) ― -b3- And Sab~a AlHabola fiY Albiy^ori [(assumed tropical:) He lowered, or let down, the rope into the well] on the occasion of drawing water. (M in art. tl.) ― -b4- And lamo yaSub~a raA^osahu (assumed tropical:) He did not bend down his head: occurring in a trad. relating to prayer. (T, TA.) ― -b5- And Sub~a rijolaA fulaAnK fiY Alqayodi (tropical:) The legs of such a one were [put into the shackles, or] shackled. (Z, L, TA.) ― -b6- And Sab~a diroEahu (tropical:) He put on, or clad himself with, his coat of mail: (A, TA:) and SababotuhaA Ealayohi (tropical:) [I put it on him]. (A.) ― -b7- And Sab~a Ealayohi nafosahu (tropical:) [He threw himself upon him]. (A.) ― -b8- And huwa yaSub~u A_ilaY~a Alxayora (tropical:) [He pours forth to me wealth]. (A, TA.) ― -b9- And Sab~a A@ll~`hu Ealayohimo sawoTa Ea*aAbK (tropical:) [God poured upon them a portion, or a share, or vehemence, or severity, of punishment; or] God punished them. (A, * TA. [See also sawoTN.]) And Sab~a A@ll~`hu Ealayohi SaAEiqapF (tropical:) [God poured upon him a thunderbolt, or a destructive punishment, &c.]. (A, TA.) See also another ex. voce Sab~N. ― -b10- And Sub~a, (K, TA,) in the pass. form, said of a man, and of a thing, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He, or it, was annihilated, caused to pass away, or done away with. (K, TA. [See also R. Q. 2.]) ＝ -A2- See also 7, with which it is syn. in the first of the senses assigned to the latter below. ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] Sab~a fiY AlwaAdiY (assumed tropical:) He descended into the valley. (M, K.) And qadamaAhu fiY baToni AinoSab~ato↓ AlwaAdiY, occurring in a trad., means (assumed tropical:) His feet descended [into the interior, or bottom, of the valley]: (TA:) or AnoSab~ato qadamaAhu fiY AlwaAdiY means (assumed tropical:) his feet rested in the valley; from AinoSab~a said of water. (Mgh.) ― -b3- And Sab~ati AlHay~apu EalaY Almaloduwgi, (S, * TA,) or AnSb~t↓, (A,) (tropical:) [The serpent darted down upon the person bitten by it], said of the serpent when it has raised itself desiring to bite. (Ez-Zuhree, S, TA. *) And AlbaAziY EalaY AlS~ayodi AnSb~↓ (tropical:) [The hawk, or falcon, stooped upon the prey, or quarry]. (A, TA.) And Sab~a *uw^aAlapu EalaY ganami fulaAnK (A, * TA) (tropical:) The wolf [rushed upon or] made havock among the sheep, or goats, of such a one. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Sab~a, (IAar, A, TA,) sec. pers. Sabibota, (S, M, * K,) aor. yaSab~u, (IAar, TA,) inf. n. SabaAbapN, (IAar, S, * M, A, K, * TA,) He (a man) was, or became, affected with excessive love, or with attachment, or admiring love, (IAar, S, TA,) and desire: (S:) or with desire: (M, A, K:) or with tenderness of desire, (S, M, A, K,) and ardour thereof: (S:) or with tenderness of love. (M, K.) One says, Sabibotu A_ilayohi [I was, or became, affected with excessive love, &c., for him]. (M, A, * TA. *) And Sab~a bihaA and A_ilayohaA He was, or became, affected with desire, or vehement desire, [&c.,] of, or for, her. (MA.) ― -b2- Lh mentions, among what is said by the women of the Arabs of the desert on the occasion of fascinating by means of charms, faA@Sobabo A_ilayohi Sab~N↓, i. e. A^ariqN faA^oraqo A_ilayohi [as though meaning May he be sleepless by reason of love, and I will be sleepless for him: but I incline to think that the explanation has been corrupted by a copyist from raq~a faA^ariq~a A_ilayohi, or lahu, meaning may he be tender-hearted to me, and I will be tenderhearted to him]. (M, L, TA.)

4 A^aSab~uwA *
4. A^aSab~uwA They (a company of men, TA) took their way down a declivity, or declivous place. (M, K, TA.)

5 taSab~a3a
5: see 7, in four places. ― -b2- And see also what here follows.

6 taSaAbabotu AlmaA='a *
6. taSaAbabotu AlmaA='a I drank what remained of the water (S, A, K) in a vessel: (S, A:) [or] you say, tSAb~ AlS~ubaAbapa and ASTb~hA↓ and tSb~bhA↓ [he drank what remained of the water, or of the milk, in a vessel]; (M, L;) all signifying the same. (L, TA.) ― -b2- And [hence,] taSaAb~a fulaAnN AlmaEiy$apa baEoda fulAnK [lit. Such a one drank the remains of life after such a one], meaning (tropical:) such a one outlived such a one: (A, * TA:) and taSaAbabotuhumo A^ajomaEiyna A_il~aA waAHidFA (tropical:) [I outlived them all except one]. (TA.) Esh-Shemmákh says, (M,) or ElAkhtal, (TA,)
laqawomN taSaAbabotu AlmaEiy$apa baEodahumo
A^aEaz~u EalaY~a mino EifaA='K tagay~araA
(tropical:) [Verily the loss of a people whom I have outlived is more severe to me than abundant and long hair that has become altered in colour]: he means, the loss of those with whom I was in a state of ease and plenty is more severe to me than my hair's becoming white: (M:) Az says, he likens what remained of his life to the remains of beverage that he was sipping up. (TA.)

7 AnSb~ *
7. AnSb~ It (water, S, M, and the like, M) poured out or forth, or became poured out or forth; (S, M, A, K;) as also Sab~a↓, (M, Msb, K,) aor.
Sabi3a
, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. SabiybN; (Msb;) and tSb~b↓, (M, K,) which is of a form rarely occurring as that of a quasi-pass. of an unaugmented triliteral verb, being generally that of the quasi-pass. of a verb of the form faE~ala; (MF, TA;) [but this app. denotes its doing so repeatedly; and abundantly, like tadaf~aqa, q. v.;] and ASTb~↓. (K.) One says, AlmaA='u yanoSab~u mina Aljabali, (TA,) and mn Aljbl yataSab~abu↓, (S, TA,) The water descends, little by little, from the mountain. (S, TA.) And AlEaraqu tSb~b↓ [The sweat flowed], and Ald~amu [the blood]. (A.) And EaraqFA taSab~abotu↓ [which may be rendered I flowed with sweat] is a phrase of the Arabs, meaning tSb~b EaraqiY [my sweat flowed]: thus the act is literally ascribed to the speaker, and what is essentially the agent becomes a specificative: it is not allowable to say EaraqFA taSab~abotu; for, as it is not allowable to put the agent before the verb, so it is not allowable to put the specificative, when it is virtually the agent, before the verb. (IJ, M.) ― -b2- One says also, AnSb~ Alkuwzu [The mug had its contents poured out or forth]. (TA in art. dfq.) ― -b3- See also 1, in three places. ― -b4- AnSb Aln~aAsu EalaY AlmaA='i [generally implies descent, but] means (assumed tropical:) The people collected together, or assembled, at the water. (Msb.) ― -b5- [And AnSb~ is often said of a place, or the ground, &c., meaning (assumed tropical:) It sloped downwards. ― -b6- Har (p. 125) uses the phrase tanoSab~u A_ilaY All~ahowi, meaning (as there expl.) (assumed tropical:) Thou inclinest to diversion, or sport..]

8 ASTb~ AlmaA='a *
8. ASTb~ AlmaA='a is expl. by Sb as signifying He took for himself the water; agreeably with general analogy: (M:) [but it is more properly rendered he poured out for himself the water:] one says, AiSoTababotu linafosiY maA='F mina Alqirobapi liA^a$orabahu [I poured out for myself water from the skin that I might drink it]: and AiSoTababotu linafosiY qadaHFA [I poured out for myself a cup]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 6. ― -b3- And see 7.

R. Q. 1 SaboSabahu *
R. Q. 1. SaboSabahu (assumed tropical:) He annihilated it, caused it to pass away, or did away with it; (M, K; *) namely, a thing. (M.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) He dispersed it, or scattered it: (K:) he (a man) dispersed, or scattered, it, namely, an army, or property or wealth. (AA, K.)

R. Q. 2 taSaboSaba *
R. Q. 2. taSaboSaba (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, annihilated, caused to pass away, or done away with; (S, M, K;) it passed, or went, away; said of a thing. (S, M. [See also Sub~a.]) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) It (the night, M, A, K, and the day, AZ, TA, and the heat, A) passed, or went, away, (AZ, M, A, K,) except a small portion, (AZ, M, TA,) or for the most part. (A. K.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) It (what was in a water-skin, or milk-skin,) became little in quantity. (Fr, TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) It (a company of men) became dispersed, or scattered. (M, TA.) ＝ -A2- He (a man) was, or became, very bold, or daring, and very adverse, or repugnant, (M, * K, * TA,) EalayonaA [against us]. (TA.) ― -b2- And, said of a day, It was, or became, intensely hot. (M, K, * TA.)

Sab~N *
Sab~N is an inf. n. [and is] used [as an epithet] in the sense of the measure faAEilN, or of the measure mafoEuwlN: (TA:) [thus it is used as an epithet] applied to water, [meaning Pouring out or forth, or poured out or forth,] like as are sakobN and gaworN: (S, TA: [see also SaAb~N and SabiybN:]) and hence, in 'Alee's description of Aboo-Bekr, when he died, kunota EalaY AlkaAfiriyna Ea*aAbFA Sab~FA (assumed tropical:) [Thou wast, against, or upon, the unbelievers, a punishment pouring forth, or poured forth]. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence, app.,] one says, Darabahu DarobFA Sab~FA, meaning (assumed tropical:) He smote him with the edge of the sword [as though with a smiting pouring down, or poured down]; as also
HadorF. (IAar, L, TA.) ― -b3- One says also, Darabahu miAy^ipF faSab~FA, (TA,) or A^axa*a miAy^apF faSab~FA, (A,) meaning, (tropical:) [He smote him with a hundred blows, or he took a hundred,] and less than that, i. e. faduwna *`lika, (TA,) contr. of faSaAEidFA; (A;) or and more [than that], or above [that], i. e. like faSaAEidFA, (A, TA,) i. e. maA fawoqa *`lika. (TA.) ― -b4- And Ealayohi AlbalaA='u Sub~a↓, mino Sab~K, meaning (tropical:) [Trial, or affliction, was poured upon him] from above. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, applied to a man, Affected with excessive love, or with attachment, or admiring love, (IAar, S, A, * TA,) and desire: (S:) or with desire: (M, A, * K:) or with tenderness of desire, (S, * M, A, * K,) and ardour thereof: (S: * [see Sab~a:]) or with tenderness of love. (M, K.) One says, huwa Sab~N bihaA (and A_ilayohaA (see Sab~a)] He is affected with excessive love of her; &c.: (A:) fem. Sab~apN: (M, K:) dual masc. Sab~aAni, pl. masc. Sab~uwna; dual. fem. Sab~ataAni, pl. fem. Sab~aAtN: thus accord. to those who hold rajulN Sab~N to be similar to rajulN fahimN and Ha*irN, originally SabibN: (TA:) [hence it appears that some hold Sab~N to be originally an inf. n., and therefore use it as an epithet in its original form, without regard to gender or number: but] accord. to Sb, Sab~N is [originally] of the measure faEilN, because you say Sabibotu SabaAbapF, like as you say qaniEotu qanaAEapF. (M.) See also 1, last sentence.

Sub~N *
Sub~N: see Sub~apN. ― -b2- Accord. to AO, it may also be pl. of SabuwbN↓ or of SaAb~N↓: but Az says that, accord. to others, it is not pl. of either of these two words; their pl. being SububN: (L, TA:) it is said in a trad., (S, L, TA,) respecting conflicts and factions, or seditions, (L, TA,) lataEuwdun~a fiyhaA A^asaAwida Sub~FA yaDoribu baEoDukumo riqaAba baEoDK: (S, L, TA:) here by A^asaAwid are meant “ [great and noxious] serpents: ” (L, TA:) and Sub~FA, accord. to Ez-Zuhree, is from AlS~ab~u [“ the act of pouring out or forth ”]; for the serpent, he says, when it desires to bite, raises itself, and then darts down (lit. pours down) upon him that is bitten: (S, L, TA:) [as though the meaning were, Ye will be, therein, like great and noxious serpents, one portion of you smiting the necks of another portion:] Ez-Zuhree says that Sub~FA is pl. of SabuwbN↓, and originally SububFA; like as rajulN Sab~N is originally SabibN; and so says IAmb: but IAar is related to have said that A^asaAwid means companies, pl. of sawaAdN; and Sub~FA, pouring, one upon another, with slaughter: and some say that it is Sub~aY, in measure like HubolaY; and it is said to be from SabaA, [for SabaA A_ilaY Ald~unoyaA,] aor. yaSobuw, meaning “ he inclined to the things of the present world; ” and thus to be like guz~aY, pl. of gaAzK: [see SaAbK, in art. Sbw:] IAar used also to say that it is originally Sub~aA^F, with ', [pl. of SaAbiy^N,] from SabaA^F Ealayohi “ he came, or came forth, upon him unexpectedly. ” (L, TA.)

Sub~apN *
Sub~apN A quantity of wheat or food, &c., that is poured out or forth (M, K) together, or collectedly; (M;) also (M, K) sometimes (M) termed Sub~N↓. (M, K.) See also 1, near the beginning. ― -b2- And A suforap [or piece of skin in which the traveller puts his food; or the thing upon which one eats]; (M, K;) so called because the food is poured into it, or upon it: (M:) or a thing like the suforap: (M, K:) and Sun~apN, with n, signifies the same. (M.) ― -b3- See also SubaAbapN, with which it is syn. ― -b4- Also A company of men: (M, Msb, K:) [app. tropical; but it is said that] this is the primary meaning, and it is used in relation to camels, and sheep or goats, and the like, tropically. (TA.) ― -b5- (tropical:) A detached number of horses, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) and of camels, (A, K,) and of sheep or goats, (A, Msb, K,) and of dirhems, or pieces of money: (A:) or from ten to forty: (A, K:) or from twenty to thirty and forty of camels and of sheep or goats: or less than a hundred (M, A, K) of camels: (M, K:) or of camels i. q. SiromapN: (S:) and from ten to forty of goats: (AZ, S:) or a flock of sheep or a herd of goats, as being likened to a company of men: (TA:) or from twenty to forty of sheep and of goats; or peculiarly of goats: or about fifty: or from sixty to seventy: and of camels about five or six: (IAth, TA:) and a collection of dirhems, or pieces of money, and of wheat, or food, &c.: and a piece of a thing: (Msb:) [or] a small quantity or portion of wealth or property. (M, K.) ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) A part, or portion, of the night: so in the saying, maDato Sub~apN mina All~ayoli (assumed tropical:) [A part, or portion, of the night passed]. (S.)

SababN *
SababN The descent, (taSaw~ub, M, L, TA, in the K erroneously written taSab~ub, TA,) of a river, or rivulet, or channel of water, or of a road, down a declivity. (M, L, K, TA.) ― -b2- And A declivity, declivous place, or ground sloping down; (M, A, K, TA;) and (TA) so SabiybN↓, of which the pl. is A^aSobaAbN; (S, TA;) so too SabuwbN↓ and SubuwbN↓, with fet-h and with damm; (TA;) [i. e.] AlS~abuwbu↓ signifies that down which you descend, or have descended, (maA A@noSababota fiyhi,) and its pl. is SububN [like EumudN pl. of EamuwdN]; (M, TA;) [and so AlS~ubuwbu↓;] or, as some say, AlS~abuwbu↓, with fet-h, is a name for the water, &c., that is poured out upon a man, like TahuwrN and gasuwlN; and SubuwbN↓, with damm, is pl. of SababN: but AZ mentions his having heard the Arabs apply SabuwbN↓ to a declivity, or declivous place; and says that its pl. is SububN: (TA:) and AlS~ababu mina Alr~amoli signifies what has poured out or forth or down, of sand: (M, K: *) and the pl. of SababN is A^aSobaAbN. (M, K.)

SubaAbN *
SubaAbN: see SubaAbapN.

SabuwbN *
SabuwbN [app. syn. with SaAb~N↓ as part. n. of the intrans. verb Sab~a, signifying Pouring out or forth or down; or like the latter but having an intensive meaning]: see Sub~N, in two places. ― -b2- See also SababN, in four places.

SubuwbN *
SubuwbN: see SababN, in three places.

SabiybN *
SabiybN [Poured out or forth: (see also Sab~N, first sentence:) or, as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates,] water poured out or forth; syn. maA='N maSobuwbN↓. (M, K.) ― -b2- And (M, K) some say (M) Blood: (S, M, K:) and sweat; (K;) as in the saying,
hawaAjiru taHotalibu AlS~abiybaA
[Vehement midday-heats that draw forth the sweat]: (TA:) [or what is poured forth of sweat and of blood; for] one says, jaraY Sabiybu AlEaraqi and Ald~ami [What was poured forth, of the sweat and of the blood, ran, or flowed]. (A.) ― -b3- And (M, K) some say (M) The expressed juice of Eanodam [or dragon's blood]. (M, K.) ― -b4- And (M, K) some say (M) A certain red dye. (M, K.) ― -b5- And (K) The juice of the leaves of sesame: (S, M, * K: *) A 'Obeyd (so in a copy of the S, or Aboo-'Obeydeh accord. to the TA,) says, it is the juice of the leaves of sesame, or of some other plant, which was described to me in Egypt, the colour of which juice is red tinged with blackness: and some say, it is the expressed juice of the leaves of the Hin~aA=' [q. v.]. (S, TA.) ― -b6- And EuSofur [i. e. Safflower]: (K:) or purified EuSofur. (S.) ― -b7- And A kind of tree [or plant] resembling sa*aAb [or rue], (M, K,) with which the hair is dyed. (M.) ― -b8- And Senna, (M, K,) with which beards are dyed, as with Hin~aA='. (M.) ― -b9- And A certain thing [or plant] resembling the wasomap [or wasimap, q. v.], (M, K, TA,) with which beards are dyed. (TA.) ― -b10- Also Hoar-frost. (AA, K.) AA cites, as descriptive of the sky,
walayosa bhaA Al~aA SabFA waSabiybuhaA
[And there is not in it aught save east wind and its hoar-frost]. (TA.) ― -b11- And Good, or excellent, honey. (K.) ― -b12- Also, (K,) or Sabiybu sayofK, (TA,) The extremity of a sword: (K, TA:) or the extremity next the siylaAn [q. v.] thereof: or, as some say, its sylAn absolutely. (TA.) ― -b13- See also SababN.

SabaAbapN *
SabaAbapN [is an inf. n., mentioned as such in the latter part of the first paragraph, and, when used as a simple subst.,] signifies [Excessive love, or attachment, or admiring love: (see its verb:) or] desire: (M, A, K:) or tenderness of desire, (S, M, A, K,) and ardour thereof: (S:) or tenderness of love. (M, K.)

SubaAbapN *
SubaAbapN and Sub~apN↓ A portion, (S, M, Msb, K,) or a small quantity, (Fr, A, and A 'Obeyd in explanation of the former,) of water, (Fr, S, M, Msb, K,) and of milk, (M, K,) or of wine, or beverage, (A 'Obeyd,) remaining (A 'Obeyd, S, M, Msb, K) in a vessel. (A 'Obeyd, S, M, Msb.)
SubaAbatiY turowiY walayosato giylaA
My remaining portion of water in the vessel &c. satisfies thirst, though it is not water running [copiously] upon the surface of the earth, is a prov., applied to him who makes use of that which is bestowed though it be not much. (Meyd, TA. *) In the following verse, cited by IAar,
walayolK hadayotu bihi fitoyapF
AlkaraY AlA^agoyadi suquwA biSubaAbi↓
(tropical:) [During many a night have I guided in the right way young men infused with the remains of drowsiness that made them to bend their necks from side to side], SubaAb may be put for SubaAbap; or it may be pl. of the latter, [or rather a coll. gen. n. of which SubaAbap is the n. un.,] like as $aEiyrN is of $aEiyrapN: the poet uses this word metaphorically, in relation to drowsiness, like as he has used the word suquwA. (M, L, TA.) One says also lamo A^udoriko mina AlEayo$i A_il~aA SubaAbapF and A_il~aA SubaAbaAtK (tropical:) [I did not attain, or obtain, of life, save a small remainder and small remains]. (A, TA.)

SaAb~N *
SaAb~N: see SabuwbN: and see also Sub~N.

SaboSabN *
SaboSabN, (M, K,) applied to a camel, (M,) Thick, or big, and strong; as also SubaASibN↓, (M, K, TA, in the CK SabaASib,) so applied; (M;) and SaboSaAbN↓, (K,) likewise so applied. (TA.)

SaboSaAbN *
SaboSaAbN: see what next precedes. ― -b2- Also, applied to a [journey such as is termed] qarab, Hard, or severe: (M, TA:) and, applied to a [journey such as is termed] ximos, i. q. baSobaASN (As, S, K) and HaSoHaASN, i. e., in which is no delay, or intermission, nor any flagging. (As, TA.) ＝ -A2- And AlS~aboSaAbu also signifies What remains of the thing: or what is poured out from it; (K, TA;) i. e., from the thing; by which is here said to be meant the water-skin or milk-skin. (TA.)

SubaASibN *
SubaASibN: see SaboSabN.

AlA^aSab~u *
AlA^aSab~u [app. a dial. var. of AlA^aSam~u], an epithet applied to the month rajabN: (TA in art. Hrm:) see muHar~amN.

maSab~N *
[maSab~N A place where water, or the like, pours out or forth, from a river into another river or into the sea &c., or from a tank or a gutter &c., and from high ground into a valley (see DaAjiEapN); and a sink, or sink-hole: pl. maSaAb~u (occurring in the S and K in art. rfq, &c.).]

miSobaAbN *
[miSobaAbN, accord. to Reiske, signifies A ship: so says Freytag: but for this I find no authority.]

maSobuwbN *
maSobuwbN: see SabiybN, first sentence.

1 SabaA^a *
1. SabaA^a, (S, M, K,) aor.
SabaAa
, (M, K,) inf. n. Subuwo'N, (S, M, K, [in the last of which it is implied that this verb in all its senses except the last has Sabo'N also for an inf. n., and likewise Sabuw^a as a syn. form, but this I do not find authorized by any other lexicon,]) said of the tush (S, M, K) of a camel (S, M) and of a cloven-hoofed animal and of a solid-hoofed animal, (M,) and said of a cloven hoof, (K, [but this, I doubt not, is a mistake, for in the place of SabaA^a AlZ~ilofu wAln~aAbu, the reading in the K, I find in the M SabaA^a naAbu AlZ~ilofi waAlxuf~i waAlHaAfiri, and the like in the L,]) It grew forth; (M, K;) or its point, or extremity, grew forth: (S:) and accord. to the K, it appears that ASbA^↓ signifies the same; but this is not the case. (TA.) And SabaA^at said of the vaniy~ap [i. e. a central incisor] of a boy, It grew forth. (S.) ― -b2- Also, said of a star, (M, K,) and of the moon, (M,) It rose; and so ASbA^↓: (M, K:) or taSobaA^a Aln~ujuwmu the stars come forth from their places of rising: (AO, S:) or SabaA^ati Aln~ujuwmu the stars appeared: (TA:) and Aln~ajomu ASbA^↓ the Pleiades [antonomastically called Alnjm] rose. (S.) ― -b3- [Hence,] SabaA^a, (S, M, K,) or SabaA^a mino diynihi A_ilaY diynK A=xara, (AO, S, Msb, *) aor.
SabaAa
, (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. Subuwo'N (S, M, K) and Sabo'N; and Sabuw^a, (M, K,) aor.
SabuAa
, (TA,) inf. n. Subuwo'apN; (CK [but not in the TA nor in my MS. copy of the K];) (assumed tropical:) He departed from his religion to another religion; (S, M, Msb, K;) like as the stars come forth from their place of rising. (AO, S.) And SabaA^a, (S,) or SabaA^a fiY diynihi, aor.
SabaAa
, inf. n. Subuwo'N, (T, TA,) He was, or became, a SaAbiy^ [or Sabian]. (T, S, TA. [See SaAbiy^N, below.]) ― -b4- And SabaA^a Ealayohimo, (S, M,) aor.
SabaAa
, (S,) inf. n. Sabo'N and Subuwo'N, He came forth upon them; (S, M;) as also ASbA^↓: (M:) and accord. to IAar, SabaA^a Ealayohi he came forth, or went forth, upon him, or against him: and he inclined against him with enmity: (TA:) or he came, or came forth, upon him unexpectedly: whence, he says, the word Sub~FA in the saying of the Prophet, lataEuwduwn~a fiyhaA A^asaAwida Sub~FA, [which see in art. Sb,] the said word being of the measure fuE~alFA, [originally Sub~aA^F,] and the ' being suppressed: (L in art. Sb:) and A^aSobaA^ahumo↓ signifies he came upon them suddenly, not having knowledge of their place. (K.) ＝ -A2- One says also, SabaA^a Ealayohimu AlEaduw~a, (M, * K,) aor.
SabaAa
, inf. n. Sabo'N; (M;) as also SabaEa; (TA;) He guided to them (M, K) the enemy: (K:) mentioned by IAar, from AZ. (TA.) ― -b2- And qud~ima A_ilayohi TaEaAmN famaA SabaA^a walaA A^aSobaA^a↓ Food was presented to him, and he did not put (M, K *) his hand (M) or his finger (A_iSobaEahu K) into it, or upon it: (M,) K: [see also SabaEa:]) mentioned by IAar. (M.) And SabaA^a fiY AlT~aEaAmi, aor.
SabuAa
, He [app. a camel] put his head into the food: as also Sabaga. (O in art. Sbg.) And SabaA^ato fiyhaA raA^osahaA [or fiyhi, She put her head into it]; like Sabagato. (TA in that art.)

4 A^aSobaAa
4: see the preceding paragraph, in six places.

SaAbiy^N *
SaAbiy^N [part. n. of SabaA^a: and as such signifying] One who departs from his religion to another religion. (Msb.) The Arabs used to call the Prophet AlS~aAbiY [for AlS~aAbiy^u], because he departed from the religion of Kureysh to El-Islám; and him who entered the religion of El-Islám, maSobuw~N, changing the ' to w; and the Muslims [collectively], AlS~ubaApN, as though pl. of AlS~aAbiYi, without ', like quDaApN and guzaApN pls. of qaADK and gaAzK. (TA.) And [the pl.] AlS~aAbiy^uwna in the Kur [v. 73, &c.,] is said by Zj to mean Those who depart from one religion to another. (TA.) ― -b2- Then this appellation, SaAbiy^N, was applied to [Any individual of] a certain sect of the unbelievers, [the Sabians,] said to worship the stars secretly, and openly to profess themselves to belong to the Christians: they are called AlS~aAbiy^apu and AlD~aAbiy^uwna: and they assert that they are of the religion of Sábi the son of Sheyth [or Seth] the son of Adam: their appellation may also be pronounced AlS~aAbiyuwna, and thus Náfi' read it [in the Kur]: (Msb:) or the SaAbiy^uwna are a certain class of the people who possess revealed scripture: (S:) or a people whose religion resembles that of the Christians, except that their kibleh is towards the place whence blows the [south, or southerly, wind called] januwb: (Lth, T, TA:) [or] whose kibleh is from (mino [or this may mean some point of]) the place whence blows the [north, or northerly, wind called] $amaAl at midday: (M, K:) or, accord. to some, their kibleh is the Kaabeh: (MF:) and they assert that they are of the religion of Noah, (Lth, T, M, K,) lyingly: (Lth, T, M:) in the R it is said that they are thus called in relation to Sábi the son of Lámak [or Lamech], the brother of Noah: Bd says, it is said that they are worshippers of the angels: and it is said that they are worshippers of the stars: and that their appellation is Arabic; from SabaA^a “ he departed from a religion; ” or from SabaA “ he inclined, ” because of their inclining from truth to falsehood. (MF, TA.)

1 SabaHahu *
1. SabaHahu, (S, Mgh, TA,) aor.
SabaHa
, (Mgh, TA,) inf. n. SaboHN; (S, TA;) and Sb~Hhu↓, (K, TA,) inf. n. taSobiyHN; (TA;) He gave him to drink a morning-draught, or what is termed a SabuwH; (S, Mgh, K, TA;) [and] so SabaHahu SabuwHFA: (MA:) and the first [and second also] he handed to him a morning-draught of milk or of wine. (TA.) And SabaHa AlA_ibila, aor. and inf. n. as above, He watered the camels in the morning, between daybreak and sunrise. (TA.) ― -b2- And both are said respecting a gaArap [meaning (assumed tropical:) He made a hostile, or predatory, incursion upon him in the morning; as though he made the gArp to be to him a morning-draught: see SaAbiHN]. (Ham p. 66.) ― -b3- [And accord. to Reiske, as stated by Freytag, SabaHa signifies He drank in the early morning: but I think that Reiske may have assigned to it this meaning from his having found the pass. form of the verb, not distinguished as such, used in a case in which it might be supposed to signify thus.]. ― -b4- See also 2, in five places. ＝ -A2- SabaHN as an inf. n. [of which the verb is SabiHa accord. to a general rule] signifies The being satiated, or having the thirst quenched, by a morning-draught, or what is termed a SabuwH. (L.) ＝ -A3- And SabiHa, aor.
SabaHa
, inf. n. SabaHN [in the CK (erroneously) SaboH] and SuboHapN, [He, or it, was of the colour termed SuboHapN meaning as expl. below: or] it (hair) had whiteness naturally intermixed in it with redness; as also ASbAH~↓, (K, TA,) inf. n.
AiSbiyHaAHN. (TA.) ＝ -A4- SabuHa, aor.
SabuHa
, inf. n. SabaAHapN, [q. v.,] He was, or became, beautiful, comely, pretty, or elegant; (S, A, K, TA;) as some say, peculiarly in the face: (TA:) or he was, or became, bright (Msb, TA) in the face. (Msb.)

2 Sb~Hhu *
2. Sb~Hhu, (S,) or Sb~Hhumo, (K,) inf. n. taSobiyHN, (TA,) He came to him, or to them, in the morning, in the time termed the SabaAH; (S, K;) as also [SabaHahu↓, or] SabaHahumo, aor.
SabaHa
: (K:) the teshdeed in the former does not imply muchness, or frequency: (S:) and Sab~aHatohumu Alxayolu and SabaHatohumu↓ The horsemen came to them at daybreak, at the time termed the SuboH: (TA:) but Aboo-'Adnán says that there is a difference between Sab~aHonaA and SabaHonaA↓; which is this: you say, Sab~aHonaA balada ka*aA [We came in the morning to such a town, or country], and Sab~aHonaA fulaAnFA [We came in the morning to such a one], with teshdeed; and A^aholahaA xayorFA SabaHonaA↓ or $ar~FA [We came in the morning to its people, or inhabitants, with good or with evil, without teshdeed; as though we made the good or the evil to be a morning-draught, or putting the second of the nouns following the verb in the accus. case because of bi suppressed]: you say also, Sb~Hhu bika*aA; and you may also say, bk*A SabaHahu↓, as well as SabaHahu ka*aA; He came to him in the morning with such a thing. (L.) ― -b2- And Sab~aHaka A@ll~`hu bixayorK (S, * A, Msb) or biAlxayori (TA) (assumed tropical:) [May God visit thee in the morning with good, or good fortune, or happiness; or make thee to be in, or during, the morning attended with good, &c.; i. e. make thy morning good, or happy; or grant thee a good, or happy, morning]: a prayer for the person thus addressed, (Msb.) ― -b3- And Sab~aHotuhu I said to him Eimo SabaAHFA [expl. below, see SabaAHN]; (S;) and Sab~aHahumo he said to them EimuwA SabaAHFA: (K:) or Sab~aHotuhu means I said to him Sab~aHaka A@ll~`hu bixayorK [expl. above]. (Msb.) ― -b4- See also 1, first sentence. ― -b5- [Hence,] Sab~aHotu Alqawoma AlmaA='a, inf. n. as above, I journeyed with the people, or party, by night until I brought them in the morning to the water. (K.) ― -b6- Sab~aHaniY fulaAnN AlHaq~a (tropical:) Such a one declared, or told clearly, to me the truth; syn. maH~aDaniyhi. (A, TA. [See SuboHN.]) ＝ -A2- taSobiyHN as a subst., see below.

4 ASbH *
4. ASbH He entered upon the time of morning termed SabaAH [which means both dawn and forenoon]: (S, * Msb: [in the former this meaning is indicated, but not expressed:]) or he entered upon the time of daybreak, or dawn, the time termed SuboH. (L, K.) By the following words of EshShemmákh,
waqiylu AlmunaAdiY A^aSobaHa Alqawomu A^adolijiY
is meant, [And the saying of the crier is,] The people, or party, have nearly entered upon the time of dawn: prosecute the night-journey: for the Arabs, when they have nearly arrived at a place which they desire to reach, say, qado balagonaAhu; and when travellers are near the time of daybreak, they say, A^aSobaHonaA. (T, L.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) He awoke from sleep in the jawof [i. e. last third, or last sixth,] of the night. (A, TA.) [And simply (tropical:) He awoke: for] one says to the sleeper, A^aSobiHo, meaning (tropical:) Awake thou from sleep. (A, TA.) And one says also, A^aSobiHo yaA rajulu, meaning (tropical:) Become roused, O man, (A, K, * TA,) from thy heedlessness or inadvertence, (A, TA,) and see thy right course, (K, TA,) and what will rectify thy state. (TA.) And A^aSobiHo layolu (tropical:) [Become morning, O night] a prov.: (Meyd, A, TA:) said in a distressing night, that is long by reason of evil. (Meyd. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 727.]) ― -b3- [Also He, or it, became in the morning in any particular state or condition: in this sense, and in that next following, an incomplete, i. e. a non-attributive, verb.] ― -b4- And [hence, simply,] He, or it, became; syn. SaAra. (S, K.) One says, ASbH EaAlimFA He became knowing, or learned. (S, TA.) Thus, faA^aSobaHuwA ZaAhiriyna, in the Kur lxi. last verse, means And they became victorious. (Bd.) And faA^aSobaHa yuqal~ibu kaf~ayohi, in the Kur xviii. 40, [And he became in a state, or condition, in which he turned over his hands; i. e.] and he became repentant, or grieved for what he had done. (A in art. qlb, and Bd.) And faA^aSobaHuwA laA taraY A_il~aA masaAkinahumo, in the Kur xlvi. 24, i. e. [And they became] in a condition such that, if thou wert present in their country, thou wouldst not see aught save their dwellingplaces; or, as Hamzeh and Ks read, laA yuraY A_il~aA masaAkinuhumo [there was not to be seen aught save their dwelling-places]. (Bd.) [A^aSobaHa yafoEalu ka*aA is of frequent occurrence, meaning He became occupied, or engaged, in doing such a thing; he betook, set, or applied, himself to doing such a thing; set about, or commenced, doing such a thing; or began to do such a thing.] ― -b5- [Also He performed the prayer of daybreak.] It is said in a trad., A^aSobiHuwA biAlS~uboHi, meaning Perform ye the prayer of daybreak in the time of daybreak. (L.) ― -b6- See also 8. ― -b7- Also He acted gently. (TA in art. Ar$: see an ex. in a verse cited voce maA^orwu$N.) ＝ -A2- A_iSobaAHN He trimmed a lamp, or wick; or prepared it properly for use. (TA.) ― -b2- See, again, 8. ＝ -A3- as a subst., see SuboHN, in two places.

5 tSb~H *
5. tSb~H He slept in the morning; or first part of day, before sunrise. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And He ate such food as is termed a SuboHap. (K, TA.) It is said in a trad., mano taSab~aHa bisaboEi tamaraAti EajowapK [He who eats as a SuboHap seven dates of the sort called Eajowap]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 8, in two places.

6 fulaAnN yataSaAbaHu * and yataHaAsanu
6. fulaAnN yataSaAbaHu yataHaAsanu [Such a one affects to be beautful, comely, pretty, or elegant: the latter verb is here added as an explicative of the former: see SabuHa]. (A, TA.)

8 ASTbH *
8. ASTbH He drank a morning-draught, or what is termed a SabuwH; (S, K, TA;) [and] so ASbH↓. (Msb. [Thus in my copy of the Msb, but probably a mistranscription, for the former is the verb well known in this sense, and is not in that copy.]) It is said in a trad., maAlanaA SabiY~N yaSoTabiHu [We have not a child that drinks a morningdraught]; meaning we have not as much milk as a child may drink in the early morning, in consequence of the drought. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And i. q. A^asoraja [as meaning He lighted a lamp or wick, or himself or another with a lamp &c.]; (K, TA;) and so ASbH↓ (A, TA) [in the former sense], as in the phrase ASbH miSobaAHFA [he lighted a lamp or wick]; (A;) and ASbH alone has this meaning, i. e. A^asoraja siraAjFA. (TA, from a trad.) [But it is used often in the latter sense:] one says, Al$~amoEu mim~aA yuSoTabaHu bihi Candles are of the things with which one lights [himself, or others]; syn. yusoraju: (S:) [and in like manner tSb~H↓; for] one says, huwa yataSab~aHu biAl$~umuwEi [He lights himself, or others, with candles]: (A:) [and in like manner also AstSbH↓; for] one says, AstSbH biAlmiSobaAHi (S, MA, Mgh, Msb, K *) He lighted [himself, or another,] with the lamp, or wick; (MA;) syn. A^asoraja; (S;) or Aisotasoraja: (K:) [hence it appears that ASTbH bihi and bh AstSbH↓ and bh tSb~H↓ may be aptly rendered he employed it as a means of light; and thus the second of these three verbs, is expl. in treatises on practical law:] one says also, biAld~uhoni AstSbH↓ [He employed oil as a means of light; or] he made the lamp, or wick, to give light by means of oil: (Mgh, Msb:) and it is said in a trad. respecting the several sorts of fat ($uHuwm) of carrion, bihaA Aln~aAsu yasotaSobiHu↓ The people [employ them as means of light; or] make their lamps, or wicks, to give light by means of them. (TA.)

10 A_isotaSobaHa
10: see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.

11 A_iSobaAoH~a
11: see 1, last sentence but one.

SuboHN *
SuboHN (S, A, Msb, K, &c.) and SabaAHN↓ (Msb, K) and SabiyHapN↓ (Msb, * K) and A_iSobaAHN↓ and muSobaHN↓ (K [or perhaps the last should be maSobaHN, q. v.]) Daybreak, or dawn; syn. fajorN; (S, A, Msb, K;) i. e. (so in the Msb, but in the K “ or ”) the beginning, or first part, of day: (Msb, K:) A_iSobaAHN↓ is an inf. n. [inf. n. of A^aSobaHa] used in the sense of SuboH, in the Kur vi. 96, (Jel,) and is similar to A_ibokaArN; (TA;) [and muSobaHN↓ is the n. of place and time from A^aSobaHa:] the pl. of SuboHN is A^aSobaAHN; (K;) and thus some read in the Kur vi. 96. (Bd.) See also A^aSobaHu. One says, A^atayotuhu liSuboHi xaAmisapK and xAmsp liSiboHi↓, (S, K,) meaning [I came to him] in the morning (SabaAH) [of the last] of five days; (K;) i. e., of a fifth day; (TK;) [or rather, of a fifth night, as the last word is fem.;] like as one says, limuisoYi xAmsp. (S.) ― -b2-
AlS~uboHu is also used as meaning (assumed tropical:) The truth; and the clear, or plain, thing or case. (Ham p. 449.) ― -b3- And A^um~u SuboHK is one of the names of Mekkeh. (K, * TA.)

SiboHN *
SiboHN: see the next preceding paragraph.

SabaHN *
SabaHN: see SuboHapN. ― -b2- Also The glistening of iron (K, TA) and of other things. (TA.)

SaboHapN *
SaboHapN: see the next paragraph, in three places. ― -b2- Also A watering of camels in the morning, or first part of day, before sunrise: which is not esteemed by the Arabs wholesome: the time approved by them for watering is when the sun is near the meridian. (TA.)

SuboHapN *
SuboHapN The early part of the forenoon, after sunrise; syn. DuHFY; as also SaboHapN↓: (Msb:) or the period of one's entering upon the SabaAH [which means both dawn and forenoon]: so in the saying, laqiytuhu *aAta SuboHapK [I met him when he was entering upon the dawn or forenoon]. (TA.) ― -b2- And A sleep in the morning, or first part of day, before sunrise; as also SaboHapN↓; (S, * K;) or both signify a sleep in the DuHaY [expl. above]; (A;) but the latter is by some disapproved: such sleep is forbidden in a trad., because it is in a time for the commemoration of the praises of God and then for seeking gain. (TA.) One says, fulaAnN yanaAmu AlS~uboHapa and AlS~aboHapa↓ [Such a one sleeps in the first part of day, before sunrise]. (S.) ― -b3- And Food with which one contents, or diverts, himself [so as to allay the craving of his stomach], in the morning or first part of day, before sunrise. (K.) ― -b4- See also SabuwHN. ＝ -A2- Also (Suh, K, TA,) and SabaHN↓, (Lth, S, TA,) [each said in one place in the K to be an inf. n. of which the verb is SabiHa,] Blackness inclining to redness: (K:) or intense redness in the hair: (Lth, TA:) or a colour inclining to that which is termed Suhobap: (K, TA:) or nearly the same as Suhobap: (Lth, * S, * TA:) or a colour inclining to that termed $uhobap: (K, TA:) or whiteness that is not clear, or pure; so the former is expl. by Suh. (TA. [See also A^aSabaHu.])

SaboHaAnu *
SaboHaAnu A man who has drunk a morningdraught, or what is termed a SabuwH; (TA;) or who has done so, and satisfied his thirst thereby: (Aboo-'Adnán, TA:) [in the S and K it is implied that it is syn. with muSoTabiHN, q. v.:] fem. SaboHaY. (S, TA.) Hence the prov., A^ako*abu mina AlA^axiy*i AlS~aboHaAni (Aboo-'Adnán, S, TA) More lying than the captive who had satisfied his thirst with a morning-draught: (Aboo-'Adnán, TA:) the person thus alluded to was a man who was among a people that gave him a morning-draught, after which he arose and quitted them, and was taken by another people, who said to him, “ Guide us to the place where thou wast; ” to which he replied, “ I have passed the night in the bare desert: ” but presently he sat down to make water, so they knew that he had passed the night with a people near by; and by his means they found their way to them, and exterminated them: (IAar, TA:) or the prov. is A^ako*abu mina AlA^axidi AlS~aboHaAni More lying than the young unweaned camel that has satisfied its thirst with drinking [its mother's milk in the morning]; which [seems to be thirsty but] will not drink of its mother's milk when one desires it to do so: (IAar, Sh, TA:) or, accord. to Fr, than the young unweaned camel that is affected with indigestion, or heaviness of the stomach, from drinking much milk, and therefore craves for milk again. (Meyd. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov.: he seems to have followed a faulty text.]) ― -b2- Also the fem., SaboHaY, A she-camel that has been milked [app. in the morning]. (Meyd, in his Proverbs, under the letter S; and TA.) ＝ -A2- See also SabiyHN.

SabaHaAnN *
SabaHaAnN A man who hastens to take the morning-draught, or what is termed the SabuwH. (K.)

SabaAHN *
SabaAHN: see SuboHN. ― -b2- Also (Msb) Contr. of masaA='N, (S, A, Msb,) and so SabiyHapN↓, (S,) [and A^uSobuwHapN↓ (as in a phrase following in this paragraph), and maSobaHN↓, (see this last word,)] i. e. Morning, or forenoon, counted from sunrise to noon: (Msb and TA in art. msw:) or, accord. to some, from midnight to noon: (TA in art. msw:) or, accord. to the Arabs, from the beginning of the latter half of the night to the time when the sun declines from the meridian; then commences the masaA=', extending to the end of the former half of the night; thus expl. by Th; so says El-Jawá- leekee. (Msb.) The Arabs say, when they regard a man, &c., as ominous of evil, SabaAHu A@ll~`hi laA SabaAHuka [God's morning: not thy morning]: and if you will, you may say, SabaAHa A@ll~`hi laA SabaAHaka. (Lh, TA.) And Eimo SabaAHFA, (S,) or EimuwA SabaAHFA, (K,) lit. imperative, but meaning a prayer, i. e. May thy life, or your life, be pleasant during the morning, (Har p. 32, and TA * in arts. nEm and wEm,) is a salutation of the people of the Time of Ignorance. (TA.) One says also, laqiytuhu SabaAHFA, and *aA SabaAHK, (S,) or A^atayotuhu *aA SabaAHK, (K,) which [i. e. *A SbAH] is only used adverbially, (Sb, S, K,) except in the dial. of Khath'am, (Sb, S,) meaning [I met him, or I came to him,] in a morning, [or] between daybreak and sunrise: (K:) the following verse (S, TA) by Anas Ibn-Nuheyk, of Khath'am, (TA,) or, as some say, by Iyás Ibn-Mudrikeh El-Hanafee, (so in a marg. note in a copy of the S,) presents an exception to the adverbial usage:
Eazamotu EalaY A_iqaAmapi *iY SabaAHK
liA^amorK m~aA yusaw~adu mano yasuwdu
(S, TA:) the poet means, I determined to stay until the time of the SbAH [i. e. either dawn or forenoon]: for it is on account of some particular thing, i. e. some good quality, or some praiseworthy thing, that he is made a chief who becomes a chief: thus Ibn-Es-Seeráfee explains this verse. (TA.) And one says, A^atayotuhu *aA SabuwHK↓, not used otherwise than adverbially, meaning the same as *aA SabaAHK, expl. above; (K;) and *aAta AlS~abuwHi↓ in the morning, or first part of day, before sunrise: (IAar, TA:) or *aA SabuwHK↓ [properly means] in a time of drinking the [morning-draught called] SabuwH. (TA.) And yawomi ka*aA A^atayotuhu SabiyHapa↓ [I came to him in the dawn, or in the morning, or forenoon, of such a day]: (A:) and A^uSobuwHapa↓ kul~i yawomK [in the morning of every day]; and in like manner, A^umosiy~apa kul~i yawomK. (S.) And A^atayotuhu SabaAHa masaA='a, (Sb, A, TA,) for SabaAHFA wamasaA='F, [I came to him morning and evening,] meaning every morning and evening: (Sharh esh-Shudhoor, p. 31:) the two nouns are thus constructed by some of the Arabs, after the manner of xamosapa Ea$ara: but some prefix the former noun to the other, putting the latter in the gen. case, except when the expression is used as a denotative of state, or adverbially: (TA:) [or, accord. to IHsh,] SabaAHa masaA='K is allowable as [an adverbial expression] meaning SabaAHa *aA masaA='K [lit. in a morning having an evening, or in a forenoon having an afternoon]; and a similar instance occurs in the Kur, ch. lxxix. last verse. (Sharh esh-Shudhoor, ubi suprà.) ― -b3- yawomu AlS~abaAHi means (tropical:) The day of the hostile, or predatory, incursion. (S, A, K.) The Arabs, when suddenly attacked in the morning by a troop of horsemen, cry aloud, yaA SabaAHaAho (assumed tropical:) [O! a hostile, or predatory, incursion!]; warning the whole tribe: (TA:) this is said by him who calls for aid: (JM:) for they generally made a hostile, or predatory, incursion in the morning: (TA, JM:) or, as some say, the two conflicting parties used, when night came, to abstain; and when day returned, they recommenced; so that the case is as though he who said thus meant, The time of the SabaAH [or morning] has come, therefore prepare yourselves for fighting. (JM.)

SubaAHN *
SubaAHN The $uElap [or lighted wick] of a qinodiyl [or lamp]. (K.) [See also miSobaAHN.] ＝ -A2- And I. q. SabiyHN, q. v. (Ks, S, K.)

SabuwHN *
SabuwHN A morning draught; i. e. a draught, drink, or potation, that is drunk in the morning, or first part of day, before sunrise, (S, A, Msb, TA,) and afterwards, before noon; (TA;) contr. of gabuwqN: (S, A:) and whatever is eaten, or drunk, in the morning, or first part of day, before sunrise; contr. of gabuwqN: (TA:) [and particularly] milk that is drunk at that time: (AHeyth, L:) milk, or wine, that is drunk at that time: or what is drunk at that time hot: (L:) milk that is milked at that time: (K:) and $araAb [i. e. beverage, or wine,] that people have, (K, TA,) and drink, (TA,) in the morning: (K, TA:) pl. SabaAy^iHu. (TA.) A^aEano SabuwHK turaq~iqu [Dost thou make a delicate allusion to a morningdraught?] is a prov., [the origin of which is expl. in art. rq, q. v.,] applied to him who speaks obscurely, not plainly; and to him who alludes ambiguously to some great thing or affair; and to him who by blandishing expressions makes a
thing incumbent on thee which is not really so. (TA.) ― -b2- See also SabaAHN, in three places. ― -b3- Accord. to Lth, it signifies [absolutely] Wine. (T, TA.) ― -b4- And The quantity of milk of a camel that is drawn at dawn, or in the first part of day; and so SuboHapN↓. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A she-camel that is milked at dawn, or in the forenoon, (Lh, AHeyth, K,) or in the morning, or first part of day, before sunrise; and so with p. (K.)

SabiyHN *
SabiyHN (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and SubaAHN↓ (Ks, S, K) and Sub~aAHN↓ and SaboHaAnu↓ (K) Beautiful, comely, (S, A, Mgh, K,) pretty, or elegant; (S, A, K;) as some say, peculiarly in the face; (TA;) or applied to the face: (A:) or bright (Msb, TA) in the face: (Msb:) the first is expl. by Lth as signifying fair of face: fem. SabiyHapN and SubaAHapN: and the pl. of SabiyHN and SubaAHN, and of their fems. here mentioned, is SibaAHN. (L. TA.)

SabaAHapN *
SabaAHapN Beauty, comeliness, prettiness, or elegance; (S, A, K;) as some say, peculiarly in the face: (TA:) or brightness in the face: (Msb:) it is said that SabaAHap is in the face; waDaA='ap, in the skin; jamaAl, in the nose; HalaAwap, in the eye; malaAHap, in the mouth; Zarof, in the tongue; ra$aAqap, in the stature; labaAqap, in the qualities of the mind; and that the completion of beauty is in the hair. (L, TA.) [See 1, last sentence.]

SabiyHapN *
SabiyHapN: see SuboHN: and SabaAHN, in two places.

SubaAHiY~N *
SubaAHiY~N Intensely red blood: (K, TA:) from A^aSobaHu signifying one “ whose hair is overspread with redness. ” (TA.) ＝ -A2- A^asin~apN SubaAHiy~apN Wide spear-heads. (K, TA. [In the CK the latter word is without teshdeed.]) ISd says, I know not the person or thing in relation whereto they are thus called. (TA.) [See also miSobaAHN.]

Sub~aAHN *
Sub~aAHN: see SabiyHN.

SaAbiHN *
SaAbiHN [Giving to drink a morning-draught, or what is termed a SabuwH: act. part. n. of 1, q. v.: see also Ham p. 66. And] One who waters his camels in the morning, between day-break and sunrise. (TA. [See SaboHapN.]) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) One who makes a hostile, or predatory, incursion upon a people in the morning; as though he made it to be to them a SabuwH. (Ham p. 66.) ― -b3- AlHaq~u AlS~aAbiHu (tropical:) The plain, manifest, clear, truth. (K, * TA.)

A^aSobaHu *
A^aSobaHu Of a black colour inclining to redness: (K:) or having redness intermixed in his black hair: (Sh, TA:) or whose hair, or beard, has a red hue overspreading it: (Aboo-Nasr, Sh, TA:) or having hair intensely red: (TA:) it is nearly the same as A^aSohabu: (Lth, S:) and is an epithet applied to a man and to a lion: (S:) and to hair as meaning having whiteness naturally intermixed in it with redness; (K, TA;) of whatever kind it be: (TA:) fem. SaboHaA='u: (K:) and pl. SuboHN: (TA:) and hence [accord. to some] AlS~uboHu↓ meaning “ the dawn; ” for, as Az says, the colour of the true dawn inclines a little to redness. (TA.) [Hence, because of his colour,] AlA^aSobaHu signifies The lion. (K.) In the phrase A^usuwdN SuboHN, the epithet is added as a corroborative. (Z, TA.) ― -b2- And the fem., SaboHaA='u signifies A female conspicuous, or clear, or fair, in the jabiyn [or side of the forehead]. (TA.)

A^aSobaHiY~N *
A^aSobaHiY~N A whip: (S, K:) and siyaATN A^aSobaHiy~apN certain whips: (AO, S, TA:) so called in relation to *uw A^aSobaHa, one of the Kings of El-Yemen, (AO, S, K, TA,) of Himyer. (TA.)

A_iSobaAHN *
A_iSobaAHN: see SuboHN, in two places. ― -b2- It is said to signify also Darkness; contr. of SuboHN, which is its primary signification: and accord. to EshShereeshee, redness of the hair. (Har p. 284.)

A^uSobuwHapN *
A^uSobuwHapN: see SabaAHN, in two places.

taSobiyHN *
taSobiyHN The morning meal, that is eaten between daybreak and sunrise; syn. gadaA='N: (A, K:) a subst. of the measure tafoEiylN, (K, TA,) similar to taroEiybN &c.: pl. taSaAbiyHu. (A, TA.) One says, qar~aba A_ilaY AlD~uyuwfi taSaAbiyHahumo [He brought near to the guests, or put before them, their early morning-meals]. (A, TA.)

maSobaHN *
maSobaHN, (S, Msb, and some copies of the K,) formed from the unaugmented verb, (S, Msb,) and muSobaHN↓, (S, Msb, K,) formed from the augmented verb A^aSobaHa, (S, Msb,) The place of entering upon the time of morning called SabaAH: and the time of entering upon the same: (S, Msb, K:) or the former signifies i. q. SabaAHN, and the time thereof, and the place thereof. (Marg. note in a copy of the S.) See also SabaAHN.

muSobaHN *
muSobaHN: see the next preceding paragraph: and see also SuboHN, in two places.

miSobaHN *
miSobaHN: see the paragraph here following, in four places.

miSobaAHN *
miSobaAHN A lamp: or its lighted wick: syn. siraAjN: (S, K:) the latter is the proper meaning (L) [though not the more usual], and is the meaning intended in the Kur xxiv. 35, (Bd, L, Jel,) or a large, bright, or brilliant, siraAj: (Bd:) and miSobaHN↓ signifies a lamp: (L:) [the pl. of this is maSaAbiHu: and] the pl. of miSobaAHN is maSaAbiyHu. (Msb.) — maSaAbiyHu Aln~ujuwmi means A^aEolaAmu AlkawaAkibi [i. e. (assumed tropical:) The stars, or asterisms, that are signs of the way to travellers]. (L, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A large [drinking-vessel of the kind called] qadaH; (AHn, K;) and so miSobaHN↓: (K:) or maSaAbiyHu [the pl. of the former] signifies the [vessels called] A^aqodaAH [pl. of qadaH] with which one drinks the morning-draught called SabuwH. (S.) ― -b2- And A she-camel that remains in the morning in the place where she has lain down, (S, K, TA,) not going forth to pasture, (S, TA,) until the sun has risen high, (S, K, TA,) by reason of her strength (K, TA) and her fatness: (TA:) the quality thus described is approved: (As, S, TA:) and such a she-camel is also termed miSobaHN↓: pl. of the former as above. (TA.) ― -b3- And A wide spear-head; (K, TA;) [app. of such as are termed A^asin~apN SubaAHiy~apN;] as also miSobaHN↓. (TA.)

muSoTabiHN *
muSoTabiHN Drinking a morning-draught, or what is termed a SabuwH. (S, K. [See also SaboHaAnu, first sentence.])

1 Sabarahu *
1. Sabarahu, aor.
Sabira
, (S, M, A, K,) inf. n. SaborN, (M, K,) He confined him; held him in custody; detained, retained, restrained, or withheld, him, or it; (S, M, A, K;) Eanohu from it. (M, A, K.) [Accord. to a copy of the A, Sb~rhu↓ signifies the same; but this may be a mistranscription. Hence,] Sabarotu nafosiY I restrained, or withheld, myself, or my soul; (S, Mgh;) EalaY ka*aA [to endure such a thing]. (Mgh.) 'Antarah says, mentioning a battle in which he was engaged,
faSabarotu EaArifapF li*`lika Hur~apF
tarosuwA A_i*aA nafosu AljabaAni taTal~aEu
meaning Habasotu nafosFA SaAbirapF [i. e. And I restrained thereat a soul patient and ingenuous, that is firm when the soul of the coward yearns: the last word (for tataTal~aEu) I have here rendered on the supposition that the poet describes the soul of the coward as one that is yearning for home]. (S.) [And hence,] Sabara is also used intransitively: (Msb:) [or as a trans. verb of which the objective complement, namely, nafosahu, is understood:] you say, Sabara, aor. and inf. n. as above, (S, M, Msb, K,) He was, or became patient, or enduring; contr. of jaziEa: (M, K:) or he restrained, or withheld, himself, or his soul, from impatience: (S, Msb:) or he restrained, or withheld, himself, or his soul, from impatience, and his tongue from complaint, and his members from broil: or, accord. to Dhu-n-Noon, he shunned acts of opposition, and was calm in suffering the pangs of afflictions, and made a show of competence in a state of protracted poverty in places where the means of subsistence were found: or, as some say, he endured trial, or affliction, with good manners: or he was contented in trial, or affliction, without show of complaint: or he constrained himself to attempt things that he disliked: or, accord. to 'Amr Ibn-'Othmán, he maintained constancy with God, and received his trials with an unstraitened mind: or, accord. to El-Khowwás, he steadily adhered to the statutes of the Kur-án and the Sunneh: or, as some say, he was content to perish for gaining the approval of him whom he loved: or, accord. to El-Hareeree, he made no difference between a state of ease, comfort, and affluence, and a state of affliction; preserving calmness of mind in both states: (B:) and you also say AiSoTabara↓, (S, M, Msb, K,) and AiS~abara↓, (S, M, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, ASobar~a,])
changing the T into S, but not AiT~abara, for S is not to be incorporated into T; (S;) and likewise tSb~r↓; (M, K;) both syn. with Sabara; (M;) or tSb~r↓ signifies he constrained himself to be patient; (S, TA;) [or he took patience: and ASTbr↓, he acquired patience; and he was tried with patience: see SaAbirN.] One says, Sabara fulaAnN Einoda AlmuSiybapi Such a one was patient on the occasion of affliction. (S.) And Sabarotu EalaY maA A^akorahu [I was patient of, or I endured with patience, or bore with, what I dislike]. (A.) And Sabarotu Eam~aA A^uHib~u [I endured with patience the withholding of myself, or the being debarred, from what I love, or like; or I was patient of the loss, or want, of what I love, or like]: (A:) and Eanohu taSab~arotu↓ [I constrained myself to endure with patience the withholding myself, or the being debarred, from it, or him; or I constrained myself to be patient of the loss, or want, of it, or him]. (L, voce tajal~ada.) And A^afoDalu AlS~abori Alt~aSab~uru↓ [The most excellent kind of patience is the constraint of oneself to be patient]: a saying of 'Omar. (IAar.) And badaniY laA yaSobiru EalaY Albarodi (tropical:) [My body will not be patient of cold, or will not endure patiently cold]. (A.) And SaborN signifies also The being bold or daring [in enduring, or attempting, a thing]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also He made him, or it, firm, or fast; or bound, or tied, him, or it, firmly, or fast. (TA.) [Hence,] Sabarahu EalaY Alqatoli, inf. n. as above, He confined him, namely, a man, and other than man, [with bonds or otherwise,] (K, TA,) alive, (TA,) and shot, or cast, at him until he died: (K, TA:) or he set him up for slaughter: (M:) and you say also, qatalahu SaborFA; (S, M, Msb, K;) and Sabarahu; meaning he confined him (i. e. a man) to die, until he died; and in like manner you say ASbrhu↓; (S;) which latter signifies also he slew him in retaliation. (T in art. bwA^.) And qutila SaborFA He (i. e. any living thing) was confined alive, and then shot at, or cast at, until he was put to death: (S:) or he (any living thing) was bound until he was put to death: (Msb:) or he (a man) was bound hand and foot, or held by another man, until he was beheaded: (Mgh:) or he was slain [deliberately,] not on the field of battle, nor in war or fight, nor by mistake: (A 'Obeyd:) and Subira he was confined, (A,) or held and confined, (B,) to be put to death. (A, B.) Saboru Alr~uwHi [signifies The confining the living, and shooting, or casting, at him until he dies; as is shown in the TA: but it] occurs in a trad., in which it is forbidden, as meaning the act of gelding, or castrating. (A, TA.) ― -b3- Also, (S, Msb,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Msb,) He confined him to make him swear, until he swore, or took an oath; as also ASbrhu↓: (S:) or he made him to swear a most energetic oath; (Msb;) as also Sabara yamiynahu, (A, Mgh,) which is a tropical phrase: (A:) and ASbrhu↓, (TA in art. blt,) or EalaY yamiynK ASbrhu↓, (TA in the present art.,) he (the judge, or governor,) constrained him to swear, or take an oath. (TA.) And Subira He was confined, or held in custody, in order that he might be made to swear, or take an oath. (A.) And Halafa SaborFA He swore, or took an oath, being confined, or held in custody, (S, M,) by the judge, or governor, (M,) in order that he might be made to do so. (S, M.) And Sabara yamiynFA He swore, or took an oath: (TA in art. blt:) and he compelled one to take an oath. (Mgh.) ― -b4- See also 2. ― -b5- Also He clave to him; namely, a man; syn. lazimahu. (M, K.) ＝ -A2- Sabaraminohu: see 8. ＝ -A3- Sabarotu, (S, [thus in my copies, without any complement,]) or Sabarotu bihi, (M, Msb, K,) aor.
Sabura
, inf. n. SaborN (S, M, Msb, K) and SabaArapN, (S, Msb, K,) I became responsible, or surety, for him, or it. (S, M, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And AuSoburoniY Give thou to me a surety. (S, K.) ＝ -A4- SabaruwA TaEaAmahumo, (so in the CK, [agreeably with an explanation of the pass. part. n. maSobuwrN, q. v.,]) or Sab~aruwhu↓, (so in the M, and in my MS. copy of the K, [both probably correct,]) They collected their wheat together without measuring or weighing it; made it a Suborap [q. v.] (M, K.)

2 Sb~rhu *
2. Sb~rhu, (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. taSobiyrN, (TA,) He urged him, or made him, to be patient, by a promise of reward: or he said to him, Be thou patient: and Sabarahu↓ he made him to be patient: (Msb:) or the former, he commanded him, or enjoined him, to be patient; as also ASbrhu↓: (M, K:) and the first, he required of him that he should be patient: (Sgh, TA:) and ASbrhu↓, he attributed to him (jaEala lahu) patience; (M, K;) as also ASTbrhu↓. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, second sentence. ＝ -A2- Sb~rwA TaEaAmahumo: see 1, last sentence. ― -b2- Sb~r Al$~aYo'a, inf. n. as above, He heaped up the thing. (O.) ＝ -A3- [Sb~r also signifies He embalmed a dead body with Sabir, meaning accord. to Freytag myrrh; but for this I know not any authority: he mentions the verb as occurring in this sense in “ Hamak. Waked. ” p. 94, last line. ＝ -A4- Also He ballasted a ship: used in this sense in the present day. See SaAbuwrapN.]

3 SAbrhu *
3. SAbrhu, (A, MA,) inf. n. muSaAbarapN (A, K) and SibaArN, (K,) [He vied with him in patience, or endurance; as shown in what follows: or] he acted patiently with him: (MA:) SaAbiruwA in the Kur iii. last verse means Vie ye in patience, or endurance: (Ksh, Bd, Jel: *) or in this instance, in the saying AiSobiruwA waSaAbiruwA waraAbiTuwA, the three verbs are progressive in meaning; the first meaning less than the second; and the second, less than the third: or the meaning is, [be ye patient] with yourselves, and [vie ye in patience] with your hearts in enduring trial with respect to God, and [remain ye steadfast] with your minds in desire for God: or [be ye patient] with respect to God, and [vie ye in patience] with God, and [remain ye steadfast] with God. (B, TA.) [See also 3 in art. rbT.]

4 ASbrhu *
4. ASbrhu: see 1, latter half, in four places: ― -b2- and see 2, in two places. ＝ -A2- [maA A^aSobarahu How patient, or enduring, is he!] ― -b2- maA A^aSobarahumo EalaY A@ln~aAri [in the Kur ii. 170] means How bold are they [to encounter the fire of Hell]! (K.) ― -b5- He ate the Sabiyrap, (IAar, K,) i. e. the thin, round cake of bread so called. (TA.) ― -b6- And He stopped the head of a flask, or bottle, with a SibaAr, (K, TA,) i. e. a stopper. (TA.)

(TA.) ＝ -A2- [And accord. to Reiske, It was collected: (mentioned by Freytag:) app. as quasi-pass. of 1 in the last of the senses assigned to it above.] ＝ -A3- ASTbrhu: see 2.
