10. AstSbr It (a vapour, TA) became dense. (K, TA. [See SabiyrN.])

R. Q. 1
R. Q. 1: accord. to the S, Sanobara: see art. Snbr.

SaborN *
SaborN [inf. n. of 1, q. v. ― -b2- Used as a simple subst.,] Patience, or endurance; contr. of jazaEN: (M, K:) or restraint of oneself, or of one's soul, from impatience. (S. [Several other explanations of this word are shown by explanations of the verb.]) ― -b3- $ahoru AlS~abori The month of fasting: (K:) fasting being called Sabor because it is self-restraint from food and beverage and sexual intercourse. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b4- [qatalahu SaborFA, and qutila SaborFA: see 1.] ― -b5- yamiynu AlS~abori The oath for which the judge, or governor, [in the CK AlHukomu is erroneously put for AlHakamu,] holds one in custody until he swears it: (M, K:) or the oath that is obligatory (K, TA) upon the swearer, (TA,) and which the swearer is compelled to take, (Mgh, K,) he being confined by the Sultán until he do so: (Mgh, * TA:) such an oath is also termed yamiynN maSobuwrapN↓: (Mgh:) [i. e.] the term maSobuwrapN is applied to an oath, (S, K, TA,) meaning one on account of which a man is confined, in order to make him swear it; (TA; [and this seems to be indicated by the context in the S and K;]) but the man being maSobuwr, and not the oath, the latter is thus
termed tropically. (TA.) ― -b6- [Halafa SaborFA: see 1.] ＝ -A2- See also SabirN.

SuborN *
SuborN (S, M, Msb, K) and SiborN↓ (M, Msb, K) The side of a thing: (S, M, K:) or a side rising above the rest of a thing: (Msb:) or its upper part, or top: (TA:) and the edge of a thing: (S, M, K:) and its thickness: formed by transposition from buSorN: (S:) pl. A^FSobaArN, (S, M, Msb, K,) and pl. pl. A^aSobaArapN. (Msb.) A^aSobaArN signifies The sides of a vessel, (S,) and of a grave. (TA.) And you say, He filled the drinking-cup, (S, M, A, K,) and the measure, (A, TA,) A_ilaY A^aSobaArihi, (S, M, A, K,) to its top, (S, M, K,) as also AlY A^aSomaArihi; (S;) or to its uppermost parts; (TA;) or to its edges. (A.) And A^axa*ahu biA^aSobaArihi He took it altogether. (S, M, A, Msb, * K.) And laqiYa Al$~id~apa biA^aSobaArihaA (assumed tropical:) He met with complete distress, or adversity. (As, S.) And in a trad., the tree called sidorapu AlmunotahaY is said to be Subora Aljan~api in the highest part of Paradise. (A, TA.) ― -b2- Also the former, (S, M, K,) and SuburN↓, (M, K,) Land in which are pebbles, (S, M, K,) not rugged. (S, M.) Hence, A^um~u Sab~aArK↓, q. v. (S, M.) ― -b3- See also SabiyrN, in two places.

SiborN *
SiborN: see SuborN: ― -b2- and SabiyrN in two places: ＝ -A2- and see also SabirN.

SabarN *
SabarN Ice; syn. HamadN: (A, Sgh, K:) and [its n. un.] with p, a piece thereof: (A, Sgh:) from A^aSobara meaning Ai$otad~a. (A.)

SabirN *
SabirN (S, M, Msb, K) and SaborN↓, which latter is allowable only in cases of necessity in poetry, (S, Msb, K,) or it is allowable in other cases, as also SiborN↓, agreeably with analogy, (Ibn-Es-Seed, Msb,) [Aloes;] a certain bitter medicine; (S, Mgh, Msb;) the expressed juice of a certain bitter tree; (M, K;) the expressed juice of a certain tree of which the leaves are like the sheaths of knives, long and thick, with a dusty and dull hue in their greenness, of rough appearance, from the midst of which there comes forth a stalk whereon is a yellow flower, vmd [but what this means I know not] in odour; (Lth, TA;) it grows like the green suwsan [or lily], save that the leaves of the Sbr are longer and broader and much thicker, and it contains very much juice; (AHn, M, O, TA;) it is crushed and thrown into the presses, then bruised with pieces of wood, and trodden with the feet until its expressed juice flows, when it is left until it thickens, then it is put into leathern bags, and exposed to the sun until it dries: (AHn, O:) the best sort is the suquToriY~ [i. e. of the Island of Sukutrà]: and it is also known by the name of Sab~aArapN↓ [a name now applied to the plant]: (TA:) the n. un. is SabirapN [and SaborapN and SiborapN]: and the pl. is SubuwrN. (M, TA.) ― -b2- [Accord. to Freytag, it signifies also Myrrh: but for this I know not any authority.]

SuburN *
SuburN: see SuborN.

SaborapN *
SaborapN: see SubaArapN: ＝ -A2- and see SabaAr~apN, in two places. ＝ -A3- Also Urine, and dung of camels and other beasts, compacted together in a wateringtrough. (K.) ＝ -A4- A^abuw Saborapa, (so in a copy of the M,) or A^abuw Subayorapa↓, (so in the K and TA,) A certain bird; (M, K;) red in the belly, black in the head and wings and tail, the rest of it being red; (M;) thus in the L; (TA;) or red in the belly, black in the back and head and tail; (K;) thus in the Tekmileh: (TA:) [but] AHát says, in “ the Book of Birds, ” A^abuw Subayorapa, which is [the same as] A^abuw Sabirapa↓, is [a bird] red in the belly, black in the head and wings and tail, the rest of it being red, of the colour of Sabir: and the pl. is SubayoraAtN and SabiraAtN. (O.)

SuborapN *
SuborapN A quantity collected together, of wheat (&c.], without being measured or weighed, (S, * M, Msb, * K,) heaped up: (TA:) pl. SubarN. (S, Msb.) You say, Ai$otarayotu Al$~aYo'a SuborapF I bought the thing without its being measured or weighed. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- And Reaped grain collected together; or wheat collected together in the place where it is trodden out: (M, TA:) or when trodden out and thrashed. (Msb in art. kds.) ― -b3- And Wheat sifted (M, K) with a thing resembling a saranod [or sirinod, which is a Pers. word, here app. meaning a kind of net]. (M.) ― -b4- And Rough, or rugged, stones, collected together: pl. SibaArN. (M, K.) [See also SubaArapN.]

A^abuw Sabirapa *
A^abuw Sabirapa: see SaborapN.

SabaArN *
SabaArN: see SubaArapN, in two places.

SubaArN *
SubaArN (M, K) and Sub~aArN↓ (K) The fruit of a kind of tree, intensely acid, having a broad, red stone, brought from India, said to be (M) the tamarind, (M, K,) used as a medicine. (M.)

SibaArN *
SibaArN A stopper [of a bottle]; syn. sadaAdN. (K. [See 4, last sentence.]) ＝ -A2- And The fruit of a certain acid tree. (K. [But in this sense it is probably a mistake for SubaArN, q. v.])

SabuwrN *
SabuwrN: see SaAbirN, in four places.

SabiyrN *
SabiyrN: see SaAbirN, in two places. ― -b2- Also A surety. (S, M, Msb, K.) You say, huwa bihi SabiyrN He is a surety for him, or it. (TA.) ― -b3- And Sabiyru qawomK The chief, head, director, conductor, or manager, of the affairs of a people, or party: (M, K:) he who is patient for, and with, a people, or party, in [the managing of] their affairs: (A:) pl. SubaraA='u. (M.) ― -b4- [And accord. to Golius, A solitary man, having neither offspring nor brother: but app. a mistake for SunobuwrN, which is thus expl. in the S in this art.] ＝ -A2- Also, (S, M, K,) and SubaArapN↓, (M,) A white cloud; (M, K;) and so SiborN↓ and SuborN↓, of which the pl. is A^aSobaArN: (K:) or white clouds; (M, K;) as also A^aSobaAnN, pl. of SiborN↓ and SuborN↓: (Fr, Yaakoob, S:) or white clouds that scarcely ever, or never, give rain: (S:) or clouds, (M, K,) or white clouds, (As, S,) that become disposed one above another (As, S, M, K) in the manner of steps: (As, S, M:) or a dense cloud that is above another cloud: (M, K:) or a stationary portion of cloud: (K:) or a portion of cloud which one sees as though it were maSobuwrap, i. e. detained; but this explanation is of weak authority: or, accord. to AHn, clouds remaining stationary a day and a night; as though detained: (M:) or clouds in which are blackness and whiteness: or, as some say, clouds slow in motion, by reason of their heaviness and the abundance of their water: (Ham p. 786:) the pl. of SabiyrN is the same as the sing., (M,) or it is SuburN. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- And SabiyrN, A mountain: (O, K:) or AlS~abiyru is the name of a particular mountain. (TA.) ― -b3- [And accord. to Freytag, as from the K, in which I do not find this meaning, A hill consisting of stones.] ＝ -A3- Also SabiyrN, (K,) i. e. (TA) the Sabiyr of a xawaAn [or table, or thing upon which one eats], (M, A, TA,) A thin, round cake of bread, which is spread beneath the food that one eats: (M, A, K:) or (K, TA, but in the CK “ and ”) upon which the food to be eaten at a wedding-feast is ladled (K, TA) by the maker of the bread: (TA:) also called SabiyrapN↓. (K.)

SabaArapN *
SabaArapN: see the next paragraph: ＝ -A2- and see SabaAr~apN.

SubaArapN *
SubaArapN (S, M, K) and SabaArapN↓ and SibaArapN↓ (K) Stones: (S, M, K:) or smooth stones: (TA:) or SubaArapN signifies, (M,) or SabaArapN signifies also, (K,) a piece of stone, or portion of stones: or of iron. (M, K.) A poet says, (S,) namely, El-Aashà, (M,) or 'Amr Ibn-Milkat Et-Tá-ee, addressing 'Amr Ibn-Hind, who had a brother slain, (IB,)
mano muboligN EamorFA biA^an~a Almaro'a lamo yuxolaqo SubaAraho
(so in the S; but in the M and TA this verse is given differently, with $ayobaAna and A^an~a in the places of EamorFA and biA^an~a; and it is said in the M that accord. to one relation the last word is SiyaAraho, [with Y,] which, it is added, is like SubaArah in meaning;) [i. e. Who will tell 'Amr, or Sheybán, that man was not created stones?] but IB says that the last word is correctly SibaAraho, with kesr to the S; and the poet means, man is not stone, that he should patiently endure the like of this: (TA:) [J says,] accord. to one relation, the last word is SabaAraho, with fet-h, which is pl. of SabaArN↓, the SabaArN being affixed to denote its being a pl. pl., for SaborapN is pl. of ↓signifying strong, or hard, stones: [and he adds,] El-Aashà says,
qubayola AlS~uboHi A^aSowaAtu AlS~abaAri↓
(S:) but IB says that SabaArN and SabaArapN are not pls. of SaborapN; for faEaAlN is not a pl. form, but fiEaAlN, with kesr, like HijaArN and jibaAlN: (TA:) [and it is said that] the verse from which this is cited is not by El-Aashà, and is correctly and completely as follows:
kaA^an~a taran~uma AlhaAjaAti fiyhaA
qubayola AlS~uboHi A^aSowaAtu AlS~iyaAri
by AlSyAr being meant the Sanoj, (TS, K, TA,) the stringed instrument thus called: (TS, TA:)
accord. to the reading given in the S, the verse means, As though the croaking of the frogs in it, a little before daybreak, were the sounds of falling stones: and this is correct. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also SabiyrN.

SibaArapN *
SibaArapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

rajulN SabuwrapN *
rajulN SabuwrapN: see maSobuwrN.

SabiyrapN *
SabiyrapN: see SabiyrN, last sentence.

A^abuw Subayorapa *
A^abuw Subayorapa: see SaborapN.

SabaAr~apN *
SabaAr~apN, [respecting the form of which see HamaAr~apN,] (S, M, K,) and SabaArapN↓, without teshdeed, (Lh, M, K,) and SaborapN↓, (K,) The intenseness of the cold (S, M, K) of winter: (S, M:) and [in an absolute sense] intenseness of cold: (TA:) and SaborapN↓ signifies also the middle of winter; (K;) and so SawobarapN↓. (TA.)

Sab~aArN *
Sab~aArN: see SaAbirN, in two places. ― -b2- A^um~u Sab~aArK (S, M, A, K) and A^um~u Sab~uwrK↓, (K,) or the former only is meant in the K as having the first of the significations here following, (TA,) A stony tract, of which the stones are black and worn and crumbling, as though burned with fire; syn. Har~apN; (T, S, M, A, &c.;) for which Har~ is erroneously put in copies of the K: (TA:) from SuborN↓, q. v.; (S, M;) or from SubaArapN: or, accord. to some, such as is level, abounding with stones, and difficult to walk upon: (M:) or the former is [the tract called] Har~apu layolaY, and [that called] Har~apu Aln~aAri: (ElFezáree:) or it has the first of the above-mentioned significations, and signifies also a [mountain, or hill, such as is termed] haDobap: (ISk:) or smooth rock upon which nothing makes an impression: but the latter, accord. to Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee, signifies a haDobap without a pass. (ISh.) ― -b3- Also A^um~u Sab~aArK (M, K) and A^Fm~u Sab~uwrK↓ (S, M, K) A calamity, or misfortune: and a severe war: (M, K:) or the latter, a distressing case. (S.) One says, waqaEuwA fiY A^um~i Sab~aArK (M) and A^um~i Sab~uwrK↓ (S, M) They fell into a calamity, &c.: (M:) or the latter, they fell into a distressing case: (S:) or into a perplexing and distressing case, from which they could not escape, like the haDobap, above mentioned, without a pass: (Aboo-'Amr EshSheybánee:) but in some of the copies of the “ Alfádh ” [of ISk], A^um~i Say~uwrK, as though derived from SiyaArapN, signifying “ stones. ” (TA.)

Sub~aArN *
Sub~aArN: see SubaArN.

A^um~u Sab~uwrK *
A^um~u Sab~uwrK: see Sab~aArN, in three places.

Sab~aArapN *
Sab~aArapN Rugged ground, rising above the adjacent part or parts, and hard, (K, TA,) in which is no herbage, and which produces none: or i. q. A^um~u Sab~aAri. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also SabirN.

SaAbirN *
SaAbirN and SabuwrN↓, (M, K,) the latter of which is also applied to a female, without p, (M,) and SabiyrN↓ (M, K) and Sab~aArN↓, (M,) are epithets from Sabara “ he was patient, or enduring: ” (M, K:) the five following epithets are said to denote different degrees of patience: SaAbirN is the most general of them [in signification, meaning simply Patient, or enduring]: muSoTabirN↓ signifies acquiring patience; and tried with patience: mutaSab~irN↓, constraining himself to be patient: SabuwrN↓, having great patience; [or very patient;] whose patience is greater than that of others; [as also SabiyrN↓; or this signifies rendered patient, from Sabarahu;] denoting quality, or manner: and Sab~aArN↓, having an intense degree of patience; [or having very great patience;] denoting measure, and quantity: the pl. of SabuwrN↓ is SuburN. (TA.) As an epithet applied to God, (Aboo-Is-hák [i. e. Zj],) AlS~abuwru↓ signifies The Clement, or Forbearing, who does not hastily avenge Himself upon the disobedient, but forgives, or defers: (Aboo-Is-hák, K:) [it may be well rendered The Long-suffering:] it is an intensive epithet. (TA.) One says also, huwa SaAbirN EalaY Albarodi (tropical:) [He is a patient endurer of cold]. (A.)

SanobarN *
SanobarN; &c.: see art. Snbr.

SawobarapN *
SawobarapN: see SabaAr~apN.

SaAbuwrapN *
SaAbuwrapN Ballast of a ship; the weight that is put in the bottom of a ship. (TA.)

A^aSobaru *
A^aSobaru [More, and most, patient or enduring]. A^aSobaru mino HimaArK [More patient than an ass] is a prov. (Meyd.) And one says, huwa A^aSobaru EalaY AlD~arobi mina AlA^aroDi (tropical:) [He is more patient of beating than the ground]. (A.) [The fem.] SuboraY is applied to a she-camel by Honeyf El-Hanátim [as meaning Surpassingly patient or enduring]. (IAar, TA in art. bhY.)

A^aSobirapN *
A^aSobirapN Sheep or goats, and camels, that return in the evening and morning to their owners, not remaining away from them: (M, K: *) [a pl. having no sing.: (K:) [ISd says,] I have not heard any sing. of it. (M.)

maSobuwrN *
maSobuwrN [pass. part. n. of 1, q. v. Confined, &c. ― -b2- ] Confined [with bonds or otherwise], (K,) or set up, (M,) to be put to death: (M, K:) and rajulN SabuwrapN↓ a man confined, (K,) or set up, (M,) to be put to death; (M, K;) i. q. maSobuwrN liloqatoli: (Th, M, K:) and maSobuwrapN, applied to a beast (bahiymapN, A), confined [or bound] to be put to death [and in that state killed by arrows or the like]; i. q. maHobuwsapN EalaY Almawoti: such is forbidden to be eaten. (S, A.) ― -b3- maSobuwrapN applied to an oath: see SaborN. ＝ -A2- Also Made into a Suborap, like a Suborap of wheat; so gathered or collected together. (TA.)

muSoTabirN *
muSoTabirN: see SaAbirN. [mSTyr is expl. by Reiske as signifying Collecta caro ( ὄγκοσ τῆσ σαρκός): mentioned by Freytag: if so, it is app. muSoTabirN: see its verb.]

mutaSab~irN *
mutaSab~irN: see SaAbirN.

1 SabaEa bihi *
1. SabaEa bihi, aor.
SabaEa
, (AZ, S, K,) inf. n. SaboEN, (AZ, S,) He pointed at him, or towards him, with his finger, (biA_iSobaEihi,) disparagingly: (AZ, S, K:) or, as some say, he meant some evil thing to him when he (the latter) was inadvertent, not knowing. (TA.) ― -b2- And SabaEa fulaAnFA EalaY fulaAnK He directed such a one to such a one by pointing, or indication: (S, K:) because, when one directs a man to a way, or road, or to a thing that is latent, or obscure, he points towards it with the finger. (TA.) One says, maA SabaEaka EalayonaA What directed thee to us? (TA.) And SabaEa bayona Alqawomi He directed others to the people, or party. (TA.) Of one who magnifies himself, or acts proudly, in his government, or administration, one says, SabaEahu Al$~ayoTaAnu (assumed tropical:) [app. meaning The Devil has directed him]: and A^adorakatohu A^aSaAbiEu Al$~ayoTaAni [The fingers of the Devil have reached him]. (TA. [See the pass. part. n. below.]) ― -b3- And one says, qur~iba A_ilayohi TaEaAmN famaA SabaEa fiyhi i. e. [Food was presented, or offered, to him, or was placed, or put, before him, and] he did not put his finger into it. (TA.) [See also SabaA^a, near the end.] ― -b4- And SabaEa Ald~ajaAjapa, (O, K,) inf. n. as above. (TA,) He inserted his finger into the hen in order that he might know if she were [near] laying an egg or not: (O, K:) mentioned by Z. (TA.) ― -b5- And SabaEa AlA_inaA='a He put his finger upon the vessel so that what was in another vessel flowed upon it [into the former vessel]: (A'Obeyd, S, O, K:) or, as some say, he put together his two fingers, [or two of his fingers,] then discharged, or let flow, what was in the vessel, of wine, or beverage, into a thing with a narrow head [or mouth]: or, accord. to Az, he discharged, or let flow, what was in the vessel, of wine, or beverage, between the extremities of [either of] his two thumbs and fore fingers, in order that it might not become scattered, and pour forth copiously. (TA.) ― -b6- And SabaEahu, inf. n. as above, He hit, or hurt, his finger. (TA.) ＝ -A2- SabaEa EalaY Alqawomi, inf. n. as above, meaning He came forth upon the people, or party, is said to be originally SabaA^a, with '. (TA.)

4. ASbE, followed by EalaY, is said by Freytag, as on the authority of Meyd, to signify He (a pastor) fed and managed well his cattle: but this is perhaps taken from a mistranscription of the saying, mentioned by Meyd, lilr~aAEiY EalaY maA$iyatahi A_iSobaEN, q. v. infrà.]

SaboEN *
SaboEN (tropical:) Self-magnification, or pride; (O, K, TA;) such as is consummate; (TA;) and haughtiness, or insolence, or vain glory; (O, TA;) and muSobaEapN↓ signifies the same. (O, K, TA.)

SuboEN *
SuboEN i. q. SuboHN [q. v.]: the E being substituted for the H. (MF on the letter E.)

A_iSobaEN *
A_iSobaEN and A^uSobaEN and A^uSobuEN and A_iSobiEN and A^aSobiEN (S, O, Msb, K) and A_iSobuEN and A^aSobaEN (O, Msb, K) and A^aSobuEN and A^uSobiEN, the ' being thus trebly vowelled, and the b likewise (Msb, K) with every one of the vowellings of the ', (K,) and A^uSobuwEN↓ also, (Msb, K,) of all which forms the
first is the [only] one commonly known and the one approved by persons of chaste speech, (Msb,) all mentioned by Kr, (K,) and by Lh also on the authority of Yoo, (TA,) A finger: and a toe: (MA, KL, &c.:) of the fem. gender, (Msb,) or fem. and masc., (S, O, Msb, K, *) but generally fem.: (O, Msb, K: *) pl. (of ASbE, MA) A^aSaAbiEu and (of ASbwE, MA) A^aSaAbiyEu. (MA, K.) ― -b2- One says, bihimo tuvonaY AlA^aSaAbiEu [With the mention of them the fingers are bent]; meaning that they are reckoned as the best, [or among the best,] for the best are not many. (M, on a verse cited in the first paragraph of art. vnY.) [See also two similar exs. in the first paragraph of art. Hnw and HnY.] ― -b3- And lilr~aAEiY EalaY maA$iyatihi A_iSobaEN (tropical:) [The pastor has a finger pointing at his cattle, or camels or sheep or goats]; meaning, [has upon his cattle] an impress of a good state or condition; (S, K, * TA;) i. e. they are pointed at with the fingers because of their goodliness and fatness and good tending. (TA.) [See also a verse cited voce SulobN.] And similar to this saying is the prov., Ealayohi mina A@ll~`hi taEaAlaY A_iSobaEN HasanN, meaning (assumed tropical:) [Upon him is, from God, (acknowledged be his absolute supremacy,)] an impress of a good state or condition. (Meyd.) And one says also, A_in~ahu laHasanu AlA_iSobaEi fiY maAlihi, meaning (assumed tropical:) Verily he is good in respect of the impress upon his cattle [indicative of their state or condition]. (IAar, TA.) ― -b4- And fulaAnN mugil~u AlA_iSobaEi (tropical:) Such a one is unfaithful, treacherous, or perfidious. (O, K, * TA. *) ― -b5- And lahu A_iSobaEN fiY h`*aA AlA^amori (tropical:) [He has a finger in this affair]. (TA.) ― -b6- The Prophet said qalobu Almuw^omini bayona A_iSobaEayoni mino A^aSaAbiEi A@ll~`hi yuqal~ibuhu kayofa $aA='a (tropical:) [The heart of the believer is between two of the fingers of God: He turneth it about as He pleaseth]. (O.) ― -b7- And a man says, in respect of a difficult affair, when he has been made to have recourse to a strong man, able to bear his burden, A_in~ahu yaA^otiY Ealayohi biA_iSobiEK waAHidapK (assumed tropical:) [Verily he will make an end of it with one finger]: and A_in~ahu yakofiyhi biSugoraY A^aSaAbiEihi (assumed tropical:) [Verily the smallest of his fingers will suffice him for its accomplishment; the b thus prefixed to the agent being redundant, as in kafaY biA@ll~`hi $ahiydFA and many other instances]. (O.) ― -b8- A^abuw AlA_iSobaEi is one of the surnames of The Devil. (TA. [See SabaEahu Al$~iyoTaAnu, above.]) ― -b9- [A_iSobaEN signifies also (assumed tropical:) A prong, as resembling a finger: so in the S and K in art. Hfr, and in other instances.] ― -b10- A^aSaAbiEu AlfatayaAti, (O, TS, K,) in the “ Minháj ” of Ibn-Jezleh ASAbE AlftyAn, [app. a mistranscription,] and in the I, ASAbE Albunay~aAti, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) [Common clinopodium, or wild basil,] the sweet-smelling plant called in Pers. Alfaranojamu$ok, (AHn, O, K,) which grows abundantly in the southern parts of Arabia, and is not depastured by any animal. (AHn, O.) ― -b11- A^aSaAbiEu AlEa*aAraY (assumed tropical:) A species of grapes, (AHn, O, K,) black, (AHn, O,) long, like the acorn, likened to the dyed fingers of virgins; (AHn, O, K; *) the bunch thereof is about a cubit [in length], compact [so I render mutadaAxis, supposing it to be similar to dxys applied to herbage &c.,] in the grapes; its raisins are good; and it grows in the Saráh (Als~araAp). (AHn, O.) ― -b12- A^aSaAbiEu huromusa (assumed tropical:) The flowers (fuq~aAH) of the suwranojaAn [or Hermodactylus (the Iris of Linn.?) now applied to meadow-saffron, a species of colchicum]; (O, K;) the potency of which is like that of the swrnjAn [itself]. (TA.) ― -b13- A^aSaAbiEu firoEawna (assumed tropical:) [Certain things] resembling the maraAwiyd [or maraAwid with which kuHol is applied], of the length of the finger, (K, TA,) red; (TA;) brought from the Sea of El-Hijáz; of proved efficacy for the speedy consolidation of wounds. (K.) ― -b14- A^aSaAbiEu SuforN (assumed tropical:) The root (A^aSol) of a certain plant of which the form is like the hand, (O, K,) variegated with yellowness and whiteness, hard, and having a little sweetness; and there is a species thereof yellow, with a dust-colour, but without whiteness: (O, TA:) so says Ibn-Jezleh: (TA:) it is beneficial as a remedy for madness, or diabolical possession, and for poisons, (K, TA,) and the sting, or bite, of venomous, or noxious, reptiles, or the like, and it acts as a dissolvent of thick excrescences. (TA.) ― -b15- As a measure, A_iSobaEN signifies [A digit; i. e. a finger's breadth;] the width of six moderate-sized barley-corns; (Msb voce jariybN;) the forth part of the qaboDap. (Mgh and Msb ibid.)

Sabuga
and

, (Fr, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. SabogN (S, O, Msb, K) and SibagN (As, O, K) and SibagapN, (AHn, TA,) [of which last, SibogapN (q. v.), also said to be an inf. n., is perhaps a contraction, or, as is said in the Ksh ii. 132, it means a mode, or manner, of Sabog,] He dyed it, or coloured it; (K TA;) namely, a garment, or piece of cloth; (S, O, Msb, TA;) and white, or hoary, hair, and the like. (TA.) [It is said that] the primary meaning of AlS~abogu in the language of the Arabs is The altering [a thing]: and hence Subiga Alv~awobu, meaning The garment, or piece of cloth, was altered in colour to blackness or redness or yellowness [&c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Sabaga All~uqomapa, aor.
Sabuga
, inf. n. SabogN, (assumed tropical:) He moistened the mouthful with oil or grease [or any kind of Sibog i. e. sauce & c.]; and he dipped it, or immersed it; and in like manner any other thing. (TA.) [Thus] one says, Sabaga yadahu biAlmaA='i (As, O, K) and fiY AlmaA='i (TA) (tropical:) He dipped, or immersed, his hand, or arm, in the water. (As, O, K, TA.) And Sabagati Aln~aAqapu ma$aAfirahaA fiY AlmaA='i (As, O) or biAlmaA='i (TA) (assumed tropical:) The she-camel dipped her lips in the water. (As, O, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] the term SabogN is used by the Christians as meaning (assumed tropical:) The dipping, or immersing, of their children, [i. e. baptizing them,] in water. (Az, S, * TA.) One says, Sabaga waladahu fiY Aln~aSoraAniy~api, inf. n. [SabogN (as shown in the next preceding sentence) and] SibogapN, (assumed tropical:) He introduced his child into the Christian communion, it is said, by dipping, or immersing, him in the water of baptism. (TA.) And Sabaga waladahu fiY Alyahuwdiy~api (assumed tropical:) He introduced his child into the Jewish communion [probably by baptism combined with circumcision: but see SibogapN, an explanation of which seems to indicated that circumcision alone is meant in this case]. (TA.) ― -b4- And yaSobuguwna AlHadiyva (assumed tropical:) They colour and alter information, or discourse. (O.) ― -b5- And Sabaguwhu fiY Eayonihi (assumed tropical:) They altered him in his estimation; and informed him that he had become altered from the state in which he was. (TA.) And it is said that SabaguwniY fiY Eayonika and SabaguwniY Einodaka mean They pointed me out to thee as one who would accomplish what thou desiredst of me; from the saying of the Arabs, Sabagotu Alr~ajula biEayoniY and biyadiY I pointed at the man with my eye and with my hand: (O, K: *) but Az says that this is a mistake; that the Arabs when they mean thus say SabaEotu, with the unpointed E. (O.) ― -b6- One says also, Sabaga yadahu biAlEilomi, (Msb,) or bifan~K mina AlEilomi, and biAlEamali, (TA,) (tropical:) He laboured in science, [or in a species of science or knowledge, and in work,] and became notable therein [or thereby]. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- Sabaga DaroEuhaA, inf. n. SubuwgN, (tropical:) Her udder became full, and goodly in colour: (O, K, TA:) said of a camel. (O, TA.) ― -b2- And Sabagato EaDalatuhu, (O, K,) aor.
Sabuga
, (O, TA,) inf. n. SubuwgN, (TA,) said of a man, (O,) His EDlp [or muscle] became long: (O, K:) like sabagato. (O, TA.) And Sabaga Alv~awobu, inf. n. SubuwgN, The garment, or piece of cloth, was long and ample: a dial. var. of sabaga. (TA.) ＝ -A3- And Sabaga fiY AlT~aEaAmi, aor.
Sabuga
, He [app. a camel] put his head into the food: as also SabaA^a. (O.) And Sabagati AlA_ibilu fiY Alr~iEoYi [The camels put their heads into the pasture, or herbage]. (O, TA.) And Sabagato fiyhaA raA^osahaA [or fiyhi, She put her head into it]; like SabaA^ato. (TA.)

SbogN *
SbogN (AZ, As, S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and SibogapN↓ (S, O, Msb, K) and SibagN↓, (O, K,) or this is an inf. n., differing from SibogN, (AZ, As, L,) and SibaAgN↓, (Mgh, O, Msb, K,) as some say, (O,) or this last is a pl. of the first, (O, * Msb,) [or] the pl. of SibogN is A^aSobaAgN, (S,) A dye; (AZ, As, S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) used for colouring clothes [& c.]: (TA:) the pl. of SibaAgN↓ is A^aSobigapN; and A^aSaAbiygu is a pl. pl. [i. e. pl. of A^aSobaAgN]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] one says of a girl, or young woman, when one first takes her as a concubine, or when he first has her conducted to him as a bridge, (AZ, O,) or when one first marries her, (K,) A_in~ahaA laHadiyvapu AlSibogi (assumed tropical:) [Verily she is one newly taken as a concubine, or a bride: app. alluding to the recent application of the dye of the hinnà]. (AZ, O, K.) And one says also, maA A^axa*otuhu biSibogi Alv~amani, (AZ, O,) or maA A^axa*ahu biSibogi vamanihi, (K,) i. e. [I did not, or he did not, take it, or acquire it,] for its proper price, [app. meaning its cost-price, or prime-cost,] but for a high [or raised] price. (AZ, O, K. *) ― -b3- SibogN also signifies, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, TA,) and so does SibaAgN↓, (Mgh, TA,) or the latter is pl. of the former, (S, O, TA,) (tropical:) A seasoning, or condiment, for bread, to render it savoury; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, TA;) particularly (Msb) such as is fluid, (Mgh in art. Adm, and Msb,) as vinegar, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) and olive-oil, (Mgh, TA,) and the like, (Msb, TA,) [i. e. any sauce,] in which the bread is dipped: (Msb:) so called because the bread is dipped in it, (Mgh, TA,) and coloured thereby: (Mgh:) the pl. of SibaAgN↓ is A^aSobigapN: one says, kavurati AlA^aSobigapu EalaY AlmaAy^idapi (tropical:) (tropical:) The sauces, or fluid seasonings, were abundant upon the table.] (TA.) SibogN is used in this sense, but not explained, in the K. (TA.) Hence, in the Kur [xxiii. 20], waSibogK liloA=kiliyna (assumed tropical:) [And a sauce for those that eat]; (S, O, Msb, TA;) where it means, accord. to Fr, olive-oil; but accord. to Zj, the olive [itself]; and Az prefers the latter explanation: (TA:) some read waSibaAgK↓. (Bd.)

SubogapN *
SubogapN, in a sheep or goat, or in a ewe, (assumed tropical:) Whiteness of the extremity of the tail; the quality denoted by the epithet SabogaA='u. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A date that has become partly ripe, i. e. ripe in a part thereof. (O, K.)

SibogapN *
SibogapN: see SibogN, first sentence. ― -b2- It also means (assumed tropical:) Religion, syn. diyn, (AA, O, K,) and mil~ap; (K;) and the religious law, syn. $ariyEap; (TA;) and anything whereby one advances himself in the favour of God: (AA, TA:) [thus,] in the Kur [ii. 132], (O, TA,) Sibogapa A@ll~`hi means the religion of God, syn. fiTorapa A@ll~`hi, (O, Msb, K,) or diyna A@ll~`hi, (S, Msb,) which is the meaning of fiTorapa A@ll~`hi; (Msb;) the religion of God, with an adaptation to which mankind are created; because its effect appears in him who has it like the dye in the garment; (Bd, Jel;) or because it intermingles in the heart like the dye in the garment; (Bd;) and it is said to be from the Christians' Sabog [or Sabogap i. e. baptism] of their children in a sort of water that they have; (S; [and the like is said in the O, and Ksh, & c.;]) Sbgp being in this instance in the accus. case as an objective complement; (Msb;) for the meaning is “ follow ye the religion of God; ” (O, Msb;) or “ we will follow the religion of God: ” (O:) or it means that which God has prescribed to Mohammad; i. e. circumcision: (O, K:) or Sbgp is in this instance an inf. n., (Ksh, Bd, Jel,) signifying a mode, or manner of, Sabog [i. e. of baptism], (Ksh,) relating to the baptism of the Christians, (Ksh, Bd,) a corroborative of the saying A=man~aA [in verse 130], as such put in the accusative case, (Ksh, Bd, Jel,) by reason of a verb understood, (Jel,) the meaning being SabaganaA A@ll~`hu Sibogatahu [God hath baptized us with his baptism]; (Ksh, Bd, Jel; *) [so that Sibogapa A@ll~`hi signifies the baptism of God, and may here be rendered We have received the baptism of God;;] the Muslims being hereby commanded to say to the Christians, “ Say ye, God hath baptized us (SabaganaA) with the faith, with a baptism (Sabogap) not like ours [i. e. not like our Christian baptism], and purified us with a purifying not like ours; ” or the Muslims being hereby commanded to say [of themselves], “ God hath baptized us (SabaganaA) with the faith, as a baptism (SibogapF), and we have not been baptized with your baptism (lamo nuSobago Sibogatakumo). ” (Ksh.)

SibaAgapN The craft, or art, of the dyer. (O.)

Sab~aAgN *
Sab~aAgN A dyer (O, L, K) of garments. (O, K.) ― -b2- And [hence,] (tropical:) A liar: (K:) one who colours and alters information, or discourse. (O, K. *) The Prophet is related to have said, A^ako*abu Aln~aAsi AlS~ab~aAguwna waAlS~aw~aAguwna or mino A^ako*abi Aln~aAsi Alx [Which may mean The most lying of men, or of the most lying of men, are the dyers and the goldsmiths; or (assumed tropical:) those who colour, and those who transform, information, or discourse]: El-Khat- tábee says, the meaning is, that the persons who practise the two crafts to which these words relate make many promises as to returning the goods, and often break their promises; wherefore they are said to be of the most lying of men; not that every one of them is one who lies: but he adds that it has been said to mean the moulding and colouring of speech with falsehood. (O.)

naAqapN SaAbigN *
naAqapN SaAbigN, (O, K,) without p, (O,) A she-camel having her udder full, and goodly in colour. (O, K.) ― -b2- And A_ibilN SaAbigapN fiY Alr~iEoYi [meaning Camels putting their heads into the pasture], with p. (O. [See 1, last sentence but one.])

A^aSobagu *
A^aSobagu (assumed tropical:) A horse white in the forelock, (AO, S, Mgh, O, K,) all of it: (AO, Mgh: [see also A^asoEafu:]) or white in the extremities of his tail: (S, O:) or white in the extremities of the ear: (K:) when the whiteness is in his tail, he is termed A^a$oEal: or, accord. to AO, it signifies also white in the whole of the tail, including its extremities. (TA.) And (tropical:) A bird white in the tail: (S, O, K, TA:) or, accord. to the book entitled “ Ghareeb el-Hamám ” by El-Hasan Ibn-' Abd-Allah ElIsbahánee El-Kátib, white in the whole of the head; but used in the former sense by the keepers of pigeons. (TA.) And [the fem.] SabogaA='u (assumed tropical:) A sheep or goat ($aAp, S, O, K) or a ewe (AZ, TA) white in the extremity of its tail, (AZ, S, O, K, TA,) the rest of it (i. e. of the animal) being black. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A species of weak birds. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, (applied to a man, O,) (tropical:) One who voids his excrement (O, K, TA) in his clothes (K, TA) when he is beaten (O, K, TA) and when he is frightened: mentioned by Z. (TA.) ― -b4- And SabogaA='u, (assumed tropical:) A certain tree, or plant, ($ajarap,) like the vumaAm [which is applied to several species of panic grass], having a white fruit, growing in sands: (K:) [but this seems to have been taken from three different explanations, here following:] accord. to Aboo-Ziyád, a certain tree, or plant, that grows in the sands, resembling the DaEap [which is applied to a species of the vumaAm], which is one of the abodes of the gazelles in the hot season, lurking-places being excavated by them at its roots: accord. to another, of the Arabs of the desert, it is like the vumaAm, but the DaEap is larger in the leaves, and of a brighter green: accord. to
Aboo-Nasr, a certain tree, or plant, having a white fruit. (O.) And, (O, K,) as some say, (O,) (assumed tropical:) A bunch of herbage, of which, when it comes up, the upper portions are green on the side next the sun, and white on the side next the shade. (O, K.) ＝ -A2- Also (i. e. A^aSobag) The greatest of torrents. (Ibn-' Abbád, O, K.) [In this sense, though used as a subst., it seems to be, as in other senses, imperfectly decl., being originally an epithet: if not originally an epithet, it might, accord. to some authorities, be perfectly decl.]

SabonaA='u The hand of a player at a game of hazard inclined for acting treacherously to a companion. (IAar, K.)

SaAbuwnN *
SaAbuwnN a word of well-known meaning, (S, M, K,) [Soap;] a compound with which clothes [&c.] are washed: the best of which is made of pure olive-oil and clear potash and good jiyr [meaning lime], well cooked [i. e. boiled], and dried, and cut into particular shapes: the magoribiY~ sort is not cut, nor well cooked [or boiled], but is like cooked starch: (TA:) it is hot and dry; and produces a pleasurable sensation in the body; (K;) but the washing the head with it hastens hoariness: (TA: [in which many other supposed properties of it are mentioned:]) IDrd says the word is not of the language of the Arabs: (TA:) [Fei, in the Msb, fancifully derives it from Sabana AlkaA^osa, because it removes filths and impurities:] MF says that it is one of the words common to all languages, Arabic and Persian and Turkish and others [as Greek &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] SuAbuwnu Alhumuwmi is a term for (assumed tropical:) Wine. (TA voce tiroyaAqN, q. v.)

SaAbuwniY~N *
[SaAbuwniY~N Of, or relating to, soap; saponaceous. ― -b2- And A maker, or seller, of soap: mentioned in the K and TA only as a surname.]

1 SabaA *
1. SabaA, (S, M, K,) aor. yaSobuw, inf. n. SabowapN, (S,) or SabowN, (M, K,) and Subuw~N (S, M, K) and SibFA [also written SibFY, in the CK (erroneously) SabFY,] and SabaA='N, (M, K,) [app., in its primary acceptation, He was a youth, or boy, or child; agreeably with an explanation of a phrase in what follows, and with explanations of SibFA and SabaA='N which will be found below: ― -b2- and hence,] He was, or became, youthfully ignorant, or foolish, or silly: (M, K:) [and, as seems to be indicated in the TA, he indulged in amorous dalliance; a sense in which the verb, more especially with SibFA (q. v. infrà) for its inf. n., is very frequently used:] or he inclined to ignorant, or foolish, or silly, and youthful, conduct; and in like manner tSAbY↓; from AlS~ibaA, which is from Al$~awoq [i. e. “ desire ”]: (S: [see an ex. of the inf. n. of the latter verb in a verse cited voce $aAba, in art. $yb:]) or SibFA and SabaA='N, as inf. ns., signify the inclining the heart to any one; and have other significations expl. in what follows: and taSaAbK↓ signifies the manifesting passionate love, and desire: (KL:) [but SibFA and SabaA='N are often used in different senses: thus Et-Tebreezee says that] in the following hemistich of a poem by Dureyd Ibn-Es-Simmeh,
SabaA maA SabaA Hat~aY EalaA Al$~ayobu raA^osahu
the first SbA may be from AlS~ibaY [or AlS~ibaA], and the second SbA from AlS~abaA='u signifying AlfataA='u; so that the meaning may be, He engaged in play, or sport, and AlS~ibaY [or amorous dalliance, &c.], as long as he was a youth, [until hoariness came upon his head;] or the meaning may be, he engaged in AlS~ibiY as long as he engaged therein, &c. (Ham p. 380.) And SabiYa, (S, M, K,) [aor. yaSobaY,] inf. n. SabaA='N, (S,) or SibFA, (M,) [or both, as will appear from what follows,] signifies He played, or sported, with the SiboyaAn [i. e. youths, or boys, or children]: (S:) or he acted in the manner of the SiboyaAn: (M, K: *) or both SibFA and SabaA='N, as inf. ns., signify the acting as a youth, or boy, or child; and the playing, or sporting, with youths, or boys, or children: (KL:) and tSb~Y↓ and tSAbY↓, said of an old man, signify he acted in a youthful, boyish, or childish, manner. (TA.) ― -b3- SabaA, inf. n. Subuw~N and SabowapN, also signifies He inclined. (Msb.) You say, SabaA A_ilayohaA He inclined to her, namely, a woman; as also SabiYa: and in like manner, Sabato A_ilayohi and Sabiyato [She inclined to him]. (M. [See also Sub~N, in art. Sb.]) And SabaA A_ilayohi, (M,) or A_ilayohaA, (K,) inf. n. SabowapN (M, K) and SubowapN (K) and Subuw~N; (M, K;) and SabiYa; (K;) He yearned towards, longed for, or desired, (M, K,) him, (M,) or her: (K.) ― -b4- [Hence, app.,] Sabati Aln~axolapu, (M, K,) aor. taSobuw, (M,) The [female] palm-tree inclined, or leaned, towards the male palm-tree that was distant from it. (M.) ― -b5- And Sabati Alr~aAEiyapu, (M, K,) aor. taSobuw, (M,) inf. n. Subuw~N, The pasturing beast inclined its head and put it upon the pasturage. (M, K.) [See also 2.] ＝ -A2- Sabato, (S, M, K,) aor. taSobuw, (S, M,) inf. n. Subuw~N (S, M, K) and SabFA, (M, K,) in [some of] the copies of the K SabaA', (TA,) said of the wind called AlS~abaA, (S, M, K,) It blew. (K.) ― -b2- And SubiYa Alqawomu, (M, K,) like EuniYa, (K,) The people, or party, were blown upon by the wind called AlS~abaA. (M, K.)

2 Sb~Y raA^osahu *
2. Sb~Y raA^osahu, inf. n. taSobiyapN, He inclined his head towards the ground. (TA.) [See also 1, near the end.]

3 SAbY rumoHahu *
3. SAbY rumoHahu, (T, S, *, M, K, TA,) inf. n. muSaAbaApN, (TA,) He inclined his spear, (M, K,) or he lowered the head of his spear towards the ground, (T, TA,) [or, as the context in the S seems to indicate, he inverted his spear,] to pierce, or thrust, (T, M, K,) with it. (M, TA.) ― -b2- SAbY Als~ayofa He put the sword into its gimod [which generally means its scabbard] (S, M, K,) or into its qiraAb [which generally means its case for enclosing it together with its scabbard,] (TA,) reversed, or inverted: (S, M, K, TA:) or, accord. to the A, SAbY sayofahu, and sik~iynahu, means he put his sword, and his knife, into its qiraAb not in the right manner: and one says to one who hands a knife, SaAbi sik~iynaka i. e. Reverse thy
knife, putting the handle towards me. (TA.) ― -b3- SAbY binaA='ahu He made his building to incline, or lean. (K.) ― -b4- SAbY ma$aAfirahu He (a camel) inverted his lips on the occasion of drinking. (K.) ― -b5- SAbY Al$~ayoxa He, or it, overturned the old man; and made him to incline. (TA.) ― -b6- SAbY Albayota, (M, K,) i. e. Albayota mina Al$~iEori, (TA,) He recited the verse not rightly, or not regularly. (M, K, TA. [In the CK, SAbAhu Albayota.]) And SAbY AlkalaAma He made the speech, or language, to deviate from its proper course, or tenour. (M, K.) ― -b7- SaAbayonaA Eani AlHamoDi is a phrase mentioned by AZ as meaning We turned away from the [plants called] HmD. (TA.) ― -b8- And one says, AljawaAriY yuSaAbiyna fiY Als~itori, meaning yTlEn [i. e. yaT~aliEona, but I think that fiY is a mistranscription for min, and that the meaning is, The girls, or young women, look from within the curtain]. (TA.)

4 A^aSobato *
4. A^aSobato She (a woman) had a child such as is termed SabiY~ [i. e. a boy, or a young male child]; (S, M;) and a child, male or female. (S.) ＝ -A2- A^aSobatohu She (a woman, M, K, or a girl, or young woman, S) excited his desire, and invited him, (M, K,) or made him to incline, (S,) to ignorant, or foolish, or silly, and youthful, conduct, (S, M, K,) so that he yearned towards her; as also taSab~atohu↓. (M, K.) And taSab~aAhaA↓ He invited her to the like thereof. (M.) And tSb~AhA↓ also signifies He deceived, or beguiled, her, and captivated her heart; (M, K; [see also another rendering in an explanation of a verse cited voce A_iSaArN;]) as also tSAbAhA↓. (K.) And ASbY Eirosa fulaAnK He endeavoured to cause the wife of such a one to incline [to him]. (TA.) ＝ -A3- A^aSobawoA They entered upon [a time in which blew] the wind called AlS~abaA. (M, K.)

5 taSab~awa
5: see 1, latter half: ＝ -A2- and see also 4, in three places.

6 taSaAobawa
6: see 1, in three places: ＝ -A2- and see also 4.

10 AstSbY *
10. AstSbY, as stated by Freytag, is expl. by Reiske as signifying Pueriliter se et proterve gessit: ＝ -A2- and by Jac. Schultens as signifying Pro puero habuit. But the usage of this verb in any sense is app. post-classical.]

SabFA *
SabFA [is of the fem. gender, and] is a subst. and an epithet, [so that one says riyHN SabFA, as well as SabFA alone and riyHu AlS~abaA,] (M, TA,) [and signifies The east wind: or an easterly wind:] the wind that blows from the place of sunrise: (Msb:) or the wind of which the mean place whence it blows is the place where the sun rises when the night and day are equal; the opposite wind of which is the dabuwr: (S:) or the wind that faces the House [of God, i. e. the Kaabeh; app. meaning that blows from the point opposite to the corner, of the Kaabeh, that is between the Black Stone and the door]; as though yearning towards the House: (M, TA:) or, accord. to IAar, (M,) the wind of which the place whence it blows extends from the place of rising of Alv~uray~aA [or the Pleiades] to [the place of] banaAt naEo$ [meaning the tail of Ursa Major]: (M, K:) [it is often commended by poets as a gentle and pleasant gale, like the Zephyr with us:] the dual is SabawaAni and SabayaAni: (Lh, M, K:) and pl. SabawaAtN and A^aSobaA='N. (M, K.)

SibFA *
SibFA [also written SibFY] and SabaA='N↓, the former with kesr and the short alif, and the latter with fet-h and the long alif, (S, Msb,) [both mentioned before as inf. ns.,] Youth, or boyhood; the state of the SabiY~ [q. v.]: (S:) or childhood. (Msb.) One says, kaAna *`lika fiY SibaAhu and SabaAy^ihi [That was in his youth or boyhood: or in his childhood]. (Msb.) [See also an ex. in a verse cited in the first paragraph of art. $fE.] ― -b2- And the former [or each, as is shown in the first sentence of this art.,] has also a signification derived from Al$~awoqu [or “ desire; ” i. e., each signifies also An inclining to ignorant, or foolish, or silly, and youthful, conduct; and amorous dalliance]: (S:) and SabowapN↓ signifies [the same, as is also shown in the first sentence of this art., or, like SibFA and SabaA='N,] the ignorance, or foolishness, or silliness, of youth; (Lth, M, K;) and amorous dalliance. (Lth, TA.) [See an ex. of the first in a verse cited in the first paragraph of art. AdY; and another in a verse cited voce EaAraDa.]

SabowapN *
SabowapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

SabaA='N *
SabaA='N: see SabFA.

SabiY~N *
SabiY~N A youth, boy, or male child; syn. gulaAmN: (S:) or a young male child; (Mgh, Msb;) before he is called gulaAm: (Mgh:) or one that has not yet been weaned, (M, K,) so called from the time of his birth: (M:) and SaAbK↓ signifies the same as SabiY~N; these two words being like qaAdirN and qadiyrN: (TA:) the pl. of the former is SiboyapN [a pl. of pauc., in which the w is changed into Y because of the kesreh before it, like as is said in the M respecting another of the pls.,] (S, M, Msb, K, but not in the CK,) and SibowapN (M, K, TA, in the CK SabowapN,) and SuboyapN (M, K) and SaboyapN, (K, TA, but not in the CK,) [or rather the last two are quasi-pl. ns.,] and A^aSobK [another pl. of pauc.] (K) and A^aSobiyapN [also a pl. of pauc.], (M, K,) but this last is said by J to have been unused, because the usage of SiboyapN rendered it needless, (TA,) and SiboyaAnN, (S, M, Msb, K, but not in the CK,) in which the w is changed into Y because of the kesreh before it, (M,) and SuboyaAnN, (M, K,) as some say, preserving the Y notwithstanding the dammeh, (M,) and SibowaAnN (M, K, but not in the CK,) and SubowaAnN: (M, K:) and [ISd says,] accord. to Sb, the dim. of SiboyapN is A^uSayobiyapN↓, and that of A^aSobiyapN is Subay~apN↓, each irreg.; but in my opinion, Subay~apN is the dim. of SiboyapN, and A^uSayobiyapN is that of A^aSobiyapN: (M:) [J says,] A^uSayobiyapN occurs in poetry as being the dim. of A^aSobiyapN. (S.) Sabiy~apN↓ signifies A young woman, girl, or female child; (S, TA;) and so too, [sometimes,] SabiY~N: (TA:) and the pl. is SabaAyaA. (S TA.) ― -b2- A^um~u AlS~iboyaAni is a term applied to The flatus, or flatulence, (Alr~iyHu,) that is incident to children. (TA in art. Am.) [Golius, in that art., explains it as meaning Larva, terriculamentum puerorum; on the authority of Meyd.: and also as meaning Epilepsy; on the authority of Ibn-Beytár.] ― -b3- SabiY~N also signifies (assumed tropical:) The pupil of the eye: (M, K:) but Kr ascribes this meaning to the vulgar. (M.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) The extremity of each of the jaw-bones: (K, TA:) i. e. (TA) AlS~abiy~aAni signifies the two extremities of the two jaw-bones (S, M, TA) of the camel and of other animals: or, as some say, the two edges curving outwards from the middle of the two jaw-bones: (M, TA:) or, accord. to the A, the thin portions of the two extremities thereof: and it is [said to be] tropical. (TA.) And (assumed tropical:) A bone below the lobe, or lobule, of each of the two ears: (K:) or, as some say, the head of the bone that is below the lobe, or lobule, of each of the two ears by the space of about three fingers put together. (M.) ― -b5- And (tropical:) The edge (Had~) of the sword: (M, K, TA:) or the ridge thereof, (M, TA, in the copies of the K A^awo gayorihi is erroneously put for A^awo Eayoruhu, TA,) which rises in [i. e. along] its middle; (M, K, TA;) and likewise of a spear-head: (M, TA:) or, accord. to the A, that part of a sword below, or exclusive of, (duwna,) its Zubap [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) The head of the human foot; (M, A, TA; in the copies of the K raA^osu Alqawomi is erroneously put for raA^osu Alqadami; TA;) i. e. the part [thereof] between its HimaArap [q. v.] and the toes. (A, TA.) And AlS~abiy~aAni signifies also (assumed tropical:) The two sides of the [camel's saddle called] raHol. (M.) ― -b7- It is also said that SiboyaAnu Aljaliydi signifies (tropical:) The grains of hoar-frost that resemble pearls: and SiboyaAnu AlmaTari (tropical:) the small drops of rain: but accord. to the author of the “ Khasáïl, ” it is Siy^obaAn [pl. of Suw^aAbapN, q. v.], with ' and then b. (TA.)

Sabiy~apN *
Sabiy~apN fem. of SabiY~N, q. v.

Subay~apN *
Subay~apN: see SabiY~N, former half.

SaAbK *
SaAbK: see SabiY~N, first sentence. ― -b2- Also i. q. SaAHibu SabowapK [i. e. One who indulges in youthful folly, and amorous dalliance]. (TA.) ― -b3- Kureysh, (M,) or the Jews, (TA,) used to call the Companions of the Prophet SubaApN. (M, TA. [See SaAbiy^N, in art. SbA^.]) And Náfi' read [in the Kur ii. 59 and xxii. 17] AlS~aAbiyna instead of AlS~aAbiy^iyna; (TA;) and [in v. 73] AlS~aAbiyuwna instead of AlS~aAbiy^uwna. (TA voce SaAbiy^N.) ― -b4- Sub~aY, a pl. of SaAbK, is expl. as meaning Those who incline to conflicts and factions, seditions, or the like, and love to be foremost therein. (TA. [See Sub~N, in art. Sb.])

AlS~aAbiyapu *
AlS~aAbiyapu The oblique wind (Aln~ukayobaA='u, dim. of Aln~akobaA='u,) that blows in a direction between that of the east or easterly wind (AlS~abaA) and that of the
north or northerly wind (Al$~amaAl): (S, K:) it is very cold, (S and TA voce nakobaA='u,) and very boisterous, and unattended by rain or by any good. (TA ibid.)

A^uSayobiyapN *
A^uSayobiyapN: see SabiY~N.

muSobK *
muSobK, (Ks, Az, M,) or muSobiyapN, (S, A,) or both, (K,) applied to a woman, (Ks, Az, S, M, A, K,) and the former also applied to a man, (Er-Rághib, TA,) Having Siboyap [i. e. children, or young children, or young unweaned children], (S, Er-Rághib, A, *) or having a child such as is termed SabiY~. (M, K.) ― -b2- Hence the latter is metaphorically applied by El-Hareeree to (tropical:) Wine of which the sealed cover has been broken. (Har p. 450.) ― -b3- [See also the verb, 4.]

maSobuw~N *
maSobuw~N: see SaAbiy^N, in art. SbA^.

muSaAbiyapN *
muSaAbiyapN A calamity, or misfortune. (K.)

1 SaH~a *
1. SaH~a, (S, A, MA, Msb, K,) aor.
SaHi3a
(MA, Msb, K) and
SaHa3a
, (MA,) inf. n. SiH~apN (S, * A, * MA, Msb, * MF, TA) and SuH~N, (S, * K, * MF, TA,) two forms of the inf. n. of which there are some other exs., as qil~apN and qul~N, and *il~apN and *ul~N, (MF, TA,) and SaHaAHN also, (K, * TA, * TK,) [like salaAmN &c.,] He was, or became, healthy, or sound; (MA;) or restored to health, or soundness, mino Eil~atihi [from his disease]; (S, A;) as also AstSH~↓: (S:) or his disease departed. (K, TK.) And (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, [or proved,] sound, valid, (MA,) [substantial, real, sure, certain,] true, right, (MA, Msb,) correct, just or proper, whole or entire, (MA,) or [unmarred, or unimpaired,] free from every imperfection or defect or fault or blemish, (L, K, TA,) and from everything that would occasion doubt or suspicion or evil opinion: (L, TA:) and (tropical:) it was, or became, suitable to the case, or event. (Msb.) You say, SaH~ato $ahaAdatuhu (tropical:) [His testimony was sound, valid, &c.]. (A, TA.) And SaH~a qawoluhu (tropical:) [His saying was, or proved, true]. (A, TA.) And SaH~a Einoda AlqaADiY Haq~uhu (tropical:) [His right, or due, or just claim, was, or became, established, substantiated, made good, or verified, in the estimation of the judge; like vabata]. (A, TA.) And SaH~a lahu Ealayohi ka*aA (tropical:) [Such a thing became established, or verified, as due to him from him; like vabata]. (A, TA.) And SaH~a AlEaqodu (tropical:) The contract became established by its execution. (Msb,) And SaH~ati AlS~alaApu, as used by the lawyers, (tropical:) The prayer [was suitable to the ordinance thereof, so that it] annulled the obligation of performing it after the appointed time. (Msb, * and Dict. of Techn. Terms of the Mussalmans pp. 815-816. [This meaning is expressed in the former by the phrase A^asoqaTati AlqaDaA='a; which is fully expl. in the latter work, with other conventional meanings of SiH~apN, all reducible to explanations given above.] ＝ -A2- SaH~a Al$~aYo'a [if not a mistranscription for A^aSaH~a or SaH~aHa] signifies (assumed tropical:) He made the thing SaHiyH [i. e. sound, valid, &c.]. (L, TA. [In the latter app. taken from the former.])

2 SH~Hhu *
2. SH~Hhu, [inf. n. taSoHiyHN,] He rendered him healthy, sound, or free from disease; (S, A, MA, TA;) said of God; (S, TA;) and (A, TA) so ASH~hu↓. (A, K, TA.) One says, A@ll~`hu badanaka A^aSaH~a↓, and SaH~aHa jisomaka, May God render thy body healthy, sound, or free from disease. (A.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) He rendered it sound, valid, (MA,) [substantial, real, sure, certain,] true, right, (MA, Msb,) just or proper, whole or entire, (MA,) [or free from every imperfection or defect or fault or blemish, and from everything that would occasion doubt or suspicion or evil opinion: see 1.] You say, SaH~aHotu AlkitaAba, and AlHisaAba, (assumed tropical:) I corrected the book, or writing, and the reckoning; rectified what was wrong thereof. (L, TA.) And SH~H baraA='atahu [He verified his being free from a thing; clear, quit, or guiltless, of it; or irresponsible for it]. (Mgh in art. brA^.)

4. ASH~hu: see 2, in two places. ― -b2- Also He found him to be SaHiyH [or healthy, sound, or free from disease]; namely, a man. (L, TA.) ＝ -A2- And ASH~ He had his family and his cattle in a healthy, or sound, state; (L, K;) whether he himself were in health or sick: (L:) or, said of a people, or party, they had their cattle in a healthy, or sound, state, after they had been affected by a plague, or murrain, or distemper. (S, L.)

5. tSH~H bihi [He was rendered healthy, or sound, by it]. (O and TA voce $ayoEapN, q. v.)

10: see 1, first sentence. ＝ -A2- One says also, A^anaA A^asotaSiH~u maA taquwlu (tropical:) [I hold to be true, right, or just, what thou sayest]. (TA.)

R. Q. 1 SaHoSaHa *
R. Q. 1. SaHoSaHa It (a thing, or an affair,) was, or became, distinct, apparent, or manifest; (K;) like HaSoHaSa. (TA.)

SuH~N *
SuH~N: see the next paragraph, in two places.

SiH~apN *
SiH~apN (S, A, MA, O, K) and SuH~N↓ (S, * O, K) and SaHaAHN↓ (O, K) [all app. inf. ns., of SaH~a, q. v.; and used as simple substs. meaning] Health, or soundness of body; (S, A, MA, O;) contr. of suqomN or saqamN: (S, A, O:) or departure of disease: (K:) SiH~apN is said to be in the body and in religion; like as are [its contrs.] maraDN and suqomN: (Aboo-Is-hák, TA in art. mrD:) in the body, it is a natural state or condition, wherewith the actions [and functions] of the body have the natural course: and it is metaphorically used in relation to [other things, including] attributes, or ideal things: (Msb:) and signifies [a sound, valid, substantial, real, sure, certain, true, right, correct, just or proper, whole or entire, state or condition; as is indicated in the first paragraph of this art.; or] freedom from every imperfection or defect or fault or blemish, (L, K, TA,) and from everything that would occasion doubt or suspicion or evil opinion. (L, TA.) One says, A^awoSaY fiY SiH~atihi wa$iH~atihi. (K in art. $H, q. v.) And wasuqomihi kaAna *`lika fiY SuH~ihi↓ [That was in his state of health, or soundness, and his illness, or sickness]. (AO, S.) And mina maA A^aqoraba AlS~aHaAHa↓ Als~aqaAmi [How little removed is health, or soundness, from illness, or sickness!]. (O.)
