SaHaAHN: see SiH~apN, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see SaHiyHN, in four places. ― -b2- SaHaAHu AlT~ariyqi means (assumed tropical:) The hard part of the road, that has not been rendered soft, or plain, (K, TA,) nor smooth, or easy to walk or ride upon. (TA.)

SuHaAHN *
SuHaAHN: see the next paragraph.

SaHiyHN *
SaHiyHN (S, A, MA, Msb, K, KL) and SaHaAHN↓ (S, A, Msb, K) Healthy, sound, or free from disease; (S, A, MA, K, KL;) and so SaHiyHu Aljasadi, applied to a man: (Msb:) and (assumed tropical:) sound, valid, (MA, KL,) [substantial, real, sure, certain,] true, right, (MA, KL, and Msb in explanation of the former word,) correct, just or proper, whole or entire, (MA, KL,) or [unmarred, or unimpaired,] free from every imperfection or defect or fault or blemish, (L, K, TA,) and from everything that would occasion doubt or suspicion or evil opinion: (L, TA:) [and (assumed tropical:) suitable to the case, or event: (see 1:)] fem. SaHiyHapN, applied to a woman [and to other things]: (TA:) pl. SaHaAHN, (A, Msb, K,) a pl. of SaHiyHN, (Msb,) and applied to men [and other things], (A, K, TA,) and of SaHiyHapN, and applied to women, (TA,) and A^aSiH~aA='u, (A, Msb, K,) a pl. of SaHiyHN, (Msb,) and applied to men, (A, K,) and A^aSiH~apN, likewise applied to men, (A,) and SaHaAy^iHu, (K,) a pl. of SaHiyHapN, and applied to women. (TA.) SaHiyHu AlA^adiymi means [lit. Sound of skin; or] not [having the skin] cut; as also SaHaAHu↓ AlA^adiymi: (S:) [but each has a tropical signification; for] one says, fulaAnN SaHiyHu AlA^adiymi (Ham p. 628) meaning (tropical:) [Such a one is sound] in respect of origin, and of honour, or reputation. (Har p. 135.) And dirohamN SaHiyHN means A dirhem free from defect; as also SaHaAHN↓; and SuHaAHN↓, [which I find as syn. with SaHiyHN in my copy of the K,] with damm, is allowable, like TuwaAlN as syn. with TawiylN. (L, TA.) And it is said in a trad., yuqaAsimu A@bonu A=dama A^ahola Aln~aAri qisomapF SaHaAHFA↓ i. e. The son of Adam, meaning Kábeel [or Cain], who slew his brother Hábeel [or Abel], will make a right division with the people of Hell, so that half of it shall be for him, and half for them. (L, TA.)

SaHoSaHN *
SaHoSaHN (S, L, Msb, K) and SaHoSaAHN↓ and SaHoSaHaAnN↓ (S, L, K) A place, (S, Msb,) or ground, or land, (L, K,) that is plain, or even,
(S, L, Msb, K,) destitute of herbage: pl. of the first SaHaASiHu: (L:) and the first signifies a tract of land destitute of herbage, plain, or even, and containing small pebbles: (L:) or a smooth tract of land: (R, MF:) and A^aroDN SaHaASiHu and SaHoSaHaAnN↓ a land destitute of everything, containing no trees, nor any depressed resting-place for water, said by AM to be seldom found except in the rising ground of a valley, or in a mountain near to such rising ground, and not so plain as what is termed SaHoraA='. (L.) ― -b2- [Hence, app., (see art. trh,)] tur~ahaAtN SaHaASiHu, and tur~ahaAtu SaHaASiHa, [the latter preferred by J, as he says in the S,] (tropical:) What is vain, or false; (S, K, TA;) like tr~hAt basaAbis: (S:) or [rather] vain, false, untrue things, that have no foundation. (TA.)

SuHoSuHN *
SuHoSuHN and SuHoSuwHN↓ One who pursues, or investigates, minute things, and retains them in his memory (yuHoSiyhaA), and knows them. (K.)

SaHoSaAHN *
SaHoSaAHN: see SaHoSaHN.

SuHoSuwHN *
SuHoSuwHN: see SuHoSuHN.

SaHoSaHaAnN *
SaHoSaHaAnN: see SaHoSaHN, in two places.

muSiH~N *
muSiH~N A man having his family and his cattle in a healthy, or sound, state; whether he himself be in health or sick: (L:) or having his cattle in a healthy, or sound, state, after their having been affected by a plague, or murrain, or distemper: pl. muSiH~uwna. (S, L.) It is said in a trad., laA yuwridan~a *uw EaAhapK EalaY muSiH~K (S, L) i. e. One whose camels are affected by a murrain, or distemper, shall by no means bring them to water immediately after one whose camels are in a healthy, or sound, state, so as to water the former beasts with the latter: a prohibition apparently given for fear that the latter beasts should become diseased like the former, and it should be supposed that the disease had passed by contagion, which ought not to be imagined. (L. [See also mumoriDN.])

maSaH~apN *
maSaH~apN A cause of one's being rendered healthy, or sound in body. (L, K.) So in the saying, AlS~awomu maSaH~apN [Fasting is a cause of one's being rendered healthy]. (L, K.) One says also, Als~afaru maSaH~apN [Travel is a cause of one's becoming healthy]. (S, A.) And A^aroDN maSaH~apN A land free from plagues, or any common, or epidemic, diseases; in which maladies are not common or frequent. (TA.)

muSaHoSiHN *
muSaHoSiHN True, sincere, or honest, in love, or affection. (K.) And it is also said to signify Counselling, or admonishing, or one who counsels or admonishes, faithfully, or sincerely: so in a verse of Meleeh El-Hudhalee; as though used by poetic license for muSaH~iHN. (L.) ＝ -A2- And (tropical:) One who does, or says, vain, or false, things. (A, K.)

1 SaHibahu *
1. SaHibahu, aor.
SaHaba
, inf. n. SuHobapN (S, A, Msb, K, &c.) and SaHaAbapN (S, A, K) and SiHaAbapN, (K,) He associated, kept company, or consorted, with him; (A, K;) [he accompanied him;] he was, or became, his companion, associate, comrade, fellow, friend, or fellow-traveller: (MA:) and SAHbhu↓ signifies the same. (TA. [See this latter verb below.]) ― -b2- [Hence] one says, SaHibaka A@ll~`hu and SaAHabaka↓, (A, TA,) [inf. n. of the former (in the TA inadvertently said to be of the latter) SiHaAbapN, (said in the TA to be with kesr,) or SaHaAbapN, and, as will be shown by what follows, SuHobapN also,] (tropical:) May God guard, keep, protect, or defend, thee; may God be thy guardian, keeper, &c.: (TA in explanation of the former:) and A^aHosana A@ll~`hu SaHaAbataka (A, and Ham p. 443) or SiHaAbataka (TA) (tropical:) [May God make the guarding, &c., of thee to be good]. And (TA) [in like manner,] fulaAnFA ASHb↓ signifies (assumed tropical:) He guarded, kept, or protected, such a one; as also ASTHbhu↓: and he defended such a one; syn. manaEahu: (K, TA:) one says, biSuHobapK Aall~`hum~a A^aSoHibonaA↓ waA^aqolibonaA bi*im~apK (assumed tropical:) O God, guard us with thy guarding in our journey, and make us to return with thy safeguard to our country, or land, &c.; occurring in a trad.: (TA:) and walaA humo min~aA yuSoHabuwna↓, (A, TA,) in the Kur [xxi. 44], (TA,) means (tropical:) Nor shall they (i. e. the unbelievers, TA) be defended from us, (A, TA,) as expl. by Zj; (TA;) and preserved in safety: (A:) or, accord. to Katádeh, nor shall they be attended by good from us: or, as some say, it is from the phrase SaHibaka A@ll~`hu meaning as expl. above. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 4, last sentence but one. ＝ -A2- SaHaba, aor.
SaHaba
, (K,) inf. n. SaHobN, (TK,) He skinned a slaughtered animal. (K.)

3 SAHbhu *
3. SAHbhu, (MA,) inf. n. duSaAHabapN, (KL,) i. q. SaHibahu; (TA;) He associated, kept company, or consorted, with him. (MA, KL.) See 1, first and second sentences. ― -b2- And see the next paragraph, last sentence but one.

4 A^aSoHabotuhu qulaAnFA *
4. A^aSoHabotuhu qulaAnFA [I made such a one to be a companion, or an associate, to him]. (A.) And A^aSoHabotuhu Al$~aYo'a (tropical:) I made the thing to be [as it were] a companion to him; (S, K, TA;) and so AstSHbthu↓; as in the saying, AstSHbth AlkitaAba wagayorahu (tropical:) I made the book, or writing, &c., to be [as it were] his companion. (S, * TA.) ― -b2- And ASHbhu (tropical:) He did to him that which caused him to be a companion, or an associate, to him. (A, TA.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) He left upon it, namely, a skin, its hair, (S, A,) or its wool; not subjecting it to the process termed EaTonN. (S.) ― -b4- See also 1, in three places. ＝ -A2- ASHb, intrans., He (a man) became one having a companion, or an associate: (K, TA: [in the latter said to be tropical; but, I think, without reason:]) and he was, or became, one having companions, or associates. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence,] (tropical:) He (a man) had a son who had attained to manhood (S, A, TA) and so become like him: (TA;) i. e. he was alone, and became one having a companion; (A;) or as though his son became his companion. (TA.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) He (a camel, and a horse or similar beast, S, TA, or an animal, and a man to a man, A, TA *) became tractable, submissive, or obsequious, after being refractory, or incompliant; (S, A, TA;) [and so SaAHaba↓, as is implied by an explanation of its part. n. muSaAHibN; and AstSHb↓, for] hence, (A,) one says also, AisotaSoEaba tum~a A@sotaSoHaba (tropical:) [He was refractory, or incompliant: then he became tractable, submissive, or obsequious]: (A, TA:) and accord. to A 'Obeyd, one says, SaHibotu↓ Alr~ajula, from AlS~uHobapu, and A^aSoHabotu [app. ASHbt lahu], meaning (assumed tropical:) I became tractable, submissive, or obsequious, to the man. (TA.) ― -b4- And, said of water, (tropical:) It became overspread with [the green substance termed] TuHolub. (S, A. *)

5 yataSaH~abu min~aA *
5. yataSaH~abu min~aA (assumed tropical:) He is ashamed, or bashful, with respect to us; or shy of us; (K, TA;) i. e. he is ashamed to sit with us, or shy of sitting with us. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA.) And fulaAnN maA yataSaH~abu mino $aYo'K (tropical:) Such a one does not guard himself against anything, and is not ashamed to do it, or shy of doing it, does not shun it, or avoid it. (A.)

6 taSaAoHaba
6: see the next paragraph, in two places.

8 ASTHbwA *
8. ASTHbwA, (S, A, K,) originally AStHbwA, (S,) They associated, kept company, or consorted, one with another; (S, A, K;) as also tSAHbwA↓: (A:) and in like manner ASTHbA and tSAHbA↓ said of two men. (TA.) ＝ -A2- ASTHbhu: see 1.

10 AstSHbhu *
10. AstSHbhu He desired him, or demanded him, as a companion, an associate, a comrade, or a friend: (MA:) or he invited him to associate, keep company, or consort, with him: and he clave to him: (A, K:) [he chose him, or took him, as a companion, &c.: and] he had him with him. (MA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, AisotaSoHabotu kitaAbFA liY (tropical:) [I made a book a companion to me; or I made a book belonging to me my companion]. (A, L, TA.) And AisotaSoHabotu AlkitaAba wagayorahu (assumed tropical:) I carried the book &c. with me. (Msb.) And one says of anything, AstSHbhu as meaning (assumed tropical:) It clave, adhered, or held-fast, to it; namely, another thing; (IF, S, Msb, TA;) or coalesced, or united, with it. (S, TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce raAmikN.] ― -b3- See also 4, second sentence: ＝ -A2- and see the last sentence but one of the same paragraph.

SaHobN *
SaHobN: see SaAHibN.

SuHobapN *
SuHobapN an inf. n. of SaHibahu [q. v.]. (S, A, Msb, K, &c.) ― -b2- [As a simple subst., Companionship. Hence, lahu SuHobapN, often occurring in biographies as meaning He had companionship with the Prophet; i. e. he was one of the Companions of the Prophet. And xarajotu SuHobapa Alr~asuwli, frequently occurring in trads., meaning I went forth in the companionship of the Apostle, or in company with the Apostle. Hence also] one says, Hamalotu AlkitaAba SuHobatiY (assumed tropical:) [I carried the book with me]. (Msb.) SuHobapu Als~afiynapi [The companionship of the ship] is a post-classical phrase, denoting, by way of comparison, that which has no permanence. (Har p. 258.) ― -b3- See also SaAHibN, of which it is a quasipl. n.

SaHaAbapN *
SaHaAbapN an inf. n. of SaHibahu [q. v.]. (S, A, K.)
― -b2- See also SaAHibN, of which it is a quasi-pl. n. [AlS~aHaAbapu is commonly applied to The Companions of the Prophet:] SaHaAbiY~N↓ [is the n. un., meaning a Companion of the Prophet; and] is conventionally applied to one who saw Mohammad, and whose companionship with him was long, even if he have not related anything from him; or, as some say, even if his companionship with him was not long. (KT.)

SaHaAbiY~N *
SaHaAbiY~N: see the next preceding paragraph.

SaAHibN *
SaAHibN A companion, an associate, a comrade, a fellow, or a friend; (A, MA, KL, TA;) a fellow-traveller: (MA:) [an accomplice: (assumed tropical:) an accompanier, or attendant, as applied to a thing:] and (tropical:) a lord, or master; a possessor, an owner, an occupant, a haver, or a proprietor; of anything: (A, TA:) it is not trans. like the verb, therefore you may not say, zayodN SaAHibN EamorFA; (TA;) [i. e.] it is not used as an act. part. n., but as a subst., like waAlidN; (Ham p. 32:) the pl., (S, Msb,) or term applied to a pl. number, (A, K, TA,) is SaHobN↓, (S, A, Msb, K,) a pl. like rakobN of raAkibN, (S,) or [rather] a quasi-pl. n., (TA,) and A^aSoHaAbN, [the most common of all,] (A, Msb,) a pl. like A^a$ohaAdN of $aAhidN, (TA,) or pl. of SaHobN, like A^aforaAxN of faroxN, (S,) and A^aSaAHiybu, (S, K,) pl. of A^aSoHaAbN, (S,) and SuHobaAnN, (S, K,) a pl. like $ub~aAnN of $aAb~N, (S,) and SiHaAbN, (S, A, K,) a pl. like jiyaAEN of jaAy^iEN, (S,) and SiHaAbapN, (A, K,) in which the p may be regarded, agreeably with analogy, as an affix to the pl. SiHaAbN characteristic of the fem. gender, (TA,) and SaHaAbapN↓, (S, A, Msb, K,) which is more common than SiHaAbapN, (TA,) but the only instance of faEaAlapN as the pl. measure of a word of the measure faAEilN, (L, TA,) or originally an inf. n., (S,) or not so, but a quasi-pl. n., though written like the inf. n. [that is said to be its original], (from a marginal note in a copy of the S,) and SuHobapN↓, (S, A,) a pl. like furohapN of faArihN, (S, TA,) or [rather] a quasi-pl. n.: (TA:) the fem. is SaAHibapN, and its pl. is SawaAHibu and SawaAHibaAtN, (Mgh, Msb,) the latter mentioned by AAF on the authority of Abu-l- Hasan: (TA:) hence, in a trad. of 'Áïsheh, A^anotun~a SawaAHibu yuwsufa [Ye are the female companions, or the mistresses, of Joseph; meaning, enticers to lewdness]; or, as some relate it, SawaAHibaAtu yuwsufa: (Mgh:) the dim. of SaAHibN is SuwayoHibN↓ (A) [and that of SaAHibahN is SuwayoHibapN↓]. yaASaAHi for yaASaAHibiY [O my companion, &c.,] is the only allowable instance of such curtailing of a prefixed noun, related as heard from the Arabs. (S, TA.) One says, fulaAnN SaAHibu SidoqK [Such a one is a good companion, &c.]. (A, * TA.) [And SaAHibu jayo$i The commander of an army. And SaAHibu Albariydi and SaAHibu Al$~uroTapi &c.: see arts. brd and $rT &c. And AlS~aAHibu, alone, in post-classical times applied to The Wezeer, when an officer of the pen: see De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., sec. ed., ii. 59.] And SaAHibu Alyamiyni [The companion of the right hand] and SaAHibu Al$~imaAli [The companion of the left hand]; appellations of each man's recording angels, who write down his good and evil actions. (A trad. thus commencing in the Jámi' es-Sagheer.) And SaAHibu AlS~uwri (assumed tropical:) The angel who is the possessor of the horn. (Idem.) [And SaAHibu bayotK (assumed tropical:) The owner, or master, of a house or tent.] And A^aSoHaAbu Aljan~api (assumed tropical:) [The inmates, or occupants, of Paradise]: (Kur ii. 76, &c.:) and A^aSoHaAbu Aln~aAri (assumed tropical:) [The inmates, &c., of the fire of Hell]. (Kur ii. 37, &c.) And SaAHibu sijonK (assumed tropical:) An inmate of a prison. (Bd and Jel in xii. 39.) And SaAHibu AlS~af~i waAljumoEapi (assumed tropical:) He who keeps to praying in the first rank and to the prayer of Friday. (El-Munáwee on a trad. thus commencing in the Jámi' es-Sagheer.) And A^aSojaAbu Al$~aAfiEiY~i (tropical:) The followers of the persuasion of EshSháfi'ee: and in like manner one says of the followers of other persuasions. (Msb.) [And SaAHibu kitaAbK (assumed tropical:) The author of a book.] And SaAHibu EilomK wamaAlK (tropical:) A possessor of science and of wealth. (A, TA.) And SaAHibu witorK (assumed tropical:) [One who has a claim for blood-revenge: see an ex. in a verse cited voce dar~aAkN]. (Keys Ibn-Rifá'ah, TA in art. drk.) [And SaAHibu A^amorK wanahoYK (assumed tropical:) One who possesses authority to command and to forbid. And SaAHibu A^amorK also signifies (assumed tropical:) The author of an affair or event or action; the doer of a thing; the manager, or disposer, thereof: and one who keeps, or adheres, to a thing. And SaAHibu dayonK (assumed tropical:) A debtor.] And one says, xaraja waSaAHibaAhu Als~ayofu waAlr~umoHu (tropical:) [He went forth, the sword and the spear being his companions]. (A, TA.)

SuwayoHibN *
SuwayoHibN and suwayoHibapN dims. of SaAHibN and SaAHibapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

A^aSoHabu *
A^aSoHabu i. q. A^aSoHaru, (S, K,) Of a colour inclining to redness: applied to an ass [app. to a wild ass]. (S, TA.)

muSoHabN *
muSoHabN [properly Made to have a companion. ― -b2- And hence,] (assumed tropical:) A man possessed by a jinnee or demon; a demoniac; or insane. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- See also muSoHibN. ― -b4- And (tropical:) A skin, or hide, (A, K,) or a [skin such as is termed] ziq~, (S,) having its hair remaining upon it, (S, A, K,) or its wool, or its fur; (K;) and maSoHuwbN↓ signifies the same. (A.) Hence, qirobapN muSoHabapN (K, TA) (tropical:) A water-skin that has somewhat of its wool [or hair] remaining upon it, and that has not been subjected to the process termed EaTonN. (TA.) ― -b5- And (tropical:) A branch, or stick, that has not been stripped of its bark, or peel. (TA.)

muSoHibN *
muSoHibN [properly Having a companion. ― -b2- And hence,] A man having a son that has attained to manhood, and become like him. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) One who talks to himself; and so, sometimes, muSoHabN↓. (K, TA.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) Tractable, submissive, or obsequious, after being refractory, or incompliant; (K;) as also muSaAHibN↓, (A, K,) and musotaSoHibN↓. (TA. [See also the next paragraph.]) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) Going straight on, or right on, without delay. (K.)

huwa miSoHaAbN lanaA bimaA nuHib~u *
huwa miSoHaAbN lanaA bimaA nuHib~u (assumed tropical:) He is [very] submissive, or compliant, to us in that which we like. (K.) [See also muSoHibN.]

maSoHuwbN *
maSoHuwbN [Associated with, or accompanied]. ― -b2- [Hence,] one says [to a person departing], AimoDi maSoHuwbFA (tropical:) Go thou, kept in safety, preserved from harm; and [so] muSaAHabFA↓: (A, TA:) and [in like manner,] in bidding farewell, muEaAfFA muSaAHabFA↓ (tropical:) [Be thou kept in safety or health, preserved from harm]: and a poet says,
waSaAHibiY mino dawaAEiY Als~uwo'i muSoTaHabu↓
(assumed tropical:) [And my companion is preserved, or defended, from the causes of evil]. (TA.) ― -b3- See also muSoHabN.

muSaAHabN *
muSaAHabN: see maSoHuwbN, in two places.

muSaAHibN *
muSaAHibN: see muSoHibN.

muSoTaHabN *
muSoTaHabN: see maSoHuwbN.

musotaSoHibN *
musotaSoHibN: see muSoHibN.

1 SaHarahu *
1. SaHarahu, aor.
SaHara
, (S, K,) inf. n. SaHorN, (S, TA,) namely, milk, He made it to become what is termed SaHiyrap: (S, TA:) or he cooked it, (K, TA,) and then gave it to a sick person to drink. (TA.) ― -b2- SaHaratohu Al$~amosu The sun pained his brain: (K:) it is like Saharatohu; (A;) or, as some say, melted him. (TA.) ＝ -A2- SaHara, aor.
SaHara
, inf. n. SaHiyrN and SuHaArN, He (an ass) uttered a sound [or braying] more vehement than the neighing of horses. (TA.) ＝ -A3- [Golius explains SaHara as meaning It spread out wide, said of a place, on the authority of J: but the verb is ASHr, q. v.; and the authority is not J.]

3 SaAoHara
3: [SiHaArN is an inf. n. of SaAHara, a verb not mentioned: hence,] A^aboraza lahu maA fiY nafosihi mina AlA^amori SiHaAraA (assumed tropical:) [He showed to him what was in his mind, of the thing, or affair, openly]: a saying like jaAharahu bihi jihaArFA. (K, * TA. [See also 4.])

4 ASHr *
4. ASHr, (S, A, Mgh, K,) or ASHr AlS~aHoraA='a, (Msb, [but I think that this is a mistake for ASHr A_ilaY AlS~aHoraA='i,]) inf. n. A_iSoHaArN, (Msb,) He went forth to the SHrA=' [or desert, &c.], (S, A, Mgh,) or into the SHrA=': (Msb, K:) tSH~r [in this sense] has not been heard. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Hence, in a trad., the saying of Umm-Selemeh to 'Áïsheh, sak~ana A@ll~`hu EuqayoraAki falaA tuSoHiriyhaA [app. meaning, accord. to explanations of it in the TA in art. Eqr, God hath made thy dwelling and estate, or, as Z explains it, thy person (nafosaki), to be quietly settled, therefore do not thou remove it forth to the desert]; i. e. laA tuboriziyhaA A_ilaY AlS~aHoraA='i; the verb, accord. to IAth, being made trans. by
the suppression of the prep.; [i. e. tuSoHiriyhaA being for tuSoHiriY bihaA;] for it is [properly] intrans. (TA. [See also the next sentence but one, in which the verb is tropically made trans.]) ― -b3- A^aSoHiro liEaduw~ika means (assumed tropical:) Be thou in a state of clearness [or certainty] with respect to the case of thy enemy: (JM, TA:) occurring in a trad. of 'Alee. (TA.) ― -b4- One says also, A^aSoHara biAlA^amori and A^aSoHarahu (tropical:) He revealed, or made manifest, the affair, or case: and laA tuSoHiro A^amoraka (tropical:) [Reveal not thy affair, or case]: and A^aSoHirohu bimaA fiY qalobika (tropical:) [Reveal to him what is in thy mind]. (A, TA.) ― -b5- ASHr said of a place, It was, or became, wide, or spacious; (O, K, TA;) i. e. it became like the SaHoraA='. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Said of a man, He was, or became, blind of one eye. (K.)

11 ASHAr~ *
11. ASHAr~ It (a plant) dried up; or became yellow; or dried up and became yellow: (S:) or became of a dingy red colour, and then dried up and became yellow: (TA:) and (TA) it (a plant, K, or an ear of corn, TA) became red: or its first parts became white. (K, TA.)

SiHorN *
SiHorN an imitative sequent to SiforN [q. v.]. (Kh, Ham p. 354.)

SaHarN *
SaHarN: see SuHorapN.

laqiytupu SaHorapa baHorapa *
laqiytupu SaHorapa baHorapa, in which the two nouns are imperfectly decl., (S, L,) being regarded as one, (L,) and SaHorapF baHorapF, (K in art. bHr,) and buHorapa SuHorapa↓, with damm, (O,) and SuHorapF buHorapF, (MF in art. bHr,) and SaHorapF baHorapF naHorapF, (O, K,) and SaHorapa baHorapa naHorapa, (K, [but this last is implicitly disallowed in the O, and expressly by MF in art. bHr,]) and with damm also in all these words, [i. e. SuHorap &c.,] (K,) I met him openly, or in open view, nothing intervening to conceal him. (S, L, K. [See also baHorapN; and see SaroHapN.]) And one says likewise, A^axobarahu biAlA^amori SHrp bHrp [He acquainted him with the affair, or case, openly]. (TA.)

SuHorapN *
SuHorapN (S, K, in the CK, SuHarapN [which is a mistake,]) and SaHarN↓ (K [in some copies of the K SaHorN, which, as observed in the TA, is wrong,]) A colour in which is [the kind of red termed] $uqorapN: (S:) or a colour nearly the same as [the kind of red termed] SubohapN: (K:) or the latter, (TA, [and app. the former also,]) a dust-colour with a slight redness, (in the K, in Humorap xafiy~ap, the latter of these two words is a mistake for xafiyfap, TA,) inclining to a little whiteness: (K, TA:) or the former, redness inclining to dustcolour: (TA:) or dust-colour with redness: (A:) and [redness of the kind termed] $uqorap in the head: (As, TA:) and both words, a colour in which is whiteness and redness: (TA:) and whiteness overspreading blackness; like suHorapN and saHarN: (TA in art. sHr:) and the latter, accord. to Sgh, whiteness. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, both words, The quality of a SaHoraA=' [q. v.]. (ISh.) ― -b2- And the former, A clear space in a [stony tract such as is called] Har~ap, (S, K,) consisting of soft and clean soil with stones in it: (TA:) pl. SuHarN; (S, K;) the only pl. (TA.) ― -b3- See also SaHorap.

SaHoraA='u *
SaHoraA='u, imperfectly decl., (S, K,) though not an epithet; (S;) or it is an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates; (TA;) and is imperfectly decl. because it is of the fem. gender, (S,) and because the letter characteristic of the fem. gender [namely the long A] is inseparable from it, (S, K,) A desert; a waste; syn. bar~iy~apN: (S, Msb:) or a tract of land like the back of a beast, bare, or destitute of herbage, without trees and without hills and without mountains; smooth [throughout]: (ISh:) or a plain, or level tract of land, with smoothness and ruggedness, (A, K,) less [rugged] than what is termed quf~: (K:) or a spacious tract of ground in which is no herbage: (M, A, K:) or the most plain and even of land, whether it have produced herbage or not, not having any mountain or hill near it; as also jahaAdN: (ISh, TA in art. jhd:) you say SaHoraA='u waAsiEapN [a wide desert &c.]; (S;) but you do not say SaHoraA='apN, adding one fem. sign after another: (S, Msb:) the pls. are SaHaAriY~u (S, Msb, K) and SaHaArK (S, M, Msb) [in the K, SaHaAriY, which, without the art. Al, and except when it is prefixed to another noun, and in a case of pausing, is a manifest mistake, as is shown in every complete treatise on inflection,] and SaHaAraY (S, Msb, K) and SaHoraAwaAtN: (S, K:) the first of which four pls. occurs in poetry, and is the original form of the second: for when you form the pl. of SaHoraA='u, [which is originally SaHoraAA,] you introduce an A between the H and the r, and give kesr to the r as in all similar cases: then the first A which is after the r [in SHrAA] is changed into Y, because of the kesreh preceding it; and the second A, which is the characteristic of the fem. gender, is also changed into Y, and incorporated into the former: then they reject the first Y, and change the second into A, [though still writing it Y,] and say SaHaAraY, with fet-h to the r, that the A may not be elided in the case of tenween, [which the word would have if the r were with kesr]; and this they do to distinguish between the Y that is changed from the A which is a characteristic of the fem. gender and the Y that is changed from the A which is not a characteristic of the fem. gender as the A of maromFY when they say maraAmK: some of the Arabs, however, do not reject the first Y [in SaHaAriY~u], but reject the second Y, and say AlS~aHaAriY, with kesr to the r, and h`*ihi SaHaArK, like as you say jawaArK (S. [In the Ham, p. 54, SuHarN is mentioned as a pl. of SaHoraA='u; but I think it doubtful.])

SuHaArN *
SuHaArN The sweat of horses: (O, K:) or the fever of horses. (K.) [ ― -b2- See also 1.]

SaHuwrN *
SaHuwrN: see A^aSoHaru.

SaHiyrN *
SaHiyrN A certain uttering of the voice of the ass, (A, K,) of a vehement kind, (A,) more vehement than the neighing of horses: an inf. n. (TA. [See 1.])

SaHiyrapN *
SaHiyrapN Milk into which heated stones are thrown, so that it boils, after which some clarified butter is poured upon it, and it is drunk; and sometimes some flour is sprinkled upon it, and then it is supped: or, accord. to Abu-l-Gheyth, it is called SaxiyrapN, from AlS~axoru; like fahiyrapN, from Alfihoru: (S:) or fresh milk into which heated stones are thrown, or which is put in the cooking-pot and made to boil in it once, until it burns; and sometimes flour is put into it, and sometimes clarified butter: (TA:) or fresh milk which is made to boil, after which some clarified butter is poured upon it, (K,) and it is drunk: (TA:) or fresh milk which is heated until it burns: (A:) or pure milk of camels, or of sheep, or of goats, which, when they want soup, and have not flour, it not being found in their land, they cook, and then give to drink to a sick person, hot. (TA.)

vawobN SuHaAriY~N *
vawobN SuHaAriY~N A kind of garment, so called in relation to SuHaAr, a town of El-Yemen: or, as some say, of the colour termed SuHorap, like A^aSoHaru↓. (TA, from a trad.)

SuHayoraA='u *
SuHayoraA='u A certain sort of milk: (K:) so says Kr, without particularizing it. (TA.)

A^aSoHaru *
A^aSoHaru Of the colour termed SuHorap: (S, K:) or similar to A^aSobaHN: (As:) a man of a red colour inclining to dust-colour: (TA:) or having a colour such as is termed $uqorap upon his head: (As:) and an ass in which is a red colour: (S:) or of a dust-colour with redness: (A:) or in which is whiteness and redness; (TA;) and so SaHuwrN↓ applied to a she-ass; or this signifies wont to kick with her hind leg: (K, TA:) fem. SaHoraA='u: (S, TA:) and pl. SuHorN. (TA.) See also SuHaAriY~N. ― -b2- AlA^aSoHaru and AlmuSoHiru↓ The lion. (Sgh, K.)

AlmuSoHiru *
AlmuSoHiru: see what next precedes.

muSaAHirN *
muSaAHirN One who fights with his adversary in the desert (AlS~aHoraA='), and does not act deceitfully with him. (S.)

2 taSoHiyfN *
2. taSoHiyfN signifies (primarily, Msb) The making a mistake (S, O, Msb, K, TA) in a SaHiyfap, (S, O, K, TA,) by reason of the ambiguity, or dubiousness, of the letters: a postclassical term: (TA:) or the reading a thing in a manner at variance with what the writer intended, or at variance with the conventional usage thereof: (Mgh:) a secondary signification is the altering a word, or an expression, in such a manner that the meaning intended by the application [thereof] becomes altered: (Msb:) or it consists in the altering of a diacritical point [or points]; as in AlnfY for AlnqY, or vice versâ: (KT, after Alt~aHoriyfu:) one says, SH~f All~afoZa He altered the word, or expression, [in such a manner that the meaning intended by the application thereof became altered, or] so that it became dubious [to the reader]. (Msb.) [See also taHoriyf, in the first paragraph of art. Hrf.]

4 A^uSoHifa *
4. A^uSoHifa It had SuHuf [i. e. written pieces of
paper or of skin] (S, O, K, TA) collected in it, (S, O,) or put in it (K, TA) between two boards. (TA.)

5 tSH~f *
5. tSH~f, said of a word, or an expression, It became altered [so as to have a meaning different from that intended by the application thereof, (see 2,) or] so as to be dubious. (Msb.) One says, tSH~f Ealayohi lafoZu ka*aA [Such a word, or such an expression, became altered so as to be dubious to him]. (O, K. *)

SaHofapN *
SaHofapN [A sort of bowl;] a vessel like the qaSoEapN, (S, ISd, O, Msb, K, * TA,) expanded, wide, (ISd, TA,) or a large, expanded qaSoEap, (Mgh,) or, accord. to Z, an oblong qaSoEap, (Msb,) that satisfies the hunger of five [men] (Ks, S, ISd, Mgh, O, TA) and the like of them: (ISd, TA:) Ks says, (S, O,) the largest sort of qaSoEap is the jafonap; next to which is the qaSoEap [properly so called], (S, O, K,) which satisfies the hunger of ten [men]; (S, O;) then, the SaHofap, (S, O, K,) which satisfies the hunger of five; (S, O;) then, the miy^okalap, (S, O, K,) which satisfies two men, and three; (S, O;) and then, the SuHayofap↓, (S, O, K,) which satisfies one man: (S, O:) the pl. of SaHofapN is SiHaAfN. (S, O, Mgh, Msb.) It is said in a prov., Aisotaforaga fulaAnN maA fiY SaHofatihi Such a one chose for himself, as his share, [or exhausted, all of] what was in his SHfp. (TA.)

SaHafiY~N *
SaHafiY~N One who makes mistakes in reading the SaHiyfap [or writing, or written piece of paper or of skin]; incorrectly termed by the vulgar SuHufiY~N, with two dammehs; (O, K;) [for the formation of a rel. n. from a pl. of this kind (i. e. from SuHufN) is not allowable,] though the pl. is not restored to the sing. in forming the rel. n. in the case of proper names, such as A^anomaAriY~N &c., nor in the case of words that are used in a manner like that of proper names, such as A^anoSaAriYN &c.: (O:) or a learner, or one who acquires knowledge, (Mgh, Msb,) from the SaHiyfap, (Mgh,) inferior [in rank] to the ma$aAyixi [pl. of $ayoxN]: (Msb:) a rel. n. from SaHiyfapN; (Mgh, Msb;) like HanafiY~N and bajaliY~N from Haniyfapu and bajiylapu: (Msb:) and muSaH~ifN↓ signifies the same as SaHafiY~N [in the former of these senses]. (TA.)

SiHaAfN *
SiHaAfN Small places that are made for water to collect and remain therein (manaAqiEu SigaArN tut~axa*u lilomaA='i): pl. SuHufN. (Esh-Sheybánee, O, K.)

SaHiyfN *
SaHiyfN [appears from what here follows, to be syn. with SaHiyfapN↓, or rather it is a coll. gen. n. of which the latter is the n. un.:] (tropical:) The surface of the ground or earth; (O, K, TA;) as being likened to the thing [i. e. paper or skin] that is written upon. (TA.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

SaHiyfapN *
SaHiyfapN A written piece of paper (MA, Mgh, Msb) or of skin; (Msb;) a writing, or thing written; a book, or volume; a letter, i. e. an epistle; syn. kitaAbN; (S, O, K;) [syn. with kitaAbN in all of these senses; in the last of them in an anecdote related in Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 721-2, and in Har p. 119, q. v.;] and a [portion of a book, such as is termed] kur~aAsap; and a register; [for] in the A_inoqaAE [a title of several books, it is said that] the kur~aAsap and muSoHaf↓ and SaHiyfap and kitaAb and dafotar are one: (MA:) pl. SuHufN (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and SuHofN, a contraction of the former, (TA,) and SaHaAy^ifu, (S, O, Msb, K,) like safaAy^inu pl. of safiynapN; (Lth, O;) the first of these pls. anomalous, (Lth, Sb, O, K,) the sing. being likened to qaDiytN (Sb, O, TA) and qaliybN (Sb, TA) and ragiyfN, (O,) of which the pls. are quDubN (Sb, O, TA) and qulubN (Sb, TA) and rugufN: (O:) [or SaHiyfN may be its original, as well as regular, sing.:] see the next preceding paragraph. SuHufi A_ibor`hiyma wamuwsaY, in the Kur [lxxxvii. last verse], means [In the books of Abraham and Moses; i. e.] the books revealed to Abraham and Moses. (O.) [SaHiyfapN also means The record of the actions of anyone, that is kept in heaven: (see raq~N:) one says, SaHiyfanuhu sawodaA='u, meaning (assumed tropical:) The record of his actions is black; a phrase often used in the present day, in speaking of a bad man.] Mohammad [the Hanafee Imám] speaks of SuHuf not written upon; saying, faA_ino kaAnati Als~ariqapu SuHufFA layosa fiyhaA kitaAbN [And if the stolen property be papers, or books, not having any writing upon them]. (Mgh. [See, again, raq~N.]) ― -b2- SaHiyfapN signifies also A plank, board, or leaf, of a door; like SaHaAy^ifu [from which it is perhaps formed by transposition, or it may be tropical in this sense]: pl. SaHiyfN. (MA.) ― -b3- Also (tropical:) The external skin, or scarf-skin, of the face: (O, TA:) or as some say, the part thereof that fronts one: pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] SaHiyfN↓; or this may be used, in a verse in which it occurs, for SaHiyfap. (TA.) ― -b4- One says also SaHaAy^ifu mino $aHomK [meaning (assumed tropical:) Layers of fat]. (A in art. nyr.)

SuHayofapN *
SuHayofapN: see SaHofapN.

SaH~aAfN *
SaH~aAfN [A bookseller;] a seller of SuHuf: or [a bookbinder;] a maker [meaning binder] of SuHuf. (TA.)

maSoHafN *
maSoHafN: see what next follows.

muSoHafN *
muSoHafN (Th, S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and miSoHafN↓ (Th, S, O, Msb, K) and maSoHafN↓; (Th, O, K;) the first of which is the original, (Fr, S, O, Msb,) being from A^uSoHifa meaning as expl. above, and one of certain words that are pronounced by [some of] the Arabs with kesr to the m instead of damm because the latter is deemed by them difficult of utterance, of which words are also mixodaEN and miTorafN and migozalN and mijosadN, (Fr, S, O,) or, accord. to AZ, Temeem pronounce the m with kesr, and Keys pronounce it with damm, [as do most persons in the instance of mSHf in the present day,] and Th says that maSoHafN, with fet-h, is correct and chaste; (O;) [A book, or volume, consisting of] a collection of SuHuf, (S, Mgh, O, K, TA,) written upon, and put between two boards: (TA:) [generally applied in the present day to a copy of the Kur-án:] and also signifying a [portion of a book, such as is termed] kur~aAsap: but the former is the primary [and more common] signification: (Mgh:) pl. maSaAHifu. (KL.) See also SaHiyfapN.

miSoHafN *
miSoHafN: see the next preceding paragraph.

muSaH~ifN *
muSaH~ifN: see SaHafiY~N.

1 SaHila *
1. SaHila, aor.
SaHala
, inf. n. SaHalN, He was, or became, hoarse, rough, harsh, or gruff, in voice; said of a man: (S, O:) [and] SaHila Sawotuhu, aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) His voice was, or became, hoarse, rough, harsh, or gruff: or sharp, together with hoarseness, roughness, &c.: or SaHalN signifies a roughness, (xu$uwnapN, K,) or a rattling, (Ha$orajapN, Lh, TA,) in the chest: and a cracking in the voice, without a right tenour thereof: (Lh, K, TA:) one says, fiY Sawotihi SaHalN In his voice is a hoarseness [&c.]: (S, O:) and SaHila Haloquhu His fauces became hoarse [&c.]: (IB, TA:) but accord. to IAth and others, it is not Arabic [in origin]. (TA.) See also SahalN.

SaHolN *
SaHolN [app. a mistake for SaHalN]: see SaHalN.

SaHilN *
SaHilN, (K,) or SaHilu AlS~awoti, (S, O,) Hoarse, rough, harsh, or gruff, [&c.,] in voice; as also A^aSoHalu↓. (S, O, K.) And SawotN SaHilN [A voice that is hoarse, &c.]. (TA, from a trad.)

A^aSoHalu *
A^aSoHalu: see the next preceding paragraph.

8 ASTHm *
8. ASTHm i. q. ASTxm, q. v.

11 ASoHaAm~a *
11. ASoHaAm~a, (K,) inf. n. AiSoHiymaAmN, (TA,) said of a plant, or herbage, It became intensely green: and it became yellow, (K, TA,) and altered in colour; or, as J says, [in the S,] ASHAm~t Albaqolapu the herb, or leguminous plant, became yellow: (TA:) thus it has two contr. meanings: or it (i. e. a plant, or herbage,) became intermixed with yellowness in its dark greenness. (AHn, K.) And ASHAm~t AlA^aroDu The land became altered [for the worse] in its herbage, and its rain departed: (K:) or, as some say, the land became altered in the colour of its seed-produce, for the reaping: and in like manner, ASHAm~ AlHab~N the grain became thus altered. (TA.) And ASHAm~ Alz~aroEu The seed-produce was smitten by cold: or began to dry up. (K.)

SuHomapN *
SuHomapN Blackness inclining to yellowness: or a dust-colour inclining a little to blackness: or redness in whiteness: (K:) or, as some say, yellowness in whiteness. (TA.)

A^aSoHamu *
A^aSoHamu Of the colour termed SuHomapN: (K:) i. e. black inclining to yellowness: (S, K:) &c.: (K:) or, accord. to AA, intensely black: (TA:) fem.
SaHomaA='u. (K.) ― -b2- The latter, applied to a fayofaA=' [or smooth, or waterless, desert], (Sh, K,) or to a balodap [or district, &c.], (S,) signifies Dusty. (Sh, S, K.) ― -b3- And AlS~aHomaA='u is the name of A certain herb, or leguminous plant, (S, K, TA,) not intensely green. (TA.)

muSoHaAm~N *
muSoHaAm~N, applied to a plant, or herbage, [&c.,] part. n. of 11 [q. v.]. (TA.)

1 SaHanahu *
1. SaHanahu, (S, K,) [aor.
SaHana
,] inf. n. SaHonN, (TA,) He gave him something in a SaHon, (S, K,) i. e. the bowl so called: (S:) from Fr. (TA. [See 5.]) And SaHanahu diynaArFA He gave him a deenár. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (AA, S, K,) aor. as above, (K,) He struck him. (AA, S, K.) You say, SaHanotuhu SaHanaAtK i. e. I struck him [strokes: the latter word being pl. of SaHonapN↓, the inf. n. of un.]. (S.) And SaHanahu Ei$oriyna sawoTFA He struck him twenty strokes of the whip. (TA.) ― -b3- SaHanati AlHaAliba birijolihaA She (a camel) kicked the milker with her hind leg. (TA.) ＝ -A2- SaHana bayonahumo, (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He made peace, or he effected a rectification of affairs, an agreement, a harmony, or a reconciliation, between them. (S, K.)

5 tSH~in *
5. tSH~in He asked, or begged: (K, TA:) one says, xaraja fulaAnN yataSaH~anu Aln~aAsa Such a one went forth begging of the people; (AZ, TA;) or, [as is a custom of many Arab and other Eastern mendicants,] begging of them in a bowl, [see 1, first sentence,] or some other thing. (TA.)

SaHonN *
SaHonN A great Eus~ [i. e. bowl, or drinkingcup]; (S, K;) nearly as large as the tibon [q. v.]: (Ks, S in art. tbn:) or a shallow Eus~: (so accord. to a copy of the S:) or a bowl, or drinking-cup, (qadaH) that is neither large nor small: (TA:) [now applied to a plate, and a dish:] pl. [of pauc.] A^aSoHunN (Msb, * TA) and [of mult.] SiHaAnN (TA) [and app., agreeably with modern usage, SuHuwnN]. ― -b2- And [hence,] A [kind of] cymbal; (PS;) a small brazen basin, (TusayotN, [dim. of TasotN,]) one of what are termed SaHonaAni, (S,) this meaning two little brazen basins, (TusayotaAni SagiyrataAni, K,) which are struck together. (S. K.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) The interior of the solid hoof; (K, TA;) also called skrjp [i. e. sukur~ujap or sukur~ajap]. (TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) The interior of the ear: or the maHaArap [i. e. concha] thereof. (TA.) And SaHonaA AlA^u*unayoni [thus accord. to the TA and my MS. copy of the K, in the CK SaHonA'u,] (assumed tropical:) The resting-place (musotaqar~) of the interior of each of the ears; (K;) meaning the place of hearing [or meatus auditorius] of the resting-place of the interior of each of the two ears of the horse: pl. A^aSoHaAnN. (TA.) ― -b5- Also The middle of a house; (S, K;) meaning the saAHap [i. e. court] of the middle of a house [and of a mosque &c.]: (TA:) [and also a hall: for] it is thus called whether without, or with, a roof. (Kull, voce bayotN.) And The saAHap [or spacious vacant part] of the middle of a desert; and of an elevated and plain, or hard and elevated, tract; and of a wide space of low, or depressed, ground: pl. SuHuwnN, the only pl. form. (TA.) A wide part of a desert: so in the saying, sironaA fiY SaHoni AlfalaApi [We journeyed in the wide part of the desert]. (Msb.) And A level, or plain, tract of ground. (TA.) And An acclivity (sanad) of a valley, in which is some elevation above [other] elevated ground, as though supported [by the latter]; and in like manner, of a mountain, and of a hill such as is termed A^akamap; the SuHuwn of the ground being the dufuwf [i. e. banks, or acclivities,] thereof: it is bare, and such as flows [with rain]; and is not thus called unless bare of everything, and even: and it means also an even tract of ground like the area of the place in which dates are put to dry. (TA.) ― -b6- [Hence,] one says, jaraY Ald~amoEu EalaY SaHonaYo wajonatayohi (tropical:) [The tears ran upon the middle of each of his cheek-balls]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A gift. (TA. [See 1, first sentence.])

SaHonapN *
SaHonapN; pl. SaHanaAtN: see 1. ＝ -A2- Also A bead (xarazapN) with which women fascinate men, and restrain them, or withhold them from other women. (Lh, TA.)

SuHonapN *
SuHonapN A clear space of a [stony tract such as is called] Har~ap. (K.)

SiHonaA='N *
SiHonaA='N, (S, and so accord. to some copies of the K,) and SaHonaA='N, (thus also accord. to some copies of the K,) and with the short alif, [app. SiHonFY and SaHonFY,] (S, and so accord. to some copies of the K,) or SiHonaApN and SaHonaApN, (Mgh, Msb,) or thus also, (accord. to some copies of the K,) or thus, and also SiHonaA='apN and SaHonaA='apN, (accord. to other copies of the K,) or when with p having a more special signification, [being a n. of un., and, if so, accord. to a general rule, with tenween when without p, as is said to be the case in the TA, on the authority of Az, accord. to whom, as is also there stated, the word is pluralized by the elision of the p,] (S,) A certain condiment, or seasoning, made of fish, (S, K,) of small fish, which has the properties of exciting appetence, and rectifying the state of the stomach: (K:) or i. q. SiyrN, (Mgh, Msb,) i. e. what is called in Pers. maAhiY A=wahN [jelly of salted fish]: (Mgh:) AZ is related to have said that SHnAp is Pers., meaning what the Arabs call Siyr: IAth says that Syr and SHnAp are both of them Pers. words. (TA.)

SaHuwnN *
SaHuwnN A she-camel that has a habit of kicking: (AA, S, K:) and a kicking mare or horse: and a she-ass that kicks the he-ass with her hind leg whenever he comes near to her: or, as some say, a she-ass in which are whiteness and redness [app. meaning a wild she-ass]. (TA.)

miSoHanapN *
miSoHanapN A vessel like the [bowls called] SaHofap (K, TA) and qaSoEpa. (TA.)

1 SaHaA *
1. SaHaA, said of a day, [aor. yaSoHuw,] inf. n. SaHowN, It was, or became, cloudless: (TA:) and so A^aSoHaY↓: (Msb, K, TA, but not in the CK:) [it is said that] SaHowN signifies the departing of the clouds: (S, Mgh, K:) [but] Es-Sijistánee says that the vulgar think it to have this meaning, whereas it only means the dispersing of the clouds with the departing of the cold. (Msb, TA.) And Als~amaA='u A^aSoHati↓ The sky became cloudless. (Ks, S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA, but not in the CK.) ― -b2- And SaHaA mino sukorihi, (S, Msb,) aor. yaSoHuw, (Msb,) inf. n. SaHowN (S, Msb, K) and SuHuw~N, (Msb,) [He recovered, or became free, from his intoxication; or] his intoxication ceased; as also ASHY↓: (Msb:) and SaHiYa, (K, TA,) inf. n. SaHFA; (TA;) as also ASHY↓; (IKtt, K, TA;) is [likewise] said of one intoxicated; (K, TA;) both meaning he recovered from his state of insensibility; (TA;) and in like manner both are said of one affected with desire, or yearning or longing in the soul; (K, TA;) [and also of one sleeping, meaning he awoke: see an ex. of the former of these two verbs in this last sense in the latter part of the second paragraph of art. frT.] ― -b3- SaHowN signifies also (tropical:) The relinquishing of youthful folly, and amorous dalliance, and of what is vain, or futile. (K, TA.) Hence the saying of a poet,
SaHaA Alqalobu Eano salomaY waA^aqoSara baATiluho
(tropical:) [The heart relinquished, or has relinquished, youthful folly and amorousness by becoming rid of Selmà, and its vain, or futile, occupation ceased, or has ceased]. (TA.) ― -b4- And one says, SaHati AlEaA*ilapu (assumed tropical:) The censuring female relinquished censuring. (TA.)

4 ASHY *
