Sad~N: see Sud~N, in four places. ― -b2- Also The face, or front, of the hand. (TA.)

Sud~N *
Sud~N (M, A, L, Msb, K) and Sad~N↓ (K) The side of a valley, (M, A, Msb, K,) or of a $iEob [i. e. the kind of water-course so called, or a ravine], and of a mountain where it forms a ravine, (M, L,) and (tropical:) of a road: (A:) pl. [of pauc.] A^aSodaAdN and [of mult.] SuduwdN. (TA.) And Sad~N↓ (L) and SadadN↓ (M, L) signify [in like manner] A side; a lateral, or an adjacent, part, quarter, tract, or the like; syn. of the former jaAnibN, (L,) and of the latter naAHiyapN. (M, L.) AinoDam~a Ealayohimu AlS~ud~aAni [lit. The two sides of the road confined them] means (tropical:) they occupied the middle of the road. (A.) And AlS~ud~aAni signifies also (tropical:) The two edges, or extremities, or cusps, of the notch of an arrow, between which is the place of the bow-string; syn. $aroxaA Alfuwqi. (O. [In the K, erroneously, $aroxaA Alfaroqi.]) ― -b2- Also Sud~N and Sad~N↓ A mountain: (AA, S, M, L, Msb, K:) and so sud~N and sad~N: (AA, S, M:) pl. A^aSodaAdN and SuduwdN. (M, L.) ― -b3- And Sad~N↓ [or Sud~N] A cloud, or collection of clouds, rising high, and appearing like a mountain: and so sad~N [or sud~N (q. v.)], which is the more approved word. (M, L.)

SadadN *
SadadN: see Sud~N. ― -b2- Also i. q. qurobN [used as a n. of place, meaning Vicinity, or a near place or sport; as in phrases here following]: (ISk, S, M, A, Msb, K:) and the place, or part, that is before, in front, facing, or opposite. (ISk, * T, S, * M, A, * L, K. *) One says, daAruhu biSadadi Almasojidi [His house is in the vicinity of, i. e. near to, the mosque; or his house is opposite to the mosque]. (Msb. [The former meaning is there indicated; but no meaning is expressed.]) And A^axa*otuhu mino SadadK i. e. mino qurobK [I took it from a near place or spot]. (A.) And daAriY Sadada daArihi, (ISk, S, A, K,) in which Sdd is in the accus. case as an adv. n. of place, (S, K,) and biSadadihi, (ISk, A,) and EalaY Sadadihi, (Lth, ISk,) My house is opposite to, i. e. in the place, or part, that is in front of, his house: (ISk, S, A, K:) and in the vicinity of, or near to, his house. (K.) And h`*aA Sadada h`*aA, and biSadadihi, This is in front of, or opposite to, this. (M.) ― -b3- [Hence, app.,] laA Hadada liY duwnahu walaA Sadada There is no impediment to me in the way of it, nor any obstacle. (A.) ― -b4- And huwa Sadadaka i. q. qaSodaka [i. e. He, or it, is tending, or looking, in the direction of thee; or is before thee, or before thy face: see art. qSd]. (Sb, M.) ― -b5- And A^anaA biSadadK mino h`*aA AlA^amori [I am directing myself, or my attention, to this affair]. (A.) [narojiEu A_ilaY maA naHonu biSadadihi, meaning We will return to that subject to which our attention is directed, is a phrase of frequent occurrence after a digression.]

SidaAdN *
SidaAdN A woman's sitor [app. meaning veil, or covering]. (Nawádir el-Aaráb, O, K.) ― -b2- See also what next follows.

SaduwdN *
SaduwdN i. q. mijowalN [app. meaning A kind of garment for women or for young girls, which is thus called]; (O, K; in the CK miHowal;) as also SidaAdN↓; so says Th. (O.)

SadiydN *
SadiydN an inf. n. of Sad~a [q. v.] in one of its senses. (S, A, K.) ＝ -A2- Also The ichor, i. e. thin water, [or watery humour,] of a wound, (S, A, Mgh, K,) mixed [or tinged] with blood, (S, A, Mgh,) before the matter becomes thick: (S, A:) or matter, or pus, like water, in which is a mixture of red and white: (M:) or matter, or pus, like water in thinness and like blood in its having a mixture of red and white: (AZ, Msb:) and some add that when it has thickened, it is mid~ap: (Msb:) or matter, or pus, mixed with blood, (Lth, Mgh, Msb,) in a wound. (Lth.) In the Kur xiv. 19, it means What flows from the skins of the inmates of Hell: (M:) or what flows from their insides, and is mixed with matter and blood: (Jel:) or hot water (HamiymN) boiled until it thickens. (M, K.) ― -b2- And hence, as being likened thereto, Sadiydu AlfiD~api i. e. *uwaAbatuhaA [app. meaning What is melted of silver]. (M.)

Sud~aY *
Sud~aY A species of fig, white without, black within, and very sweet. (AHn, M, TA.)

Sud~aAdN *
Sud~aAdN A road to water. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- And AlS~ud~aAdu The serpent: (K:) and (K, TA, in the CK “ or ”) a certain small animal (duwayob~ap, S, K) of the kind of the [field-rats called] jiro*aAn: (S:) or [a species of lizard;] what is called saAm~u A^aboraSa [q. v.]; (AZ, S, M, K;) used in this sense by Keys: (AZ, S:) or, accord. to Yaakoob, the [lizard called] wazaE: or, as some say, a species of the [field rats called] jiro*aAn: (M:) pl. SadaAy^idu, (S, M, K,) which is anomalous. (S, M.)

SaAd~N *
SaAd~N Turning away, avoiding, shunning, and leaving; or averse: fem. SaAd~apN: pl. of both Sud~aAdN; and of the fem. SawaAd~u also. (M.)

maSoduwdN *
maSoduwdN [pass. part. n. of Sad~ahu, q. v.]. One says, fulaAnN maSoduwdN Eani Alxayori [Such a one is turned away from, or prevented from attaining, what is good, or prosperity]. (A.)

1 Sadiy^a *
1. Sadiy^a, (S, M, L, K,) aor.
SadaAa
, (L,) inf. n. SadaA^N, (S, M,) said of a horse, (K, TA,) and of a kid, (S, TA,) [or a goat,] He was of the colour termed SudoA^ap [i. e. sorrel inclining to blackness; or blackness intermixed, or tinged over, with redness; or a colour like that of the rust of iron; probably from the same verb in the sense next following]; (S, M, L, K, TA;) as also Saduw^a, (K,) aor.
SaduAa
; (TA; [and it is implied in the K that the latter verb is syn. with the former in all its senses;]) but the former verb is that which is commonly known, and that alone which is required by analogy as a verb denoting a colour, and the latter is not known to have been heard; (MF, TA;) and in the L it is said that the verb in this sense is Sadiy^a and AiS~adaA^a↓, this latter [formed from AiSoTadaA^a, originally AiSotadaA^a,] of the measure AifotaEala. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (M, K,) Sadiy^a, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (S, Msb, TA,) and so the inf. n., (S, TA,) said of iron, It was, or became, rusty, or rusted; (S, M, Msb, K;) in which sense it is said also of the like of iron. (M.) ＝ -A2- And Sadiy^a said of a man, He stood erect, and looked. (K.) ＝ -A3- SadaA^a AlmiroA=pa, aor.
SadaAa
, (K,) inf. n. Sado'N, (TK,) He polished the mirror, (K, TA,) i. e., removed from it the rust, (TA,) in order to use it as a collyrium; (K, TA;) as also Sad~aA^ahaA↓, (K,) inf. n. taSodiy^apN. (TA.) [Whether the mirrors
of the Arabs were made of bronze, or of what other metal they were made, is not said. See also 1 in art. HlA^.] ＝ -A4- And, aor. as above, said of an owl, He uttered a cry or cries. (Sh, TA. [See also art. Sdw.])

2 Sad~aAa
2: see the preceding paragraph.

5 tSd~A^ lahu *
5. tSd~A^ lahu, (K,) as also tSd~E lh, (TA,) i. q. tSd~Y lh, (K, TA,) which is the original, meaning tEr~D lh [i. e. He addressed, or applied, or directed, himself, or his regard, or attention, or mind, to him, or it; &c.]. (TA.)

8 AiS~adaA^a *
8. AiS~adaA^a: see 1, first sentence.

SadaA^N *
SadaA^N inf. n. of Sadiy^a [q. v.]. (S, M.) ― -b2- Also [a subst.] signifying The rust of iron, (S, M, * TA,) and of copper and the like. (Har p. 481. [But there erroneously written SdA='.]) ＝ -A2- Also A man slender in body; (K, TA;) light, or active, therein: its ' is said to be substituted for E. (TA. [See SadaEN; and see also SadFY.])

Sadiy^N *
Sadiy^N [part. n. of Sadiy^a, q. v.]. ― -b2- One says, yadiY mina AlHadiydi Sadiy^apN My hand is disagreeable in smell [from the rust of iron]. (S.) ― -b3- And huwa SaAgirN Sadiy^N (assumed tropical:) He is one to whom disgrace, or shame, and baseness, or meanness, attach. (S, K.) ― -b4- See also A^aSodaA^u.

SudoA^apN *
SudoA^apN, (S, M, K,) in a horse, (S, K,) and in a goat, or kid, (S,) A sorrel colour ($uqorapN) inclining to blackness, (M, K, TA,) the latter predominating: (TA:) or blackness intermixed, or tinged over, with redness [app. like the rust of iron]. (S.)

A^aSodaA^u *
A^aSodaA^u, (S, M, K,) applied to a horse, (K, TA,) or to a kid, (TA,) Of a sorrel colour (i. e. of the colour termed $uqorap) inclining to blackness, (M, K, TA,) the latter predominating: (TA:) or, applied to a horse, and to a goat, or kid, (S,) or applied to a kid, (K,) of a black colour intermixed, or tinged over, with redness [app. like the rust of iron]: (S, K:) fem. SadoA='u (S, M, K,) and Sadiy^apN↓. (M, L, TA.) And kumayotN A^aSodaA^u [A bay, or dark bay, or brown, horse,] tinged over with dinginess. (S.) ― -b2- Also Rusty, or rusted; applied to iron and the like. (M.) ― -b3- And [hence] katiybapN SadoA='u, (M, and so in copies of the K,) or SadoA^FY, (K accord. to the TA,) and the former also, (TA,) [A body of troops having their arms or armour] overspread with the rust of iron. (M, K.) ― -b4- And SadoA='u A land (A^aroDN) of which the stones are of a red colour inclining to blackness, and rugged, not even with the ground, these stones having beneath them [other] rough stones, or, sometimes, soil and stones. (Sh, L.)

1 SadaHa *
1. SadaHa, (S, A, K, &c.,) aor.
SadaHa
, (K,) inf. n. SadoHN (S, K, &c.) and SudaAHN, (K,) in a verse of Wejeehah Bint-Ows Ed-Dabbeeyeh Sud~aAH, (Ham p. 617,) He cried, or raised a loud cry; (S, A;) or raised his voice vehemently; (Lth, T;) said of a cock [i. e. he crowed, or crowed loudly or vehemently]; (Lth, T, S, A;) and of a crow [i. e. he croaked, or croaked loudly or vehemently]: (Lth, T, S:) said of an ass, he brayed loudly: (L:) said of a bird, and (assumed tropical:) of a man, he raised his voice in singing (L, K) or otherwise; cried out vehemently and sharply; or uttered a vehement and sharp voice. (L.)

SadoHapN *
SadoHapN (S, L, K) and SudoHapN↓ and SadaHapN↓ (L, K) A kind of bead (xarazapN, Lh, S, L, K) used for the purpose of captivating, or fascinating: (K:) or with which men are captivated, or fascinated: (S:) or with which women captivate, or fascinate, men: (Lh:) or with which men are conciliated. (L.)

SudoHapN *
SudoHapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

SadaHapN *
SadaHapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

SaduwHN *
SaduwHN Having a loud cry or voice; as also Sad~aAHN↓; both applied to a cock [meaning loudcrowing]; (A;) [and to a crow as meaning loudcroaking]; and so the former applied to an ass [meaning loud-braying]; and so SayodaHN↓ applied to a horse [meaning loud-neighing]; (S, K;) [and app. also applied to a camel as meaning loudbraying, for] SayodaHu was the name of the she-camel of Dhu-r-Rummeh: (S, K:) or SaduwHN (L, K) and Sad~aAHN↓ (L) and SayodaHN↓ and SayodaAHN↓ and miSodaHN↓ (L, K) signify that raises his voice much in singing or otherwise; (L;) [app. thus applied to a bird, and (assumed tropical:) to a man; (see 1;)] or that cries out vehemently, or much; or has a loud, or strong, voice; (L, K;) and so SayodaHiY~N↓. (Ham p. 558.) [Hence,] qayonapN SaAdiHapN↓ (tropical:) [A loud-voiced female singer]. (A, TA.) And HaAdK SayodaHN↓ (tropical:) [A loud-voiced man urging camels by his singing]. (A, TA.) And mizoharN Sad~aAHN↓ (tropical:) [A loud-sounding lute]. (S, A.)

Sad~aAHN *
Sad~aAHN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

SaAdiHapN *
SaAdiHapN: see SaduwHN.

SayodaHN *
SayodaHN: see SaduwHN, in three places.

SayodaHiY~N *
SayodaHiY~N: see SaduwHN.

SayodaAHN *
SayodaAHN see SaduwHN.

AlA^aSodaHu *
AlA^aSodaHu The lion: (K:) so called because of his roaring. (TA.)

miSodaHN *
miSodaHN: see SaduwHN.

1 Sadara *
1. Sadara, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) aor.
Sadura
(S, M, Msb, K) and
Sadira
, (K,) inf. n. SadorN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and SuduwrN (A, TA) and maSodarN (M, K) and mazodarN because of the similarity [of the letters S and z], (M,) He returned, went back; (S, M, A, Msb, K;) and went, or turned, away; (Msb;) from (Eano) water, (S, M, A,) and a country, (S, M,) or a place, (Msb,) and (assumed tropical:) any affair. (Lth.) ― -b2- Hence, Sadara Alqawolu, aor.
Sadura
, inf. n. SuduwrN, (assumed tropical:) [The saying issued, proceeded, or emanated, Eanohu from him.] (Msb.) [And Sadara Eanohu AlfiEolu, with the same aor. and inf. n., (assumed tropical:) The action proceeded from him.] ― -b3- And Sadara A_ilayohi He went to it; namely, a place: (TA:) he came to it. (Kull. p. 228.) ＝ -A2- Sadarahu: see 4. ＝ -A3- Also, (M, K,) aor.
Sadura
, inf. n. SadorN, (M,) He hit, struck, or hurt, his Sador [i. e. breast]. (M, K.) You say, Darabotuhu faSadarotuhu I struck him and hit his breast. (A.) ― -b2- And Sadira He had a complaint of the Sador [or chest]. (M, K.) [See its part. n., below.]

2 Sd~rhu *
2. Sd~rhu: see 4. ＝ -A2- Sd~r baEiyrahu, (K,) inf. n. taSodiyrN, (TA,) He tied a cord from the girth of his camel to the part behind [or beyond] the callous lump on his breast: (K, TA:) or, accord. to Lth, (L,) one says, Sd~r Eano baEiyrihi, (M, L,) and the meaning is, he tied a cord from the taSodiyr [or breast-girth] to the part behind [or beyond] the callous lump on the breast of his camel, to keep the tSdyr in its place, when it had become loose in consequence of the animal's having become lank in the belly: the cord above mentioned is called sinaAfN [q. v.]. (Lth, L.) ― -b2- And Sd~r EalaY AlbaEiyri [app. He put the breast-girth upon the camel]: from Alt~aSodiyru, i. e. “ the girth ” [thus called]. (MA.) ― -b3- Sud~ira His (a horse's) breast became wetted with sweat. (S.) See 5. ― -b4- Sd~rhu, (TA,) or Sd~rhu fiY Almajolisi, (S,) (assumed tropical:) He placed him, or seated him, in the upper, or highest, part in the sitting-room, or sitting-place. (TA.) And Sud~ira He was advanced, or promoted. (A.) ― -b5- Sd~r kitaAbahu, (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (K,) (tropical:) He put to his book, or writing, a Sador, (S, K, TA,) i. e. a title, or a commencement. (TA.) And Sd~r kitaAbahu bika*aA (tropical:) [He commenced his book, or writing, with such a thing]. (A.) ＝ -A3- See also 5, where it is expl. as intrans., in two places.

3 muSaAdarapN *
3. muSaAdarapN signifies The returning, or going back, [app. with another, from water, &c.] (KL.) [The verb is probably trans., agreeably with general analogy, in all its senses; SAdrhu app. signifying primarily He returned, or went back, with him from water &c. ― -b2- Ibr D thinks that it signifies also (assumed tropical:) He vied, or contended, with him for precedence, or priority.] ＝ -A2- Also (assumed tropical:) The exacting a fine or the like [app. from another: or the suing, or prosecuting, another, for a debt &c.]. (KL.) You say, SAdrhu EalaY ka*aA mina AlmaAli (S, * K, * TA) (assumed tropical:) He desired, or sought, to obtain from him; or he demanded of him; or he sued, or prosecuted, him for; such a sum, or such an amount, of property. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- And SaAdarotuhu EalaY ka*a A waka*aA (assumed tropical:) I released him from my reckoning with him on such and such terms agreed upon by both. (TA in art. frq.) And Suwdira EalaY maAlK yuw^ad~iyhi (assumed tropical:) He (an agent) was released from being reckoned with (fuwriqa) on the condition of his paying certain property for which he became responsible: a phrase of the registrars of accounts. (TA in the present art.)

4 ASdrhu *
4. ASdrhu, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) and Sadarahu↓, (M, K,) and Sd~rhu↓, (K,) He caused him to return; sent him, or brought him, back, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) or away; (Msb;) from (Eano) water, and a country [or place], (S,) and (assumed tropical:) any affair. (Lth.) You say, A^aSodaronaA rikaAbanaA We sent, or brought, back our riding-camels satisfied with drink so that it was not necessary for us to remain with them for the sake of the water. (TA.) And A^aworadahu waA^aSodarahu He brought it and he took it away. (Har p. 361.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A^aworada waA^aSodara (tropical:) He began and completed. (TA.) You say, A_i*aA A^aworada A^amorFA A^aSodarahu (tropical:) When he begins a thing, or an affair, he completes it. (A.) And fulaAnN yuwridu walaA yuSodiru (tropical:) Such a one begins and does not complete. (A.) ― -b3- And ASdr Alqawola (assumed tropical:) [He issued forth the saying; made it to issue, proceed, or emanate, Eanohu from him]. (Msb. [See 1.]) [And ASdr Eanohu AlfiEola (assumed tropical:) He, or it, made the action to proceed from him.]

5 tSd~r *
5. tSd~r He [a man, TA) erected his chest in sitting. (M, K.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He [a horse) outreached the other horses with his chest; (M, K, * TA;) as also Sd~r↓, (S, * M, MA, K,) inf. n. taSodiyrN: the latter verb is afterwards expl. in the K as meaning baraza biraA^osihi; but this is a mistake. (TA.) Tufeyl says, describing a horse,
mino EaraqK kaA^an~ahu baEoda maA Sad~arona↓
siydN tamaT~ara jinoHa All~ayoli maboluwlu
As though he were, after they had outreached with their chests, from a row of [other] horses, [a wolf that had exposed himself to rain during a portion of the night, and had become wetted:] but accord. to one relation, it is Sud~irona↓, meaning their breasts were wetted [mino EaraqK] by reason of sweat: the former reading, however is the better. (S.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) He sat, or became placed or seated, in the upper, or highest, part in the sitting-room, or sitting-place. (S, * K, * TA.) And He became advanced, or promoted. (A.) tSd~r liA^umuwri Aln~aAsi (assumed tropical:) [He became advanced to the foremost place for the conducting of the affairs of the people]. (Har p. 194.)

6 tSAdrwA *
6. tSAdrwA [app. They returned together from water, &c.]. (A. [This meaning seems to be there indicated by the context.]) ― -b2- And one says, tSAdrwA EalaY maA $aAw^uwA (tropical:) [app. meaning They released one another from being reckoned with, by mutual agreement, on such terms as they would: see 3]. (A.)

SadorN *
SadorN Anything that fronts, or faces, one. (M, K.) ― -b2- And hence, (M,) The Sador [i. e. breast, or chest, or bosom,] of a man, [often meaning his mind,] (M, Msb, K,) and of other than man: (Msb:) of the masc. gender: (Lh, S, M, K:) pl. SuduwrN, (S, M, Msb,) the only pl. form. (M.) [See also SudorapN.] As to the saying of the poet, (S, M,) El-Aashà, (S,)
wata$oraqu biAlqawoli Al~a*iY qado A^a*aEotuhu
kamaA $ariqato Sadoru AlqanaApi mina Ald~ami
[And thou becomest, or wilt become, red by reason of the saying that I have published, like as the fore part of the spear becomes red from blood], (S, * M,) he has made Sdr fem. because the Sdr of the qnAp is a part of the qnAp; for they [sometimes] make a noun fem. when it is prefixed to a fem. noun: (S:) or if you will, you may say that he has made Sdr fem. because he meant [thereby] the qnAp; and if you will, you may say that the Sdr of a qnAp is a qnAp. (M.) [Hence,] banaAtu AlS~adori (tropical:) The spaces between the bones of the breast. (M, TA.) [And also] (assumed tropical:) Anxieties. (T in art. bnY.) And *aAtu AlS~uduwri (assumed tropical:) What is in the minds. (Ksh and Bd and Jel in iii. 115, &c.) And DaAqa Sadoruhu (assumed tropical:) His bosom, or mind, became strait, or contracted. (Msb in art. Dyq. [See the Kur xv. 97 and xxvi. 12.]) And $araHa biAlkufori SadorFA (assumed tropical:) He opened and dilated his bosom, meaning, was pleased, with infidelity. (Jel in xvi. 108. [See also the similar phrases $araHa A@ll~`hu Sadorahu liloA_isolaAmi and liqabuwli Alxayori expl. in art. $rH.]) And Aino$araHa Sadoruhu (assumed tropical:) His bosom became dilated or enlarged [with joy]. (S in art. $rH.) And waAsiEu AlS~adori and raHiybu AlS~adori (assumed tropical:) Ample, or dilated, in the breast, or bosom; [meaning free-minded; free from distress of mind; without care: and free from narrowness of mind; liberal, munificent, or generous.] (S and TA in art. rHb.) [And Day~iqu AlS~adori (assumed tropical:) Having the bosom, or mind, strait, or contracted.] And rajulN baEiydu AlS~adori (tropical:) A man who is not to be turned, or bent, or inclined. (M.) In the saying halo yasotaTiyEu mano bihi SadorN A_il~aA A^ano yanofiva [meaning Is he who has the disease of the chest (daA='u AlS~adori) able to do without spitting?], if it be correct, the prefixed noun [dA='] is suppressed. (Mgh.) [Sadoru Ald~ajaAjapi, as said by Freytag, is the name of (assumed tropical:) The star γ of Cygnus.] ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) The upper, or uppermost, part of the front of anything. (M, K.) [Hence,] Suduwru AlwaAdiY (assumed tropical:) The higher, or upper, parts, and fronts, or fore parts, of the valley; (M, K;) as also SadaAy^iruhu, which is pl. of SadaArapN↓, (K,) or SidaArapN↓, (as in a copy of the M,) or SaAdirapN↓, (as in the L,) or of SadiyrapN↓. (M, L, K.) And Sadoru Almajolisi (assumed tropical:) The upper, or highest, part [or end] of the sitting-room, or sitting-place: (TA:) the elevated part thereof. (Msb.) ― -b4- [(assumed tropical:) The fore part of anything. (assumed tropical:) The prow, or fore part, of a ship.] (assumed tropical:) The fore part of the foot, between the toes and the [protuberant part called the] HimaArap. (M.) (assumed tropical:) The fore part of the sandal, before the [hole through which is put the thong called the $iraAk, i. e. the hole called the] xurot. (M.) (tropical:) The part of the arrow that is above the middle, as far as the mrA$: (so in a copy of the A: [an evident mistranscription for raA^os, i. e. head:]) or the part of the arrow that is beyond the middle, as far as the slender part, (S, M, Msb, K,) which is next the head; (M;) so called because it is the fore part when it is shot: (S, Msb, K:) and likewise of the spear [as in the verse cited above in this paragraph]. (M.) yawomN kaSadori Alr~umoHi [lit. (assumed tropical:) A day like the fore part of the spear] means (assumed tropical:) a day of straitness and distress: accord. to Th, it is a day by which war, or battle, is peculiarly distinguished. (M, L.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) The first, first part, or commencement, of anything; (S, M, K;) even (assumed tropical:) of the day, (M, Msb,) and (assumed tropical:) of the night, and (assumed tropical:) of the winter, and (assumed tropical:) of the summer, and (assumed tropical:) the like, (M,) and (tropical:) of an affair. (A. [See an ex. voce EajuzN.]) (tropical:) The title of a book or writing: and the first part, or commencement, thereof. (TA.) [(assumed tropical:) The first foot of the first hemistich of a verse.] And The first hemistich (altogether) of a verse. (O voce EajuzN.) [And (assumed tropical:) The first verse of a qaSiydap.] ― -b6- Sadoru AlT~ariyqi (assumed tropical:) The wide, or widening, part of the road. (Msb.) ― -b7- Sadoru Alqawomi (assumed tropical:) The head, or chief, of the people, or party; as also AlmaSodaru↓. (TA.) And hence, Sadoru AlS~uduwri (assumed tropical:) [The chief of the chiefs; a title applied to the prime minister of the king; and also to the chief judge; app., in the earlier times, to the former;] he who performs the onerous duties of the king, or of the state. (TA.) ― -b8- And (assumed tropical:) A part, or portion, of a thing. (S, K.)

SadarN *
SadarN a subst. signifying Return, (S, M, Msb, K,) from (Eano) water, (S, M,) and a country, (S,) or a place, (Msb,) and (assumed tropical:) any affair: (Lth:) as some say, from anything. (M.) Hence, TawaAfu AlS~adari, (K, TA, in the CK AlS~adori,) i. e. The compassing of the Kaabeh on the occasion of the return of the pilgrims from ' Arafát. (TA.) [Hence also,] AlS~adaru The fourth day of the days of the sacrifice [performed by the pilgrims]: (M, K:) so called because the people then return from Mekkeh to their abodes. (M.) [And hence the saying,] tarakotuhu EalaY mivoli layolapi AlS~adari I left him as in the night preceding the fourth day of the days of the sacrifice: (A:) or [as in the night preceding the day] when the people return from their pilgrimage; (S;) meaning, (assumed tropical:) possessing nothing. (M.) ＝ -A2- Also quasi-pl. n. of SaAdirN, q. v. (M, K.)

SudorapN *
SudorapN The Sador [or breast] (M, K) of a man [or beast]: (TA:) or the prominent part of the upper portion thereof. (T, S, M, K.) ― -b2- Hence, (S,) A certain garment [which covers the breast], (S, M,) well known: (K:) a short shirt: a short diroE: and the dim., SudayorapN↓, is applied to a short shirt which is worn next the body. (TA.) [In the present day, SudayoriY, which is a corruption of the dim., is applied to A kind of waistcoat; a short vest without sleeves: and its pl. is SudayoriyaAt.] See also the next paragraph.

SidaArN *
SidaArN A certain garment, of which the head, or upper part, is like the miqonaEap, [covering the head,] and the lower part of which covers the breast (M, K) and the shoulders: (M:) a woman in mourning for the death of her husband or relation used to wear a SdAr of wool: (Az:) or i. q. SudorapN↓ [q. v.] and mijowalN and A^uSodapN: (IAar:) or a certain garment with which the head and breast are covered, worn by a woman in mourning for her husband: (A:) or a small shirt worn next the body: (S:) or a diroE worn next the breast: (As:) or i. q. A_itobN [q. v.]. (T in art.
Atb.) It is said in a prov., kul~u *aAti SidaArK xaAlapN [Every female having a SdAr is as a maternal aunt]: i. e., it is incumbent on a man to be jealous for every woman like as he is jealous for his women under covert, or the females of his family whom he is under an obligation to respect and protect. (S. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 310.]) ― -b2- Also A certain mark made with a hot iron upon the breast of a camel. (S.)

SadaArapN *
SadaArapN (assumed tropical:) Precedence, or priority. (TA.) ― -b2- See also SadorN, near the middle of the paragraph.

SidaArapN *
SidaArapN: see SadorN, near the middle of the paragraph.

SadiyrapN *
SadiyrapN: see SadorN, near the middle of the paragraph.

SudayorapN *
SudayorapN dim. of SudorapN, q. v. (TA.)

SaAdirN *
SaAdirN Returning [from water, &c.]; going, or turning, back, or away: (TA:) quasi-pl. n. SadarN↓. (M, K.) ― -b2- [Hence the saying,] maA lahu SaAdirN walaA waAridN (tropical:) He has not anything: (M, K:) or he has not a thing nor a people. (Lh, M.) ― -b3- And TariyqN SaAdirN (tropical:) A road, or way, by which people return from water: (S, M, A, K:) opposed to TariyqN waAridN. (M, A.)

SaAdirapN *
SaAdirapN: see SadorN, near the middle of the paragraph.

A^aSodaru *
A^aSodaru A man (M) having a large breast, or chest; (M, K, TA;) i. e. having the breast, or chest, or the upper part thereof, prominent; as also muSad~arN↓. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AlA^aSodaraAni Two veins (M, K) that beat, or pulse, (M,) beneath the temples: (M, K:) or the two sides of a man: or the two shoulder-joints: (TA:) the word has no singular. (M.) [Hence the saying,] jaA='a yaDoribu A^aSodarayohi; (M, Meyd, K, TA;) and some say A^asodarayohi [q. v.], (Meyd, TA,) and this is the original; (Meyd;) and some, A^azodarayohi; (Meyd, TA;) a prov.; (M, Meyd, TA;) meaning He came beating [with his hand] his two sides, (TA,) or his two shoulderjoints: (Meyd, TA:) i. e. he came empty [-handed]; (M, Meyd, K, * TA;) not having accomplished the object of his desire: (Meyd:) or he came exulting, or behaving insolently, (Meyd, and Har p. 603,) not knowing where were his A^aSodaraAni: so accord. to Yoo: and some say, jaA='a baDoribu biA^aSodarayohi. (Har.)

taSodiyrN *
taSodiyrN [a subst. like ta*oriyEN and tanobiytN] The [fore-girth, i. e. breast-girth, or] girth that is upon the breast of the camel: (S, A: *) [the hind girth, or belly-girth,] that which is next the viyl, is called the Haqab: (S:) or the girth of the camel's saddle (Alr~aHol), and of the [camel-vehicle called] hawodaj. (M.)

maSodarN *
maSodarN A place of returning or going back, (S, TA,) or of going, or turning, away [from water, and from a country or place, and (assumed tropical:) from an affair or thing]. (TA. [See 1, first sentence.]) ― -b2- [Hence, maSodaru A^amorK (tropical:) The way of return from, or of completing, a thing or an affair: opposed to maworiduhu.] One says, huwa yaEorifu mawaArida AlA^umuwri wamaSaAdirahaA (tropical:) [He knows the ways of betaking himself to things or affairs, and the ways of withdrawing himself from them; or of commencing them and of completing them]. (A.) [See also another ex. in art. rHb, conj. 6.] ― -b3- And hence [also], the maSaAdir [pl. of maSodar] of verbs: (S, TA:) maSodarN signifies (assumed tropical:) The root of a word, from which proceed the derivatives of verbs: (Lth, TA:) [in this sense it is a conventional term of grammar and lexicology, not belonging to the classical language; but on account of the importance of understanding its true application in lexicology, it is necessary to give here a full explanation of it: it is, agreeably with its etymology, the source (lit. place) of derivation, accord. to the grammarians of ElBasrah; and is what I term an infinitive noun: it is defined as] a noun signifying, by its original application, an accident as subsisting in, or proceeding from, an agent (as AlfaraHu [“ the being joyful ”], AlD~arobu [“ the act of beating ”], and AlquEuwdu [“ the act of sitting ”]), or affecting an object of action, (as Aljunuwnu [“ the being possessed by a jinnee ”]), conformable to its verb, so as to comprise all the letters in that verb, either literally (as in the instances above) or virtually (as in AlqitaAlu [“ the act of fighting ”], which wants the A that is before the t in the verb, yet wants it as to the letter only, and not virtually, wherefore it is sometimes pronounced as if with the said letter, as in qaAtala qiytaAlFA, but the A is changed into Y on account of the kesr of the letter before it), or substituting another letter for any of those letters that it wants (as in AlEidapu [“ the act of promising ”], which wants the w that is in its verb as to the letter and virtually, but has p substituted for it [by way of compensation]): (from a comparison of definitions &c. in the Expos. of the “ Kitab Hodood en-Nahw ” by the author of the work thus entitled, arts. mSdr and Asm mSdr; the Expos. of the “ Shudhoor edh-Dhahab ” by the author of the work thus entitled, section on the nouns that govern as verbs; I' Ak; &c.:) but the grammarians of El-Koofeh hold that the verb is the root, and that the mSdr is derived from it: (I' Ak p. 148:) some mSAdr, moreover, are derived from real (as opposed to ideal) substantives, as Alt~aHaj~uru [“ the becoming stone ”] from AlHajaru [“ stone ”]. (Kull p. 327.) The mSdr has the same government as its own verb: it is often, and may be at pleasure, used as an ideal subst. or abstract noun: and it is often employed in the place of an act. or a pass. part. n.: (Kull, &c.:) [when thus used as an epithet, it is employed alike as sing. and pl. and masc. and fem.:] accord. to Zj, every mSdr used as an epithet is for *uw [or *aAt &c.] followed by the mSdr, and therefore it has no dual nor pl. [nor fem.] form. (TA voce HaraDN.) [It has also other uses, which are expl. in the grammars. Used as a maSodar, it is sometimes made fem.; as it is also when used in the sense of a noun that is properly fem.: see SarofN, third sentence.] ― -b4- Aisomu maSodarK, called by some AisomN lilomaSodari, is a term applied to [(assumed tropical:) A quasi-infinitive noun; i. e.] a noun which is not a mSdr, but which is occasionally used in the place of a mSdr; like as a mSdr is used in the place of an act. part. n., and in that of a pass. part. n.: such as AlwuDuwo'u for Alt~awaD~uw^u [“ the performing of the ablution preparatory to prayer ”], and Algusolu for AlAigotisaAlu [“ the washing of oneself ”]; each of which wants somewhat that is in its verb without substituting anything for that which is wanting. (Expos. of the “ Kitáb el- Hodood, ” cited above.) This kind of noun the grammarians of El-Koofeh and Baghdád allow to govern as a mSdr; but the grammarians of ElBasrah hold that the noun governed in the accus. case in each of the exs. adduced by the former as confirmatory of their opinion is so governed by a verb understood. (Expos. of the “ Shudhoor, ” ubi suprà.) It is also applied to A proper name signifying an accident [or attribute]; as fajaAri and HamaAdi, proper names, by original application, for Alfajorapu and AlmaHomadapu [“ vice ” and “ praise ”] and the like: and this kind does not govern as a mSdr. (Expos. of the “ Kitáb Hodood enNahw, ” ubi suprà; and Expos. of the “ Shudhoor, ” ubi suprà.) It is also applied to [what is more properly termed AisomN lilomaEonaY AlHaASili biAlmaSodari, by some termed simply HaASilN biAlmaSodari, i. e. An ideal substantive, or abstract noun;] a noun applied to signify an accident [or attribute] considered abstractedly [such as SadarN signifying “ return; ” and this kind is commonly termed in the lexicons simply an Aisom as distinguished from a mSdr]. (Kull p. 327.) Some apply it also to what is [properly] termed maSodarN miymiY~N [i. e. A mSdr commencing with an augmentative m], if not of the measure mufaAEalapN: but such is really a maSodar. (Expos. of the “ Shudhoor, ” ubi suprà.) And some of the grammarians [and of the lexicographers likewise] apply it to A noun that signifies the instrument [or means] with [or by] which the action signified by a mSdr is performed: as AlA^ukolu [“ food, ” as being “ that by means of which the act of eating (AlA^akolu) is performed ”]. (Kull, ubi suprà.) ― -b5- See also SadorN, last sentence but two.

muSodirN *
muSodirN [act. part. n. of 4, q. v. ― -b2- ] (tropical:) A man who completes things or affairs. (A.) ＝ -A2- And One of the names of the month jumaAdaY AlA^uwlaY: (M, K:) [ISd says,] I think it to be of the dial. of [the tribe of] 'Ad. (M.)

maSodarapu Alqawomi *
maSodarapu Alqawomi (tropical:) Those who are made to have the precedence, or priority, of the people, or party. (A, TA.)

maSodariY~N *
[maSodariY~N, as a grammatical term, Of, or relating to, the maSodar. See the particles A^ano and kaYo &c.]

muSad~arN *
muSad~arN A man (M) strong in the chest; (S, M, K;) and in like manner a lion, (M, A,) and a wolf: (M:) and the lion; (S, K;) and the wolf; (K;) because they are strong in the chest. (TA.) ― -b2- See also A^aSodaru. ― -b3- A horse to whose breast the sweat has reached. (M, K.) ― -b4- A horse, and a sheep or goat, white in the upper part (lab~ap) of the breast: (M, K:) or (with p, A)
a ewe having a black breast, (M, A, K,) the rest of her being white. (M.) ― -b5- (tropical:) A horse that outreaches others (IAar, M, A, K) with his breast: (TA:) IAar does not mention the breast. (M, TA.) [Accord. to rule, this should be muSad~irN, as is shown by a verse cited above: see 5.] ― -b6- (tropical:) An arrow thick in the part called the Sador. (M, A, K.) ― -b7- And AlmuSad~aru is a name applied to (assumed tropical:) The first of the arrows termed gufol, (M, K,) which have no notches, and to which is assigned no portion [and no fine, in the game called Almayosir]; these being added only to give additional weight to the collection of arrows from a dislike of suspicion [of foul play]. (Lh, M. [See Als~afiyHu and AlmaniyHu.])

maSoduwrN *
maSoduwrN A man (A &c.) having a complaint of the chest. (S, A, Mgh, Msb.) 'Obeyd-Allah Ibn- 'Abd-Allah Ibn-'Otbeh, on its being said to him, How long wilt thou utter this poetry? replied,
laA bud~a lilomaSoduwri mino A^ano yasoEulaA
To him who has a complaint of the chest, there is no avoiding coughing. (TA. [See also nafava.]) ― -b2- It is also often used as meaning (assumed tropical:) Grieved, afflicted, or vexed. (TA in art. nfv.)

1 SadaEahu *
1. SadaEahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
SadaEa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. SadoEN, (S, * Msb, K, *) He clave, split, slit, or cracked, it [i. e. a hard thing, such as a glass vessel, and a wall, and the like of these; (see SadoEN below;) or so generally]; syn. $aq~ahu; (S, Msb, K;) as also Sd~Ehu↓, [but app. in an intensive sense, or relating to a number of objects,] inf. n. taSodiyEN: (TA:) or so as to divide it in halves: or so that it did not separate. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, SadaEahu SadoEa Alr~idaA='i [He slit it, or rent it, as with the slitting, or rending, of the garment called rdA']. (TA.) ― -b3- And SadaEa AlfalaApa (tropical:) He traversed, or crossed, the desert; [as though he clave it;] (S, Msb, K, TA;) and in like manner, Aln~ahora the river. (TA.) And h`*aA AlT~ariyqu yaSodaEu fiY A^aroDi ka*aA waka*aA (assumed tropical:) [This road extends through such and such a land]. (TA.) And SadaEa All~ayola, inf. n. as above, (tropical:) He journeyed during [or through] the night. (IKtt, TA.) ― -b4- SadoEN also signifies The act of separating, or dispersing, or scattering; (Msb;) and so taSodiyEN↓; (S, O;) syn. taforiyqN [with which each is probably syn. in other, but similar, senses]. (S, O, Msb.) One says, SadaEa Al$~aYo'a He, or it, separated, or dispersed, or scattered, the thing. (TA.) And SadaEotu Alqawoma, inf. n. SadoEN, (assumed tropical:) I separated, or dispersed, or scattered, the people, or party. (Msb.) And SadaEatohumu Aln~awaY means [in like manner] far~aqatohum [i. e. (tropical:) The place that was the object of the journey separated them from their homes &c.]; and so Sad~aEatohum↓; whence Alt~aSodaAEu [as an inf. n., like Alt~aSodiyEu]. (TA.) And SadaEotu Alganama SidoEatayoni (assumed tropical:) I separated, or divided, the sheep, or the goats, into two flocks or herds. (S, TA.) ― -b5- [And hence,] SadaEotu Al$~aYo'a (assumed tropical:) I made the thing distinct [as though separate from others], apparent, manifest, evident, clear, or plain: whence the saying of Aboo-Dhu-eyb in a verse cited in art. fyD, conj. 4. (S.) ― -b6- And SadaEa biAlHaq~i (tropical:) He spoke the truth openly, or aloud, (S, Msb, K, TA,) distinguishing, or discriminating, between it and falsehood: and thus Kh has expl. the verb as used in the verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb above referred to. (TA.) And SadaEa biAlA^amori, (K, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He made known the affair, or case, by speaking of it. (K, TA.) ― -b7- faA@SodaEo bimaA tuw^omaru, in the Kur [xv. 94], means (assumed tropical:) Therefore cleave thou, or divide thou, their congregation, [app. by separating the believers from the unbelievers, with that wherewith thou art charged, (bihi being understood after tw^mr,) i. e.,] with the declaration of the unity [of God]: (IAar, O, Msb, K:) or (assumed tropical:) distinguish thou therewith between the truth and falsehood: (AO, O, Msb, K:) or (assumed tropical:) dispense thou among them in their collective state [that wherewith thou art charged, i. e.] the announcement [of the unity &c.]: (TA:) or (assumed tropical:) reveal thou, or make manifest, (Fr, Zj, S, Msb, K, TA,) that with which thou art charged, (Zj, Msb, TA,) and fear not any one, (Zj, TA,) or the ordinance, i. e., (Fr, TA,) thy religion; (Fr, S, TA;) mA [with what follows it] being held by Fr, who thus explains the phrase, to occupy the place of an inf. n., namely, AlA^amor: (TA:) or (assumed tropical:) utter thou openly, or aloud, (O, K, TA,) that with which thou art charged, meaning, accord. to Ibn-Mujáhid, (TA,) the Kur-án: (O, K, TA:) in the R it is said to be from AlS~adiyEu meaning “ the daybreak; ” ignorance being likened to the darkness of night, and the Kur-án to light that cleaves that darkness: (TA:) or (assumed tropical:) order thou, or ordain, or decree, [that with which thou art charged, i. e.,] the truth: and (assumed tropical:) decide thou according to the ordinance [prescribed to thee]: (O, K, TA:) or (tropical:) direct thy course by that [revelation] with [the preaching of] which thou art charged: (O, K, TA:) so says Th, on the authority of an Arab of the desert; accord. to whom, (O, TA,) ― -b8- SadaEa fulaAnFA signifies (tropical:) He directed his course to such a one because of his generosity. (Th, O, K, TA.) ― -b9- SadaEa biAlA^amori, (K, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) also signifies (assumed tropical:) He hit, or attained, with the affair, its proper place [or object]. (K, TA.) ― -b10- And SadaEotu A_ilaY Al$~aYo'i, (AZ, S, K,) aor. as above, (AZ, S,) inf. n. SuduwEN, (assumed tropical:) I inclined to the thing. (AZ, S, K. *) ― -b11- And SadaEahu Eanohu (assumed tropical:) He, or it, turned him away from him, or it. (K.) One says, maA SadaEaka Eano h`*aA AlA^amori (assumed tropical:) What turned thee away from this affair? (S, O, TA:) and some say, mA Sadagaka, with the pointed g, which is better. (O, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also the next paragraph. ＝ -A3- And see SaAdiEN, last sentence.

2: see 1, in three places. ＝ -A2- [Freytag adds two other explanations of Sd~E: namely, “ Immisit, ” followed by an accus. and fY; taken by inference from the Ham p. 196, l. 12 from the bottom: and “ Rupit, perdidit; ” from Reiske's additions to Golius: but both of these require consideration.] ― -b2- [Sd~Ehu also signifies (assumed tropical:) It affected him with headache; as though it made his head to split.] One says, Sad~aEaniY A^aziyzu Alr~aHaY (assumed tropical:) [The sounding of the mill-stone affected me with headache]. And Sud~iEa, inf. n. taSodiyEN, (assumed tropical:) He (a man, S) was, or became, affected with SudaAE [or headache]; (S, O, K; [see the Kur lvi. 19;]) and SudiEa↓ [without teshdeed], pass. part. n. maSoduwEN↓, is allowable in poetry. 7. AnSdE [generally said of a hard thing, such as a glass vessel, and a wall, and the like of these, (see 1, first sentence,)] It became cloven, split, slit, or cracked; or, in an intrans. sense, it clave, split, slit, or cracked; syn. Aino$aq~a: (S, Msb, K:) [or so as to become divided in halves: or so that it did not separate: (see again 1, first sentence:)] as also tSd~E↓ [but app. in an intensive sense, meaning it became cloven &c., or it clave &c., much, or in several places]. SadoEN [originally an inf. n.] A cleft, split, slit, or crack, (Lth, S, O, K, TA,) [generally] in a hard thing, (Lth, O, K, TA,) such as a glass vessel, and a wall, and the like of these: pl. SuduwEN. (TA.) Hassán says, satirizing El-Hárith Ibn-'Owf El-Murree,
