mivolu Alz~ujaAjapi SadoEuhaA lamo yujobari
[And the fidelity of the Murree, where (meaning wherever) thou meetest him, is like the glass vessel, of which the crack is not repaired]. (O, TA.) ― -b2- And A part, or portion, separated, of a thing, (O, K, TA,) of sheep or goats, and the
like: (TA:) an inf. n. used as a subst. [properly thus termed]: (O, K, TA:) like xaloqN in the sense of maxoluwqN, &c. (O, TA.) ― -b3- And The plants of the earth; (K;) because they cleave it: (TA:) [i. e.] the plants from over which the earth cleaves: so in the phrase waA@lA^aroDi *aAti A@lS~adoEi, in the Kur lxxxvi. 12: (Bd:) or this phrase means And the earth which is cloven by the plants (Th, Bd, TA) and by the springs. (Bd.) ＝ -A2- And i. q. A_ilobN: (TA:) you say, Aln~aAsu Ealayohimo SadoEN waAHid, (K, TA,) and A_ilobN waAHidN [or A^alobN waAHidN], (TA,) The people are one company combined in hostility against them: (K, TA:) and in like manner waEolN wAHd and DilaEN wAHd: so says AZ. (TA.) ＝ -A3- And A man light of flesh; and so SadaEN↓, (S, K,) sometimes: (S:) or of middling stature, light of flesh: (Ks, TA:) like the mountain-goat thus termed. (TA.) ― -b2- See also SadaEN.

SidoEN *
SidoEN The half of a thing that is cloven, or split, or slit, in halves. (K, * TA. [See also SidoEapN.]) You say, SadaEa Al$~aYo'a SidoEayoni He clave, or split, or slit, the thing in halves. (TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A company of men. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) A woman who makes a division in the state of a people and does not repair it. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, TA.)

SadaEN *
SadaEN and SadoEN↓, (K,) or the former only, (S,) applied to a mountain-goat, and a gazelle, and an ass, [app. a wild ass,] (S, K,) and a camel, (K,) Of a middling size, neither great nor small, but between the two: (S:) or youthful and strong: [see also SadiyEN:] or [in the CK “ and ”] the former word signifies a thing of any sort between two things; between tall and short, and youthful and advanced in age, and fat and lean, and great and small. (K.) ― -b2- For the former word as applied to a man: see SadoEN. ― -b3- Also, thus applied Penetrating, sharp, or effective, in his affair. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [It is said that] SadaEN signifies also The SadaA^ [i. e. rust] of iron. (K.) [But this seems to be a mistake, which has arisen from what here follows.] It is said that [a certain person called] El-Uskuff [which generally means “ the bishop ”], being asked by 'Omar respecting the Khaleefehs, designated [him who was afterwards] the fourth of them ['Alee] as SadaEN mino HadiydK, meaning [lit.] thereby A mountain-goat of iron; using it as a hyperbolical appellation to denote his might and courage and endurance and hardness: or the phrase, as some relate it, is SadaA^N HadydN [which may be rendered, “ light or active in body ” (a meaning assigned to SadaA^N and SadaEN, the latter of which is said to be in this sense the original), and “ sharp ”]; or SadaA^u HadiydK [i. e. “ rust of iron, ” app. alluding to his frequent and long-continued wearing of mail and bearing of weapons]; which last is thought by As to be most probably correct. (O, * TA.)

SidoEapN *
SidoEapN The half of a thing that is cloven, split, or slit, in halves; as also SadiyEN↓. (K. [See also SidoEN.]) ― -b2- And A [herd such as is termed] Siromap of camels; (S, O, K;) and so SadiyEN↓: (S, O, K: *) or, accord. to AZ, a herd of camels amounting to sixty. (O, TA.) And A separate flock, or herd, of sheep or goats; as also SadiyEN↓: (S, O, K:) or, as some say, of these also, amounting to sixty: and it is said to signify also a herd of gazelles: (TA:) and SadiyEN↓ signifies also a herd of oxen [probably meaning wild oxen]. (O, TA.) ― -b3- One says also, Ealayohi SidoEapN mino maAlK i. e. [On him lies a debt of] a small amount of property. (TA.)

SadaEaAtN *
SadaEaAtN (tropical:) [Divisions in opinion &c.]. One says, bayonahumo SadaEaAtN fiY Alr~aA^oYi waAlhawaY (tropical:) Between them is division [in opinion and affection; or rather between them are divisions &c.]. (O, K, TA.) And A^aSoliHuwA maA fiykumo mina AlS~adaEaAti (tropical:) [Repair ye the divisions that are among you;] i. e. become ye in a state of unity. (O, TA.) And A_in~ahumo EalaY maA fiyhimo mina AlS~adaEaAti A^alib~aA='u kiraAmN (tropical:) [Verily they, notwithstanding the divisions that are among them, are intelligent and generous]. (TA.) [It is stated in the TA, among the additions to the K in this art., that one says also, A_in~ahumo EalaY maA taraY lakiraAmN mino SadaAEatihimo↓ app. as meaning (assumed tropical:) Verily they, notwithstanding what thou seest of their disunion, are generous: but I think it most probable that SadaAEatihimo is a mistranscription for SadaEaAtihimo.] ＝ -A2- [Reiske, as stated by Freytag, explains it as signifying also Camels going swiftly.]

SudaAEN *
SudaAEN (assumed tropical:) Headache: (S, O, Msb, K:) Er-Rághib says that it is like a splitting in the head by reason of pain; and is a metaphorical term. (TA.)

SadiyEN *
SadiyEN Either half of a garment, or piece of cloth, (O, K,) that is slit in halves: (O:) and a thing [$aYo'N accord. to the copies of the K, but I think that the right reading is $aYo'K i. e. “ of a thing, ”] that is cloven, or split, or slit, in halves: pl. SuduEN. (K.) See also SidoEapN, first sentence. It is also said to signify A [garment of the kind called] ridaA=', that is slit in halves. (TA.) And A new patch in an old and worn-out garment. (O, K.) And A garment much rent. (TA.) And A black garment which a wailing woman wears with a white garment beneath it, and which she rends at her bosom so that the white one appears: so says Kásim Ibn-Thábit. (TA.) And A garment that is worn beneath the coat of mail. (O, K.) And A shirt [of a middling size] between two shirts, neither large nor small. (TA.) ― -b2- See also SidoEapN, second and third sentences, in three places. ― -b3- Accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, (O,) applied to a mountain-goat, it signifies Youthful: and (some say, O) of middling size; syn. marobuwEu Alxaloqi; (O, K, TA;) i. e. between two [in size]; like SadaEN [q. v.]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also (assumed tropical:) Daybreak: (S, O, K:) because it cleaves the night. (O.) ＝ -A3- And Fresh milk which is put in a place, and becomes cool, and overspread by a thin skin: (O, K:) so called because you skim off (taSodaEu, lit. “ cleave, ”) that thin skin from the clear milk. (O.)

SadaAEapN *
SadaAEapN: see a saying mentioned above, voce SadaEaAtN.

SaAdiEN *
SaAdiEN [act. part. n. of SadaEa; Cleaving, splitting, &c.] ― -b2- [Hence,] applied to a valley, (O, K,) and a road, or way, (sabiylN, O, TA, in the K erroneously written sayolN [a torrent], TA, [or both may be correct,]) and a mountain, (K, TA, [in the O, HabolN is put for jabalN,]) (assumed tropical:) Extending far along the earth. (O, K, TA.) ― -b3- And, applied to the daybreak, (assumed tropical:) Shining, or bright; syn. mu$oriqN. (IDrd, O, K.) ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) One who decides, or judges, between, or among, a people, or party. (TA.) ― -b5- A poet (qys bn *ryH) says,
falam~aA badaA minohaA AlfiraAqu kamaA badaA
biZahori AlS~afaA AlS~alodi Al$~uquwqu AlS~awaAdiEu
[i. e. And when separation from her appeared, like as appear the cleaving cracks in the surface of the hard and smooth rock]: it may be that SadaEa↓ is syn. with taSad~aEa in some dial. [and that SawaAdiE is pl. of its part. n.]: or this may be an instance of a possessive epithet, meaning having a cleaving. (TA.)

entry.key: huwa A^aSodaEuhumo biAlS~awaAbi fiY A^asoraEi jawaAbK

superEntry.entry:
huwa A^aSodaEuhumo biAlS~awaAbi fiY A^asoraEi jawaAbK *
huwa A^aSodaEuhumo biAlS~awaAbi fiY A^asoraEi jawaAbK (assumed tropical:) [app. He is the most effective of them in deciding rightly in a most quick answer]. (TA.)

maSodaEN *
maSodaEN (tropical:) A smooth, or plain, road, in a rugged tract of ground: pl. maSaAdiEu. (IDrd, O, K, TA.)

miSodaEN *
miSodaEN A [sort of arrow-head, or arrow, such as is termed] mi$oqaS [q. v.]: pl. maSaAdiEu. (IDrd, O, K.) Hence the quiver is called xaAbiy^apu AlmaSaAdiEi [The concealer, or guarder, of the mSAdE]. (TA.) ― -b2- daliylN miSodaEN (assumed tropical:) A guide going his way [app. with energy]. (TA.) ― -b3- And xaTiybN miSodaEN (assumed tropical:) An orator, or a preacher, perspicuous, (O, K, TA,) eloquent, (K, TA,) and bold in speech. (TA.)

maSoduwEN *
maSoduwEN: see 2, last sentence.

1 Sadagotuhu *
1. Sadagotuhu, (A'Obeyd, S, O, K, *) aor.
Sadaga
, (K,) inf. n. SadogN, (TK,) [may be rendered I walked, or went along, cheek by jole with him; lit.] I had my Sudog [or temple] over against his (another man's) in walking, or going along. (A'Obeyd, S, O, K *) [See also 3. Accord. to Golius, it means also I overtook him, and joined myself to him by his side: but for this explanation he names no authority.] ― -b2- And Sadagahu, aor. as above [and probably
Saduga
also, like that of damagahu], and inf. n. as above, He struck his Sudog [or temple]. (TA.) ― -b3- And Sudiga, like EuniYa, inf. n. as above, He had a complaint of his Sudog [or temple]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Sadagahu Eani AlA^amori He turned him away, or back, from the affair. (K. [And so, accord. to Freytag, as from the S, on the authority of As, ASdgh: but he has app. taken this from a mistranscription in a copy of the S.]) One says, maA Sadagaka Eano h`*aA AlA^amori What turned thee away, or back, from
this affair? (As, S, O:) and SadaEaka also: (S and O in art. SdE:) but the former is the better. (O in that art.) And Ait~abaEa fulaAnN baEiyrahu famaA Sadagahu i. e. [Such a one followed his camel, and] he did not turn him aside: this is said when he has taken fright, or become refractory, and run away. (As, S, O.) And Selemeh is related to have said, Ai$otarayotu sin~aworFA falamo yaSodagohun~a [I bought a cat, and he did not drive them away]; meaning the rats, or mice. (O.) ― -b2- One says also, fulaAnN maA yaSodagu namolapF Such a one does not kill an ant; (S, K; *) by reason of his weakness. (S.) ― -b3- And Sadagahu, inf. n. as above, He straightened his, or its, Sadag, i. e. crookedness, and bending, or inclining. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Sadaga A_ilaY Al$~aYo'i, inf. n. SuduwgN, He inclined to the thing. (TA.) And Sadaga Eano Tariyqihi He declined from his way, or road. (TA.) ＝ -A4- Saduga, aor.
Saduga
, (S, O, K,) inf. n. SadaAgapN, (S, O,) He (a man, S, O,) was, or became, weak. (S, O, K.) [See its part. n. SadiygN.]

3 SAdghu *
3. SAdghu i. q. daAraAhu [He treated him with gentleness, or blandishment; soothed, coaxed, wheedled, or cajoled, him; &c.]: or EaAraDahu fiY Alma$oYi [he went along over against him]: (K:) Ibn-'Abbád says that SaAdagotu Alr~ajula means daArayotuhu: and he adds, wahiYa AlmuEaAraDapu fiY Alma$oYi: (O: [but the right reading seems to be A^awo hiYa:]) accord. to the A, one says, SaAdagotuhu fiY Alma$oYi SudogiY liSudogihi [I walked, or went along, with him, my temple towards his temple]. (TA.) [See also 1, first sentence.]

SudogN *
SudogN [The temple; i. e.] the part between the eye and the ear; (S, O, K;) the part between the outer angle of the eye and the root (A^aSol) of the ear; (A, Msb;) the part of the head that slopes down to the place of attachment of the jaws; as expl. by AZ, it is [from] the place of juncture between the lHyp [app. a mistranscription for laHoY i. e. jaw, agreeably with the explanation next preceding,] and [the main portion of] the head, to the part beneath the qaron [which is the temporal ridge]; (TA;) each of what are termed the SudogaAni: (AZ, A, TA:) ISd mentions also Sudug↓, as occurring in poetry, and expresses a doubt whether it be, or be not, peculiar to poetry: (TA:) and sometimes they said sudogN, with s: Ktr says that certain persons of the Benoo-Temeem, called Bel'ambar [a contraction of Benu-l-'Ambar], change s into S [or use these two letters indiscriminately] when followed by any of the letters T and q and g and x, whether the latter be second or third or fourth; saying siraATN and SiraATN, and basoTapN and baSoTapN, and sayoqalN and SayoqalN, &c.: (S, O:) the pl. is A^aSodaAgN (S, O, Msb, TA, [in all except the Msb mentioned after the signification expl. in the next sentence, and properly a pl. of pauc.,]) and also A^aSodugN [which is probably used only as a pl. of pauc.]. (TA.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) The hair that hangs down upon the place above-mentioned. (S, O, Msb, K.) One says SudogN muEaqorabN (tropical:) [A curled lock of hair hanging down upon the temple]. (S, O, TA.)

SadagN *
SadagN Crookedness, and bending, or inclining. (TA. [See 1, near the end.])

SudugN *
SudugN: see SudogN.

SadaAgN *
SadaAgN A mark made with a hot iron upon the Sudog [or temple, of a camel], (S, O, K, TA,) or, as in the A, upon the even part of the Sudog, lengthwise. (TA.)

SadiygN *
SadiygN an epithet applied to a child (S, K) In the stage extending to his completion of seven days: (S:) or that is seven days old: (Mgh, O, K:) because his temple becomes firm (ya$otad~u Sudoguhu) only to this period, (so in the O, [and the like is said in the Mgh,]) or because his temples are not bound (laA yu$ad~u SudogaAhu) save for seven days: (so in the TA:) or it may be an instance of faEiylN in the sense of mafoEuwlN from Sadagahu Eani Al$~aYo'i meaning “ he turned him away, or back, from the thing. ” (O.) ― -b2- And [hence, perhaps,] Weak. (S, O, K.)

AlA^aSodagaAni *
AlA^aSodagaAni [The two temporal arteries;] two veins beneath the SudogaAni [or two temples], (O, K,) which, as is said by As, are always pulsing, in everyone in the world: a word having no sing., like as they say of Almi*orawaAni. (O.)

miSodagN *
miSodagN: see what next follows.

miSodagapN *
miSodagapN A pillow, or cushion; (S, O, K;) because placed beneath the Sudog [or temple]; also pronounced misodagapN; and sometimes they said mizodagapN; (S, O;) and [miSodagN↓ and] misodagN and mizodagN signify the same. (TA in art. sdg.)

maSod~agN *
maSod~agN, and its fem.: see what follows.

maSoduwgN *
maSoduwgN, A camel marked with the mark termed SidaAg; as also muSad~agN↓: (K, * TA:) or the former is applied in this sense to a camel, and muSad~agapN↓ in like manner to camels. (ISh, O, TA.)

1 Sadafa Ean~iY *
1. Sadafa Ean~iY, (S, O,) or Eanohu, (Msb, K,) aor.
Sadifa
, (O, K,) He turned away from, avoided, shunned, and left, (S, O, Msb, K,) me, (S, O,) or him, or it; (Msb, K;) so the verb signifies in the Kur vi. 158 [and a similar instance occurs in verse 46 of the same chap.]; (O;) and so Eanohu tSd~f↓: (O, * K:) and (so in the K [but more properly “ or ”]) Sadafa, (A'Obeyd, M, O, K,) aor.
Sadifa
(M, K) and
Sadufa
, (K,) inf. n. SadofN and SuduwfN, (M, O, K, TA, [SadafFA in the CK is a mistake,]) he turned away, (A'Obeyd, M, O, K, TA,) or became turned away, or back, (O, K, TA,) and declined, (K, TA,) Eanohu from it, (M, O,) namely, a thing; (O;) said of a man. (K.) And Sadafato, said of a woman, She turned away her face. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- See also 4. ＝ -A3- SadafN is an inf. n. (S, M, O, Msb) of which the verb is Sadifa, (M, Msb,) and from which is derived the epithet A^aSodafu↓ applied to a horse, or to a camel: (S, M, O:) it signifies, in relation to a horse, The having the thighs near together, and the hoofs far apart, with a twisting of the pasterns (S, O, K:) or a crookedness in the fore legs: (M:) or an inclining in the hoof towards the off side: (ISk, S, M, Mgh, O, K:) or an inclining of the foot (As, S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K) of the fore leg or of the kind leg (As, S, M, O, Msb) of the camel, towards the off side; (As, S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) if towards the near side, the epithet applied to him is A^aqofadu, (As, S, O, K,) and the verb is qafida, inf. n. qafadN: (TA:) or an inclining in the qadam [or human foot]; As says, I know not whether from the right or from the left: or an approaching of one of the knees towards the other; thus, peculiarly, in the horse: or a nearness together of [the two tendons called] the EujaAyataAni, and a wideness apart of the hoofs, with a twisting of the pasterns; one of the natural faults of horses: (M:) (Mtr says,] as meaning a twisting in the neck, I have not found it. (Mgh.)

3 SAdfhu *
3. SAdfhu, (S, O, K, TA,) inf. n. muSaAdafapN, (M, TA,) He found him; or lighted on him; syn. wajadahu; (S, O, K, TA;) namely, another man; (S, O;) and laqiyahu [which may also be rendered he met with him; or encountered him]; (O, K, TA;) and waAfaqahu [which signifies the same]. (M, * TA, and S and K in art. wfq.) One says, SaAdafotu fulaAnFA bimawoDiEi ka*aA I found, or met with, such a one in such a place; syn. waAfaqotuhu. (TA in art. wfq.) And SaAdafota A^amoraka muwaAfiqFA liA_iraAdatika [Thou foundest thine affair, or thy case, suitable to thy wish; i. e., foundest it to be so: thus, in this instance, and in many others, like its syns. wajadota and laqiyta, the verb has two objective complements]. (S * and K * and TA in art. wfq.) ― -b2- And muSaAdafapN signifies also The being opposite, one to another; or the facing one another; or the matching one another; syn. muHaA*aApN. (TA.)

4 ASdfhu *
4. ASdfhu He, or it, turned him away, (S, M, O, K,) or back; or caused him to return, go back, or revert; (K, TA;) Eanohu from it; (M;) and Sadafahu↓, (O, K,) inf. n. SadofN, (O,) signifies the same; (O, K;) the latter verb being trans. as well as intrans., but when trans. having only one inf. n., that mentioned above. (O.) One says, A^aSodafaniY Eanohu ka*aA waka*aA Such and such things turned me away from it. (S, O.)

5 tSd~f *
5. tSd~f: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Also I. q. taEar~aDa: (TA:) in the saying of Muleyh ElHudhalee,
falam~aA A@sotawato A^aHomaAluhaA wataSad~afatN
bi$um~i AlmaraAqiY baAridaAti AlmadaAxili
[app. describing a she-camel, or a number of camels, meaning And when her, or their, burdens were, or became, adjusted, or firm or steady, and she, or they, went alternately to the right and left, (see the phrase taEar~aDati AlA_ibilu AlmadaArija, in art. ErD,) in the high places of ascent, cold in the
entrances thereof, because of their height], Skr says, taSad~afato means taEar~aDato. (M, TA.)

6 taSaAdafaA *
6. taSaAdafaA, said of two sides of a mountain, They met together, and faced each other. (TA.)

SadafN *
SadafN inf. n. of Sadifa [q. v.]. (M, Msb.) ＝ -A2- Also Anything high, or lofty, (As, S, M, O, K,) such as a wall and a mountain, (M,) or such as a wall and the like; (K;) like what is termed hadafN: (As, S, O:) and the side of a mountain: (M:) or SadafN and hadafN both signify any building or structure, that is high, or lofty, and great; (A'Obeyd, TA;) accord. to Az, likened to the Sadaf of a mountain, which is the side that faces one, thereof: (TA:) and SadafN and SudufN↓ (S, M, O, K) and SudafN↓ and SadufN↓, (O, K,) accord. to different readings of a passage in the Kur, (S, M, O, K,) [xviii. 95,] in which the dual occurs, (S, M, O,) signify the place of ending, or breaking off, (S, O, K,) of a mountain, (K,) or of a lofty mountain: (S, O:) or the side of a mountain: (K:) or the part between two mountains: (M:) or, as used in this instance, (K, TA,) in the verse of the Kur, (TA,) AlS~adafaAni, (M, K,) as also AlS~udufaAni↓, (M,) means two mountains (M, L, K) meeting together, (M, L, TA,) in the copies of the K, mutalaAziqaAni [i. e. cleaving together], but the correct reading is mutalaAqiyaAni, as in the L [and M], (TA,) between Ya-jooj and Ma-jooj: (M, L, K, TA:) and AlS~udufaAni↓, (M, K,) with damm to the d (M,) i. e. with two dammehs, especially, (K,) or this as well as AlS~adafaAni, (TA,) means the two sides of the $iEob [app. here meaning ravine, or gap, between two mountains], or of the valley: (M, K, TA:) so says IDrd: (M, TA:) both signify the two sides of the mountain when they [meet together, and] face each other, so called litaSaAdufihimaA, i. e. because of their meeting together, and facing each other, having between them a [road such as is termed] faj~, or a $iEob [expl. above], or a valley. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Also [The mother-of-pearl shell; or oyster-shell; and any shell of a mollusk: and, by an extension of its primary application, the oyster itself; and any shell-fish, or testaceous mollusk of the water, and likewise of the land:] the cover of the pearl; (K;) or this is called Sadafu Ald~ur~api, (S, O,) or Sadafu Ald~ur~i; (Msb;) a kind of cover created in the sea, composed of [what are termed] SadafataAni [i. e. a pair of shell-valves], which are opened from [i. e. so as to disclose] a kind of flesh in which is life, called the maHaArap [i. e. oyster], and in the like thereof are found pearls; (Lth, TA;) i. q. maHaArN [which means oyster-shells, and also oysters themselves, and both of these may be here meant, as both are correct meanings of SadafN]: (M:) n. un. with p: (S, M, O, Msb, K:) [in the Msb it is also said that AlS~adafapu signifies the maHaArap, which is the maHomil of the pilgrims; but I think that this is a mistake, caused by understanding maHaArap here in a wrong sense; for I find no other authority for assigning this meaning to AlS~adafapu:] pl. A^aSodaAfN. (O, K.) [See an ex. of the pl. voce HalazuwnN.] ― -b2- [Hence,] AlS~adafapu signifies also, (M, TA,) or Sadafapu AlA^u*uni, (O,) The maHaArap [or concha, i. e. the external, deep, and wide, cavity, around the hole,] of the ear. (M, O, TA.) ― -b3- [And hence, also,] AlS~adafataAni signifies The two small hollows, or sockets, in each of which is set the head of one of the two thing-bones, and in each of which is a ligament (EaSabapN [app. that called ligamentum teres, forming a tie]) to that head. (M, TA.) [And in like manner, The two sockets in the scapula, in each of which turns the head of one of the two upper arm-bones: (see HaAriqapN:) or these, it seems, are called by some AlS~adafaAni; for it is said that] AlS~adafu signifies the part of the scapula which is the place of the waAbilap. (O, K.) ― -b4- And SadafN also signifies (tropical:) Flesh, (O,) or a piece of flesh, (K, TA,) growing in a wound of the head, next the skull, resembling the cartilages. (O, K.) ＝ -A4- And in the Tekmileh it is said that [the pl.] A^aSodaAfN signifies Waves of the sea. (TA.) ＝ -A5- See also SudafN.

SadufN *
SadufN: see SadafN, second sentence.

SudafN *
SudafN: see SadafN, second sentence. ＝ -A2- Also, i. e. like SuradN, (O, K,) or SadafN↓, (so in a copy of the M,) A species of animal of prey: (M, O, K: *) or, as some say, a bird. (M, O, K.)

SudufN *
SudufN: see SadafN, in three places.

SadafiY~N *
SadafiY~N A camel of a certain sort, (M, K, *) of excellent quality, (K,) [ISd says,] so called, (M, K,) I think, in relation to a tribe of Arabs of El-Yemen, (M,) or in relation to a sub-tribe (baTon) of Kindeh, (K,) called AlS~adifu. (M, K.) [See also SarafiY~N.] ＝ -A2- [Also a rel. n. from SadafN; Testaceous.]

SaduwfN *
SaduwfN A woman who turns away her face (Lh, M, Msb) from her husband: (Lh, M:) or a woman who turns her face towards one and then turns away: (S, O, K:) or a woman who desires not kisses: (M:) or having a stinking mouth, (Lh, Ibn-'Abbád, M, O, K,) as an epithet applied to a female, (Lh, M,) or to a male: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) applied in this last sense to a man because he turns away his face whenever any one speaks to him. (TA.) ― -b2- And A she-camel that will not come to the watering-trough until it is left to her unoccupied: like SaruwmN. (TA in art. Srm. [See also what next follows.])

SawaAdifu *
SawaAdifu [pl. of SaAdifapN] Camels that come to others at the drinking-trough, and wait at their rumps until the drinkers have gone away, that they may go in. (S, O. [See also what next precedes.])

A^aSodafu *
A^aSodafu: see SadafN, in the first paragraph.

muSad~afN *
muSad~afN meaning One often attacked by diseases is a word used by the vulgar. (TA.)

maSoduwfN *
maSoduwfN Veiled, or concealed; covered; or protected; syn. masotuwrN. (TA.)

1 Sadaqa *
1. Sadaqa, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) aor.
Saduqa
, (M, TA,) inf. n. SidoqN (S, * M, O, * Msb, K, TA) and SadoqN, (M, K,) the former of which is the more chaste, (TA,) or the latter is an inf. n. and the former is a simple subst., (K,) and taSodaAqN (M) and maSoduwqapN, (O, K, TA,) which is one of the [few] inf. ns. of the measure mafoEuwlapN, (O, TA,) [or a fem. pass. part. n. used as an inf. n. like as is said of its contr. mako*uwbapN,] he spoke, said, uttered, or told, truth, or truly, or veraciously; contr. of ka*aba: (Msb: [and in like manner it is said in the S and M and O and K that SidoqN is the contr. of ka*ibN:]) Er-Rághib says that SidoqN and ka*ibN are primarily in what is said, whether relating to the past or to the future, and [in the latter case] whether it be a promise or other than a promise; and only in what is said in the way of information: but sometimes they are in other modes of speech, such as asking a question, and commanding, and supplicating; as when one says, “ Is Zeyd in the house? ” for this implies information of his being ignorant of the state of Zeyd; and when one says, “ Make me to share with thee, or to be equal with thee, ” for this implies his requiring to be made to share with the other, or to be made equal with him; and when one says, “ Do not thou hurt me, ” for this implies that the other is hurting him: SidoqN, he says, is [by implication] the agreeing of what is said with what is conceived in the mind and with the thing told of, together; otherwise it is not complete Sidoq, but may be described either as Sidoq or sometimes as Sidoq and sometimes as ka*ib according to two different points of view; as when one says without believing it, “ Mohammad is the Apostle of God, ” for this may be termed Sidoq because what is told is such, and it may be termed ka*ib because it is at variance with what the speaker conceives in his mind. (TA.) One says, Sadaqa fiY AlHadiyvi [He spoke truth in the information, or narration]. (S, O, K.) And Sadaqahu i. e. He told him, or informed him, with truth, or veracity, (AHeyth, * M, Msb, *) fiY Alqawoli [in the saying]; for it is trans. as well as intrans. (Msb.) And Sadaqahu AlHadiyva (S, O, K, in the CK [erroneously] Sad~aqa fulAnFA AlHadiyva) He told him with truth, or veracity, the information, or narration; for it is sometimes doubly trans. (TA.) And SadaqaniY sin~a bakorihi [He hath told me truly the age, or as to the age, of his youthful camel; or SadaqaniY sin~u bakorihi the age of his youthful camel has spoken truly to me]: (S, O, K:) a prov., (S, O,) expl. in art. bkr [q. v.]. (K.) And fulaAnN laA yaSoduqu A^avaruhu and A^avarahu, meaning Such a one, when asked, will not tell truly whence he comes. (M.) And Sadaqato yamiynuhu His oath was, or proved, true. (Msb in art. bt.) Sadaqotu A@ll~`ha HadiyvFA A_ino lamo A^afoEalo ka*aA is an oath of the Arabs, meaning laA Sadaqotu Alx [May I not utter truly to God a saying, i. e. may I not speak truth to God, if I do not such a thing]. (AHeyth, O, K.) One says also, Sadaqahu Aln~aSiyHapa, and AlA_ixaA='a, He rendered to him truly, or sincerely, good advice, and brotherly affection. (M.) And Sada quwhumu AlqitaAla (S, M, K, * TA) [They gave them battle earnestly,
not with a false show of bravery; as is implied in the S, and M, and K; i. e.] they advanced against them boldly in fight: (M, TA:) and in like manner, SadaquwA fiY AlqitaAli they advanced boldly in fight: or, accord. to Er-Rághib, the former means they gave them battle so as to fulfil their duty: and hence, in the Kur [xxxiii. 23], rijaAlN SadaquwA maA EaAhaduwA A@ll~`ha Ealayohi, Men who fulfilled the covenant that they had made with God. (TA.) And Sadaqa All~iqaA='a, inf. n. SidoqN, He was firm, or steady, in encounter, or conflict. (M, TA.) And Sadaqa Zan~iY My opinion was, or proved, true, or correct, like as one says [in the contrary case], ka*aba: (Er-Rághib, TA:) whence, in the Kur [xxxiv. 19], walaqado Sadaqa Ealayohimo A_iboliysu Zan~ahu, meaning fiY Zan~ihi [i. e. And assuredly Iblees was, or proved to be, correct in his opinion that he had formed against them]: but some read Sad~aqa↓, meaning, as Fr says, Haq~aqa [i. e. Iblees proved, or found, to be true, his opinion &c.]. (TA.) And Sadaqatohu nafosuhu His soul [told him truth; meaning,] diverted him, or hindered him, or held him back, from an undertaking, causing him to imagine himself unable to prosecute it. (TA in art. k*b.) And Sadaqa AlS~uboHu [The dawn shone clearly]. (S in art. sqT.) [And one says of a word or the like, yaSoduqu EalaY ka*aA, meaning It applies correctly to such a thing.] ― -b2- Sadaqa AlwaHo$iY~u: see 2, near the end.

2 Sd~qhu *
2. Sd~qhu, (S, M, O, &c.,) inf. n. taSodiyqN, contr. of ka*~abahu. (O, * K.) [This explanation implies several meanings here following.] He attributed, or ascribed, to him truth, veracity, or the speaking truth. (Msb.) And He said to him, “ Thou hast spoken truth. ” (Msb.) He accepted, or admitted, [or assented to, or believed,] what he said: (M:) you say, Sd~qhu fiY Hadiyvihi [He accepted, &c., what he said in his information, or narration]: (S:) and you say Sd~q bilisaAnihi [He assented to the truth of what was said with his tongue]; as well as biqalobihi [with his heart, or mind]. (T in art. Aamn.) He held him to be a speaker of truth. (MA.) [He found him to be a speaker of truth. He, or it, proved him to be a speaker of truth; verified him; or confirmed the truth of what he said: see an ex. in a verse cited voce bayonN.] He found it (an opinion) to be true, or veritable. (Ksh and Bd and Jel, in xxxiv. 19.) He verified it; confirmed its truth; or proved it to be true, or veritable; i. e. an opinion [&c.]; syn. Haq~aqahu: (Ksh and Bd, ibid.:) one says, Sad~aqa Alxabara Alxuboru [The trial, proof, or test, verified the information]. (S in art. xbr.) See 1, near the end. In the saying in the Kur [xxxix. 34], waA@l~a*iY jaA='a biAlS~idoqi waSad~aqa bihi, [which seems to be best rendered But he who hath brought the truth and he who hath accepted it as the truth, (see ka*~aba biAlA^amori,)] 'Alee the son of Aboo-Tálib is related to have said that by Al*Y jA=' bAlSdq is meant Mohammad; and by Al*Y Sd~q bh, Aboo-Bekr: or, as some say, Gabriel and Mohammad [are meant by the former and the latter respectively]: or by the former, Mohammad; and by the latter, [every one of] the believers: (M:) accord. to Er-Rághib, by wSd~q bh is meant and hath found, or proved, to be true (Haq~aqa) that which he hath brought by word, by that which he hath aimed at (bimaA taHar~aAhu) by deed. (TA.) ― -b2- Sd~q is also said to signify He said, “ This thing is the truth; ” like Haq~aqa. (TA in art. Hq.) ― -b3- And this verb also denotes AlmubaAlagapu fiY AlS~idoqi: thus in the saying,
Sad~aqato fiyhimo ZunuwniY
[My opinions respecting them were, or proved to be, very true or correct]. (Ksh, in xxxiv. 19.) ― -b4- Sd~q AlwaHo$iY~u, (O, K, TA,) or Sadaqa↓, (so in a copy of the M,) (tropical:) The wild animal ran without looking aside, when charged upon, or attacked: (M, O, K, TA:) mentioned by IDrd. (O, TA.) ＝ -A2- Sad~aqahumo He exacted from them the poor-rate. (TA. [See SadaqapN.]) ― -b2- See also 5.

3 SaAdaqotuhu *
3. SaAdaqotuhu, (M,) inf. n. muSaAdaqapN (S, M, O, K) and SidaAqN, (M, O, K,) the latter like kitaAbN, (TA, [in the CK erroneously written SadAq,]) I acted, or associated, with him as a friend, or as a true, or sincere, friend. (S, * M, O, * K. *) [See also 6.]

4 ASdq AlmaroA^apa *
4. ASdq AlmaroA^apa He named for the woman a SadaAq [or dowry]: (S, M, * O, K:) or he gave her her SadaAq: (M, * Msb:) or he appointed her, or assigned her, a SadaAq, on taking her as his wife: (TA:) and he married her, or took her as his wife, on the condition of his giving her a SadaAq. (Msb.) And sometimes this verb is doubly trans.; whence, in a trad., maA *aA tuSodiquhaA faqaAla A_izaAriY [It was said, “ What is it that thou meanest for her, or givest her, as her dowry? ” and he said, “ My waist-wrapper ”]. (Mgh.)

5 tSd~q Ealayohi *
5. tSd~q Ealayohi He gave him (i. e. the poor, Mgh, Msb) what is termed Sadaqap, (M, Mgh, Msb,) meaning [an alms, or] what is given for the sake of God, (M,) or what is given with the desire of obtaining a recompense from God: (M, * Mgh:) and Elyh Sad~aqa↓ signifies the same; (M, TA;) and in this sense Sd~q is [said by some to be] used in the Kur lxxv. 31. (TA.) Hence, in the Kur [xii. 88], wataSad~aqo EalayonaA: (TA:) or this means (assumed tropical:) And do thou confer a favour upon us by giving that which is [not like the mean merchandise that we have brought, but of middling quality,] between good and bad. (M.) One says, taSad~aqotu bika*aA, meaning I gave such a thing as a Sadaqap. (Msb.) See an ex. voce $iq~N. The saying, in a trad., A_in~a A@ll~`ha taSad~aqa Ealayokumo bivuluvi A^amowaAlikumo, meaning (tropical:) [Verily God] hath conferred a favour [upon you by giving you a third of your possessions to bequeath to whom ye will], if correct, is tropical. (Mgh.) ― -b2- It is said by Ibn-Es-Seed, on the authority of AZ and IJ, and mentioned by IAmb, that tSd~q signifies also He asked, or begged, for what is termed Sadaqap [or alms]: but Fr and As and others disallow the beggar's being called mutaSad~iq: (Az, TA:) IKt says that the verb is improperly used in this sense by the vulgar: (Msb:) [and accord. to J and Sgh,] one says, mararotu birajulK yasoA^alu, and one should not say yataSad~aqu. (S, O.)

6 taSaAduqN *
6. taSaAduqN signifies The acting, or associating, as friends, or as true, or sincere, friends, one with another. (K. [See also 3.]) And I. q. SidoqN: (TA:) [or rather mutual Sidoq; contr. of takaA*ubN:] one says, taSaAdaqaA fiY AlHadiyvi and fiY Almawad~api (S, O, TA) They were true, or sincere, each to the other, in information, or narration, and in love, or affection; contr. of takaA*abaA. (O, TA.)

SadoqN *
SadoqN is an inf. n. of Sadaqa [q. v.]: (M, K:) ― -b2- and is used as an epithet, applied to a man &c.: (S, M, O, K, TA:) [and] SidoqN↓ [also, if not a mistranscription for SadoqN,] is an inf. n. used as an epithet, applied to a man and to a woman: (so in a copy of the M and in the TA:) [it is said that] the former signifies Hard, (S, M, O, Msb,) applied to a spear, (S, M, O,) and to other things: (M:) or even, or straight; (S, O;) or it signifies thus also, applied to a spear, and to a sword: (M:) or hard and even or straight, applied to a spear, (K, TA,) and to a man, (K,) or to the latter as meaning hard: or, as IB says, on the authority of IDrst, it is not from hardness, but means combining those qualities that are commended; and it is applied to a spear as meaning long and pliant and hard, and the like; and to a man, and to a woman likewise [without p, but see what follows], as meaning true in hardness and strength and goodness; for, IDrst says, if it meant hard, one would say HajarN SadoqN and HadiydN SadoqN, which one does not: (TA:) and, applied to anything, (O, K, TA,) it means complete, or perfect, (Kh, O, K, TA,) thus applied to a man, (TA,) such as is commended; (O;) fem. with p, (O, K, TA,) applied to a woman: (O:) the pl. is SudoqN, applied to a company of men, (S, O, K,) and SuduqN (K) and Sadoquwna, so applied, and SadoqaAtN applied to women: (O, K:) and Ru-beh says, describing asses,
maqo*uw*apu AlA=*aAni SadoqaAtu AlHadaqo
meaning [Rounded, as though pared, in the ears,] penetrating in the eyes; (O, TA;) which is [said to be] tropical. (TA.) SadoqN signifies also Firm, or steady, in encounter, or conflict: (M:) or one says Sadoqu All~iqaA='i, applying this epithet to a man, (S, O, K, TA,) meaning thus: (TA:) and Sadoqu Aln~aZari [firm, or steady, in look]. (S, O, K, TA. [Said in the TA to be tropical.])

SidoqN *
SidoqN is an inf. n. of Sadaqa [q. v.]: (M, K, &c.:) or a simple subst., (K,) signifying [Truth; veracity; or] agreement of what is said with what is conceived in the mind and with the thing told of, together; otherwise it is not complete Sidoq, as expl. above in the first paragraph of this art. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b2- It is also syn. with $id~apN [meaning Hardness; firmness, compactness, or soundness; strength, power, or force; vigour, robustness, sturdiness, or hardiness; and courage, bravery, or firmness of heart]: (K, TA: [in the latter of which it is said to be tropical; but this is
evidently not the case accord. to the O, in which it is said that it radically denotes quw~apN (i. e. strength, force, &c.,) in a saying &c.: in the K it is implied by the context that it is syn. with $id~ap when used as the complement of a prefixed n. in instances mentioned in what here follows: but Sgh says, more correctly,]) a noun signifying anything to which goodness is attributed is prefixed to Sidoq, governing it in the gen. case; so that one says (O) rajulu SidoqK (Sb, M, O, K) [A man of good nature or disposition or character &c.], contr. of rajulu sawo'K; (Sb, M;) and Sadiyqu SidoqK [a friend of good nature &c.]; (O, K;) and likewise AimoraA^apu SidoqK [a woman of good nature &c.]; (K;) and in like manner also HimaAru SidoqK [an ass of a good kind]; (Sb, M, K;) and vawobu SidoqK [a garment, or piece of cloth, of good quality]. (Sb, M.) The saying in the Kur [x. 93], (O,) walaqado baw~aA^onaA baniY AisoraAy^iyla mubaw~aA^a SidoqK means And verily we assigned to the Children of Israel a good place of abode. (O, K.) ― -b3- See also SadoqN.

SadoqapN *
SadoqapN: see SadaAqN; each in two places.

SudoqapN *
SudoqapN: see SadaAqN; each in two places.

SadaqapN *
SadaqapN [An alms; i. e.] a gift (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K) to the poor (S, O, Msb) for the sake of God, (M, K,) or to obtain a recompense from God; (M, * Mgh, K; *) a portion which a man gives forth from his property by way of propitiation, [to obtain the favour of God,] like zakaApN, except that the former is primarily applied to such as as is supererogatory, and the latter to such as is obligatory: but it is said to be applied to such as is obligatory [i. e. to the zakaAp, q. v., meaning the poor-rate, which is the portion, or amount, of property, that is given therefrom, as the due of God, by its possessor, to the poor, according to a fixed rate,] when the person who does so aims at conformity with the truth in his deed: (Er-Rághib, TA:) [in this latter sense, which is indicated in the S and O &c., and more plainly in the M, it is very frequently used:] and thus it is used in the Kur ix. 104, and in like manner its pl. in ix. 60: (Er-Rághib, TA:) the pl. is SadaqaAtN. (S, M, O, Msb.) It is said in a trad., laA Sadaqapa fiY AlA_ibili AljaAr~api [There is no poorrate in the case of working camels], because they are the riding-camels of the people; for the poorrate is in the case of pasturing camels, exclusively of the working. (S in art. jr.) ― -b2- See also SadaAqN.

SaduqapN *
SaduqapN: see SadaAqN, in two places.

SuduqapN *
SuduqapN: see the next paragraph.

SadaAqN *
SadaAqN and SidaAqN↓, (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) the former of which is the most common of the dial. vars. here mentioned, (Msb,) [but] the latter is [said to be] more chaste than the former, (Mgh,) and SaduqapN↓, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) of the dial. of El-Hijáz, (Msb,) and SudoqapN↓, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) of the dial. of Temeem, (Msb,) and SadoqapN↓ (M, O, Msb, K) and SuduqapN↓ (M, O, K) and SadaqapN↓, (M, K,) The mahor (S, M, Mgh, O, K) of a woman; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) [i. e. a dowry; nuptial gift; or gift that is given to, or for, a bride:] the pl. of SdAq is SuduqN, (M, Mgh, Msb,) a pl. of mult., (M,) or SudoqN, (O,) or both, (K,) and A^aSodiqapN, a pl. of pauc., (M,) or this is accordant to analogy, but has not been heard; (Mgh;) the pl. of SaduqapN↓ is SaduqaAtN; (S, Msb, K;) the pl. of SudoqapN↓ is SudoqaAtN and SudaqaAtN and SuduqaAtN, (O, * Msb, K,) which last is the worst; (K;) and the pl. of SadoqapN↓ is SudaqN, (Msb,) or SadoqaAtN [by rule SadaqaAtN]. (O.)

SidaAqN *
SidaAqN: see the next preceding paragraph.

SaduwqN *
SaduwqN Having the quality of speaking, saying, uttering, or telling, truth, or truly, or veraciously, in a high, or an eminent, degree; very, or eminently, true or veracious: (Msb:) pl. SuduqN and SudoqN. (K.) See also A^aSodaqu.

SadiyqN *
SadiyqN A friend: (O, K:) or a true, or sincere, friend: (S, M, Msb, TA:) applied likewise to a female, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) as also SadiyqapN, (S, M, Msb, K,) the former anomalous, the latter regular; (MF;) and to a pl. number, (S, M, O, K,) as in the Kur xxvi. 101 (M) [and in several other instances, of which see one in a verse cited voce rawiY~N]: its proper pl. is A^aSodiqaA='u (S, M, O, K) and SudaqaA='u and SudoqaAnN, (M, K,) the last on the authority of Fr, (TA,) and A^aSaAdiqu, (M, O, K,) which is a pl. pl., (K,) said by IDrd to be anomalous, unless it be a pl. pl.: (O:) and the dim. is Suday~iqN↓; one says, huwa Suday~iqiY, meaning He is the most special, or most distinguished, of my friends, or of my true, or sincere, friends. (S, O, K.)

SadaAqapN *
SadaAqapN Love, or affection: (K:) or truth, or sincerity, of love or affection: (TA:) or friendship, or friendliness; (S, M;) or true, or sincere, friendship or friendliness: (S, M, Msb:) or true firmness of heart in love or affection; an attribute of a human being only. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

Suday~iqN *
Suday~iqN dim. of SadiyqN, q. v. (S, O, K.)

Sid~iyqN *
Sid~iyqN One who speaks, says, utters, or tells, truth, or truly, or veraciously, much, or often: (Mgh, O, K:) [or rather having the quality of speaking, saying, uttering, or telling, truth, or truly, or veraciously, in a very high, or very eminent, degree; for] it has a more intensive signification than SaduwqN [q. v.]: (TA:) or i. q. muSad~iqN [which may have the latter of the two meanings expl. above, or may mean one who accepts, or admits, the truth of what is said, or who verifies, &c.: or muSad~iq in a high, or an eminent, degree; for it is added that] the fem. as used in the Kur v. 79 means superlative in AlS~idoq and Alt~aSodiyq; as a possessive epithet, i. e. *aAtu taSodiyqK: (M:) or it signifies daAy^imu Alt~aSodiyqi [i. e. always muSad~iq in one or another or all of the senses assigned to this word above: it may be correctly rendered eminently, or always, veracious: and eminently, or always, accepting, or confirming, the truth]: and it may mean one who verifies his saying by deed, or act: (S:) it is said in the “ Mufradát ” [of Er-Rághib] that it has the first of the meanings expl. in this paragraph: or rather means, one who never lies: or rather, one by whom lying cannot be practised because of his habitual veracity: or rather, one who is true in his saying and his belief, and who confirms his truth by his deed, or acting. (TA.)

SaAdiqN *
SaAdiqN Speaking, saying, uttering, or telling, truth, or truly, or veraciously; true in respect of speech &c., or veracious. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- SidoqN SaAdiqN is a phrase like $iEorN $aAEirN, meaning Eminent, and exalted, veracity. (M, TA. *) ― -b3- And HamolapN SaAdiqapN [A charge, or an assault, made with earnestness, not with a false show of bravery,] is like the saying [in the contr. case] HamolapN kaA*ibapN. (M, TA: * said in the latter to be tropical.) See also maSodaq, in two places. ― -b4- One says also tamorN SaAdiqu AlHalaAwapi, meaning Very sweet dates. (IDrd, O.) ― -b5- And barodN SaAdiqN Vehement, or intense, cold. (TA voce baHotN &c.)

AlS~ayodaqu *
AlS~ayodaqu The small star cleaving to the middle one of [those called] banaAtu naEo$K AlkuboraY [which compose the tail of Ursa Major]; (Kr, M, TA;) [i. e. the star called Als~uhaA, q. v.; for] it is said that the first of bnAt nE$ AlkbrY, that is at the extremity thereof, is named AlqaAy^idu; and the second is AlEanaAqu, and by the side of it is a small star named Als~uhaA and AlS~ayodaqu; and the third is AlHawaru: (O:) or, accord. to AA, (O, TA,) the pole-star (AlquTobu). (O, K, TA. [But this is strange; and the more so as it is added in the K that it is expl. in art. qwd; for the explanation in that art. (though not free from obvious mistakes) identifies AlS~ayodaqu with Als~uhaA.]) ― -b2- And, (K,) accord. to Sh, (O, TA,) it signifies AlA^amiynu [The trusted, trusted in, or confided in, &c.]. (O, K. [But it is added in the O that Sh cites a verse of Umeiyeh Ibn-Abi- s-Salt in which AlA^amiynu is applied as an epithet to the star called AlSaydq.]) ― -b3- And, (K,) accord. to some, as AA says, (O,) it signifies The king. (O, K.)

faEalahu fiY gib~i SaAdiqapK *
faEalahu fiY gib~i SaAdiqapK [in the CK faEalahu gib~a SAdiqapK] means He did it after the affair, or case, had become manifest to him. (IDrd, O, K, TA.)

SunoduwqN *
SunoduwqN, mentioned in this art. in the S and Msb: see art. Sndq.

A^aSodaqu *
A^aSodaqu [More, and most, true or veracious]. One says A^aSodaqu mino qaTaApK [More veracious than a katáh]; because the bird thus called cries qaTaA qaTaA; [thus telling where it is to be found;] its name being imitative of its cry: (Meyd, and TA in art. qTw:) hence it is called by the Arabs AlS~aduwqu↓: the saying is a prov. (Meyd.)

*uw maSodaqK *
*uw maSodaqK, (JK, S, M, O,) with fet-h, (S,) or *uw miSodaqK↓ like minobar, (K,) applied to a man, (JK, M,) [i. e.] applied to a courageous man, (S, O, K,) means AlHamolapi SaAdiqu↓ [Earnest, not
making a false show of bravery, in the charge, or assault]; (JK, S, M, O, K;) or courageous [in the charge, or assault]: (JK:) maSaAdiqu, occurring in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb, may be for *awuw maSaAdiqa; or it may be an anomalous pl. of SidoqN [used as an epithet], like malaAmiHu and ma$aAbihu [pls. of lamoHapN and $abahN]. (M.) Also, (S, M, O, K,) applied to a horse, (M,) [i. e.] applied to a fleet and excellent horse, (S, O,) in like manner, (M,) meaning AljaroYi SaAdiqu↓ [Earnest in running]; (S, O, K;) as though fulfilling his promise of running: (S, O: [said in the TA to be tropical:]) Khufáf Ibn-Nudbeh says,
A_i*aA maA A@sotaHam~ato A^aroDuhu mino samaAy^ihi
jaraY wahowa mawoduwEN wawaAEidu maSodaqi
meaning When his hoofs are wetted with the sweat of his upper parts, he runs, being left to himself, not beaten nor chidden, and a fulfiller of his promise to do his utmost. (S, O.) And sometimes it is applied to an opinion, in like manner [as meaning True, or sincere]. (M.) ― -b2- maSodaqN also signifies Hardness. (Th, M.) ― -b3- Also i. q. Had~N [as meaning The edge of a sword]: (TA:) [in a copy of the M written jid~, which I think an evident mistake; for it is added,] and it is said to have this meaning in a verse of Dureyd Ibn-Es- Simmeh [relating to a sword]. (M, TA.)

miSodaq *
miSodaq: see the next preceding paragraph.

muSad~aqN *
muSad~aqN A man from whom the poor-rate (Sadaqap) of his cattle is exacted. (TA.)

muSad~iqN *
muSad~iqN One who accepts, admits, assents to, or believes, another in his information, or narration. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also The exactor, or collector, (S, M, O, Msb, K, TA,) of the SadaqaAt, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) i. e. (TA) of the Huquwq [or dues, meaning poor-rates], (M, TA,) of the cattle, (Msb,) or of the sheep or goats, (S, M, O, TA,) and of the camels, (M, O, TA,) for the persons to whom pertain the shares [thereof]. (TA.)

muS~ad~iqN *
muS~ad~iqN: see mutaSad~iqN.

miSodaAqN *
miSodaAqN A thing that confirms, or proves, the truth of a thing: (S, K:) [and] a verbal evidence of the truth, or veracity, of a man. (Har p. 106.) One says, h`*aA miSodaAqu h`*aA This is what confirms, or proves, the truth of this. (S.) And $aYo'N layosa lahu miSodaAqN [A thing having nothing to verify it]. (IAar, TA in art. brq.)

maSoduwqapN *
maSoduwqapN [see 1, near the beginning]. One says layosa liHamolatihi maSoduwqapN [meaning There is no earnestness attributable to his charge, or assault]; like as one says [in the contr. case], lys lahaA mako*uwbapN. (M.)

mutaSad~iqN *
mutaSad~iqN One who gives what is termed Sadaqap [meaning alms]: (S, O, Msb, K:) accord. to Kh, it means thus, and also one who asks [alms]; (O, TA;) and IAmb says the like; but Az says that the skilful of the grammarians disallow this; and thus say Fr and As and others: (TA:) [J, also, and Sgh and Fei, say that] it has only the former meaning: (S, O, Msb:) it is also pronounced muS~ad~iqN↓, by substitution [of S for t] and incorporation [of one S into the other]; (S, * O, * Msb, K; *) and this pronunciation of the pl. both masc. and fem. occurs in the Kur lvii. 17, (S, O, K,) where Ibn-Ketheer and Aboo-Bekr, differing from others, read without teshdeed to the S. (O.)

SayodalN *
SayodalN Stones [i. e. pieces of ore] of silver: mentioned by IB on the authority of IDrst: and he says that HijaArapu AlEaqaAqiyri [meaning drugs resembling pieces of stone, such as pieces of gum &c.,] are likened thereto. (TA.)

SayodalapN *
SayodalapN [The trade of the SayodalaAniY~;] the sale of EiTaArap [i. e. drugs and perfumes]. (K, * TA.)

SayodalaAniY~N *
SayodalaAniY~N (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) a word of wellknown meaning: (M:) A seller of medicines (Mgh, Msb, TA) and of drugs (TA) and of perfumes: (K, TA:) a rel. n. from SayodalaAnu, the name of a town or place, (K,) or from SayodalN meaning as expl. above; (IB, TA;) or a Pers. word arabicized: (M:) and SayodanaAniY~N signifies the same, (S, Msb, K, [in the CK, erroneously, SanodanaAniY~N,]) and so SanodalaAniY~N: (K in this art., and O and K in art. Sndl:) the pl. of the first is SayaAdilapN. (M, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Also A king: and so SayodanaAniY~N. (M in art. Sdn.)

1 Sadamahu *
1. Sadamahu, (S, M, K,) aor.
Sadima
, (M, K,) inf. n. SadomN, (S, M, Mgh, K,) He dashed himself, i. e. his body, (S, Mgh, TA,) against him, (S, TA,) or against it, (S, Mgh, TA,) i. e., a thing: (Mgh:) or he struck it, or knocked it, [or struck or knocked against it,] namely, a hard thing with the like thereof. (M, K.) Hence the saying, Alkalobu A_i*aA qatala AlS~ayoda SadomFA laA yuw^okalu [i. e. When the dog kills the game by dashing himself against it, it shall not be eaten]. (Mgh.) [See also 3.] ― -b2- And Sadamahu, aor. as above, (Msb,) and so the inf. n., (Mgh, Msb, K,) He pushed, thrust, or repelled, him, or it. (Mgh, Msb, K, TA.) One says, Sadamotu Al$~ar~a biAl$~ar~i [I repelled evil with evil]. (TA.) ― -b3- And Sadamatohu Humay~aA AlkaA^osi i. e. (tropical:) [The intoxicating influence of the cup of wine] smote him [or attacked him] in his head. (TA.) ― -b4- And Sadamahumo A^amorN, (M, TA,) inf. n. as above, (K,) (tropical:) An event befell them. (M, K, * TA.) ― -b5- And Sadamahu biAlqawoli (assumed tropical:) He silenced him by speech. (Msb.)

3 SAdmhu *
3. SAdmhu, (S, K, TA,) inf. n. muSaAdamapN, (TA,) He, or it, dashed against him, or it, being dashed against by him, or it: (S, * PS:) or struck, or knocked, him, or it, being struck, or knocked, by him, or it: (K, * PS:) or pushed, thrust, or repelled, him, or it, being pushed, &c., by him, or it; (K, * TA;) syn. daAfaEahu: (TA, and Ham p. 313:) and i. q. saAk~ahu [i. e. he struck him, or it; or struck him, or it, vehemently, with a broad thing, or with anything; or slapped him with his hand; being struck, &c., by him]: (Ham ibid.:) [but, like as daAfaEahu often signifies the same as dafaEahu, so accord. to Fei,] SaAdamahu AlHimaAru means Sadamahu [i. e. The ass dashed against him; &c.]. (Msb in art. $tm.)

6 taSaAdamaA *
6. taSaAdamaA, (S, Mgh,) said of two men running, (Mgh,) and AiSoTadamaA↓, (S, Mgh, K, K,) said of two horsemen, (Mgh,) and of two stallion [camels], (TA,) They dashed themselves together, each against the other: (S, * TA, PS:) or they struck, or knocked, [against] each other; they collided; (K, * TA;) each of them struck with himself the other: (Mgh:) or both verbs, said of two horsemen, they smote each other, each of them with his weight and his sharpness or vigorousness or valiantness: (Msb:) [or they pushed, thrust, or repelled, each other: (see 1:)] and tSAdmwA they pushed, pressed, crowded, or thronged, together; or dashed, one against another; (M, K, TA; but in the M, only the inf. n. is mentioned;) like two ships in the sea. (TA.)

8 A_iSotadama
8: see the next preceding paragraph.

SidomN *
SidomN The rugged portion of a [stony tract such as is termed] Har~ap; as also SidomapN↓. (ISh, TA.)

SadomapN *
SadomapN A single shock, or collision: (KL:) a single impulsion, push, or thrust: (TA:) and (assumed tropical:) a vehement befalling of an event. (KL.) It is said in a trad., AlS~aboru Einoda AlS~adomapi AlA^uwlaY (S, Msb, TA) i. e. (assumed tropical:) [Patience is to be exercised] at the first [shock, or] assault, or attack, of the calamity: (TA:) meaning that patience is the last thing in the case of every misfortune, (S, Msb,) but it is [most] commended, (S,) or is most rewarded, (Msb,) on the occasion of the sharpness, or vehemence, thereof. (S, Msb.) And one says, A^atayotu EalaY AlA^amorayoni SadomapF waAHidapF [I made an end of the two affairs at one dash, or at one stroke]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And A baldness in the side of the forehead; syn. nazoEapN. (K.) ― -b2- See also AlS~adimataAni, in two places.

SidomapN *
SidomapN: see SidomN.

AlS~adimataAni *
AlS~adimataAni (AZ, S, M, K) and AlS~adomataAni↓ (K) The jabiynaAni [or two parts whereof each is termed jabiyn, above the temple, on either side of the forehead]: (K:) or the two sides (AZ, S, M, K) of the jabiyn (AZ, S, K) or of the jabiynaAni: (M:) or, accord. to AA, as is stated in a marginal note in a copy of the S, the correct meaning is the two sides of the forehead. (TA.) ― -b2- And AlSdmtAn [i. e. AlS~adimataAni or AlS~adomataAni↓] signifies also The two sides of the valley: as though, by reason of their confronting, they struck each other. (TA.)

SudaAmN *
SudaAmN: see what next follows.

SidaAmN *
SidaAmN, (S, K,) or SudaAmN↓, (M,) asserted by Az to be with damm, (TA,) or the latter is vulgar, (S,) not allowable, (K,) though agreeable with analogy, (S, K,) being like SudaAEN and zukaAmN and duwaArN and other terms for diseases, (TA,) A
certain disease in the heads of horses or similar beasts: (S, M, K:) or, accord. to ISh, a certain disease that attacks camels, in consequence of which their bellies become affected with acidity, and they relinquish the water, though thirsty, for some days, until they recover or die. (TA.)

A^aSodamu *
A^aSodamu Bald in the sides of the forehead. (K.)

miSodamN *
miSodamN A man vehement in war, and courageous; or a warrior; or known, experienced warrior; syn. miHorabN. (M.)

A_ibilN muSad~amapN *
A_ibilN muSad~amapN: see what follows.

jamalN maSoduwmN *
jamalN maSoduwmN A camel affected with [the disease termed] SidaAm: and A_ibilN muSad~amapN↓ [camels affected therewith]. (TA.)

SayodanN *
SayodanN A firm, strong, or compact, building. (M.) ― -b2- And A firm, strong, or compact, garment, or piece of cloth: (M:) or a [garment of the kind called] kisaA=' that is stout, or strong, or that is thick, or compact, in texture. (K.) ― -b3- And A king; (S, M, K;) because of the firmness of his rule, or his state, or condition; as also SayodanaAniY~N↓ and SayodalaAniY~N. (M.) ― -b4- And A fox; (S, M, K;) as also SayodanaAniY~N↓: (K:) or AlS~ayodanu is one of the names thereof. (TA.) ― -b5- And The hyena. (K.) ― -b6- See also SayodanaAniY~N. ― -b7- Also A species of fly, that makes a buzzing sound over the herbage. (IKh, TA.) ― -b8- And, as also SayodalN, Stones [i. e. pieces of ore] of silver: to which are likened what are termed HijaArapN AlEaqaAqiyri. (IDrst, TA. [See SayodalN; and see also SayodaAnN, below.])

SayodaAnN *
SayodaAnN Pieces of silver, (M, TA,) when struck from the stone [or ore] thereof: (TA:) n. un. with p. (M, TA.) [See also SayodanN, above, last signification. And see SayodaAnN in art. Syd.] ― -b2- And Stone cooking-pots: (M, TA:) in this sense [likewise] a coll. gen. n.: n. un. with p. (IB and L in art. Syd, in which it is mentioned in the S and L and K.) [See, again, SayodaAnN, and also SayodaA='u, in art. Syd.] ― -b3- And Small pebbles: (IAar, M, TA:) or so SayodaAnu AlHaSaY. (L in art. Syd.)

SayodaAnapN *
SayodaAnapN [as a n. un.: see SayodaAnN, above. ― -b2- Also] Rugged, hard ground, in which is fine stone. (M, TA.) ― -b3- See also two other significations (mentioned here in the TA) in art. Syd.

SayodanaAniY~N *
SayodanaAniY~N A certain creeping thing, (daAb~apN, M,) or a small creeping thing, (duwayob~apN, S, K,) that makes for itself a habitation in the ground, (S, M, K,) within the ground, (M,) and conceals it; (S, M, K;) i. e. covers it over; (M;) so says A 'Obeyd; (S;) also called SayodanN↓: (S, K:) accord. to IKh, a certain small creeping thing (dwyb~p) that collects pieces of stick, or wood, from the plants: accord. to IAar, a certain creeping thing (daAb~apN) having many legs, so many that they cannot be counted, which are short and long. (TA.) ― -b2- See also SayodanN, in two places. ― -b3- Also i. q. SayodalaAniY~N (S, Mgh, K, TA) as meaning A seller of medicines, (Mgh,) or of perfumes: so called as being likened to the small creeping thing mentioned above: or from SayodanN in a sense expl. above as syn. with SayodalN. (TA.)

1 SadowN *
1. SadowN as an inf. n. of which the verb is SadaA: see 2 in art. SdY, in two places.

SadowN *
SadowN as a subst. A certain liquid poison which is applied upon arrow-heads, or spear-heads, or the like, resembling the blood of the [serpent called] A^asowad. (M, TA.)

1 SadiYa *
1. SadiYa, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. yaSodaY, (S, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. SadFY, He thirsted: (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K:) or he thirsted vehemently. (M.) ＝ -A2- SadaA, inf. n. SadowN: see 2, in two places.

2 taSodiyapN *
2. taSodiyapN signifies The clapping with the hands; syn. taSofiyqN; (S, K;) accord. to Er-Rághib, as being like the echo (AlS~adaY), inasmuch as there is no profit in it; (TA;) or it is from AlS~ad~u, because they [who practised it in their worship] used to turn away (kaAnuwA yaSud~uwna) from El-Islám; (K;) [see more in the second paragraph of art. Sd;] and SadowN [an inf. n. of which the verb is SadaA↓] signifies the same; (K;) and so taSad~K↓, of which AHeyth cites as an ex. the saying of Hassán
SalaAtuhumu Alt~aSad~aY waAlmukaA='u
[Their prayer is the clapping with the hands, and whistling: like the saying in the Kur viii. 35]: (TA:) one says of a man, Sd~Y, (M,) or Sd~Y biyadayohi, (TA,) meaning He clapped with his hands; (M, TA;) [said to be] originally Sad~ada; (M;) and biyadayohi SadaA↓, inf. n. SadowN [mentioned above], meaning the same. (TK.) ＝ -A2- also muSad~iyapN.

3 SAdAhu *
3. SAdAhu, (K,) inf. n. muSaAdaApN, (S,) He imitated him, or it; syn. EaAraDahu: (S, * K:) and he, or it, corresponded, and was equal, to him, or it. (TA.) In the Kur xxxviii. 1, some read SaAdi, with kesr, as an imperative from AlmuSaAdaApu (Bd, TA) as meaning AlmuEaAraDapu; and hence AlS~adaY [i. e. the echo], because it imitates (yuEaAriDu) the first sound: so that the meaning is, Imitate thou (EaAriD) the Kur-án by thy works. (Bd.) ― -b2- [And] i. q. dab~arahu [i. e. He considered, or forecast, its issues, or results; did, performed, or executed, it with thought, or consideration; or managed, conducted, ordered, or regulated, it]; relating to an affair: (M:) [or] AlmuSaAdaApu signifies the turning about, or revolving, the opinion, or idea, [that one forms] respecting the management (tadobiyr) of a thing, and the doing of it: (Ham p. 35:) [or,] accord. to As, the minding a thing attentively, carefully, or solicitously: a man who had assisted his she-camel in her bringing forth said, bit~u A^uSaAdiyhaA Tuwla layoliY [I passed all my night minding her attentively, carefully, or solicitously]; because he disliked binding her fore shank to her arm, as it would distress her; or leaving her, as she might go away at random and the wolf might devour her young one: and in like manner one says of the pastor, yuSaAdiY A_ibilahu [He minds attentively, &c., his camels]; when they thirst before the completion of their usual period of being kept from drinking, he restricts them to journeying by night so as to arrive at water on the morrow. (TA.) ― -b3- And He soothed, coaxed, wheedled, or cajoled, him; or deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, him; or strove, endeavoured, or desired, to do so: syn. daAraAhu, (S, M, K, TA,) and daAjaAhu, and saAtarahu, (S, K, TA,) all of which have one meaning, (TA,) [though the last implies concealing enmity,] and laAyanahu. (M.) mano SaAdaAka faqado SaAdaka [He who soothes thee, or coaxes thee, surely ensnares thee] is a saying mentioned in the A. (TA.)

4 ASdY *
4. ASdY It (a mountain) returned an echo. (S, * K.) ― -b2- And He (a man, TA) died; (K, TA;) as though [meaning] his echo ceased; the | having a privative effect. (TA.)

5 Alt~aSad~iY *
5. Alt~aSad~iY, accord. to Er-Rághib, signifies The corresponding to a thing like as does the echo returning from the mountain. (TA.) [But accord. to others,] tSd~Y lahu is originally taSad~ada; (Az and L in art. Sd;) and signifies taEar~aDa, (S, M, K,) and taDar~aEa. (M.) [See 5 in art. Sd; where the usages of this verb, except in the senses mentioned and indicated here below, are fully explained.] ― -b2- It signifies also The feigning oneself unmindful, negligent, inattentive, inadvertent, inconsiderate, or heedless, not being really so. (TA.) ― -b3- And The diverting oneself. (TA.) ― -b4- See also 2.

SadFY *
SadFY [sometimes written SadFA] An echo; i. e. AlS~adaY signifies what the mountain returns to him who utters a sound, or voice, or cry, therein; (K;) or the sound of the mountain and the like that responds to one; (M;) or what responds to one with the like of his voice, or cry, in the mountains &c. (S.) One says, Sam~a SadaAhu (tropical:) [His echo became dumb, or may his echo become dumb]; (S, TA;) meaning he perished, or may he perish: (S and K and TA in art. Sm:) and A^aSam~a A@ll~`hu SadaAhu (tropical:) [May God make his echo to return no sound]; (S, K, TA;) meaning may God destroy him: (S, K, and TA in art. Sm:) for when a man dies, the SdY hears not from him anything, that it should respond to him. (S. [See also another explanation of this saying in what follows.]) ― -b2- And A sound, voice, or cry, (M, TA,) in an absolute sense. (TA.) ― -b3- Also The part of the head, (M,) or the part of the brain, (TA,) which is the place [or seat] of hearing. (M, TA.) And therefore one says, A^aSam~a A@ll~`hu SadaAhu [May God render deaf the part of his brain which is the seat of hearing]. (TA.) ― -b4- And The brain, (M, K, TA,) itself. (TA.) And The [entire] contents (lit. the stuffing, Ha$ow,) of the head; (M, K, TA;) also called the haAmap. (TA.) One says, SadaEa A@ll~`hu SadaAhu [May God crack his brain, or the contents of his head]. (M.) ― -b5- And A bird that cries in the
haAmap [or head] of the slain when his blood has not been avenged by retaliation: (M:) or a bird that comes forth (M, K) from his head, (mino raA^osihi, M,) or from the head of the slain, (K,) when he, or it, has become consumed, or decayed, (M, K,) also called the haAmap; (M;) accord. to the assertion of the people of the Time of Ignorance; (M, K;) mentioned by A 'Obeyd; and some of them used to say that the bones of the dead became a haAmap, which flew: pl. A^aSodaA='N: (TA:) and [this may be meant by the saying that it signifies] the male of the buwm (S, M, K, TA) and haAm: pl. A^aSodaA='N: (M:) they used to say that when a man was slain and his blood was not avenged by retaliation, there came forth from his head a bird like the buwmap, i. e. the haAmap, the male being called the SdY; and it cried upon his grave, AisoquwniY AisoquwniY [Give ye me to drink, give ye me to drink, meaning, of the blood of the slayer]; and if the slayer was slain, it abstained from its crying: (TA:) and [it is said that] it signifies also the body [itself] of a human being after his death; (M, K;) or the remains of the dead in his grave, i. e. his juv~ap [or corpse]. (Jm, TA.) ― -b6- And, (K,) accord. to El- 'Adebbes, (S,) [A cricket;] a certain flying thing, that creaks by night, and hops, (S, K,) and flies, thought by the [common] people to be the junodab, but it is only the SdY, the jndb being smaller than the SdY. (S. [See also AlS~ar~aAru.]) ― -b7- And A certain fish, black, long, (K, TA,) and bulky: n. un. SadaApN. (TA.) ― -b8- And [A man] small, or slender, in person; (AA, M, K, TA;) and so SadaA^o, with ', as mentioned by Az. (TA. [See also SadoEN and SadaEN.]) ― -b9- And Knowing in respect of what is conducive to the good of cattle: (K:) or SadaY maAlK means thus: (M:) or gentle in the management of cattle; like A_izaA='u maAlK: so in the Jm: (TA:) or, as some particularly say, of camels: (M, TA:) [i. e.] you say, A_in~ahu laSadaY A_ibilK, meaning Verily he is knowing in respect of camels, and of what is conducive to their good. (S.) ＝ -A2- Also Thirst: (S, M, K:) or vehement thirst: (M:) [see the first paragraph, in which it is mentioned as an inf. n.:] it is said that thirst does not become vehement but the brain dries, and therefore the skin of the forehead of him who dies of thirst cracks. (TA.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph. ＝ -A3- And The act of the mutaSad~iY, (M, K, TA,) i. e., [as is indicated in the M,] of him who raises his head and breast, looking towards, or regarding, a thing; and so SadaApN↓. (TA.)

SadK *
SadK and SaAdK↓ and SadoyaAnu↓ (S, M, Msb, K) and SadFY↓ [which last is an inf. n. used as an epithet] (M) Thirsting: (S, M, Msb, K:) or thirsting vehemently: (M:) fem. [of the first] SadiyapN (Msb) and [of the second] SaAdiyapN (Msb, K) and [of the third] SadoyaA↓: (S, M, Msb, K:) and the pl. of SaAdiyapN is SawaAdK. (Ham p. 329.)

SadaApN *
SadaApN: see SadFY, last sentence.

SadoyaAnu *
SadoyaAnu; and its fem., SadoyaA: see SadK.

SaAdK *
SaAdK (fem. with p, and pl. of the latter SawaAdK): see SadK. ― -b2- As pl. of SaAdiyapN, (M,) SawaAdK signifies [also] Tall palm-trees: (S, K:) and sometimes, such as drink not water: (S:) or palm-trees that drink water: [thus in a copy of the M:] and some say, such as are tall thereof, and of other trees. (M.)

kaA^osN muSodaApN *
kaA^osN muSodaApN [A cup of wine] having much water: contr. of muEoraqapN, this meaning “ having little water. ” (M.)

miSodaA='N *
miSodaA='N A man who thirsts much. (M.)

muSad~iyapN *
muSad~iyapN The woman who faces, or decorates, (tuSad~iY↓, [which I thus render conjecturally, finding nothing to indicate its meaning except what here follows,]) the wisaAdap [i. e. pillow, or cushion,] with AlA^aranodaj, meaning black lines, upon the leather [that forms its covering]. (TA.)

1 Sar~a *
1. Sar~a, (S, A, TA,) aor.
Sari3a
, (S, TA,) inf. n. SariyrN, said of the junodab [which is app. a species of locust], and of a writing-reed, and of a door, (S, A, TA,) or of a dog-tooth, (nAb, so in a copy of the S in the place of bAb in other copies as in the A and TA,) It made a sound, or noise; (S, A, TA;) or a prolonged sound or noise; [meaning it creaked; or made a creaking, or grating, sound;] and so anything that makes a similar prolonged sound: and [in like manner] AiSoTar~at↓ said of a mast (saAriyap), it creaked, or made a creaking sound: (TA:) but when there is a lightness, or slightness, and reiteration, of the sound, they use the reduplicative form, SaroSara↓, inf. n. SaroSarapN, (S, * TA,) signifying he (the bird called A^axoTab, S, A, TA, and the hawk, or falcon, S, M, TA, or other bird, or flying thing, M) uttered his [reiterated quavering] cry; (S, M, A, TA;) as though they imitated prolongation in the cry of the junodab [and the like], and reiteration in the cry of the A^axoTab [and the like thereof]. (S, TA.) Sar~a Aljunodabu is a prov., expl. in art. jdb [q. v.]. (TA in that art.) ― -b2- Also He (a sparrow) [chirped, or] uttered a cry, or cries. (TA.) ― -b3- Sar~a, aor.
Sari3a
, inf. n. Sar~N and SariyrN; and SaroSara↓; He cried, called out, or raised a cry or clamour, (M, K,) with vehemence, (K,) or with the utmost vehemence: (M:) and [in like manner] one says, jaA='a yaSoTar~u↓ He came [making a clamour, or] in clamour. (TA.) ― -b4- And Sar~a SimaAxuhu, inf. n. SariyrN, His ear-hole sounded, (M, K,) or tingled, or rang, (A,) by reason of thirst. (M, A, K.) And Sar~ati AlA^u*unu The ear tingled, or rang. (ISk, A.) ― -b5- And Sar~a, aor. as above, He thirsted [app. so as to hear a ringing in his ears]. (IAar.) ＝ -A2- Sar~N [as inf. n. of Sar~a] also signifies The act of binding [a captive, &c.: see the pass. part. n., maSoruwrN]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- You say, Sar~a, [aor.
Saru3a
,] (S, M, A,) inf. n. Sar~N, (M, TA,) He tied up a purse, (S, M, * TA,) and money in a purse. (A.) ― -b3- And Sar~aAln~aAqapa (S, M, K) and biAln~aAqapi, (M, K,) or Sar~a Aln~aAqapa biAlS~iraAri, (Msb,) aor.
Saru3a
, (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. Sar~N; (M, K;) [and app. Sar~arahaA↓; (see the pass. part. n., voce maSoruwrN;)] He bound the SiraAr [q. v.] upon the she-camel; (S;) [i. e.] he bound the she-camel's udder with the SiraAri: (M, Msb, K, * TA:) and Sar~a AlA^aTobaA='a biAlS~iraAri [He bound the teats with the SrAr]. (A.) [See a verse of ElKumeyt cited voce rijolN: and see also what there follows it.] ― -b4- [Hence,] Sar~ahaA means also (assumed tropical:) He left off milking her [i. e. the camel]. (Msb.) ― -b5- And tuSar~u, [aor. of Sur~at,] said of a leathern bucket (dalow) that has become flaccid, It is tied, and has a loop-shaped handle affixed within it, having another such opposite to it. (K, * TA.) ― -b6- And one says, Sar~a EalaY~a AlT~ariyqa qalaA A^ajidu masolakFA (tropical:) [He closed, or has closed, against me the road, or way, so that I find not any passage]. (A.) And Sur~ato EalaY~a h`*ihi Albalodapu falaA A^ajidu minohaA maxolaSFA (tropical:) [This town has become closed against me so that I find not any way of escape from it]. (A.) ― -b7- And Sar~a A^u*unayohi, [aor.
Saru3a
, inf. n. Sar~N,] He (a horse) contracted his ears to his head: (ISk, S:) or pointed and raised his ears; which a horse does only when he exerts himself and hastens in his pace: (TA:) or he (an ass) straightened and erected his ears to listen; as also A^aSar~ahumaA↓: (A:) and A^aSar~a↓ used intransitively, (ISk, S,) without the mention of the ears, (A,) signifies the same as Sar~a A^u*unayohi: (ISk, S, A:) and Sar~a biA^u*unihi and Sar~a A^u*unahu, aor. and inf. n. as above; and bihaA A^aSar~a↓; he (a horse, and an ass,) straightened and erected his ear to listen; (M, K;) as also Sar~arahaA↓. (TA.) ― -b8- [The inf. n.] Sar~N signifies also The act of confining, withholding, hindering, or preventing. (TA.) ― -b9- And Sur~a (tropical:) He had an iron collar put upon his neck, or round his neck and hands together. (A.) ― -b10- And Sar~a, aor.
Saru3a
, He collected together a thing, or things, (IAar,) or anything. (TA.) And kalaAmFA Sar~ara↓ (assumed tropical:) He collected something to be said in his bosom, or mind. (L and TA, from a trad.) (T, TA.) ＝ -A3- And Sur~a It (a plant, or herbage,) became smitten by cold, or by intense cold. (M, K.)

4: see 1, latter part, in three places. ＝ -A2- ASr~ Ealayohi, (S, TA,) inf. n. A_iSoraArN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He persevered, or persisted, in it; or kept to it perseveringly. (S, TA.) You say, ASr~ EalaY fiEolihi (assumed tropical:) He persevered, or persisted, in doing it. (Msb.) And ASr~ EalaY Al*~anobi (tropical:) He persevered, or persisted, in the crime, sin, or act of disobedience. (M, TA.) The verb is used in this sense when its object is evil, or crime, or the like. determined, resolved, or decided, upon it. (M, Mgh, K.) You say, ASr~ EalaY fiEolihi (assumed tropical:) He determined, resolved, or decided, upon going on in doing it, and not turning back. (TA.) ― -b3- ASr~ yaEoduw (assumed tropical:) He hastened (M, K) somewhat (M) in running: (M, K: [in the CK, for A^aSar~a yaEoduw A^asoraEa, is put AaSar~a baEuda waAasoraEa:]) accord. to A 'Obeyd, the verb in this sense is A^aDar~a; but Et-Toosee asserts that this is a mistranscription. (M.) ＝ -A3- ASr~Als~unobulu The ears of corn became such as are termed Sarar [q. v.]: (M, K:) [or] accord. to ISh, one says, ASr~ Alz~aroEu, inf. n. A_iSoraArN, meaning The seed-produce [i. e. corn] put forth the extremities of its awn, before its ears had become developed. (TA.)

8: see 1, former half, in two places. ＝ -A2- ASTr~ said of a solid hoof, It was, or became, narrow, or contracted, (S, TA,) in an unseemly manner, or immoderately. (TA.)

R. Q. 1 SaroSara *
R. Q. 1. SaroSara, inf. n. SaroSarapN: see 1, former half, in two places: ＝ -A2- and the same paragraph, last sentence but one.

Sar~N *
Sar~N A leathern bucket (dalow) that, in consequence of its having become flaccid, is tied, and has a loop-shaped handle affixed within it, having another such opposite to it. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- See also SariyrapN.

Sir~N *
Sir~N (S, M, A, Msb, K) and Sir~apN↓ (M, A, K) Cold: (Th, M, A, Msb, K:) or intense cold; (Zj, M, A, K;) as also SaroSarN↓: (Ham p. 719:) or cold that smites the herbage and the seed-produce of the field: (S:) in the Kur iii. 113, the first of these words has the first of the meanings expl. above: (IAmb:) or the second meaning: (Zj:) or signifies noise and commotion: or, accord. to I 'Ab, fire. (IAmb.) ― -b2- And riyHN Sir~N (M, A, K) and SaroSarN↓ (S, M, A, K) A wind intensely cold: (S, M, A, K:) or very intensely cold: (T in explanation of the latter:) or vehemently loud: (M, A, K:) of SaroSarN↓ some say that it is originally Sar~arN, from Sir~N meaning “ cold; ” the incipient letter being repeated, and put in the place of the medial r: others, that it is from Sariyru AlbaAbi [ “ the creaking of the door ”], and from Sar~apN meaning “ vociferation, or clamour. ” (ISk.) ― -b3- And Sir~N is the name of A certain bird, like the sparrow (K, TA) in size, (TA,) of a yellow colour: (K, TA:) so called because of its cry: or, as some say, the sparrow (EuSofuwr) itself. (TA.)

Sar~apN *
Sar~apN Vociferation, or clamour: (S, M, A, TA:) so in the Kur li. 29: (TA:) or the most vehement vociferation or clamour or crying (Zj, M, K *) of a man and of a bird &c. (Zj, M.) [In the K, this meaning is erroneously assigned to Sir~apN.] ― -b2- And Vehemence of grief or anxiety (S, M, K) and of war (M, K) and of heat, (K,) or of the hot season, (M,) &c.: (S, M:) and vehemence of the heat of summer. (S, A.) ― -b3- And A contraction, or much contraction, and sternness, or moroseness, of the face, (K, TA,) by reason of dislike, or hatred. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A company, a collection, or an assemblage. (S, M, K.) So in the following words of Imra-el-Keys:
jawaAHiruhaA fiY Sar~apK lamo tuzay~ali
(S, M) i. e. Those of them that remained behind, in a herd, not dispersed: (EM p. 48: [see the entire verse voce duwnN:]) or fY Sr~p here means in [the midst of] clamour: (S:) or in vehemence of grief or anxiety. (S, M.) ＝ -A3- Also i. q. EaTofapN (M, K) [i. e.] A certain bead (xarazapN) by which women fascinate men so as to withhold them from other women. (Lh, M, K, TA. [This is evidently what is meant by EaTofap, but is given in the M and K as a signification distinct therefrom.]) ＝ -A4- See also muSar~aApN.

Sur~apN *
Sur~apN A purse ($arajN, M, K, in the CK $arojN,) for money; (S, M, A, Msb, K;) as also maSar~N↓, with fet-h, (TA,) or miSar~N↓: (so in a copy of the A:) pl. of the first, SurazN. (Msb.) Hence the prov., AifotaHo Suraraka taEolamo Eujaraka, meaning (assumed tropical:) Return to thyself, [or lay open the recesses of thy mind,] and thou wilt know [thy vices, or faults, or] thy good from thy evil. (Meyd. [See also SuradN, last explanation.])

Sir~apN *
Sir~apN: see Sir~N.

SararN *
SararN Ears of corn (sunobul) after the culm is produced, (M, K, [in the CK, yuqaS~abu is put in the place of yuqaS~ibu,]) before they become apparent: (M:) or ears of corn while the farina has not come forth into them: n. un. with p: (AHn, M, K:) or, accord. to ISh, corn when the leaves become twisted, and the extremity of the ears becomes dry, or tough, though the farina have not come forth into them. (TA.) [See 4, last sentence.]

SaraArN *
SaraArN: see SaruwrapN, in two places.

SiraArN *
SiraArN The thing with which a she-camel's udder is bound: (M, K:) the string which is tied over the she-camel's udder and over the [piece of wood called] tawodiyap, in order that her young one may not suck her; (S;) and in order that it may not make any impression upon her, they smear her teats with fresh [dung of the kind called] baEar: (TA:) or a piece of rag which is bound upon the she-camel's teats, in order that her young one may not such her: (Msb:) pl. A^aSir~apN. (M, A, K.) It is a custom of the Arabs to bind the SrAr upon the udders of their milch camels when they send them to pasture by themselves; and when they return in the evening, they loose the ASr~p, and milk. (IAth.) ― -b2- [Hence,] jaEalotu duwna fulaAnK SiraArFA (tropical:) I put an obstruction, or obstacle, in the way of such a one. (A.) ＝ -A2- Also Elevated places over which the water does not come. (S.)

SaruwrN *
SaruwrN: see SaruwrapN.

SaraArapN *
SaraArapN: see the next paragraph, in three places.

SaruwrapN *
SaruwrapN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and SaAruwrapN↓ (S, M, Msb, K) and SaruwrN↓ and SaAruwrN↓ (M, K) and SaraArapN↓ (S, M, K) and SaruwriY~N↓ (S, M, Msb, K) and SaAruwriY~N↓ (M) or SaAruwraA='u↓, (Sgh, K,) the last like EaA$uwraA='u, mentioned on the authority of Ks, (TA,) A man who has not performed the pilgrimage to Mekkeh: (S, M, A, Msb, K:) so called from Sar~N, signifying the “ act of confining, withholding, hindering, or preventing; ” (TA;) or because the person so called refrains from expending of his property in pilgrimage: (Msb:) you say also, AimoraA^apN SaruwrapN a woman who has not performed the pilgrimage to Mekkeh: (S, Msb:) pl. SaraArN↓ and SaraArapN↓: (K:) [or, rather, the former is a coll. gen. n., of which SaraArapN is the n. of un.; and the latter is a quasi-pl. n., like SaHaAbapN, as well as n. un. of SaraArN:] Fr cites, from certain of the Arabs, SaraArN↓ as used collectively; and one of the number is termed SaraArapN↓: (S:) each of the forms ending with the relative Y receives the dual and pl. and fem. inflections: and accord. to IAar, the forms preceding those receive also the dual and pl. inflections: (M, * TA:) and some say that SawaAriyru is pl. of SaAruwrapN↓: (TA:) or SaAruwrapN↓ and SaAruwrN↓, (M,) or SaruwrapN, (Lh, S, M, A, Msb,) as occurring in the poetry of En-Nábighah, (Yaakoob, S,) not used without p, (Lh, M,) or all the sing. forms above mentioned, (K,) signify one who has not married: (M, A, K:) or who has not had intercourse with women: as though he had determined (A^aSar~a) upon relinquishing them: (Yaakoob, S, Msb: *) applied in like manner to a woman, and to a plurality of persons: (M, K:) the p in SaruwrapN applied to a man and to a woman is not to denote the fem. gender, but to give the utmost intensiveness to the signification. (IJ, M.) ― -b2- It is said in a trad., laA Saruwrapa fiY AlA_isolaAmi, (S, M,) meaning, accord. to A 'Obeyd, There is no abstinence from intercourse with women in El-Islám: (M, TA:) i. e., no one should say, I will not marry: (TA:) thus he makes Srwrp a noun signifying an accident: but it is better known as an epithet: (M:) and IAth says that the meaning is, he who slays another in the Haram [or sacred territory of Mekkeh] shall be slain: his saying, “ I am a Srwrp; I have not performed the pilgrimage, and I know not the sacredness of the Haram; ” shall not be accepted of him: for in the Time of Ignorance, the Kaabeh was a place of refuge. (TA.)

daraAhimu SariyrapN i. q. maSoruwrapN [i. e. Dirhems, or pieces of money, tied up in a purse]: (K:) termed in the present day Sar~N↓. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also SaAr~apN.

SaruwriY~N *
SaruwriY~N: see SaruwrapN.
