Sur~aY: see Sir~aY: ＝ -A2- and see also art. SrY.

Sur~iY *
Sur~iY: see the next paragraph.

hiYa min~iY Sir~aY *
hiYa min~iY Sir~aY, said of an oath, (S,) or huwa min~iY, Sir~aY, (M, K,) and A^aSir~aY↓, and Sir~iY↓, and A^aSir~iY↓, (Yaakoob, S, M, K,) and Sur~aY↓ and Sur~iY↓, (K, TA,) or Sur~iY~N↓ and Sir~iY~N↓, (as in a copy of the M,) It is a determination, or resolution, from me; (S, M, K;) a serious assertion; not a jest. (S, K.) Aboo-Semmál El-Asadee, his she-camel having strayed, said, “ I swear to Thee, [O God,] that, if Thou restore her not to me, I will not serve Thee: ” (S:) or, “ O God, if Thou restore her not to me, I will not say a prayer to Thee: ” (TA:) and he found her, her nose-rein having caught to a thorntree (Eawosajap); and he took her, and said, Ealima rab~iY A^an~ahaA min~iY Sir~aY My Lord knew that it was a determination, or resolution, or serious assertion, from me: (S:) or a confirmed determination: (ISk:) it is derived from A^aSorarotu EalaY Al$~aYo'i “ I persevered, or persisted, in the thing: ” (S:) [or “ I determined, or resolved, upon the thing: ”] AHeyth says, Sir~iY↓, i. e., Determine thou, or resolve thou; as though he addressed himself; from A^aSar~a EalaY fiEolihi “ he determined, or resolved, upon going on in doing it, and not turning back: ” it is also said that A^aSir~Y↓ is changed into A^aSir~aY↓, like as they say biA^abiY A^anota and biA^abaA A^anota: and in like manner, Sir~iY↓ is changed into Sir~aY; the A in A^aSir~iY being elided: not that they are two dial. vars., Sararotu EalaY Al$~aYo'i and A^aSorarotu: and Fr. says that Sir~aY and A^aSir~aY↓ are originally imperatives; and that, when they desired to change them [i. e. the imperatives] into nouns, they changed the Y into | [written Y after fet-h]: and in like manner, [changing verbs into nouns,] they say, nuhiYa Eano qiylK waqaAlK; &c. (TA.) Accord. to AZ, one says, A_in~ahaA min~iY laA^aSir~aY↓ meaning Verily, it is a truth, or reality, from me; and Aboo-Málik says the same of A^aSir~iY↓. (TA.)

Sar~iY~N and Sir~Y~N↓ A dirhem, (S, M, A, K,) and a deenár, (A,) that sounds, (S, M, K,) or rings, (A,) when struck: (S, M, A, K; in some copies of the last of which, in the place of A_i*aA nuqira, is put A*A nuqida: TA:) accord. to some, used only in negative phrases: (IAar, M:) thus used in the phrase, maA lifulaAnK Sar~iY~N, [expl. as] meaning Such a one has not a dirhem nor a deenár: (IAar, A: *) and so used, as meaning a dirhem, by Khálid Ibn-Jembeh; who does not assign to it a dual nor a pl. Sur~iY~N: see Sir~Y.

AlS~ar~aAru, (Msb,) or Sar~aAru All~ayoli, (S, K,) or both, (Mgh in art. xTb,) and AlS~aroSaru↓, (M and L in art. jd,) The judojud; [a cricket, which is called the Sar~aAr in the present day]; (S, M, Mgh, L;) a certain thing that creaks (yaSir~u); (Msb;) a small flying thing; (K;) it is larger than the junodab, and is called by some of the Arabs AlS~adaY: (S, Mgh:) A 'Obeyd says that this last term signifies a certain flying thing that creaks (yaSir~u) by night, and hops, and flies, thought by the [common] people to be the junodab, and found in the deserts. (Msb.)

(M, K, TA.) [Accord. to Forskål, (Descr. Animal., p. xxii.,) SrSr, pronounced “ sursur, ” is applied to an insect which he terms Blatta Aegyptiaca.] ― -b3- And The cock: (K, TA: [written by Golius and Freytag SiroSirN:]) so called because of his cry. (TA.) ― -b4- See also SuroSuwrN.

SuroSurN: see SaroSarN: ― -b2- and see also SuroSuwrN.

SaroSaraAnN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

SaroSaraAniY~N sing. of SaroSaraAniy~aAtN, (S, Msb,) which signifies Camels between the baxaAtiY~ [or Bactrian (in the CK, erroneously, najAtiY)] and the Arabian: (S, M, Msb, K:) or such as are called fawaAlij: (S, M, K:) and SaroSaraAnN↓ [if not a mistranscription] signifies the same. Bactrian]: (M, K:) [see also SaroSaraAniY~N:] or its offspring; as also surosuwrN: (M:) or an excellent stallion-camel. (IAar.) ― -b3- See also SaroSarN. ＝ -A2- Also A ship, or boat: [or a long, or great, ship or boat:] and so quroquwrN. (TA.)

AlS~araASirapu *
AlS~araASirapu The Nabathæans of Syria. (S, K.)

rajulN SaAr~N bayona Eayonayohi *
rajulN SaAr~N bayona Eayonayohi A man contracted in the part between the eyes, like him who is grieving, or mourning. (TA.) ― -b2- And SaAr~N signifies Trees ($ajar) tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, not without shade (K, TA) in their lower parts, by reason of their perplexedness. (TA.)

SaAr~apN *
SaAr~apN A want; a thing wanted; an object of want; or a needful, or requisite, thing: (S, M, K:) pl. SawaAr~u. (TA.) One says, liY qibala fulaAnK SaAr~apN [I have a want to be supplied to me on the part of such a one]. (A 'Obeyd, S.) ― -b2- Also Thirst: (S, K:) pl. SaraAy^iru, (K,) which is extr., (TA,) and SawaAr~u: (K:) or the latter is pl. of SAr~p in the sense first expl. above; as A 'Obeyd says; and this is meant in the K: (TA:) AA says that its pl. in the latter sense is SaraAy^iru; and he cites the following words of Dhu-r-Rummeh:
faA@noSaAEati AlHuqobu lamo taqoSaEo SaraAy^irahaA
[And the wild asses turned back, retreating quickly, not having quenched their thirst]: but fault has been found with AA for this; and it is said that SaraAy^iru is pl. of SariyrapN↓, [which is not expl.,] and that the pl. of SAr~p is SawaAr~u. (S.) One says, qaSaEa AlHimaAru SaAr~atahu, meaning The ass drank water until he quenched his thirst. (S.)

SaAruwrN: see SaruwrapN, in two places.

SaAruwrN: see SaruwrapN, in three places.

SaAruwriY~N: see SaruwrapN.

HajarN A^aSar~u A hard stone: (Tekmileh, TA:) and SaxorapN Sar~aA='u a hard rock: (M, K:) or a smooth rock. (L.)

A^aSir~aY: see Sir~aY, in four places.

A^aSir~iY: see Sir~aY, in three places.

maSar~ataA Albawoli waAlgaAy^iTi [The two sphincters that serve as repressers of the urine and dung]. (K in art. Asr.)

SrY [q. v.]. (TA.)

muSar~arapN *
muSar~arapN: see the next paragraph.

maSoruwrN *
maSoruwrN Bound, as a captive. (Mgh.) ― -b2- And maSoruwrapN and muSar~arapN↓ A she-camel having her udder bound with the SiraAr. (IAth, TA.) ― -b3- And maSoruwrN applied to a solid hoof, Contracted: or narrow: (M, K:) or narrow and contracted: (S:) and muSoTar~N↓ signifies the same; (M, K;) or narrow in an unseemly manner, or immoderately. (TA.) ― -b4- Also (tropical:) A man having an iron collar put upon his neck, or round his neck and hands together. (A.)

maSaAr~ *
maSaAr~ [app. an irregular pl. of maSiyrN, and therefore without tenween,] The A^amoEaA=' [or guts, bowels, or intestines, into which the food passes from the stomach]. (M, K.) One says, $ariba Hat~aY malaA^a maSaAr~ahu, meaning [He drank until he filled] his A^amoEaA=': mentioned by AHn on the authority of IAar, with no more explanation than this. (M.)

muSoTar~N *
muSoTar~N: see maSoruwrN. ― -b2- One says also AimoraA^apN muSoTar~apu AlHaqowayoni [meaning (tropical:) A woman narrow in the flanks]. (A.) ＝ -A2- See also muSoTaridN, in art. Srd.

1 Saraba *
1. Saraba He made the sour milk termed Sarob: (K, * TA:) [or] Saraba All~abana, (M, TA,) aor.
Sariba
, (M,) or
Saruba
, (TA,) inf. n. SarobN, he made the milk to become what is termed Sarob: and he milked some of the milk upon other milk, and left it to become sour: (M, TA:) or Saraba All~abana fiY AlwaTobi he collected the milk in the skin, portion after portion, and left it to become sour; as also AiSoTarabahu↓: (S:) or you say, Saraba All~abana fiY Als~iqaA='i and Als~amona fiY Aln~iHoYi [he collected, portion after portion, and left, the milk in the skin called siqaA=' and the clarified butter in the skin called niHoY]. (M, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Sarabotu All~abana fiY AlD~aroEi (assumed tropical:) I caused the milk to collect in the udder, not drawing it forth. (Kt, TA.) ― -b3- And Saraba (assumed tropical:) He kept in, or retained, and collected, [his] urine: (K, TA:) or withheld it long: and accord. to some, particularly said of a stallion-camel: (TA:) [or] Saraba bawolahu, (S, M,) aor.
Saruba
and
Sariba
, inf. n. SarobN, (M,) (assumed tropical:) he kept in, or retained, and collected, his urine: (S, M:) accord. to some, particularly said of a stallion-camel. (M.) ― -b4- And Saraba AlS~abiY~u [*aA baTonihi being app. understood] (assumed tropical:) The boy remained some days without discharging his excrement, or ordure: (M, TA:) and Saraba baTonu AlS~abiY~i, inf. n. SarobN, (assumed tropical:) the boy's belly became constipated (Eaqada), that he might become fat: (M:) [or] Saraba AlS~abiY~u liyasomana (assumed tropical:) the boy's excrement, or ordure, (*uw baTonihi,) became confined, so that he remained a day without discharging it, when he was about to become fat. (S.) [In the copies of the K, Saraba is expl. as signifying Eaqada baTona AlS~abiY~i liyasomana, to which, written without the syll. signs, the TA assigns the last of the meanings above; therefore, I doubt not, the right reading is baTonu, agreeably with the explanation of Saraba baTonu AlS~abiY~i in the M, given above: otherwise, the meaning must be (assumed tropical:) He, or it, caused the boy's belly to become bound, or constipated, that he might become fat.] ＝ -A2- Sariba, aor.
Saraba
, (K, TA,) inf. n. SarabN, (TK,) said of milk, (TA,) It became collected (K, TA) in the udder. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Sarabati AlA^aroDu The land produced herbs, or trees, such as are termed Sarab [a coll. gen. n. of which the n. un. is SarabapN, q. v.]. (M, K. * [The meaning is indicated in both by the context.]) ＝ -A4- Saraba also signifies He cut, or cut off; (K, TA;) i. q. Sarama; like as one says Darobapa laAzibK and laAzimK. (TA.) ＝ -A5- And i. q. kasaba [He gained, acquired, or earned; &c.]. (K.)

2 taSoriybN *
2. taSoriybN The drinking of sour milk, (O, K, TA,) such as is called Sarob. (TA.) ― -b2- And The eating of gum, (O, K, TA,) i. e., what is called Sarob. (TA.)

4 ASrb *
4. ASrb He (a man, TA) gave. (O, K.) One says, ASrb A_ilayohi maAlFA He (a man) gave to him property. (TK.)

8 A_iSotaraba
8: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- ASTrb SarobapF He provided, or took, for himself some milk, either fresh or sour, in a skin, for a journey. (M, TA.)

11 ASoraAb~a *
11. ASoraAb~a [said by MF to be written by ISd AiSoraA^ab~a↓] It was, or became, smooth, (M, O, K, TA,) and clear; (TA;) said of a thing, (M, K, TA,) or of milk. (O.)

Q. Q. 4 AiSoraA^ab~a *
Q. Q. 4. AiSoraA^ab~a: see what next precedes.

SarobN *
SarobN and SarabN↓ (S, M, &c.) Sour milk (M, Mgh, K) that has been collected in a skin: (M, K:) or very sour milk: (S, Msb:) or milk that has been collected in a skin for some days so that it has become very sour: (As, M:) n. un. SarobapN↓ and SarabapN↓: (M, TA:) SiraAbN, occurring in some of the Expositions of the Jámi' es-Sagheer, is a mistranscription; or it may be a pl. of SarobN accord. to the analogy of HabolN and HibaAlN, and ramolN and rimaAlN. (Mgh.) One says, tazowiY jaA='anaA baSarobapK↓ Alwajoha [He brought us some sour milk, or very sour milk, that had been collected in a skin, making the face to contract in wrinkles]. (S.) [SM here adds,] Az says that AlS~aromu is like AlS~arobu, and is better known. (TA. [But this evidently relates to the signification of “ the act of cutting, ” or “ cutting off; ” not to AlS~arobu as applied to milk.]) ― -b2- Also, (K,) or the former word, (M,) Milk that is provided in a skin for a journey, (M, K,) whether fresh or sour. (M.) ― -b3- And both words, (M, K, TA,) or SarabN↓ [only], (S, Msb,) Gum: (Msb:) or red gum: (T, S, M, L, TA: in the K, AlS~ibogu AlA^aHomaru is erroneously put for AlS~amogu AlA^aHomaru: TA:) some say (M) it is the gum of the TaloH (S, M) and of the EurofuT, peculiarly; the pieces of which are red, as though they were ingots [of gold], and they are broken with stones: (M:) the n. un. is SarabapN↓: (S, M: [SarobapN as a n. un. in this sense I do not find mentioned:]) and sometimes it [i. e. SarobN or SarabN] has SiraAbN for pl.: (M:) sometimes, (S,) what is called SarabapN↓ is a thing like the head of the cat [in size], within which is a thing [or substance] like dibos [or honey of dates], (S, K,) and like glue, (S,) which is sucked and eaten. (S, K.)

SirobN *
SirobN A few tents (buyuwt [in the O, erroneously, butuwt]) of the weak sort of the Arabs of the desert: (IAar, O, * K, TA:) and so SiromN. (O.)

SarabN *
SarabN: see SarobN, in two places. ― -b2- Also Red honey. (TA in art. Drb.) ― -b3- See also SarabapN.

SarobapN *
SarobapN: see SarobN, in two places. ― -b2- Hence, (tropical:) The water [by which is meant the seminal fluid] that collects in the back [of a man]; as being likened to the [sour] milk that is collected in a skin. (M, TA.)

SarabapN *
SarabapN: see SarobN, in three places. ― -b2- Also A herb, (M, K,) and tree, (M,) that becomes green, and puts forth leaves, when dry, or that has grown, or become somewhat restored to a good state, after having been eaten [or depastured], (yatajab~aru, so in the M, [in the K yataxay~aru, which, as is remarked in the TK, is a mistake,]) after men [have fed their cattle therefrom]: pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] SarabN↓. (M.)

SarobaY *
SarobaY, (S, K,) accord. to Sa'eed Ibn-El-Museiyib, (TA,) The [she-camel called] baHiyrap, (S, K,) whose milk was forbidden [by the pagan Arabs] for the sake of the idols (AlT~awaAgiyt), no man milking her [for himself]: (TA:) thus called, (S, K, TA,) it is said, (TA,) because they used not to milk her save for the guest, so that her milk became collected [and retained] (S, K, TA) in her udder: (S, TA:) Kt says, it is from Sarabotu All~abana fiY AlD~aroEi [expl. above]; or, as some say, from [AlS~arobu as signifying] “ the act of cutting, ” or “ cutting off; ” and this seems to be the more correct of the two explanations: accord. to IAar, it signifies a she-camel having the ear slit, like the baHiyrap, or cut off: and its pl., he says, is SurobN. (TA.)

SiraAbN *
SiraAbN See-produce, or corn, which has been sown after that which has been carried off to the place where it is trodden in the autumn. (O, K.)

SariybN *
SariybN Milk that has been made what is termed Sarob; as also maSoruwbN↓: (M, TA:) or sour milk: (A, K, TA:) pl. SurobN. (K.) So in the saying AlD~ariyba laA AlS~ariyba, i. e. [Give me] the thick [milk], from a number of milch camels, that has been mixed together; not the sour. (A, TA.)

SaraAbapN *
SaraAbapN Clearness, and smoothness: thus in the phrase SaraAbapu HanoZalK in a verse of Imra-el-Keys; as some relate it: (M, TA:) as others relate it, SaraAyap, (M,) or SalaAyap. (TA.)

miSorabN *
miSorabN A vessel in which milk is collected, portion after portion, and left to become sour: (S, K: *) and so mikoraSN and miqoraEN: pl. maSaAribu. (TA.)

maSoruwbN *
maSoruwbN: see SariybN.

muSar~abapN *
muSar~abapN (assumed tropical:) A she-camel that is kept from being milked, in order that she may become fat. (L in art. SfH, from the T.)

2 Sr~j *
2. Sr~j, inf. n. taSoriyjN, He plastered with
SaAruwj a watering-trough or tank (K, * TA) &c.: and sometimes they said $r~q. (TA.)

SaAruwjN *
SaAruwjN Quick lime (nuwrap), and the mixtures thereof; (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) with which are plastered watering-troughs, or tanks, and baths, &c.: (M, TA:) a Pers. word, (S, TA,) originally JaAruw, (TA,) arabicized, (S, M, Msb, K,) as is every word in which occur both S and j, (S, Msb,) or SamajN is an exception to this rule: (TA in art. Swbj:) sometimes it is called $aAruwqN. (TA.)

1 SaruHa *
1. SaruHa, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
SaruHa
, (K,) inf. n. SaraAHapN and SuruwHapN, (S, O, Msb,) [both strangely said in the K, to be substs.,] It was, or became, pure, sheer, free from admixture, unmingled, unmixed, genuine, or clear; (S, O, Msb, K;) said of a thing (S, O, Msb) of any kind of which the meaning is predicable, (S, O,) [and particularly] said of one's race, or genealogy. (K.) ＝ -A2- SaraHa: see 2, in two places.

2 Sar~aHato *
2. Sar~aHato She (a camel) yielded pure, or clear, milk. (TA in art. Hlb.) ― -b2- [Hence, probably,] taSoriyHN signifies The speaking clearly, plainly, explicitly, directly, or without ambiguity or equivocation; contr. of taEoriyDN. (S, A, K.) You say, Sr~H bimaA fiY nafosihi, (S, A, L, Msb, K,) and bimaA Einodahu, (A,) He made apparent, manifest, or plain, or he manifested, exposed, or revealed, (S, A, L, K,) what was in his mind, (S, L, K,) and what he had; (A;) as also bihi SArH↓; (L, K;) and bh SaraHa↓: (TA:) or he declared, or made clear, what was in his mind, so as to express the intended meaning according to the first [or most obvious] interpretation; or he made it free from expressions susceptible of tropical meanings and a secondary [or remote] interpretation. (Msb.) And Sr~H Al$~aYo'a, (TA,) inf. n. taSoriyHN; (K, TA;) and SaraHahu↓, (TA,) inf. n. SaroHN; (K, TA;) and ASrHhu↓, (TA,) inf. n. A_iSoraAHN; (K, TA;) He made the thing apparent, manifest, clear, or plain. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- This verb is also intrans. (K.) One says, Sr~Ht Alxamoru, (S, A, Msb,) inf. n. taSoriyHN, (S, K,) The wine became free from froth; (S, A, Msb, K;) [it became clear] after fermenting and frothing. (S.) And Sr~H Aln~ahaAru The day became free from clouds, and sunny: (A:) or Sr~H Alyawomu the day became free from mists and clouds. (Msb.) And Sr~Ht kaHolu The year of drought, or sterility, became one of unmixed severity; (S, Meyd, L, K;) and in like manner, Sr~Ht Als~anapu: (L:) or the former means the sky became clear of clouds. (S in art. kHl, and Meyd.) And Sr~H, (S, Msb, TA,) inf. n. as above, (K, TA,) said of an affair, (K, TA,) or, as in a copy of the K, [and in the S and Msb,] said of the truth, (TA,) It became apparent, manifest, exposed, or revealed; (S, Msb, K, TA;) and so AnSrH↓, (S, K, TA,) said of the truth. (S, TA.) Hence the prov. Einoda Alt~aSoriyHi turiyHu, meaning On the appearing of the truth thou findest rest; (Meyd, TA;) no doubt remaining in thy mind. (Meyd.) And Sar~aHa AlHaq~N Eano maHoDihi, (S, Meyd, A, Msb,) another prov., meaning (tropical:) The truth, or affair, became revealed, or manifest, (S, Meyd, Msb,) after its being concealed: (Meyd, Msb:) or, as AA says, falsity became detected, or exposed, and the truth became apparent and known. (Meyd. [See also zubodN.]) And Sar~aHato bijilo*aAna, another prov., (Meyd, L,) meaning It (the affair, or case,) became apparent, or manifest, to thee, in Jildhán; which last word is variously written, [see Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 730, and Har p. 106,] a place in Et-Táïf, soft and even, like the palm of the hand, containing no covert in which one may conceal himself; the t in Sr~Ht denoting the qiS~ap or xuT~ap: (Meyd:) i. e. the man made apparent, or revealed, the utmost of what he desired, or meant. (L.) ― -b2- See also a trad. cited in art. SwH, conj. 2. ― -b3- Sr~H said of an archer or the like means [He made his arrow, or missile, to go clear of the butt or mark; or] he shot, or cast, and missed (K, TA) the butt [or mark]. (TA.)

3 SArH bihi *
3. SArH bihi: see 2. ＝ -A2- [SArHhu, inf. n. muSaAraHapN and SiraAHN, He confronted him, or faced him.] One says, $atamahu muSaAraHapF, and SiraAHFA, (S, K,) and SuraAHFA↓, (K,) which last is a subst. [used as an inf. n., i. e. a quasi-inf. n.], (S, K,) He reviled him confronting him, or face to face, or to his face. (S, K.) And laqiytuhu muSaAraHapF, (A, TA,) and SiraAHFA, and SuraAHFA↓, (TA,) I met him face to face. (A, TA.)

4 A^aSoraHa
4: see 2.

5 tSr~H Alz~abadu Eani Alxamori *
5. tSr~H Alz~abadu Eani Alxamori The froth became cleared away from the wine. (TA.)

7 A_inoSaraHa
7: see 2.

SaroHN *
SaroHN A qaSor [i. e. palace, or pavilion, &c.]: (Zj, S, A, K:) and (as some say, TA) any lofty building: (S, A, K, TA:) or a single house or chamber, built apart, or detached, large, and lofty: (Msb, TA:) pl. SuruwHN. (S, A.)

SaraHN *
SaraHN: see SariyH.

SaroHapN *
SaroHapN The court, or open area, of a house; i. e. a spacious vacant part or portion thereof, in which is no building; its EaroSap, (S, TA,) or its saAHap [which means the same]: (A, Msb, TA:) pl. SaraHaAtN. (Msb.) ― -b2- And A tract of ground that is hard and elevated (S, L) and even: or a tract that is even, and open to view, of ground, and of a place where camels or other animals are confined, or where dates are dried, and of a house or dwelling: or a tract that is even, and of goodly appearance, though not open to view: Aboo-Aslam asserts it to mean a [desert tract such as is called] SaHoraA='. (L.) ― -b3- [Hence, app.,] one says, xaraja lahumo SaroHapa baroHapa, (so accord. to the TA as from the K,) or SaroHapa baroHapK, (O, and so in my MS. copy of the K,) or SaroHapF baroHapF, (so in the CK,) He went forth openly, or into the field [of battle], to them: (O, K:) and A^in~a xuruwja SaroHapK baroHapK lakaviyrN, (so accord. to the TA as from the K,) or SaroHapa baroHapK, (O, and so in the CK,) or SaroHapa baroHapa, (so in my MS. copy of the K,) [accord. to SM,] with fet-h in the end of each [app. in the former phrase], and with tenween in each [app. in the latter phrase], (TA,) [i. e. Verily the going forth openly, or into the field of battle, is frequent. See also SaHorap, and baHorap.]

SuroHaAnN *
SuroHaAnN: see SariyHN.

SaraAHN *
SaraAHN: see SariyHN.

SuraAHN *
SuraAHN: see SariyHN, in six places. ― -b2- Also Thin milk, containing much water, so that in some parts of it one sees a tawniness and xuDorap [here app. meaning a blackish hue]. (L.) ＝ -A2- See also 3, in two places.

SiraAHN *
SiraAHN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

SariyHN *
SariyHN Anything pure, sheer, free from admixture, unmingled, unmixed, genuine, or clear; (S, A, Msb, K, TA;) as also SaraHN↓, (S, K,) which is by some restricted by the [additional] epithet white, (TA,) and SuraAHN↓, (L, K,) and SiraAHN↓, which is [said to be] more chaste [though much less usual] than SuraAHN, (L,) and SaraAHN↓, (K,) and SumaAriHN↓, (S, K,) in which last the m is augmentative, or, as is related on the authority of AA, it is SumaAdiHN, with d, but [J says] I do not think this to have been retained in the memory [as transmitted from the Arabs of classical times]. (S.) You say labanN SariyHN Milk of which the froth has gone, (S, A, L,) or free from froth, (T, L,) and clear: (T, A, L:) or just drawn. (TA in art. zhr.) And bawolN SariyHN Urine free from froth. (T, L.) And xamorN SuraAHN↓, (L,) and SuraAHiyapN↓, (L, K,) without teshdeed, (K,) Pure wine, (L, K,) without admixture. (TA.) And kaA^osN SuraAHN↓ A cup of wine without admixture. (S, A, Msb, K.) And jaA='a banuw tamiymK SariyHapF The sons of Temeem came unmixed with any others. (S.) And rajulN SariyHN, (T, S, L, K, *) and EarabiY~N SariyHN, (A, Msb,) A man, (T, S, L,) and an Arab, (A, Msb,) of pure, or unmixed, race or genealogy; pl. SuraHaA='u: (T, S, A, L, Msb, K:) and farasN SariyHN a horse of pure race; (T, TA;) pl. SaraAy^iHu, (T, K, TA,) in this case as distinguished from the former. (T, TA.) And nasabN SariyHN Pure, or unmixed, race or genealogy. (A.) And kalimapN SuraAHN↓ and SuraAHiyapN↓ [A word, an expression, or a sentence,] that is pure, genuine, or clear. (K.) And ka*ibN SuraAHN↓ and SiraAHN↓, the latter with kesr, and SuraAHiyapN↓ and SuraAHiY~N↓ (TA) and SuroHaAnN↓ with damm, (Lh, TA,) (assumed tropical:) A pure, sheer, or unmixed, lie, (Lh, TA,) manifest, and known
to men. (TA.) And qawolN SariyHN (assumed tropical:) A saying [that is explicit, plain, or clear,] not requiring anything to be conceived in the mind, nor any interpretation. (Msb.) And $ar~N SuraAHN↓ (tropical:) [Pure unmixed, evil, or mischief]. (A, TA.) And SariyHu Aln~uSoHi (assumed tropical:) Pure, or sincere, in admonition, or counsel. (L, TA.)

SaraAHapN *
SaraAHapN: inf. ns. of SaruHa [q. v.]. (S, O, Msb.)

SuruwHapN *
SuruwHapN: inf. ns. of SaruHa [q. v.]. (S, O, Msb.)

SuraAHiyapN *
SuraAHiyapN: see SariyHN, in three places. ― -b2- [Hence the saying,] A^ataAhu biAlA^amori SuraAHiyapF [app. He stated to him the affair, or case,] clearly, or without admixture. (L, TA.)

SuraAHiY~N *
SuraAHiY~N: see SariyHN.

SariyHiY~N *
SariyHiY~N an epithet applied to a horse, in relation to a certain stallion named SariyHN, (S, TA,) or AlS~ariyHu, (TA,) that begat a generous breed. (S, TA.)

SuraAHiy~apN *
SuraAHiy~apN A vessel for wine: (K:) [in Pers. SuraAHiY:] but IDrd doubts its correctness. (TA.)

Sur~aAHN *
Sur~aAHN A certain flying thing, resembling the [species of locust called] junodab, which is eaten. (K.)

SumaAriHN *
SumaAriHN: see SariyHN.

yawomN muSar~iHN *
yawomN muSar~iHN, (S, K,) like muHad~ivN [in measure], (K,) [in one of my two copies of the S muSar~aHN also, and in the other copy the latter only,] A day free from clouds: (S, K:) occurring in the poetry of Et-Tirimmáh. (S.)

miSoraAHN *
miSoraAHN A she-camel that does not yield frothy milk; (T, K; [in the CK, lA taroEaY is put for lA turag~iY;]) that yields pure milk, with little froth. (M, TA.)

1 SaroxapN *
1. SaroxapN, (L, K,) an inf. n. of Saraxa, (S,) signifies The calling or calling out, or crying or crying out, vehemently; [or screaming;] (L, K;) on an occasion of fright, or alarm, or of some affliction, or evil accident: (L:) one says, Saraxa, inf. n. SaroxapN; and ASTrx↓; [He called or called out, &c.;] both meaning the same. (S.) And SuraAxN is also an inf. n. of Saraxa, (A, Mgh, Msb,) and signifies The raising the voice, calling or calling out, crying or crying out: (S, A, L, K:) or doing so vehemently: (L, K:) and the calling, or crying, for aid, or succour; (A;) which last meaning is said to be tropical, but conventionally regarded as proper; (MF;) as also SariyxN, (S, TA,) which is likewise an inf. n. of Saraxa: (A, Mgh:) one says, Saraxa, aor.
Saruxa
(A, MA, Mgh, L, Msb) and
Saraxa
, (MA,) inf. n. SuraAxN (A, MA, Mgh, L, Msb) and SariyxN, (A, Mgh,) He raised his voice, called or called out, cried or cried out: (A, MA, L, Msb:) or did so vehemently: (Mgh, L, Msb: *) and he called, or cried, for aid, or succour, (A, Mgh, L, Msb,) saying, waA gawovaAho [Alas, a crying for aid!] and waA SaroxataAho [Alas, a crying of alarm!]; (L;) and AstSrx↓ signifies the same: (AHát, L:) and ASTrxwA↓ is syn. with tSArxwA↓; (S, TA;) meaning SaraxuwA; as also AstSrxwA↓; (TA;) or [rather] meaning They called or called out, &c., (SaraxuwA,) one to another. (TK.) kaAnato kaSaroxapi AlHubolaY [It was like the vehement crying-out, or the screaming, of the pregnant woman] is a prov., said of a thing that comes upon one suddenly, when he is not aware. (T.)

4 ASrx *
4. ASrx He aided, or succoured, another; in answer to a call, or cry; (S, A, Mgh, Msb;) as also AstSrx↓: (AHát, L:) the | in the former verb is said to have a privative effect, so that A^aSoraxotuhu signifies I made his crying, or vehement crying, &c., to cease: (TA:) and SaArixapN↓ has the signification of the inf. n. of this verb, as an inf. n. [or rather quasi-inf. n.] of the measure faAEilapN; (K;) and SariyxN↓ also may have this signification in the Kur xxxvi. 43, as is said in the Ksh [and by Bd]. (TA.)

5 tSr~x *
5. tSr~x He made an effort to call or call out, to cry or cry out, or to do so vehemently; [or, to scream;] (S, A, K;) or he made an effort in calling or calling out, &c., (PS,) in calling or calling out, &c., vehemently, and in crying for aid or succour. (KL.) One says, Alt~aSar~uxu bihi HumoqN, (S,) meaning Alt~aSar~uxu biAlEuTaAsi [i. e. The making an effort to call or call out, &c., or in calling or calling out, &c., in sneezing, is stupidity]. (S, TA.)

6 tSArxwA *
6. tSArxwA They called or called out, cried or cried out, or did so vehemently, one to another; (A;) [and so, accord. to a copy of the A, AstSrxwA↓; and app. ASTrxwA↓, as seems to be indicated in the L and K;] see 1.

8 A_iSotaraxa
8: see 1, in two places: and see also 6.

10 AstSrxhu *
10. AstSrxhu He called, or cried, to him for aid, or succour. (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb.) ― -b2- And He incited him, urged him, or induced him, to call or call out, to cry or cry out, [app. for aid, or succour,] or to do so vehemently. (L, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] AusotuSorixa AlA_inosaAnu There came to the man a voice, or cry, informing him of an event on account of which his aid was invoked, or announcing to him a death. (IAth, TA.) AisotiSoraAxu AlHaY~i means The tribe's being invoked for aid to perform what is requisite for the dead: and hence the trad. of Ibn-'Omar, faA@sotuSorixa EalaY A@moraA^atihi, not biA@moraA^atihi, meaning, And he was called to aid in furnishing for the grave, and burying, the corpse of his wife: or it may mean, was informed that his wife was at the point of death. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, in two places; and 6: ― -b2- and see 4.

SaroxapN *
SaroxapN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) The call to prayer. (K, TA.)

SuraAxN *
SuraAxN an inf. n. of Saraxa [q. v.]. (A, &c.)

SariyxN *
SariyxN an inf. n. of Saraxa [q. v.]: (A, Mgh:) see also 4. ＝ -A2- See also SaArixN, in four places.

AlS~ar~aAxu *
AlS~ar~aAxu [He who calls or calls out, or cries or cries out, or does so vehemently, or screams, &c., much, or often. ― -b2- And hence,] The peacock. (IAar, K.)

SaArixN *
SaArixN Calling or calling out, or crying or crying out, or doing so vehemently; [or screaming;] as also SariyxN↓. (A, Msb.) And Calling, or crying, for aid, or succour; (S, Msb, K;) and so SariyxN↓; (S, K;) and musotaSorixN↓. (S.) ― -b2- Also, and SariyxN↓, (AHeyth, S, A, K,) or the latter [only] of these, (T, Msb,) and muSorixN↓, (S, A, Msb, K,) and SaArixapN↓, (Lth, TA,) Aiding, or succouring; or an aider, or a succourer: (Lth, T, S, A, Msb, K:) Az says that he had not heard SaArixN in this sense on the authority of any except As; but that all men agree that it has the second of the senses given above, and that muSorixN↓ has the last of those senses. (TA.) A^amapN EabodN Sariyxuhu↓, meaning [A male slave] whose aider [is a female slave], is a prov. applied in the case of a mean man who is aided by one meaner than he. (Meyd.) And it is said in the Kur [xiv. 27], maA A^anaA bimuSorixikumo wamaA A^anotumo bimuSorixiY~a↓ I am not your aiders, nor are ye my aiders. (TA.) ― -b3- AlS~aArixu is an appellation of The cock; (K, TA;) because he cries much in the night: and it is said by some to be tropical. (TA.) ― -b4- And SaArixN signifies also A voice, or cry, informing a man of an event on account of which his aid is invoked, or announcing to him a death. (IAth, TA.)

SaArixapN *
SaArixapN The voice, or cry, of the calling for aid, or succour. (K.) Hence the saying, samiEotu SaArixapa Alqawomi [I heard the cry of the people, or party, calling for aid, or succour]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 4. ― -b3- And see SaArixN.

muSorixN *
muSorixN: see SaArixN, in three places.

musotaSorixN *
musotaSorixN: see SaArixN.

1 Sarida *
1. Sarida, aor.
Sarada
, inf. n. SaradN, He, or it, was, or became, cold: or intensely cold. (M, L. [See SarodN.]) One says, Saridotu Alyawoma SaradFA $adiydFA [I was, or became, to day, very cold; or very intensely cold]. (A.) And Sarida yawomunaA [Our day was, or became, very cold; or very intensely cold]. (A.) ― -b2- And Sarida, aor. as above, (S, K,) and so the inf. n., (S,) He (a man) was quickly sensible of cold. (S, K.) ― -b3- And Sarida said of milk, It became in a state of decomposition, by reason of cold. (TA.) ― -b4- And, said of a skin, (O, K,) inf. n. as above, (O, TA,) It emitted its butter in clots: (O, K:) of the doing of which it is cured with hot water. (O, TA.) ― -b5- Sarida Eani Al$~aYo'i,
inf. n. as above, means (assumed tropical:) He abstained, refrained, or desisted, from the thing; [as though he became cold with respect to it;] he left, relinquished, or forsook, it: (M:) and Sarida qalobiY Eani Al$~aYo'i (tropical:) My heart refrained from the thing; left, relinquished, or forsook, it: (S, A, O, K:) like as one says, A^aSobaHa qalobiY SaridFA↓: (TA:) the [lizard called] Dab~ is spoken of as saying,
laA ya$otahiY A^ano yaridaA
A^aSobaHa qalobiY SaridaA
[(assumed tropical:) My heart has become cold, or indifferent, (meaning disposed to abstinence,) not desirous of coming to drink]. (O.) ＝ -A2- Sarida, (M, L, K,) or Sarida Eani Alr~amiy~api, (S,) or mina Alr~amiy~api, (A,) said of an arrow, (S, M, A, K,) and of a spear, (M, L,) aor. as above, (L,) and so the inf. n., (M, A, L,) It passed through, or transpierced, or a part of it passed through, (S, M,) the animal at which it was shot [or thrown], by reason of its sharpness; expl. by nafa*a Hid~apF: (S:) or it penetrated so that its extremity passed through; expl. by nafa*a Had~uhu; (L, K;) or xarajato $abaApu Had~ihi; and so Sarada, aor.
Saruda
. (A. [See SaAridN: and see an ex. in a verse cited voce buqoyaA.]) ― -b2- And Sarida, (K,) inf. n. SaradN and SarodN, (M, L,) [the latter inf. n. suggesting that one says also Sarada,] said of an arrow, (M, K,) and of a spear and the like, (M,) It missed the object of aim: thus having two contr. significations: (M, L, K:) and ASrd↓ also has the latter of these two significations. (L.) ＝ -A3- Sarida said of a horse, aor.
Sarada
, [inf. n. SaradN,] (tropical:) He became galled in the place of the saddle: (K, TA:) [or he had a white place, or white places, on his back, produced by galls, or by hair growing in the places of galls: (see SaridN and SuradN:)] and, said of a camel, he had white fur growing in the place of a gall produced by the saddle, after its healing. (AO.) ＝ -A4- See also 4.

2 taSoriydN *
2. taSoriydN, (S, M, K,) in the giving to drink, (S, K,) is The giving to drink less than satisfies thirst. (S, * M, K. *) One says, Sr~dhu He gave him to drink less than satisfied his thirst. (M.) And Sar~adotu Al$~aAriba Eani AlmaA='i I stopped short the drinker from drinking the water. (A.) And saqaY saqoyFA gayora taSoriydK [He gave to drink a quantity not less than satisfied thirst]. (A.) And Sr~d Als~aqoYa He stopped short the giving to drink before satisfying thirst. (A.) And Sr~d $urobahu He cut short, or put a stop to, his drinking. (TA.) And Sr~d $araAbahu He made his beverage to be little in quantity. (A.) And accord. to the T, taSoriydN signifies The drinking less than satisfies thirst. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (S, K,) in giving, (S,) (tropical:) The making to be little, or small, in quantity or number. (S, K, TA.) One says, Sr~d AlEaTaA='a (tropical:) He made the gift to be little, or small, (M, A, TA,) lahu to him. (A, TA.) And it is said in a trad., [app. relating to a particular class of persons,] lano yadoxula Aljan~apa A_il~aA taSoriydFA, meaning qaliylFA [i. e. (assumed tropical:) They will not enter Paradise save in small number]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [Also, app., An arrow's hitting the object of aim: see its part. n. muSar~idN.] ＝ -A3- And The act of scattering, or dispersing. (El- Kálee, TA.) ＝ -A4- And Sr~d said of barley and of wheat, It put forth its awn, but not its ears, though almost doing the latter. (El-Hejeree, M.)

4 ASrd Als~ahoma *
4. ASrd Als~ahoma, (S, M, L, K,) and Alr~umoHa; (M;) and Saradahu↓; (M, L, K;) He made the arrow, and the spear, or a part thereof, to pass through (S, M) the animal at which it was shot [or thrown]: (S:) or to penetrate so that its extremity passed through. (M, L, K.) [See Sarida and SaAridN.] ＝ -A2- See also 1, latter part.

7 AinoSiraAdN *
7. AinoSiraAdN is said to mean The experiencing of cold. (Meyd. [Mentioned by him, with the expression of a doubt as to the true meaning, and as only occurring, to his knowledge, in a prov., which see in Freytag's “ Arab. Prov. ” i. 357: but A^akaAmK, there, should be A_ikaAmK.])

SarodN *
SarodN (S, M, L, K) and SaradN↓, (M, L,) the former a simple subst. and the latter an inf. n., (Lth,) and SariydN↓, (TA,) Cold, or coldness: (S, M, L, K:) or intense cold: (M, L:) SarodN is a Pers. word, [originally sarod,] arabicized: (S, K:) or, accord. to a number of authors, it is an Arabic word adopted by the Persians. (MF.) One says yawomu SarodK and SaradK↓ [A day of cold: or of intense cold]. (A.) ― -b2- For the former, see also SaridN, in two places. ― -b3- Also, the former, A high place in mountains; (AA, L, K;) being the coldest part. (AA, L.) ＝ -A2- SarodN signifies also Pure, unmixed, unadulterated, or genuine; (S, M, L, K;) applied to beverage, (L,) such as is termed nabiy*, (S, L,) and to wine, (L,) and to anything. (M, K.) One says ka*ibN SarodN (assumed tropical:) An unmixed lie. (S, L.) And A^uHib~uhu Hub~FA SarodFA I love him with a pure, genuine, or sincere, love. (AZ, S, L.) ― -b2- [Hence,] jayo$N SarodN (assumed tropical:) An army composed only of the sons of one father or ancestor: (L:) or an army altogether consisting of sons of one's paternal uncle [meaning of one's relations]: (AO:) or, (M, A, L, K,) and jayo$N SaridN↓ (M, A, L) and SaradN↓, (K,) (assumed tropical:) A great army; (K;) (tropical:) an army that appears, from the slowness of its motion, by reason of its great number, to be inanimate. (M, A, L.) ＝ -A3- See also SuradN, near the end.

SaradN *
SaradN: see SarodN, in three places: ＝ -A2- and see SuradN, near the end.

yawomN SaridN *
yawomN SaridN An intensely-cold day; and layolapN SaridapN an intensely-cold night: (M, L:) [or] yawomN SarodN↓ a cold day: (S:) and riyaAHN SawaAridu. [pl. of riyHN↓ SaAridapN↓] cold winds. (Ham p. 596.) And A^aroDN SarodN↓ A cold land: pl. SuruwdN: (M:) the latter (i. e. the pl.) contr. of juruwmN. (S.) And rajulN SaridN A cold, or an intensely-cold, man: and qawomN SarodaY↓ a cold, or an intensely-cold, company of men. (M, L.) See also miSoraAdN. ― -b2- SaridN applied to milk, In a state of decomposition, (O, K, TA,) by reason of cold. (TA.) ― -b3- SaridN Eano $aYo'K (assumed tropical:) Abstaining, refraining, or desisting, from a thing; [as though cold with respect to it;] leaving, relinquishing, or forsaking, it. (M.) See 1. ＝ -A2- See also SarodN. ＝ -A3- And see SaAridN ＝ -A4- SaridN applied to a horse, (tropical:) Galled in the place of the saddle: (K, TA:) or, (L,) as also muSar~adN↓, (A, TA,) having a white place, or white places, on his back, produced by galls, (L, TA,) or having on his back white places, termed SirodaAn, [pl. of SuradN,] produced by hair growing in the places of galls. (A.) [And app. applied in a similar sense to a camel: see Sarida.]

SuradN *
SuradN A certain bird, (S, M, K,) above the size of the sparrow, (M,) having a large head, (K,) which preys upon sparrows: (T, K:) a certain bird, black and white, or party-coloured, (A^aboqaEu,) with a white belly: (A:) a certain bird of the crow-kind, also called AlwaAqiY: (Msb:) the Arabs used to regard its cry, (L, Msb,) and the bird itself, (L,) as of evil omen, (L, Msb,) and used to kill it; and they are forbidden to kill it, in order to dispel the idea of a thing's being of evil omen: (Msb:) there are two species thereof; one species is called by the people of El-'Irák AlEaqoEaqu [a name now applied to the magpie, corvus pica]; the other species, called AlS~uradu AlhamohaAmu, [so in the L, but in my copy of the Msb AlhyAm,] is the wild sort, which is found in Nejd, upon the trees called EiDaAh; it is never seen but upon the ground, [so in the L, but in my copy of the Msb, it is never seen upon the ground,] springing from tree to tree: (Sukeyn En-Numeyree, L, Msb:) when chased, and hard pressed, it is overtaken, and utters a cry like that of the hawk: it preys upon sparrows: (Msb:) it is described by AHát as a bird black and white, or party-coloured, (A^aboqaEu,) with a white belly, and a back of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour (A^axoDar), [or, as is said in the L, half white and half black, found in trees,] large in the head and beak, having a talon with which it preys upon sparrows and other small birds, as large as the point of a spear: (Mgh, Msb:) some add to this that it is called Almujaw~afu, because of the whiteness of its belly; and AlA^axoTabu, because of the dark, or ashy, dust-colour of its back; and AlA^axoyalu [a name now applied to the green woodpecker, picus viridis], because of its diversity of colour; that it is never seen but upon a branch (fiY $uEobapK, and so in the L,) or a tree, (Mgh, Msb,) and can scarcely ever, or never, be taken, (Msb,) or can never be taken: (Mgh, L:) it is regarded as of evil omen: (Mgh:) Sgh says that it is called sumayoTN, [perhaps a mistranscription for $umayoTN, because black and white,] in the dim. form: (Msb:) [it is said that] it was the first bird that fasted for the sake of God: (K:) the pl. is SirodaAnN: (S, M, Msb, K:) and the female is called SuradapN. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) A white place, (S, M, L, K,) produced by galls, (S, L, K,) or by the saddle; (M;) or SuradapN signifies a white place produced by hair growing in the place of a gall; likened to the colour of the bird thus called: (A:) pl. SirodaAnN. (M, A.) And (assumed tropical:) A white place on the hump of a camel: (M:) or white fur growing in the place of a gall produced by the saddle, after its healing: (AO:) pl. as above.
(AO, M.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) A certain vein (As, M) beneath the tongue, (As,) or in the lower part of the tongue, (M,) of the horse. (As, M.) And AlS~uradaAni (assumed tropical:) Two veins, (Lth, Ks, S, M, L, K,) of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour, (A^axoDaraAni, Lth, Ks, M, L,) in the lower part of the tongue, by means of which the tongue moves about, (Lth, Ks, L,) or penetrating within (yasotaboTinaAni) the tongue: (S, M, K:) or two veins, on the right and left of the tongue: (L:) or, as some say, two bones, which erect (yuqiymaAni) the tongue. (M.) Yezeed Ibn-Es- Sa'ik in his saying
lahu SuradaAni munoTaliqaA All~isaAni
means *aribaAni [i. e. *aribaA All~isaAni, for *aribN lisaAnuhumaA, as though he said lahu lisaAnN *aribN He has a long, or an unbridled, tongue; the phrase that he uses being pleonastic]. (S.) ― -b4- Also, (M, L,) or SarodN↓, (so in the K,) and SaradN↓, which is the more known, (TA,) A nail in a spear-head, (M, L, K,) by means of which the shaft is fastened to it. (L, K. *) ― -b5- Accord. to Sh, fat~aHa Suradahu means He opened his mind, so as to reveal his secrets. (TA. [But this is perhaps a mistranscription, for ftH Surarahu: see Sur~apN.])

SarodaY *
SarodaY [pl. of SaridN; and, agreeably with analogy, of SariydN]: see SaridN, and Sur~aAdN.

SariydN *
SariydN: see SarodN. ― -b2- Also Hoar-frost, or rime; syn. jaliydN. (TA.) ― -b3- See also Sur~aAdN.

SariydapN *
SariydapN [app. a subst.; for if it were an epithet, having the meaning of a pass. part. n. of the fem. gender, it should by rule be without p;] A female animal, (M,) or a ewe, (K,) injured, (M, K,) and emaciated, (M,) by cold: pl. SaraAy^idu: (M, K:) on the authority of IAar. (Kudot;.)

Sur~aAdN *
Sur~aAdN Cold and humid clouds in which is no water: (As:) or cold and humid clouds which the wind carries away; as also Sur~ayodN↓ and SariydN↓: (M:) or thin clouds in which is no water; (S, K;) as also Sur~ayodN↓ (K) and SarodaY↓. (L, TA.)

Sur~ayodN *
Sur~ayodN: see what next precedes, in two places.

SaAridN *
SaAridN: see its fem., with p, voce SaridN. ＝ -A2- Also, (S, A, L, K,) and miSoraAdN↓, (S, L, K,) and SaridN↓, (A,) An arrow that has passed, or of which a part has passed, through the animal at which it has been shot; syn. naAfi*N: (S, L, K:) or of which the extremity only has passed through: when part of the arrow has passed through, it is termed naAfi*N; and when the whole has passed through, maAriqN. (A.) And nabolN SawaAridu Arrows of which the extremities have passed through the animals at which they have been shot. (A.)

A^aSoradu *
A^aSoradu More [and most] cold; or more [and most] affected by cold: ＝ -A2- and More [and most] transpiercing. (Meyd, in explanations of provs. commencing with this word. [See Freytag's “ Arab. Prov. ” pp. 743-4.])

muSoradN *
muSoradN: see what next follows.

muSoridN *
muSoridN, (Ktr, L,) or muSoradN↓, (so accord. to the K, [the former agreeable with its verb, the latter app. a mistake,]) An arrow missing the object of aim. (Ktr, L, K.) [See also muSar~idN.]

muSar~adN *
muSar~adN Beverage, (S,) or drink, (A,) made little in quantity. (S, A.) ― -b2- And Given little to drink: or (assumed tropical:) given a small gift. (S.) ＝ -A2- See also SaridN.

muSar~idN *
muSar~idN An arrow hitting the object of aim. (Ktr, L.) [See also muSoridN.]

miSoraAdN *
miSoraAdN A wind (riyHN) cold; or intensely cold: or accompanied by cold and humid clouds. (IAar, M.) ― -b2- Also, and SaridN↓, (T, S, M, K,) A man quickly sensible of cold; (S;) weak in enduring cold; (K;) impatient of cold. (T, M.) ― -b3- And the former, Strong in enduring cold. (K.) ― -b4- And A land without trees, and without anything (K, TA) of herbage. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also SaAridN.

muSoTaridN *
muSoTaridN A man vehemently angered or enraged: (K:) and so muSoTar~N, without d. (TA.)

SuraATN *
SuraATN A long sword: a dial. var. of suraATN [q. v.]. (K.)

SiraATN *
SiraATN A road, or way; as also siraATN, (S, K,) which is the original; (TA;) and ziraATN: (S:) [see the second of these three words:] Akh says that the people of El-Hijáz make it fem., and Temeem make it masc. (S and Msb voce zuqaAqN, q. v.) ― -b2- AlS~iraATu, also written with s, is likewise [The name of] a bridge extended over the midst of Hell, (K, TA,) sharper than a sword, and thinner than a hair, over which the creatures will pass, the people of Paradise passing over it with their works, some like the blinding lightning, and some like the wind sent forth, and some like coursers, and some running, and some walking, and some dragging themselves along; and a crier will cry, from the lower parts of the empyrean, “ Lower your eyes until Fátimeh, the daughter of Mohammad, (may God bless and save him, and may God be well pleased with her and her two sons,) pass over; ” and the fire will say to the believer, “ Pass thou over, O believer, for thy light hath extinguished my flame; ” and thereupon, the feet of the people of the fire will slip. (TA.)

maSoraTN *
maSoraTN and miSoraTN: see masoraTN.

1 SaraEahu *
1. SaraEahu, aor.
SaraEa
, inf. n. SaroEN (S, O, * Msb, K) and SiroEN, (S, O, * K,) the former inf. n. of the dial. of Temeem and the latter of Keys, (S, O,) and maSoraEN, which is also a n. of place, [and, accord. to rule, of time also,] (S, O, K,) said of a man, (S, Msb,) He threw him down, or prostrated him, on the ground; (O, L, K, TA;) namely, a man. (T, TA.) And SaraEatohu is also said of a beast, [the pronoun referring to the rider,] meaning It threw him down. (TA in art. qmS.) Hence the saying, Almaniy~apu taSoraEu AlHayawaAna (tropical:) [Death prostrates the animal]. (TA.) And mavalu Almuw^omini kaAlxaAmapi mina Alz~aroEi taSoraEuhaA Alr~iyHu mar~apF fataEodiluhaA A^uxoraY i. e. [The similitude of the believer is as the fresh, or juicy, plant of seedproduce,] which the wind bends at one time, throwing it from side to side, [and straightens at another.] (TA, from a trad.) And SuriEa Al$~ajaru The trees were cut and thrown down. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 3. ― -b3- [Hence also,] SuriEa He was affected with the disease termed SaroE [expl. below]. (Msb.) And He (a man) was affected with diabolical possession, or madness; inf. n. SaroEN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 2, in two places.

2 Sr~Ehu *
2. Sr~Ehu, [inf. n. taSoriyEN,] He threw him down or prostrated him, on the ground, vehemently; namely, a man. (K.) ＝ -A2- Sr~E AlbaAba, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He made the door-way to have what are termed miSoraAEaAni [i. e. a pair of folding doors]; as also SaraEahu↓. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And [hence,] Sr~E Al$~iEora (tropical:) He made the poetry to have what are termed miSoraAEaAni; as also SaraEahu↓: (K, TA:) or Alt~aSoriyEu fiY Al$~iEori, (S,) or taSoriyEu Albayoti mina Al$~iEori, (TA,) is the making the first miSoraAE [meaning hemistich] to rhyme [like the second]; (S;) [i. e.] the making the last foot of the first hemistich like the last of the second [in rhyme]: (TA:) derived from the miSoraAE of the door-way. (S, TA.)

3 SaAoraEa
3: SaAraEotuhu faSaraEotuhu↓, (S, Msb, TA,) inf. n. of the former muSaAraEapN and SiraAEN, (Msb, TA,) I wrestled with him, each of us endeavouring to throw down the other, [and I overcame him in doing so, or and I threw him down.] (TA.)

5 tSr~E lahu *
5. tSr~E lahu (tropical:) He became lowly, humble, or abased, and abashed, to him; as also tDr~E: (Az, TS, TA:) or (tropical:) he lowered, humbled, or abased, himself to him: one says, maA zilotu A^ataSar~aEu lahu and A_ilayohi (tropical:) [I ceased not to lower, humble, or abase, myself to him] Hat~aY A^ajaAbaniY [until he answered me, or gave me his assent]. (Z, TA.)

6 tSArEwA *
6. tSArEwA They wrestled, one with another, endeavouring to throw down one another; and [ASTrEwA↓ signifies the same; or] ASTrEA↓ they two wrestled, each endeavouring to throw down the other. (TA.)

7 AnSrE *
7. AnSrE [He, or it, became thrown down, or prostrated, on the ground]. (Occurring in the K in art. jA^v.)

8 A_iSotaraEa
8: see 6, in two places.

SaroEN *
SaroEN an inf. n. of 1. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Also, [as a subst., Epilepsy, or falling sickness: and sometimes, app., ecstatic catalepsy; a sort of trance into which a person falls:] a certain disease, (S, O, Msb, K,) well known, (S, O,) resembling madness, or diabolical possession, (Msb,) accord.
to the Ra-ees [Ibn-Seenà, whom we call “ Avicenna ”], (TA,) preventing, but not completely, the vital organs from performing their actions [or functions]; the cause of which is an obstruction that occurs in one or more of the venters (buTuwn) of the brain and in the ducts of the A^aEoSaAb [here meaning nerves] by which the members are moved, [arising] from an abundant thick or viscous xiloT [or humour], whereby the ruwH [by which is here meant, as in many other instances, the vital spirit, or nervous fluid,] is prevented from pervading them in the natural manner, and consequently the members become [spasmodically] contracted. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A sort, or species: and a state, condition, or manner of being: syn. DarobN and fan~N: (S, K:) of a thing: (K:) and so SiroEN↓: and likewise DaroEN and DiroEN: (TA:) [See also SaroEapN:] pl. [of mult.] SuruwEN (S, K) and [of pauc.] A^aSoruEN. (K.) One says, huwa *uw SaroEayoni, meaning *uw lawonayoni [i. e. He, or it, has two sorts, or species: or two distinctive qualities or properties]. (Ibn-'Abbád, Z, O, K.) And tarakotuhumo SaroEayoni I left them changing from state to state. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) And liloA^amori SaroEaAni, meaning TarafaAni [i. e. There are two ways of performing the affair, either of which may be chosen]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also SiroEN, in three places. ― -b3- SaroEaAni Two camels of which one comes to the water when the other returns from it, by reason of their [the camels'] multitude. (S, O, K.) ― -b4- And [hence, perhaps,] AlS~aroEaAni signifies The night and the day; (K;) [and] so AlS~iroEaAni↓, with kesr, like AlS~irofaAni: (TA in art. Srf:) or the forenoon and the afternoon; from the first part of day to midday and from midday to sunset; each of these being termed SaroEN: (S, O, K:) or the morning, between daybreak and sunrise, and the evening, between sunset and nightfall; as also AlEaSoraAni; (S and K in explanation of AlA^aboradaAni;) and some assert that it is formed by transposition from AlEaSoraAni: (TA:) or the two extremities of the day. (A, TA.) And one says, A^atayotuhu SaroEaYi Aln~ahaAri I came to him in the morning and evening; or between daybreak and sunrise and between sunset and nightfall. (S, O, K.) And laqiytuhu SaroEaYi Aln~ahaAri I met him at the two extremities of the day. (A, TA.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says,
kaA^an~aniY naAziEN yavoniyhi Eano waTanK
SaroEaAni raAy^iHapF EaqolN wataqoyiydu
meaning As though I were one, i. e. a camel, yearning towards his place of abode, which an evening and a morning, in evening a binding of the fore shank to the arm and in the morning a shackling of the legs, turn [or keep] away from a settled abiding-place: or, as Aboo-'Alee relates it, raAy^iHapN, [as a partial substitute for SaroEaAni,] meaning, an evening, when there is a binding of the fore shank to the arm, and a morning, when there is a shackling of the legs; for they bind the camel's fore shank to his arm in the evening when he is lying down, and they shackle his legs in the morning so that he may pasture [but not stray]: another reading is SaroEaAhu [his morning and evening]. (TA.) ― -b5- One says also, huwa SaroEu ka*aA i. e. Hi*aA='ahu [app. meaning It is over against, or corresponding to, such a thing]. (O, K.)

SiroEN *
SiroEN an inf. n. of 1. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- And i. q. muSaAriEN. (K.) See the latter in two places. ＝ -A3- See also SaroEN, former half. ― -b2- [Also Either of two opposite conditions in which one is or stands &c. in respect of an affair or case.] One says, Talabotu mino fulaAnK HaAjapF faA@noSarafotu wamaA A^adoriY EalaY A^aY~i SiroEaYo A^amorihi huwa [I sought, or demanded, of such a one, an object of want, and then turned away, and I know not in which of the two opposite conditions he was in respect of his affair, or case]; i. e., his affair, or case, did not become apparent, or clear, or known, to me. (S, O, K. *) And a poet says,
faruHotu wamaA wad~aEotu layolaY wamaA darato
EalaY A^aY~i SiroEaYo A^amorihaA A^ataraw~aHu
[And I went, and bade not farewell to Leylà, and she knew not in which of the two opposite conditions in respect of her affair, or case, I was going]; i. e., whether I went from her presence retaining attachment, or forsaking; (S, TA;) or, as Z says, in a condition of success or of disappointment. (TA.) ― -b3- See also SaroEN, in the middle of the paragraph. ― -b4- Also A like; a similar person or thing; and so SaroEN↓. (O, K.) One says, humaA SiroEaAni (S, O) and SaroEaAni↓ (O) They two are likes: (S, O:) and so $iroEaAni, &c. (S.) And h`*aA SiroEuhu and SaroEuhu↓ This is the like of him, or it: and so DiroEuhu and DaroEuhu, &c. (IAar, TA.) ― -b5- And A strand of a rope: (O, K:) and so DiroEN: (O:) pl. SuruwEN (O, K) and DuruwEN. (O.)

SaroEapN *
SaroEapN A single act of throwing down, or prostrating, on the ground; or a single suffering of prostration. (K, TA.) See also SiroEapN. ― -b2- And A state, or condition: (O, K:) so in the saying, huwa yafoEaluhu fiY kul~i SiroEapK [He does it in every state, or condition]: (O:) [see also SaroEN:] or, accord. to the “ Mufradát ” [of Er-Rághib], the state, or condition, of him who is thrown down, or prostrated. (TA.)

SuroEapN *
SuroEapN One who is often thrown down, or prostrated, by men. (K.)

SiroEapN *
SiroEapN A mode, or manner, of throwing down, or prostrating; or of being thrown down, or prostrated: (S, * K, TA:) a word similar to rikobapN and jilosapN. (S.) Hence, (K,) one says, suwo'u AlAisotimosaAki xayorN mino Husoni AlS~iroEapi [The bad manner of holding fast upon one's beast is better than the good manner of being thrown down, or prostrated]: (S, K:) i. e., when one holds fast, though he ride not well, it is better than one's being thrown down, or prostrated, in a manner that does not hurt him; because he who holds fast sometimes overtakes, but he who is thrown down will not attain: (TA:) a prov.: or, as some relate it, Husoni AlS~aroEapi↓, which means the good manner of the single suffering of prostration. (K, * TA. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 623.])

SuraEapN *
SuraEapN One who throws down, or prostrates, others; (S, O, K;) as also Sir~iyEN↓ and Sur~aAEapN↓: (K:) or one who throws down, or prostrates, his antagonists much, or often; (TA;) and so Sir~iyEN↓, (S, O,) and Sur~aAEapN↓, with damm and teshdeed, mentioned by Ks: (O:) or Sir~iyEN↓ signifies one who throws down, or prostrates, vehemently, though he be not well known for doing so; as also Sar~aAEN↓ and SariyEN↓, the latter like A^amiyrN [in measure, but this I think doubtful, probably added from finding Sir~iyEN mistranscribed]: or Sir~iyEN↓, accord. to the T, one whose occupation, whereby he is known, is the throwing down, or prostrating, others [as a wrestler]. (TA.) It is said in a trad. that the Prophet asked, Whom do ye reckon the SuraEap among you? they said, Him whom men will not throw down: and he said, He is not such, but is (assumed tropical:) he who governs himself on the occasion of anger: or, as some relate it, (assumed tropical:) the forbearing on the occasion of anger, (O, TA. *)

SaruwEN *
SaruwEN One who wrestles much with others, endeavouring to throw them down: (T, K, TA:) pl. SuruEN. (K.)

SariyEN *
SariyEN i. q. maSoruwEN↓ [meaning Thrown down, or prostrated, on the ground]: pl. SaroEaY. (O, K.) ― -b2- [And i. q. maSoruwEN↓ meaning (as the latter is expl. in the Msb) Affected with the disease termed SaroEN, q. v.] ― -b3- And [i. q. maSoruwEN↓ meaning] Affected with diabolical possession, or madness. (TA.) ― -b4- One says also, baAta SariyEa AlkaA^osi (tropical:) [He passed the night prostrated by the influence of the wine-cup]. (TA.) ― -b5- And raA^ayotu $ajarahumo SaroEaY and muSar~aEaAtK↓ (tropical:) I saw their trees cut down [and laid prostrate]. (TA.) And nabaAtN SariyEN (tropical:) A plant, or plants, or herbage, growing upon the surface of the earth, not erect. (TA.) And guSonN SariyEN (tropical:) A branch falling down to the ground: (TA:) or a branch broken down and fallen to the ground: (Msb:) and [in like manner] one says guSonN maSoruwEN↓; and maSaAriEu is said to occur in a verse of Lebeed as pl. of the latter word, the reg. pl. of which is maSaAriyEu: but in that verse some read muSar~aE↓ [which has a similar meaning. (TA. [See EM p. 157.]) ― -b6- SariyEN also signifies (assumed tropical:) Slain: from the same word as applied to a branch and expl. above: pl. SaroEaY. (Msb.) ― -b7- And (tropical:) A twig, or rod, drooping, or hanging down, to the ground, falling upon it, but with its base upon the tree, so that it remains falling in the shade, the sun not reaching it, and therefore becomes more soft, or supple, than the branch [from which it depends], and more sweet in odour; and it is used for rubbing and cleaning the teeth [i. e. masaAwiyk are made of it]: pl. SuruEN: (K, TA: [the pl. is thus in the L; but in some copies of the K SuroEN:]) or, accord. to the T, the
sing. signifies a twig, or rod, that falls from the tree called ba$aAm [q. v.]; and the pl. is SuroEaAnN: the former pl. occurs in a trad., in which it is said that the Prophet was pleased to rub and clean his teeth with SuruE. (TA.) ― -b8- Also (tropical:) A bow from which nothing has been pared off: or of which the wood has dried upon the tree; (S, O, K, TA:) or this [latter] is only called SariyfN. (TA.) ― -b9- And (tropical:) A whip, in like manner, (S, O, K, TA,) from which nothing has been pared off. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also SuraEapN.

SaraAEapN *
SaraAEapN The quality of throwing down, or prostrating, vehemently. (TA.)

Sar~aAEN *
Sar~aAEN: see SuraEapN.

Sir~iyEN *
Sir~iyEN: see SuraEapN, in four places.

Sur~aAEapN *
Sur~aAEapN: see SuraEapN, in two places.

SaAriEN *
[SaAriEN act. part. n. of 1: pl. SaAriEuwna and SaraEapN. Hence,] qawomN SaraEapN A people, or party, who throw down, or prostrate, those with whom they wrestle. (TA.)

maSoraEN *
maSoraEN A place [and accord. to rule a time also] of throwing down, or prostrating, on the ground: (S, O, K:) [pl. maSaAriEu.] ― -b2- [And (assumed tropical:) A place of slaughter: for] maSaAriEu Alqawomi signifies the places of slaughter of the people, or party. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, O, K.)

miSoraEN *
miSoraEN: see miSoraAEN.

muSar~aEN *
muSar~aEN [pass. part. n. of 2, q. v.]. One says, mararotu biqatolaY muSar~aEiyna [I passed by slain persons thrown down, or prostrated, on the ground]: with teshdeed because relating to many objects. (S.) ― -b2- See also SariyEN, in two places.

miSoraAEN *
miSoraAEN Either half [i. e. leaf] of a door [meaning of a folding door]: (MA, * Msb, KL: *) either one of what are termed the miSoraAEaAni of a door or door-way: (S, Msb:) miSoraAEaA baAbK means two doors that are set up, meeting together, the place of entrance thereof being in the middle of them [i. e. between them]: (T, O, K, TA:) [and in like manner, miSoraAEaA sitorK (occurring in the S in art. sjf) means the two separate halves, that hang side by side, so as to meet together, of a curtain; like the two leaves of a folding-door:] and the miSoraAE of a door [or curtain] is also called its miSoraE↓: (TA:) the pl. of miSoraAEN is maSaAriyEu. (MA.) ― -b2- Hence, the miSoraAE in poetry; (S;) A hemistich: (MA, KL:) [this is the general meaning: in a more restricted sense,] miSoraAEaAni in poetry means a single verse [i. e. a pair of hemistichs] having two rhymes: (T, O, * K, * TA:) [using it in the latter sense, i. e. as meaning a verse of which the former hemistich rhymes with the latter, which is app. the primary signification,] Aboo-Is-hák says, the miSoraAEaAni are the two doors of the ode, like the mSrAEAn of the house, or chamber, or tent: and he says that the derivation of the word is from AlS~aroEaAni meaning “ the two extremities of the day. ” (TA.)

maSoruwEN *
maSoruwEN: see SariyEN, in four places; where it is stated that maSaAriEu is said to occur as a pl. thereof; the reg. pl. being maSaAriyEu.

muSaAriEN *
muSaAriEN One who wrestles with another, endeavouring to throw him down; as also SiroEN↓: you say, humaA SiroEaAni↓ i. e. They are two persons wrestling together, each endeavouring to throw down the other. (K, * TA.)

AlS~arofu *
AlS~arofu signifies The turning, or sending, or putting, a thing away, or back, from its way, or course; the causing it to turn away, or back; therefrom; the averting it, or repelling it therefrom: (M:) or the shifting a thing from one state, or condition, to another; (Bd in vi. 105;) and so Alt~aSoriyfu↓. (TA.) You say, Sarafahu, (M, K,) or Sarafahu Eano wajohihi, (Msb, TA,) i. e. Eano sananihi, (TA in art. wjh,) aor.
Sarifa
, (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. SarofN, (M, Msb,) He turned, sent, or put, him, or it, away, or back, &c., (M, K,) from his, or its, way, or course. (M.) And nafosahu Eani SArf↓ Al$~aYo'i, meaning SarafahaA Eanohu [He turned himself away, or back, from the thing]. (M.) And Sarafotu Alr~ajula Ean~iY [I turned the man away, or back, or I averted him, or repelled him, from me]. (S.) And Sarafa AlS~iboyaAna He dismissed the boys, or sent them away, syn. qalabahumo, (S, K,) from the school: (K:) or Sarafotu AlS~abiY~a I let the boy go his way; and in like manner, AlA^ajiyra the hired man. (Msb.) And Sarafa A@ll~`hu Eanoka AlA^a*aY [May God avert from thee harm]. (S.) And ASTrf↓ wajohahu (K in art. sfw and sfY) [meaning Sarafahu i. e.] He turned away his face. (TK in that art.) Sarafa A@ll~`hu quluwbahumo, in the Kur [ix. 128], means God hath made them to err in requital of that which they have done: (M, TA:) or God hath turned them away, or may God turn them away, from belief. (Bd.) And saA^aSorifu Eano A=yaAtiY, in the Kur [vii. 143], means [in like manner] I will requite by causing to err from the direction of my signs. (O, TA.) [And one says also, Sarafahu A_ilaY ka*aA He turned him (i. e. another man, or the like, as in the Kur xlvi. 28), or it (for ex. his mind or intention), to such a thing.] ― -b2- [Hence,] Sarafa Alkalimapa, (TA,) inf. n. SarofN, (O,) He declined, or inflected, the word [i. e. the noun] with tenween. (O, TA.) See also 2. ― -b3- [Hence, also,] AlS~arofu means The exchanging, or giving in exchange, gold for silver [and the reverse]: because it is turned (yuSorafu) thereby from one metal to another. (M.) You say Sarafa Ald~araAhima He exchanged, or gave in exchange, the dirhems for [other] dirhems or for deenárs. (Mgh.) And Sarafotu Al*~ahaba biAld~araAhimi I exchanged, or gave in exchange, the gold for dirhems: (Msb:) and Ald~araAhima biAld~anaAniyri [the dirhems for deenárs]. (S.) ― -b4- It is said in a trad. respecting Al$~ufoEap [or the right of pre-emption], A_i*aA Surifati AlT~uruwqu falaA $ufoEapa i. e. When the roads thereof are made distinct [app. by their being turned in different directions, from the house, or piece of land, in question, to the possessions of different proprietors, there is no right of pre-emption]: (TA:) the inf. n. of the verb in this case is SarofN. (TA.) ― -b5- You say also, Sarafotu AlmaAla I expended the property; (Msb;) [and so Sr~ftuhu↓; for] Alt~aSoriyfu, (M,) or taSoriyfu Ald~araAhimi, (O,) fiY AlbiyaAEaAti, (M, O, K, *) means the expending of money [in the purchase of articles of merchandise]. (M, O, K. *) ― -b6- And Sarafotu AlkalaAma I embellished the speech [app. by distorting it, or otherwise altering it]; and Sar~afotuhu↓ has a similar, but intensive, meaning: (Msb:) or Sarofu AlHadiyvi means the embellishing of discourse, or speech, (A 'Obeyd, S, M, O, K,) by adding in it, (A 'Obeyd, S,) or and adding in it; (M, O, K;) and in like manner Sarofu AlkalaAmi: (K: [of which see another explanation voce SarofN:]) and is [said to be] from AlS~arofu in pieces of money, meaning “ the superiority of one over another in value. ” (O, K.) ― -b7- Sarafa liA^aholihi [as though meaning Sarafa nafosahu liA^aholihi]: see 8. ― -b8- [See also SarofN, below.] ＝ -A2- Sarafa Al$~araAba, (M, O, K,) inf. n. SuruwfN, (M, TA,) He did not mix the beverage, or wine; (M, O, K, TA;) as also Sr~fhu↓, and ASrfhu↓; the last mentioned by Th. (M, TA.) And Sarafa Alxamora, (K, TA,) aor.
Sarifa
, inf. n. SarofN, (TA,) [or perhaps this should be SuruwfN, as in the next preceding sentence,] He drank the wine unmixed; (K, TA;) [and so Sar~afahaA↓; for] taSoriyfu Alxamori, (S, O,) or Alt~aSoriyfu fiY Alxamori, (K,) signifies the drinking of wine unmixed. (S, O, K. [Freytag has erroneously expl. Sarafa as meaning simply He drank wine.]) ＝ -A3- Sarafati Albakorapu, (S, O, K,) aor.
Sarifa
, (S, O,) inf. n. SariyfN, (S, M, O, K,) The sheave of the pulley caused a sound to be heard on the occasion of the drawing of water: (S, M, * O, K:) and the Sariyf of the door, and of the tush of the camel, is like that of the sheave of the pulley; (S, O;) [i. e.] the Sariyf of the door, (M, K,) and of the writingreed (M, Msb) and the like, (M,) is a creaking, or grating; (M, Msb, * K;) and so that of the tush of the camel: (K: [wnAbu AlbaEiyri in the CK is a mistake for wnAbi AlbEyr:]) one says of a man, and of a camel, Sarafa binaAbihi, (M, TA,) and Sarafa naAbahu, (TA,) aor.
Sarifa
, inf. n. SariyfN, He grated his canine tooth [against its opposite] so as to cause a sound to be heard: (M, TA:) the Sariyf of the stallioncamel is [indicative of] his threatening: (M:) or that of the canine tooth of the she-camel denotes her weariness; and that of the canine tooth of the he-camel, his lust: (IKh, TA:) or the Sariyf of the stallion is from briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness; and that of the female, from fatigue. (As, TA.) [But] ― -b2- Sarafato, (IAar, S, M, O, K,) aor.
Sarifa
, (S, M, O,) inf. n. SuruwfN (S, M, O, K) and SiraAfN, (Lth, Lh, IAar, S, M, O, K,) said of a bitch, (S, O, K,) or of any female having a cloven hoof and of any having a claw, (Lh, M,) or of a ewe or she-goat and of bitch and of a cow, (Lth, TA,) or of any female animal of prey, but
mostly of a bitch, (IAar, TA,) signifies She lusted for the male: (Lth, Lh, IAar, S, M, O, K:) and the epithet applied to such an animal is SaArifN↓. (Lh, IAar, S, M, O, K.)

2 Alt~aSoriyfu *
2. Alt~aSoriyfu [in its primary acceptation is like AlS~arofu in the primary acceptation of the latter, but generally relates to several objects, or is used in an intensive sense]: see 1, first sentence: it signifies The turning of the winds (Lth, O, K, TA) from one state or condition, to another; (O, TA;) or from one direction, or course, or way, to another; (Lth, O, K, TA;) and so of the torrents, and of the horse, and of affairs, and of the verses of the Kur-án; (Lth, TA;) the making of the winds to very, or differ; and so of the clouds; (M;) the changing of the winds to south and north [&c.] and hot and cold [&c.]; (Jel in ii. 159, and xlv. 4;) or the making of the winds to be south and north, and east and west, and to be of various sorts in their kinds: (TA:) or taSoriyfu AlA=yaAti signifies [the varying, or diversifying, of the verses of the Kur-án, by repeating them in different forms; or] the making of the verses of the Kur-án distinct [in their meanings by repeating and varying them, as expl. by many of the expositors in the instances occurring in vi. 46 and 65 and 105, and xlvi. 26]. (O, K.) ― -b2- It signifies also The deriving one word from another [by modification of the form for the purpose of modifying the meaning; including what we term the declining of nouns (like AlS~arofu) and the conjugating of verbs]. (O, K.) [The science of Alt~aSoriyf in language is commonly termed Eilomu AlS~arofi↓.] ― -b3- In relation to property, or money, see 1, near the middle of the paragraph. ― -b4- And in relation to speech, see 1, near the middle of the paragraph. ― -b5- One says also, Sr~f Al$~aYo'a, (M,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) meaning He employed the thing in other [i. e. more] than one way; as though he turned it from one way to another way. (M, TA.) ― -b6- And [hence,] Sar~afotuhu fiY AlA^amori, (K,) or fiY A^amoriY, speaking of a man, (S, O,) i. q. qal~abotuhu [meaning I employed him to act in whatsoever way he pleased, according to his own judgment or discretion or free will, or I made him a free agent, in the disposal, or management, of the affair, or my affair: or (assumed tropical:) I made him, or employed him, to practise versatility, or to use art or artifice or cunning, in the affair, or in my affair; for the quasi-pass., tSr~f, is said to be from AlS~arofu as signifying AlHiylapu, and is expl. as syn. with AiHotaAla: but the former meaning is the more common: and it is also used as meaning simply I employed him in the managing of the affair, or my affair]. (K.) ― -b7- [Hence also, Sr~f Alfarasa He exercised the horse.] ＝ -A2- Sr~f Al$~araAba: and Sr~f Alxamora: see 1, latter half.

3 SaAorafa
3: see 1, third sentence. ― -b2- The inf. n. muSaArafapN signifies also (assumed tropical:) The dealing, or buying and selling, with any one biSarofK [app. meaning with art or artifice or cunning, or it may perhaps mean in the exchanging of money: see SayorafiY~N], (KL.)

4 ASrf Al$~araAba *
4. ASrf Al$~araAba: see 1, latter half.

5 tSr~f *
5. tSr~f [quasi-pass. of 2: thus,] said of a man's face, It turned about; or was, or became, turned about; syn. tql~b. (Jel in ii. 139.) ― -b2- And It (a thing) was, or became, employed in other [i. e. more] than one way; as though it were turned from one way to another way. (M.) ― -b3- [Hence,] tSr~f fiY AlA^amori, (K,) or fiY A^amoriY, (S,) quasi-pass. of Sar~afotuhu fiyhi, (S, * O, K,) thus syn. with tql~b [meaning He acted in whatsoever way he pleased, according to his own judgment or discretion or free will, or as a free agent, in the disposal, or management, of the affair, or my affair; or he was, or became, employed to do so]: (K:) or it is from AlS~arofu as signifying AlHiylapu; (S, M, TA;) i. e. it means (tropical:) [he practised versatility, or] he used art or artifice or cunning, in the affair, or in my affair; syn. AiHotaAla. (TA [and in like manner Bd in xxv. 20: but the former meaning is the more common: see also 8].) [It is also used as meaning simply He employed himself, or was employed, in the managing of the affair, or my affair; because the management of affairs generally requires the practice of versatility, or the use of art or artifice or cunning.] ― -b4- [Hence also, said of a horse, He was exercised.]

7 AnSrf *
7. AnSrf, (S, M, O, K,) inf. n. AinoSiraAfN, (O,) and munoSarafN is also sometimes an inf. n. thereof as well as a n. of place, (S,) quasi-pass. of Sarafahu, (S, M,) said of a thing, (M,) or of a man; (S;) as such signifying It [or he] turned, or went, away, or back, from its [or his] way, or course; or was, or became, turned, or sent, or put, away, or back, therefrom; or averted, or repelled, therefrom: (M:) [or shifted from one state, or condition, to another: (see 1, first sentence:)] or i. q. Ainokaf~a; so in the copies of the K; but [this is an inadequate explanation;] the right [or better] explanation is AnokafaA^a [i. e. he, or it, reverted, or returned; or was, or became, turned away or back]; agreeably with what is said in the O. (TA.) vum~a A@noSarafuwA in the Kur [ix. 128] means Then they return, or go back, from the place in which they have listened: or then they turn away from doing aught of that which they have heard. (M.) ― -b2- [Accord. to Golius, it signifies also It ran in a small stream; or the like; for he explains it as meaning “ manavit: ” but for this he names no authority. ― -b3- Said of a noun, it means It was inflected, or declined, with tenween.]

8 ASTrf *
8. ASTrf (tropical:) He sought, sought after, or sought to gain, sustenance or the like, (M, TA,) and used art or artifice or cunning [in so doing]; (M;) for his family, or household; (M, TA;) as also Sarafa↓, aor.
Sarifa
; you say, Sarafa liA^aholihi [as though meaning Sarafa nafosahu liA^aholihi] and ASTrf: (M:) or he used art or artifice or cunning (tSr~f) in the seeking of gain: (O, K, TA:) or [meaning thus] you say, ASTrf fiY Talabi Alkasobi. (S.) ＝ -A2- It is also trans.: you say, ASTrf wajohahu: see 1, first quarter. ― -b2- And ASTrf Ald~araAhima He procured the dirhems in exchange for [other] dirhems or for deenars. (Mgh.)

10 AisotaSorafotu A@ll~`ha AlmakaAriha *
10. AisotaSorafotu A@ll~`ha AlmakaAriha (S, O, K) I begged God to avert from me the things, or events, that are objects of dislike or hatred. (O, K.)

SarofN *
SarofN [as an inf. n.: see 1]. ― -b2- Used as a subst., The evil accidents, mishaps, or calamities, of time, or fortune; [thus expl. as having a pl. signification;] Sarofu Ald~ahori meaning HadavaAnuhu, (S, M, O, K,) and nawaAy^ibuhu, (S, O, K,) or HawaAdivuhu; (Msb;) because it [i. e. time, or fortune,] turns things from their way, or course: (M:) [but it seems to be more properly rendered the shifting of fortune, or its shifting about; and to be an inf. n. sometimes used as a simple subst., and therefore having a pl., for] its pl. is SuruwfN. (M, Msb.) In the phrase qado $aHaTato Sarofu nawaAhaA, in a verse of Sakhr-el-Ghei, [ISd says,] he has made it fem. because of its dependance upon Aln~awaY [which is fem.; as though the meaning were The afflictions that are the consequence of the course taken by her in her journey have exceeded the bounds of moderation]: (M:) [or it is here made fem. because having the signification of a broken pl., which is fem.:] or the meaning is, qado baEudato taSar~ufu wajohihaA Al~a*iY A^axa*ato fiyhi [i. e. the shiftingabout of her course that she has taken has become far-extending; Sarof being thus used as an inf. n.; for the Arabs sometimes make the inf. n. fem., saying A^awojaEatoniY Darobuka as well as A^awojaEaniY Darobuka; (see EM p. 157;) and this I think the most preferable explanation]. (Skr in his Expos. of the Poems of the Hudhalees, p. 14 of the vol. edited by Kosegarten.) ― -b3- Also Repentance. (S, M, O, Msb, K.) [See a phrase below, in which this and other meanings are assigned to it.] ― -b4- And (tropical:) Art, artifice, or cunning. (Yoo, S, M, O, K, TA.) Hence, in the Kur [xxv. 20], famaA= yasotaTiyEuwna SarofFA walaA naSorFA (tropical:) [And they are not able to put in practice art or artifice or cunning, nor aid]: (S, TA:) or this means and they are not able to avert, or repel, from themselves punishment, (O, K, TA,) nor to aid themselves. (O, TA.) ― -b5- And Excellence, or superiority, of a dirhem, (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) and of a deenár, (M,) over another, (S, M, &c.,) in goodness, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or in value; (M, Mgh, O, K;) as in the saying, bayona Ald~irohamayoni SarofN [Between the two dirhems is a difference of excellence], because of the [superior] goodness of the silver of one of them: (S:) and in like manner, of speech; (O, K;) as in the saying fulaAnN laA yaEorifu Sarofa AlkalaAmi Such a one knows not the excellence of speech over other speech: (O:) and [in like manner] one says, lih`*aA EalaY h`*aA SarofN There is, or pertains, to this, an excess, and an excellence, over this; for when one is judged to excel, it, or he, is turned aside from its, or his, likes, or fellows. (O, K. *) ― -b6- And The night; and the day: (K:) [because of their interchanging:] AlS~arofaAni signifies the night and the day; (S, O, K;) as also AlS~irofaAni↓; (K;) the latter accord. to Ibn-'Abbád; (O;) like AlS~iroEaAni, with kesr also [as well as with fet-h]. (TA.) ― -b7- In the saying (S, M, O, Msb) of the Arabs, (M,) or of the Prophet, (O, Msb,) in a certain trad., (K,) laA yuqobalu minohu SarofN walaA EadolN
[Neither Sarof nor Eadol shall be accepted from him], (S, M, * O, Msb, *) by Sarof is meant repentance; (S, M, O, Msb, K;) and by Eadol, ransom: (M, Msb, K:) or by the former, art, or artifice, or cunning; (Yoo, S, M, O, K;) and by the latter, ransom: (M:) or by the former, acquisition of gain; and by the latter, ransom: (K:) or by the former, a supererogatory act; (A'Obeyd, M, O, K;) and by the latter, an obligatory act: (A'Obeyd, M, K:) or vice versâ: (K:) or by the former, weight; and by the latter, measure: (M, O, K:) or by the former, deviation; and by the latter, a right, or direct, course: (IAar, M:) or by the former, maA yutaSar~afu fiyhi [app. meaning an evasive artifice]; and by the latter, a like: (Th, M:) or by the former, value, or price; and by the latter, a like; the saying originally relating to the bloodwit (Ald~iyap): one says, lamo yaqobaluwA minohumo SarofFA walaA EadolFA, i. e. They did not accept from them a bloodwit, nor did they slay one man for him, of their people, who had been slain; but they required from them more than that; for the Arabs used [often] to slay two men, and three, for one man; when they slew a man for a man, that was AlEadol with them; and when they took a bloodwit, having turned from the blood to another thing, that was Sarof, i. e. the value, or price, was Sarof: then the saying was applied in relation to anything, so as to be proverbially used in the case of him who was to render more than was incumbent on him: it has also been said that by Sarof is meant [in the saying cited above] something additional, or in excess; but this is nought. (M.)

SirofN *
SirofN: see its dual in the next preceding paragraph, near the middle. ＝ -A2- Also Pure, unmixed, or free from admixture; (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) applied to wine, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) or beverage, as meaning unmixed, (S, M, O, Msb,) and so maSoruwfN↓, (O, K,) and to other things, (K,) to blood, and to phlegm, (TA,) and to anything (M, Msb) as meaning free from turbid foulnesses: (Mgh, * Msb:) and SariyfN↓ likewise signifies anything having in it no admixture. (TA.) ＝ -A3- And A certain dye, (Msb,) a red dye, (S, O, K,) with which the thongs, or straps, of sandals are dyed, (S, O,) or with which the hide is dyed: (Msb:) or a certain red thing with which the hide is tanned (yudobagu [perhaps a mistranscription for yuSobagu]). (So in a copy of the M.)

AlS~arofapu *
AlS~arofapu One of the Mansions of the Moon; [the Twelfth Mansion;] a single very bright star, [ β of Leo,] (S, O, K, and Kzw in his Descr. of the Mansions of the Moon,) by which are some small evanescent stars; (Kzw;) over against, (bitiloqaA=', so in my copies of the S,) or following, (O, K and Kzw ubi suprà,) Alz~uborap; (S, O, K, Kzw;) [i. e.] it is a single star behind the xaraAtaAni of the Lion; (M;) it is on the hinder part of the tail (*anab) of the Lion; [wherefore it is called by our astronomers Deneb;] and is also called the qunob, which means the sheath of the penis, of the Lion: (Kzw in his Descr. of Leo: [in the S and O, erroneously, “ the qalob of the Lion: ”]) [it rose aurorally, in Central Arabia, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, on the 8th of Sept., O.
