S.; and set aurorally on the 9th of March:] Ibn-Kunáseh says, (M,) it is called AlS~arofapu because of the turning away of the cold (S, M, O, K) from the heat, (M,) and the coming of the heat, (S, O,) accord. to the [O and] K at its rising, but [as] IB says, correctly because of the turning away of the heat [at its rising], and the coming of the cold: (TA:) [i. e., correctly,] it is thus called because of the turning away of the cold at its setting in the early mornings, and the turning away of the heat at its rising from beneath the rays of the sun in the early mornings: (Kzw in his Descr. of Leo:) when it rises before the dawn, that is the beginning of autumn; and when it sets with the rising of the dawn, that is the beginning of spring. (M.) [Hence,] AlS~arofapu is [called] naAbu Ald~ahori Al~a*iY yufotar~u, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) or naAbu Ald~ahori Al~a*iY yafotar~u Eanohu [The dog-tooth of time, or fortune, which it shows smiling]: for when AlSrfp rises, [a mistake for “ sets, aurorally, ”] the blossoms come forth and the herbage attains its full height: (M and K in art. fr:) in the T it is said that AlS~arofap is called by the Arabs naAbu Ald~ahori [the dog-tooth of time, or fortune,] liA^an~ahu yafotar~u Eani Albarodi waEani AlHar~i fiY AlHaAlatayoni [i. e. because it smiles revealing (the advent of) the cold and (that of) the heat, in its two states (of auroral rising and setting)]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- SarofapN also signifies A certain kind of bead (xarazapN); (Lh, S, M, O, K;) mentioned among those by means of which men are captivated, or fascinated, or restrained by women from other women; (S, O, K; *) or by means of which men are conciliated, so as to be turned thereby from their ways of acting or conduct or the like. (Lh, M.) ＝ -A3- And A bow having upon it a black mark or spot ($aAmapN sawodaA='u), the arrows of which, when they are shot, will not hit the object of aim. (O, K.) ＝ -A4- And one says, Halabotu Aln~aAqapa SarofapF, meaning I milked the she-camel in the early morning, between dawn and sunrise, and then left her until the like time of the morrow. (O, K. *)

AlS~arafaAnu *
AlS~arafaAnu Death; (M, K;) a name of death. (IAar, O.) ＝ -A2- And SarafaAnN signifies Lead; syn. raSaASN: (S, Msb, K:) or raSaASN qaloEiY~N [q. v.]: (M:) and (K) accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, (O,) copper; syn. nuHaAsN. (O, K.) ＝ -A3- And A sort of dates; (S, M, O, Msb;) a heavy sort of dates: (K:) n. un. with p: (M:) AHn says, (M, O,) on the authority of certain of the Arabs, (O,) that the SarafaAnap is a red date, like the baroniy~ap, (M, O, Msb,) but (M, O) hard to be chewed, (M, O, K,) tough, (M, O,) and the heaviest of all dates: (M, O, Msb:) persons having households and slaves and hired men provide it, because of its satisfying quality, (O, K, [but for ljrA=tihaA in the O, referring to the n. un., and lijazaAtihaA in copies of the K, and ljizAyatihA in the CK, I read lijazaAy^ihaA, which is evidently the right reading, and agrees with what here follows,]) and its standing in great stead: (O, K:) or it is the [sort of dates called] SayoHaAniY~ [q. v.]: (K:) AHn says, En-Nowshajánee told me that the SarafaAnap is [called] AlS~ayoHaAniy~apu in El- Hijáz, and in like manner its palm-tree. (O.) SarafaAnapN riboEiy~aho tuSoramu biAlS~ayofi watuw^okalu biAl$~atiy~aho is one of their proverbs [expl. in art. rbE]. (AHn, O, K.)

SarafiY~N *
SarafiY~N A camel of a certain excellent sort; (M, O, K;) a rel. n.: (O, K:) or it is correctly with d; (O, * K;) i. e. SadafiY~N [q. v.]: (O:) some say that it is with d; and this is the right. (M.)

SaruwfN *
SaruwfN A she-camel that makes a grating, or creaking, sound with her tushes, or canine teeth. (S, O, K.)

SariyfN *
SariyfN inf. n. of 1 in the senses expl. in the last sentence but one of the first paragraph [q. v.]. (S, M, &c.) ＝ -A2- See also SirofN. ― -b2- Applied to milk, (S, M, O, K,) Just milked; (K;) brought away from the udder while hot, (S, M, O,) when milked. (S, O.) ― -b3- Also Dry saEaf [or palmbranches]: n. un. with p: (AHn, M:) [i. e.] SariyfapN↓ signifies a dry saEafap. (K.) And AHn says, (M, O,) in one place, (M,) AlS~ariyfu signifies, (M, O, K,) as some assert, (O,) What has become dry, of trees; (M, O, K;) like AlD~ariyEu; (M;) called in Pers. Hu*oxuw$, (so in copies of the K, in the CK xudoxuw$, and in the O Alxa*oxuwa$, [all app. mistranscriptions, for I find nothing like them in Pers. except partially, i. e. xuw$ meaning “ dry, ” like xu$ok,]) and also called [in Arabic] Alqafolapu [the tree that has become dry]. (O.) [See also SariyEN, with the unpointed S.] ＝ -A3- Also Silver: so in a verse cited voce A_ino (page 107, third col.): (ISk, S, O:) or pure silver. (K.) ＝ -A4- See also the next paragraph.

SariyfapN *
SariyfapN: see the next preceding paragraph. ＝ -A2- Also A thin, round cake of bread; syn. ruqaAqapN: pl. SurufN and SiraAfN and [coll. gen. n.] SariyfN↓. (K.)

xamorN Sariyfiy~apN *
xamorN Sariyfiy~apN Wine of Sariyfuwnu, (S, O, K,) a place, (S, O,) i. e. a town, (O,) in El-' Irák, (S, O,) in the Sawád of El-' Irák near 'Okbarà, (O, TA;) not, as it is implied in the K, from another of the same name in Wásit: (TA:) or, as some say, wine just taken from the dan~ [or jar]; like [as one says] labanN SariyfN. (O, K.)

Sar~aAfN *
Sar~aAfN: see SayorafiY~N: ＝ -A2- and see also SaArifN.

Sir~iyfN *
Sir~iyfN: see the next paragraph.

SaArifN *
SaArifN [act. part. n. of 1: as such having, among other meanings, the meaning of Grating, or creaking; or making a grating, or creaking, sound: and so Sar~aAfN↓, but properly in an intensive sense; for] the dual of Sar~aAfN is used by the poet Aboo-Khirásh as meaning two thongs of a sandal that make a creaking sound: (M:) [and Sir~iyfN↓ likewise means making a creaking sound with the teeth: so accord. to Freytag, from Jereer.] One says, maA fiY famihi SaArifapN, meaning He has not in his mouth a canine tooth [lit. a
grater or creaker; for sin~N SaArifapN a tooth that makes a grating, or creaking, sound]. (M.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, last sentence.

SaArifapN *
SaArifapN: pl. SawaArifu: see taSaAriyfu, below.

SayorafN *
SayorafN One who practices art or artifice or cunning, in the disposal, or management, of affairs; (S, M, O, K;) as also SayorafiY~N↓; (S, O, K;) which latter is applied by the poet Suweyd Ibn-Abee-Káhil El-Yeshkuree [in the like sense] as an epithet to a tongue, in his saying,
walisaAnFA Sayorafiy~FA SaArimFA
kaHusaAmi Als~ayofi maA mas~a qaTaEo
[And a cunning, sharp tongue, like the edge of the sword, what it touches it cuts]. (S, O.) ― -b2- See also what next follows.

SayorafiY~N *
SayorafiY~N i. q. Sar~aAfN↓, (S, M, O, Msb,) or Sar~aAfu daraAhima, (K,) and so SayorafN↓, (M, Msb, K,) i. e. A money-changer; (M, Msb, TA;) except that Sar~aAfN has an intensive signification [app. as meaning a skilful money-changer, and hence it is often used in the present day as meaning a banker]: (Msb:) all are applied to him who knows and distinguishes the relative excellence, or superiority, of pieces of money: (Mgh:) these appellations are from AlmuSaArafapu, (S, O,) or from Alt~aSar~ufu, (M,) or from SarofN meaning “ excellence, ” or “ superiority, ” of one dirhem [or deenár] over another, (Mgh, and Msb on the authority of IF in relation to the first,) because such as excels, or is superior, is turned aside from the deficient: (Mgh:) the pl. is SayaArifapN (S, M, O, K) and SayaArifu (M) and SayaAriyfu, this last occurring in poetry, (S, M, O, K,) by poetic license, for the sake of the measure. (S, O.) ― -b2- See also SayorafN.

taSaAriyfu AlA^umuwri *
taSaAriyfu AlA^umuwri [and SawaArifuhaA pl. of SaArifapN↓] The varieties, or vicissitudes, of affairs or events. (M, TA.)

maSorifN *
maSorifN A place of turning away or back: [see also munoSarafN:] hence, in the Kur [xviii. 51], walamo yajiduwA EanohaA maSorifFA, (TA,) meaning [And they shall not find] a place to which to turn away, or back, from it: (Bd, Jel:) or, a turning away, or back, from it: (Bd:) pl. maSaArifu. (TA.)

maSoruwfN *
maSoruwfN [pass. part. n. of 1: see its verb: ― -b2- and] see munoSarifN: ＝ -A2- see also SirofN.

mutaSar~afN *
mutaSar~afN i. q. mutaqal~abN [as meaning Place, or scope, or room, for free action]. (A, voce sarobN [q. v.]; and so in the Fáïk.)

mutaSar~ifN *
mutaSar~ifN is an epithet applied to a verb [as meaning That is perfectly inflected], opposed to jaAmidN [q. v.]. (TA, voce qado.) ― -b2- [ZarofN mutaSar~ifN and TarofN gayoru mutaSar~ifK signify the same, respectively, as ZarofN mutamak~inN and ZarofN gayoru mutamak~inK: see art. mkn. ― -b3- wakiylN mutaSar~ifN, means A factor, an agent, or a deputy, who acts according to his own free will in the disposal, or management, of an affair.]

munoSarafN *
munoSarafN is a n. of place, [meaning A place of turning away or back, like maSorifN,] as well as an inf. n. [of 7]. (S.)

munoSarifN *
munoSarifN and gayoru munoSarifK denote the two different sorts of nouns, (O, K,) meaning, respectively, [like maSoruwfN↓ and gayoru maSoruwfK,] Inflected, or declined, with tenween, and not so inflected or declined. (O, TA.)

1 Saramahu *
1. Saramahu, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
Sarima
, (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. SaromN (S, M, Msb, K) and SuromN, (M, K,) or the latter is a simple subst., (M, Msb,) He cut it, syn. qaTaEahu, (S, M, Mgh, Msb,) in any manner: [i. e. it signifies also he cut it through; or he cut it off, or severed it; for thus the meaning of qaTaEahu is generally explained:] (M:) or it signifies [only] he cut it (qaTaEahu) so as to separate it: (M, K:) namely, a thing, (S,) such as a rope, and a raceme of dates. (TA.) One says, Surimato A^u*unuhu i. q. Sulimato [i. e. His ear was cut off, entirely]. (TA.) And Sarama Aln~axola, (S, M, Msb, K,) and Al$~ajara, (M, K,) and Alz~aroEa, aor. as above, inf. n. SaromN, (M,) He cut off the fruit, or produce, of the palm-trees, (S, M, Msb, * K,) and the trees, (M, K,) and the corn, or the like; (M;) as also ASTrmhu↓. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Saramahu, (S, M, MA, K,) [aor. as above,] inf. n. SaromN (S, MA,) or SuromN, (M, MA,) or the latter is a simple subst., (S,) (assumed tropical:) He cut him (i. e. another man); meaning he ceased to speak to him, or to associate with him; he cut him off from friendly, or loving, communion or intercourse; forsook him, or abandoned him; syn. qaTaEa kalaAmahu; (S, M, K;) and hajarahu: (A and Mgh and K in art. hjr:) or he cut himself off, or separated himself, from him, namely, his friend; he cut off [or withdrew] his friendship from him. (MA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce A^ab~a.] And Sarama waSolahu, aor. as above, inf. n. SaromN and SuromN, (assumed tropical:) [He cut, or severed, his bond of union,] as indicative of resemblance [to the act of cutting, or severing, properly thus termed]. (M.) ― -b3- And Sarama A^amorahu (assumed tropical:) [He decided his affair]. (O voce DahoyaA^a, q. v. [See also SaArimN, and SariymapN.]) ＝ -A2- Sarama is also intrans., as syn. with AnSrm, q. v. (M, K.) And [hence] one says, A^adobarati Ald~unoyaA biSaromK i. e. (assumed tropical:) [Worldly good departed] by becoming cut off, or by ceasing, and coming to an end. (TA.) ― -b2- One says also, Sarama EinodanaA $ahorFA, meaning (assumed tropical:) He stopped, stayed, or tarried, with us a month: (K, TA:) mentioned by El-Mufad- dal, on the authority of his father. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Sarama, (Msb,) [aor.
Saruma
,] inf. n. SaraAmapN and SuruwmapN, (M,) It (a sword) was, or became, sharp, (M, Msb,) and did not bend. (M.) ― -b2- And [hence,] Saruma inf. n. SaraAmapN, said of a man, (S, M, Msb, K, TA,) as being likened to a sword, (TA,) (tropical:) He was, or became, courageous; (Msb;) or hardy, strong, or sturdy, (S, TA,) or sharp, penetrating, or vigorous and effective, (M, K, TA,) and courageous. (S, M, K, TA.)

2 Sr~mhu *
2. Sr~mhu [He cut it; cut it through; or cut it off, or severed it; namely, a number of things considered collectively; or a single thing much, or in several places]: (M:) taSoriymu AlHibaAli signifies taqoTiyEuhaA [i. e. the severing of the ropes]: the verb being with teshdeed to denote muchness [of the action], or multiplicity [of the objects]. (S, TA.) [Hence, taSoriymu AlA^aTobaA='i The cutting off of the teats of camels: a phrase mentioned in the TA.]

3 SArmhu *
3. SArmhu, (MA,) inf. n. muSaAramapN, (KL, TA,) (assumed tropical:) He effected a disunion with him: (MA:) or he cut him off from himself, being in like manner cut off by him: (KL:) or he cut him off from friendly, or loving, communion or intercourse, being so cut off by him: forsook him, or abandoned him, being forsaken, or abandoned, by him: cut him, i. e. ceased to speak to him, being in like manner cut by him: for AlmuSaAramapu signifies AlmuhaAjarapu and qaToEu AlkalaAmi. (TA.)

4 ASrm Aln~axolu *
4. ASrm Aln~axolu The palm-trees attained, or were near, to the time, or season, for the cutting off of their fruit. (S, M, Msb, K, TA.) ― -b2- And [hence perhaps,] ASrm said of a man, (S, K, TA,) inf. n. A_iSoraAmN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, poor, (S, K,) having a numerous family, or household: (K:) or in a evil condition, though having in him intelligence (tamaAsuk): [it is said that] the original meaning is he had a Siromap, i. e. portion, of property remaining to him. (TA.)

5 tSr~m *
5. tSr~m quasi-pass. of Sar~amahu; (M;) i. q. tqT~E [i. e. It became cut; cut through; or cut off, or severed; said of number of things considered collectively; or of a single thing as meaning it became cut, &c., much, or in many places, or into many pieces]. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also 7, in three places. ＝ -A2- Also (assumed tropical:) He affected hardiness, strength, sturdiness, and endurance, or patience; or constrained himself to behave with hardiness, &c. (S, K.)

6 tSArmwA *
6. tSArmwA (assumed tropical:) They cut, forsook, or abandoned, one another; (MA;) they separated themselves, one from another; (KL, in which only the inf. n. is mentioned;) they severed the bond of union, or communion, that was between them; disunited, or dissociated, themselves, one from another; syn. taqaATaEuwA. (S, * MA, in the former of which only the inf. n. is mentioned.)

7 AnSrm *
7. AnSrm It became cut; cut through; or cut off, or severed; (S, M, K, TA;) quasi-pass. of Saramahu; (M, TA;) said of a rope [&c.]; and so Sarama↓. (M, K, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AnSrm mina Aln~aAsi [or Eani Aln~aAsi] (assumed tropical:) He separated himself from mankind; said of the wolf and of the crow [&c.]. (ISk, S, M. *) And AnSrm All~ayolu (assumed tropical:) The night went away, or departed; as also tSr~m↓: (Msb:) and AnSrm Al$~itaA='u (assumed tropical:) The winter ended; and tSr~mt↓ Als~anapu (assumed tropical:) The year ended: (TA:) and AlqitaAlu tSr~m↓ (assumed tropical:) The fighting ended, or ceased. (Mgh.)

8 ASTrmhu *
8. ASTrmhu: see 1, third sentence.

SaromN *
SaromN Skin: [or leather:] (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) a Pers. word (S, Msb) arabicized, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) originally jarom [correctly Jarom]. (Mgh, Msb, TA.)

SuromN *
SuromN is an inf. n. like SaromN, (M, K,) or a simple subst.: (M, Msb:) [see the first paragraph, in three places: in one of its senses, there expl.,] it is syn. with hijoraAnN and qaTiyEapN: (TA:) and SariymapN↓ [likewise] signifies (assumed tropical:) Separation from a friend: pl. SuramN. (MA. [This pl. is app. there mentioned as of SariymapN; but it is more probably of SuromN.]) ＝ -A2- Suromu Ald~iyki: see daliykN.

SiromN *
SiromN Tents (A^aboyaAtN), (S, M,) of men, (S,) collected together, (S, M,) separate from [those of other] men: (M:) or i. q. SirobN, (O in art. Srb,) which means a few tents (buyuwt [in the O, erroneously, butuwt]) of the weak sort of the Arabs of the desert: (IAar, O, * K, TA; all in art. Srb:) and hence, (M,) a company (M, Msb, K, TA) of men, (Msb, TA,) not many; or simply a company (TA) alighting and abiding with their camels by the side of the water: (Msb, TA:) pl. A^aSoraAmN [a pl. of pauc.] (S, M, Msb, K) and A^aSaArimu, (S,) or A^aSaAriymu, (M,) or both, (K,) but accord. to IB the latter of these two is the right, [being a pl. pl., i. e. pl. of A^aSoraAmN,] (TA,) and SuromaAnN, (Sb, M, K,) with damm. (K.) ― -b2- And i. q. DarobN. (K. [So, app., in all the copies; accord. to the TK as meaning A sort, or species: but I think it most probable that this is a mistranscription for SirobN, with which, as has been stated above, SiromN is syn. accord. to the O.]) ＝ -A2- Also i. q. xuf~N munoEalN (M) or xuf~N munaE~alN (K) [i. e. A soled boot: that xuf~ here means a boot, not a camel's foot, is indicated by its being immediately added by SM that] Sar~aAmN↓ signifies A seller thereof. (TA.)

SaromapN *
SaromapN [an epithet applied to a man, but used as a subst., and therefore having for its pl. SaramaAtN]. One says, huwa SaromapN mina AlS~aramaAti, [the last word said to be thus (muHar~akap) in the TA, but in the CK (in which as well as in my MS. copy of the K mn is omitted) written AlS~aromAti,] meaning (tropical:) He is [a person] slow to revert from his anger. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, [if not a mistranscription for Siromap↓,] A portion of silver, melted, and cleared of its dross, and poured forth into a mould. (TA.)

Siromap *
Siromap A herd, or detached number, of camels, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) consisting of about thirty: (S:) or from twenty to thirty: (M, K:) or from thirty to five and forty: (M:) or to fifty, and forty; (K;) if amounting to sixty, termed SidoEap: (TA: [but see this latter word:]) or from ten to forty: (M, Msb, K:) or from ten to some number between that and twenty: (M, K:) or more than a *awod [which is at least two or three] up to thirty: (T voce A_ibilN:) or about forty: (Ham p. 753:) or less than a hajomap, which is a hundred or nearly a hundred: (Id. p. 637:) pl. SiramN. (S, * M, * Msb.) ― -b2- A portion of property. (TA.) ― -b3- And A detached portion of clouds: (S, M, Msb, K:) pl. as above. (S, M.) ― -b4- See also SariymapN. ― -b5- And see SaromapN.

SaraAmN *
SaraAmN and SiraAmN↓ The cutting off of the fruit of palm-trees: (S, * Msb, and L voce jadaAdN:) and (L voce ja*aAdN) the time, or season, thereof: (S, L:) or the time, or season, of the ripening of the fruit of palm-trees. (M, K.) ＝ -A2- SaraAmi: see the next paragraph, in two places.

SuraAmN *
SuraAmN: see SaArimN. ＝ -A2- Also The last milk [remaining in the udder] after what is termed Alt~agoriyz [which is variously explained (see 2 in art. grz), in the CK and in one of my copies of the S erroneously written Alt~agoziyr,] which a man draws when in need of it. (S, K. *) Bishr says,
A^alaA A^aboligo baniY saEodK rasuwlFA
wamawolaA humo faqado Hulibato SuraAmu
[Now deliver thou to Benoo-Saad a message, and to their chief, that the last milk in the udder has been drawn]: (S:) the last two words [the latter of which is written in the CK SarAmi↓] are a prov., meaning (assumed tropical:) the excuse has reached its uttermost: (S, K:) thus says AO: (S:) IB says that SuraAmu in the saying of Bishr means the she-camel that is termed AlS~aromaA='u↓, that has no milk; [i.e. that the phrase means the she-camel that has now no milk has been milked;] and that he makes it a proper name; and that he [also] means thereby the latter of the two senses here following. (TA.) ― -b2- AlS~uraAmu is also one of the names for War, or battle; (As, S, K; *) and so SaraAmi↓, [indecl.,] like qaTaAmi: (K:) and one of the names for calamity, or misfortune. (As, S, K. * [See also SayoramN.])

SiraAmN *
SiraAmN: see SaraAmN. ― -b2- Sometimes it is applied to signify Palm-trees themselves; because the fruit is cut off: so in a trad. (TA.)

SaruwmN *
SaruwmN: see SaArimN, in two places. ― -b2- Also a she-camel that will not come to the watering-trough to drink until it is left to her unoccupied; (K, TA;) cutting herself off from the other camels. (TA.)

SariymN *
SariymN i. q. maSoruwmN↓, (M, Msb,) Cut; cut through; or cut off, or severed: (S, Msb, K:) and having the fruit cut off; syn. majoduwdN; (S, K;) applied to palm-trees (naxol). (M.) And the former, A heap (kudos) of corn or the like that has been cut, or of which the produce has been cut off; syn. maSoruwmN↓. (M, TA.) And Whose ear has been cut off entirely (Aal~a*iY Surimato A^u*unuhu): pl. SuromN. (TA. [See also the fem., with p, voce baHiyrapN, where the pl. is said to be SurumN.]) ― -b2- [Applied to the lungs, it means properly Burst asunder. Hence the saying,] jaA='a Sariyma saHarK, [so in copies of the K, accord. the TA siHor, but correctly either saHarK or saHorK q. v., in the CK bA'a and Sariymu, which last word is obviously wrong,] meaning (tropical:) He came disappointed of attaining what he desired, or sought, and in a state of despair. (K, TA.) And huwa Saraymu sHrK EalaY h`*aA AlA^amori [i. e. Sariymu saHorK or saHarK] (tropical:) He is wearied and eager for this thing, or affair. (TA.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) An affair decided, determined, or resolved, upon. (M, TA.) ― -b4- Used as a subst., see SariymapN, in two places. ― -b5- Also (assumed tropical:) The daybreak, or dawn; (S, M, K;) because cut off from the night; (M;) as also SariymapN↓: (S:) and the night; (ISk, M, K;) because cut off from the day; (M;) or the dark night: (S:) thus having two contr. meanings: (S, K:) and a portion thereof; (Th, M, K;) i. e., of the night; (TA;) as also SariymapN↓: (M, K:) and SariymaA All~ayoli the first and last parts, or beginning and end, of the night. (TA.) The phrase in the Kur [lxviii. 20] faA^aSobaHatN kaA@lS~ariymi means [And it became in the morning] burnt up and black like the night: (S, M, Bd, TA:) or like the dark night, being burnt up: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or like the black night: (Katádeh, TA:) or like the day, by its whiteness from excessive dryness: (Bd:) or like that garden of which the fruits have been cut off: (Bd, TA: *) or like the sands [that are termed Sariym (see SariymapN)]: (Bd:) or the meaning of Srym in this instance is that which here next follows. (TA.) ― -b6- Black land, that does not give growth to anything. (K.) ― -b7- And A piece of wood, or stick, which is placed across upon the mouth of a kid, (M, K,) or of a young weaned camel, and then tied to his head, (M,) in order that he may not such. (M, K.) ＝ -A2- See also SaArimN.

SaraAmapN *
SaraAmapN (tropical:) A man (TA) who follows his own opinion, cutting himself off from consultation with others: (M, TA:) or who acts with penetrative energy, or vigorousness and effectiveness, in the performing of his affairs: an inf. n. used as an epithet. (TA.)

SuraAmapN *
SuraAmapN What is cut off [of the fruit] of palmtrees. (Lh, M.)

SariymapN *
SariymapN Land (A^aroD) of which the seed-produce has been reaped: (S, K:) of the measure faEiylapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN. (TA.) ― -b2- And A portion, (S, M, K,) or large portion, (TA,) detached from the main aggregate, of sand; (S, M, K;) as also SariymN↓: (M, K:) [or the latter is a coll. gen. n., being used in a pl. sense:] one says A^afoEaY SariymapK (S) or SariymK↓ (K) [A viper of a detached sand-heap or of detached sand-heaps]; like as one says Hay~apu xal~K. (S in art. xl.) ― -b3- And A group, or an assemblage, (S,) or a detached number, (M,) of the trees called gaDFA, and salam, (S, M,) and A^aroTFY, and of palm-trees; and likewise SiromapN↓, of A^aroTFY, and of samur. (M.) ― -b4- See also SariymN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also (assumed tropical:) Decision, or determination, (S, M, K TA,) EalaY $aYo'K [to do a thing]: (S, TA:) and the deciding of an affair, (M, K, TA,) and the firm, or sound, execution thereof: (TA:) or an object of want upon accomplishment of which one has decided,
or determined; as also EaziymapN: (AHeyth, TA:) pl. SaraAy^imu. (TA.) One says, huwa maADi AlS~ariymapi and AlS~araAy^imi [He is effective of decision &c. and of decisions &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also SuromN.

SurayomapN *
SurayomapN A detached number [or a small detached number, for it is app. dim. of SiromapN,] of camels. (TA.)

Sar~aAmN *
Sar~aAmN: see SaArimN. ― -b2- Also A preparer, or seller, of Sarom, (MA,) whence it is derived, (Mgh,) i. e. skin, or leather: (MA:) or it signifies as expl. voce SiromN, last sentence. (TA.)

SaArimN *
SaArimN Cutting; cutting through; or cutting off, or severing; and Sb says that SariymN↓ is used in the same sense, like as Dariyb in the phrase Dariybu qidaAHK is used in the sense of DaArib. (M.) A_ino kunotumo SaArimiyna, in the Kur [lxviii. 22], means If ye be deciding, or determining, upon the cutting off of the fruit of the palm-trees. (TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A man cutting, or severing, his bond of union; or one who cuts, or severs, that bond; and so [but in an intensive sense] Sar~aAmN↓ and SaruwmN↓; (M;) or this last signifies, (M, K,) as also SuraAmN↓, (K,) having strength to cut, or sever, (M, K,) the bond of his union. (M.) ― -b3- Also, applied to a sword, (S, M, Msb, K,) and [in an intensive sense] SaruwmN↓, (M, K,) Sharp, (S, M, Msb, K,) and not bending: (M:) pl. of the former SawaArimu. (TA.) ― -b4- And the former, (S, M, K, TA,) applied to a man, (S, M, TA,) as being likened to a sword, (TA,) (tropical:) Hardy, strong, or sturdy, (S, TA,) or sharp, penetrating, or vigorous and effective, (M, K, TA,) and courageous. (S, M, K, TA.) ― -b5- And AlS~aArimu (tropical:) The lion. (K, TA.)

SayoramN *
SayoramN A calamity (K, TA) that extirpates everything. (TA. [See also SuraAmN, last sentence.]) ＝ -A2- Also Firm, or sound, of judgment. (K.) ＝ -A3- And i. q. wajobapN, (S, M, K,) like SayolamN, (TA,) i. e. An eating once in the day: (M, K, * TA: *) or, accord. to Yaakoob, an eating at the time [of morning] called AlD~uHaY (M, TA) [and not again] to the like time of the morrow: (TA:) one says, fulaAnN yaA^okulu AlS~ayorama (S, M, * K *) i. e. [Such a one eats] once (K, TA) in the day: but AHát says, I asked El-Asma'ee respecting the bazomap and the Sayoram, and he said, I know it not: this is the language of the devil. (TA.)

A^aSoramu *
A^aSoramu A man having the extremity of his ear cut off. (Mgh.) ― -b2- See also muSorimN. ― -b3- Also [the fem.] SaromaA='u A she-camel having little milk; (M, K;) because her abundance of milk has become cut off: (M:) pl. SuromN. (K.) See also SuraAmN. [In the Ham, p. 230, it is implied that it signifies A she-camel such as is termed muSar~amapN↓ as meaning whose A^axolaAf (or teats) have been cut off: for it is there said that the poet 'Orweh has applied the term SaromaA=' to (assumed tropical:) a cooking-pot, likening it to the she-camel termed muSar~amapN meaning as expl. above.] ― -b4- Also, (S, K,) or falaApN SaromaA='u, (M,) A desert in which is no water. (S, M, K. [See also one of the explanations of the dual, here following.]) ― -b5- AlA^aSoramaAni signifies The wolf and the crow; (ISk, S, M, K;) because of their separating themselves (ISk, S, M) from mankind: (ISk, S:) and the [bird called] Surad and the crow: and the night and the day; (K, TA;) because each is cut off from the other. (TA.) El-Marrár says,
EalaY SaromaA='a fiyhaA A^aSoramaAhaA
waxir~iytu AlfalaApi bihaA maliylu
[Upon a waterless desert, in which are its wolf and crow, and in which the skilful guide of the desert is burned by the sun]. (ISk, S, M.) And tarakotuhu biwaHo$i AlA^aSoramayoni is a saying mentioned by Lh, but not expl. by him: (M, TA:) ISd says, (TA,) in my opinion it means, [I left him in] the desert, or waterless desert: (M, TA:) or, accord. to Z, in a desert, or waterless desert, in which was nothing but the wolf and the crow. (TA.)

maSorimN *
maSorimN A narrow place, that quickly flows with water: (K, TA:) so called because the flow of water is quickly cut off from it. (TA.)

muSorimN *
muSorimN A possessor of a Siromap of camels. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence], as also A^aSoramu↓, (M, K,) Having little property: (M:) or poor, [and] having a numerous household, or family. (K.) One says, kalaA^N tiyjaEu minohu kabidu AlmuSorimi [Herbage by reason of which the liver of him who has little property is pained]; i. e., abundant, so that when he who has little property sees it, he grieves that he has not many camels which he may pasture upon it. (M.)

miSoramN *
miSoramN The curved knife of the parer of spindles. (S, MA, K.)

muSar~amapN *
muSar~amapN A she-camel whose [fore or kind] pair of teats have been cut off, (S, M, K,) in order that the A_iHoliyl [or orifice through which the milk passes forth from the udder of each teat] may dry up and the milk not issue, for the purpose of giving greater strength to her: and (AA used to say, S) this is sometimes in consequence of the stoppage of the milk, something having happened to the udder, for which it is cauterized, and her milk stops, (S, K,) no milk ever issuing from the udder: (S:) see also SaromaA='u, voce A^aSoramu: or muSar~amapu AlA^aTobaA='i means a she-camel treated (Euwlijato) so that her milk has stopped. (Mgh.)

maSoruwmN *
maSoruwmN: see SariymN, first and second sentences.

1 SariYa *
1. SariYa, (S, M, Msb,) aor.
SaraYa
, (Msb,) inf. n. SarFY, (M, Msb,) said of water, It remained, or stagnated, long: or it remained long, and became altered [for the worse]: (S, Msb:) or, said of water and of milk, it remained so that its flavour became altered [for the worse]: (M:) or, said of milk, it remained undrawn from the udder, so that its flavour became bad, or corrupt. (TA.) And SariYa Ald~amoEu The tears collected [in the eye] and did not run. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Sariyati Aln~aAqapu, (Fr, M, Msb, TA,) aor. as above, (Msb,) and so the inf. n.; (M, Msb, TA;) but Ibn-Buzurj says Sarat, aor.
SariYa
; (TA;) The she-camel's milk became collected in her udder; (M, Msb, TA;) as also A^aSorat↓. (M, TA.) ― -b3- And SariYa fiY yadihi, (S, M, IKtt, TA,) with kesr; (S, TA;) or SaraY fiY yadihi;) (thus accord. to the K;) He (a man) remained in his hand, as a pledge, (S, M, K, TA,) held in custody. (S, K, TA.) ― -b4- And SirYi [thus written without any syll. sign, app. SriY,] i. q. AinoqaTaEa [It, or he, became cut off, cut short, or stopped; &c.: quasi-pass. of SaraAhu in one of the senses of the latter]: from IAar. (TA.) ＝ -A2- SaraAhu, (IKtt, Msb, TA,) aor.
SariYa
, (Msb,) inf. n. SaroYN, (IKtt, Msb, TA,) He confined it, namely, water, in a resting-place or a vessel; and in like manner, milk, and tears: (IKtt, TA:) or he collected it, namely, water, and it remained long and became altered [for the worse], or remained or stagnated long; and in like manner, but in an intensive sense, Sr~Ahu↓. (Msb.) One says also of cows [and the like], taSoriY All~abana fiY DuruwEihin~a They confine and collect the milk in their udders. (TA.) And [of a man] one says, SaraY AlmaA='a fiY Zahorihi zamaAnFA He retained the mA' [i. e. sperma] in his back a long time, (S, M, K, *) by abstaining from sexual intercourse. (M, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] SarayotuhaA, (M, Msb,) aor.
SariYa
, inf. n. SaroYN; (Msb;) and Sar~ayotuhaA↓, (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. taSoriyapN, (S, Msb,) but the latter verb has an intensive meaning; (Msb;) and A^aSorayotuhaA↓; (M;) namely, a ewe or she-goat, (S,) or a she-camel, (M, Msb,) and any other milch animal, (M,) I caused the milk to collect in her udder, (S, M, Msb,) by abstaining from milking her for some days. (S, M.) ＝ -A3- Also, i. e. SaraAhu, (M, K,) aor.
SariYa
, (K,) inf. n. SaroYN, (M,) i. q. qaTaEahu [He cut it off, cut it short, or stopped it; &c.]; (M, K;) namely, a thing. (M.) You say, SaraY bawolahu, inf. n. as above, meaning qaTaEahu [He, or it, cut short, or stopped, his urine]. (S.) And Sarayotu AlmaA='a [app. I cut short, or stopped, the drawing of the water; for it is expl. as said] A_i*aA A@sotaqayota vum~a qaTaEota. (S.) And maA yaSoriyka min~iY A^aYo EabodiY, occurring in a trad., means What cuts short (yaqoTaEu) thine asking of Me [O my servant]? (TA.) ― -b2- And i. q. dafaEahu [He repelled it]. (M, K.) One says, SaraY A@ll~`hu Eanohu $ar~ahu i. e. dafaEa [God repelled, or may God repel, from him his, or its, evil, or mischief]. (S.) ― -b3- And i. q. manaEahu [He prevented it, &c.]. (S, M, K.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says,
wawad~aEona mu$otaAqFA A^aSabona fuw^aAdahu
hawaAhun~a A_ino lamo yaSorihi A@ll~`hu qaAtiluho
[And they bade farewell to one affected with desire, whose heart they had smitten; the love of them, if God had not prevented it, had been his slayer]. (S. [But this verse may be well rendered as an ex. of SaraAhu in the sense next following, which is also a meaning of manaEahu: in the M, it is
cited as an ex. of SaraAhu in the sense of dafaEahu.]) ― -b4- Said of God, (M,) He protected, defended, guarded, or preserved, him: (M, K:) or (M) He saved him (M, K) from destruction, or perdition: (K:) or (M) He sufficed him: (M, K:) or He aided him. (TA.) ― -b5- SaraY bayonahumo, (K,) or SaraY maA bayonahumo, (S, M,) He decided [between them, or the case between them]; (S, K;) namely, persons who had applied to him as a judge: (S:) or he rectified, or adjusted, the case between them. (M.) ＝ -A4- SaraY also signifies EaTafa [He bent, or inclined]: (K, TA:) [app. intrans., or trans. by means of bi, for] a poet uses the phrase Sarayona biAlA^aEonaAqi [They bent, or inclined, with the necks]. (TA.) [But it is said in the TK that SaraAhu means EaTafahu He bent, or inclined, it.] Accord. to Ibn-Buzurj, Sarati Aln~aAqapu EunuqahaA means The she-camel raised her neck by reason of the heaviness of the burden. (TA.) ＝ -A5- Also He preceded, or went before; syn. taqad~ama. (IAar, K.) [Accord. to the TK, one says SaraY Alqawoma, meaning taqad~amahumo He preceded, or went before, the people, or party.] ― -b2- And [the contr., i. e.] He receded, or retreated; or became, or remained, or lagged, behind; syn. taA^ax~ara. (IAar, K.) [Accord. to the TK, one says SaraY Eanohumo, meaning He receded, or retreated, from them; &c.]. ― -b3- Also He, or it, was, or became, high; syn. EalaA. (IAar, K.) ― -b4- And the contr., i. e. He, or it, was, or became, low; syn. safula. (IAar, K.)

2 Sar~aYa
2: see 1, former half, in two places.

4 A^aSoraYa
4: see 1, former half, in two places. ― -b2- ASrY also signifies He sold a ewe or she-goat, (K, TA,) or a she-camel, (TA,) whose milk had been caused to collect in her udder in consequence of her not having been milked for some days; such as is termed muSar~aApN. (K, TA.)

8 AiSodaraAhu *
8. AiSodaraAhu i. q. AizodaraAhu [the d in each being substituted for t]: see the latter, in art. zrY.

SarFY *
SarFY, (S, M, Msb, K,) an inf. n. used as an epithet, (Msb,) and SirFY↓, (S, M, K,) [and Freytag adds SurFY↓, as from the K, in which I do not find it,] Water remaining, or stagnating, long, accord. to Fr; (S;) or that has remained, or stagnated, long: (Msb:) or water remaining long, (K,) or that has remained long, and become altered [for the worse], (S, M, Msb,) accord. to AA. (S.) And the first, (M, K,) an inf. n. used as an epithet, (TA,) Milk that has remained (M, K) long (K) so that its flavour has become altered [for the worse]; (M, K;) as also SarK↓, which is in like manner applied to water: (M:) or milk left [long] in the udder of the camel, not drawn, so that it becomes salt and windy: (IAar, TA:) or milk drawn in the night from a camel abounding therewith, having a bad and burning flavour. (Az, TA.) And, (M, K,) some say, (M,) [used as a subst.,] A portion remaining (M, K) of milk (M) in the udder, (Ham p. 661,) and of water. (TA.) And Tears (damoEN) that have become collected: and the sing. [or epithet applied to a single tear (damoEapN)] is SaraApN. (M.) And nuTofapN SaraApN [Sperma of a man] altered [for the worse]: and long retained by him in his back. (M. [This is also mentioned in the S, app. in the latter of these senses; the meaning being there only indicated by the context.]) ― -b2- For the fem., SaraApN, see also muSar~aApN.

SurFY *
SurFY: see SarFY, first sentence: ― -b2- and see also muSar~aApN.

SrFY *
SrFY: see SarFY, first sentence. ― -b2- In relation to a she-camel it is Her being pregnant twelve months, and bringing forth, and then yielding her biestings, or having her biestings milked: mentioned by Az. (TA. [But what is meant by this is, to me, doubtful; for sometimes an inf. n., and sometimes and epithet, and sometimes a subst., is expl. in this manner.])

SarKi *
SarKi [part. n. of SariYa]: see SarFY. ― -b2- Also A she-camel whose milk has collected in her udder. (Msb.) [See also muSar~aApN.]

SaroyapN *
SaroyapN Milk collected [in the udder]: a poet says,
wakul~u *iY SaroyapK laA bud~a maHoluwbu
[And whatever udder has milk must be milked]. (TA.)

SaroyaA='u *
SaroyaA='u: see muSar~aApN.

SaroyaAnu *
SaroyaAnu, applied to a man and to a beast, Whose maA=' [i. e. sperma] has collected in his back. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also The [bird called] yamaAmap [n. un. of yamaAmN, q. v.]: and the [bird called] samaAmap [n. un. of samaAmN, q. v.]. (TA.)

SaraA='N *
SaraA='N Colocynths (S, M, K, in the CK [erroneously] SirA'N [expressly said in the TA to be with fet-h and medd,]) when they become yellow; (S, M;) as also SaraAyaAtN: (so in one of my copies of the S [in which it is shown to be correct by an ex. in a verse of Suleyk there cited: in the M and TA SaraAyaA, which I think a mistranscription]: in the other of my copies of the S omitted:) one thereof is termed SaraAyapN↓. (S, M, K. *) [In the M and K, SaraA='N is termed pl. of SaraAyapN; but it is properly speaking a coll. gen. n., originally SaraAYN.] ― -b2- SaraAyapN↓ also signifies The water in which colocynths have been steeped. (M, K.)

SariY~N *
SariY~N One who acts with boldness towards the wife of his father: (K, TA:) such was Ibn-Mukbil. (TA.)

SaraAyapN *
SaraAyapN: see SaraA='N, in two places.

Sur~aY *
Sur~aY: see muSar~aApN, below.

SaArK *
SaArK [act. part. n. of SaraY: as such signifying] Guarding or preserving [&c.], or a guarder or preserver [&c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A sailor: (S, M, K:) because he guards, or preserves, the ship: (TA:) pl. Sur~aA='N (S, M, K) and (M, K) pl. pl. (M) SaraAriY~u and SaraAriy~uwna. (M, K. [But see SaraAriY~N in art. Sr.]) ― -b3- Also [said to signify] The transverse piece of wood in the middle of the ship: (M, K:) [but] IAth says that it is the daqal [i. e. mast] of the ship, which is set up in the middle thereof, and upon which is the $iraAE [or sail: it is now commonly called SaAriyapN↓ and saAriyapN: both of which are also sometimes applied to a column]: pl. SawaArK. (TA.)

SaAriyapN *
SaAriyapN A well (rakiy~apN) of which the water is old, altered for the worse, and overspread with [the green substance termed] EaromaD: (K, * TA:) mentioned by Az. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also SaArK, last sentence.

muSar~aApN *
muSar~aApN A ewe, or she-goat, whose milk has been caused to collect in her udder by her not having been milked for some days; (S, K;) as also Sur~aY↓, like rub~aY; (so in copies of the K; [but this, if correct, should be mentioned in art. Sr, in which the former is also mentioned; accord. to the TA, however, it seems to be SurFY↓, without teshdeed, for it is there said to be like rubY;]) both likewise applied to a she-camel, and to a cow; (TA;) and SaraApN↓ signifies the same, (K,) applied to a she-camel and to a ewe or she-goat; (TA;) and so, applied to a she-camel, SaroyaA='u↓, of which the pl. is SaraAyaA, (M, K,) an irreg. pl. (M.) [See also SarK.] ― -b2- Aboo-'Alee, in the Bári', makes it syn. with maSoruwrapN; and so says the Imám EshSháfi'ee; as though originally muSar~arapN: but Suh, in the R, disallows this. (TA.)

A^aSaATibu *
A^aSaATibu is the pl., and A^uSayoTibN is the dim., of A_iSoTabolN, q. v. (TA in art. ASTbl.)

A^uSoTub~apN *
A^uSoTub~apN [i. q. A^usoTub~apN, q. v.;] Tow; i. e. what falls from flax in the process of combing. (M, K.)

mSTb *
mSTb [app. a mistranscription for miSoTabapN↓ or maSoTabapN, like masoTabapN, q. v.,] A blacksmith's anvil: so in the T, on the authority of IAar. (TA.)

miSoTabapN *
miSoTabapN (so in copies of the K) [and maSoTabapN, like masoTabapN], or miSoTab~apN, (so accord. to the TA, with teshdeed to the b, [but the word is of frequent occurrence and commonly written without tesh-deed,]) A place where people assemble, (AHeyth, TA,) like a duk~aAn, [i. e. a kind of wide bench, of stone or brick &c., generally built against a wall,] for the purpose of sitting upon it: (AHeyth, K, TA:) Az heard an Arab of the desert, of the tribe of Fezárah, apply this word to a square, flat-topped pile of earth, raised for the purpose of passing the night upon it: (TA:) also, [sometimes, app. in late ages,] a hospice for strangers; or a place in which the poor and the beggars assemble: (MA, and Har p. 375:) not [originally, or properly,] an Arabic word: (Har ubi suprà:) [see more in art. sTb, for it is a dial. var. of masoTabapN,] of the dial. of Baghdád: (MA:) [the pl. is maSaATibu.] ― -b2- See also the next preceding paragraph.

1 SaEuba *
1. SaEuba, (S, A, MA, Msb, K,) aor.
SaEuba
, (A, K,) inf. n. SuEuwbapN; (S, MA, Msb, K;) and AstSEb↓;
(S, A, MA, Msb, K;) and ASEb↓, (IAar, K,) inf. n. A_iSoEaAbN; (IAar, TA;) It (a thing, Msb, or an affair, or event, S, MA, Msb, K) was, or became, SaEob, (S, A, &c.,) i. e. difficult, hard, hard to be done or accomplished, hard to be borne or endured, or distressing. (A, MA, K.) One says, Ealayohi AlA^amoru AstSEb↓, (S, MA, Msb,) like SaEuba, (S, Msb,) The affair, or event, was, or became, difficult, &c., to him. (MA.)

2 SE~bhu *
2. SE~bhu, (K,) inf. n. taSoEiybN; (TA;) [and] ASEbhu↓, (A,) inf. n. A_iSoEaAbN; (KL;) and tSE~bhu↓; (K;) He made, or rendered, it SaEob, (A, K,) i. e. difficult, hard, &c. (A, K, KL.)

4 ASEb *
4. ASEb: see 1. ― -b2- Said of a camel, He was, or became, SaEob [meaning refractory, or untractable]: (K, TA:) [and in like manner one says AstSEb↓: (see its contr. AstSHb:) and tSE~b↓, which is also said of a man:] and ASEb said of a camel, he was unridden, (A, TA,) and untouched by a rope. (A.) ― -b3- Also, said of a man, His camel was, or became, refractory, or untractable. (L, TA.) ＝ -A2- ASEbhu: see 2. ― -b2- Also He left him (i. e. a camel) unridden, (S, K, TA,) and untouched by a rope, so that he became refractory, or untractable. (S, K.) [See muSoEabN]. ― -b3- And He found it (i. e. an affair, or event, S, Msb, or a thing, K) to be SaEob [i. e. difficult, hard, &c.]; (S, Msb, K;) as also AstSEbhu↓: (Msb, K:) or both signify he saw it, or held it, to be so. (TA.) [See an ex. of the former in a verse cited voce rayovN.]

5 tSE~b *
5. tSE~b, intrans.: see 4. ＝ -A2- tSE~bhu: see 2.

10 AstSEb *
10. AstSEb, intrans.: see 1, in two places: ― -b2- and see also 4. ＝ -A2- AstSEbhu: see 4.

SaEobN *
SaEobN Difficult, hard, hard to be done or accomplished, hard to be borne or endured, or distressing; (A, MA, K;) contr. of saholN; (Mgh, TA;) as also SuEobuwbN↓: (T, O, K, TA:) pl. of the former SiEaAbN; (Msb;) and of ↓the latter, SaEaAbiybu. (T, TA.) One says A^amorN SaEobN A difficult, hard, or distressing, affair or event. (A.) And EaqabapN SaEobapN (thus in the A, but in the Msb and TA without any syll. signs,) [A mountainroad] difficult, hard, or distressing: (TA:) pl. EiqaAbN SiEaAbN (A, Msb *) and SaEobaAtN with sukoon [to the E because the word is an epithet; for if it were a subst., it would be SaEabaAtN]. (Msb.) [Or EuqobapN SaEobapN may perhaps be meant in the TA, i. e. A difficult, hard, or distressing, stage of a journey.] ― -b2- Also Refractory, untractable, incompliant, obstinate, or stubborn; (K, * TA;) contr. of *aluwlN; (S, A, TA;) applied to a camel, (S, A,) or to a beast; (TA;) [and to a man;] fem. SaEobapN, (S, TA,) which is applied to a woman: (S:) and the pl. of this is SiEaAbN, [as of the masc.,] (TA,) and SaEobaAtN, applied to women, with sukoon [to the E because the word is an epithet]. (S, TA.) rakiba Aln~aAsu AlS~aEobapa waAl*~aluwla, occurring in a trad. of I'Ab, [lit. The people rode the refractory and the tractable she-camel,] means (assumed tropical:) the people entered upon difficult and easy affairs; i. e. they cared not for things, nor were cautious respecting what they said and did. (L, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] AlS~aEobu The lion; (O, K;) because of his untractableness. (TA.)

SuEobuwbN *
SuEobuwbN: see the next preceding paragraph, first sentence, in two places.

SaAEibN *
SaAEibN Land containing stones such as fill the hand, and other stones, which is tilled, or cultivated. (K, TA.)

muSoEabN *
muSoEabN A stallion [of camels]: (S, K:) and a camel, (S, A,) or a stallion [of camels], (ISk, TA,) left unridden, and untouched by a rope, (ISk, S, A, TA,) so as to become refractory, or untractable: (S:) or an unbroken camel, upon whose back nothing is allowed to be put: (L, TA:) pl. maSaAEibu and maSaAEiybu. (ISk, TA.) ― -b2- It is also applied as an epithet to a man, (A, Msb, TA,) meaning masaw~adN [i. e. (assumed tropical:) Made a chief or lord &c.]: (TA:) pl. maSaAEibu. (A, Msb.) One says, fulaAnN muSoEabN mina AlmaSaAEibi (tropical:) [Such a man is one of those who have been made chiefs or lords &c.]; like as one says, qaromN mina Alquruwmi. (A.)

muSoEibN *
muSoEibN A man whose camel is refractory, or untractable: occurring in a trad. (L, TA.)

SaEotarN *
SaEotarN I. q. saEotarN [q. v.]: (K, and S and Msb in art. sEtr:) it grows in the country of the Arabs, and is of two kinds, suholiY~N [i. e. of the plain] and jabaliY~N [i. e. of the mountain]: (AHn, TA:) when strewn in a place, it drives away venomous or noxious reptiles and the like, (K,) such as serpents and scorpions. (TA.)

1 SaEida fiY Als~ul~ami *
1. SaEida fiY Als~ul~ami, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
SaEada
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. SuEuwdN (S, Msb, K) and SaEadN and SuEudN; (Ham p. 407;) and tSE~d↓, (A,) or AiS~aE~ada, (L,) inf. n. AiS~aE~udN; (K;) and tSAEd↓, (A,) or AiS~aAEada, (L,) inf. n. AiS~aAEudN; (K;) and ASTEd↓; (K;) He ascended, or went up, the ladder, or stair: (L, Msb, K:) and so the verb is used of ascending a thing similar to a ladder, or stair: but in a case of this kind one should not say ASEd. (L.) And SaEida Als~aToHa and A_ilaY Als~aToHi (A, Msb) He ascended, or ascended to, the flat house-top. (Msb.) And SaEida AlmakaAna, and fiY AlmakaAni, and ASEd↓, and SE~d↓, He ascended the place, or upon the place. (L.) And fiY SE~d↓ Aljabali, (S, A, Msb, K,) and EalaY Aljabali, inf. n. taSoEiydN; (S, K;) and SaEida fiyhi, a form rarely used, (Msb,) disallowed by AZ, (S, TA,) and said by him to have been unknown, (S,) or unheard, (K,) but he afterwards authorized it, and it is also authorized by IAar and ISk, (TA,) and SaEida Aljabala; (S in art. dxl; [for SaEida fiY Aljabali, see daxalotu Albayota;]) and fiyhi tSE~d↓, (MF, from a trad.,) and AiS~aE~ada fiyhi, (AZ,) inf. n. AiS~iE~aAdN; (TA; [app. a mistranscription for AiS~aE~udN; or AiS~aE~ada may be a mistranscription for AiS~aEada↓, a var. of AiSoTaEada, and its inf. n. is AiS~iEaAdN;]) He ascended the mountain. (Msb, K.) And fiY AlA^aroDi SE~d↓ He ascended the land. (AZ, TA.) One says, TaAla fiY AlA^aroDi taSowiybiY wataSoEiydiY↓ [Long have continued my descending, or going down, and my ascending, or going up, in the land]. (A. [There immediately following SaE~ada fiY Aljabali, expl. above: see also rakabN muSaE~idN.]) ＝ -A2- See also 4, last sentence.

2 SE~d *
2. SE~d, inf. n. taSoEiydN, as intrans.: see above, in four places. ― -b2- And see also 4, in four places. ＝ -A2- SE~dhu He made him, or caused him, to ascend, or mount; syn. Eal~aAhu; (K and TA in art. Elw;) and raq~aAhu; (TA in art. rqY;) [and so ASEdhu↓; and AstSEdhu↓; like as one says in the contr. sense naz~alahu and A^anozalahu and Aisotanozalahu.] You say, SE~dhu jabalFA and daAb~apN [He made him to ascend, or mount, a mountain and a beast]. (TA in art. Elw.) And fiY Aljabali yuSoEiduwnahaA↓ is said with reference to wild bulls or cows [as meaning They make them to ascend upon the mountain]. (S and TA in art. slE.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says also, SaE~ada fiY~a Aln~aZara waSaw~abahu, meaning (assumed tropical:) He looked at me from head to foot, contemplating me. (L, from a trad. [And a similar phrase occurs in Har p. 640.]) ― -b3- [SE~dhu, inf. n. taSoEiydN, (the latter as used in the K voce kaAfuwrN,) also signifies (assumed tropical:) He sublimated it: often occurring in medical books, and used in this sense in the present day.] ― -b4- And taSoEiydN signifies also The act of liquifying, melting, or dissolving. (K.) ＝ -A3- See also 4, last sentence.

4 ASEd fiY AlmakaAni *
4. ASEd fiY AlmakaAni: see 1. ― -b2- [Hence,] ASEd fiY AlA^aroDi He went through the land towards a land higher than the other [from which he came]: (A, TA:) taken from the saying of Lth, that ASEd, inf. n. A_iSoEaAdN, signifies He went towards a declivity, or a river, or a valley, higher than the other [from which he came]. (TA.) And ASEd fiY AlbilaAdi He went up, or upwards, through the countries, or lands. (AA, Msb.) And ASEd mino baladi ka*aA A_ilaY baladi ka*aA He journeyed [upwards] from such a region, or town, to such another region, or town; from one that was lower to one that was higher. (Msb.) [And hence,] ASEd, inf. n. A_iSoEaAdN, He journeyed, or went, towards Nejd, and El-Hijáz, and El-Yemen: [or towards a higher region:] and AinoHadara signifies “ he journeyed, or went, towards El-'Irák, and Syria, and 'Omán: ” (ISk, on the authority of 'Omárah:) or the former, he journeyed, or went, towards the Kibleh: and the latter, “ he journeyed, or went, towards El-'Irák: ” (Aboo- Sakhr, T:) or the former, he came to Mekkeh; (K;) but this is a defective explanation: (TA:) and muSoEadN, also, is used as an inf. n. of this verb; and munoHadarN, as an inf. n. of AnHdr: (T, TA:) or ASEd, inf. n. A_iSoEaAdN, he commenced a journey, or went forth; as from Mekkeh, and from ElKoofeh to Khurásán, and the like: (Fr:) or he
commenced a journey, or the like, in any direction: and AnHdr signifies “ he returned, from any town or country. ” (Ibn-'Arafeh.) And ASEd fiY AlA^aroDi, (Akh, S, K,) or fY AlbilaAdi, (Akh accord. to the T,) He went away, and journeyed, through the land, (Akh, S, K,) or through the countries, (Akh, T,) in any direction. (L.) And ASEdt Als~afiynapu, inf. n. A_iSoEaAdN; (L;) or SE~dt↓; (A;) The ship spread her sail, and was borne along by the wind, (A, L,) upwards [app. meaning up a river or the like]. (L.) ― -b3- ASEd fiY AlwaAdiY; (Akh, S, L, K;) and fiyhi SE~d↓, inf. n. taSoEiydN; (Akh, S, Msb, K;) and AiS~aE~ada↓, (Lth,) but this last is disapproved by Az; (TA;) He descended, or went down, into the valley, (Akh, S, L, Msb, K,) from the part whence the torrent comes; not going to the bottom of the valley: and in like manner, ASEd fiY AlA^aroDi He descended, or went down, into the land: (L:) and fiY Aljabali SE~d↓ He descended the mountain; as well as he ascended it. (IB, L.) Akh cites the following words of 'Abd-Allah Ibn-Hemmám Es-Saloolee,
TaworFA fiY AlbilaAdi waA^uforiEu A^uSaE~idu↓
(S, L,) as meaning I descending, or going down, at one time, through the countries, and [another time] ascending, or going up: this, says IB, is what induced Akh to explain SE~d as he has done; but it presents no proof, because A_iforaAEN has two contr. significations, that of A_iSoEaAdN and that of AinoHidaArN: and accord. to AZ, by A^uSaE~idu the poet means I ascending, or going up, to high places; and by A^uforiEu, the contrary. (L.) ― -b4- ASEd also signifies He advanced towards another. (L.) ― -b5- And He went far; syn. A^aboEada. (Ham p. 22.) ― -b6- And ASEd fiY AlEadowi He exerted himself vehemently in running. (L.) ＝ -A2- ASEd as trans.: see 2, in two places. ＝ -A3- ASEdt She (a camel) became such as is termed SaEuwd [q. v.]. (S, L, K.) ― -b2- And A^aSoEadotu Aln~aAqapa, (S, L, K,) and SaEadotuhaA↓, [probably imperfectly transcribed for SaE~adotuhaA↓,] (L,) I made the she-camel to be, or became, such as is termed SaEuwd. (IAar, S, L, K.)

5 tSE~d *
5. tSE~d, and its var. AiS~aE~ada: see 1, in two places: ― -b2- and see also 4. ― -b3- tSE~d Aln~afasu The breath passed forth with difficulty. (L.) ＝ -A2- tSE~dhu (S, A, K) and tSAEdhu↓ (A, K) It (a thing, S, K, or an affair, A) was, or became, difficult, or distressing, to him; it distressed, or afflicted, him: (A'Obeyd, S, A, K:) from SaEuwdN as signifying “ a mountain-road difficult of ascent: ” (A' Obeyd:) or from AlS~aEuwdN as the name of “ a certain mountain in Hell. ” (TA.)

6 tSAEd *
6. tSAEd, and its var. AiS~aAEada: see 1: ＝ -A2- and see also 5.

8 ASTEd *
8. ASTEd, and its var. AiS~aEada: see 1, in two places.

10 AstSEdhu *
10. AstSEdhu: see 2. ― -b2- AstSEd Albariyra He plucked or gathered, the fruit of the A^araAk to eat. (TA in art. br.)

SuEodN *
SuEodN: see SuEudN.

SaEadN *
SaEadN: see SaEuwdN, in two places. ― -b2- Ea*aAbN SaEadN A vehement, severe, rigorous, or grievous, punishment; (S, A, K;) i. e. *uw SaEadK: (TA:) or a distressing, or an afflicting, punishment, (Bd and Jel in lxxii. 17,) that shall overcome the sufferer thereof, the latter word being an inf. n. used as an epithet. (TA.)

SuEudN *
SuEudN an inf. n. of SaEida [q. v.]. (Ham p. 407.) [Hence,] *ahaba Als~ahomu SuEudFA [The arrow went upwards]. (A.) And h`*aA Aln~abaAtu yanomiY SuEudFA This plant increases in height. (S.) And tanaf~asa SuEudFA: see SuEadaA='u. And mino SuEodK↓ [used by poetic license for mn SuEudK], said of a thing falling, i. e. From above; from a higher place. (Ham p. 349.) ＝ -A2- Also a pl. of SaEuwdN: and of SaEiydN. (S, L, K.) ＝ -A3- SuEudN, thus, with two dammehs, is also the name of A certain tree from which pitch is melted forth. (L.)

SaEodapN *
SaEodapN A high, or an elevated, piece of land or ground; contr. of haboTapN. (Mgh in art. hbT.) And SaEodapu is said to be a proper name for The earth. (Ham p.22.) ― -b2- And A she-ass: (L, K:) or a long-backed she-ass: (L:) or long [in the back], applied to a she-ass as an epithet, and therefore the pl. is SaEodaAtN, with the E quiescent. (Ham p. 385.) And banaAtu SaEodapa Wild asses: (S, K:) said to be so called from SaEodapu meaning as expl. above; and if this be correct, it is like the appellation banaAtu Albar~i: (Ham p. 22:) or as being likened to the women [or rather woman (as will be shown in what follows)] termed SEdp; and in like manner, A^awolaAdu SaEodapa: (Har p. 471:) the rel. n. [applied to a single wild ass] is SaAEidiY~N↓, (S, L, K,) irregularly formed: thus in the saying of Aboo-Dhu-eyb,
faramaY faA^aloHaqa SaAEidiy~FA miToHarFA
biAlka$oHi faA@$otamalato Ealayohi AlA^aDoluEu
[And he shot, and made a far-flying arrow to reach a wild ass in the flank, and the ribs enclosed it]. (S, L.) ― -b3- And A spear, or spear-shaft; syn. qanaApN: (L:) a spear-shaft (qanaApN) straight by its growth, (S, L, K,) not requiring to be straightened: (S, L:) and a kind of A^al~ap [or broad-headed dart], which is smaller than a Harobap: (L:) or [simply] an A^al~ap: (K, TA:) [in the CK A`lap: and] in some copies of the K A^akamap, which is a mistranscription: (TA:) pl. SiEaAdN and SaEadaAtN; (L;) the latter with fet-h to the E because it is a subst. (Ham p. 385.) One says, taTaAEanuwA biAlS~iEaAdi i. e. [They thrust, or pierced, one another] with the spears. (A.) ― -b4- [Hence,] jaAriyapN SaEodapN (tropical:) A girl, or young woman, straight in figure, (A, L,) like a spear, or spear-shaft: (L:) pl. jawaArK SaEodaAtN, the latter word with the E quiescent, (A, L,) because it is an epithet. (L.)

SuEodapN *
SuEodapN: see SaEiydN, last sentence but one.

SaEodaA='u *
SaEodaA='u: see SaEuwdN, in two places.

SuEadaA='u *
SuEadaA='u A sigh, or sighing; a breathing with an expression of pain, grief, or sorrow: or with difficulty: (L:) a long breathing: (K:) or a prolonged breathing: (S:) or a loud breathing: (A:) accord. to some, a breathing emitted upwards. (L.) You say, tanaf~asa AlS~uEadaA='a, (L,) or tnf~s SuEadaA='a, (A,) and tnf~s SuEudFA↓, (L,) He sighed; uttered a sigh or sighing; or breathed with an expression of pain, grief, or sorrow: (L:) [or uttered a prolonged breathing:] or breathed loudly. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] fulaAnN yatobaEu SuEadaA='ahu, (A,) or yatatab~aEu SuEudaA='ahu, (L, [in which the noun is evidently mistranscribed,]) (tropical:) Such a one raises his head, and does not stoop it, by reason of pride: (A:) or does not raise his head nor stoop it. (L. [The former explanation seems to be the right.]) ― -b3- See also SaEuwdN, in four places.

SuEodudN *
SuEodudN: see the next paragraph.

SaEuwdN *
SaEuwdN An acclivity; contr. of habuwTN, (S, L, K,) or of HaduwrN; (Msb;) and SaEadN↓ is [syn. therewith, being] contr. of SababN: (L:) pl. SaEaAy^idu and SuEudN. (S, K.) An ascending road: of the fem. gender: pl. [of pauc.] A^aSoEidapN and [of mult.] SuEudN. (L.) A mountain-road difficult of ascent; (S, A, L, K;) as also SaEuwdaA='u↓, (L, K,) and SuEadaA='u↓: (L in art. kA^d:) a difficult place of ascent. (L in that art.) [Hence,] AlS~aEuwdu A certain mountain in Hell, (L, K, MF,) consisting of fire, which the unbeliever will ascend during a period of seventy years, after which he will fall down it, and thus he will do for ever: (MF:) it is of one live coal; the unbeliever will be compelled to ascend it, and will be beaten with maqaAmiE [pl. of miqomaEapN, q. v.]; and whenever he puts his leg upon it, it will dissolve as high as the lower part of his hip, and will then become replaced whole and sound. (L.) ― -b2- [Hence also,] (tropical:) Difficulty, grievousness, distress, affliction, or trouble; (A, L, Msb;) as also SaEadN↓ (L) and SaEodaA='u↓, (K,) or SuEadaA='u↓, (L,) and SuEodudN↓. (K.) You say, A^arohaqotuhu SaEuwdFA (tropical:) I made him, or constrained him, to do a difficult, grievous, distressing, afflicting, or troublesome, thing: (A:) or I imposed upon him such a punishment. (L.) And lils~iyaAdapi SaEodaA='u↓ [or SuEadaA='u↓? (see above)] (tropical:) There is a difficult, or distressing, ascent to lordship, or mastery. (A.) And A^akamapN *aAtu SuEadaA='a↓ (assumed tropical:) A hill difficult to ascend. (L.) ― -b3- Also A she-camel that brings forth a young one imperfectly formed, (As, S, K,) after six or seven months, (As,) and is made to take an affection to the young one of the preceding year, (As, S,) or and takes an affection to the young one of the preceding year: (K:) or a she-camel whose young one dies, and which returns to her former young one, and yields it milk: when she does this, her milk is the sweeter: (Lth:) or a she-camel that brings forth her young one after its hair has grown, and then takes an affection to her former young one, or to the young one of another: pl. SaEaAy^idu and SuEudN; but this latter pl. is disapproved by Sb. (L.)

SaEiydN *
SaEiydN High, or elevated, land or ground: or high, or elevated, land or ground, above such as is low, or depressed: or even land or ground:
(L:) or even land or ground, without any trees: (Lth, L:) or a [desert such as is termed] SaHoraA=': (A:) or the surface of the earth; (Th, Zj, S, A, Msb, K;) whether it be dust or earth, or otherwise: Zj says, I know not any difference of opinion among the lexicologists on this point: (Msb:) [such is said to be its meaning in the Kur iv. 46 and v. 9; and therefore in performing the act termed Alt~ayam~am,] a man should strike his hands upon the surface of the earth, and not care whether there be in chat place dust or not: (Zj:) [hence] one says, TaAra Siytuka fiY Alqariybi waAlbaEiydi wabalaga munotahaY AlS~aEiydi [Thy fame has flown through the near and the distant regions, and reached the extremity of the surface of the earth]: (A:) or SaEiydN signifies the earth, or ground, itself; (IAar, A, L;) as in the saying Ealayoka biAlS~aEiydi, meaning Sit thou upon the earth, or ground: (A:) or good earth or land: or earth, or land, not mixed with sand nor with salt soil: (L:) or dust, or earth, (Fr, S, L, Msb, K,) such as is pure, upon the surface of the ground or that has come forth from within it; thus accord. to Az in the Kur iv. 46 and v. 9, in the opinion of most of the learned: (Msb:) or only earth containing dust; not applied to a coarse, nor to a fine, baToHaA='; nor to a coarse kaviyb; although it be mixed with dust: (Esh-Sháfi'ee, L:) pl. SuEudN and SuEudaAtN, (S, L, K,) the latter a pl. pl. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- And A wide, or an ample, place. (L.) ― -b3- And A road, (L, Msb, K,) whether wide or narrow: (L:) pls. as above (L, Msb) and SuEodaAnN. (L.) It is said in a trad., A_iy~aAkumo waAlquEuwda biAlS~uEudaAti A_il~aAmano A^ad~aY Haq~ahaA, i. e. Beware ye of sitting in, or by, the roads, save he who performs the duty relating thereto: [respecting which duty see TariyqN:] SuEudaAt is here the pl. of SuEudN, which is pl. of SaEiydN: or, as some say, it is pl. of SuEodapN↓, which signifies A court, or an open space, before the door of a house, and the place through which men pass in front of it. (L.) ― -b4- Also A grave. (AA, Mtr, L, K.)

A_in~ahaA lafiY SaEiydapi baAzilayohaA *
A_in~ahaA lafiY SaEiydapi baAzilayohaA (tropical:) Verily she (a camel) is near to cutting her two teeth called the baAzilaAni. (L, TA.)

SaEuwdaA='u *
SaEuwdaA='u: see SaEuwdN.

SuEaAdiy~apN *
SuEaAdiy~apN, applied to a she-camel, Tall, or long; syn. TawiylapN. (K.)

SaE~aAdN EalaY AljibaAli *
SaE~aAdN EalaY AljibaAli One who climbs the mountains much or often. (TA in art. rqY.)

SaAEidN *
SaAEidN [Ascending, &c.]. ― -b2- [Hence,] EunuqN SaAEidN (tropical:) A tall neck. (A, L.) ― -b3- And $arafN SaAEidN (tropical:) [High nobility]. (A.) ― -b4- [Hence also,] one says, balaga ka*aA faSaAEidFA (tropical:) It reached such an amount and upwards: (K, TA:) and A^axa*otuhu bidirohamK faSaAEidFA (tropical:) I got it for a dirhem and upwards; an elliptical phrase, for A^axa*otuhu bidirohamK fazaAda Alv~amanu SaAEidFA I got it for a dirhem and the price increased upwards, or *ahaba SaAEidFA went upwards: you may not say waSaAEidFA, because you do not mean to tell that the dirhem with something more made the price, as when you say bidirohamK waziyaAdapK; but you mention the lowest price that you offered, and mean that you then offered more and more. (Sb, L.) And qaraA^a faAtiHapa AlkitaAbi faSaAEidFA (assumed tropical:) He read the opening chapter of the Book [i. e. of the Kur-án] and more is a phrase of the same kind. (L.)

SaAEidiY~N *
SaAEidiY~N rel. n. of SaEodapu, q. v.

maSoEadN *
maSoEadN [A place of ascent: pl. maSaAEidu]. One says rutobapN baEiydapu AlmaSoEadi and AlmaSaAEidi (tropical:) [meaning A station, or post of honour, to which the ascent and ascents (lit. the place and places of ascent) is, and are, distant]. (A.)

muSaE~adN *
muSaE~adN A high mountain. (L.) And rakabN muSaE~adN, or muSaE~idN↓, A high, or prominent, pubes. (L.) ＝ -A2- Also Beverage, or wine, (K,) and vinegar, (TA,) prepared with pains by means of fire, or well boiled, (Euwlija biAln~aAri, K, TA,) until it becomes altered in flavour and colour. (TA.)

muSaE~idN *
muSaE~idN: see the next preceding paragraph.

miSoEaAdN *
miSoEaAdN The [rope called] HaAbuwl, [made in the form of a hoop,] by means of which a man ascends palm-trees. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- [And A scaling-ladder. ― -b3- And, accord. to Freytag, A chain with which the feet of captives are shackled, to prevent their taking wide steps: ― -b4- and A chain upon the feet of women, serving as an ornament: in relation to which he refers to Schröder de vestitu mulierum Hebr. p. 123.]

1 SaEira *
1. SaEira, aor.
SaEara
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. SaEarN; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) and tSE~r↓; (A, K;) He had a wryness, or distortion, in the cheek, (S,) or in the face, (A, K,) or in either side [thereof], (K,) or in the neck, (Lth, A, Mgh, Msb,) by reason of pride, (A,) with a turning of the face on one side: (Lth, Mgh, Msb:) [see also 5:] or he (a camel) had a disorder by reason of which he twisted his neck, (K,) and distorted it. (TA.) You say, fiY Eunuqihi waxad~ihi SaEarN In his neck, and in his cheek, is a wryness, or distortion, arising from pride. (A.) And laA^uqiyman~a SaEaraka [I will assuredly straighten thy wryness, or distortion, of the neck, or cheek]. (A.) And A^aSaAba AlbaEiyra SaEarN A disease which made him to twist his neck befell the camel. (Mgh, TA.) ― -b2- [See also SaEarN below.] ＝ -A2- Also SaEira, (TK,) inf. n. SaEarN, (K, TK,) He (a man, TK) ate SaEaAriyr [pl. of SuEoruwrN, q. v.], (K, * TK,) i. e., gum. (TA.)

2 SE~rhu *
2. SE~rhu He caused him to have a wryness, or distortion, in the neck, and a turning of the face on one side, by something smiting or befalling him. (Msb.) ― -b2- SE~r xad~ahu, (inf. n. taSoEiyrN, K,) and SAErhu↓, (S, A, Msb, K,) and ASErhu↓, (K,) He turned away his cheek (S, A, Msb) from the people, (Msb,) by reason of pride (S, A, Msb) and dislike; (S, Msb;) he turned away his cheek from looking towards the people, by reason of contempt arising from pride. (K.) It is said in the Kur [xxxi. 17], walaA tuSaE~iro xad~aka liln~aAsi, (Mgh, TA,) and accord. to one reading, laA tuSaAEiro↓, (TA,) meaning, And turn thou not away from people through pride. (Fr, Aboo-Is-hák, Mgh.) [See also 5.]

3 SaAoEara
3: and 4: see 2; the former in two places.

5 tSE~r *
5. tSE~r and tSAEr↓ He distorted his cheek by reason of pride. (Sgh, TA.) See also 1.

6 taSaAoEara
6: see what next precedes.

9 ASEr~t AlA_ibilu *
9. ASEr~t AlA_ibilu The camels went a vehement pace: or became dispersed. (TA.)

R. Q. 1 SaEorarahu *
R. Q. 1. SaEorarahu, (S, K,) inf. n. SaEorarapN, (TA,) He made it round: (S, K:) he rolled it. (TA.) [See muSaEorarN.]

R. Q. 2 taSaEorara *
R. Q. 2. taSaEorara It became round: (S, K:) it rolled. (TA.)

R. Q. 3 AiSoEanorara *
R. Q. 3. AiSoEanorara, and AiSoEar~ara, (K,) in which latter the n is incorporated into the r, (TA,) He (being beaten or struck) writhed, (TA,) and turned round by reason of pain, in his place, and became contracted. (K, TA.)

SaEarN *
SaEarN inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. ― -b2- The saying fiY AlS~aEari Ald~iyapu is expl. as meaning In [the case of] the distorting of the face [the whole bloodwit shall be exacted: as though the verb of which SaEarN is the inf. n. were trans.; but this is obviously a loose rendering]. (Mgh.) ― -b3- SaEarN also signifies Pride: (Mgh:) or the being proud. (TA.) ― -b4- And Smallness of the head: (K:) or the being small, said of a man's head: (K, * TA:) one says, SaEira raA^osuhu, inf. n. SaEarN, meaning his head was small. (TK.)

SuEoruwrN *
SuEoruwrN (S, K, & c.) and SuEur~urN↓ (Sgh, K) Long, slender, twisted gum: (K:) or a piece of gum having a long and twisted form: (AZ, S:) and [gum of the kind called] lavFY that has become concrete: (K:) or this is the signification of SaEaAriyru, (S, K,) which is the pl. [of SErwr], (TA,) accord. to AA: (S:) or the pl. signifies concrete gum resembling fingers: and SErwr is said to signify a piece of gum: accord. to Aboo-Nasr, it is like a read-pen, and twisting like a horn: and AHn says that SuEoruwrapN, with p, signifies a small round piece of gum: (TA:) and the fruit, (K,) or any fruit, (TA,) of a tree that is like (that of, TA) the A^abohal, and like pepper, and what resembles this, of such as are hard: (K, TA:) or such they term SaEaAriyru: (TA:) or gum in general: pl. SaEaAriyru. (K.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) or SuEoruwrN [only], (TA,) (assumed tropical:) A certain substance, yellow, [in the CK ASgr is put for ASfr,] thick, tough with [somewhat of] softness and moisture, that comes forth from the teat: (K:) so called by way of comparison: (TA:) or what is first milked, of biestings: (K:) or milk that is gummy (muSomigN), in biestings, before it becomes clear. (TA.) ― -b3- SuEoruwrapN The little ball which is rolled along by the [kind of beetle called] juEal. (K, TA.) ― -b4- SaEaAriyru (assumed tropical:) Long fingers. (TA.)

SuEur~urN *
SuEur~urN: see the next preceding paragraph.

SaE~aArN *
SaE~aArN Proud, or haughty: because he declines with his cheek, and turns away his face from people: occurring in a trad.: or the word as there used is Saq~aArN, or Daf~aAzN, accord. to different relaters. (TA.)

SayoEariY~N *
SayoEariY~N applied to a camel's hump, Great, or large, (K, TA,) and round. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And A^aHomaru SayoEariY~N Intensely red. (K.)

SayoEariy~apN *
SayoEariy~apN Obliquity in going or march or course: (S, K:) from SaEarN [inf. n. of SaEira]. (S.) ＝ -A2- Also A mark made with a hot iron upon the neck of a camel: (S:) or of a she-camel (K) only: (TA:) a mark of the people of El-Yemen, only made upon she-camels: (Tedhkireh of Aboo-'Alee:) not upon a camel whether male or female, (K,) as it is said to be by A'Obeyd [and J]. (TA.) J was led into error by a verse of El-Museiyab (K) Ibn 'Alas; wherein he uses the phrase binaAjK Ealayohi AlS~ayoEariy~apu [With a swift he-camel marked with the SyEry~p]; (TA;) on hearing which, Tarafeh (K) Ibn-El-'Abd (TA) said, qadi A@sotanowaqa Aljamalu [The male camel has assumed the characteristic of the female camel]. (K, TA.) El-Bedr El-Karáfee urges that the term baEiyr, used by J, includes the female; and that the masc. epithet [naAjK] is used [by the poet] because the male is the more honourable, being more hardy, and stronger than the female: but this demands consideration. (TA.)

A^aSoEaru *
A^aSoEaru Having a wryness, or distortion, in the cheek, (S,) or in the face, (A, K,) or in either side [thereof], (K,) or in the neck, (A, Msb,) by reason of pride, (A,) with a turning of the face on one side: (Msb:) or a camel having a disorder by reason of which he twists his neck, (K,) and distorts it: (TA:) sometimes the being so is natural (S, A, Msb, K) in a man (S, Msb) and in an ostrich; (S, A, Mgh;) and sometimes it is accidental: (Msb:) pl. SuEorN. (TA.) ― -b2- It occurs in a trad. as signifying Such as withdraws himself [from others, through pride]; syn. *aAhibN binafosihi: (S, TA: [thought by Ibr D to be a mistake for zaAhK binafosihi: but this seems to me improbable:]) or such as turns away his face, by reason of pride: (IAth:) and in another trad. as signifying such as turns away from the truth, and is faulty. (TA.)

muSoEar~N *
muSoEar~N, (S,) in the K muSoEarN, said to be like mukoramN, but the former is the right, as is shown by the ex. below, (TA,) applied to a night-journey to water, Hard, or severe. (S, K.) A poet says,
waqado qarabona qarabFA muSoEar~aA
[And they had performed a hard night-journey to water]. (S, TA.)

muSaEorarN *
muSaEorarN [Made round: and simply, round]. A rájiz says,
suwdN kaHab~i Alfulofuli AlmuSaEorari
[Black, like the round grains of pepper]. (S.)

1 SaEaTahu *
1. SaEaTahu, aor.
SaEaTa
and
SaEuTa
, (K,) inf. n. SaEoTN and SuEuwTN, (TA,) a dial. var. of saEaTahu; and so is ASEThu↓ of AsEThu. (K, * TA.) See art. sET.

4 A^aSoEaTa
4: see what here precedes.

SaEuwTN *
SaEuwTN i. q. saEuwTN, q. v. (Lh, K.)

1 SaEaqatohumu Als~amaA='u *
1. SaEaqatohumu Als~amaA='u, (S, O, K,) aor.
SaEaqa
, (K,) inf. n. SaAEiqapN, (O, K,) The sky smote them with what is termed SaAEiqap [i. e. a thunderbolt]. (S, O, K.) [And SaqaEatohum signifies the same.] ― -b2- SaEiqa is quasi-pass. of the verb in the phrase above; (Z, TA in art. srf;) signifying He was smitten by a SaAEiqap; (TA in art. SqE;) as also SaqiEa; (K and TA in that art.;) and so SuEiqa and SuqiEa. (O in that art.) ― -b3- And SaEiqa, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
SaEaqa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. SaEaqN, (Msb,) or SaEoqapN, (S, O,) or both, and SaEoqN, (K,) and taSoEaAqN, (S, O, K,) He (a man, S, O) swooned, or became insensible, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) and lost his reason, (TA,) in consequence of a sound that he heard, (Msb, TA,) such as the vehement sound of the fall of a wall or the like or of a part of a mountain; (TA;) as also SuEiqa. (Msb, TA. *) ― -b4- And SaEiqa, aor.
SaEaqa
, inf. n. SaEoqN and taSoEaAqN, He (a man) died. (TA.) faSaEiqa mano fiY Als~am`waAti wamano fiY AlA^aroDi, in the Kur [xxxix. 68], means And those in the heavens and those upon the earth shall die: (S, TA:) or shall fall down dead, or in a swoon: (Bd:) or shall lose their reason. (TA.) ― -b5- And SaEiqati Alr~akiy~apu, inf. n. SaEaqN, The well fell in ruins, or to pieces; or collapsed. (TA.) ― -b6- SuEaAqN [as an inf. n.] signifies The sounding of thunder: and SaEiqa, aor.
SaEaqa
, inf. n. SuEaAqN, is said of a bull, meaning He bellowed, or lowed: (TA:) and likewise of a man [app. as meaning he bel-lowed, or roared]. (ISk, TA in art. Am.)

4 A^aSoEaqatohu AlS~aAEiqapu *
4. A^aSoEaqatohu AlS~aAEiqapu The SAEqp [or thunderbolt] smote him. (TA.) ― -b2- And ASEqhu He, or it, caused him to swoon, or become insensible. (S.) ― -b3- And He, or it, killed, or slew, him. (TA.)

SaEoqN *
SaEoqN: see the next paragraph.

SaEaqN *
SaEaqN is an inf. n. of SaEiqa [q. v.]: (Msb, K:) and primarily signifies A swooning, or becoming insensible, in consequence of a vehement sound that one hears; and sometimes, such that one dies in consequence thereof: ― -b2- afterwards often used as meaning Death. (TA.) ― -b3- [Also] Vehemence of sound or voice: (O, K:) and vehemence of braying of an ass; used in this sense by Rubeh; (O, * TA;) and said by Az to be originally SaEoqN↓. (TA.)

SaEiqN *
SaEiqN Expecting, or looking for, a SaAEiqap [or thunderbolt]. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) ― -b2- Also Swooning, or becoming insensible; (K, TA;) and so maSoEuwqN↓; or the latter signifies dying suddenly: and the former, swooning, or becoming insensible, and losing his reason, in consequence of a sound that he has heard, such as the vehement sound of the fall of a wall or the like or of a part of a mountain. (TA.) ― -b3- And Dying, or dead. (TA.) ― -b4- Also, (K, TA,) or SaEiqu AlS~awoti, (S, O,) Vehement in voice, (S, O, K, TA,) and in braying; (TA;) applied to an ass. (S, O, TA.)

SaEoqapN *
SaEoqapN: see SaAEiqapN. ― -b2- Also The sound proceeding from a SaAEiqap [or thunderbolt]. (TA.) ― -b3- AlS~aEoqapu AlA^uwlaY means The first blast [of the horn on the day of resurrection]. (Msb.) ― -b4- And SaEoqapN also signifies A death. (TA.)

SaAEiqN *
SaAEiqN A camel meagre in his marrow. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O.)

SaAEiqapN *
SaAEiqapN [A thunderbolt; i. e.] a thing descending from the thunder, that smites not anything but it alters it and burns it: (Msb:) or fire that falls from the sky, (AZ, S, O, K,) in vehement thunder: (AZ, S, O:) or fire that God sends with vehement thunder: (TA:) or the scourge (mixoraAq) that is in the hand of [the angel who is] the driver of the clouds, and that comes not upon anything but it burns it: (O, K:) or a vehement sound from a thundering with which falls a piece of fire: or the sound of thunder: (TA:) Wahb Ibn-Munebbih, being asked respecting it, whether it were a tangible thing or fire or what else, answered that he thought no one knew it except God: (O, TA:) accord. to some, (TA,) it signifies also the cry, or vehement cry, or shout, [that is an efficient] of punishment: (S, O, K:) and death; (O, K;) so accord. to Katádeh (O, TA) and Mukátil: (TA:) or a cause of death: (Zj, TA:) and any destructive punishment: (O, K:) and SaEoqapN↓ and SaAqiEapN are dial. vars. thereof: (TA:) the pl. is SawaAEiqu. (O, Msb, TA.)

maSoEuwqN *
maSoEuwqN: see SaEiqN.

1 SaEila *
1. SaEila, aor.
SaEala
, (K,) inf. n. SaEalN, (TA,) He, or it, was, or became, such as is termed SaEolN and A^aSoEalu meaning as expl. below; as also ASEAl~↓. (K, TA.) One says, Aln~axolapu ASEAl~t↓ meaning The palm-tree was, or became, slender in the head. (IDrd, O, TA.)

11 A_iSoEaAol~a
11: see the preceding paragraph, in two places.

SaEolN *
SaEolN Small in the head; applied to a man, (As, S, O,) and to an ostrich; (S, O;) as also A^aSoEalu↓; (O;) and SaEolaA='u↓ applied to a woman: (S:) or small in the head and long and slender in the neck; applied to a man: (Sh, TA:) or SaEolN and its fem. SaEolapN, and A^aSoEalu↓ and its fem. SaEolaA='u↓, such as is slender in the head and neck, of mankind, and of ostriches, and [in like manner] of palm-trees: (K, * TA:) or, accord. to As, only the first is applied to a man, and its fem. (with p) to a woman: but IB says that others mention SaEolaA='u↓ as applied to a woman; and accord. to this, one applies A^aSoEalu↓ to a man. (TA.) And naxolapN SaEolapN A palm-tree that is crooked, and bare in the lower parts of its branches: (S, O,
K:) or a tall palm-tree; which is disapproved, because often when it is tall it becomes crooked. (IB, TA.) And HimaArN SaEolN An ass that has lost his soft hair, (S, K,) or his abundant and long hair, (O,) or both. (TA.) And SaEolN signifies also Tall, or long: (K:) applied by El-'Ajjáj to a mast of a ship as meaning tall, and having its upper part even, or uniform, with its middle; not as meaning slender in the head. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, [used as a subst.,] A male ostrich; because small in the head: and with p, a female ostrich. (TA.)

SaEalN *
SaEalN Slenderness. (S, O.)

SaEolapN *
SaEolapN, (O, TA,) or SaEalapN↓, which is preferred by Sh, (O,) Smallness of the head: (O, TA:) or slenderness, and lightness of the body. (TA.)

SaEalapN *
SaEalapN: see what next precedes.

A^aSoEalu *
A^aSoEalu, and its fem. SaEolaA='u: see SaEolN, in six places.

Q. 1 SaEolakahu *
Q. 1. SaEolakahu, (O, K,) inf. n. SaEolakapN, (TA,) He rendered him poor, or needy. (O, K.) ＝ -A2- SElk Alv~ariydapa He made the vrydp [or mess of crumbled bread moistened with broth] to hare a head: or he raised its head. (K.) And SElk A^asofala Als~anaAmi He stretched up the lower part of the camel's hump so as to make its upper part of a rounded form. (Sh, O.) ― -b2- And SElk Albaqolu AlA_ibila The herbs, or leguminous plants, fattened the camels. (Sh, O, K.)

Q. 2 taSaEolaka *
Q. 2. taSaEolaka He was, or became, poor, or needy. (S, * O, * K.) And He made a show of poverty. (KL.) [He affected to be such as is termed SuEoluwk.] ― -b2- tSElkt AlA_ibilu The camels cast, or shed, their fur, (S, K, TA,) and, some add, became bare. (TA.) Accord. to Sh, The camels became slender in their legs in consequence of fatness [of the body; app. meaning that their legs became slender in comparison with their bodies]. (TA.) And accord. to As, tSElk said of a horse, He became slender, and shed his abundant and long hair. (TA.)

SuEoluwkN *
SuEoluwkN Poor, or needy; (S, O, K, TA;) [a poor man;] and ISd adds, having no property; and Az adds, and having no reliance [upon any person or thing]: (TA:) and a thief, or robber: (KL:) pl. SaEaAliyku. (S, O.) SaEaAliyku AlEarabi means *uw^obaAnuhaA [i. e., as expl. voce *iy^obN, The thieves, or sharpers, and paupers, of the Arabs; or the paupers of the Arabs who practise thieving: because they act like wolves]. (S, O.) 'Orweh Ibn-El-Ward was called Eurowapu AlS~aEaAliyki because he used to collect the poor in a HaZiyrap [i. e. an enclosure for cattle] and sustain them by means of the plunder that he took. (S, O, K.)

muSaEolaku Alr~aA^osi *
muSaEolaku Alr~aA^osi A man round in the head: (O, K, TA:) or, as some say, small in the head. (TA.) And maSaEolakN applied to a camel's hump, Such as is as though one rounded its upper part, and stretched up its lower part with the hand so as to make it assume that rounded form. (Sh, O.)

1 SaEaA *
1. SaEaA, aor.
SaEawa
, He, or it, was slender; and was small: (IAar, K:) from SaEowN, here following. (TA.)

SaEowN *
SaEowN A small EuSofuwr [or bird of the sparrowkind], (K, TA,) red in the head; (TA;) fem. with p: (K:) or small EaSaAfiyr [or birds of the sparrow-kind], the heads of which are red; n. un. with p: (Msb:) or SaEowapN signifies a certain bird; and its pl. is SaEowN and SiEaA='N: (S:) or the pl. (of SaEowapN, Msb) is SiEaA='N (Msb, K) and SaEawaAtN, (K, in the CK SEowAtN,) and the pl. of SaEowN is A^aSoEaA='N: some say that SaEowN is originally waSoEN. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) naAqapN SaEowapN A she-camel small in the head. (K.) ＝ -A2- And the pl. A^aSoEaA='N signifies A^uSuwlN [pl. of A^aSolN, q. v.]. (TA.)

1 Sagura *
1. Sagura, aor.
Sagura
; (S, Msb, K;) and Sagira, aor.
Sagara
; (K;) inf. n.
