SufaAriy~apN *
SufaAriy~apN A certain bird; (IAar, S;) as also SufaAriyapN, without teshdeed; (S;) the bird called tuba$~irN, (S in art. b$r,) or tubu$~irN: (K in that art.:) [Golius (who writes the word SafaAriy~apN) adds, “ ut puto, quæ in Syria SufayorA dicitur, flava, duplo major passere, nam et passer luteus, ut reddit Meid. ”:] i. q. SaEowapN. (IAar.) [See also AlA^aSoqaEu.]

Sufuwriy~apN *
Sufuwriy~apN, accord. to the K, A kind of nabaAt [i. e. plant]: but in the Tekmileh, a kind of viyaAb [i. e. garments, or cloths]; pl. of vawob; and it bears the mark of correctness. (TA.)

Saf~aArN *
Saf~aArN: see SaAfirN ＝ -A2- Also A fabricator of Sufor [or brass]. (M, K.)

Suf~aArN *
Suf~aArN, with damm, The entire quill of a feather. (AA, O.)

Saf~aArapN *
Saf~aArapN [A whistle: so in the present day: and also a fife:] a hollow thing (M, K) of copper, (K,) in which a boy whistles (M, K) to pigeons, (K,) or to an ass, that he may drink. (TS, L, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlS~af~aArapu The anus; syn. AlAisotu; (M, K;) in the dial. of the Sawád. (TA.)

SaAfirN *
SaAfirN Whistling; or a whistler. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (TA,) A thief; (K;) as also Saf~aArN↓: [or this signifies a frequent, or habitual, whistler:] the thief being so called because he whistles in fear of his being suspected: whence, as some explain it, the saying A^ajobanu mino SaAfirK [More cowardly than a thief]: (TA:) a prov.: accord. to AO, it means in this instance one who whistles to a woman for the purpose of fornication or adultery; because he fears lest he should be seen: or ― -b3- accord. to A'Obeyd, Any bird that whistles; for birds of prey do not whistle, but only ignoble birds, that are preyed upon: (Meyd:) [or] any bird that does not prey: (M, K:) and any bird having a cry: and a certain cowardly bird: (K:) [accord. to Dmr, as stated by Freytag, it is a bird of the passerine kind; also called SaAfiriy~apN↓:] accord. to Mohammad Ibn- Habeeb, (Meyd,) a certain bird that suspends itself from trees, hanging down its head, whistling all the night in fear lest it should sleep and be taken; and so in the prov. above mentioned: (Meyd, A: *) or, accord. to IAar, it means bihi maSofuwrN↓ [whistled to]: i. e., when he is whistled to, he flees: and by bihi AlmaSofuwru↓ is meant the bird called Altnw~T [i. e. Alt~anaw~uTu or Alt~unaw~iTu &c.], the cowardice of which induces it to weave for itself a nest like a purse, suspended from a tree, narrow in the mouth and wide in the lower part, in which it protects itself, fearing lest a bird of prey should light upon it: (Meyd: [see also art. nwT:]) or any coward. (TA.) ― -b4- maA bihaA SaAfirN There is not in it (i. e. the house, Ald~aAr, TA) any one: (S, K:) [lit.] any one who whistles: (M:) or any one to be called by whistling; SaAfirN being here an instance of the measure faAEilN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN followed by bihi. (T, TA.)

SaAfiriy~apN *
SaAfiriy~apN: see the next preceding paragraph.

A^aSofaru *
A^aSofaru [a comparative and superlative epithet form Safara]. One says A^aSofaru mino bulobulK [A greater whistler, or warbler, than the blbl]. (S.) ＝ -A2- See also SiforN. ― -b2- [Also More, and most, empty, void, or vacant.] It is said in a trad., A^aSofaru Albuyuwti mina Alxayori Albayotu AlS~iforu mino kitaAbi A@ll~`hi [That one of houses which is the most void of good is the house that is destitute of the Book of God]. (S.) ＝ -A3- Also [Yellow;] of the colour termed SuforapN: (S, M, K:) fem. SaforaA='u: (Msb, &c.:) pl. SuforN. (TA.) And Black (A'Obeyd, S, K) is sometimes thus termed: (S:) applied to a camel, as in the Kur lxxvii. 33, because a black camel always has an intermixture of yellow: (TA:) or, applied to a camel, of a colour whereof the ground is black, with some yellow hairs coming through. (M.) Applied to a horse, Of the colour termed in Pers. zarodaho [a kind of sorrel], (S,) but not unless having a yellow [or sorrel] tail and mane. (As, S.) ― -b2- banuw AlA^aSofari The Greeks (Alr~uwmu): (S, A:) or their kings: because the sons of El-Asfar the son of Room the son of 'Eesoo (or 'Eysoon, TA, [i. e. Esau,]) the son of Is-hák [or Isaac] (K) the son of Ibráheem [or Abraham]: (TA:) or El-Asfar was a surname of Room: (TA:) or they were so called because their first ancestor, (A, IAth,) Room the son of 'Eysoon, (IAth,) was of a yellow complexion: (A, IAth:) or because they were conquered by an army of Abyssinians by whom their women had yellow children: (K:) [or] they are the modern Muscovites. (TA.) ― -b3- AlA^aSofaraAni Gold and saffron; (S, M, K;) which are said to destroy women: (TA:) or the plant called waros and saffron: (S, K:) or the plant called waros and gold: (M:) or saffron and raisins. (ISk, Sgh, K.) ― -b4- And AlS~aforaA='u Gold. (M, K. [See also SuforN.]) Hence the saying of 'Alee, yaA SaforaA='u A@Sofar~iY wayaA bayoDaA='u A@boyaD~iY wagur~iY gayoriY O gold, [be yellow,] and O silver, [be white, and beguile other than me:] and one says also, maA lifulaAnK SaforaA='u walaA bayoDaA='u [There is not belonging to such a one gold nor silver]. (TA.) ― -b5- Also A kind of bile, (M, K,) well-known; (K;) [the yellow bile; one of the four humours of the body; of which the others are the black bile (Als~awodaA='u), the blood (Ald~amu), and the phlegm (Albalogamu):] so called because of its colour. (M.) ― -b6- And The bow that is made of [the tree called] naboE. (S, * K, * TA.) ― -b7- And The female locust that is devoid of eggs. (M, K.) ― -b8- And A certain plant, (S, M, K,) of the plain or soft tracts, and of the sands, (M, K,) and sometimes growing in hard level ground: (M:) or a certain herb, that spreads upon the ground, (AHn, M,) the leaves of which are like those of the xas~ [or lettuce], (AHn, M, K,) and which the camels eat vehemently: (AHn, M:) it is of the kind called *ukuwr. (Aboo-Nasr, M.)

muSofarN *
muSofarN: see its fem., with p, voce maSofuwrN.

muSofirN *
muSofirN A poor man. (S.)

muSaf~arN *
muSaf~arN; and its fem., with p: see maSofuwrN.

huwa maSaf~iru A@sotihi *
huwa maSaf~iru A@sotihi is from AlS~afiyru, [see Safara,] not from AlS~uforapu, (S,) and means He is a Sar~aAT; (S, K;) as though denoting cowardice: (TA:) or it is from Saf~ara “ he dyed yellow; ” (M;) and was applied to Aboo-Jahl; (M, TA;) meaning that he dyed his Aisot with saffron, and was addicted to [the enormity termed] A^ubonap: this, accord. to Sgh, is the correct explanation; and he adds that it is said of a luxurious man, whom experience and afflictions have not rendered firm, or sound, in judgment. (TA.) ― -b2- AlmuSaf~irapu is an appellation applied to Those whose sign [meaning the colour of their ensign] is Suforap; (M, K;) [i. e. whose ensign is yellow;] and is similar to AlmuHam~irapu and Almubay~iDapu. (M.)

maSofuwrN *
maSofuwrN: see SaAfirN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also Hungry; and so muSaf~arN↓. (K.) ― -b2- Of the maSofuwrap, (TA,) and muSofarap↓, (Mgh, TA,) or muSaf~arap↓, (Mgh,) which one is forbidden to offer in sacrifice, (Mgh, TA,) it is said that the first is Such as has the ear entirely cut off; because its ear-hole is destitute of the ear: and the second, the lean, or emaciated; because devoid of fatness; or, accord. to Kt, the first and second have the latter meaning, as though destitute of fat and flesh: (TA:) or the second and third have the latter meaning; or the former meaning: (Mgh:) but accord. to the relation of Sh, what is thus forbidden is termed AlmaSoguwrapu, with g, having the former of the meanings expl. above; which IAth disapproves: (TA in art. Sgr:) or AlmuSag~arapu. (Mgh in that art.) ＝ -A3- Also Having the disease termed SufaAr: (A, TA:) or one from whose belly comes forth yellow water. (TA.)

SiforidN *
SiforidN A certain bird, (S, M, K,) of a cowardly nature, (K,) larger than the sparrow, (M,) that frequents houses, and is the most cowardly of birds; (Lth;) it is afraid of the [little bird called] SaEowap; (IAar;) and is by the vulgar (S) called A^abuw AlmaliyHi. (S, K. [Accord. to Golius, the nightingale: but this I think a mistake.]) A^ajobanu mino SiforidK [More cowardly than a sifrid] is a prov., (S, Meyd,) asserted by AO to be postclassical. (Meyd. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 372.])

A_iSofanoTN *
A_iSofanoTN a dial. var. of A_isofanoTN, q. v. (As, K.)

1 SafaEahu *
1. SafaEahu, aor.
SafaEa
, (O, Msb, K,) inf. n. SafoEN, (S, * O, Msb, TA,) accord. to Lth, (O, TA,) He struck him with his fist, not vehemently, on the back of his neck: (O, K, TA:) or, (O, K,) accord. to Az (O, Msb, TA) and others, (Msb,) he struck him [i. e. slapped him] with his expanded hand (O, Msb, K, TA) on the back of his neck, or on his body; not with the fist: (O, Msb, TA:) or it is post-classical: (S, K:) [but Fei says,] the assertion that it is post-classical is not to be regarded: (Msb:) Az adds, IDrd says that it is from SawofaEapN↓, (O, TA,) which signifies the top, or uppermost part, of the [cap called] kum~ap, and of the turban: (O, K, TA:) or this is a mistranscription, and is correctly with q: (K, TA:) [Sgh says,] this which Az mentions, [as] on the authority of IDrd, I have not found in the Jm; and it is correctly with q. (O.)

SafoEapN *
SafoEapN A single act of striking [or slapping] with the expanded hand upon the back of the neck, or upon the body. (Msb.)

SafoEaAnu *
SafoEaAnu or SafoEaAnN (accord. to different copies of the S and K) A man who is struck [or slapped] in the manner expl. above in the first paragraph; (S, Msb, K;) as also maSofaEaAniY~N↓. (O, K.)

SawofaEapN *
SawofaEapN: see the first paragraph of this art.

maSofaEaAniY~N *
maSofaEaAniY~N: see SafoEaAnu.

1 SafoqN *
1. SafoqN [inf. n. of Safaqa] signifies The striking [a thing] so as to cause a sound to be heard in consequence thereof; (S, O, K;) as also taSofiyqN [inf. n. of Sf~q↓, but this has an intensive signification]: (S:) and taSofaAqN is [also] an inf. n. of Safaqa, like Safoq in the phrase Safoqu Alkaf~i EalaY AlA^uxoraY [the striking of the hand upon the other hand], but denoting muchness of the action. (Sb, M, TA.) [Hence several meanings of both of these verbs, here following.] ― -b2- Safaqa raA^osahu, and Eayonahu, (M,) and Safaqahu EalaY raA^osihi, (Msb,) aor.
Safiqa
, inf. n. SafoqN, (M, Msb,) He struck his head, and his eye, (M,) and he struck him on his head with the hand. (Msb.) And Safaqahu biAls~ayofi, (O, K,) inf. n. SafoqN, (O,) He struck him with the sword. (O, K.) And Safaqa bihi AlA^aroDa [lit. He smote the ground with him; meaning he flung him upon the ground]. (L, TA.) ― -b3- Safaqa bijanaAHayohi, (M, K,) aor. as above, (M,) [inf. n. SafoqN,] said of a bird, He beat [his sides, or the air,] with his wings; (M, L, K; *) as also Sif~q↓, (M, K,) inf. n. taSofiyqN. (TA.) ― -b4- Safaqatohu Alr~iyHu, and Sf~qthu↓, The wind smote it so as to cause a sound to be heard: (S:) or the latter signifies [simply] the wind smote it, or beat it: (Ham p. 719:) [or the wind beat upon it; namely, a sail &c.: (see $iraAEN:)] [and] both signify the wind shifted it to the right and left, and turned it back: (TA: [in the CK, Alt~atoliybu is erroneously put for Alt~aqoliybu as an explanation of Alt~aSofiyqu:]) and Alr~iyHu AlmaA='a Sf~qt↓ The wind beat the water so that it made it clear: (M:) and Safaqati Alr~iyHu AlA^a$ojaAra, (K,) aor. as above, inf. n. SafoqN, (O,) The wind put the trees in motion, or into a state of commotion, (O, K,) and shook them: (O, TA:) and Alr~iyHu Sf~qt↓ Als~aHaAba The wind smote the clouds, [for Saramatohu in my original, an obvious mistranscription, I read Darabatohu,] and blew in different directions upon them. (TA.) ― -b5- Safaqa AlEuwda, (inf. n. SafoqN, TA,) He put in motion [by striking them] the chords of the lute. (S, O, K.) ― -b6- Safaqa yadahu biAlbayoEapi and Safaqa EalaY yadihi, inf. n. SafoqN (M, K) and SafoqapN, (K,) [or the latter, which see below, is a simple subst.,] He struck his hand upon his [another's] hand by way of ratifying the sale, or the covenant; (M, K;) and so Safaqa lahu AlbayoEa, aor.
Safiqa
, (K,) inf. n. SafoqN: (TA:) or Safaqotu lahu biAlbayoEi and biAlbayoEapi, inf. n. SafoqN, I struck my hand upon his hand [by way of ratifying the sale and the covenant]. (S, O, Msb.) [See also safaqa. And see an ex. in a verse cited voce radaAdN.] ― -b7- SafoqN (S, O, K) as inf. n. of Safaqotuhu, (S, O,) also signifies The shutting, or closing [a thing]; and the turning, or sending, or putting, [a thing] back, or away; (S, O, K;) as also A_iSofaAqN↓. (K.) You say, Safaqa Eayonahu He shut, or closed, his eye. (S, O, K.) And Safaqa AlbaAba, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) aor.
Safiqa
, (M,) inf. n. SafoqN, (M, Msb,) He shut or closed, the door; (S, O, Msb, K;) as also ASfqhu↓: (S, O:) or both signify he locked the door: (M, K:) and in like manner safaqahu [and Asfqhu]. (TA.) And He opened the door: (ADk, O, Msb, K:) thus having two contr. significations. (Msb.) And Safaqa maA$iyatahu, inf. n. SafoqN, He turned, or sent, his cattle back, or away. (M, TA.) And Safaqahumo Eano ka*aA He turned them [i. e. men] back, or away, from such a thing. (TA.) And one says, maA zaAluwA yaSofiquwnaniY They ceased not to turn me about in an affair: [meaning that] they endeavoured to induce him to do it. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.) ― -b8- Safaqahumo mino baladK A_ilaY baladK They expelled them from town to town, or from country to country, forcibly and ignominiously. (TA.) ― -b9- Safaqa Al$~araAba: see 2. ― -b10- Safaqa AlqadaHa, (O, K,) inf. n. SafoqN, (O, TA,) He filled the drinking-vessel; as also ASfqhu↓; (O, K;) and Sf~qhu↓: (O:) or AlkaA^osa Sf~q↓, and ASfqhA↓, he filled the drinking-cup, or wine-cup: (Lh, M:) and AlHawoDa ASfqnA↓ We collected the water in the watering-trough. (TA.) ― -b11- And SafaqahaA, inf. n. SafoqN, He compressed her; syn. jaAmaEahaA. (TA.) ― -b12- And SafoqN signifies also The collecting together [a thing or things]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Safaqa Alr~ajulu, (M, K,) inf. n. SafoqN, (M,) The man went away. (M, K.) ― -b2- mina Safaqato EalayonaA SaAfiqapN↓ Aln~aAsi A company of men alighted at our abode. (IDrd, M, * O, K. *) ― -b3- Safaqato, (IDrd, O, K,) inf. n. SafoqN, (TA,) said of a she-camel, Her womb closed against the passage of her fœtus, (A^arotajato raHimuhaA Eano waladihaA, [or A^urotijato i. e. became closed, the syll. signs of this word in the O being doubtful, in the CK erroneously written Artaxato,]) so that the fœtus died. (IDrd, O, K, TA.) ＝ -A3- Safuqa, aor.
Safuqa
, (M, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. SafaAqapN, said of a garment, or piece of cloth, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) It was strong, stout, or firm; (M;) thick, substantial, close, or compact, in texture: (O, Msb, K:) and so safuqa. (T, S, &c., in art. sfq.) ― -b2- And, said of a face, (S, O, K, TA,) (tropical:) It was impudent; or had little shame. (O, K, TA.)

2: see 1, former half, in five places. ― -b2- Alt~aSofiyqu biAlyadi means The making a sound with the hand [by clapping]: (S:) one says, Sf~q biyadayohi [He clapped with his hands; or clapped his hands]: (O, Msb:) and Aln~isaA='u yuSaf~iqona EalaY Almay~iti [The women clap their hands in lamenting over the dead: thus they often do in the present day, over the corpse and over the grave]: (TA:) Alt~aSofiyqu is syn. with Alt~aSofiyHu: (As, O:) or (O) the former signifies the striking with the palm of one hand upon that of the other; (O, K;) but the latter is better expl. as the striking with the outer side of the right hand upon the inner side of the left hand. SfH.] ― -b3- Sf~q Alqirobapa, (M, TA,) inf. n. tSofiyqN, (TA,) He poured water into the skin, (M, TA,) and shook it about, (TA,) the skin being new, so that the water came forth yellow. (M.) ― -b4- See also 1, latter half, in two places. ― -b5- Sf~q Al$~araAba He mixed the wine, or beverage. (M.) ― -b6- And, (M,) inf. n. as above; (S, O, K;) and Safaqahu↓, (M,) inf. n. SafoqN; (K;) and ASfqhu↓, (M,) inf. n. A_iSofaAqN; (K;) He transferred the wine, or beverage, from one vessel to another, (S, M, O, K,) or from one jar to another, (As, TA,) it being mixed, (K,) in order that it might become clear. (M, K.) ― -b7- taSofiyqu AlA_ibili means The removing of camels from a place which they have depastured to a place in which is pasture: (S, O, K: *) thus in the saying of the rájiz (Aboo-Mohammad El-Fak'asee, O) cited in the first paragraph of art. zl: (S, O:) or Alt~aSofiyq in that instance, accord. to IAar, is from Sf~q Alqawomu fiY AlbilaAdi The people, or party, went far in the country in search of pasture: (M:) [or] Sf~q, said of a man, (Ibn- 'Abbád, O,) inf. n. as above, (K,) means He went away; and he went round about. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K.) ― -b8- And Alt~aSofiyqu signifies also The forming a determined intention or purpose, and then reversing it. (TA.)

3 SAfq Einoda Safoqapi AlbayoEi *
3. SAfq Einoda Safoqapi AlbayoEi [He struck his hand upon that of another in token of the ratification of the sale]. (T in art. dw. [See also 6.]) ― -b2- SAfqt said of a she-camel, She lay, or slept, upon one side one time and upon the other side another time: from SafoqN meaning jaAnibN. (M. [And the same is indicated in the O.]) And fulaAnN yuSaAfiqu bayona janobayohi Such a one turns over upon this Safoq [or side] one time and upon the other another. (O.) And baAta fulaAnN yuSaAfiqu [Such a one passed the night turning over from side to side]. (Z, TA.) ― -b3- [Accord. to the K, said of a she-camel, She was taken with the pains of parturition; i. q. maxaDato: but this is app. a mistake; for it seems to have been taken from the saying in the O, (one of the principal sources of the K,) A_i*aA maxaDati Aln~aAqapu SaAfaqato, which evidently means When the she-camel is taken with the pains of parturition, she turns over from side to side; as is there indicated by the context both before and after.] ― -b4- SAfq bayona qamiySayoni, (M,) or byn vawobayoni, (K,) He wore two shirts, (M,) or two garments, (K,) one of them over the other. (M, K.)

4 A^aSofaqa
4: see 1, latter half, in five places: ― -b2- and see also 2. ＝ -A2- A^aSofaquwA Ealayohi i. q. tabaAyaEuwA Ealayohi [i. e. They made a covenant, or compact, respecting it, or to do it, as though by striking their hands together], namely, the thing, or affair: (TA in art. byE: [see Safaqa yadahu biAlbayoEapi; and see also 3, and 6, and SafoqapN:]) they combined consentaneously, or agreed together, respecting it, or to do it, namely, the thing, or affair; syn. A^aTobaquwA Ealayohi, (S, O, K,) or AijotamaEuwA Ealayohi. (M.) And A^aSofaquwA EalayonaA [They combined, or collected themselves together, against us]. (M, from a verse of Zuheyr.) A^aSofaqato lahu
nisowaAnu mak~apa occurs in a trad. as meaning The women of Mekkeh collected themselves together to him: or, as some relate it, AinoSafaqato↓. (TA.) And one says, A^aSofaquwA lahu meaning Ha$aduwA [i. e. They collected themselves together to him; or they combined to treat him with courtesy and honour]. (M.) ― -b2- ASfq lahumo He brought them as much food as would satisfy their hunger: (O, K:) said in relation to the entertainment of guests. (O.) ― -b3- A^aSofaqato yaduhu bika*aA, (S, O,) or yadiY, (K,) His hand, or my hand, lighted on, met with, or encountered, such a thing; syn. SaAdafatohu and waAfaqatohu. (S, O, K.) En-Nemir Ibn-Towlab says, (S, O, TA,) describing a jaz~aAr [or slaughterer of camels], (TA,)
Hat~aY A_i*aA qusima Aln~aSiybu waA^aSofaqato
yaduhu bijalodapi DaroEihaA waHuwaArihaA
[Until, or until when, the share was divided, and his hand lighted on the skin of her udder and her young one]. (S, O, TA: but in the S, TuriHa is put in the place of qusima.) ＝ -A3- A^aSofaqa Alqawomu The people, or party, were, or became, in a state of commotion, or tumult; syn. AiDoTarabuwA. (M, TA. [See also 8.]) ＝ -A4- A^uSofiqa liY It was appointed, or ordained, for me; or prepared for me. (TA.) ＝ -A5- ASfq Alganama He milked the sheep, or goats, but once in the day; (S, M, O, TA;) and so with s: (TA in art. sfq:) or AlA_iSofaAqu signifies the milking once in the day and night. (TA.) ＝ -A6- ASfq Alv~awoba He wove the garment (M, TA) strongly, stoutly, firmly, (M,) thickly, substantially, closely, or compactly. (TA.)

5 tSf~q *
5. tSf~q He (a man) turned over and over; (M;) he moved repeatedly to and fro, syn. tarad~ada, (M, O, K,) from side to side. (M.) And tSf~qt She (a camel) turned herself over, upside down (lit. back for belly), (O, K, TA,) when taken with the pains of parturition. (TA.) ― -b2- tSf~q liloA^amori He addressed, or applied, or directed, himself, or his regard, or attention, or mind, to the affair; syn. taEar~aDa lahu. (Sh, O, K.)

6 tSAfqwA *
6. tSAfqwA (S, M, O) They struck their hands upon the hands of others (O) Einoda AlbayoEapi [on the occasion of the ratifying of a sale, or covenant]: (S, O:) or they [struck a bargain;] bought and sold; or made a covenant, or compact; one with another. (M, TA.)

7 AnSfq *
7. AnSfq It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) was beaten by the wind, so that it moved to and fro. (M. TA.) [See also 8.] ― -b2- It (a door) became shut, or closed: and so with s: (TA in art. sfq:) [or it shut again of itself:] said of a door which, when opened, will not remain open. (TA in art. dlq.) ― -b3- He (a man, TA) turned, or became turned or sent or put, back, or away: (S, O, K, TA:) he [or it] returned. (TA.) ― -b4- And AnSfqwA They collected themselves together: the contr. of the next preceding signification. (TA.) See also 4. ― -b5- And one says, AnSfqwA EalayonaA yamiynFA wa$imaAlFA They came upon us on the right and left. (M, TA.)

8 ASTfqt AlA^a$ojaAru *
8. ASTfqt AlA^a$ojaAru The trees became shaken, or agitated, by the wind. (S, O, K, TA.) And ASTfq AlEuwdu The lute had its chords put in motion, (S, O, K, TA,) so that they responded, one to another. (TA.) ― -b2- ASTfq AlA=faAqu biAlbayaADi The tracts of the horizon flickered with whiteness, and the light thereof spread. (TA.) ― -b3- And ASTfq Almajolisu biAlqawomi The sitting-place became a scene of commotion, or tumult, with the people, or party. (TA. [See also 4, latter part.])

SafoqN *
SafoqN: see SafoqapN. ＝ -A2- Also A side; a lateral part or portion; (S, M, O, K;) and so SufoqN↓, (S, O, K,) and SafaqN↓; (M, O, K;) syn. naAHiyapN, (S, M, O, K,) and jaAnibN. (M, TA.) Of a mountain, (S, O, K,) it signifies in like manner, (O,) its SafoH, (S, O, K,) and its naAHiyap: (S:) [both of which signify as above: or by the former may be meant what here follows:] or its face, (M, K,) in the upper part thereof, above the HaDiyD [or low ground at, or by, the base, or foot]: (M:) pl. SufuwqN. (S, O.) [In like manner also,] SafoqaA AlEunuqi signifies The two sides of the neck. (M, K.) And SafoqaA Alfarasi The two cheeks of the horse. (M, K.) ― -b2- Also A place. (K.) ― -b3- See also SifoqN. ＝ -A3- And see SafaqN, in two places.

SufoqN *
SufoqN: see the next preceding paragraph.

SifoqN *
SifoqN, with kesr, The miSoraAE [i. e. either half, or leaf,] of a door [meaning of a folding door]: (K:) [or, accord. to the O, it is SafoqN↓, for it is there said that SafoqaA AlbaAbi means miSoraAEaAhu; but SM follows the reading in the K without remarking upon the difference in the O; and adds,] and one says, baAbu daArihi SifoqN waAHidN [meaning The door of his house is one leaf; i. e.] when it does not consist of what are termed miSoraAEaAni. (TA.)

SafoqN *
SafoqN: see SafoqN. ＝ -A2- Also Water that is poured into a new skin, and shaken in it, and in consequence becomes yellow; (S, O, K;) or yellow water that comes forth from a new skin upon which water has been poured; (M;) and so SafoqN↓. (M, K.) Hence, (TA,) one says, waradonaA maA='F kaA^an~ahu SafaqN [We came for the purpose of drinking to water as though it were the yellow water that comes forth from a new skin]. (S, O.) ― -b2- And A new skin upon [or into] which water is poured, in consequence whereof yellow water comes forth from it. (M.) ― -b3- Also, accord. to AHn, (M,) or so SafoqN↓, (K,) The odour, and savour, of dibaAg [or tan]. (M, K.) ― -b4- And The former, accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, The last of dibaAg [or tan]: (O, TA:) in the K, A=xiru Ald~imaAgi is erroneously put for A=xr Ald~ibaAg. (TA.)

SafoqapN *
SafoqapN A striking of the hand [of one person] upon the hand [of another] in [ratifying] a sale or purchase and a covenant: (Mgh:) and SafoqN↓ is [used in the same sense, being an inf. n. and also] a subst. from the verb in the phrase Safaqa yadahu biAlbayoEapi [expl. in the first paragraph of this art.]; (M, K;) as also Sifiq~aY↓, like zimij~aY, (K,) or Sifaq~aY↓, (so in a copy of the M,) which is mentioned by Sb, (M, TA,) and of which Seer says that it may be from Safoqu Alkaf~i EalaY AlA^uxoraY. (TA. [See 1, first sentence.]) ― -b2- Hence it is used to signify The contract itself that is made in the case of a sale, (Mgh, Msb,) and the covenant that one makes: (Mgh:) or an agreement respecting a thing: (M, TA:) Az says that it relates to the seller and the buyer. (Msb.) [And it is sometimes with s in the place of S.] One says, rabiHato Safoqatuka i. e. [May] thy purchase [bring profit]. (S, O.) And baAraka A@ll~`hu laka fiY Safoqapi yamiynika i. e. [May God bless thee in] the contract [(lit. the striking) of thy right hand]. (Msb.) And SafoqapN raAbiHapN, and SafoqapN xaAsirapN, (S, O, K,) A sale or bargain [bringing gain, and a sale or bargain occasioning loss]. (K.) And A_in~ahu lamubaAraku AlS~afoqapi [Verily he is blessed in respect of bargaining]; meaning that he buys not anything without gaining in it. (TA.) And qadi A@$otarayotu Alyawoma SafoqapF SaAliHapF [I have purchased to-day a good purchase]. (TA.) And AlbayoEu SafoqapN A^awo xiyaArN Selling is decisive or with the option of returning. (Mgh.) And it is said in a trad. (of Ibn-Mes'ood, TA), SafoqataAni fiY SafoqapK ribFA i. e. Two bargains in a [single] bargain [are an unlawful gain]: this is of two kinds: one is the seller's saying to the buyer, “ I sell to thee such a thing for a hundred dirhems on the condition of thy buying of me this garment, or piece of cloth, for such a sum: ” the other kind is his saying, “ I sell to thee this garment, or piece of cloth, for twenty dirhems on the condition of thy selling to me thy commodity for ten dirhems. ” (O.) And it is said in another trad., A_in~a A^akobara AlkabaAy^iri A^ano tuqaAtila A^ahola Safoqatika i. e. [Verily the greatest of great sins is] thy fighting those with whom thou hast made a covenant: because each of the two persons making a covenant puts his hand in the hand of the other, like as is done by each of two persons selling and buying. (TA.)

Sifiq~aY *
Sifiq~aY or Sifaq~aY: see the next preceding paragraph.

SifaAqN *
SifaAqN The inferior [or inner] skin, that is beneath the skin upon which is the hair: (S, O, K:) a thin skin beneath the upper skin and above the flesh: (IAth, TA:) or the SifaAq of the belly is the skin, (M,) the inner skin, (TA,) that is next to the sawaAd, (M, TA,) the sawaAd of the belly, (TA,) [i. e. the liver,] and which is the part where the farrier perforates the beast (banoqubu mina Ald~aAb~api) [at the navel, in order that a yellow fluid may issue forth]: (M, TA:) or the SafaAq is the part around the navel, where the farrier performs the operation above mentioned: (AA, TA:) or the skin which, when the masok [or hide] is stripped off, remains cleaving to the belly, and the rending of which occasions a [rupture termed] fatoq; so says As, in the “ Book of the Horse: ” (TA:) or what is between the jilod [or outer skin] and the muSoraAn [or intestines into which the food passes from the stomach]; (ISh, O, K;) com-
prising all of what are termed the maraAq~ of the belly, beneath the jilod thereof, to the sawaAd of the belly [i. e. the liver]; the maraAq~ of the belly being all that has not a bone curving over it: (ISh, O:) or the skin of the whole of the belly: (O, K:) the pl. is SufuqN, only. (M, TA.)

SafuwqN *
SafuwqN An abominable acclivity or ascending road or mountain-road difficult of ascent: pl. SafaAy^iqu and SufuqN. (M, K.) And A mountain, (K,) or an obstacle, or elevated portion, of mountains, (O,) such as is inaccessible. (O, K.) And A smooth, high rock: pl. SufuqN. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) ＝ -A2- Also, applied to a bow, Pliant. (Fr, O, K.) ― -b2- [In the TA, in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb describing a bow, to which it seems to be there applied as an epithet, it is expl. as signifying rAjEp; but I think that this is a mistranscription for raAjifapN, meaning Quivering. ― -b3- Freytag has assigned to it three explanations which belong to SifaAqN.]

SafiyqN *
SafiyqN, applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) strong, stout, or firm; (M;) thick, substantial, close, or compact, in texture: (Mgh, O, Msb, K:) and safiyqN is a dial. var. thereof. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Hardy, strong, sturdy, enduring, or patient. (M.) ― -b3- And applied to a face (S, O, K, TA) as meaning (tropical:) Impudent; or having little shame. (O, K, TA.) And rajulN Safiyqu Alwajohi (assumed tropical:) A man having no shame. (Har p. 368.)

SafiyqapN *
SafiyqapN: see SaAfiqapN.

SafaAy^iqu *
SafaAy^iqu Travelling-camels (rikaAbN) coming and going. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.) ― -b2- See also SaAfiqapN.

Saf~aAqN *
Saf~aAqN A cock that beats with his wings when crowing. (TA.) ― -b2- It occurs in a trad., followed by A^af~aAq in apposition, and is said by As to mean Aal~a*iY yaSofiqu EalaY A^amorK EaZiymK [app. One who goes away on some great affair]: but in the opinion of Az, it means one who makes many journeys, and who employs himself, or uses art or artifice or cunning, in affairs of traffic; thus nearly agreeing in meaning with A^f~aAqN. (O: the latter meaning only is assigned to it in the K.)

SaAfiqapN *
SaAfiqapN A company (IDrd, M, O, K) of men [alighting at one's abode]. (IDrd, M, O.) See 1, near the end. ― -b2- Also A calamity, or misfortune: (M, TA:) pl. SawaAfiqu: (M:) this pl. and SafaAy^iqu↓, (O, K, TA,) which latter may be pl. of SafiyqapN↓, (TA,) signify accidents, or evil accidents, (O, K, TA,) and varieties, or vicissitudes, of events. (O, TA.)

A^aSofaqu *
A^aSofaqu A garment, or piece of cloth, more [strong, stout, firm,] thick, substantial, close, or compact, in texture, than another. (Mgh.)

A^aSofaqaAniy~apN *
A^aSofaqaAniy~apN [written in one place with fet-h, and in another with kesr, to the f,] i. q. xawalN [A man's slaves, or servants, and other dependents; or slaves, and cattle, or camels &c.;] in the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)

maSofaqN *
maSofaqN A place of passage; a way, road, or path; syn. masolakN. (O, TA.)

muSaf~aqN *
muSaf~aqN [pass. part. n. of 2, q. v.]. One says, laka EinodiY wud~N muSaf~aqN wanuSoHN muraw~aqN (tropical:) [I have, for thee, an affection defecated like wine that has been transferred from one vessel to another and left to settle, and a benevolence purified like clarified wine]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A full [or filled] drinking-vessel. (Fr, TA.)

muSaAfiqN *
muSaAfiqN A camel lying, or sleeping, upon one side one time and upon the other side another time. (O, K.) ― -b2- And muSaAfiqN bayona vawobayoni Wearing two garments, one of them over the other. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)

1 Safana *
1. Safana, aor.
Safina
, inf. n. SufuwnN, said of a horse, He stood upon three legs and the extremity of the hoof of the fourth leg; (AZ, * S, K, TA;) [thus expl.] without restriction to a fore leg or a hind leg: (TA:) or he stood upon three legs, and turned back the extremity of the fore part of the fourth hoof, that of his fore leg: (M, TA:) [or he stood upon three legs, and otherwise: (see SaAfinN:)] accord. to Fr, the poems of the Arabs indicate that SufuwnN signifies peculiarly, or specially, [or simply,] the act of standing, or standing still. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (M, Msb, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M, Msb,) said of a man, (K,) or Safana qadamayohi, (TA, from a trad.,) meaning Saf~a qadamayohi [He set his feet evenly, side by side], (M, Msb, K, TA,) standing, (Msb,) and praying. (TA.) [Or, said of a man standing in prayer, it signifies, or in this case it signifies also, He put his feet close together: or he turned one of his feet backward, like as the horse turns one hoof when standing upon three legs: see, again, SaAfinN.] ＝ -A2- Safana AlHa$iy$a (M, TA) waAlwaraqa, aor.
Safina
, (M,) inf. n. SafonN, said of a bird, or flying thing, It compacted the dry herbage (M, TA) and the leaves, [to make a habitation,] for its young ones, (M,) or around its place of entrance [into its habitation]; (TA;) and Sf~nhu↓ signifies the same: (M:) taSofiynN↓ as the act of the hornet and the like is the compacting for itself, or for its young ones, a habitation (K, TA) of dry herbage and of leaves: so says Lth. (TA.) ― -b2- And Safana viyaAbahu He collected together his clothes (JM, TA) fiY sarojihi [upon his saddle], (TA,) or fiY Als~aroji wanaHowihi [upon the saddle and the like thereof]. (JM.) ― -b3- Safana bihi AlA^aroDa, (K, TA,) aor.
Safina
, inf. n. SafonN, (TA,) He flung him, or it, upon the ground. (K, TA.) ＝ -A3- And Safanahu, aor.
Safina
, inf. n. SafonN, He rent, or slit, his Safan, i. e. scrotum. (M.)

2 Sf~n *
2. Sf~n, and its inf. n.: see 1, in two places.

3 muSaAfanapN *
3. muSaAfanapN The standing confronting a people, or party. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [Also The dividing of water among a people, or party, in the manner described in the next paragraph:] one says, SaAfana AlmaA='a bayona Alqawomi faA^aEoTaAniY SafonapF↓ i. e. maqolapF [for juroEapa maqolapK, the meaning being He divided the water in that manner among the people, or party, and gave me a gulp as much as would cover a pebble in the bottom of a vessel]. (TA.)

6 tSAfnwA AlmaA='a *
6. tSAfnwA AlmaA='a, (AA, S, M, K,) said of people in a journey and having little water, (M,) They divided the water among themselves (AA, S, M, K) by shares, (S, K,) by means of the pebble, (AA, S, M,) which they threw into the vessel to pour the water into it, (AA,) giving to each of them as much as would cover the pebble. (AA, S.) See also 6 in art. H*Y.

SafonN *
SafonN [if not a mistake for SufonN, q. v.,] signifies The [round piece of skin, or leather, in which food is put, and upon which people eat; commonly called] suforap; as also SafonapN↓: (K:) the latter is expl. by AA and IAar as a suforap that is gathered together by a [running] string [near the edge, by means of which it is converted into a bag, agreeably with a modern custom]. (TA.) ― -b2- And The [bursa faucium, or faucial bag, of the camel; commonly called] $iqo$iqap; as also SafonapN↓: (K:) so expl. by AA. (TA.) ― -b3- See also SafanN.

SufonN *
SufonN A thing like the suforap [described in the next preceding paragraph], and between the Eayobap and the qirobap, in which are [put] goods or utensils or the like: or it is of skin, or leather, (M,) [i. e.] a receptacle of skin, or leather, (S, in which it is expressly said to be with damm,) like the suforap, (S, M,) pertaining to the people of the desert, in which they put their travelling-provisions, and (M) with which (S, M) sometimes (M) water is drawn, (S, M,) like [as is done with] the dalow: (M:) occurring in a verse of Sakhr El-Hudhalee [cited in art. xD]: (S:) or a thing like the [small bucket, or small drinking-vessel, of skin or leather, called] rakowap, (Fr, Mgh, K,) in which the ablution termed wuDuwo' is performed: (Fr, K:) or it signifies, (Mgh,) or signifies also, (K,) accord. to AA, (S,) a [pouch such as is called] xariyTap, pertaining to the pastor, in which are [put] his food, and his zinaAd [for producing fire], (S, Mgh, K,) and his other utensils or apparatus, (K,) or what other things he requires; (S, Mgh;) and sometimes water is drawn with it, like [as is done with] the dalow; (TA;) as also SafonapN↓: (K:) or, accord. to A'Obeyd, SafonapN↓ signifies a thing like the Eayobap, in which are [put] a man's goods or utensils, and his [other] apparatus; and when the p is elided, it is pronounced with damm [i. e. SufonN]: (TA:) or SafonapN↓, (TA,) or SuqonapN↓, (so in a copy of the M,) signifies a small dalow [or leathern bucket], having a single Haloqap [or ring]; and when it is large, it is called SufonN: and the pl. is A^aSofunN. (M, TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) Water [app. considered as contained in the vessel thus called]: so expl. as used in the saying of Aboo-Du-ád,
haraqotu fiY HawoDihi SufonFA liya$orabahu
[I poured into his drinking-trough water that he might drink it]. (TA.) ― -b3- See also what next follows.

SafanN *
SafanN The scrotum (S, M, Msb, K) of a man; (S, Msb;) as also SufonN↓, (M,) or SafonN↓, (K,)
and SafonapN↓ and SufonapN↓: (M:) pl. A^aSofaAnN (S, M, Msb) and SufonaAnN. (Msb.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) The envelope of the ear of corn: (K, TA:) so called by way of comparison [to the scrotum]. (TA.) ― -b3- And The habitation that is compacted (M, * K, TA) by a bird, or flying thing, (M,) or by the hornet and the like, (K, TA,) of dry herbage and of leaves, (M, TA,) for its young ones, (M, K, TA,) or for itself. (K, TA.)

SafonapN *
SafonapN: see SafonN, in two places: ― -b2- and SufonN, in three places: ― -b3- and SafanN: ― -b4- and see also 3.

SufonapN *
SufonapN: see SufonN, latter part: ― -b2- and SafanN.

SaAfinN *
SaAfinN A horse standing upon three legs and the extremity of the hoof of the fourth leg: (A'Obeyd, * S, TA:) or standing upon three legs, and turning back the extremity of the fore part of the fourth hoof, that of his fore leg: (M, TA:) or standing upon three legs, and otherwise: thus, says Fr, I have found the Arabs use the word: (TA: [see 1, first sentence:]) pl. SufuwnN (M, TA) and SawaAfinu and [the pl. of SaAfinapN is] SaAfinaAtN. (TA.) SaAfinaAtN occurs in the Kur xxxviii. 30. (M, TA.) And in the same, xxii. 37, I'Ab and Ibn-Mes-'ood used to read SawaAfina [instead of SawaAf~a]; the former explaining it as meaning Having the shank of one fore leg tied up to the arm; for thus is done with the camel when he is slaughtered: the latter, as meaning standing, or standing still. (TA.) ― -b2- And applied to a man, it means SaAf~N qadamayohi [setting his feet evenly, side by side], (A'Obeyd, M, TA, and the like is said in the S and Msb,) standing. (A'Obeyd, Msb, TA.) It is said in a trad., (S, M, Msb, TA,) referring to the Prophet mentioned as praying, (S, M,) qumonaA xalofahu SufuwnFA [app. meaning We stood behind him setting our feet evenly, side by side; for so the context seems to indicate]. (S, M, Msb, K.) [But] in another trad., Sal`wpu AlS~aAfini is said to be forbidden; meaning [The praying] of him who puts his feet close together: or, as some say, of him who turns back his foot [i. e. one of his feet] like as the horse turns his hoof [i. e. one of his hoofs, when standing upon three legs]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AlS~aAfinu signifies [The saphena, or crural vein; so in the present day; i. e.] the vein of the saAq: (S: [see A^aboharu, and see also Aln~asaA:]) or a vein lying deep in the arm (Al*~iraAE) [and] amid the sinews of the [fore] shank of a beast: or the SaAfinaAni are two veins penetrating into the interior of the two shanks: or two veins in the legs: or two branches [of veins] in the two thighs: and the SAfn is [strangely said to be] a vein in the interior of the back bone, extending lengthwise, uniting with the niyaAT [q. v.] of the heart, also called the A^akoHal. (M.)

1 SafaA *
1. SafaA, (S, M, Msb,) aor. yaSofuw, (S, Msb,) inf. n. SafaA='N (S, M, Msb, K *) and Sufuw~N (M, Msb, K *) and SafowN (K, * TK) and SafowapN` and SifowapN, (MA,) said of wine, or beverage, (S,) or of water, (TK,) or of a thing, (M,) It was, or became, clear, limpid, or pure; contr. of kadira; (S, M, K; *) or free from Alkadar [i. e. turbidness, thickness, or muddiness]; (Msb;) or free from admixture. (Er-Rághib, TA.) And, said of the air, or atmosphere, It was, or became, cloudless; free from any particle of cloud. (M, K.) [And it is also said, tropically, of life; and of the mind, or heart; and of love, or affection; &c.] ― -b2- Safato, (AA, S, M, K,) aor. taSofuw; (AA, S;) and Safuwto; (M, K;) said of a she-camel, (AA, S, M, K,) and of a ewe, or she-goat, (AA, S,) She abounded with milk. (AA, S, M, K.) ＝ -A2- SafaA Al$~aYo'a He took the clear, or pure, part, or portion, of the thing; (M, TA;) as also Safowahu AstSfY↓; (M;) and AstSfAhu↓ [alone] signifies the same; (K, TA;) as also ASTfAhu↓; (Er-Rághib, TA;) or he took the best, or choice, part, or portion, of it. (TA.) You say, Safawotu Alqidora I took the clear, or pure, part, or portion, [of the contents] of the cooking-pot. (S.)

2 Sf~Ahu *
2. Sf~Ahu, inf. n. taSofiyapN, He cleared, or clarified, it, namely, wine, or beverage, (S, TA,) by means of the raAwuwq [or miSofaAp]. (TA.) And He removed from it the floating particles, or motes, or the like, that had fallen into it; (TA;) or so Sf~Ahu mina Alqa*aY. (Msb.) ― -b2- And Sf~Y Earamatahu, inf. n. as above, He winnowed his heap of trodden-out corn, or grain. (TA.)

3 SAfAhu *
3. SAfAhu, (S, M, K, TA,) inf. n. muSaAfaApN, (TA,) (tropical:) He regarded him, or acted towards him, with reciprocal purity of mind, or sincerity; or with reciprocal purity, or sincerity, of love, or affection; syn. xaAlaSahu; (S in art. xlS;) he rendered him true, or sincere, brotherly affection; (M, K, TA;) as also ASfAhu↓; (K;) or Alwud~a ASfAhu↓, (S, Msb,) or Almawad~apa, (TA,) he rendered him pure, or sincere, love or affection; (S, Msb, TA;) and [in like manner] one says also SAfAhu AlA_ixaA='a. (TA.)

4 ASfAhu Al$~aYo'a *
4. ASfAhu Al$~aYo'a He made the thing to be his, or he assigned, or appropriated, to him the thing, purely, absolutely, or exclusively. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 3 in two places. ― -b3- And ASfAhu (S, Msb, K, TA) biAl$~aYo'i (S) or bika*aA (K, TA) (tropical:) He chose him in preference to others (S, Msb, K, TA) for, or to give him, the thing or such a thing; (S, K, TA;) and he distinguished him particularly, peculiarly, or specially, i. e. above, or from, or exclusively of, others, by the thing or by such a thing. (TA.) ― -b4- And ASfY EiyaAlahu bi$aYo'K qaliylK (assumed tropical:) He contented, or satisfied, his family, or household, with something little, or scanty. (TA.) ― -b5- ASfY AlA^amiyru daAra fulaAnK means (assumed tropical:) The prince, or governor, took what was in the house of such a one: (S, * TA:) and maAlahu AstSfY↓ (tropical:) He took all his property. (S, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- ASfY, intrans., (tropical:) He was, or became, destitute, or devoid, mina AlmaAli [of property], and mina AlA^adabi [of good education, good breeding, or polite accomplishments, &c.]: (S, K, TA:) as though clear thereof. (TA.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) He (a man, TA) became exhausted of his sperma by women: (Az, K, TA:) or he ceased from sexual intercourse. (IKtt, TA.) ― -b3- And ASft said of a hen, (assumed tropical:) She ceased to lay eggs: (S, M, K, TA:) as though she became clear. (TA.) ― -b4- Hence, (TA,) ASfY said of a poet, (tropical:) He ceased to utter poetry, or to poetize. (S, M, A, K, * TA.) ＝ -A3- ASfY Alqawomu The people had abundance of milk in their camels, and in their sheep or goats. (TA.) ＝ -A4- ASfY said of a digger, He reached stone (SafFA, M, TA, i. e. HajarFA, TA), so that he was repelled [thereby], (M, TA,) or prevented from digging [further]. (TA.)

5 tSf~Y *
5. tSf~Y [It became cleared, or clarified]. (K in art. nTb.)

6 taSaAfayonaA *
6. taSaAfayonaA We regarded one another, or acted reciprocally, with purity, or sincerity, [of mind, or] of love, or affection; syn. taxaAlaSonaA. (S. [See also 3.])

8 ASTfAhu *
8. ASTfAhu: see 1, last sentence but one. ― -b2- Also He took it clear, limpid, or pure; (M, TA;) and so [accord. to SM, which, however, I think doubtful,] AstSfAhu↓, which is expl. in the K as signifying he reckoned it clear, limpid, or pure; though the former meaning is assigned in the M to ASTfAhu only. (TA.) ― -b3- And He chose, made choice of, selected, elected, or preferred, it, (S, M, K,) namely, a thing; (M;) as also AstSfAhu↓. (M, K.) And AiSoTafayotu ka*aA EalaY ka*aA I chose such a thing in preference to such a thing. (TA.) But AiSoTifaA='u A@ll~`hi EibaAdahu [sometimes means God's creating his servants pure; for it] is sometimes by his bringing them into existence clear from the admixture that is found in others: and sometimes it is by his choice and judgment. (TA.)

10 A_isotaSofawa
10: see 1, last sentence but one, in two places: ― -b2- see also 8, in two places: ― -b3- and see 4.

SafFA *
SafFA Stones: or smooth stones: and one thereof is termed SafaApN: [i. e. the former word is a coll. gen. n., and the latter is its n. un.:] the two words being like HaSFY and HaSaApN: (Msb:) or SafaApN signifies a smooth rock: (S:) or a hard and smooth stone, large, and such as does not give growth to anything: (M, K:) and the pl. of this is SafFA [improperly thus termed a pl.] (S, M, K) and SafawaAtN, (M, K,) and (S, M, K) that of SafFA, (M, K, *) not of SafaApN, (M,) A^aSofaA='N and SufiY~N (S, M, K) and SifiY~N: (M, K:) or SafFA signifies stones that are broad and smooth: (ISk, TA:) and [accord. to F,] SafowaA='u↓ signifies the same as SafaApN, as also SafowaAnapN [in the CK erroneously written SafowaAp], of which the pl. is SafowaAnN↓ and SafawaAnN↓, (K,) which last is said by El-Háfidh to be a mistaken pronunciation of SafowaAnN; (TA;) [but correctly,] SafowaA='u↓ [which is a quasi-pl. n.] and SafowaAnN↓ [a coll. gen. n.] (As, T, S, M, TA) of which the sing. or n. un. is SafowaAnapN (S, M, TA) signify the same as SafFA, (As, T, M, TA,) or stones, (S,) or soft, smooth stones; (TA;) or SafowaAnN↓ is used as a pl. and as a sing.; as a pl. meaning smooth stones, one of which is termed SafowaAnapN; and as a sing., stone, or a stone: (Msb:) the dual of SafFA is SafawaAni. (ISk, TA.) maA tanodaY SafaAtuhu is a prov., (S,) applied to the niggardly, like maA yabiD~u Hajaruhu, (S, in art. bD,) meaning (assumed tropical:) No good is obtained from him. (TA in that art.) And one says also, qaraEa SafaAtahu, meaning (assumed tropical:) He im-
pugned his character; blamed, or censured, him; or spoke against him. (Mgh in art. gmz.) ― -b2- AlS~afaA A certain place in Mekkeh (S, Msb) may be masc. or fem., as meaning either the makaAn or the buqoEap. (Msb.) ― -b3- [binotu SafFA, accord. to Reiske, as stated by Freytag, signifies The echo.]

SafowN *
SafowN Clearness, limpidness, or purity; contr. of kadarN; (M, K;) like [the inf. ns.] SafaA='N and Sufuw~N [&c. when used as simple substs.: see 1, first sentence]. (K.) See also SafaA='N, below. ― -b2- Also, and SafowapN↓ and SifowapN↓ and SufowapN↓, (S, M, Msb, K,) but only with fet-h when without p, (AO, S,) The clear, or pure, part, or portion, of a thing; (S, M, Msb, K;) the best, or choice, part, or portion; (TA;) and so SafiY~N↓, (K, * TA,) of a thing. (K, TA.) One says AlmaA='i Safowapu↓, (T, TA,) and AlmaAli, (AO, T, S, TA,) and AlA=xaA='i, (T, TA,) and Sifowatuhu↓, (AO, T, S, TA,) and Sufowatuhu↓, (AO, S,) [i. e. The clear, or pure, part, or portion, or the best, or choice, of water, and of property, and of brothers,] but only Safowu AlA_ihaAlapi [the clear, or pure, part, or portion, or the best, or choice, of the grease, or melted fat, &c.]. (T, TA.) And Mohammad is said to be A@ll~`hi mino xaloqihi Safowapu↓ and muSoTafaAhu↓ [i. e. God's choice one, or elect, or favourite, of his creatures]: (S:) and [in like manner] Adam is said to be A@ll~`hi SafiY~u↓ i. e. the chosen one, or elect, of God. (TA.)

SafaApN *
SafaApN as meaning SaAfiyapN: see SaAfK. ＝ -A2- Also n. un. of SafFA [q. v.].

SafowapN *
SafowapN: see SafowN, in three places.

SufowapN *
SufowapN: see SafowN, in two places.

SifowapN *
SifowapN: see SafowN, in two places. ― -b2- One says also, fiY AlA_inaA='i SifowapN mino maA='K, or xamorK, i. e. [In the vessel is] a small quantity [of water, or of wine]. (M.)

SafowaA='u *
SafowaA='u: see SafFA, in two places.

yawomN SafowaAnu *
yawomN SafowaAnu, (S, M, K,) and SaAfK↓, (M, K,) A day in which the sun is clear, and which is very cold: (S:) or a cold day, (K,) or a very cold day, (M,) without clouds and without thickness [of the air]. (M, K.) ― -b2- SafowaAnu is also a name of The second of the days of cold: (K, TA:) so called because the sky therein is clear of clouds: [as a proper name,] it is determinate, and imperfectly decl. (TA. [See also Sufay~apu.]) ＝ -A2- SafowaAnN [as a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is with p; and said to be used as a sing. and as a pl.]: see SafFA, in three places.

SafawaAnN *
SafawaAnN: see SafFA.

SafaA='N *
SafaA='N an inf. n. of SafaA. (S, M, &c. [See 1, first sentence.]) ― -b2- [It is often used by moderns as meaning (assumed tropical:) Serenity of life, and of the mind; freedom from trouble; comfort; content; complacency; happiness, joy, or pleasure: and so, sometimes, SafowN↓.] ― -b3- Also (tropical:) [Reciprocal purity or sincerity of mind, or of love or affection, or of brotherly affection; or pure, or sincere, reciprocal love &c.;] a subst, from SaAfaAhu. (TA.)

SafiY~N *
SafiY~N: see SaAfK. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) A friend who regards one, or behaves towards one, with reciprocal purity or sincerity of love or affection, or of brotherly affection: (S, * M, * K, TA:) pl. A^aSofiyaA='u. (TA.) One says, fulaAnN SafiY~u fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) [Such a man is the friend &c. of such a man]: and fulaAnapu SafiY~u fulaAnK and Safiy~atuhu (assumed tropical:) [Such a woman is the friend, &c. of such a man]. (Ham p. 430.) ― -b3- See also SafowN, in two places. ― -b4- Also (tropical:) The portion, of the spoil, which the chief, or commander, chooses for himself before the division; (S, Msb, K, TA;) and so Safiy~apN↓, of which the pl. is SafaAyaA: (S, Msb:) or, accord. to As, SafaAyaA is pl. of SafiY~N, which signifies the portion which the chief chooses for himself, exclusively of his companions, such as the horse, and that which cannot be divided among the army: or, as AO says, the portion which the chief chose for himself, after [taking] the fourth part, such as the she-camel, and the horse, and the sword, and the girl or young woman; and thus it continued to be in the case of El-Islám, but the fourth became reduced to the fifth. (Msb.) ― -b5- Also, applied to a she-camel, (S, M, K,) and to a ewe, or she-goat, (S,) Abounding with milk; (S, M, K;) or so Safiy~apN↓: (Z, TA:) or the former, a she-camel whose milk lasts throughout the year: (IAar, TA in art. $kr:) pl. of the former, (Sb, S, M, K,) or of the latter, (Z, TA,) as above: (Sb, S, M, Z, K:) Sb says that it is not pluralized with A and t because the sing. is without p. (M.) ― -b6- And A palm-tree (naxolapN) abounding with fruit; (M, K;) or so Safiy~apN↓: (Z, TA:) pl. of the former, (TA,) or of the latter, as above. (Z, TA.)

Safiy~apN *
Safiy~apN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

Sufay~apu *
Sufay~apu a name of The first of the days of cold: (K, TA:) so called because the sky therein is clear of clouds. (TA. [See also SafowaAnu.])

SaAfK *
SaAfK Clear, limpid, or pure; free from kadar [or turbidness, &c.]; (Msb;) and so SafiY~N↓, applied to anything. (M.) Applied to pasturage, the former word may mean Clear of dried-up leaves or similar rubbish: or it may be formed by transposition from SaAy^ifN, meaning “ of the [season called] Sayof, ” and so belonging to art. Syf. (M. [See also SaAfK in another sense as formed by transposition from SaAy^ifN, voce SaAfN, in art. Swf.]) In the phrase All~awoni SafaApu↓ applied by the poet Kutheiyir-'Azzeh to honey (janaApu Aln~aHoli), and expl. as meaning Clear in respect of colour, [ISd says,] I think that SfAp is originally Safiyap, as a possessive epithet. (M.) [SaAfK is also applied to a sword, and the like, as meaning Bright, or free from rust.] And in the Kur xxii. 37, [instead of the common reading SawaAf~a, pl. of SaAf~N and SaAf~apN,] some read SawaAfiYa, [pl. of SaAfiyapN, as well as of SaAfK applied to irrational animals,] as meaning that the animals there mentioned are [to be regarded as] things purely [or exclusively] belonging to God. (TA.) ― -b2- See also SafowaAnu. ＝ -A2- Also A certain fish, which [it is said] chews the cud; pl. SawaAfK. (TA.)

SaAfiyapN *
SaAfiyapN [fem. of SaAfK, q. v. ― -b2- And also, as a subst.,] (tropical:) One of what are termed SawaAfiY AlA_imaAmi, which means the towns, or villages, of those who have rebelled against him, which the Imám [or Khaleefeh] chooses for himself [as his peculiar property]: (A, TA:) or, as in the T, AlS~awaAfiY signifies what the Sultán appropriates exclusively to those persons whom he specially favours: or, as some say, it means the possessions and lands which their owners have abandoned, or of which the owners have died leaving no heirs thereof. (TA.)

miSofaApN *
miSofaApN i. q. raAwuwqN; (S, MA, K, TA;) i. e. A strainer; (MA; [thus accord. to modern usage;]) a clarifier; i. e. a thing from which clearing, or clarifying, is effected; called by the vulgar mSfy~ap [i. e. miSofay~ap, and also miSofaAyap]: pl. maSaAfK. (TA.)

EasalN muSaf~FY *
EasalN muSaf~FY [Clarified honey; or] honey cleared of the floating particles, or motes, or the like, that had fallen into it. (TA.)

muSoTafFY *
muSoTafFY: see SafowN, last sentence.

1 Saqiba *
1. Saqiba, (S, K,) aor.
Saqaba
, (K,) inf. n. SaqabN, (M, A, K,) [like saqiba,] He, or it, was, or became, near. (S, M, * A, * K.) You say, Saqibato daAruhu, (S, A,) with kesr [to the q], (S,) inf. n. as above, (S, * A,) His house was near; (S, A;) and (A) so daAruhu A^aSoqabato↓, (M, A, K, TA,) and A^asoqabato. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., (S, A,) AljaAru A^aHaq~u biSaqabihi, (S, A, K,) i. e. [The neighbour has a better, or the best, claim to pre-emption by reason of his being near: see, with respect to this explanation, and other explanations also, what is said of another reading, bisaqabihi, voce saqiba: or has a better, or the best, claim] to close connection, and nearness; meaning pre-emption: (IAmb, O, TA:) or, to what is next to him, and near to him: (A, K, TA:) accord. to some, the meaning is the partner: (O, TA:) or the partner who has not divided with his copartner; this, says Az, being shown to be the meaning by another trad.: (Msb in art. jwr:) or the neighbour whose dwelling is adjoining. (O, TA.) ― -b2- Also He, or it, was, or became, distant, or remote: thus it has two contr. significations. (K.) ＝ -A2- Saqabahu, (K,) inf. n. SaqobN, (M,) He collected it, or gathered it together. (M, K.) ― -b2- And Saqabahu He raised it; namely, a building, &c. (M, O, K.) ― -b3- And Saqabahu, (K,) or Saqaba qafaAhu, (M, TA,) He struck (M, K, TA) him, or it, (K,) or the back of his neck, with his Saqob, (M, TA,) i. e. (TA) with his fist. (K, TA.) [The inf. n.] SaqobN signifies The striking anything solid and dry or tough. (S, TA.) ＝ -A3- Saqaba, (K, TA,) or Sq~b↓, (so in a copy of the M,) said of a bird, It uttered a cry or cries: (M, K:) from Kr. (M, TA.)

2 Saq~aba
2: see what immediately precedes.

3 SAqbhu *
3. SAqbhu He drew near to him: and he faced
him, or met him face to face: (A:) or SaAqabahumo, inf. n. muSaAqabapN and SiqaAbN, he faced them, or met them face to face: (K:) or SaAqabonaAhumo, inf. ns. as above, we drew near to them: and laqiytuhu muSaAqabapF and SiqaAbFA I met him face to face. (M.)

4 A^aSoqabato daAruhu *
4. A^aSoqabato daAruhu: see 1, second sentence. ＝ -A2- ASqbhu He made him, or it, to be near. (S, K.) And ASqb A@ll~`hu daArahu May God make his house to be near. (A.) [And so with s.] ― -b2- And one says, A^aSoqabaka AlS~ayodu The game, or object of the chase, has become near to thee, so that thou art able to shoot, or cast, at it. (K.)

SaqobN *
SaqobN The young one of a camel: (M, L, K:) and so saqobN [q. v.]: (M:) but the latter is the more chaste, and some have rejected the former word: (MF:) pl. SiqaAbN and SuqobaAnN (M, K) [and app. SuquwbN also, like suquwbN,] and [pl. of pauc.] A^aSoqubN. (TA.) ― -b2- And Anything [i. e. any animal] tall, together with plumpness, or with fatness, softness, thinness of the skin, and plumpness; (S, M, K;) and so with s; (M;) as also SaqabN↓. (TA.) Applied to a branch, Juicy, thick, and long. (TA.) ― -b3- And A tent-pole: (M, K:) or the middle tent-pole, which is the longest: (S, M, K:) and so with s: (M:) pl. SuquwbN. (S, M, K.) [See also this pl. below.] ― -b4- And The fist: so in the phrase Darabahu biSaqobihi [expl. above]. (TA.)

SaqabN *
SaqabN [is an inf. n., of Saqiba, as mentioned above: and, used as a simple subst.,] signifies Vicinity, or nearness. (M, A, &c.) Thus in the phrase huwa Saqabaka [lit. He is in thy vicinity; meaning he is near thee]; mentioned by Sb among instances of adv. nouns which he classes apart because of their strangeness. (M.) And one says also, daAriY mino daArihi biSaqabK [lit. My house is in a situation of nearness with respect to his house:] meaning, near [his house]. (TA.) ― -b2- It [is also used as an epithet, and as such] signifies Near: (M, K:) you say makaAnN SaqabN, and saqabN [q. v. voce saAqibN], A near place; (M;) and makaAnN SaAqibN↓ and saAqibN: (A in art. sqb:) and daAruhu SaqabN min~iY [His house is near me]. (A in the present art.) ― -b3- See also SaqobN.

SuquwbN *
SuquwbN a pl. of SaqobN [q. v.]. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- Also The kind legs of camels; a dial. var. of suquwbN: (IAar, M:) the s is changed into S app. because the latter is more agreeable with q. (M.)

SaAqibN *
SaAqibN: see SaqabN.

SayoqabaAniY~N *
SayoqabaAniY~N A seller of perfumes [&c.: for the Arab dealer in perfumes sells a great variety of things, such as drugs, many articles of grocery, and the like]: (O, K:) so called because he collects [somewhat] of everything. (TA.)

A^aSoqabu *
A^aSoqabu [More, and most, near]. One says, h`*aA A^aSoqabu mino h`*aA This is nearer than this: (M: [and the like is said in the A and TA:]) and so A^asoqabu. (M, TA. *)

huwa muSaAqibiY *
huwa muSaAqibiY He is my neighbour: (TA in the present art.:) he is one whose house, or tent, adjoins mine. (TA in art. jwr.)

1 Saqara *
1. Saqara, (S, M, K,) aor.
Saqura
, (M,) inf. n. SaqorN, (S, M,) He broke, (S, K,) or struck, (M,) stones, (S,) or a stone, (M, K,) with a SaAquwr [q. v.]. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- Saqarahu biAlEaSaA, (M, K,) inf. n. as above, (M,) He struck him, or beat him, (M, K,) on his head, (M,) with the staff, or stick. (M, K.) ― -b3- Suqira bihi AlA^aroDu He was thrown, or cast, upon the ground; lit. the ground was struck with him. (O, K. [In some copies of the K, Sqr in this instance and the verb explaining it (Drb) are in the act. form, and AlArD is therefore in the accus. case.]) ― -b4- Saqara Aln~aAra, (M, K,) inf. n. as above; (M;) and Sq~rhA↓, (M, K,) inf. n. taSoqiyrN; (TA;) He lighted, or kindled, the fire; or made it to burn, burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, blaze, or flame. (M, K.) ― -b5- Saqaratohu Al$~amosu, (S, M, A,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) (tropical:) The sun hurt him by its heat: (A:) or pained his brain: (S:) or fell vehemently, with fierce heat, upon him, or upon his head: or was hot upon him. (M, TA.) [See also 1 in art. sqr.] ― -b6- SaqaraniY bikalaAmihi (tropical:) [app. He cursed me, and calumniated me]. (A. [These meanings seem to be there indicated by the context.]) ＝ -A2- Saqara All~abanu The milk was, or became, intensely sour; as also ASqr~↓, inf. n. AiSoqiraArN; (K;) and Samoqara↓, (K in art. Smqr,) and AiSomaqar~a↓. (K in that art and in the present art. also.) ― -b2- [See also SaqorN, below, last explanation but one.]

2 Sq~r Aln~aAra *
2. Sq~r Aln~aAra: see 1. ＝ -A2- Sq~r Alt~amora, (M,) or Alr~uTaba, inf. n. taSoqiyrN, (As, TA,) He poured Saqar [q. v.], (M,) or dibos, [which is the same,] (As,) upon the dates, (M,) or upon the fresh ripe dates. (As.)

4 ASqrt Al$~amosu *
4. ASqrt Al$~amosu (tropical:) The sun was, or became, burning, or fiercely burning; syn. Ait~aqadat; (M, K;) as also AiSomaqar~at↓, (L and K in art. Smqr,) in which the m is augmentative: (L in that art.:) the former is from AStqrt said of fire. (M.)

5 tSq~rt Aln~aAru *
5. tSq~rt Aln~aAru: see 8. ＝ -A2- tSq~r [He hawked;] he hunted with the Saqor. (A, K.) ＝ -A3- And He tarried, stayed, or waited, (K, TA,) in a place. (TA.)

8 AStqrt Aln~aAru * and ASTqrt
8. AStqrt Aln~aAru ASTqrt The fire became lighted or kindle; burned, burned up, burned brightly or fiercely, blazed, or flamed; (M, K;) as also tSq~rt↓. (K.)

9 ASqr~ *
9. ASqr~: see 1, last explanation.

Q. Q. 1 Samoqara *
Q. Q. 1. Samoqara: see 1, last explanation.

Q. Q. 1
Q. Q. 1: Sawoqara He (a bird) uttered the cry termed Sawoqariyr [q. v.]: (K:) reiterated his cry. (TA.)

Q. Q. 4 AiSomaqar~a *
Q. Q. 4. AiSomaqar~a: see 1, last explanation: ― -b2- and see also 4.

SaqorN *
SaqorN [The hawk;] the bird with which one hunts, or catches, game; (S;) whatever preys, or hunts or catches game, of the birds called buziAp [pl. of baAzK] and $awaAhiyn [pl. of $aAhiyn]; (M, A, K;) a kind of bird including the baAziY and the $aAhiyn and the zur~aq and the yuw^oyuw^ and the baA$aq: (AHát, TA in art. b$q:) [like our term “ saker, ” and the French “ sacre, ” &c.:] pl. [of pauc.] A^aSoqurN (M, K) and [of mult.] SuquwrN and SuquwrapN (M, A, K) and SiqaArN and SiqaArapN and SuqurN; (M, K;) the last of which is said by Th to be pl. of SuquwrN, which is pl. of SaqorN, but [ISd says] I hold it to be pl. of SaqorN: the fem. is SaqorapN↓. (M.) ― -b2- [And accord. to Reiske, as mentioned by Freytag, A liberal man: perhaps a noble man, as likened to a hawk.] ＝ -A2- Also, (S, K,) and SaqorapN↓, (S, M, K,) Vehemence of the stroke of the sun, (S, M, K,) and fierceness of its heat: (M:) or the vehemence of its stroke upon the head: (M:) pl. [of the latter] SaqaraAtN. (S, A.) ＝ -A3- Also the former, Sour milk; (K;) [and] so SaqorapN↓: (A:) or milk rendered sour by a stroke of the sun: (Sh:) or milk sour in the utmost degree: (As:) or very sour milk; as also SaqorapN↓: (S:) or this latter is milk that has curdled, and of which the thick part has become separate, and the whey become clear, and that has become sour, so as to be a good kind of sauce. (L.) One says, tazowiY Alwajoha jaA='anaA biSaqorapK↓ [He brought us some sour milk, or very sour milk, &c., such as contracts the face, or makes it to wrinkle: like as one says biSarobapK]. (S, A, L.) ― -b2- Also, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) and SaqorapN↓, (M,) [The exuded, or expressed, juice called] dibos; (S, K;) in the dial. of the people of El-Medeeneh: (S:) or the dibos of dates; (M;) or of fresh ripe dates, (Mgh, Msb,) before it is cooked; i. e. what flows from them, like honey, and what, when it is cooked, is called rub~: (Msb:) or the honey of fresh ripe dates and of raisins; as also SaqarN↓: (K:) or the honey of fresh ripe dates when it has become dry, or tough: or what exudes from grapes, and from raisins, and from dates, without their being pressed; (M;) as also SaqarN↓: (TA:) or, in the dial. of the Bahránees, [or people of El-Bahreyn,] the crude dibos, resembling honey, which flows from baskets of dates when they [i. e. the dates] are deposited and congested, in an uncovered chamber, [so I render bayot muSar~aH, but the meaning of the epithet is not clear,] with green earthen pots beneath them. (AM, TA.) ― -b3- And the former, (SaqorN,) (assumed tropical:) Water that has become altered for the worse in taste and colour. (K, O, TA. [See also muSaq~arN and SaqarapN.]) ＝ -A4- Saqoro also signifies A daAy^irap [or feather, i. e. portion of the hair naturally curled or frizzled in a spiral manner or otherwise,] behind the place of the liver (AO, K, TA) of a horse or similar beast, (K, TA,) on the right and on the left, (TA,) or in the back of a horse: (AO, TA:) there are two such feathers, (AO, K, TA,) which are the limit of the back. (AO, TA.) ＝ -A5- Also, [probably as an inf. n., of which the verb is Saqara,] The acting the part, or performing the office, of a pimp to
[men's] wives, or women under covert. (IAar, M, O, K. [In the CK, AlHarami is erroneously put for AlHurami.]) Hence the epithet Saq~aAr, [as some explain it,] occurring in a trad. [which see below]. (TA.) ― -b2- And A cursing of such as is not deserving [thereof]: pl. SuquwrN and SiqaArN. (K.)

Saqaru *
Saqaru a name of Hell; a dial. var. of saqaru [q. v.]. (K.) ＝ -A2- SaqarN Fallen leaves of the [kind of trees called] EiDaAh, and [particularly] of the EurofuT, (M, K,) and of the salam, and of the TaloH, and of the samur: not so called until they fall. (M.) ＝ -A3- See also SaqorN, in two places.

ruTabN Saqri *
ruTabN Saqri, (S,) or SaqirN maqirN, (M, K,) in which the latter word is an imitative sequent, (K,) Fresh ripe dates containing Saqor: (M, K:) [melliferous:] or proper for dibos [or Saqor]. (S.) ＝ -A2- AimoraA^apN SaqirapN A woman sharp, or acute, of mind, (*akiy~apN, [in the CK, erroneously, zakiy~apN,]) strongsighted. (Sgh, K.)

jaA='a biAlS~uqari waAlbuqari *
jaA='a biAlS~uqari waAlbuqari, (A, K, TA,) and biAlS~uqaAraY↓ waAlbuqaAraY, (K, TA,) (tropical:) He came with lies, and excitements of dissension: (A, TA:) or with sheer lying: (K:) or with sheer, and excessive, or abominable, lying: (TA:) each being a name for that which is unknown: (K, TA:) and in like manner one says jA=' biAl$~uqari waAlbuqari, and biAl$~uqaAraY waAlbuqaAraY; mentioned by IDrd, in the Jm; and by Meyd, in the Collection of Proverbs. (TA in art. bqr.) [See also Har p. 399.]

SaqorapN *
SaqorapN: see SaqorN, in six places.

SaqarapN *
SaqarapN (assumed tropical:) Water remaining in a watering-trough in which dogs and foxes void their urine, (O, K, TA,) altered for the worse in taste and colour. (TA. [See also SaqorN and muSaq~arN.])

SuqorapN *
SuqorapN (assumed tropical:) A colour, of a bird, in which the xuDorap [or dark, or ashy, dust-colour] thereof, or the blackness thereof, is mixed with redness or yel-lowness; as being likened to [the colour of] Saqorap [or Saqor], i. e. dibos: a bird of that colour is termed muSaq~arN↓: so in the book entitled “ Ghareeb el- Hamám, ” by Hoseyn Ibn-'Abd-Allah el-Kátib El-Isbahánee. (TA.)

SaquwrN *
SaquwrN, (so in a copy of the M in two instances, and so in the O in one instance,) or Saq~uwrN↓, (so in the O in another instance, and so accord. to the K, in which latter it is expressly likened to tan~uwrN,) A wittol, or tame cuckold; syn. day~uwvN: (M, K:) or one who acts the part of a pimp to his own wives, or women under covert; as also Saq~aArN↓: (O:) the former epithet occurring in a trad. (M, O.)

SuqaAraY *
SuqaAraY: see jaA='a biAlS~uqari waAlbuqari, above.

Saq~aArN *
Saq~aArN [A falconer, or rearer of hawks. (Golius, from Meyd: and so in the present day.) ＝ -A2- And] i. q. dab~aAsN [A seller of dibos, or Saqor]. (O, K.) ＝ -A3- Also (assumed tropical:) One who is in the habit of cursing (M, O, K) those who are not deserving [of being cursed]: (M, O, K:) and (assumed tropical:) a calumniator: and (assumed tropical:) an unbeliever. (M, O, K.) The Prophet, being asked the meaning of Saq~aArN, (M, TA,) or of saq~aArapN, (T, TA,) or of Saq~aAruwna, (O,) occurring in a trad., said (assumed tropical:) Young people who shall be in the end of time, whose mutual greeting will be mutual cursing. (T, M, O, TA.) See also SaquwrN.

Saq~uwrN *
Saq~uwrN: see SaquwrN.

SaAqirN *
SaAqirN, applied to a Saqor [or hawk] Sharp-sighted. (K.)

SawoqarN *
SawoqarN: see SaAquwrN.

SaAqirapN *
SaAqirapN A calamity, (M, K,) or a vehement calamity, (O,) befalling. (M, K.)

SaAquwrN *
SaAquwrN [A pickaxe;] a large faA^os (AA, S, M, K) with one slender head, with which stones are broken; (AA, S, M;) i. q. miEowalN; (AA, S, A;) and SawoqarN↓ signifies the same; (M, K;) [but] this latter is expl. by IDrd as meaning a thick faA^os with which stones are broken. (TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) The tongue. (M, K.) ― -b3- See also what next follows.

SaAquwrapN *
SaAquwrapN The inner side of the cranium, over the brain, (M, K, TA,) as though it were the bottom of a bowl: in the T said to be termed SaAquwrN↓. (TA.) ― -b2- And SaAquwrapu, (M,) and AlS~aAquwrapu, (M, K,) a name of (assumed tropical:) The Third Heaven. (M, K.)

SawoqariyrN *
SawoqariyrN A cry of a bird, (M, K,) with a reiteration, (M,) resembling the sound of this word. (M, K.)

A^aSoqaru *
A^aSoqaru in the following saying, (M,) h`*aA Alt~amoru A^aSoqaru mino h`*aA These dates have more Saqor than these, (AHn, M, K,) has no verb. (M.)

muSoqar~N *
muSoqar~N Milk that is sour and disagreeable: (Ibn-Buzurj, TA:) and muSomaqir~N↓ signifies milk intensely sour. (TA in art. Smqr.)

ruTabN muSaq~arN *
ruTabN muSaq~arN Fresh ripe dates, (A,) or fresh ripe dates that have become dry, (S,) upon which is poured dibos (S, A) of ripe dates, (A,) in order that they may become soft: and sometimes it occurs with s; for they often change S into s when there is in the word q or T or g or x; as in buSaAqN and SiraATN and SudogN and SamaAxN: (S:) or excellent fresh ripe dates, picked from the raceme, which are put into [earthen vessels of the kind called] basaAtiyq [pl. of busotuwqapN (in the TA erroneously written basaAtiyn)], and upon which Saqor is poured: they remain moist and good all the year. (AHn, L.) ― -b2- And maA='N muSaq~arN (assumed tropical:) Water altered for the worse [in colour, as though Saqor, i. e. dibos had been mixed with it]. (M. [See also SaqorN and SaqarapN.]) ― -b3- And TaAy^irN muSaq~arN (assumed tropical:) A bird of the colour termed, SuqorapN, q. v. (TA.)

muSaq~irN *
muSaq~irN One who hunts with hawks. (A, * TA.)

muSomaqir~N *
muSomaqir~N A day intensely hot: the two m in this word are augmentative. (TA.) ― -b2- See also muSoqar~N.

1 SaqaEahu *
1. SaqaEahu, (S, Mgh, O, K,) aor.
SaqaEa
, (O, Mgh, K,) inf. n. SaqoEN, (O,) He struck him, or beat him: (K:) or he struck [or slapped] him with his expanded hand: (TA:) [like SafaEahu:] or, (S, Mgh, O, K,) as also SawoqaEahu↓, (O, K,) he struck him (S, Mgh, O, K) upon his head, (O, K,) or upon his SawoqaEap, (S, O,) [i. e.] upon the top of his head: (Mgh:) this last is the primary signification: and hence, metaphorically, he struck him, or beat him, in an unrestricted sense: (Mgh, * O, TA:) and he struck it, namely, a dry, or tough, and solid thing, with a similar thing; as, for instance, a stone with a stone, and the like: or, as some say, he struck it, namely, anything dry, or tough. (TA.) It is said in a trad., respecting Munkidh, SuqiEa A=m~apF i. e. He was struck on the top of his head: (O:) or he had his head broken so that the wound reached the membrane over his brain. (TA.) ― -b2- One says also, SaqaEa bihi AlA^aroDa (O, K) He threw him down, or prostrated him, on the ground; (K;) [lit.] he smote the ground with him. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.) ― -b3- And SaqaEatohu AlS~aAqiEapu i. q. SaEaqatohu AlS~aAEiqapu, (S, O, K,) The thunderbolt smote him. (TA.) And SuqiEa He was smitten by a thunderbolt; i. q. SuEiqa; of the dial. of Temeem: (O:) and so SaqiEa; (K, TA;) like SaEiqa. (TA.) ― -b4- And SaqaEahu bikaY~K He branded him, or marked him by cauterizing, upon his head, [or his SawoqaEap,] or his face. (O, K.) ― -b5- And SaqaEa Alv~ariydapa, aor. and inf. n. as above, He ate the vrydp [or mess of crumbled bread with broth] from its SawoqaEap [or top, or upper part, or hollow made therein]. (TA. [See also Q. Q. 1.]) ＝ -A2- SaqoEN also signifies The raising of the voice: (O, TA:) and the uttering it by consecutive emissions. (TA.) You say, SaqaEa biSawotihi He raised his voice. (TA.) And hence, (TA,) SaqaEa said of a cock, (S, O, K,) aor.
SaqaEa
, (O,) inf. n. SaqoEN and SuqaAEN (IDrd, O, K) and SaqiyEN, (K,) He [crowed, or] uttered a cry: (IDrd, S, O, K:) and so saqaEa. (S.) ― -b2- And, accord. to IAar, The being eloquent in speech, and lighting upon the [proper] meanings. (TA.) ― -b3- SaqaEa biDaroTapK, said of an ass, He emitted a sounding wind from the anus, in a moist and dispersed state. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) ― -b4- SaqaEa Albayota He attached to the tent the rope called SiqaAE [q. v.]. (Az, O, TA.) ― -b5- And SaqaEa, (S, O, K,) said of a man, (K,) He went away, (S, O, K, TA,) fiY kul~i Aln~awaAHiY [in all directions]: (TA:) one says, maA A^adoriY A^ayona SaqaEa, (S, O, TA, [but in the second, laA is put in the place of maA,]) and baqaEa, (TA,) meaning I know not whither he went away: (O, TA:) and the verb is seldom used in this sense without the particle of negation. (TA.) Or it signifies, (K,) or signifies also, (O,) or so SaqiEa, (S, TA,) like fariHa, not SaqaEa, (TA,) He deviated from the way, (S, O, K, TA,) and alighted, or descended and abode, alone, by himself: (TA:) or he deviated from the way of goodness and generosity. (IF, O, K, TA.) And SaqoEN signifies The going astray; losing one's way; or becoming lost; and perishing;
or dying. (TA. [But I think that this is probably a mistranscription for SaqaEN, inf. n. of SaqiEa.]) You say also, SaqiEa fulaAnN naHowa ka*aA Such a one repaired towards such a thing. (TA.) ― -b6- And SaqiEati Albiy^oru, aor.
SaqaEa
, (A'Obeyd, S,) inf. n. SaqaEN, The well collapsed; or broke down. (A'Obeyd, S, K. *) ＝ -A3- SaqiEato, (TA,) inf. n. SaqaEN, (O, K, TA,) said of horses, and of birds, &c., They became white (O, K, TA) in the [SawoqaEap, or] uppermost part of the head, (TA,) or in the middle of the head. (O, K.) ― -b2- And [the inf. n.] SaqaEN, in relation to the head, signifies The being bald: or, as some say, the going away of the hair. (TA.) ＝ -A4- SuqiEati AlA^aroDu The earth, or ground, became overspread with the SaqiyE [i. e. hoarfrost, or rime]; (S, O, Msb, K;) as also A^uSoqiEat↓; each with damm. (IDrd, K.)

2 Sq~E lahu *
2. Sq~E lahu, inf. n. taSoqiyEN, He swore to him respecting a thing: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) and so bq~E lh, inf. n. taboqiyEN. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)

4 ASqE *
4. ASqE He (a man, O, TA) entered upon [a time, or a tract, of] SaqiyE [i. e. hoar-frost, or rime]. (IDrd, O, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- And ASqE AlS~aqiyEu AlA^aroDa, (K, TA,) and Al$~ajara, (O, TA,) The SqyE [or hoar-frost] fell, or lighted, upon the earth, or ground, (K, * TA,) and the trees. (O, TA.) And A^uSoqiEati AlA^aroDu: see 1, last sentence. And A^uSoqiEa Aln~aAsu The men, or people, became overspread with the SaqiyE. (TA.)

Q. Q. 1 SawoqaEahu *
Q. Q. 1. SawoqaEahu: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- SawoqaEa Alv~ariydapa He spread evenly the vrydp [or mess of crumbled bread moistened with broth]. (TA.)

SuqoEN *
SuqoEN A district, quarter, or tract, syn. naAHiyapN, (S, O, Msb, K,) of a country: (Msb:) and a place, region, quarter, tract, or point, towards which a person, or thing, goes, tends, or is directed; syn. jihapN: and a place of alighting, or of descending and stopping or sojourning or abiding or lodging or settling; or a place of abode or settlement; syn. maHal~apN: (Msb:) pl. [of pauc.] A^aSoqaAEN, (O, TA,) and pl. pl. A^aSaAqiEu: (TA:) and SuqogN is a dial. var. thereof. (IJ, TA; and K in art. Sqg.) One says, fulaAnN mino A^aholi h`*aA AlS~uqoEi i. e. mino h`*ihi Aln~aAHiyapi [Such a one is of the people of this district, &c.]. (S, O.) And huwa fiY SuqoEi baniY fulaAnK He is in the naAHiyap [or district, &c.], and the maHal~ap [or place of alighting, &c.], of the sons of such a one. (Msb.) See also miSoqaEN. ― -b2- Also A part, or portion, of the surrounding and inferior sides of a well: pl. A^aSoqaAEN: but the more approved word is with s. (TA.)

SaqaEN *
SaqaEN inf. n. of SaqiEa. (S, &c.) ― -b2- Also An affection like gam~N, [i. e.] that takes away the breath, (yaA^oxu*u biAln~afasi, S, O, K, [in the CK, bAln~afosi,]) by reason of the vehemence of the heat. (S, O, K.)

SaqiEN *
SaqiEN [Smitten by a thunderbolt: (see its verb, SaqiEa:) or] smitten as by a thunderbolt from the enemy: so accord. to some: (O, TA:) 'Ows Ibn-Hajar says,
A^abaA dulayojapa mano liHaY~K muforadK
SaqiEK mina AlA^aEodaA='i fiY $aw~aAli
(S, * O, TA, but in the TA A^aAabaA) [which may be rendered O Aboo-Duleyjeh, who is for a solitary tribe, smitten as though by a thunderbolt from the enemies, in Showwál (which was, in the time of the poet, a cold month)?]: or, accord. to IAar, the meaning here is, in a state of retirement, remote from the enemies; (S, * O;) for when the winter pressed severely upon the man, he used to retire to a distance, lest a guest should alight at his abode; the enemies being the strange guests; and by saying fY $w~Al, he means that the cold was in Showwál: (O, TA:) or SaqiEN means absent and remote, so that one knows not where he is: or that has gone away, and alighted alone, or by himself: (TA:) [pl. SaqoEaY:] see an ex. voce daqiEN. ＝ -A2- A^aroDN SaqiEapN, (TA,) and maSoquwEapN↓, Earth, or ground, overspread with the SaqiyE [i. e. hoarfrost, or rime]: (S, Msb, TA:) and in like manner, $ajarN SaqiEN, and muSoqaEN↓, trees overspread with the SaqiyE. (TA.)

SaqoEapN *
SaqoEapN Intenseness of cold; from AlS~aqiyEu [meaning “ hoar-frost, ” or “ rime ”]. (TA.)

SuqoEapN *
SuqoEapN A whiteness in the middle of the head of a horse and of a bird &c.; (S, O, K;) or in the middle of the head of a black sheep or goat, accord. to Abu-l-Wázi'. (TA.)

SaqoEaAn *
SaqoEaAn Stupid, dull, or wanting in intelligence: but this is a vulgar word. (TA.)

SaqaEiY~N *
SaqaEiY~N The first increase, or offspring, (nitaAj,) [of sheep, or goats,] when the sun smites (taSoqaEu) the heads of the lambs or kids: (Aboo-Nasr, O, K: [in the CK, Albuhomi is erroneously put for Albahomi:]) and some of the Arabs call it the $amosiY~, and the qayoZiY~: then is the SafariY~, after the SaqaEiY~: (Aboo-Nasr, TA:) it is also expl. as signifying such as is brought forth in the [period called] Safariy~ap: (TA: [but see SafariY~N:]) and, (O, K,) accord. to AZ, (O,) the young camel that is brought forth in [the time of] the SaqiyE [i. e. hoar-frost, or rime]; which is of the best of the increase [of camels]. (O, K.)

SiqaAEN *
SiqaAEN A piece of rag with which a woman protects her ximaAr [or muffler] from the oil [in her hair], (S, O, K, TA,) putting it on her head; (TA;) as also SawoqaEapN↓: (K:) or this latter signifies a thing by which the head is protected, such as a turban and a ximaAr and a ridaA='. (TA.) ― -b2- And The [woman's face-veil termed] buroquE (S, O, K) is sometimes thus called. (S, O.) ― -b3- And A thing with which a she-camel's nose is bound, (S, O, K, TA,) as expl. in art. drj [voce durojapN], (S,) when they desire her to affect her young one or the young one of another: or, accord. to A'Obeyd, a piece of rag with which her eyes are bound; that with which her nose is bound, [or stopped, (see 1 in art. ZA^r)] when she is made to affect a young one not her own, being termed gimaAmapN. (TA. [But see durojapN.]) ― -b4- And A mark made with a hot iron upon the qa*aAl [or back of the head] of a camel. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) ― -b5- And An iron thing that is in the place of [the kind of curb called] the Hakamap of the bit. (O, K.) ― -b6- And A thing that is next to the head of the horse, beneath (duwna) the larger buroquE. (TA.) ― -b7- The SiqaAE of a tent (xibaA=') is A rope that is extended from its top, and pulled tight, the two ends of which are tied to two pegs, or stakes, stuck into the ground, when the wind is violent and it is feared that the tent may be thrown down. (O, TA.)

SaqiyEN *
SaqiyEN The jaliyd [i. e. hoar-frost, or rime,] that nips, or blasts, (lit. burns, [see A^aHoraqa,]) the plants, or herbage; (Msb;) what falls from the sky in the night, resembling snow. (S, O, K.) ＝ -A2- Also A species of zunobuwr [or hornet]: (O, K:) so says AHát, as having been heard by him from a man of Et-Táïf. (O.)

SaAqiEN *
SaAqiEN [Deviating from the truth; as is indicated in the TA: and hence,] a liar: (TA:) one says, Saho SaAqiEu i. e. Be silent, O liar. (Yoo, O, K.)

SaAqiEapN *
SaAqiEapN i. q. SaAEiqapN [i. e. A thunderbolt]: (Fr, S, O, K:) of the dial. of Temeem: pl. SawaAqiEu. (TA.) [See also SaAEiqapN.]

SawoqaEapN *
SawoqaEapN The place of the whiteness termed SuqoEap in the head of a horse and of a bird &c.: (S:) or the middle of the head [in an absolute sense]: (O, K:) or the top, or uppermost part, [of the head, or] of the [cap called] kum~ap, and of the turban. (O, K, TA: all in art. SfE.
