[See 1 in that art., where this last meaning is assigned to SawofaEapN.]) ― -b2- And A turban [itself]: (O, K:) and any other thing that protects the head: (TA;) accord. to IDrd, a piece of rag which a woman puts upon her head as a protection. (O. See SiqaAEN, first sentence.) ― -b3- A piece of rag which is tied upon the top of the [kind of women's camel-vehicle called] huwodaj, and which the wind blows about. (TA.) ― -b4- The head [or top] of the [woman's face-veil called] buroquE. (IAar, TA in this art. and voce $ibaAmN [q. v.].) ― -b5- The hollow (waqobap) [that is made in the upper part of a dish] of variyd [or crumbled bread moistened with broth]: (S, O, K, TA:) or the top, or upper part, of variyd. (TA.) ― -b6- Also The place of a battle in which is much smiting. (IDrd, O, K.)

A^aSoqaEu *
A^aSoqaEu, applied to a horse, and a bird, &c., Having a whiteness in the middle of the head: (S, O, K:) or a horse white in the top of his head: (Mgh:) fem. SaqoEaA='u, (S, O, K,) applied to an eagle (EuqaAb), (S, O, TA,) and to a female ostrich [&c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- AlA^aSoqaEu A certain bird, resembling the EuSofuwr [or sparrow], in the feathers and head of which is a whiteness, found near water; mentioned [in the K] in art. sqE [as with s in the place of S]: (TA:) accord. to Ktr, (O, TA,)
the bird called AlS~ufaAriyapu [q. v.]: (O, K, TA:) you may form its pl. after the manner of substs. [i. e. saying A^aSaAqiEu], because it is an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates; or after the manner of the epithet [i. e. saying SuqoEN]. (TA.) ― -b3- Accord. to AHát, AlS~aqoEaA='u signifies A [bird such as is termed] dux~alap [q. v.], of a dingy colour, small, with a yellow head, short in the zimik~aY [or tail] and the legs and the neck: (TA:) or, accord. to him, the SaqoEaA=' with a yellowness is a dux~alap of a dingy yellow colour, small, short in the zimik~aY and the legs and the neck: and all dux~al are with the Arabs of the [birds termed] EaSaAfiyr and Hum~ar: but the SaqoEaA=' with a blackness is a dux~alap of a dingy reddish colour, black in the head, and short in the zimik~aY and the neck. (O.) ― -b4- AlA^aSoqaEu also signifies The forelock of a horse: or the white forelock thereof. (TA.) ― -b5- And AlS~aqoEaA='u, The sun. (S, O, K.)

maSoqaEN *
maSoqaEN A place towards which one tends, repairs, or betakes himself. (TA.)

muSoqaEN *
muSoqaEN: see SaqiEN, last sentence.

xaTiybN miSoqaEN *
xaTiybN miSoqaEN An eloquent speaker or orator or preacher: (S, O, K:) or one loud in voice: (K:) or one who is not impeded in his speech, and who does not reiterate in speech by reason of inability to say what he would, or is not unable to find words to express what he would say: (Katádeh, O, K:) or one who is skilful, and penetrating, or effective, in his speech: (O:) or one who goes into every SuqoE↓, i. e. naAHiyap, [meaning province,] of speech: (TA in this art. and in art. rqE:) [said to be] from AlS~aqoEu meaning “ the raising of the voice; ” (O, TA; *) or from AlS~uqoEu [expl. above]; or, as some say, from SaqaEahu meaning “ he struck him upon his SawoqaEap; ” but this last derivation is far-fetched: (TA:) pl. maSaAqiEu. (O, TA.)

A^aroDN maSoquwEapN *
A^aroDN maSoquwEapN: see SaqiEN, last sentence.

1 Saqalahu *
1. Saqalahu, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) aor.
Saqula
, (M, Msb,) inf. n. SaqolN (S, M, O, Msb) and SiqaAlN, (S, O, Msb,) or the latter is a simple subst., (M, K,) He polished it: (S, M, O, Msb, K;) i. e. a thing, (M,) or a sword, (S, O, Msb,) and the like: (Msb:) and so saqalahu. (S.) ― -b2- Saqala Aln~aAqapa (assumed tropical:) He (a man, AA, O) made the she-camel lean, or light of flesh: (AA, O, K:) and in like manner it is said of journeying: (AA, O:) and in like manner also, Alfarasa the horse: (Sh, TA:) or this means he tended the horse well, with the coverings for protection from cold, and with fodder, and took good care of him. (TA. [See SiqaAlN, below.]) ― -b3- Saqalahu biAlEaSaA (tropical:) He struck him, or beat him, with the staff, or stick, (Z, O, K, TA,) and disciplined him. (Z, TA.) ― -b4- And Saqala bihi AlA^aroDa (assumed tropical:) He flung him upon the ground (lit. smote the ground with him). (Aboo-Turáb, O, K.) ＝ -A2- Saqili, aor.
Saqala
, inf. n. SaqalN, It (a thing, such as iron, and copper,) was smooth, solid, and impenetrable to water. (Msb.) ＝ -A3- And Saqila, inf. n. SaqalN, He (a man) differed, or varied, in his gait, or manner of walking. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)

SaqolN *
SaqolN, (so in a copy of the M,) or SuqolN↓ (K,) [the former, if correct, perhaps a contraction, by poetic license, of SaqilN, for which it is not a mistranscription, as is shown by a verse cited as an ex. of it in the M,] Light, or active; applied to a beast (daAb~ap). (M, K.)

SuqolN *
SuqolN The xaASirap [or flank]; as also SuqolapN↓: (S, M, O, K: [in the CK, erroneously, Saqolap:]) the former, in this sense, said by AA to be from Saqala Aln~aAqapa: (TA:) seldom is the Suqolap of a horse long except his sides be short, which is a fault: (S, O:) and the SuqolaAni are the qurobaAni [by which may be meant either the two flanks or the two portions between the groin and the armpit on each side] of a daAb~ap [i. e. horse or similar beast] &c. (M.) And The janob [or side]. (M, K.) HumurN zaHaAlifu AlS~uqoli means Asses having smooth and fat bellies. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA in art. zHlf.) ― -b2- And i. q. naAHiyapN [meaning A district, quarter, tract, &c.]: (O, TA:) so in the saying, A^anota fiY SuqolK xaAlK [Thou art in a vacant district &c.]; like SuqoEK xaAlK. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also SaqolN.

SaqalN *
SaqalN Length of the flanks; in a horse: (S, O:) or depression (AinohiDaAm) of the flank. (M.)

SaqilN *
SaqilN A horse long in the flanks: (S, O:) or long in the flanks and short in the sides: (AO, TA: [see SuqolN:]) and (O) having little flesh, (O, K, TA,) whether long or short, (O, K,) or whether long in the flank or short. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, applied to a man, (Ibn-'Abbád, O,) Differing, or varying, in his gait; or manner of walking. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

SuqolapN *
SuqolapN: see SuqolN. ― -b2- Also Leanness, or lankness in the belly, and slenderness. (TA.)

SiqaAlN *
SiqaAlN an inf. n. of Saqalahu, (S, O, Msb,) or a simple subst. (M, K.) [See 1, first sentence.] ― -b2- SiqaAlu Alfarasi (assumed tropical:) The tending of the horse well, taking good care of him, supplying him with fodder and fattening him. (S, * M, O, * K.) One says, Alfarasu fiY SiqaAlihi [The horse is in his state of good tending and feeding]. (S, O.) [See also 1, second sentence]. ＝ -A2- Also The belly. (K.)

SaqiylN *
SaqiylN A thing, (M,) or a sword, (Msb,) [and the like,] Polished; as also maSoquwlN↓. (M, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And A thing, such as iron, and copper, smooth, solid, and impenetrable to water. (Msb.) ― -b3- [Also, as a subst., implying the meaning of an epithet,] A sword. (S, TA.)

Saq~aAlN *
Saq~aAlN: see SayoqalN.

SaAqilN *
SaAqilN Polishing: pl. SaqalapN. (S, M, Msb, K.)

SayoqalN *
SayoqalN One who practises the art of polishing (S, M, O, Msb, K) and sharpening (M, K) swords (S, M, O, Msb, K) and the like: (Msb:) [commonly called in the present day Saq~aAl↓:] pl. SayaAqilapN (S, M, O, Msb, K) and SayaAqiylu: (so in a copy of the M:) the p in the former pl. is affixed irregularly, as in malaAy^ikapN and qa$aAEimapN. (M.)

miSoqalN *
miSoqalN: see the next paragraph. ＝ -A2- Also, applied to a speaker, an orator, or a preacher, i. q. miSolaqN, (M, K,) used by a poet in the sense of the latter word, i. e. as meaning Eloquent. (Th, M.)

miSoqalapN *
miSoqalapN (S, M, O, K, KL) and miSoqalN↓ (KL) An instrument, (S, M, O, KL,) or a xarazap [which may here mean either a bead-shaped stone or a shell], (K,) with which one polishes (S, M, O, K, KL) a sword (S, O, KL, TA) and the like, (S, TA,) a knife, (KL,) a mirror, a garment, or piece of cloth, and paper. (TA.)

maSoquwlN *
maSoquwlN: see SaqiylN. ― -b2- maSoquwlu AlkisaA='i means (assumed tropical:) Milk overspread with a pellicle: (O, * TA:) a rájiz says,
fahowa A_i*aA maA A@hotaAfa A^awo tahay~afaA
yuboqiY Ald~uwaAyaAti A_i*aA tara$~afaA
Eano kul~i maSoquwli AlkisaA='i qado SafaA
[And he, when he thirsts, or experiences the hot south-west wind (Alhayof), leaves only the pellicles when he sucks in with his lips from every quantity of milk overspread with a pellicle, that has become clear]: accord. to As, it means the froth of milk: (TA:) IAar explained it accord. to its apparent signification, as used in a verse of 'Amr Ibn-ElAhtam El-Minkaree, (O, TA,) i. e. as meaning a [glossy] red kisaA='; [a sense not indicated by that verse, and clearly inconsistent with the ex. cited above;] and when told how As had explained it, replied that, when he had said it, he was ashamed to retract it. (TA.)

1 Sak~ahu *
1. Sak~ahu, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
Saku3a
, (TA,) inf. n. Sak~N, (Mgh, * Msb, TA,) He struck him, or it: (S, Mgh, O:) or he struck him, or it, vehemently, with a broad thing; or in a general sense, (K, TA,) with anything whatever: (TA:) or he slapped him with his hand, i. e. struck him with his expanded hand, (Msb,) like laTamahu, (TA in art. lTv, &c.,) upon the back of his neck, and upon his face. (Msb.) Hence, in the Kur [li. 29], faSak~ato wajohahaA (S, TA) And she slapped her face with her hand; syn. laTamatohu. (Jel.) And Sak~a AlbaAziY Sayodahu The hawk, or falcon, struck his prey with his foot, and so cast it down. (Ham p. 799.) And [hence, app.,] one says, xu*o h`*aA A^aw~ala Sak~K, meaning A^aw~ala maA A^aSuk~u bihi [Take thou this on my first striking with it]: and so A^aw~ala SawokK (O, TA.) ― -b2- Also He pushed him, or thrust him; (As, TA;) like dak~ahu and lak~ahu. (TA in art. dk.) ― -b3- And Sak~a AlbaAba He shut, or closed the door: (S, O, Msb, K:) or he locked the door. (Lth, O, K.) ＝ -A2- And Sak~a, aor. and inf. n. as above, He wrote what is termed a Sak~ [expl. below]. (Msb.) ＝ -A3- Sakikota, (S, O, K,) like malilota, (K,) third pers. Sakka, (MA, in which it is mentioned
as said of an ass,) [and it is also implied in the TA that the third pers. is Sakika, like laHiHato said of the eye, and some other instances, which are extr.,] a verb of the class of taEiba, (Msb,) inf. n. SakakN, (S, Mgh, * O, Msb, K, TA,) [in the CK SakiykFA is erroneously put for SakakFA, and it seems from what follows that Sak~N is also an inf. n. like SakakN,] Thou wast knock-kneed: (S, O, Msb:) or thou hadst a colliding (AiDoTiraAb) of the knees, and [when used in relation to an ostrich or a horse or the like] of the EuroquwbaAni [which evidently means here, as in many other instances, the hocks]: (K:) [for] the verb is used in relation to a man, (S, O, K, TA,) and to other than man: (TA: [and the same is implied in the S and O, as is shown voce A^aSak~u:]) SakakN [sometimes particularly] signifies the colliding of the knees [or of the hocks] in running, so that it makes a mark, or scar, upon each of them: (TA:) [and it is said that] this word, (Mgh,) or Sak~N, (TA, [perhaps a mistranscription for SakakN,]) signifies the colliding of the EuroquwbaAni. (Mgh, TA.)

3 SAk~hu *
3. SAk~hu [He struck him, or it; or struck him, or it, vehemently, with a broad thing, or with anything; or slapped him with his hand; being struck, &c., by him]. (Ham p. 313.)

8 AiSoTak~aA *
8. AiSoTak~aA They (two men, O, TA, and two bodies, TA) struck each other. (O, TA.) One says, taSoTak~u rukobataAhu [His two knees collide, or knock together]. (S, O, Msb. *) And AiSoTak~uwA biAls~uyuwfi They struck one another with the swords. (TA.)

Sak~N *
Sak~N inf. n. of Sak~a. (Mgh, * Msb, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also a Pers. word (S, O) arabicized, (S, Mgh, O, TA,) A certain writing, (S, O, K, *) called in Pers. jak, (O,) or Jako; (TA;) a debenture, or written acknowledgement of a debt (Mgh, Msb) of money or property, or of some other thing: (Mgh:) and a written statement of a commercial transaction, purchase or sale, transfer, bargain, contract, or the like: (Msb, TA:) i. q. sijil~N [in this last sense or in the senses next following]: (S and TA in art. sjl:) a sijil~ of a qaADiY [i. e. a sealed, or signed and sealed, statement of a judicial decision; a judicial record; or the record of a judge, in which his sentence is written]: (KL:) and a written order for the payment of subsistence-money, or of a stipend, salary, pension, or allowance; which some persons used to sell, but the selling of which is forbidden: (Msb, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^aSuk~N and [of mult.] SikaAkN and SukuwkN. (S, O, Msb, K.) [Hence,] layolapu AlS~ak~i The night of the middle [of the month] of Shaa- bán; because in it are written the SikaAk of the allowances of subsistence [of individuals]: also called layolapu AlbaraA='api. (O, TA.) [Hence also] Sak~u AlmusaAfiri The traveller's pass, given him to prevent any one's offering opposition to him. (A and Mgh in art. jwz.)

Sak~apN *
Sak~apN The vehemence of the midday-heat in summer: (K:) or the most vehement heat of midday in summer: (S:) and it is prefixed to EumaY~: (K:) one says, laqiyutuh Sak~apa EumaY~K, (S, O,) a prov., meaning I met him in the most vehement heat of midday in summer when the heat almost blinded by its vehemence: (Lh, O, TA:) for EumaY~ is said to be an abbreviated dim. of A^aEomaY: (S, O, TA:) and by it is said to be meant the gazelle, because he is dazzled and confounded in the midday-heats of summer, and knocks against the thing that is before him: some say, Sak~apa HumaY~K, from Hamiyati Al$~amosu: and some assert that EumaY~ means the heat, itself: (O, TA:) or it is the name of a certain man [as will be found expl. in art. EmY, with variations of this saying]. (S, O, K, TA.)

SukaAkN *
SukaAkN The air [or atmosphere, between heaven and earth]; like sukaAkN; (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K;) a dial. var. of the latter word. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.)

SakiykN *
SakiykN Weak: (IAmb, Hr, K, TA:) of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN; [lit.] meaning one who is struck much, or often, because deemed weak. (TA.)

Sak~aAkN *
Sak~aAkN [A writer of the statements termed SikaAk, pl. of Sak~N: or, accord. to Golius, as on the authority of Meyd, an actuary, who commits to writing the sentences of the judge].

A^aSak~u *
A^aSak~u Knock-kneed: (S, O, Msb:) or having a colliding (AiDoTiraAb) of the knees, and [when used in relation to an ostrich or a horse or the like] of the EuroquwbaAni [which evidently means here, as in many other instances, the hocks]; as also miSak~N↓; (K;) which latter [in this sense is rare, and is written in the CK maSak~N, but] is with kesr to the m: (TA:) thus applied to a man; (S, O, K, TA;) and to other than man; (TA;) [i. e.] applied also to a horse; (O;) and to an ostrich, because he is long in step, long-legged, and sometimes, or often, his rukobataAni [here improperly used as meaning “ hocks ”] being near together, his legs strike each other: (S, O:) and a man is also said to be A^aSak~u Alr~ijolayoni: (TA:) the fem. is Sak~aA='u: (Mgh, Msb:) and the pl. is Suk~N. (TA.) ― -b2- Also One whose teeth, both the A^asonaAn and the A^aDoraAs, cleave close together: like A^alaS~u. (Az, TA.) ― -b3- See also the next paragraph.

miSak~N *
miSak~N Strong: (S, O, K;) applied to a man; and to other than man; (K;) [i. e.] applied to a camel, and to an ass, (S, O,) as in a verse cited in the last paragraph of art. shr; (O;) and A^aSak~u↓ signifies the same: (K:) the fem. of the former is with p; (S, O, TA;) which is held by Sb to be rare; for epithets of the measures mifoEalN and mifoEaAlN seldom have p affixed to denote the fem. (TA.) ― -b2- One says also raA^osN miSak~N lilr~uw^uwsi [app. meaning A head strong to butt, or knock, against other heads]. (K in art. rA^s.) ― -b3- See also A^aSak~u. ＝ -A2- Also A lock; syn. migolaAqN. (K.)

muSak~akN *
muSak~akN: see what follows.

maSokuwkN *
maSokuwkN and muSak~akN↓ are epithets applied to a camel, [app. as meaning Fleshy;] as though flesh were thrust (Suk~a, i. e. $uk~a,) into him. (O.)

1 Sakamahu *
1. Sakamahu, (S, K,) [aor.
Sakuma
,] inf. n. SakomN, (TA,) He (a man, Fr, S) struck him, or it. (Fr, S, K.) See also SawaAkimu. ― -b2- And He (a man, Fr, As, S) pushed, thrust, or repelled, him, or it. (Fr, As, S, K.) ― -b3- And one says of a horse, yaSokumu, (S,) or Sakama EalaY lijaAmihi, (K,) or EalaY faA^osi All~ijaAmi, (TA,) The horse champs, (S,) or champed, (K,) his bit, (S, K,) or the fA^s of the bit, (TA,) and stretches forth his head, (S,) or then stretched forth his head, as though desiring to contend for superiority [with his rider]. (K.)

SakomapN *
SakomapN A vehement shock, collision, impetus, push, or thrust, (Lth, S, K, TA,) with a stone or some other thing. (Lth, TA.)

Suk~amN *
Suk~amN i. q. A^axofaAfN [which means Camels' feet, and boots; probably, here, the former: in the TK it is expl. as meaning the hoofs of camels: and it is there said that the sing. is SaAkimN]. (K.)

SawaAkimu *
SawaAkimu Calamities, misfortunes, or evil accidents. (K.) The Arabs say, SawaAkimu Ald~ahori Sakamatohu↓ [The calamities of fortune smote him; or may the calamities of fortune smite him]. (S.)

1 Sal~a *
1. Sal~a, aor. yaSil~u, inf. n. SaliylN, It sounded; or made, produced, emitted, or sent forth, a sound; (S, M, O, K;) as also SaloSala↓, inf. n. SaloSalapN and muSaloSalN, (M, K, [in the CK SaloSalFA is erroneously put for muSaloSalFA,]) or muSaloSalN may be a n. of place; (M;) and SaloSalapN [sometimes, or always, implies repetition, as will be shown by what follows, or], accord. to Lth, is more intensive, or more vehement, than SaliylN: (TA:) the former verb is said of iron [when struck with iron or the like, (see Ham p. 353, and what here follows,) meaning it made a clashing, or a ringing, sound], as also SaloSala↓; (TA;) of a nail &c., (S, O,) of a nail when struck so that it is forced to enter into a thing, (M, K,) as in a verse of Lebeed cited in art. Hkm, conj. 4; (S, M, O;) of helmets of iron (bayoD) when struck with swords, meaning they made a ringing sound; (M, K; *) [see an ex. of the inf. n. voce raEodN;] also of an empty jar when it is struck; (TA;) and of any dry clay, or baked pottery: (M:) also of a lijaAm [i. e. bit], meaning it made a prolonged sound; (M, K;) and SaloSala↓, (M, K,) inf. n. SaloSalapN, (S,) said of the same, (S, M, * K, *) it made repeated sounds, (S, M, K,) and so taSaloSala↓; (M, K;) which last is also said of a woman's, or other, ornament, meaning it made a [tinkling, or ringing,] sound; (S, K;) and of clay mixed with sand when it has become dry [app. as meaning it made a crackling sound when trodden upon]; (S;) mention is also made, in a trad., of the SaloSalap↓ [i. e. ringing, or tinkling,] or a bell; (K;) and
[its verb] SaloSala is said of anything dry [as meaning it made a sound, or noise, when struck, or put in motion]; (Lth, TA;) and also of thunder, meaning it made a clear sound. (M, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Sal~ati AlA_ibilu, (M, K,) aor. taSil~u, (M,) inf. n. SaliylN, The camels made a [rumbling] sound to be heard on the occasion of drinking in consequence of their intestines' having become dry: (M, K:) [and in like manner Alxayolu the horses:] one says, jaA='ati Alxayolu taSil~u EaTa$FA The horses came making a [rumbling] sound to be heard from their bellies in consequence of thirst: (S, O:) and samiEotu lijawofihi SaliylFA mina AlEaTa$i [I heard a rumbling sound of his belly in consequence of thirst]. (T, TA.) And Sal~a Als~iqaA='u, inf. n. SaliylN, (tropical:) The water-skin became dry, (M, TA,) not having any water in it, so that it was such as would make a kind of clattering or crackling noise (yataqaEoqaEu) [when struck or shaken or bent]. (TA.) And SaliylN also signifies The sounding of the entering of water into the earth, or ground. (M in art. Sm.) ＝ -A2- Sal~a, (S, M, O, K,) aor. yaSil~u, (S, M, O,) inf. n. SuluwlN; (S, M, O, K;) and also, sec. pers. Salilota, aor. taSal~u; (O, TA;) and ASl~↓; (S, M, O, K;) or only the latter; (Zj, TA;) or it may be AlS~uluwlu is said, as it occurs in a verse of El-Hotei-ah, and not Sal~a; like AlEaTaA='u from A^aEoTaY, and AlquluwEu from A^aqolaEati AlHum~aY; (IB, TA;) It was, or became, stinking; said of flesh-meat, (S, M, O, K,) whether cooked or raw; (S, O;) said by some to be used only in relation to that which is raw; but A^aSal~ato↓ occurs, in a verse of Zuheyr, said of a muDogap [or bit of flesh-meat that is chewed], which indicates that it is used in relation to that which is cooked and roasted; or, accord. to some, the verb here means A^avoqalat [which has rendered heavy the eater]: (M:) and one says also All~iHaAmu Sal~alati↓ [the flesh-meats were, or became stinking (in both of my copies of the S All~ijaAmu is erroneously put for All~iHaAmu, the reading in other copies of the S and in the O)]; the verb in this instance being with teshdeed lilokavorapi [i. e. because of its relation to many subjects, or to a pl.]. (S, O.) In the Kur [xxxii. 9], some read A^aA_i*aA SalalonaA fiY A@loA^aroDi, (M, O, TA,) [instead of the common reading, which is DalalonaA, with D,] and some read SalilonaA, (O, TA,) which has two meanings: i. e. When we shall have become stinking, in the earth, and altered in ourselves and in our forms? and when we shall have become dried up? from Sal~apN meaning “ dry ground. ” (TA.) ― -b2- And Sal~a, (M, K,) inf. n. SuluwlN, (TA,) is also said of water, meaning It became altered for the worse in taste and colour. (M, K.) ＝ -A3- Sal~atohumu AlS~aAl~apu, (S, M, O, K,) aor. taSul~uhumo, (S, O,) (tropical:) Calamity, or the calamity, befell them. (S, M, O, K, TA.) ＝ -A4- Sal~a Al$~araAba, (M, K,) aor. yaSul~uhu, (TA,) inf. n. Sal~N, He cleared the wine, or beverage. (A, O, K, TA.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) An equal, or a match. (Z, K, TA.) One says, h`*aA Sil~u h`*aA (tropical:) This is the equal, or match, of this. (Z, TA.) SilaAlN. [See also another explanation of this phrase in what follows.]) ― -b3- Also Skin: one says xuf~N jay~idu AlS~al~api [A boot good in respect of the skin; somewhat differently expl. above]: (S, O:) or dry skin, before the tanning. (S, O.) ― -b6- And Moist earth. (O, K.) ― -b7- See also Sul~apN. ＝ -A3- Also The Aisot [i. e. podex, or anus]. (TA.)

2. Sl~bhu, (inf. n. taSoliybN, TA,) He, or it, rendered it, or him, hard, firm, rigid, stiff, tough, strong, robust, sturdy, or hardy. (S, M, K, TA.) El-Aashà says,
mino saraApi AlhijaAni Sal~abahaA AlEu
D~u wariEoYu AlHimaY waTuwlu AlHiyaAli
(S, TA) i. e. [Than the back of the excellent she-camel] which the provender of cities, such as [the trefoil called] qat~, and date-stones, and the pasture of El-Himè, meaning Himè Dareeyeh, the place of pasture of the camels of the kings, and the being long without conceiving, (TA,) have rendered hard, or firm, or strong. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence] one says, Sl~b Aln~abiy*a biHab~i Ald~aA*iY~i (assumed tropical:) [He made the beverage termed nby* to become strong by means of the grain called Hb~ AldA*Y~]. (Mgh in art. dw*.) ＝ -A2- Sal~aba Alr~uTabu, (AA, S, K,) inf. n. taSoliybN, (AA, TA,) The ripe dates became dry: (AA, S, K:) and Sal~abati Alt~amorapu the date became dry. (M, L.) ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps, Sal~aba is said in the K to be syn. with Saluba:] see 1, first sentence. ＝ -A3- See also 1, latter half, in two places. ― -b2- Sl~b said of a monk, (M,) or Sl~bwA (K, TA) said of monks, (TA,) He, (M,) or they, (K, TA,) made, or took, (M, K, TA,) for himself, (M,) or for themselves, (K, TA,) a Saliyb [or cross], (M, K, TA,) in his church, (M,) or in their churches. (TA.) ― -b3- Alt~aSoliybu also signifies [The making the sign of the cross. And] The figuring of a cross [or crosses] upon a garment; (T, Mgh, TA;) and hence, the figure thereof; the inf. n. being thus used as a subst. properly so termed; (Mgh;) as in a trad. where it is said of the Prophet, qaDaba Alt~aSoliyba; meaning qaTaEa mawoDiEa Alt~aSoliybi minohu [He cut off the place of the figuring of the cross, or crosses, from it]. (T, Mgh, TA.) And Sal~aba bayona Eayonayohi occurs in a trad., meaning He made a mark like the cross between his eyes by a blow. (TA.) ― -b4- Also A particular mode of wearing, or disposing, the [muffler called] ximaAr, (M, K,) for a woman. (K.) One says of a woman, Sal~abato ximaArahaA [She disposed her muffler cross-wise]. (TA.) And a man's praying fiY taSoliybi AlEimaAmapi [with the turban disposed cross-wise] is disapproved: he should wind it so that one part [or fold] thereof is above [not across] another. (TA.)

(TA.)

8: see 1, former half, in three places.

SulobN Hard, firm, rigid, stiff, tough, strong, robust, sturdy, or hardy; syn. $adiydN; (S, A, Msb, * K;) contr. of lay~inN; (M, TA;) as also SaliybN↓ and Sul~abN↓ (S, M, A, K) and SalabN↓: (M:) pl. of the first or second, [accord. to analogy of the latter, and also of the last,] SilaAbN. (of SulobN, S) is SilabapN. (S, M, K.) One says of land that has not been sown for a long time, A_in~ahaA A^aSolaAbN↓ muno*u A^aEowaAmK (tropical:) [Verily it has been hard by lying waste for years]. [Hard, &c., having the veins of his limbs appearing: thou wilt see him to have a finger pointing at them, i. e. his camels, because of their good condition, when the people are afflicted with drought].
