SbE, we find DaEiyf in this verse instead of Saliyb.) ― -b4- And [in like manner] huwa SulobN fiY diynihi and Sul~abN↓ (tropical:) [He is hard, firm, or strong, in his religion]. (A, TA.) ― -b5- And jaroYN SulobN (Lth, TA) or SaliybN↓ (M, L, TA) (tropical:) A hard, or vehement, running. (Lth, M, L, TA.) ― -b6- And SahiylN SulobN (assumed tropical:) A vehement neighing. (Lth, TA.) And SawotN SaliybN↓ (tropical:) A vehement sound or cry or voice. (M, L, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) and SulubN↓ (Msb, TA) and SalabN↓ (S, M, A, K) and SaAlibN↓, (IAth, L, K,) which last is rarely used, (IAth, TA,) and is said to occur only in one instance, in poetry, but another instance of it in poetry is cited, (TA,) The back-bone; i. e. the bone extending from the kaAhil [or base of the neck] to the Eajob [or rump bone]; (M, A, K;) the bone upon which the neck is set, extending to the root of the tail [in a beast], and in a man to the EuSoEuS [or os coccygis]: (Zj in his “ Khalk el-Insán: ”) or a portion of the back: (S:) and any portion of the back containing vertebræ: (S, Msb, TA:) [and particularly the lumbar portion; the lions:] and the back [absolutely]; as is said in an explanation of a verse of 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd cited in what follows: (M, TA:) pl. [of mult.] SilabapN and [of pauc.] A^aSolubN and A^aSolaAbN, (M, K,) each of which two is used in poetry in a sing. sense, as though every part of the Sulob were regarded as a Sulob in itself, and SilobapN, (M, TA,) of which last ISd says, [but this I do not find in the M,] I do not think it to be of established authority, unless it be a contraction of SilabapN. (TA.) Lh mentions, as a phrase of the Arabs, h`w^ulaA='i A^abonaA='u Silabatihimo [These are the sons of their loins: because the sperma of the man is held to proceed from the Sulob of the man, as is said in the Ksh &c. in lxxxvi. 7]. (M. [See also a similar phrase in the Kr iv. 27.]) ― -b2- [Hence SulobN is used as signifying The middle of a page, as distinguished from the haAmi$ (or margin): and in like manner, of other things.] ― -b3- [Hence, likewise,] SulobN signifies also HasabN [meaning (assumed tropical:) Rank or quality, &c.]: (AA, S, M, K:) and power, or strength. (M, K.) A poet says, (M,) namely, 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd, (S, TA,)
A_ijola A^an~a A@ll~`ha qado faD~alakumo
fawoqa maA A^aHokiY biSulobK waA_izaAro
(assumed tropical:) [Because God hath made you to have excellence above what I can relate, in rank or quality, or in power, and abstinence from unlawful things]: (S, M, TA:) AA says that Sulob here signifies Hasab; (S;) and A_izaAr here signifies EafaAf: (S, M, TA:) but some expl. Sulob here by both Hasab and quw~ap: and some relate the latter hemistich otherwise, i. e.
fawoqa mano A^aHokaA^a SulobFA biA_izaAro
meaning above such as binds the back with an izár. (M, TA.) And it is said in a trad., A_in~a AlmugaAliba Suloba A@ll~`hi magoluwbN, meaning (assumed tropical:) [Verily he who strives to overcome] the power of God [is overcome]. (TA.) ― -b4- Also Coitus (jimaAE): because the sperma [of the man] issues from the part so called. (TA.)

SalabN *
SalabN, and its pl. A^aSolaAbN: see SulobN, former half, in six places: ＝ -A2- and see also SaliybN, in two places.

SulabN *
SulabN A certain bird, (O, K,) resembling the Saqor [or hawk], but which does not prey, and which is vehement, or loud, in its cry. (O.)

SulubN *
SulubN: see SulobN, near the middle.

SaliybN *
SaliybN: see SulobN, former half, in five places. ― -b2- [Hence,] maA='N SaliybN (tropical:) Water upon which cattle grow fat and strong and hard. (A, TA.) ― -b3- And EarabiY~N SaliybN (tropical:) An Arabian of pure race: (A, Mgh, TA:) and AimoraA^apN SaliybapN (tropical:) A woman of noble, or generous, origin. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also Grease, or oily matter, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) of bones; (S,
M, * Msb;) and so SalabN↓; (M, K;) which latter signifies also ichor, or watery humour, mixed with blood, that flows from the dead: (M:) pl. [of the former accord. to analogy, and perhaps of the latter also,] SulubN. (K.) Hence, in a trad., the phrase A^aSoHaAbu AlS~ulubi [in the CK AlS~alabi↓] Those who collect bones, (K, TA,) when the flesh has been stripped off from them, and cook them with water, (TA,) and extract their grease, or oily matter, and use it as a seasoning. (K, TA.) ＝ -A3- Also [A cross;] a certain thing pertaining to the Christians, (Lth, S, M, Msb, K,) which they take as an object to which to direct the face in prayer: (Lth, TA:) pl. [of mult.] SulobaAnN (S, M, A, Msb) and SulubN (Lth, S, M) and [of pauc.] A^aSolubN. (Msb.) ― -b2- [And The figure of a cross upon a garment &c.: see muSal~abN.] ― -b3- And A certain brand, or mark made with a hot iron, upon camels; (M, K;) which, as Aboo- 'Alee says in the “ Tedhkireh, ” is sometimes large and sometimes small, and may be upon the cheeks, and the neck, and the thighs: (M, TA:) or, as some say, it is upon the temple; and as some say, upon the neck; being two lines, one upon [or across] the other. (TA.) ― -b4- And i. q. EalamN [as meaning A banner, or standard; properly, in the form of a cross]: (O, K:) En-Nábighah Edh-Dhubyánee is said to have thus called the Ealam because there was upon it a Saliyb [i. e. a cross]; for he was a Christian. (O.) ― -b5- [And hence, as Freytag says, (referring to the “ Historia Halebi ” and “ Locman. Fabul. ” p. ٤٣ The text is unclear, the number could be 43 or 42.
1. 5. 8,) (assumed tropical:) An army of ten thousand soldiers.] ― -b6- And AlS~aliybu is the name of The four stars behind Aln~asoru AlT~aAy^iru [which is the asterism consisting of the three principal stars of Aquila; whence it seems to be the four principal stars of Delphinus]: inconsiderately said by J to be behind Aln~asoru AlwaAqiEu [which is α Lyræ]. (L, K, and so in the margin of some copies of the S,) [And Freytag says, (referring to Ideler Unters. p. 35,) that AlSlyb AlwAqE is the name of (assumed tropical:) Stars in the head of Draco.] ― -b7- SaliybaAni of a leathern bucket: see 1, last sentence but one. ＝ -A4- See also maSoluwbN.

SalaAbapN *
SalaAbapN inf. n. of Saluba. (S, M, A, &c.) ― -b2- [Using it as a subst. properly so called,] one says, ma$aY fiY SalaAbapK mina AlA^aroDi (tropical:) [He walked, or went along, upon hard ground]. (A, TA.)

Saliybapu Alr~ajuli *
Saliybapu Alr~ajuli He who was, or those who were, in the loins (Sulob) of the father [or ancestor] of the man: hence the family of the Prophet, who are forbidden to receive of the poor-rate, are termed Saliybapu baniY haA$imK wabaniY Eabodi AlmuT~alibi. (Mgh.)

Sul~abN *
Sul~abN: see SulobN, former half, in two places. ― -b2- Also A hard stone, the hardest of stones. (TA.) ― -b3- And Whetstones; (S, M, K, TA;) as also Sul~abapN↓ (TA) and Sul~abiY~N↓ (M, K, TA;) and Sul~abiy~apN↓: (S, M, K, TA:) [or a whetstone:] or [a thing] like a whetstone. (A.) ― -b4- See also Sul~abiY~N.

Sul~abapN *
Sul~abapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

Sul~abiY~N *
Sul~abiY~N: see Sul~abN. ― -b2- Also A spear-head sharpened; (S, TA;) and so muSal~abN↓, (S,) or Sul~abN↓: (TA: [but this last is perhaps a mistranscription for muSal~abN:]) or a thing polished and sharpened with whetstones: (K:) and muSal~abN↓ signifies a spear sharpened with the Dul~abiY~, (M, TA,) or a spear-head sharpened upon the Sul~ab, which is like the whetstone. (A.)

Sul~abiy~apN *
Sul~abiy~apN: see Sul~abN.

SulobuwbN *
SulobuwbN The mizomaAr [or musical reed, or pipe]: (O, K:) or, as some say, the qaSabap [or tube] that is in the head of the mzmAr [app. meaning its mouth-piece]. (O.)

SaAlibN *
SaAlibN A hot fever; contr. of naAfiDN [which means “ attended with shivering, or trembling ”]: (S:) or a fever not such as is termed naAfiDN: (M:) or a fever attended with vehement heat, and not attended with cold: (TA:) or a fever attended with tremour (A, K, TA) and quivering of the skin: (TA:) or a continual fever: (Msb:) or a fever attended with SudaAE [or headache]: (Ham p. 345:) it is said by Ibn-Buzurj to be from the SudaAE: (L, TA:) it is masc. and fem.: one says, A^axa*atohu AlHum~aY biSaAlibK [which may be rendered Fever with burning heat, &c., seized him] and A^axa*atohu Hum~aY SaAlibN [virtually meaning the same]; the former of which is the more chaste: and one seldom or never makes one of the two nouns to govern the other in the gen. case: (M, TA:) or, accord. to Fr, they said Hum~aY SaAlibN and Hum~aY SaAlibK and SaAlibu Hum~aY. (MF, TA.) SaAlibiY A^a$ad~u mino naAfiDika [My burning fever, or continual fever, &c., is more severe than thy fever attended with shivering] is a prov., (Meyd, TA,) applied to two things, or events, of which one is more severe than the other. (Meyd.) ＝ -A2- See also SulobN, in the middle of the paragraph.

SawolabN *
SawolabN and SawoliybN↓, (Lth, O, K, TA,) in some of the lexicons SayoliybN↓, (TA,) Seed that is scattered (Lth, O, K, TA) upon the earth, (Lth, O, TA,) and upon which the earth is then turned with the plough: (Lth, O, K, TA:) Az thinks it to be not Arabic. (TA.)

SawoliybN *
SawoliybN: see the next preceding paragraph.

SayoliybN *
SayoliybN: see the next preceding paragraph.

muSal~abN *
muSal~abN A garment, or piece of cloth, figured with the resemblance of the Saliyb [or cross]: (S, M, TA:) or figured with a Saliyb: (A, Msb:) or figured with the resemblances of SulobaAn [or crosses]. (TA.) [See 2.] ― -b2- And A camel marked with the brand called the Saliyb; (M, A, TA;)as also maSoluwbN↓: fem. of the latter with p, applied to a she-camel; (M, TA;) as of the former also, applied to camels. (TA.) ― -b3- And An Abyssinian (Haba$iY~N) marked with the figure of the Saliyb [or cross] upon his face. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also Sul~abiY~N, in two places.

ruTabN maSal~ibN *
ruTabN maSal~ibN, (S, K,) and tamorapN muSal~ibapN, (M,) [Ripe dates, and a date,] becoming, or having become, dry. (S, M, K.) When date-honey (dibos) has been poured on such dates, that they may become soft, they are termed muSaq~arN. (S.) ＝ -A2- maTarN muSal~ibN Vehement, injurious rain. (L, TA.)

maSolowbN *
maSolowbN (M, A, Msb, K) and SaliybN↓ (M, A, K) [Crucified;] put to death in a certain wellknown manner: (M:) applied to a slayer of another, (Msb,) or to a thief. (A.) [See 1, latter half.] ― -b2- See also muSal~abN. ＝ -A2- maSoluwbN Ealayohi Affected by a continual and vehement fever; (S, TA;) or by a fever such as is termed SaAlibN. (TA.)

1 Saluta *
1. Saluta, aor.
Saluta
, inf. n. SuluwtapN, said of the jabiyn [or side of the forehead], It was such as is termed Salot [i. e. conspicuous, or clear, or fair; &c.]: (S, K:) or he (a man) was such as is termed Salot in respect of the jabiyn, (S, * K, * TA,) or of the face, or of the cheek (TA. [Accord. to the S and K, the verb is app. said of the jabiyn: accord. to the TA, of a man.]) ＝ -A2- Salatahu, (S,) aor.
Saluta
, (TK,) inf. n. SalotN, (K,) He urged him to run, by striking him with his foot, or leg; or struck him with his feet or legs, to urge him; namely, a horse; syn. rakaDahu. (S, K. *) ― -b2- And He poured it forth; namely, what was in the cup, or bowl. (S.) ＝ -A3- jaA='a bilabanK yaSolitu, and bimaraqK yaSolitu, He brought milk, and broth, having much water, (T, S, M,) with little oily, or greasy matter. (T, S.)

3 muSaAlatapN *
3. muSaAlatapN signifies The taking to oneself a verse of another poet without altering anything in it. (Har p. 267. [But this I believe to be postclassical.])

4 ASlt sayofahu *
4. ASlt sayofahu He drew his sword from the scabbard. (S, M, A.)

7 AnSlt *
7. AnSlt He advanced with a penetrative energy, and outstripped; syn. maDaY, and sabaqa; (K;) or so AnSlt fiY sayorihi [i. e., in his pace]: (S:) he outstripped; syn. tajar~ada: and he was quick, or he hastened, in his pace, or going. (TA.) One says of the eagle (AlEuqaAb), AnoSalatato munoqaD~apF [It was swift in making a stoop]. (A. [This meaning is there indicated by the context.]) ― -b2- AnSlt yaEoduw He hastened in some measure, running: and so Ainokadara yaEoduw. (A'Obeyd, TA.) ― -b3- AnSltt Als~aHaAbapu (assumed tropical:) The cloud was going to rain. (TA, from a trad.)

SalotN *
SalotN, applied to the jabiyn [or side of the forehead], Conspicuous, or clear, or fair; syn. waADiHN: (S, A, K:) open, or uncovered, and even: (M, K:) or smooth: (TA:) anything bare; and open, or uncovered: (IAar, TA.) wide, even, and beautiful, or comely. (ISh, TA.) One says rajulN Salotu Aljabiyni A man conspicuous, or clear,
or fair, in respect of the jbyn: (M, TA:) or smooth and shining: (A:) or wide, white, conspicuous, or clear, or fair: (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, TA:) or even: (A'Obeyd, TA:) or hard. (IAar, TA.) And rajulN Salotu Alwajohi waAlxad~i A man conspicuous, or clear, or fair, in respect of the face and of the cheek. (TA.) And fulaAnN yukaw~inu AlA^asowada SalotFA [Such a one makes the black to be white, or fair]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, and munoSalitN↓, (M, K,) and A_iSoliytN↓, applied to a sword, (S, M, A, K,) Sharp: (S:) or polished, and sharp, or penetrating: (K:) or unsheathed, and sharp, or penetrating: (M:) or such as penetrates into that which is smitten with it: (A:) but some say that a sword is not termed SalotN unless long: (TA:) or A_iSoliytN↓ may have the same meaning as muSolatN↓, i. e. unsheathed: (S:) accord. to AA, SalotN applied to a sword and to a knife and to a needle means having no sheath. (TA.) And one says, Darabahu biAls~ayofi SalotFA (S, M, A) and SulotFA↓ (S, M) He smote him with sword unsheathed. (S, M, A.) ― -b3- SalotN applied to a man, as also A^aSolatiY~N↓ and munoSalitN↓ (S, M, K) and miSolatN↓ and miSolaAtN↓, (S, K,) pl. [of the last] maSaAliytu, (S,) Hard, firm, strong, or hardy, (M,) sharp, or penetrating, (S, M, K,) in affairs, (S,) or in needful affairs, (M, K,) light in clothing: (M:) and [in like manner] SalataAnN↓ signifies sharp, or penetrating, and quick (munoSalitN), in his affair. (Ham p. 536.) ― -b4- See also SalataAnN below. ― -b5- And see SulotN. ― -b6- A^abuw AlS~aloti is a surname of The HidaA^ap [or kite]. (TA in art. HdA^.)

SulotN *
SulotN (S, M, K) and SalotN↓ (M, K) A large knife: (S, M, K:) or an unsheathed knife: (M:) pl. A^aSolaAtN. (S, M.) ― -b2- For the former, see also SalotN.

SilotN *
SilotN A thief, or robber: (K:) formed by transposition from liSotN. (TA.)

SalataAnN *
SalataAnN, applied to a man, and to an ass, Strong, and hard, firm, or hardy: pl. SilotaAnN: (M:) or, applied to a man, as expl. above voce SalotN, q. v.: (Ham p. 536:) and, applied to an ass, strong: (S: [in some copies of which, for mina AlHimaAri, meaning mina AlHumuri, we find mn AljimaAri, whence an error in the Lexicon of Golius:]) and, applied to a horse, brisk, lively, or sprightly, and sharp of spirit; (S, K;) and so applied to a man; like falataAnN: (T and TA in art. flt:) and, accord. to As, applied to an ass, smooth, having short hair: (TA:) or sometimes it means having no hair upon him; and so SalotN↓. (Ham p. 536.) ＝ -A2- [And accord. to ISd, it seems to be an inf. n., of which the verb is not mentioned; for he says that] it signifies also The act of leaping, springing, or bounding. (M.)

A^aSolatiY~u *
A^aSolatiY~u: see SalotN.

A_iSoliytN *
A_iSoliytN: see SalotN, in two places.

muSolatN *
muSolatN: see SalotN.

miSolatN *
miSolatN: see SalotN.

miSolaAtN *
miSolaAtN: see SalotN. ― -b2- miSolaAtu AlEunuqi [app. applied to an ass] Having the neck stretching out, and smooth, or with short, or little, hair upon it. (As, TA.)

munoSalitN *
munoSalitN: see SalotN, in two places. ― -b2- Also, applied to anything, Quick, or swift. (M, TA.) ― -b3- Applied to a river, or rivulet, (tropical:) Vehement in its manner of running. (A, TA.)

1 SalaHa *
1. SalaHa, (S, Mgh, Msb, &c.,) aor.
SaluHa
, (S, MA, Mgh, Msb,) the well-known form, though omitted in the K, (TA,) and
SalaHa
, (MA, K, Msb,) [said by some to be] the more chaste, because agreeable with analogy, (TA,) [but the former is the more common,] inf. n. SuluwHN (S, MA, Mgh, Msb, K * [in the CK AlS~aluwH is erroneously put for AlS~uluwH]) and SalaAHN (S, * MA, Mgh, Msb, K *) and maSolaHapN; (MA;) and SaluHa, aor.
SaluHa
, (S, MA, Mgh, Msb, K,) mentioned by Fr, on the authority of his companions, (S, TA,) but said by IDrd to be not well established, (TA,) inf. n. SalaAHN and SalaAHapN, (MA,) or SalaAHiyapN; (TA;) said of a thing, (S, Mgh, Msb,) and of a man, (TA,) It, and he, was, or became, good, incorrupt, right, just, righteous, virtuous, or honest; it was or became, in a good, incorrupt, sound, right, or proper, state, or in a state of order; he, or it, throve; contr. of fsd [i. e. fasada and fasuda]; (MA; [and S and A and Mgh and K by implication; see SalaAHN below;]) in Pers. nyk $d; (MA;) [and AstSlH↓ signifies the same, for] SalaAHN and AisotiSolaAHN both signify in Pers. nyk $dn. (KL.) One says, SalaHato HaAlu fulaAnK [The state, or condition, of such a one became good, right, or proper]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] h`*aA A^adiymN yaSoluHu liln~aEoli (tropical:) [This is leather that is suitable for the sandal]. (A.) And h`*aA Al$~aYo'u yaSoluHu laka (tropical:) This thing is suitable to thee; or fit, or meet, for thee. (S, K, * TA.) And fulaAnN laA yaSoluHu liSuHobatika (tropical:) [Such a one is not fit for being thy companion]. (A.)

3 SAlHhu *
3. SAlHhu, (A, Msb, K,) inf. n. SalaAHN (S, Msb, K) and muSaAlaHapN, (S, K,) the former of which is made fem. in a verse of Bishr Ibn-Abee-Házim, (TA,) [He made peace, or became at peace or reconciled, with him; or he reconciled himself with him: for] muSaAlaHapN is the contr. of muxaASamapN. (Mgh.) And SAlHhu EalaY ka*aA He made peace, or reconciliation, [or a compromise,] with him on the condition of such a thing. (MA.) And SAlHhu EalaY baEoDi maA lahu [He compounded with him for part of what was owed to him; he made a compromise with him on the condition of receiving part of what was due to him]; said of a creditor and debtor. (Mgh in art. DgT.) And SaAlaHotu bayona Alqawomi, inf. n. muSaAlaHapN, I made peace, or a reconciliation, between the people, or party; syn. laA='amotu. (Msb in art. lA^m. [See also 4.])

4 ASlHhu *
4. ASlHhu, (A, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_iSolaAHN, (S, A,) and quasi-inf. n. SalaAHN, (L in art. lqH,) said of a man, (A, Msb,) and of God, (TA,) [and of a thing,] He, and it, made, or rendered, it, or him, good, incorrupt, right, just, righteous, virtuous, or honest; constituted it, disposed it, arranged it, or qualified it, well, rightly, or properly; rectified, corrected, redressed, or reformed, it; put it into a good, incorrupt, sound, right, or proper, state; or restored it to such a state; put it to rights, or in a state of order; set it right, set it in order, ordered it, managed it well, cultured it; adjusted, dressed, or trimmed, it; prepared it properly for use; repaired, mended, amended, or improved, it; made it, or him, to thrive; contr. of A^afosadahu. (S, * K. [And so by implication in the Mgh &c.]) One says, A^aSolaHotu Alqidora biAlt~aAbali [I made good, qualified properly, or seasoned, (the contents of) the cooking-pot with the seeds that are used in cooking]. (Msb in art. tbl.) And A^aSolaHotu Als~iqaA='a biAlr~ub~i [I seasoned the skin with rob, or inspissated juice]. (S in art. rb.) And A^aSolaHotu bayona Alqawomi [in which AlA^amora is understood, so that the meaning is I rectified, or reformed, or amended, the circumstances subsisting between the people, or party; or] I made peace, or I effected a rectification of affairs, an agreement, a harmony, a reconciliation, an accomodation, or an adjustment; [or I adjusted the affair;] between the people, or party. (Msb.) And saEaY fiY A_iSolAaHi *aAti Albayoni [He laboured in rectifying, or improving, the bad, or the good, state of circumstances, or the disunion or union, subsisting between people]. (A.) One says also, ASlH Ald~aAb~apa, (TA,) and ASlH A_ilaY Ald~aAb~api, (T, A, Mgh, TA,) the latter because ASlH implies the meaning of A^aHosana, (Mgh,) (tropical:) He acted well to the beast, (T, A, TA,) and put it into a good, or right, or proper, state, or took care of it, or paid frequent attention to it. (A, TA.) And ASlH A_ilayohi (tropical:) He acted well to him, did good to him, or benefited him. (K, TA.) And ASlH [alone] (assumed tropical:) He did that which was good, right, or just. (Msb.)

6 tSAlHA * and AiS~aAlaHaA
6. tSAlHA AiS~aAlaHaA &c.: see 8, in four places.

7 AnSlH *
7. AnSlH [quasi-pass. of A^aSolaHahu; thus signifying It became rectified, &c.: see ta$aE~aba]. (K in art. $Eb.)

8 ASTlHA *
8. ASTlHA (S, A, K) and AStlHA, (K,) and tSAlHA↓ (S, A, K) and AiS~aAlaHaA↓, (S, K,) [the last a var. of tSAlHA,] all signify the same, (TA,) and Alqawomu tSAlH↓, and ASTlHwA, (Mgh,) [They two, (i. e. two persons or two parties,) and] the people, or party, made peace, or became at peace or reconciled, [each with the other, and] one with another: (Msb:) [AiSoTilaAHN is the contr. of AixotiSaAmN and] taSaAluHN↓ is the contr. of taxaASumN. (Mgh.) ― -b2- And ASTlHwA EalaY A^amorK They (a particular class of persons) agreed together, or among themselves, respecting a particular thing. (ElKhafájee, MF.) ― -b3- [Hence,] AiSoTilaAHN signifies also The agreement of a people to name a thing by any name turned from the primary application. (KT.) ― -b4- And [as an inf. n. used in the sense of
a pass. part. n., for muSoTalaHN Ealayohi,] Conventional [or technical] language: and a conventional [or technical] term: opposed to [lugapN and] tawoqiyfN. (Mz 1st nwE.)

10 AstSlH *
10. AstSlH is the contr. of Astfsd: (S, L, K:) [i. e. it signifies He regarded, or esteemed, a thing good, incorrupt, right, just, or the like; as expl. in the TK; and in like manner, a man. ― -b2- He wished, or desired, a thing to be good, incorrupt, right, just, &c.; as in the TK; and in like manner, a man. ― -b3- And He sought to render good, incorrupt, &c. ― -b4- And hence, He treated in such a manner as to render well affected, or obedient.] ＝ -A2- Also He sought to do good or to act well [A_ilaY fulaAnK to such a one]. (KL.) ― -b2- And He sought peace, or concord. (KL.) ― -b3- And It happened well. (KL.) ― -b4- See also 1.

SuloHN *
SuloHN a subst. from muSaAlaHapN, (S, Msb, KT,) syn. with the latter; (Mgh;) masc. and fem.; (S, K;) Peace, reconciliation, or agreement, (Mgh, Msb, K, KT, TA,) after contention: and in the law it means a compact to give over, or relinquish, contention. (KT.) One says, waqaEa bayonahumaA SuloHN (A, TA) Peace, or reconciliation, took place between them two. (TA.) [And A^uxi*a SuloHFA It (a fortress or the like) was taken peacefully, or by surrender.] ― -b2- Also That in respect of which there has been made a peaceful compact: or which has been taken in the way of peace. (Mgh.) ― -b3- And A party at peace with others. (TA.) You say, humo lanaA SuloHN They are [a party] at peace with us. (A, TA.) And you say also qawomN SuluwHN↓ A people, or party, who are at peace: the latter word in this case being app. an inf. n. used as an epithet. (TA. [See also SaAliHN.])

SaloHN *
SaloHN: see SaAliHN.

SalaAHN *
SalaAHN an inf. n. of SalaHa (MA, Mgh, Msb) and of SaluHa: (MA:) [used as a simple subst, it signifies Goodness, incorruptness, rightness or rectitude, justness, righteousness, virtue, honesty; &c.: see 1:] contr. of fasaAdN; (S, A, Mgh, K;) as also SuluwHN↓: (K, TA: [AlS~aluwH in the CK being a mistake for AlS~uluwH:]) accord. to some, it is not used as an attribute of a prophet nor of an apostle, but only of a person inferior to these: accord. to others, however, this restriction is wrong. (MF.) ― -b2- Also quasi-inf. n. of 4. (L in art. lqH.) ― -b3- And [hence,] A thing that is good, and right. (Msb.) See also maSolaHapN. ＝ -A2- SalaAHi, like qaTaAmi, is a name of Mekkeh; (S, A, K;) either from AlS~uloHu or from AlS~alaAHu; (TA;) and sometimes it is perfectly decl. [pronounced SalaAHN]. (S, K.)

SuluwHN *
SuluwHN: see SuloHN, and SalaAHN: ― -b2- and see also SaAliHN.

SaliyHN *
SaliyHN: see what next follows.

SaAliHN *
SaAliHN, (MA, L, Msb, K,) from SalaHa; (MA;) and SaliyHN↓, (IAar, L, K,) from SaluHa; (MA;) and SiloHN↓; (K;) applied to a thing, (Msb,) and to a man, (MA,) Good, incorrupt, right, just, righteous, virtuous, or honest; &c.; [see 1; contr. of faAsidN:] (MA, L, K:) pl. SulaHaA='u [accord. to general analogy of SaliyHN, and app. applied only to rational beings, like SaAliHuwna,] and SuluwHN↓ [q. v.; this being said by some to be a pl. of SaAliHN; and by others, to be originally an inf. n.; like as is said of $uhuwdN]. (L.) One says rajulN SaAliHN fiY nafosihi [A man good, incorrupt, &c., in himself], mino qawomK SulaHaA='a [of a people good, incorrupt, &c.]. (L.) And huwa EalaY HaAlapK SaAliHapK [He is in a good, right, or proper, state or condition]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] SaAliHN signifies also (assumed tropical:) Suitable, fit, or meet: so in the saying, huwa SaAliHN lilowilaAyapi (assumed tropical:) [He is fit for the office of prefect, or the like]. (Msb.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) Much, copious, or frequent: one says maTorapN SaAliHapN (tropical:) A copious rain. (Yaakoob, L, TA.) And hence the saying of IJ, A^ubodilati Alt~aA='u mina AlwaAwi A_ibodaAlFA SaAliHFA, meaning (tropical:) [t is substituted for w] frequently. (TA.) ― -b4- The A in SaAliHN is [often] omitted in writing [though not in pronunciation] when it is used as a proper name [so that the name is written SlH, or more properly S`liHN]. (Durrat el-Ghowwás in De Sacy's Anthol. Gram. Ar. p. 66 of the Arabic text.)

SaAliHapN *
SaAliHapN [a subst. from SaAliHN, made so by the affix p; A good deed or action; an act of beneficence; a benefit]. One says, laA tuEad~u SaAliHaAtuhu [His good deeds, or beneficent actions, are not to be numbered]. (A, TA.) And A^atatoniY SaAliHapN mino fulaAnK [A benefit came to me from such a one]. (TA.)

AiSoTilaAHN *
AiSoTilaAHN [for muSoTalaHN Ealayohi: see 8, last sentence].

AiSoTilaAHiY~N *
AiSoTilaAHiY~N Conventional [or technical] language: opposed to [lugawiY~N and] tawoqiyfiY~N. (Mz 1st nwE.)

muSoliHN *
muSoliHN [act. part. n. of 4, q. v.]. One says, rajulN muSoliHN fiY A^umuwrihi waA^aEomaAlihi [A man who does well, rightly, justly, or properly, in his affairs and his actions]. (L.)

maSolaHapN *
maSolaHapN A cause, a means, or an occasion, of good; a thing, an affair, or a business, conducive to good, or that is for good; [and hence it may often be rendered simply an affair, when the context shows it to mean what is conducive to good or done for a good purpose;] contr. of mafosadapN; (S and Msb and K in art. fsd;) a good, right, or virtuous, affair; (KL;) a thing that is good and right; syn. SalaAHN↓ [q. v.]: pl. maSaAliHu. (S, A, Msb, K.) One says, naZara fiY maSAliHi Aln~aAsi [He considered the things that were for the good of the people]. (A, TA.) And humo mino A^aholi AlmafaAsidi laA AlmaSaAliHi [They are of the people who occupy themselves in the things conducive to evil, not the things conducive to good]. (A, TA. *) And fiY AlA^amori maSolaHapN In the affair is that which is good: (Msb:) [or a cause of good.] And raA^aY AlA_imaAmu AlmaSolaHapa fiY ka*aA The Imám saw what was good and right [or what was conducive to good] in such a thing. (TA.) ― -b2- It is also an inf. n. of SalaHa. (MA.)

mutaSal~aHN *
mutaSal~aHN A place, of a garment [&c.], that is to be repaired, or mended; syn. mutarad~amN. (T in art. rdm.)

1 Salixa samoEuhu *
1. Salixa samoEuhu, [and app. Salixa alone,] aor.
Salaxa
, (L,) inf. n. SalaxN; (S, A, L;) as also Salija; (IAar, L;) [the former of the dial. of El-Koofeh, and the latter of that of El-Basrah; (see A^aSolaxu;)] He was, or became, deaf, so as not to hear at all. (S, A, * L.) SalaxFA kaSalaxi Aln~aEaAmi [Mayest thou, or may he, suffer a deafness like the deafness of the ostrich] is a form of imprecation uttered against a man; for all ostriches are [said to be] totally deaf. (L, TA.) ＝ -A2- Salaxato jilodahaA is said of a serpent (Hay~ap`) [meaning It cast off its slough: like salaxato]. (TA.) ― -b2- And Salaxahu, namely, a camel, is said of the mange, or scab, meaning [It excoriated him; like salaxahu; or] it extended over the whole of his body. (TA.)

6 tSAlx EalayonaA *
6. tSAlx EalayonaA He feigned himself totally deaf to us; (K, * TA;) as also tSAlj, with j. (TA.)

9 ASlx~ *
9. ASlx~, inf. n. AiSolixaAxN, He (a man, TA) lay upon his side. (K, TA.)

daAhiyapN SaluwxN *
daAhiyapN SaluwxN A destructive calamity. (K.)

A^asowadu SaAlixN *
A^asowadu SaAlixN i. q. A^asowadu saAlixN [q. v.], A certain species of serpents, that casts off its slough. (AHát, L.) ― -b2- And jarabN SaAlixN i. q. saAlixN [i. e. Excoriating mange or scab]: (K, TA:) it is such as occurs in the hinder part of the camel, and one doubts not its extending over the whole of his body. (TA.)

A^aSolaxu *
A^aSolaxu, (S, K, &c.,) so accord. to all the people of El-Koofeh, but the people of El-Basrah and the Arabs of that region say A^aSolaju, (IAar, TA,) Deaf: (Fr, A'Obeyd, TA:) or deaf so as not to hear at all: (S, K, TA:) or very deaf: (Mgh:) or A^aSam~u A^aSolaxu has this last meaning. (IAar, TA.) Fr said, (S,) kaAna Alkumayotu A^aSam~a A^aSolaxa, meaning El-Kumeyt was deaf so as not to hear at all. (S, A. *) ＝ -A2- Also A camel affected with mange, or scab: [or having mange, or scab, by which he is excoriated: like A^asolaxu:] fem. SaloxaA='u: and pl. SaloxaY. (K.) ― -b2- And Affected with [the malignant species of leprosy termed] baraS. (TA.)

1 SalaAdapN * and SuluwdapN
1. SalaAdapN SuluwdapN, [inf. ns. of which the verb is Saluda,] used in relation to a stone [&c.], signify The being hard and smooth. (M.) [And SalodN has a similar meaning.] You say, Saladati AlA^aroDu, and A^aSoladat↓, The land was, or became, hard:
(K:) or (tropical:) so that it produced no plants, or herbage: (TA:) and Salada AlmakaAnu, and A^aSolada↓, (M, TA,) the place was, or became, hard: (TA:) or (assumed tropical:) produced no plants, or herbage. (M.) And Salada Ealayohi Aljabalu, aor.
Salida
, inf. n. SalodN; and Saluda, [aor.
Saluda
,] inf. n. SalaAdapN and SuluwdapN and SuluwdN; The mountain, or rock, baffled him, namely, a welldigger, [by its hardness,] and resisted his efforts. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Salada Alz~anodu, (M, K, and so in some copies of the S,) aor.
Salida
, inf. n. SalodN; (M;) or Salida, with kesr to the l, aor.
Salada
, inf. n. SuluwdN; (AZ, S;) The znd [or piece of stick, or wood, for producing fire] gave a sound without emitting fire; (S, M, K;) and ASld↓ signifies [the same, or] it emitted no fire. (Ham p. 407.) ― -b3- And [hence,] Saladato zinaAduhu [lit. “ His pieces of stick, or wood, for producing fire, gave a sound without emitting fire ”] means (tropical:) He was, or became, niggardly, tenacious, penurious, or avaricious: (AA, L, TA:) and Saluda, alone, aor.
Saluda
, (M, A, K,) inf. n. SalaAdapN; (M, A;) and Salada, (M, A,) aor.
Salida
, (M,) or
Saluda
, (A,) inf. n. SalodN, (M,) or SuluwdN; (A;) and Sl~d↓, inf. n. taSoliydN; (K;) signify the same: (M, K:) or he was, or became, very niggardly &c. (A.) ― -b4- And Saladato SalaEatuhu, or SaloEatuhu, (accord. to different copies of the K, in the TA the former,) The bald place on the front of his head shone, or glistened. (K, TA.) Salada is also used in the same sense, in a trad., in relation to milk flowing forth. (TA.) ― -b5- And one says, jaA='a bimaraqK yaSolidu, and bilabanK yaSolidu, meaning He brought broth, and milk, containing little oily, or greasy, matter, and much water: for yaSolitu. (T in art. Slt.) ― -b6- Saladato A^anoyaAbuhu His canine teeth caused a grating sound to be heard. (K, * TA.) ― -b7- Salada biyadayohi He clapped with his hands. (M.) ― -b8- Saladati Ald~aAb~apu, aor.
Salida
, (K,) inf. n. SalodN, (TA,) The beast beat the ground with its fore feet in its running. (K.) ― -b9- Salada, (M,) or Salada fiY Aljabali, (K,) aor.
Salida
, inf. n. SalodN, said of a mountain-goat, (M,) He ascended the mountain. (M, K.) ― -b10- taSoludu, [or probably taSolidu,] said of a wild cow or wild ox (baqarap waHo$iy~ap), in a verse ascribed to a Hudhalee, [but not found by SM in the Deewán of the Hudhalees,] is expl. as meaning She, or he, stands erect. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Salada Als~aAy^ila (assumed tropical:) He gave nothing to the asker, or beggar. (L.)

2 Sal~ada
2: see the preceding paragraph.

4 ASld *
4. ASld: see 1, in three places. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) He (a man) failed to produce fire with his zanod [or piece of stick, or wood, used for that purpose]. (S, A.) ― -b3- And ASld zanodahu (tropical:) He made his znd to give a sound without emitting fire. (M, TA.) And (tropical:) He (God) caused his znd to emit no fire. (A.) And saA^alahu faA^aSolada (assumed tropical:) He asked, or begged, of him, and found him niggardly: thus related on the authority of IAar; but by rule it should be faA^aSoladahu. (M.)

SalodN *
SalodN Hard and smooth; (S, M, A, K;) as also SilodN↓ (K) and SaluwdN↓ (M) and SaliydN↓ (A) and A^aSoladu↓; (M;) applied to a stone; (S, M, A;) and so the first applied to land or ground (A^aroD); (S;) and to a solid hoof, as also SilodimN↓ and SulaAdimN↓, which last is of the measure fuEaAlimN accord. to Kh, but fuEaAlilN accord. to others; (M;) and to a side of the forehead, (S, M,) or thus applied meaning smooth and tough; (L;) and to a head, as also SulaAdimN↓, (M,) or thus applied meaning (tropical:) upon which no hair grows: (A:) and SalawodadN↓, (M, K,) which is of an extr. form, (M,) has the first of the significations above, (K,) or signifies [simply] hard: (M:) the pl. of SalodN (M, L) and of SaluwdN↓ (M) is A^aSolaAdN. (M, L.) ― -b2- Also applied to a place, (makaAnN, M,) and SalodapN applied to land, (A^aroDN, A,) (tropical:) That produces no plants, or herbage. (M, A.) And A^aSolaAdu Aljabiyni (tropical:) The part of the side of the forehead upon which is no hair: likened to smooth stone. (A Heyth.) ― -b3- [Hence,] HajarN SalodN and SaluwdN↓ (tropical:) A stone that will not emit fire: (L, TA:) and zanodN SaluwdN↓ (M, A) and SaAlidN↓ and Sal~aAdN↓ and miSolaAdN↓ (M) [and muSolidN↓] (tropical:) [A piece of stick, or wood, for producing fire] that gives a sound, (M,) not emitting fire: (M, A:) and EuwdN Sal~aAdN↓ (tropical:) Wood, or a stick, from which fire cannot be produced. (T, L, K. *) ― -b4- And farasN SalodN (K) and SaluwdN↓ (S, M, A, K) (tropical:) A horse that does not sweat: (S, A, K:) such a horse is discommended: (K:) or slow to sweat: or having little seminal fluid: and slow in impregnating. (M.) ― -b5- And rajulN SalodN (M) and SaluwdN↓ (M, A) and A^aSoladu↓ (S, M, A, K) (tropical:) A niggardly, tenacious, penurious, or avaricious, man: (S, M, K:) or a man very niggardly &c. (A.) ― -b6- And naAqapN SalodapN (tropical:) A hardy, strong, enduring she-camel. (K.) And xayolN SilaAdN (tropical:) Hard, hardy, or strong, horses. (A.) [And SilodaAmN↓, also, signifies Robust, or strong. (Freytag, from Jereer.)]

SilodN *
SilodN: see SalodN, first sentence.

SilodaA='N *
SilodaA='N and SilodaA='apN Rugged and hard ground, (ISk, K,) (assumed tropical:) that produces no plants, or herbage. (ISk.)

SilodimN *
SilodimN: see SafodN, first sentence.

SilodaAmN *
SilodaAmN: see SalodN, last sentence.

SaluwdN *
SaluwdN: see SalodN, in six places. ― -b2- Also, applied to a well, Such that its mountain, or rock, baffles the digger [by its hardness], and resists his efforts. (M.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A she-camel having little, or no, milk; as also miSolaAdN↓: (S, A, K:) and the latter, [which in the former case is written in some copies of the K with p,] that has brought forth and has no milk. (K. [But this is said in the TA to be a repetition.]) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A woman in whom is little, or no, good: or hard, having no compassion in her heart. (M.) ― -b5- (tropical:) A cooking-pot (qidorN) slow to boil. (S, M, A, K.) ― -b6- A beast (daAb~apN) that beats the ground with its fore feet in its running. (TA.) ― -b7- One who ascends a mountain by reason of fear; (K, TA;) as also miSolaAdN↓: (TA:) [or] a mountain-goat that ascends the mountain. (M.) ― -b8- And Alone, apart from others, or separate; (As, L, K;) as also SaliydN↓. (K.)

SaliydN *
SaliydN: see SalodN, first sentence: ― -b2- and SaluwdN, last sentence. ＝ -A2- Also A shining, gleaming, or glistening. (K.)

Sal~aAdN *
Sal~aAdN: see SalodN, in two places; and muSolidN.

SulaAdimN *
SulaAdimN: see SalodN, first sentence, in two places.

SalawodadN *
SalawodadN: see SalodN, first sentence.

SaAlidN *
SaAlidN: see SalodN. ― -b2- A^anoyaAbN SaAlidapN Canine teeth causing a grating sound to be heard; (K, * TA;) as also SawaAlidu, (K, TA,) which is the pl. (TA.)

A^aSoladu *
A^aSoladu: see SalodN, first sentence: ― -b2- and see the same also near the end of the paragraph.

muSolidN *
muSolidN: see SalodN. ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, layosa bimuSolidi AlqadoHi [lit. He is not one whose wood gives only a sound when one endeavours to produce fire from it; meaning (assumed tropical:) he is not one who ungenerously refuses when asked]; an expression of praise; (TA in art. ksr;) and [in like manner] AlqadoHi layosa biSal~aAdi↓. (TA. in art. h$.) ＝ -A2- Also Milk milked into a greasy vessel, and therefore without froth. (K.)

miSolaAdN *
miSolaAdN: see SalodN: ― -b2- and SaluwdN, in two places.

2 Sal~aTahu A@ll~`hu Ealayohi *
2. Sal~aTahu A@ll~`hu Ealayohi, inf. n. taSoliyTN, a dial. var. of sal~aTahu, q. v. (Ibn-' Abbád, K.)

1 SaliEa *
1. SaliEa, aor.
SalaEa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. SalaEN, (S, * O, * Msb, K, * TA,) He (a man, S, O, K *) was, or became, bald in the fore part of the head: (S, * O, * Msb, K: * but in the Msb it is said in this sense of the head:) or in the fore part of the head to the kinder part thereof: and likewise in the middle of the head. (TA.) [See also jaliHa The original text has a dot above the jeem. and jalaHN.] Accord. to Ibn-Seenà, the baldness termed SalaEN does not happen to women, because of the abundance of their moisture; nor to eunuchs, because their constitutions are nearly like those of women. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] SaliEati AlEurofuTapu, inf. n. as above, (tropical:) The ErfTp [a species of mimosa] dropped the heads of its branches: and had them eaten by the camels. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 7. ＝ -A2- SalaEa raA^osahu [perhaps a mistranscription for Sal~aEa↓, and primarily signifying He made his head bald in the fore part:] (tropical:) he shaved his head. (Z, TA.) ＝ -A3- SalaEa said of such as is termed Ei*oyawoT, [but the verb in this sense is probably Sal~aEa↓, (see this latter,)] He voided his ordure (A^aHodava) on the occasion of jimaAE. (TA.)

2 Sl~E *
2. Sl~E: see above, last sentence but one. ― -b2- Sl~Et AlHay~apu (tropical:) The serpent came forth from concealment (barazat) without any earth, or dust, upon it. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K, TA. [But in the O, the verb in this and the following senses is carelessly written without the sheddeh.]) ＝ -A2- Sl~E, inf. n. taSoliyEN, (said of a man, IAar, TA,) i. q. A^aEo*ara
[meaning He voided his ordure: see taSoliyEN as a subst., below; and what here follows]. (IAar, K, TA.) And Sl~E fulaAnN, (inf. n. as above, TA,) Such a one put his hand evenly expanded (K, TA) on the ground (TA) and voided his ordure or his ordure in a thin state (salaHa): (K, TA:) thus expl. by Lth. (TA.) See also 1, last sentence.

5 tSl~Et Als~amaA='u *
5. tSl~Et Als~amaA='u (assumed tropical:) The sky became bared by the disruption of its clouds. (TA.) ― -b2- See also what next follows.

7 AnSlEt Al$~amosu *
7. AnSlEt Al$~amosu (tropical:) The sun rose, or began to rise: syn. bazagat: or culminated: or came forth from the clouds, (O, K, TA,) appearing in the time of intense heat, with nothing intervening and concealing it; (TA;) and so tiSl~Et↓, (O, K, TA,) and SalaEat↓ [or more probably SaliEat]. (TA.)

8 ASTlE *
8. ASTlE, accord. to Reiske, as stated by Freytag, signifies He, or it, was defiled, or polluted; “ conspurcatus fuit: ” but he names no authority.]

SalaEN *
SalaEN Baldness in the fore part of the head: (S, O, Msb, K:) or in the fore part of the head to the hinder part thereof: and likewise in the middle of the head. (TA. [See SaliEa, of which it is the inf. n.: and see also jalaHN.]) ― -b2- Also a dial. var. of Sul~aEN, q. v. (TA.) ― -b3- One says also, laA^uqiyman~a SalaEaka meaning [I will assuredly straighten] thy [natural] crookedness; like DalaEaka. (TA in art. DlE, from the T and M.)

SaloEapN *
SaloEapN: see what next follows.

SuloEapN *
SuloEapN: see what next follows.

SalaEapN *
SalaEapN A place of baldness such as is termed SalaEN; (S, O, Msb, K;) as also SuloEapN↓; (S, O, K;) and SaloEapN↓ is said to be a contraction of the first, (O, Msb,) by Lth, (O,) but it is disallowed by the thoroughly learned. (Msb.)

SalaAEN *
SalaAEN, (O, K,) accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, with kesr, (O,) like kitaAbN, (K,) in the L [written] with damm, (TA,) The heat of the sun. (O, K.)

SaliyEN *
SaliyEN: see A^aSolaEu. ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) A mountain having upon it no plants, or herbage. (O, K, TA.)

SulayoEaA='u *
SulayoEaA='u: see A^aSolaEu, in six places.

Sul~aEN *
Sul~aEN: see Sul~aAEN. ― -b2- Accord. to As, (S, O, TA,) (tropical:) A place that produces no plants, or herbage; (S, O, K, TA;) whether it be a mountain or land; (TA;) from SalaEN in relation to the head; (S, O, TA;) and SalaEN↓ is also syn. with Sul~aEN in the sense expl. above. (TA.) And [the n. un.] Sul~aEapN signifies A smooth rock. (TA.)

Sul~aAEN *
Sul~aAEN, (S, O, K,) or Sul~aEN↓, (K,) or the latter also, which is app. a contraction of the former, (S, O,) (assumed tropical:) Broad, (S, O, K, TA,) hard, (K, TA,) smooth, (TA,) rock: (S, O, K, TA:) n. un. (of the former, S, O, [and of the latter also,]) with p. (S, O, K.)

SawolaEN *
SawolaEN: see the next paragraph.

A^aSolaEu *
A^aSolaEu, applied to a man, (S, O, Msb,) Bald in the fore part of the head; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) denoting more than A^ajolaHu: (Mgh:) or bald in the fore part of the head to the hinder part thereof: (TA:) and likewise, (TA,) or accord. to As, (O,) bald in the middle of the head: (O, TA:) and applied also to a head, (Msb, TA,) meaning bald in the fore part: (Msb:) and SaliyEN↓ signifies the same, applied to a head, (Msb, TA,) and to a man: (Msb:) fem. SaloEaA='u; (K;) but some disapprove this, and say that the fem. epithet is zaEoraA='u, and qaroEaA='u: (TA:) the pl. is SuloEN (O, Msb, K) and SuloEaAnN: (O, K:) A^uSayoliEu↓ is the dim. of the masc., [and SulayoEaA='u↓ is that of the fem.,] meaning as expl. above. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] the fem., applied to a tree such as is termed EurofuTap, [a species of mimosa,] (tropical:) That has dropped the heads of its branches: (S, TA:) and that has had its branches eaten by the camels. (TA.) ― -b3- And, applied to a tract of sand, (ramolapN, S, O, K,) and to a land, (A^aroDN, K,) (tropical:) In which are no trees: (S, O, TA:) and (TA) in which is no herbage. (O, K, TA.) It also occurs, alone, as meaning (assumed tropical:) A desert (SaHoraA=') that produces nothing; like the head termed A^aSolaE. (TA.) And SulayoEaA='u↓, applied to a land, (assumed tropical:) That produces no plants, or herbage. (TA.) ― -b4- And the masc., applied to a mountain, (assumed tropical:) Open to view, smooth, and glistening. (TA.) ― -b5- And, applied to a spear-head, (tropical:) Glistening and smooth: (O, TA:) or polished; (K;) and so SawolaEN↓. (O, K.) ― -b6- [Hence also,] AlA^uSayoliEu↓ signifies (tropical:) The penis. (O, K, TA.) And AlA^aSolaEu is said to signify (tropical:) The head of the penis. (TA.) ― -b7- And AlA^uSayoliEu↓, (S, O, K, TA,) or AlA^aSolaEu, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) A certain serpent, slender in the neck, (S, O, K, TA,) or, accord. to Az, wide in the neck, round in the head, (TA,) its head being like a hazel-nut: (S, O, K, TA:) thought by Az to be so called as being likened to the penis. (TA.) ― -b8- A^aSolaEu applied to an affair, or event, (A^amorN,) means (assumed tropical:) Hard, distressing, or calamitous; (TA;) and so applied to a day; as also A^ajolaHu: (A and TA in art. jlH:) or, applied to a day, (tropical:) intensely hot. (Ibn-'Abbád, Z, O, TA.) ― -b9- Also, the fem., [used as a subst.,] (tropical:) Any notorious affair or event; or any such affair that is dubious, of great magnitude or moment, to accomplish which, or to perform which, one finds not the way: (O, K, TA:) and (tropical:) a calamity, or misfortune, (S, O, K, TA,) [or] such as is hard to be borne; [as though it were smooth and slippery;] because there is no escape from it: (TA:) and [in like manner] SulayoEaA='u↓ (O, K, TA) and SaloEaA='u, and sawo'apN SaloEaA='u and SulayoEaA='u↓, (TA,) an evil, abominable, or unseemly, action or saying, such as is apparent, manifest, or unconcealed: (O, K, TA:) or a calamity, or misfortune, hard to be borne: (K, TA:) and hence the saying of 'Áïsheh to Mo'áwiyeh, (O, K, TA,) when she reproached him for his having asserted the relationship to him of Ziyád, and he replied that the witnesses gave testimony, (O, K, * TA, [see Abulfedæ Annales, i. 360,]) maA $ahidati Al$~uhuwdu wal`kino rakibota AlS~ulayoEaA='a↓ [The witnesses did not bear witness (in the CK, erroneously, mA $ahidota Al$uhuwda,) but thou committedst that which was an evil, abominable, or unseemly, action, &c.]. (O, K, TA.) ― -b10- SulayoEaA='u↓ is also said to signify (assumed tropical:) The act of glorying, or boasting; syn. faxorN. (TA.)

A^uSayoliEu *
A^uSayoliEu, dim. of A^aSolaEu: (TA:) see the latter, in three places.

taSoliyEN *
taSoliyEN inf. n. of 2 [q. v.]. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And a subst., like tamotiynN and tanobiytN, signifying Ordure, or dung; or such as is thin; syn. sulaAHN: (TA:) thus expl. by Lth. (O.)

1 Salagati Albaqarapu *
1. Salagati Albaqarapu, and Al$~aApu, (S, O, K,) aor.
Salaga
, (O,) inf. n. SuluwgN, (S, O,) i. q. salagat, (S, O, K,) i. e. The bovine animal, and the sheep or goat, shed the tooth [next] behind that called the sadiys: (S and K in art. slg;) or bred its [tooth called the] naAb: (K in that art. [in which see more]:) or Salaga said of any cloven-hoofed animal, aor. and inf. n. as above, signifies he entered the sixth year: or, as some say, the fifth: this is the utmost of the ages thereof [that have verbs and epithets to denote them]: (Msb:) SuluwgN (Mgh, Msb) in these animals (Msb) or in sheep or goats and animals of the bovine kind (Mgh) is like buzuwlN in camels. (Mgh, Msb.)

SalagN *
SalagN: see SalagapN. ＝ -A2- Also A red [hill or mountain, such as is termed] haDobap [q. v.]. (O, K.)

SalogapN *
SalogapN A large ship or boat. (Lth, O, K.)

SalagapN *
SalagapN [a n. un. of which SalagN↓ is the coll. gen. n., as is indicated in the O and TA,] applied to a she-camel i. q. rabaAEiyapN [i. e. In her seventh year], and fat: or i. q. sadiysN [i. e. in the eighth year]. (AA, O, K.)

SaAligN *
SaAligN part. n. of 1 [q. v.], (S, O, Msb, K,) an epithet applied to the male and the female of all cloven-hoofed animals, (Msb,) or to an animal of the bovine kind and to the sheep or goat, (S, O, K,) I. q. saAligN, (IDrd, O, TA,) which latter is said by Sb to be the original, the S being substituted for the s because of the g: (TA:) or, applied to a sheep or goat (Ibn-Abbád, O, K) and to a bovine animal, (K,) it is like qaAriHN [q. v.] applied to a horse: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) or in the fifth year, (As, IF, O, K,) as applied to a sheep: (As, IF, O:) or in the sixth year, (AZ, O, K,) as applied to a sheep or goat: (AZ, O:) or a sheep or goat advanced in age: (IDrd, O:) [see more in art. slg:] the pl. is Sul~agN (IAar, S, O, K) and SawaAligu, (IAar, O, K,) both of which are applied to kibaA$, (K,) [or rather] the former pl. is thus applied by Ru-beh, who by kibaA$ in this instance means “ heroes, ” or “ brave men. ” (S, O.)

1 Salifa Als~aHaAbu *
1. Salifa Als~aHaAbu, [aor.
Salafa
,] inf. n. SalafN, The
clouds had in them no water: (M:) or Salifati Als~aHaAbapu the cloud had little water. (A, TA. [It is implied in the TA that this is tropical; but I doubt its being so.]) See also its part. n., SalifN. ― -b2- Salifa said of a man's Harov [or seed-produce], It did not increase, or multiply, or become plentiful or abundant. (TA.) ― -b3- SalafN as a quality of TaEaAm [or wheat] signifies Its having little increase (nuzol, S, or nazal, L, or namaA=' and barakap, K) and little goodness. (L, TA: said in the latter to be tropical.) ― -b4- [Hence, app., or from the verb as used in the sense expl. in the next sentence below,] mano yabogi, fiY Ald~iyni yaSolafo, (S, M, Meyd, &c.,) a prov., (S, Meyd, O, K,) relating to the holding fast to religion, (S,) or used in urging to the mixing in social intercourse with the holding fast to religion, (O, K,) or, accord. to IAth, a trad., (TA,) i. e., accord. to As, He who exceeds the right bounds in religion (Meyd) will not be in favour with men, or beloved by them; (S, Meyd;) or will have little increase therein: (M:) or he who finds fault with men in respect of religion, (O, K,) and regards it as an excellence [that he possesses] above them, will have little goodness in their estimation, and (O) will not be in favour with them, or beloved by them: (O, K:) or the meaning is, he who seeks worldly good by means of religion, his share of the former will be little: (Meyd:) or he who seeks, in respect of religion, more than he has had revealed to him, his share will be little. (IAth.) ― -b5- Salifato, (S, M, O,) aor.
Salafa
, (S, O,) inf. n. SalafN, said of a woman, means She was not in favour with, or was not beloved by, (S, M, O, K, *) her husband, (S, O, K,) or him by whom she was supported; (M;) and was hated by him. (S, O.) ― -b6- SalafN, (O, K,) in a man and in a woman, (O,) signifies also The saying that which one's companion dislikes, or hates. (O, K.) ― -b7- And, (O, K,) likewise in a man and in a woman, (O,) (assumed tropical:) The commending, or praising, oneself for, or the boasting of, or glorying in, that which one does not possess: (O, K:) or, (K,) as Kh asserts, (S, O,) the overpassing the due limits in AlZ~arof [here meaning elegance of mind, manners, address, speech, person, attire, and the like], (S, M, O, K,) and in excellence in knowledge or courage or other qualities, (TA,) and arrogating to oneself more than is due, through pride: (S, O, K:) but some say that this is post-classical: (M, TA:) [see an ex. voce A=fapN, in art. Awf; mentioned here in the TA as occurring in a trad.:] one says, of a man, Salifa, (M, MA,) inf. n. SalafN, (M,) meaning (assumed tropical:) He commended, or praised, himself [&c.]; (MA;) and tSl~f↓, (S, MA, O,) meaning the same; (MA;) or this latter means takal~afa AlS~alafa, (K, TA,) i. e. [he affected the overpassing of the due limits in AlZ~arof (meaning as expl. above); or he took upon himself as a task] the arrogating to himself more than was due, through pride: (TA:) [you say, tSl~f bimaA layosa Einodahu (assumed tropical:) He commended, or praised, himself for, or he boasted of, or gloried in, that which he did not possess:] the epithet from the former verb is SalifN↓, (AZ, S, M, O, K,) applied to a man, (AZ, S, M, O,) and SalifapN applied to a woman; (M;) and the pl. of SalifN is SalaAfaY (AZ, M, K) and SulafaA='u and Salifuwna: (AZ, O, K:) it is said to be from SalifN applied to a vessel, accord. to IAar as meaning “ that takes little water; ” but rather, as others say, as meaning “ thick and heavy: ” the vulgar misapply it [app. by using it in the sense assigned to it by IAar]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also the next paragraph.

4 ASlf *
4. ASlf i. q. qal~a xayoruhu [His good things became few; or his wealth, or his goodness or beneficence, became little]: (IAar, O, K:) and (TA) so tSl~f↓. (M, TA.) ― -b2- And His soul, or spirit, (ruwHuhu,) became heavy; (IAar, O, K;) and he became oppressed as though by the nightmare. (TK.) ― -b3- And He became one whose wife was not in favour with him, or not beloved by him. (M.) ＝ -A2- ASlfhA He hated her, namely, his wife; (M;) as also SalifahaA↓, (so in a copy of the M,) or SalafahaA, aor.
Salifa
; (so in the L and TA;) the latter mentioned by IAmb: (L,TA:) or ASlfhu he hated him, namely, another man. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) ― -b2- And ASlf nisaA='ahu He divorced his wives: and he made their share of his favours to be small. (A, TA.) ― -b3- And one says to a woman, A^aSolafa A@ll~`hu rufogaki, meaning May God make thee [or thy faroj or the like] to be hated by thy husband. (EshSheybánee, S, O, K.) ＝ -A3- ASlf Alqawomu, (thus in the O, on the authority of Ibn-'Abbád, [like A^aHozana, and its contr. A^asohala, &c.,]) or tSl~f↓, (thus in the K, [but the former is preferable on the ground of analogy, and the latter I think a mistake,]) The people, or party, became in the [kind of tract termed] SalofaA='. (O, K.)

5 tSl~f *
5. tSl~f: see 4, first sentence. ― -b2- And see 1, latter part. ― -b3- Also He behaved in a loving, or an affectionate, and a blandishing, or coaxing, manner. (O, K.) ― -b4- And, said of a camel, He loathed, or turned away with disgust from, the [pasturage termed] xul~ap, and inclined to the HamoD. (O, K.) ＝ -A2- See also 4, last sentence.

AlS~alofu *
AlS~alofu The branches of the heart of the palmtree that are next belong the qilabap: [in the CK, xawA'N fY qulobi Aln~axolapi is erroneously put for xawaAfiY; qlbi Aln~xlpi; and the same mistake was originally made in my MS. copy of the K:] n. un. with p. (IAar, O, K, * TA. [See xaAfiyapN, last sentence.]

SalifN *
SalifN, applied to clouds (saHaAb, S, M, O, K), Containing no water: (M:) or having little water and much thunder. (S, O, K. [Said in the TA to be tropical; but I doubt its being so.]) It is said in a prov., rub~a SalifK taHota Alr~aAEidapi, (S, and so in some copies of the K,) or rub~a SalafK↓, (M, O, and so in some copies of the K, [with an inf. n. in the place of an epithet,]) i. e. Many a cloud is there, [or many clouds are there, lacking rain, or] having much thunder with little rain, [beneath that which thunders:] (A'Obeyd, O:) applied to the wealthy niggard: (A'Obeyd, O, K:) or to him who threatens, and does not perform what he threatens: (S, O, K:) or to him who commends himself much, (M, O, K,) and is loquacious, (M, O,) but is destitute of good. (M, O, K.) ― -b2- And A vessel that takes little water: (IAar, S, M, O, K:) a small vessel: one that leaks; that will not hold water. (IAar, TA. [This, also, is said in the TA to be tropical.]) And A heavy (K, TA) and thick (TA) vessel. (K, TA.) ― -b3- Also High ground (quf~), or a hard plain, that produces no plants or herbage: (TA:) and so the fem., with p, applied to land (A^aroD). (M, TA.) ― -b4- Wheat (TaEaAm) having little increase (qaliylu Aln~azali and Alr~ayoEi): (M:) or tasteless: (M, O, K:) and SaliyfN↓ signifies the same, in the former sense or in the latter. (M.) ― -b5- And [A man] heavy in soul, or spirit; syn. vaqiylu Alr~uwHi. (TA. [See 4, second sentence, which shows that muSolifN has this meaning: but the epithet thus expl. in the TA is there said to be like katifN.]) ― -b6- And SalifapN signifies A woman not in favour with, or not beloved by, (S, M, O, K,) her husband, (S, O, K,) or him by whom she is supported; (M;) and hated by him: (S, O:) pl. SalaAy^ifu, (S, M, O, K,) which is extr. [in respect of analogy], (M,) and SalifaAtN. (O, K.) ― -b7- See also 1, near the end.

SalofaA=' *
SalofaA=' and SilofaA=', and each with p: see A^aSolafu, in five places.

SaliyfN *
SaliyfN The side (EuroD [in one of my copies of the S EaroD, and in the other copy Eirq,]) of the neck; the two being called SaliyfaAni; (S, O, K;) [i. e.] AlS~aliyfaAni signifies the two sides of the neck (jaAnibaA AlEunuqi): or this signifies what are between the liyt [or part beneath the earring] and the qaSarap [or base of the neck, on the two sides]: (M:) or the two heads of the vertebra that is next to the head, in the two sides of the neck. (AZ, O, * K, * TA.) In this last explanation, in the copies of the K, rA^s is put for rA^sA. (TA. [And in some copies of the K, $iq~ayohimaA is there erroneously put for $iq~ayohaA, which, as is said in the TA, refers to the neck.]) A^axa*a biSaliyfihi and biSaliyfatihi↓ mean, accord. to As, He took hold of the back of his neck: (O, TA:) and one says also, A^axa*ahu biSaliyfatihi↓ meaning He took him, or it, altogether. (TA. [But I think it not improbable that biSaliyfatihi↓ in these two instances may be a mistranscription for biSaliyfayohi.]) ― -b2- AlS~aliyfaAni signifies also Two staves, or pieces of wood, which are placed across [horizontally] upon the [camel's saddle called] gabiyT, by means of which the maHaAmil [pl. of maHomilN, q. v.,] are bound. (S, O, K.) And (TA) SaliyfaA AlA_ikaAfi signifies The two [similar] pieces of wood that are bound upon the upper part of the [saddle called] A_ikaAf. (M, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also SalifN, latter half.

SaliyfapN *
SaliyfapN: see SaliyfN, in three places.

SalanofFY *
SalanofFY and SalanofaA='N A loquacious man. (M, TA.)

A^aSolafu *
A^aSolafu Hard, applied to a place; and so [the fem.] SalofaA='u↓ applied to land (A^aroD): (S, O:) or both signify hard ground (M, K) containing
stones; (M;) or hard and rugged ground; (As, O;) and the pl. is SalaAfK, (M, O, K, * [in the last, erroneously, SalaAfiY, and in the O, correctly, AlS~alaAfiY, being made determinate,]) thus pluralized in the same manner as SaHoraA=' because the quality of a subst. is predominant therein, (M,) and [for the same reason] A^aSaAlifu also; (O, K;) [the former pl. of SlfA=', and the latter of ASlf:] or SalofaA='↓ (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K) and SilofaA='↓, [each, app., with tenween, the latter because of the measure fiEolaA=', and each because receiving the affix p, for it is added,] and likewise SalofaA='apN↓ (K) and SilofaA='apN↓, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) rugged, hard ground: (K:) or a smooth rock, or a hard, smooth, bare rock, even with the ground. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

muSolifN *
muSolifN A man whose wife is not in favour with him or not beloved by him. (IAar, M, O, K.)

1. Salaqa, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) aor.
Saliqa
, (Msb,) inf. n. SaloqN, (As, * S, * M, * TA,) He called out, cried out, or shouted, vehemently; or made a vehement sound; (As, S, M, O, Msb, K;) as also ASlq↓: (S, M, O, K:) he raised his voice on the occasion of a calamity, and of a death: (TA:) and he wailed; (M, TA;) and so ↓the latter verb: (M:) A'Obeyd mentions it as with s [in the place of S]. Saliqa
, or, accord. to Lth,

, inf. n. as above, (O,) The horsemen dashed amid others (fiyhimo) in making a sudden attack or incursion. (M, * O, TA. *) ＝ -A2- Salaqa naAbahu, inf. n. , inf. n. SaloqN, (M,) He struck him with the staff, or stick, (AZ, S, M, O, K,) namely, another man, (K,) upon any part of his body. (M.) And SaloqN is also said to signify The striking with stone-cutter's picks, or pickaxes. (O.) See also SulaAqapN. ― -b3- Salaqatohu Al$~amosu The sun smote him with its heat. (O, K.) ― -b4- Salaqa baniY fulaAnK (aor.
Saliqa
, TA) He attacked the sons of such a one with an abominable onslaught. (IDrd, O, K.) ― -b5- Salaqahu bilisaAnihi, aor.

, inf. n. SaloqN, (assumed tropical:) He reviled him; syn. $atamahu. (M.) Fr says that Salaquwkumo is allowable in the sense of salaquwkumo in the Kur xxxiii. 19: (S * and TA in this art.:) but it is not allowable in the reading [of the Kur]. (TA in art. slq, q. v.) ― -b6- Salaqa jaAriyatahu He spread his girl, or young woman, (K, TA,) upon her back, (TA,) and compressed her. (K, TA.) ― -b7- Salaqotu Al$~aA=pa I roasted the sheep, or goat, upon its sides. (TA.) ― -b8- Suliqa bisahomihi He was rendered unfortunate by his arrow [in the game called Almayosir]. 4 A^aSolaqa
4: see 1, former half, in four places.

5. tSl~qt AlmaroA^apu The woman, being taken with the pains of parturition, screamed, or cried out vehemently: (S, O, K:) or threw herself upon her sides, one time thus and another time thus. (Lth, O.) And tSl~qt Aln~aAqapu, (Lth, O,) or Ald~aAb~apu, (K,) The she-camel, (Lth, O,) or the beast, (K,) rolled over, back for belly, by reason of distress: and in like manner the verb is used of any one suffering pain. 8: see 1, in the middle of the paragraph.

SaloqN, (As, S, M,) an inf. n., (TA, [see 1, first sentence,]) and SalaqN↓ and SaloqapN↓, (M, TA,) A vehement crying or shouting (As, S, M, TA) or sounding: (As, S:) and a wailing. SaloqapN: see SaloqN. ― -b2- Also An onslaught, or a shock in battle. (M, TA.) ― -b3- SalaqaAtu AlA_ibili The tushes of camels, that make a sound by their being grated, one against another. (S, * O, * TA.)

SaliyqN *
SaliyqN Smooth. (O, K.)

SulaAqapN Water that has long preserved a still, or motionless, state, (A^aTaAla SiyaAmFA, JK, Ibn-'Abbád, O, K, * in which last SyAmA is omitted,) in the place, (JK, Ibn-'Abbád, O,) or in a place, (K,) i. e. in one place, (TA,) and which the beasts have beaten [with their feet], (Ald~awaAb~u SalaqahaA↓, [which, accord. to MF, should be Salaqahu Ald~awaAb~u, referring to the word maA=', but accord. to the TA it may refer to SulaAqap,]) wherefore it is [said to be] maSoluwqap↓. SalaAy^iqu: (Jm, M, O, K:) accord. to AA, salaAy^iqu, with s, signifies “ roasted lambs, ” from salaqotu Al$~aApa “ I roasted the sheep or goat. ” (TA. See also saliyqapN.) ― -b2- And A thin cake of bread: (M, TA:) accord. to some, (O,) [the pl.] SalaAy^iqu signifies thin bread: (JK, S, O:) but some say that it is SaraAy^iqu, with r, that has this meaning. (TA.)

SalanoqFY [said in the copies of the K to be like EalanodaY, but correctly EalanodFY,] and SalanoqaA='N Loquacious: (O, K:) the n is augmentative. (O.)

SulayoqaA='u *
SulayoqaA='u A species of bird. (M, TA.)

Sal~aAqN *
Sal~aAqN, applied to a speaker, an orator, or a preacher, (JK, IDrd, O, K,) is like sal~aAqN, (JK,) [i. e.] Eloquent; as also miSolaqN↓ [like misolaqN], (IDrd, O, K) and miSolaAqN↓ [like misolaAqN]. (O, K.) ― -b2- And DarobN Sal~aAqN and miSolaAqN↓ A vehement striking or beating. (M, TA.)

miSolaqN *
miSolaqN: see the next preceding paragraph.

miSolaAqN *
miSolaAqN: see Sal~aAqN, in two places.

maSaAliyqu *
maSaAliyqu [a pl. of which the sing., if it have one, is not specified,] Large, or bulky, stones. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K.) ― -b2- And Light, or active, camels. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

maSoluwqN *
maSoluwqN: see its fem., with p, voce SulaAqapN.

1 Salama *
1. Salama, aor.
Salima
, [in one of my copies of the S
Saluma
,] inf. n. SalomN, (S, M, Msb, K,) He cut off, (K,) or he cut off so as to extirpate, (S, M, Msb,) a thing, (M, K, *) or an ear, (S, M, Msb, K,) and a nose; (M, K;) as also Sl~m↓, (M, K, *) inf. n. taSoliymN; (K;) [but] the latter verb is with teshdeed to denote muchness [of the action], or multiplicity [of the objects]: (TA:) and AiSoTalama↓ [likewise] signifies he cut off so as to extirpate (S, * Msb, * K) a nose. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- And Salima, aor.
Salama
, inf. n. SalamN, He had his ear extirpated [by amputation]. (Msb.)
