2: see the preceding paragraph.

8 A_iSotalama
8: see 1. ― -b2- [Hence,] AuSoTulima Alqawomu The people, or party, were destroyed [or cut off] (M, TA) utterly. (TA.)

SulomapN *
SulomapN i. q. migofarN. (K. [See the latter word, which is variously explained.])

SalamapN *
SalamapN [written by Golius and Freytag SalamN] Strong men: (K, TA:) as though pl. of SaAlimN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also SayolamN.

SilaAmapN *
SilaAmapN (S, K) and SulaAmapN and SalaAmapN, (K,) the last on the authority of IAar, (TA,) [all three written in a copy of the M with teshdeed to the l,] A party, or distinct body, of men: (S, M, K:) pl. SlAmAt, signifying companies, and parties, or distinct bodies: (S:) or, as some say, SulaAmapN, with damm, means a party, or company, equals in age and courage and liberality or bounty. (TA.)

Sal~aAmN *
Sal~aAmN and Sul~aAmN The kernel of the stone of the nabiq [or fruit of the lote-tree]; (M, K;) which is also called A^ulobuwbN; and is eaten: mentioned by Az. (TA.)

SayolamN *
SayolamN A difficult, severe, or distressing, event; (M, K;) such as extirpates: you say A^amorN SayolamN: and such is termed Sayolamiy~apN↓. (M.) And you say also waqoEapN SayolamapN i. e. [An onslaught] that extirpates. (K.) ― -b2- And A calamity; (S, M, K;) because it [often] extirpates; and so SalamapN↓. (TA.) ― -b3- And An abominable severing from friendly, or loving, communion or intercourse. (TA.) ― -b4- And A sword. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- Also i. q. wajobapN: like SayoramN [q. v.]: (M, K:) both mentioned by Yaakoob. (M.)

Sayolamiy~apN *
Sayolamiy~apN: see the next preceding paragraph.

A^aSolamu *
A^aSolamu A man (S) having his ears (S, Mgh) or ear (Msb) extirpated [by amputation]: (S, Mgh, Msb:) or a slave whose ear has been cut off; as also muSal~amN↓: (M:) or a man who is by nature as though his ears had been cut off; and so muS~l~amu↓ AlA^u*unayoni: (K:) or this last is applied to a man as meaning whose ears have been extirpated by amputation; and to an ostrich as meaning that is naturally as though his ears had been extirpated; (S;) or [small and short in the ears; i. e.] because of the smallness and shortness of his ears; (M;) and it is said that when it is applied to a man, [or rather when a man is likened to an ostrich thus termed,] it means his being contemptible, or despised. (TA.) A^u*unN SalomaA='u means An ear that cleaves to its lobe, or lobule. (M.) And AlA^aSolamu is an appellation applied to The flea. (K.)

muSal~amN *
muSal~amN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

Q. 4 AiSolahab~ati AlA^a$oyaA='u *
Q. 4. AiSolahab~ati AlA^a$oyaA='u i. q. Aimotad~ato EalaY jihatihaA [The things extended in their proper direction]. (K. [In the O, Ai$otad~ato is put in the place of Amtd~t. Compare Aisolahab~a.])

SalohabN *
SalohabN A tall man; (As, IJ, O, K;) and so salohabN [q. v.]; (IJ, TA;) as also muSolahib~N↓ or muSalohabN↓. (K accord. to different copies.) ― -b2- And A strong camel; (K;) and so SalahobFY↓, (ElUmawee, S, K,) in which the final letter is [not a sign of the fem. gender but] to render the word quasi-coordinate to the quadriliteral-radical class; (S;) fem. SalohabapN (TA) and SalahobaApN↓: (S, K:) pl. SalaAhibu. (AA, O, TA.) ― -b3- And A large, or great, house or tent. (Lth, O, K.) ― -b4- And A hard stone; as also SulaAhibN↓. (AA, TA.)

SalahobFY *
SalahobFY, and its fem.: see the next preceding paragraph.

SulaAhibN *
SulaAhibN: see the next preceding paragraph.

muSolahib~N *
muSolahib~N or muSalohabN: see the next preceding paragraph.

1 Salawotuhu *
1. Salawotuhu, (K,) or Salawotu AlZ~ahora, (M,) I struck, or beat, that part, [of him, or] of the back, which is called SalFA: (M:) or I hit that part (M, K) with a thing, or with an arrow or some other thing: on the authority of Lh, who says that it is of the dial. of Hudheyl: and one says also Salayotuhu; which is extr. [with respect to derivation], unless it be an instance of interchangeableness [of w and Y]. (M.) ＝ -A2- Saliyato and Salato, said of a mare, or she-camel: see 4.

2 Sl~Y *
2. Sl~Y, (S, M, K,) quasi-inf. n. SalaApN or Sal`wp, for which one should not say taSoliyapN, (S, K,) or the latter is allowable as agreeable with rule and as occurring in old poetry, (MF, TA,) He prayed, supplicated, or petitioned: (S, M, K:) and [particularly] he performed the divinely-appointed act [of prayer commonly] termed SalaAp or Sal`wp. (S.) Hence, in the Kur [ix. 104], (TA,) waSal~i Ealayohimo And pray thou for them. (Msb, TA.) Sal~aY EalaY fulaAnK means He prayed for such a one, and praised him. (TA.) And hence the verse of ElAashà cited in art. rsm, conj. 8. (S, Mgh, * TA.) It is said in a trad., mano duEiYa A_ilaY waliymapK faloyujibo waA_il~aA faloyuSal~i [i. e. Whoso is invited to a banquet, or a marriage-feast, let him comply, or, if not, let him pray for the inviter]. (M.) And the saying, in a verse of El-Aashà, Ealayoki mivola Al~a*iY Sal~ayoti means Keep thou to the like of thy prayer; i. e. he enjoined her to repeat the prayer for him: or, as some relate it, Ealayoki mivolu Al~a*iY Sal~ayoti, meaning upon thee be the like of that for which thou hast prayed: (M:) these words he addressed to his daughter, on the occasion of her saying, “ O my Lord, ward off from my father diseases and pain. ” (Mgh.) The saying Eabiydu fulaAnK yuSal~uwna [The slaves of such a one perform the divinely-appointed act of prayer] means that they have attained to the age of virility. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Sl~Y Ealayohi, said of an angel, means He prayed for, or begged, forgiveness, or pardon, for him: and thus the verb sometimes means when said of other than an angel; as in the trad. of Sowdeh, in which it is said, A_i*aA mitonaA Sal~aY lanaA EuvomaAnu bonu maZoEuwnK [When we die, 'Othmán Ibn-Madh'oon will pray for forgiveness for us]; he having then died. (TA.) ― -b3- [And, said of a man, He blessed him, meaning he invoked God's blessing upon him; namely, the Prophet; or he said, Aall~`hum~a Sal~i Ealayohi (expl. by what here follows) accord. to the rendering of Sal~uwA Ealayohi, i. e. EalaY Aln~abiY~i, by Bd and others in the Kur xxxiii. 56.] One says, Sal~ayotu EalaY Aln~abiY~i [I blessed the Prophet; &c.]. (S.) ― -b4- And, said of God, He blessed him, meaning He conferred blessing upon him: and He had mercy on him: and He magnified him, or conferred honour upon him: hence the saying, Aall~`hum~a Sal~i EalaY A=li A^abiY A^awofaY, meaning O God, bless the family of Aboo-Owfà: or have mercy on &c.: but in the saying [in the Kur xxxiii. 56], A_in~a A@ll~`ha wamalaAy^ikatahu yuSal~uwna EalaY Aln~abiY~i, the verb does not import two meanings; for it has there only one meaning, which is “ magnification ” [i. e. these words mean Verily God and his angels magnify the Prophet; or rather I would render them, bless the Prophet, as this rendering implies magnification and also a meaning of the quasi-inf. n. given in the M and K, which is “ eulogy, ” or “ commendation, ” bestowed by God upon his apostle, while it imports God's “ conferring of blessing ” and the angels' “ invoking thereof ”]: (Msb, TA:) [it is said that] All~`hum~a Sal~i EalaY muHam~adK means O God, magnify Mohammad in the present world by exalting his renown and manifesting his invitation [to ElIslám] and rendering permanent his law, and in the world to come by accepting his intercession for his people and multiplying his reward: and it is disputed whether or not this form of prayer may be used for any but the Prophet [Mohammad]: El-Khattábee says that it may not, though he himself used it for others. (TA.) [Sal~aY A@ll~`hu Ealayohi wasal~ama is a phrase commonly used by the Muslims after the mention of their prophet: see art. slm. See also SalaApN below.] ＝ -A2- Sl~Y said of a horse, (S, K,) inf. n. taSoliyapN, (TA,) He followed next after the foremost [in a race, at the goal]. (S, K.) Hence the saying [in a trad. of 'Alee], sabaqa rasuwlu A@ll~`hi waSal~aY A^abuw bakorK waval~ava Eumaru [expl. in art. sbq]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- And Sl~Y AlHimaAru A^utunahu, (Sgh, K,) inf. n. taSoliyapN, (Sgh, TA,) The [wild] ass drove together his she-asses, and made them to take the way [that he would follow]. (Sgh, K, TA.)

4 A^aSolato *
4. A^aSolato, (T, S, K, TA,) and Saliyato↓, (Fr, K, TA,) and Salato↓, (Zj, TA,) said of a mare, The parts on the right and left of her tail, (SalawaAhaA, S,) or the part on either side of her tail, (SalaAhaA, K, [see SalFA, below,]) became relaxed, she being near to bringing forth: (S, K:) or, said of a she-camel, her young one fell into the part of her called SalFA, and she was near to bringing forth. (T, TA.)

SalFA *
SalFA The middle of the back of a human being and of any quadruped: (M, K:) and, (K,) or as some say, (M,) [app. in a beast,] the part that slopes down from the hips, or haunches: or the space intervening between the jaAEirap [app. meaning the hinder projection of the haunch or rump of a beast] and the tail: (M, K:) or the part on the right and left of the tail; (S, M, K;) the two together being called [the] SalawaAni, (S, K,) which is similarly expl. by Zj in relation to a she-camel; app. properly meaning the two parts bordering upon the tail-bone: (TA:) or the place in which is set the tail of the horse; dual as above: (Msb:) or the bone upon which are the two buttocks: (Mgh: [there thus expl. in relation to a man:]) or the bone in which is the place of setting of the tail-bone; thus expl. by IDrd: or the SalawaAni are the two bones projecting from the two sides of the rump: or, accord. to some of the lexicologists, two veins (EiroqaAni) in the place of the ridof [i. e. in the rump]: (Ham p. 46:) the pl. is SalawaAtN, (M, K,) an instance of a pl. formed by the addition of A and t from a masc. sing., (M,) and A^aSolaA='N. (M, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, jiy^otu fiY A^aSolaAy^ihimo, meaning I came at their rears. (TA.)

SalaApN *
SalaApN, or Sal`wp, [accord. to El-Hareeree, to be written with A when prefixed to a pronoun, and also in the dual number, (see De Sacy's Anthol. Gram. Arabe, p. 67 of the Arabic text,) but this rule I have not found to be generally observed,
even in the best MSS., nor have I in the similar case of Hay`wpN, (to which it is also applied,) in the best copies of the Kur-án,] is said to be [originally SalawapN,] of the measure faEalapN, (Mgh, MF, TA,) or, accord. to some, [SalowapN,] of the measure faEolapN: (MF, TA:) it is a quasi-inf. n. of Sal~aY [q. v.]: (S, K:) and [used as a simple subst.] it signifies Prayer, supplication, or petition: (S, M, Msb, K:) this is said to be its primary signification: and muSal~FY↓ is said to have the same meaning. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- Then applied to signify A certain well-known mode, or manner, [of religious service,] because comprising prayer; (Msb;) [the divinelyappointed act of prayer;] one of the divinelyappointed SalawaAt; (S;) a certain religious service in which are rukuwE [or lowering of the head so that the palms of the hands reach the knees] and sujuwd [or prostration of oneself in a particular manner expl. voce sajada]: (M, * K:) and muSal~FY↓ is said to have the same meaning. (TA.) [The performance of this act is fully described in my work on the Modern Egyptians.] It is said to be, in this sense, a proper term of the law, not indicated by the language of the Arabs [before El-Islám] except as importing prayer, which is its primary signification: what Esh-Shiháb says respecting it necessarily implies its being a proper term of the law known to the Arabs [before ElIslám]: in the Mz it is said to be one of the words of El-Islám: but all of these sayings require consideration. (MF, TA, [Much more, which I omit as being unprofitable, is added on this point in the TA, partly from the Msb; as well as several different opinions respecting the derivation of the word as used in this sense, which are fanciful or absurd.]) The saying of the Prophet, laA Sal`wpa lijaAri Almasojidi A_il~aA fiY Almasojidi means There is no Slwp [or divinely-appointed act of prayer] that is excellent or complete [to the neighbour of the mosque unless in the mosque]. (M.) And his saying, to Usámeh, AlS~al`wpu A^amaAmaka means The time of the Slwp [or divinely-appointed prayer], or the place thereof, [is before thee,] alluding to that of sunset. (Mgh.) And he used the term AlS~al`wpu as meaning suwrapu AlS~al`wpi, i. e. The faAtiHap [or Opening Chapter of the Kur-án, because it is a form of prayer, or] because the recital thereof is excellent, or satisfactory. (Mgh.) In the Kur xxii. 41, (I' Ab, S, M, Ksh, Bd,) [the pl.] SalawaAtN means Places of worship of the Jews: (I' Ab, S, M, Ksh, Bd, K:) said to be (Ksh, Bd) originally SaluwtaA, a Hebrew word, (Ksh, Bd, K,) arabicized: (Ksh, Bd:) this is the common reading of the word, and the most valid: other readings are SuluwaAtN and SulawaAtN and SilawaAtN; and beside these, some others which are perverted forms. (TA.) ― -b3- Also Prayer for forgiveness or pardon. (M, Mgh, K.) ― -b4- [And A blessing, as meaning an invocation of God's blessing upon any one. See 2.] ― -b5- And i. q. barakapN [as meaning A blessing, such as is bestowed by God]: (Msb:) and mercy (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) of God (S, M) on his apostle: (M:) and magnification; and this is [said to be] specially denoted by its verb when the Prophet is the object: (Msb:) and God's eulogy, or commendation, bestowed upon his apostle. (M, K.) ＝ -A2- AlS~alaApu [from SalFA] also means A_itoyaAnu AlmaroA^api fiY duburihaA. (TA in art. Swm.)

muSoliyapN *
muSoliyapN part. n. of A^aSolato [q. v.] said of a she-camel [or of a mare]. (T, TA.)

muSal~FY *
muSal~FY A place of AlS~alaAp [as meaning the performance of the divinely-appointed act of prayer]; (Mgh, Msb, K;) or of any prayer or supplication: (Mgh:) [and particularly] a place of the performance of the divinely-appointed prayer on the occasion of the [festival termed] Eiyd: (MA:) [and also such a place at a burial-ground: the place for this purpose is particularly termed muSal~aY AlA^amowaAti: see De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., i. 192.] ― -b2- And A carpet upon which one performs the divinely-appointed act of prayer. (MA.) ― -b3- See also SalaApN, former half, in two places.

muSal~K *
muSal~K Any one praying [in any manner: and particularly performing the divinely-appointed act of prayer]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And AlmuSal~iaY signifies, as applied to a horse, The one that follows next after the foremost [at the goal] (S, M, Mgh, Msb) in a race: (Mgh, Msb:) because his head is next to the part called SalFA, (Lh, S, M, Msb,) or next to the SalawaAni, (Mgh,) of the foremost. (Lh, S, M, Mgh, Msb.)

1 SalaAhu *
1. SalaAhu, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor. yaSoliyhi, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. SaloYN, (S, M, K,) He roasted, broiled, or fried, it, namely, flesh-meat, (S, M, Msb, K,) &c.; (S;) and SalaAhu fiY Aln~aAri and EalaY Aln~aAri signify the same; and also he burned it. (TA.) And (so in the M, but in the K “ or ”) SalaAhu (M, K) fiY Aln~aAri (M) He threw it into the fire to be burned; as also ASlAhu↓; and Sl~Ahu↓, (M, K,) inf. n. taSoliyapN; (TA;) namely, flesh-meat. (M, K. [But see the next sentence.]) And SalaAhu Aln~aAra and fiY Aln~aAri and EalaY Aln~aAri, (M, K,) inf. n. SaloYN and SuliY~N and SiliY~N; (M;) and Aln~aAra ASlAhu↓, and Aln~aAra Sl~Ahu↓; He made him to enter into the fire, and to remain, stay, dwell, or abide, therein: (M, K:) and fulaAnN Aln~aAra Sul~iYa↓ [Such as one was made to enter into the fire, &c.]: (M:) [or] you say, Salayotu Alr~ajula naArFA, meaning I made the man to enter fire and to be burned: and A^aSolayotuhu↓, with A, when you mean I threw him, or cast him, into the fire, as though intending burning [him]; as also Sal~ayotuhu↓, inf. n. taSoliyapN. (S.) ― -b2- And Salayotu fulaAnFA, (T, TA,) or lifulaAnK, (S, TA,) (tropical:) I laboured in a case, or an affair, desiring to calumniate, or slander, such a one therein, and to cause him to fall into destruction: (T, S, TA:) or Salayotuhu and Salayotu lahu both signify I calumniated, or slandered, him, and caused him to fall into destruction, (M, TA,) in consequence thereof: (M:) or, accord. to the K, SalaY fulaAnFA, of which the inf. n. is SaloYN, signifies he soothed, coaxed, wheedled, or cajoled, such a one: or deceived, deluded, beguiled, circumvented, or outwitted, him: which meanings are not in any of the three lexicons above mentioned: accord. to the A, Salayotu bifulaAnK [probably a mistranscription for lifulaAnK] means (tropical:) I framed a stratagem, or plot, to cause such a one to fall; there said to be tropical. (TA.) ― -b3- SalaY yadahu biAln~aAri [said in the TA to be a mistake]: see 2. ＝ -A2- SaliYa Aln~aAra, (S, M, Msb, K,) and biAln~aAri, (M, Msb, K,) aor. yaSolaY, (S, Msb, * K, *) inf. n. SalFY, (Msb,) or SuliY~N, (S, K, [SaloyFA in the CK being a mistranscription for Suliy~FA,]) or both, (M,) and SiliY~N and SilaA='N, (M, K,) and accord. to the K SalaA='N, but this is a mistake for SalFY, (TA,) He was, or became, burned [by the fire]: (S:) or he endured, or suffered, the heat of the fire; as also Aln~aAra tSl~Y↓: (M, K:) or he felt the heat of the fire: (Msb:) and one says tSl~Y↓ Har~a Aln~aAri and ASTlAhu↓ [in this last sense or in the sense next preceding]: (Ham p. 792:) and SaliYa Aln~aAra he entered into the fire: (TA in art. blh: see an ex. voce baloha:) or, accord. to Er-Rághib, SaliYa biAln~aAri means he was tried (buliYa) by fire, or by the fire; and so bika*aA (assumed tropical:) [by such a thing, as though by fire]. (TA.) [In the Kur, in which are many exs. of it, (iv. 11, xiv. 34, xvii. 19, &c.,) it is always trans. by itself, without bi.] And SaliYa biAlA^amori, (S, M, *) and biAlHarobi; (S;) and AlA^amora tSl~Y↓, and AlHaroba; (M;) He endured, or suffered, the heat, and severity, or vehemence, of the affair, or case, and of the war, or fight: (S, M:) Aboo-Zubeyd says,
Har~a Harobihimu faqado taSal~ayotu↓
Almaqoruwru mino qarasi kamaA taSal~aY↓
[And I have suffered the heat and vehemence of their war, like as he who is affected with cold suffers in consequence of coldest and most abundant hoar-frost]. (M.) ＝ -A3- [It is said that] SaliYa Alr~ajulu signifies also lazima [i. e. The man kept to, or clave to, a thing]; and so ASTlY↓: whence Zj holds SalaApN [expl. in art. Slw] to be derived; because it is a keeping, or cleaving, to that which God has appointed: and hence also, [it is said,] fiY Aln~aAri mano yuSal~aY↓, i. e. ylzm [app. yulozamu, meaning mano yulozamu Aln~aAra He who is made to keep, or cleave, to the fire; nearly agreeing with Sal~aAhu Aln~aAra as expl. above from the M and K]. (TA.) ＝ -A4- And Salayotu AlZ~ahora means I struck, or beat, that part of the back which is called SalFA: or I hit that part: but this is extr.; for by rule it should be Salawotuhu, like as Hudheyl say. (M. [See 1 in art. Slw.])

2 Sal~aYa
2: see 1, second sentence; and third sentence in three places; and last sentence but one. ― -b2- One says also, Sl~Y yadahu biAln~aAri, (M, TA,) accord. to the K SalaY↓, [without teshdeed,] but this is wrong, as is shown by a verse cited in the M, (TA,) He warmed his hand with the fire. (M, K, TA.) [And it is said in the TA that SlA Zahorahu bAlnhr means A^adofaA^ahu: but I think that the right reading is Sl~Y Zahorahu biAln~amirapi, i. e. He warmed his
back with the woollen garment called namirap.] ― -b3- And Sal~ayotu AlEaSaA biAln~aAri I made the staff supple, and straightened it, by means of fire: (S:) or Sl~Y AlEaSaA EalaY Aln~aAri, (M, K,) inf. n. taSoliyapN; (K;) and tSl~AhA↓; he parched and darkened the staff upon the fire; syn. law~aHahaA: (M, K:) or Sl~Y AlEaSaA he straightened the staff by turning it round over the fire: (T in art. dwm: see an ex. in a verse cited in that art., conj. 10:) and Sal~ayotu AlqanaApa I straightened the spear-shaft by means of fire: (A, TA:) and Sal~ayotu AlEuwda biAln~aAri I rendered supple the stick, or branch, by means of fire. (Msb.)

4 A^aSolaYa
4: see 1, second sentence; and third sentence in two places.

5 taSal~aYa
5: see the next paragraph, in two places: ― -b2- see also 1, latter half, in five places: ― -b3- and see 2, last sentence.

8 ASTlY *
8. ASTlY He warmed himself (M, K) biAln~aAri [by means of the fire]: (M:) one says, AiSoTalayotu biAln~aAri and bihaA taSal~ayotu↓ [app. meaning I warmed myself by means of the fire]: (S:) or ASTlY Aln~aAra and biAln~aAri mean he became warm by means of the fire: and biAln~aAri tSl~Y↓, he became burnt by the fire. (MA.) Hence, in the Kur [xxvii. 7 and xxviii. 29], laEal~akumo taSoTaluwna [May-be ye will warm yourselves]: (TA:) in relation to which it is said that the time was winter, and therefore AlAiSoTilaA=' was needed. (M, TA.) ― -b2- It is also said of the chameleon, as meaning He repaired to the sun. (M and L in art. $q*: see an ex. in a verse cited voce $aqa*aAnN.) ― -b3- And one says of a courageous man, with whom one cannot cope, laA yuSoTalaY binaArihi [lit. One cannot warm himself by means of his fire; meaning (assumed tropical:) one cannot approach him when he is inflamed with rage, especially in fight, or battle]. (S.) The phrase may be also used satirically, as meaning (assumed tropical:) One will not seek his hospitality. (Meyd. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 588.]) ― -b4- See also 1, latter half, in two places.

SalFY *
SalFY: see SalaA='N.

SalaA='N *
SalaA='N: see SalaAyapN.

SilaA='N *
SilaA='N Roasted, broiled, or fried, flesh-meat. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- And, as also SalFY↓, (S, M, K,) the former with kesr and the latter with fet-h, (S,) Fuel; (S, * M, K;) syn. waquwdN; (M, K, TA; [in the CK, erroneously, wuquwd;]) i. e. maA tuwqadu bihi Aln~aAru; (TA;) you say SilaA='u Aln~aAri and SalaY Aln~aAri: (S:) or both signify fire: (M, Mgh, K:) or SilaA='N signifies the heat of fire. (Msb.) One says, huwa A^aHosanu mina AlS~ilaA='i fiY Al$~itaA='i [It, or he, is better than fire in winter]. (TA.)

SaliY~N *
SaliY~N: see maSoliY~N.

SalaA='apN *
SalaA='apN: see what next follows.

SalaAyapN *
SalaAyapN and SalaA='apN↓, (S, M, Mgh, K,) the latter with ' because SalaA='N↓ is used as the pl., [or rather coll. gen. n.,] but not by those who say SalaAyapN, (Sb, M,) [for] the pl. [of this] is SuliY~N and SiliY~N (K) and SalaAyaAtN, (MA,) i. q. fihorN [i. e. A stone such as fills the hand; or of the size of that with which one bruises and breaks walnuts and the like]: (S:) or a thing with which perfume is bruised, brayed, or pounded: (M, K:) or a stone upon which one bruises, or powders, (MA, Mgh,) perfume or some other thing; (Mgh;) that with which [not upon which] one does so being called midowakN. (MA.) Imra-el-Keys [in a verse of his Mo'allakah, (see EM p. 45,) as some relate it,] uses the phrase SalaAyapu HanoZali, because colocynths, when they have become dry, are split therewith. (S. [But there are two other readings, SaraAyap and SaraAbap.]) ― -b2- Also, (K,) as being likened thereto, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The forehead. (K.) ― -b3- And the former word, A rough, rugged, sariyHap [or long strip] of [high ground such as is termed] quf~. (ISh, Az, TA.)

Sil~iyaAnN *
Sil~iyaAnN: see art. Sl.

SaAlK *
[SaAlK is expl. by Freytag as meaning Heated or warmed (“ calefactus ”), and burnt: and the pl. is said by him to be SuliY~N: but he names no authority: if this be correct, it must be a possessive epithet from SaliYa.]

SaAliyapN *
SaAliyapN A support for the cooking-pot, such as is termed A^uvofiy~apN. (MA.)

maSoliY~N *
maSoliY~N Roasted, broiled, or fried; as also SaliY~N↓. (Ham pp. 13-14. [Both of these words are there without any syll. signs.]) It is said in a trad., A^utiYa bi$aApK maSoliy~apK i. e. A roasted sheep, or goat, was brought. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And SayoHaAniy~apN maSoliy~apN means [A date of the sort called SayoHaAniY~] dried in the sun. (A, TA.)

A^aroDN maSolaApN *
A^aroDN maSolaApN A land abounding with the plant called Sil~iyaAn. (K.)

miSolaApN *
miSolaApN A snare that is set up for birds &c.: (S, M: *) pl. maSaAlK. (S, M.) It is said in a trad., A_in~a lil$~ayoTaAni fuxuwxFA wamaSaAliYa (S) or maSaAliYa wafuxuwxFA i. e. [Verily to the Devil belong snares and traps] with which he catches men. (M.)

muSoTalFY *
muSoTalFY The limbs of a man, or his arms and legs and face and every prominent part, which become cold at the time of death, and which are warmed at the fire: (AHeyth, L in art. brd:) or the face and extremities. (Z, TA.) One says, barada Almawotu EalaY muSoTalaAhu. (AHeyth, L in art. brd: see 1 in that art.)

1 S~m~a *
1. S~m~a, (S, M, Msb, K,) and Samima, which is extr., (M, K,) [first pers. of each Samimotu,] aor. yaSam~u, (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. SamamN (S, * M, Msb, K) and Sam~N; (M, K;) and A^aSam~a↓; (S, M, Msb, K;) He was, or became, deaf; (M, * Msb, K; *) [or] he had a stoppage of the ear, and a heaviness of hearing. (M, K.) And Sam~ati AlA^u*unu, aor. as above, inf. n. SamamN, The ear was, or became, deaf. (Msb.) ― -b2- [And He was, or became, as though he heard not.] One says, Sam~a Eanohu (assumed tropical:) [He was as though he heard not him, or it; he was deaf to him, or it]; (M;) and Eanohu A^aSam~a↓ [meaning the same]. (S, M.) ― -b3- [Hence Sam~a signifies also (assumed tropical:) He or it, uttered, or made, no sound or noise; like him who, not hearing, returns no reply to a call or question; (assumed tropical:) was dumb, or mute.] One says, Sam~ato HaSaApN bidamK (tropical:) [A pebble made no sound in falling upon the ground by reason of blood]; i. e. the blood was so copious that if one threw a pebble into it no sound would be heard in consequence thereof, (As, S, M, Meyd, K, TA,) because it would not fall upon the ground: (As, S, Meyd:) the saying is a prov. (Meyd.) And hence the saying of Imra-el-Keys, Sm~iY A@bonapa Aljabali, (S, K,) in the following verse:
bud~ilotu mino waAy^ilK wakinodapa Eado
waAna wafahomFA Sam~iY A@bonapa Aljabali
(assumed tropical:) [I have been given in exchange, for Wáïl and Kindeh,' Adwán and Fahm: make no sound, O pebble: app. meaning that he would shed much blood]: (S, TA: but this verse is omitted in one of my two copies of the S:) or the meaning is, O echo; (S, M, Meyd, K;) so they assert: (AHeyth, TA:) or O calamity; the saying being a prov.; (Meyd, TA;) applied to the case of a severe calamity; as though meaning be dumb, O calamity; said by As to be applied in relation to an event deemed excessively foul or evil: (TA:) or O serpent; (Meyd, TA;) which is said to be the primary meaning: (Meyd:) or O rock. (A Heyth, K, TA. [See also the second of the sentences here following.]) One says also, Sam~a SadaAhu (tropical:) [His echo became dumb, or may his echo become dumb;] meaning he perished, or may he perish. (S, K, TA.) And Sam~iY SamaAmi↓ [in the CK erroneously written Sum~iY] meaning (tropical:) Increase, O calamity: (S, K, TA:) or it is applied to a man who brings to pass a calamity, and means be dumb, O calamity: (TA:) or SamaAmi means calamity, and war; but primarily, the serpent; and this saying, like Sam~iY A@bonapa Aljabali, is a prov. said when two parties refuse to make peace, and persist in opposition; meaning answer not the charmer, O serpent, but continue as thou art wont to be. (Meyd.) ― -b4- SamamN in relation to stones, (Lth, TA,) or stone, (M,) [app. as an inf. n.,] signifies The being hard [and solid (see A^aSam~u)]; or [as a simple subst.] hardness [and solidity]: (Lth, M, TA:) and in relation to a spear-shaft, the being compact; or compactness. (M.) One says, Sam~a AlHajaru, inf. n. SamamN, The stone was hard [and solid]. (MA.) And Sam~ati Alfitonapu, meaning [The trial, or civil war, &c.,] was, or became, hard, vehement, or severe. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- Sam~a AlqaAruwrapa, (S, K,) or Sam~N raA^osa AlqaAruwrapi, (M,) aor.
Samu3a
, (PS, [in a copy of the M
Sami3a
, contr. to a general rule in the case of a trans. verb of this class, and app. a mistranscription,]) inf. n. Sam~N, (M,) He stopped the flask or bottle [app. with a SamaAm]: (S, K:)
or he stopped the head of the flask or bottle, and bound it; as also ASm~hu↓: (K:) or ASm~ AlqaAruwrapa signifies he put a SimaAm to the flask or bottle. (S, K.) ― -b2- And Sam~a AljuroHa, aor.
Samu3a
, inf. n. Sam~N, He bound the wound, and put upon it a bandage with medicament. (M.) ― -b3- And Sam~ahu, (S, M, K) inf. n. Sam~N, (M,) He struck him, (S, K,) or it, i. e. his head, (M,) with a staff, or stick, (S, M,) and with a stone, (S, M, K,) and with the like thereof. (M.) And Sum~a, with damm, He was struck vehemently. (IAar, TA.)

2 Sm~m *
2. Sm~m, said of a sword, (S, M, K, TA,) accord. to the K, signifies It struck the joint, and cut, or severed, it: or i. q. Tab~aqa: but this is at variance with what is said by J and other leading authorities; which is as follows: (TA:) it penetrated into the bone, and cut, or severed, it; but when it strikes the joint, and cuts, or severs, it, one says Tab~aqa; a poet says, describing a sword,
yuSam~imu A^aHoyaAnFA waHiynFA yuTab~iqu
[It penetrates into the bone, &c., sometimes, and at one time it strikes the joint, &c.]: (S, TA:) or it passed into the bones: (M:) and SamoSama↓, said of a sword, signifies the same: (M, TA:) or taSomiymN signifies a sword's penetrating into that which is struck with it without its causing any sound to be heard; from AlS~amamu in the ear. (Ham p. 326.) ― -b2- And hence taSomiymN signifies also (tropical:) A man's keeping constantly, or perseveringly, to the thing that he purposes, until he attains [it]. (Ham ubi suprà.) One says, Sam~ama EalaY ka*aA (assumed tropical:) He kept constantly, or perseveringly, to his opinion in respect of such a thing, after his desiring to do it. (IDrd, TA.) ― -b3- And Sm~m, (S, Msb, K, TA,) inf. n. taSomiymN, (M, K,) (tropical:) He acted, or went on, with penetrative energy, or with sharpness, vigorousness, and effectiveness, (S, M, Msb, K, TA,) in an affair, (M, Msb, K, TA,) and in journeying, (S, K, TA,) in this case said of a horse, (Z, TA,) and in other things; (S;) as also SamoSama↓. (K.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) He bit, and infixed his canine teeth, (S, K, TA,) and did not let go what he bit: (S, TA:) or Sm~m fiY EaD~atihi he infixed his teeth [or canine teeth] in his bite. (A, TA.) ― -b5- And Sm~m Alfarasa AlEalafa (tropical:) He (a man) enabled the horse to take of the fodder to such a degree that fat and repletion stuffed him. (K, * TA.) ― -b6- And Sm~m SaAHibahu AlHadiyva (tropical:) He made his companion to retain the narrative, or story, in his memory. (K, * TA.) ― -b7- See also the next paragraph.

4 ASm~ *
4. ASm~, intrans.: see 1, first and fourth sentences. ＝ -A2- ASm~hu He, (God, S, Msb, K,) or it, (a disease, M,) rendered him deaf; (S, * M, * Msb, K; *) [or] caused him to have a stoppage of the ear, and a heaviness of hearing. (M, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A^aSam~aniY AlkalaAma (assumed tropical:) He, or it, diverted me from hearing the speech; as though he, or it, rendered me deaf. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence, ASm~hu signifies also (assumed tropical:) He, or it, caused him to be as though he heard not. ― -b4- And hence, (assumed tropical:) He, or it, caused him, or it, to utter, or make, no sound or noise; like him who, not hearing, returns no reply to a call, or question; to be dumb, or mute.] One says, A^aSam~a A@ll~`hu SadaAhu (tropical:) [May God make his echo to return no sound;] meaning may God destroy him: (TA:) a prov., said in imprecating death upon a man; the Sdy being that which returns the like of his voice, or cry, from the mountains &c.; and when a man dies, the Sdy hears not from him anything that it should answer him, so that it is as though it were deaf. (Meyd.) [In the vulgar language, Sam~ama↓ likewise signifies (assumed tropical:) He silenced him, reduced him to silence, or closed his mouth: so says De Sacy, in his Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., iii. 379.] ― -b5- And ASm~hu [in the CK AaSomamahu] also signifies He found him to be A^aSam~ [i. e. deaf]. (S, M, K.) One says, naAdaAhu faA^aSam~ahu [He called him, or called to him, and found him to be deaf]. (TA.) And A^aSam~a duEaAw^uhu His call found persons deaf to it, (Th, M, K,) who would not hear his censure. (K.) ― -b6- See also 1, near the end.

6 tSAm~ *
6. tSAm~ He feigned himself to be A^aSam~ [i. e. deaf]. (S.) [It is intrans. and trans.] You say, tSAm~ Eanohu and tSAm~hu He feigned to him that he was deaf. (M.) And tSAm~ Eani AlHadiyvi (M, K) and tSAm~hu (M) He feigned (M, K) to his companion (M) that he was deaf to the narrative, or story. (M, K. *) taSaAmamotuhu means taSaAmamotu minohu [or Eanohu], i. e. I made a show of being deaf [to it], and feigned myself inattentive [to it]. (Ham p. 169.)

R. Q. 1 SamoSama *
R. Q. 1. SamoSama: see 2, in two places. ＝ -A2- SamoSamati AlS~im~apu, (TK,) inf. n. SamoSamapN, (K, TK,) The female hedge-hog uttered its cry. (K, * TK.)

AlS~im~u *
AlS~im~u a name for (assumed tropical:) Calamity, or misfortune; (S, TA;) as also AlS~im~apu↓, (TA,) and so SamaAmi↓, like qaTaAmi, in a phrase mentioned in the first paragraph, q. v. (S, K. [See also this last word below.]) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) The lion; (S, M, K;) as also AlS~im~apu↓, (M, Msb, K,) thus called because of his courage, [i. e. from the latter word as signifying “ courageous, ” but accord. to the Msb the reverse is the case,] (M,) and so AlS~umaSimu↓ and AlS~umaASimu↓: (K:) the pl. of Sim~apN↓ is SimamN. (TA.)

Sim~apN *
Sim~apN Courageous; (S, M, Msb, K;) applied to a man; (S, M;) one who renders deaf him whom he smites. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b2- See also the next preceding paragraph, in three places. ― -b3- Also A male serpent: (S, K:) pl. SimamN. (S.) ― -b4- And A female hedge-hog. (K.) ― -b5- See also SamaAmN.

SamamN *
SamamN inf. n. of the intrans. verb Sam~a [q. v.]. (S, * M, Msb, K.) ＝ -A2- See also SimoSimN, in four places.

SamaAmi *
SamaAmi [an imperative verbal noun, like nazaAli &c.]. One says, SamaAmi SamaAmi, meaning Feign ye deafness, in silence. (S, K.) Also meaning Charge ye upon the enemy. (AHeyth, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also (tropical:) Hard, or severe, calamity or misfortune; and so AlS~am~aA='u↓; (K, TA;) [as though] closed up [or obdurate, or deaf to deprecation]: (TA:) or AlS~am~aA='u signifies [simply] calamity, or misfortune: (S:) and daAhiyapN Sam~aA='u↓ signifies a calamity, or misfortune, [as though] closed up, and hard. (M.) See also AlS~im~u, above.

SimaAmN *
SimaAmN The sidaAd [or stopper], (S, M, K,) [i. e.] the thing that is put into the mouth, (Msb,) of a flask, or bottle: (S, M, Msb, K:) and its $idaAd [app. meaning the piece of skin that is tied over the head]: (M:) or accord. to some it signifies the EifaAS [which has the latter meaning]: (Msb:) or it signifies the thing that is put into the head of the flask, or bottle; and EifaAS signifies the “ thing [or piece of skin] that is tied upon it: ” (M:) and SimaAmapN↓ signifies the same as SimaAmN, (IAar, K,) as also Sim~apN↓. (K.) ― -b2- Also The faroj; perhaps for mawoDiEu SimaAmK: (Mgh, TA:) so in a trad., in which it is said that AlwaTo'u should be in one SimaAm: but, as some relate it, the word is there with s [i. e. simaAm]. (TA.)

SamiymN *
SamiymN The bone that is the [main] stay, or support, of the limb or member or the like; (M, K, and Ham p. 302;) as the Smym [or principal bone] of the shank (M and Ham) of a beast, (M,) and that of the head; (M and Ham;) opposed to wa$iyZN, because the latter is smaller than the former: (M:) and the thing that is the [main] stay, or support, of another thing. (Ham p. 359.) ― -b2- [Hence,] The heart: so in a saying of a poet cited voce dalafa. (Ham p. 678.) ― -b3- And hence, also, (TA,) (tropical:) The prime, principal, or most essential, part; (M, K, TA;) the choice, best, or most excellent, part; of a thing (S, M, Msb, K, TA) of any kind. (M.) One says, huwa fiY Samiymi qawomihi (tropical:) [He is of the choice, best, or most excellent, of his people or party; of the main stock thereof; or of those that constitute the members, exclusive of such as are followers, or incorporated confederates, thereof]: (S, TA:) contr. of $aZFY (S in art. $ZY) [and of $iq~N, q. v.]. ― -b4- And (tropical:) The greatest intenseness or vehemence or violence, or the most intense or vehement or violent degree, of heat, and of cold: (S, K, TA:) or simply the intenseness or vehemence or violence thereof. (M.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) The middle [or core] of the heart. (Msb.) ― -b6- And The shell (lit. the dry, or hard, exterior covering) of the egg. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also an epithet, applied to a man, (M, K,) and to a woman, and to two persons (M,) and to a pl. number, (M, K,) (tropical:) Pure, unmixed, or genuine, in respect of race, lineage, or parentage. (M, K, TA.)

SimaAmapN *
SimaAmapN: see SimaAmN.

Sam~aAnN *
Sam~aAnN Hard ground, (M,) [i. e.] any such ground, (K,) containing stones, by the side of sands; as also Sam~aAnapN↓: (M, K:) or the latter is a n. un.; and the former signifies hard ground: (Ham p. 285:) or rugged ground, (S, M,) falling short of what is called jabalN: (M:) it is so called because of its hardness. (TA.)

Sam~aAnapN *
Sam~aAnapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

SamoSamN *
SamoSamN Very niggardly or tenacious: (K:) or niggardly, or tenacious, in the utmost degree.
(IAar, TA.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph. ― -b3- [And see DamoDamN.]

SimoSimN *
SimoSimN, (S, M, K,) applied to a man, (S, M,) Thick: (A'Obeyd, S:) or short and thick: (M, K:) or it signifies, (S,) or signifies also, (K,) bold, or daring; that acts, or proceeds, with penetrative energy, or with sharpness, vigorousness, and effectiveness: (S, K:) and applied to a man and to a horse, (M, K,) and to a mare, (M,) [in like manner,] i. q. muSam~imN↓ [and muSam~imapN (in the CK muSam~amN is erroneously put for muSam~imN) i. e. that acts, or proceeds, with penetrative energy, or with sharpness, vigourousness, and effectiveness], (M, K,) as also SamamN↓, (K, TA,) or SamoSamN↓, (so in a copy of the M,) and SamoSaAmN↓, and SamoSaAmapN↓, and SumaSimN↓, and SumaASimN↓, (M, K, the last omitted in the TA,) and SumaASimapN↓: (K:) or strong, robust, or hardy: or compact in make: (M, in relation to all of these epithets:) or SamamN↓, applied to a man, has the former of these two meanings: or the latter of them; as also SimoSimN, and SumaSimN↓: and, accord. to AO, SamamN↓ applied to a horse, and SamamapN↓ to a mare, signify strong, firm, compact in make. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also SimoSimapN.

SumaSimN *
SumaSimN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places: ― -b2- and see also AlS~im~u.

SamoSamapN *
SamoSamapN inf. n. of R. Q. 1 [q. v.] ＝ -A2- See also the paragraph here following.

SimoSimapN *
SimoSimapN A company, or collection, (M, K,) of men; like zimozimapN; neither of which words is formed by substitution from the other: (M, TA: [in the TA in art. zm, this is said of zimozimapN and DimoDimapN:]) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] SimoSimN↓. (M, K.) ― -b2- Also The middle of a people or party; and so SamoSamapN↓. (K.) ― -b3- And A rugged [hill such as is termed] A^akamap, of which the stones are almost erect. (En-Nadr, TA.)

SamoSaAmN *
SamoSaAmN, (S, K,) or sayofN SamoSaAmN, (M,) and SamoSaAmapN↓, (S, M, K, [in the CK, erroneously, SimoSaAmap,]) A sword, (K,) or a sharp sword, (S, M,) that will not bend. (S, M, K.) AlS~amoSaAmu, (S, K,) or AlS~amoSaAmapu↓, (M,) was the name of The sword of 'Amr Ibn-Maadee-Kerib. (S, M, K.) And some of the Arabs make SamoSaAmapu↓, thus without tenween, imperfectly decl., to be the name of A particular sword. (IB, TA.) ― -b2- See also SimoSimN.

SamoSaAmapN *
SamoSaAmapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places: ― -b2- and see also SimoSimN.

SumaASimN *
SumaASimN: see SimoSimN: ― -b2- and see also AlS~im~u.

SumaASimapN *
SumaASimapN: see SimoSimN.

A^aSam~u *
A^aSam~u applied to any animal, (Mgh,) Deaf; (S, * M, * Mgh, Msb, K; *) [or] having a stoppage of the ear, and a heaviness of hearing; (M, K:) fem. Sam~aA='u: (Mgh, Msb:) pl. Sum~N (M, Msb, K) and Sum~aAnN. (M, K.) A poet says,
A^aSam~u Eam~aA saA='ahu samiyEu
(TA,) a prov., (Meyd,) meaning Feigning himself deaf to that which displeases him, (Meyd, TA,) i. e. to what is foul, (Meyd,) as though he heard it not, (TA,) but hearing (Meyd, TA) that which pleases him, i. e. what is good; as does the generous man. (Meyd.) And similar is the saying,
waliY A^u*onN Eani AlfaHo$aA='i Sam~aA
[And I have an ear deaf to that which is foul]. (TA.) [See also Ham p. 636, for another similar ex.] One says likewise, daEaAhu daEowapa AlA^aSam~i (assumed tropical:) He called him [with the call of the deaf, meaning,] with extraordinary force. (TA.) And Darabahu Daroba AlA^aSam~i (tropical:) He beat him [with the beating of the deaf, meaning,] uninterruptedly and excessively; because the deaf, when he does thus, [not hearing any cry,] imagines that he is falling short of what he should do, and therefore will not leave off. (TA.) And lamaEa bivawobihi lamoEa AlA^aSam~i (assumed tropical:) He (one warning a people from afar) made a sign by waving his garment continually, as does the deaf; as though he heard not the reply. (TA.) And Hay~apN A^aSam~u (M, K, TA) and Sam~aA='u (TA) (tropical:) A serpent that will not accept charming; (M, K, TA;) as though it heard it not; (M;) that will not obey the charmer: (TA:) and [in like manner] the epithet Sum~N is applied to scorpions. (M.) And rajulN A^aSam~u (tropical:) A man whom one does not hope to win over, and who will not be turned back from the object of his desire; (M, K, TA;) as though he were called and would not hear. (M, TA.) And dahorN A^aSam~u (assumed tropical:) [Inexorable fortune;] as though one complained to it and it would not hear. (M.) And AlS~am~aA='u and daAhiyapN Sam~aA='u as expl. voce SamaAmi, q. v. And fitonapN Sam~aA='u (assumed tropical:) A sedition, or the like, that is severe, or hard to be borne; (S, Msb;) to the allaying of which there is no way; because of its having gone to the utmost extent. (TA. [See also A^abokamu.]) And A^amorN A^aSam~u (assumed tropical:) An affair, or event, that is severe, or hard to be borne. (TA.) And SamamN is tropically attributed to AlHilom: (M:) a poet, cited by Th, says,
qulo maA badaA laka mino zuwrK wamino ka*ibK
HilomiY A^aSam~u waA^u*oniY gayoru Sam~aA='i
(tropical:) [the last word I find written thus, app. for the sake of the rhyme: i. e. Say what occurs to thee, of falsehood and of lying: my forbearance is deaf, i. e. insensible, to it, though my ear is not deaf]. (M, TA.) Sam~aA='u is applied to a qaTaAp [or bird of the species termed qaTFA, and may in this case be rendered (assumed tropical:) Small-eared, or dull-eared, being applied thereto] because of the sakak [i. e. smallness &c.] of its ear or because it is deaf when thirsting. (M.) And AlA^aSam~u [as though meaning (tropical:) The deafmute] is an epithet applied to rajab, (S, M, Msb, K,) the month thus named, (Msb,) which the people of the Time of Ignorance called $ahoru A@ll~`hi AlA^aSam~u, (Kh, S,) because the cry of the caller for aid was not heard in it, (Kh, S, M, Msb, K, *) shouting yaA lafulaAnK and yaA SabaAHaAho, (M, K,) nor the commotion of fight, (Kh, S, Msb,) nor the clash of arms, it being one of the sacred months: (Kh, S:) thus applied it is tropical, like naAy^imN in the phrase layolN naAy^imN; as though, in it, the man were deaf to the sound of arms: (TA:) and in like manner it is also called munoSilu AlA^al~i. (M. [See also AlA^aSab~u, and muHar~amN, and $ahorN.]) ― -b2- And [as that which is without a cavity is generally nonsonorous,] one says HajarN A^aSam~u meaning (tropical:) Hard (S, M, Msb, K) and solid (S, Msb, K) stone: (S, &c.:) and SaxorapN Sam~aA='u (tropical:) a hard and solid rock: (K, TA:) or this latter signifies (assumed tropical:) a rock in which is no crack nor hole: pl. Sum~N. (TA.) And qanaApN Sam~aA='u (assumed tropical:) A compact spear-shaft. (M.) ― -b3- AlS~am~aA='u also signifies (assumed tropical:) The earth, or ground. (M:) And A^aroDN Sam~aA='u (assumed tropical:) Rugged ground: pl. Sum~N. (K.) ― -b4- Also [app. (assumed tropical:) The vermiform appendage of the cœcum;] the thin, or slender, extremity of the Efjp: (K: [the last word in this explanation is thus, without any syll. signs, in my MS. copy of the K and in the TA: in the CK, Eafijap: but the right reading is evidently Eifajap, which is said in the TA, in art. Efj, to be, like A^aEofaAjN, a pl. of EafajN and its dial. vars.: see this last word:] thus called [in my opinion because resembling a meatus auditorius that is closed, and therefore deaf; though said to be so called] because of its hardness. (TA.) ― -b5- And naAqapN Sam~aA='u (tropical:) A fat she-camel: (K, TA:) and, (K,) or as some say, (TA,) one that has just conceived, or become pregnant. (K, TA.) ― -b6- Ai$otimaAlu AlS~am~aA='i, (S, Msb, K, TA,) which is forbidden in a trad., (TA,) is (assumed tropical:) The covering oneself with his garment, like [as is done in the case of] the $imolap of the Arabs of the desert with their [garments called] A^akosiyap [pl. of kisaA=']; (A'Obeyd, S;) i. e. the turning the kisaA=', from the direction of one's right, upon his left arm and the part between his left shoulderjoint and neck, and then turning it a second time, from behind him, upon his right arm and the part between his right shoulder-joint and neck, so as to cover them both: (A'Obeyd, S, K:) or the wrapping oneself with the garment without making to it a place from which to put forth the hand: (Msb:) or, (K,) as the lawyers explain it, (A'Obeyd, S,) it is the wrapping one's body and arms with one garment, not having upon him another, and then raising it [in the K, as is said in the TA, yaDaEuhu is erroneously put for yarofaEuhu] on one of its sides, and putting it upon his shoulder, so that his pudendum appears from it: (A'Obeyd, S, K:) [but] with the Arabs, libosapu AlS~am~aA='i means the covering one's whole body with his garment, and not raising a side from which to put forth his hand: (Mgh:) when you say, of a man, Ai$otamala AlS~am~aA='a, it is as though you said, Ai$otamala Al$~imolapa AlS~am~aA='a; for AlS~am~aA=' is a sort of Ai$otimaAl. (S. [See also Ai$otamala, and Al$~imolapu AlS~am~aA='u, in art. $ml.]) ― -b7- ja*orN A^aSam~u (assumed tropical:) A surd, or an irrational, root, in arithmetic; which is known only to God, accord. to a saying of 'Áïsheh: opposed to ja*orN naATiqN. (Mgh in art. j*r.) ― -b8- [fiEolN A^aSam~u A surd verb
is a term sometimes used in grammar, as meaning a triliteral-radical verb of the class commonly called muDaAEafN of which the second and third radicals are the same letter.]

SawotN maSim~N *
SawotN maSim~N A sound, or noise, or voice, that deafens the ear-hole. (TA.)

A^alofN muSam~amN *
A^alofN muSam~amN (assumed tropical:) A thousand completed; like muSam~atN and muSomatN. (TA in art. Smt.)

muSam~imN *
muSam~imN A sword that passes into the bones: (M:) or that penetrates into that which is struck with it. (TA.) ― -b2- See also SimoSimN. ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) A strong camel: so says Aboo-' Amr Esh-Sheybánee: and he cites the saying,
Ham~alotu A^avoqaAliY muSam~imaAtihaA
[as meaning I loaded their strong camels with my burdens]: (TA:) or the muSam~imaAt, here mentioned, are the camels that do not utter a grumbling cry; patient of travel. (Ham p. 791.)

1 Samata *
1. Samata, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb,) aor.
Samuta
, (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. SamotN (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and SumotN (M, L, TA) and SumuwtN and SumaAtN, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) or the first of these is the inf. n. and the rest are simple substs.; (M;) and ASmt↓, (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. A_iSomaAtN; (K;) and Sm~t↓, inf. n. taSomiytN; (S, K; but only the inf. n. is mentioned;) He was, or became, silent, mute, or speechless; syn. sakata: (S, A, Msb, K:) or he was, or became, long silent or mute or speechless: (M, Mgh:) but there is a difference between sakata and Samata; for the former is said of him who has the power, or faculty, of speech, but abstains from making use of it; whereas the latter is sometimes said of that which has not the power, or faculty, of speech. (Er-Rághib, MF and TA in art. skt.) The Arabs say, (Ks, TA,) and it is said in a trad., (TA,) laA Samota yawomFA A_ilaY All~ayoli, or yawomN, or yawomK, i. e. There shall be no keeping silence a whole day [until night]. (Ks, K, TA. [In the “ Jámi' es-Sagheer, ” we find lA SumaAta instead of lA Samota: and El-Munáwee, in his Commentary on that work, says that the keeping silence for a whole day is forbidden by the words of this trad. because it is an imitation of a Christian custom.]) And A_i*onuhaA SumaAtuhaA [in another trad., relating to the asking a virgin if she consent to be married, lit. Her permission is her silence,] means her silence is like her permission, i. e. it suffices. (Msb.) One says also, jaA='a bimaA SaA='a waSamata (assumed tropical:) [He brought what was vocal and what was mute]; maA SaA='a meaning sheep, or goats, and camels; and maA Samata, gold and silver: (IAar, TA:) SaA='a in this saying is formed by transposition from SaA^aY [q. v.]. (S in art. SA^Y.)

2 Sm~thu *
2. Sm~thu, (M, A, K,) inf. n. taSomiytN; (S;) and ASmthu↓; (M, A, Msb, K;) He made him, or rendered him, silent, mute, or speechless: (S, A, Msb, K:) or he made him, or rendered him, long silent or mute or speechless. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Sam~itiY Sabiy~aki Feed thy child with that which will silence it [or quiet it]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- And Sm~t Alr~ajula He inclined to the man who complained to him by reason of his complaint [and so quieted him; or he cared for the complaint of the man and so quieted him; see muSam~itN]. (M, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, first sentence.

4 ASmthu *
4. ASmthu: see 2. ― -b2- [Hence,] lamo yuSomitohu *`lika That did not suffice him [so as to quiet him]: said only of what is eaten and drunk. (TA.) ― -b3- And ASmthu He made it to be solid, not hollow; without a cavity. (A'Obeyd, S, K.) [For that which is without a cavity is generally non-sonorous.] ― -b4- And A^uSomitati AlA^aroDu, or A^aSomatat, (accord. to different copies of the K, the latter accord. to the O,) The land became altered (A^aHaAlat) [so as to be rugged, or hard, app. in consequence of its having been left untilled and unsown,] at the end of two years, (O, K,) and had rugged patches of urine and dung. (O.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, first sentence. ― -b2- A^aSomata also signifies He was, or became, tonguetied, (O, TA,) and spoke not; (TA;) said of a sick man. (O, TA.)

SumotapN *
SumotapN a subst. from Samata [as such signifying Silence, muteness, or speechlessness; like SamotN used as a subst., and SumotN &c.; and like sukotapN and sikotapN]. (M, TA.) ― -b2- And (M, TA) A thing, (M, A, K, TA,) i. e. food, (A, K, TA,) or the like, (K, TA,) such as a date, or something pretty, (TA,) with which one silences [or quiets] (M, A, K, TA) a child; (A, K, TA;) as also SimotapN↓; (Lh, M, TA;) like sukotapN [in this sense as well as in the former sense]. (S.) A date is called Sumotapu AlS~abiY~i [The quieter of the child], (M, TA,) and Sumotapu AlS~agiyri [The quieter of the little one], so in a trad., because when the little one cries, or weeps, he is silenced with it. (TA.) One says, maA EinodahaA Sumotapu layolapK She has not as much as would silence [or quiet] her child during one night. (A.) And maA lahu SumotapN liEiyaAlihi and SimotapN↓ He has not what would feed and silence [or quiet] his household, or family. (Lh, M.)

SimotapN *
SimotapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

maA *uqotu SamaAtFA *
maA *uqotu SamaAtFA [I did not taste, or have not tasted,] anything. (K.)

ramaAhu biSumaAtihi *
ramaAhu biSumaAtihi, (AZ, K, A, K, [in a copy of the M bSimaAtih, but this I think a mistranscription,]) or biSumaAtapK↓, (K accord. to the TA, and so in the M in art. skt,) [both probably correct, for] one says also bisukaAtihi (AZ, S) and bisukaAtapK, (S, M, A, K, in art. skt,) He (a man, AZ, S, or God, A) smote him, or afflicted him, with a thing that silenced him. (AZ, S, M, A, K.) [See ramaAhu bisukaAtK, in art. skt.] ― -b2- SumaAtN signifies also Thirst: (As, TA:) or quickness of thirsting, (M, K, TA,) in men and in beasts. (M, TA.)

fulaAnN EalaY SimaAti AlA^amori *
fulaAnN EalaY SimaAti AlA^amori Such a one is, or was, at the point of accomplishing the affair. (S.) And A^anaA EalaY SimaAti HaAjatiY I am at the point of accomplishing my want. (M.) And baAta EalaY SimaAti A^amorihi He passed the night resolved upon his affair. (TA.) And huwa biSimaAtihi He is at the point of [attaining] his purpose: (M, TA:) Aboo-Málik says that SimaAtN signifies qaSodN [i. e. purpose, intention, &c.]. (TA.) And one says, baAta mina Alqawomi EalaY SimaAtK He passed the night in a place where he was seen and heard by the people, near to them. (S, TA.)

diroEN SamuwtN *
diroEN SamuwtN (tropical:) A coat of mail from which no sound is heard to proceed when it is put on, (S, A, L, TA,) it being soft to the feel, not rough nor rusty: (L, TA:) or a heavy coat of mail. (K.) And jaAriyapN Samuwtu AlxaloxaAlayoni (tropical:) A girl, or young woman, having thick legs, form whose pair of anklets no sound is heard to proceed, (K, TA,) by reason of their being depressed in her legs. (TA. [lahA in the CK is erroneously put for lahumaA.]) And sayofN SamuwtN (assumed tropical:) A sword that penetrates deeply into the thing struck with it [so as not to make a sound by its being repelled by a bone]. (K, TA.) And DarobapN SamuwtN (assumed tropical:) A blow [with a sword or the like] passing among the bones, not recoiling from a bone (M, K, TA) so as to make a sound. (TA.) ― -b2- And $ahodapN SamuwtN (tropical:) A honey-comb that is full; not having a cell empty. (A, K.)

SumaAtap *
SumaAtap: see ramaAhu biSumaAtihi, above.

Sim~iytN *
Sim~iytN, applied to a man, (S,) i. q. sik~iytN, (S, K, TA,) [i. e. Much, or often, silent or mute or speechless; or] long silent &c. (TA.)

SaAmitN *
SaAmitN Silent, mute, or speechless: (Msb:) pl. SaAmituwna (Kur vii. 192) [and SumuwtN, occurring in the K in art. zm]. [Hence,] one says, maA lahu SaAmitN walaA naATiqN (tropical:) [He has not mute nor vocal property; or he has not dead nor live stock]: (S, M, A:) by the former are meant gold and silver; (S, M, Msb, K;) and by the latter, camels, (S, K,) and sheep or goats, (S,) or animals: (M:) i. e. he has not aught. (S.) ― -b2- Also, of camels, (assumed tropical:) Twenty, (O, K,) and the like. (O.) ― -b3- And of milk, (assumed tropical:) Such as is thick. (S, O, K.)

A^aSomatu *
A^aSomatu: see muSomitN.

laqiytuhu biwaHo$i A_iSomita *
laqiytuhu biwaHo$i A_iSomita and bibalodapi A_iSomita AZ explains as meaning [I met him, or met with him, or found him,] in a desert place, in which was no one to cheer by his company: (S: [and in like manner the latter phrase is expl. in the M:]) accord. to Kr, bibalodapK A_iSomita; but the phrase commonly known is bibalodapi A_iSomita: (M:) or tarakotuhu bibalodapi A_iSomita [I left him] in the desert, or waterless desert: or in such a place that it was not known where he was: (K:) and biSaHoraA='i A_iSomita (M, K) meaning as above, (K,) or having the latter of these two meanings: (M:) and biwaHo$i A_iSomita and A_iSomitapa↓, (M, K,) mentioned, but not expl., by Lh, (M,) meaning as above, (K,) or app. meaning in the desert, or waterless desert: (M:) and some say, biwaHo$i AlA_iSomitayoni: (TA:)
ASmt is as above, with the disjunctive alif; and also with the conjunctive [i. e. A@Somita]: (O, K:) it is imperfectly decl., (S, MF, TA,) because combining the quality of a proper name with the fem. gender or with the measure of a verb: (MF, TA:) it is said that the desert, or waterless desert, is thus called because in it one fears much; as though everyone [therein] said to his companion, ASmt [i. e. AuSomuto or A^aSomito, “ Be thou silent ”]; like as they say of a mahomah that it is so called because a man [therein] says to his companion, maho maho: (MA:) [for] accord. to some the word A_iSomit is an imperative changed into a subst., and hence the ' is disjunctive, and it may be with kesr accord. to a dial. var. [of the imperative] that has not reached us: accord. to Yákoot, it is the name of a particular desert; but others say that the proper name [of that desert] is waHo$u A_iSomita. (TA in art. wH$.)

A_iSomitap *
A_iSomitap: see the next preceding paragraph.

muDomatN *
muDomatN [primarily signifies Made, or rendered, silent, mute, or speechless. ― -b2- And hence,] Solid; not hollow; having no cavity. (A 'Obeyd, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K.) [For that which is without a cavity is generally non-sonorous.] ― -b3- And A door, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and a lock, (M, K,) closed, or locked, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) so that one cannot find the way to open it. (S, M, * K. *) A poet says,
wamino duwni layolaY muSomataAtu AlmaqaASiri
[And in the way to Leylà are what are closed, &c., of chambers to which the owner alone has access: maqaASir being used by poetic license for maqaASayr, pl. of maqoSuwrapN]. (TA.) ― -b4- Also A garment, or piece of cloth, of one, unmixed, colour. (M, Mgh, K.) The garment thus termed that is disliked is That of which the warp and woof are both of silk: or such as is woven of undressed silk, and then dressed, and dyed of one colour: (Mgh:) [or] such as is termed muSomatN mino xaz~K, i. e. consisting entirely of silk, not mixed with cotton nor with other material, was forbidden by the Prophet. (TA.) ― -b5- [Hence,] farasN muSomatN A horse of one, unmixed, colour; in which is no colour differing from the rest: (S, A, TA:) pl. xayolN muSomataAtN. (TA.) And A^adohamu muSomatN [applied to a horse] (assumed tropical:) Black unmixed with any other colour. (TA.) ― -b6- [Hence also,] A_inaA='N muSomatN (assumed tropical:) A vessel not silvered, or not ornamented with silver. (Mgh.) And bayoDapN muSomatapN (assumed tropical:) A helmet made of one piece. (AO, TA in art. byD.) And HaloYN muSomatN (assumed tropical:) A woman's ornament that is not intermixed with another: or, accord. to Ahmad Ibn- 'Obeyd, that has stuck fast upon its wearer, so that it does not move about; such as the armlet, and the anklet, and the like. (TA.) ― -b7- The fahod [or lynx, an animal proverbial for much sleeping,] is said to be muSomtu Aln~awomi (tropical:) [app. meaning A heavy sleeper]. (A, TA.) ― -b8- AlHuruwfu AlmuSomatapu are All the letters [of the Arabic alphabet] except those called Huruwfu Al*~alaAqapi [or AlHuruwfu Al*~uloqu]; (M, TA;) i. e. (TA) all the letters except those comprised in the phrase muro binafolK. (K, TA.) [What is here rendered “ except ” (i. e. maA EadaA) is said by MF to be omitted in most of the copies of the K.] ― -b9- See also muSam~ato.

muSomitN *
muSomitN Tongue-tied; (O, TA;) not speaking: (TA:) applied to a sick man [when he is unable to speak]: (O, TA:) and A^FSomatu↓ [signifies the same,] i. q. A^abohamu and mubohamN. (So in copies of the K in art. bhm. [In one of the explanations which I have given of mubohamN in consequence of an omission (to be supplied in Book II.), A^aSomatu is made syn. with muSomatN.])

A^alofN muSam~atN *
A^alofN muSam~atN (assumed tropical:) A thousand completed; (M, K;) like muSat~amN; (M;) as also muSomatN↓. (K.)

muSam~itN *
muSam~itN [A silencer, or quieter: and hence, ― -b2- ] One who cares for another's complaint. (M, * Meyd, TA.) One says, (M, Meyd, TA,) i. e. a rájiz says, addressing a camel belonging to him, (Har p. 642,)
A_in~aka laA ta$okuw A_ilaY muSam~iti
faA@Sobiro EalaY AlHimoli Alv~aqiyli A^awo muti
[Verily thou complainest not to one who cares for thy complaint; therefore endure with patience the bearing of the heavy burden, or die]. (M, Meyd, TA.) ta$okuw A_ilaY gayori muSam~itK, i. e. [Thou complainest] to one who cares not for thy case, is a proverb. (Meyd.)

SamajN *
SamajN [Lamps of the kind called] qanaAdiylu [pl. of qinodiylN]: one of which is called SamajapN: (S, K: [in the K, the former word is called pl. of the latter; but it is a coll. gen. n:]) an Arabic word, an exception to the rule that S and j cannot both occur in a genuine Arabic word: (TA:) or of Greek origin (ruwmiY~N), arabicized: (S:) EshShemmákh says,
waAln~ajomu mivolu AlS~amaji Alr~uwmiy~aAto
[And the asterism, meaning the Pleiades, like the Greek lamps]: (S, MF:) but this does not show the word to be Greek, as the epithet may be added for the purpose of restriction. (MF.)

1 Samaxahu *
1. Samaxahu, (S, A, L, K,) aor.
Samuxa
, inf. n. SamoxN, (L,) He hit, or hurt, his SimaAx [i. e. his ear-hole, or his ear]: (S, A, L, K:) and, accord. to Sh, Samaxatohu Al$~amosu The sun smote, or hurt, his SimaAx. (TA.) ― -b2- Samaxati Al$~amosu wajohahu The sun smote, or hurt, his face: or [in the CK “ and ”] fell vehemently upon it. (A 'Obeyd, K.) ― -b3- Samaxa Eayonahu, (ISk, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (ISk,) He struck his eye with his fist: (ISk, K:) in some of the lexicons, with his hand. (TA.) ― -b4- And Samaxa A^anofahu He crushed, or bruised, his nose. (Lh, TA.) [See also what next follows.]

SamoxN *
SamoxN inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (L.) ― -b2- Also Any blow that leaves a mark; accord. to AZ, upon the face. (TA.)

SimaAxN *
SimaAxN The ear-hole: (S, A, Mgh, K:) the hole, (Msb,) or inner hole, (L,) of the ear, that penetrates to [the interior of] the head: (L, Msb:) and A^uSomuwxN↓ signifies the same: (L, K:) of the dial. of Temeem: (L:) and simaAxN is a dial. var., (S, L,) as also A^usomuwxN: (L:) and, (S, L, Msb, K,) as some say, (S, L, Msb,) the ear itself: (S, L, Msb, K:) pl. A^aSomixapN, (L, Msb,) a pl. of pauc., (L,) and A^aSomaAxN, (A,) [also a pl. of pauc.,] and SumuxN and SamaAy^ixu. (L.) One says, Daraba A@ll~`hu EalaY SimaAxihi, and EalaY A^aSomixatihimo, meaning God made him, and them, to sleep: phrases similar to DarabonaA EalaY A=*aAnihimo, in the Kur [xviii. 10: see art. Drb]. (L.) And h`*aA kalaAmN yuw^olimu A^aSomaAxiY [This is speech that pains my ears]. (A.)

SamuwxN *
SamuwxN [Having merely an ear-hole; as distinguished from A^a*uwnN, meaning “ having an ear, ” i. e. “ having an external ear ”]. (Msb in art. byD.)

A^uSomuwxN *
A^uSomuwxN: see SimaAxN.

1 Samadahu *
1. Samadahu, (S, M, A, Mgh,) aor.
Samuda
, (S, Mgh,) inf. n. SamodN; (S, M, Mgh, K;) and Samada A_ilayohi; (M, A; *) He tended, repaired, betook himself, or directed himself or his course or aim, to, or towards, him, or it; or endeavoured to reach, or attain, or obtain, him, or it; or had recourse to him, or it; syn. qaSadahu: (S, M, A, Mgh, K: *) and so samadahu. (M in art. smd.) One says, Samada A_ilayohi fiY AlHawaAy^iji He repaired, betook himself, or had recourse, to him in exigencies; syn. qaSada. (M.) And Samada AlA^amora, (A,) or Samada Samoda AlA^amori, (M,) He betook himself to the thing, or affair; aimed at it; sought it, or endeavoured after it; or intended, or purposed, it; syn. AiEotamadahu; (A;) or qaSada qaSodahu. (M.) And tSm~d↓ lahu biAlEaSaA He betook himself to him or towards him, or aimed at him, with the staff, or stick; syn. qaSada. (M.) And raA^osahu biAlEaSaA tSm~d↓ He aimed (Eamada) at the main part of his head with the staff, or stick. (M.) ― -b2- Hence, Samada lahu He faced it directly; directed his face exactly towards it. (Mgh.) ― -b3- And He pointed towards it. (Mgh.) ― -b4- And Samadotu lahu Hat~aY A^amokanatoniY minohu gir~apN I sprang and betook myself towards him, watching until heedlessness on his part made me to have him within my power. (L, from a trad. respecting the slaying of Aboo-Jahl.) ― -b5- And Samadahu biAlEaSaA, (A,) inf. n. SamodN, (K,) He struck him, or beat him, with the staff, or stick. (A, K. *) ＝ -A2- AlS~amodu also signifies Aln~aSobu [The setting up, or erecting, a thing]: (K:) one says Samadahu He set it up, or erected, it. (TK.) ＝ -A3- And Samadati Al$~amosu wajohahu, (TK,) inf. n. SamodN, (K,) The sun scorched his face. (K, * TK.) ＝ -A4- Samada AlqaAruwrapa, (M, K,) aor.
Samida
, (M,) or
Samada
, (K,) but this is
strange, for there is no faucial letter, nor any other reason for it, (MF,) He put a SimaAd [q. v.] over, or into, the mouth of the flask, or bottle. (M, K.)

2 Sam~ada
2: [Sm~dhu, said of a number of persons, signifies the same as Samadahu as first expl. above; or, said of a single person, He tended, repaired, &c., repeatedly, or frequently, to him, or it; see its pass. part. n., below.] ＝ -A2- Sm~d raA^osahu, inf. n. taSomiydN, He wound a piece of cloth, or a kerchief, called SimaAd, round his head. (TA.)

3 SAmdhu *

And in a trad. of El-Hajjáj occurs the saying, laA^aqolaEan~aka qaloEa AlS~amogapi [I will assuredly pluck thee away with the plucking away of the piece of gum]; meaning I will assuredly extirpate thee. It is said in a trad. that the SimaAgaAni↓ are the two places where sit the two angels [that note and record the actions of a man]: a saying enjoining the use of the siwaAk. (TA.)

labanN muSomigN *
labanN muSomigN [app. Milk that is gummy; describing biestings not yet clear]. (TA voce SuEoruwrN, q. v.) ― -b2- And $aApN muSomigapN bilibay^ihaA, (O, TA,) in the copies of the K, erroneously, bilabanihaA, (TA,) A ewe, or she-goat, yielding fresh biestings on the first occasion of her being milked. (O, K, * TA.)

HiborN muSam~agN *
HiborN muSam~agN Ink made with [the addition of] Samog [or gum]: but [J says] I know not from whom I heard this. (S.)

dictScrap.label: Smqr: For words mentioned under this head in the K, see art. Sqr.

superEntry.entry:
SimolaAxN *
SimolaAxN The interior of the ear-hole. (K.) ― -b2- And The dirt (S, A, K) of the ear (S) [i. e.] of the ear-hole; (A, K;) and the scales that come forth therefrom; (TA;) as also SumoluwxN↓; (S, K;) and so simolaAxN and sumoluwxN: (K and TA in art. smlx:) pl. SamaAliyxu. (TA.)

SumoluwxN *
SumoluwxN: see above. ― -b2- Also sing. of SamaAliyxu (TA) which signifies The thin, or slender, shoots of the A^uSuwl [i. e. stems, or lower parts,] of the naSiY~ (K, TA) and of the Sil~iyaAn: (TA:) or the sing. signifies the A^umoSuwx of the naSiY~; which is a kind of thing that is plucked therefrom, resembling a rod. (AHn, TA.)

SumaAlixN *
SumaAlixN Thick milk, (S, K,) of a consistency resembling liver, so that it quivers. (S.)

SumaAlixiY~N *
SumaAlixiY~N and sumaAlixiY~N signify the same; (ISh, K;) i. e. Milk collected in a skin, and buried in a hole dug in the earth, and left until it becomes thick, or coagulates: (ISh, TA:) or food, and milk, having no taste. (IAar, TA.)

1 SamaY *
1. SamaY, (K,) aor. yaSomiY, (TK,) inf. n. SamayaAnN, He (a man, TK) hastened, made haste, sped, or went quickly; (K, TA;) and was light, active, or agile; this is said by Aboo-Is-hák [i. e. Zj] to be the primary signification; (TA;) as also ASmY↓. (K.) ― -b2- And SamayaAnN, (S, M, K,) likewise an inf. n. of which the verb is SamaY, aor. as above, said of a man, (TK,) signifies [also] The act of escaping, or getting loose or at liberty, syn. tafal~utN, (M, and so in some copies of the S, in other copies of the S and in the K taqal~ubN, [but the latter I regard as a mistake, and so it is said to be in the TK,]) and leaping. (S, M, K.) ― -b3- SamaY, aor. as above, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. SamoYN, (Msb,) said of an animal that is an object of the chase, means He died (S, Msb, K) in one's sight, (S, Msb,) or on the spot. (K.) ＝ -A2- SamaAhu AlA^amoru, (Lth, K,) aor. as above, (TA,) The thing, or event, betided him, or befell him. (Lth, K.) ― -b2- And maASamaAka Ealayohi What incited, urged, induced, or made, thee to do it? (K, TA.)

3 SAmY maniy~atahu *
3. SAmY maniy~atahu He tasted, or experienced, his destiny, or death; as also ASmAhA↓. (M.)

4 A^aSomaya
4: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- ASmY EalaY lijaAmihi, said of a horse, He champed his bit, (S, M, K,) and went away, or along. (S, M.) ＝ -A2- ASmY AlS~ayoda He shot the chase, or game, in such a manner that it died (S, Mgh, Msb, K) in his sight, (S, Msb,) before him, (Mgh, Msb,) quickly, (Mgh,) or on the spot: (K:) accord. to Az, he killed it by means of his dog, in his sight; but it applies also to the case of killing with an arrow: (Msb, TA:) A^anomaY is said when the chase, or game, goes out of one's sight (Mgh, Msb) after having been [seized by the dog or] hit [by the arrow], (Mgh,) and then dies, (Mgh, Msb,) so that one knows not whether it died by his dog or his arrow
or by some accident. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., kulo maA A^aSomayota wadaEo maA A^anomayota [Eat thou what thou hast pursued, or shot, so that it has died in thy sight, and leave what thou hast pursued, or shot, in the case of its dying out of thy sight]. (S, Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- And ASmY Alr~amiy~apa He transpierced the animal that he shot at, or shot. (M.) And ASmt Alqawosu Alr~amiy~apa The bow sent its arrow through the animal shot. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 3.

7 AnSmY Ealayohi *
7. AnSmY Ealayohi He darted down, or rushed, (AinoSab~a, S, K, or AinoqaD~a, M, [both meaning the same,]) upon him, (S, M, K,) and advanced towards him (M,) to which Az adds, like as the hawk, or falcon, darts down (yanoSamiY, i. e. yanoqaD~u). (TA.)

SamayaAnN *
SamayaAnN [an inf. n. used as] an epithet applied to a man, (S, M, A, &c.,) Quick, or swift: (Har p. 93: [see 1, first sentence:]) courageous; (S, M, K;) earnest, not making a false show of bravery, in the charge, or assault: (M, K:) and strong, and mature in age: (M, TA:) or the same word, (accord. to the TA,) or Simiy~aAnN↓, (so in this sense accord. to a copy of the M,) one who rushes (yanoSamiY) upon men injuriously: (M, TA:) accord. to the T, one who seizes upon men unjustly: accord. to IAar, daring in acts of disobedience: accord. to Z, applied to a man, it signifies timoDaA='N EalaY AlA^umuwri [i. e. one who executes, performs, or accomplishes, affairs with energy; or who keeps, or applies himself, thereto with much constancy or perseverance: timoDaA='N being an intensive epithet, like tikolaAmN and tiloqaAmN &c.]: (TA:) the pl. of SamayaAnN is SimoyaAnN. (Kr, M, TA.)

Simiy~aAnN *
Simiy~aAnN: see the next preceding paragraph.

1 San~a *
1. San~a, [aor., accord. to rule,
Sani3a
,] said of flesh-meat, i. q. Sal~a [i. e. It was, or became, stinking]: either a dial. var. or formed by substitution. (M, TA. [See also the next paragraph.])

4 ASn~ *
4. ASn~ He, or it, (a man, S, or a thing, Msb,) had a foul, or fetid, odour, such as is termed SunaAn: (S, Msb, K:) so too said of a he-goat, when excited by lust. (TA.) And said of flesh-meat, [like San~a,] It stank. (TA.) And ASn~t Albaqolapu The herb, or leguminous plant, when held in the hand, stank. (TA.) And ASn~ said of water, It became altered [for the worse]. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also He elevated his nose, (S, K,) or his head, (ISk, TA,) from pride. (ISk, S, K.) And hence, (S,) ASn~t said of a she-camel, She, having conceived, behaved disdainfully to the stallion. (S, K.) ― -b2- And He was, or became, angry. (K.) ＝ -A3- ASn~t said of a she-camel, (ISh, M,) or of a mare, (A 'Obeyd, K,) when near to bringing forth, (A 'Obeyd,) Her young one struggled, or was in a state of commotion, (A 'Obeyd, M,) in the part bordering upon her tail [so I render fiY SalaAhaA], (A 'Obeyd,) or its hind leg fell [or happened to come] into that part; (M;) or her young one stuck fast in her belly, and it pushed with its head, (ISh, K,) or with its shank and its nose, (ISh,) in the region of her anus. (ISh, K.) The epithet applied to her in this case is muSin~N↓: (ISh:) and the pl. is muSin~aAtN and maSaAn~u. (Az, TA.) ＝ -A4- ASn~t said of a woman, She became old, but having in her some remains [of vigour]: and such is termed muSin~N↓ and muSin~apN. (M.) ＝ -A5- ASn~ also signifies He spoke in a low, faint, gentle, or soft, manner. (TA.) ＝ -A6- And ASn~ EalaY AlA^amori He persevered, or persisted, in the affair. (K.)

San~N *
San~N, (S, M, TA,) with fet-h, (S, TA,) accord. to the K, Sin~N, which is wrong, (TA,) [A kind of basket;] a thing like a covered sal~ap, in which bread is put, (S, K, TA,) and [other] food: (TA:) a large zabiyl, like the sal~ap. (M.)

Sin~N *
Sin~N The urine of the wabor [or hyrax Syriacus], (S, M, TA,) in the copies of the K erroneously said to be of camels: (TA:) it is inspissated for medicines; (M, TA;) and is very fetid. (TA.) Sin~u Alwabori is also a term applied to Small, round, flattened cakes, (A^aqoraAS,) which are brought from El-Yemen to El-Hijáz, found there in caves; having the property of dissolving tumours, applied as a plaster with honey: mentioned by the hakeem Dáwood. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, (M, TA,) thus, without the art., but written by Az and J with it, i. e. AlS~in~u, as in the K, (TA,) One of the days called A^ay~aAmu AlEajuwzi; (S, M, K;) said to be the first of those days. (M. [See art. Ejz.])

Sun~apN *
Sun~apN i. q. Sub~apN [q. v.] as signifying A suforap, or a thing like the suforap. (M in art. Sb.)

Sin~apN *
Sin~apN: see the next paragraph.

SunaAnN *
SunaAnN A stink, or stench; (M, Msb;) whether of the armpit or otherwise: (Msb:) or, (S, K,) as also Sin~apN↓, (K,) the stink, or stench, of the armpit, (S, K,) and of the creases of the body when they are in a corrupt state: and the former is likewise applied to the odour of the he-goat when excited by lust: (TA:) and it signifies also, (TA,) or as some say, (M,) a sweet odour. (M, TA.)

San~aAnN *
San~aAnN A courageous man. (K.)

A^aSan~u *
A^aSan~u A man feigning himself unmindful, inadvertent, or heedless. (K.)

muSin~N *
muSin~N A man having a foul, or fetid, odour, such as is termed SunaAn; fem. with p: and likewise applied to a he-goat when excited by lust. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And Elevating the nose, (S, M, TA,) or the head, (AA, TA,) from pride, (AA, S, M, TA,) or from anger. (M.) So in a verse cited in art. xfD. (S.) ― -b2- And muSin~N gaDabFA Full of anger. (As, S.) ＝ -A3- See also 4, latter part, in two places. ＝ -A4- Also Silent. (TA.) ＝ -A5- And AlmuSin~u signifies The serpent that, when it bites, kills on the spot: one says, ramaAhu A@ll~`hu biAlmuSin~i Almusokiti [May God smite him with the silencing serpent that kills on the spot whomsoever it bites]. (IKh, TA.)

SinaAbN *
SinaAbN A sauce made of mustard (S, M, A, K) and raisins. (S, A, K.) ＝ -A2- And Long in the back and belly; as also SinaAbapN↓: (IAar, O, K:) and so each with s. (IAar, O.)

SinaAbapN *
SinaAbapN: see what immediately precedes.

SinaAbiY~N *
SinaAbiY~N, applied to a horse (M, A, TA) or similar beast, (M, TA,) or to a hackney, (TA,) and to a camel, (M, TA,) Of a colour between redness and yellowness, (M, A, K, TA,) with abundance of hair, and of fur: (TA:) or of a bay, or dark bay, or brown, colour; syn. kumayotN: (S, O, K:) or of a sorrel colour; syn. A^a$oqaru: (K:) or of this last colour having some white hairs intermixed therewith: (S, O, TA:) so called because his colour resembles the sauce termed SinaAb: (TA:) SinaAbiY~N being a rel. noun from SinaAbN. (S, O, TA.)

miSonabN *
miSonabN Addicted to, or fond of, eating the sauce termed SinaAb. (IAar, O, K.)

Q. 1 Sanobarati Aln~axolapu *
Q. 1. Sanobarati Aln~axolapu The palm-tree became solitary, or apart from others: (M:) or became slender in its lower part, and bared of the stumps of its branches, and scanty in its fruit. (M, K.) And Sanobara A^asofalu Aln~axolapi The lower part of the palm-tree became slender, and stripped of the external parts [or of the stumps of the branches]. (AO, and S in art. Sbr, and TA.)

SanobarN *
SanobarN, (K, TA,) or SunobuwrN↓, (O,) [both probably correct,] Anything slender and weak, (O, K, TA,) of animals and of trees [&c.]: (O, TA:) [the reg. pl. of the former is SanaAbiru: and hence, app.,] ― -b2- SanaAbiru↓ signifies Slender arrows; (T, M;) accord. to IAar: [ISd says,] I have not found it save on his authority; and he has not mentioned a sing. thereof: (M:) [but] accord. to the T, they are so called as being likened to the SanaAbir [a pl. of SunobuwrN] of the palm-tree: (TA:) occurring in this sense in a verse cited voce *il~apN. (IAar, T, M.)

SinobirN *
SinobirN, and SinaborN, and AlS~inaboru: see Sin~aborN.

SanobarapN *
SanobarapN Ground that has become rough by reason of urine and of dung, or compacted dung, of oxen or sheep &c., (K, TA,) and the like. (TA.) ― -b2- A^axa*otu Al$~aYo'a biSanobaratihi and biSinobiratihi and biSanowabirihi [which last is evidently, I think, a mistranscription for biSanawobarihi↓] is a saying mentioned by Ibn- 'Abbád as meaning I took the thing altogether. (O.)

Sin~aborN *
Sin~aborN, (S, in art. Sbr, M, O, K,) originally SinaborN↓, (O,) Cold, as a subst.; (M, O;) as also Sin~iborN: (O:) or cold clouds: (IDrd, O:) or a cold wind (M, K) with mist or clouds: (M:) occurring in a verse of Tarafeh with kesr to the b: (M:) [see also SunobuwrN:] or Sin~abirN, occurring in that verse, signifies the intense cold of winter; (S in art. Sbr;) as also SanaAbiru↓, (S, K,) of which the
sing. is SunobuwrN↓. (TA.) On the expression of Tarafeh, Hiyna haAja AlS~in~abiro, [when the cold wind, with mist, rises,] ending a verse, IJ says that the poet means AlS~in~aboru; but requiring to make the b movent, he transfers to it the final vowel, as in the phrases h`*aA bakuro and mararotu bibakiro: he should therefore have said AlS~in~aburo; but regarding the expression as meaning Hiyna hayoji AlS~in~abori, he makes the b to be with kesr, as though he transferred to it the kesreh of the r: this, he adds, is more probable than the opinion that the change is merely one of poetic necessity. (M.) For this last reason, another poet uses the word with teshdeed to the n and r, and with kesr to the b; saying,
nuToEimu Al$~aHoma waAls~adiyfa wanasoqiY A@lo
maHoDa fiY AlS~in~abir~i waAlS~ur~aAdi
[We give to eat fat and the hump of the camel, and we give to drink pure milk, in the time of cold wind and chill mist]. (K.) ― -b2- Also AlS~in~aboru, (M, K,) or AlS~inaboru↓, (as in two copies of the S in art. Sbr,) and Sin~aborN, [without the article Al, occurring in a verse of which the metre requires it to be thus written, with teshdeed to the n,] (TA,) One, (S,) namely, the second, (M, K,) of the days called A^ay~aAmu AlEajuwzi: (S, M, K: [see EajuwzN:]) AlS~inaboru [or AlS~in~aboru] and AlS~in~abiru may have the same meaning, [or meanings, or may both be applied to the day above mentioned, for the application of Sin~aborN to that day is certain;] poetic necessity requiring the b to be movent. (S.) ― -b3- Sin~abirN has also two contr. significations, namely, Hot: and cold: accord. to Th, on the authority of IAar. (M.) You say gadaApN Sin~abirN, (M,) or Sin~aborN, (K,) and SinobirN↓, (as in a copy of the M,) or Sin~iborN, (K,) A cold morning: (M, K:) and a hot morning. (K.)

SunobuwrN *
SunobuwrN A solitary palm-tree, apart from others, (AO, S in art. Sbr, and M, A in art. Sbr, and K,) the lower part of which becomes slender, (S and A in art. Sbr,) and stripped of the external parts [or the stumps of the branches]: (S ubi suprà:) and a palm-tree slender in its lower part, and bared of the stumps of its branches, and scanty in its fruit; (M, K;) as also SunobuwrapN↓: (M:) and a palm-tree that comes forth from the root, or lower part, of another palm-tree, without being planted: (M:) or a little palm-tree that does not grow from its mother-tree: (Ibn-Sim'án:) and the lowest part of a palm-tree, (AHn, Ibn-Sim'án, M, K,) from which the roots branch off: (AHn, M:) and branches that come forth from the lowest part of a palm-tree: (M, K:) or a branch that comes forth from the trunk of a palmtree, not from the ground: this is [said to be] the original signification: (T, TA:) or branches that come forth from the trunk of a palm-tree, not having their roots in the ground: such branches weaken the mother-tree, which is cured by pulling them off: the pl. is SanaAbiyru (IAar) and SanaAbiru↓: (T, TA:) and the SanaAbiyr are also called rawaAkiybu and Eiq~aAnN. (Ibn-Sim'án.) ― -b2- Hence, (A,) applied to a man, Solitary; lonely: (IAar:) or solitary, or lonely, without offspring and without brother: (S, A:) or solitary, weak, vile, or ignominious, having no family nor offspring nor assistant: (M, K:) or having no offspring, nor kinsfolk or near relations, nor assistant, whether of strangers or relations: and weak: (IAar:) and mean, or ignoble.
