SuwlapN mino HinoTapK and HinoTapN muSaw~alapN↓ [signify nearly the same, the former meaning A heap of wheat, and the latter wheat in general, cleared from rubbish by means of the implement called miSowalap or miSowal]: (O, K: [these significations are clearly indicated in the K, and more so in the O, by the context:]) the pl. of SuwlapN is SuwalN. (O.)

SiylapN *
SiylapN, mentioned here in the K: see art. Syl.

Saw^uwlN *
Saw^uwlN A camel that devours his pastor; that springs upon men, and devours them: (Lth, TA:) a camel that kills men, and springs, or rushes, upon them: (S:) or a camel that leaps, or springs, upon the [other] camels, and fights them: (Msb:) or a stallion that fights the [other] camels, (M, K,) and sends them on before. (M.) And (assumed tropical:) A man who beats others, and overbears, overpowers, or subdues, them. (TA.) Accord. to Az, it is originally without ', and is app. pronounced with ' because the w is with damm. (TA.)

SiyaAlN *
SiyaAlN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (M, O, Msb, K.) ― -b2- [And also an inf. n. of 3, q. v.]

SiyaAlapN *
SiyaAlapN: see 3: and see also SawolapN.

A^aSowalu mino jamalK *
A^aSowalu mino jamalK [More impetuous than a camel; or more wont to spring upon others, or to assault, or assail, them, than a camel]. (TA.)

miSowalN *
miSowalN A thing in which colocynths are soaked in order that their bitterness may depart. (AZ, S, O, K.) ― -b2- And, accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, An implement with which the ears of corn are swept away, or cleared, from the pieces of stick and of rubbish. (O. [See also what next follows.])

miSowalapN *
miSowalapN A broom (mikonasapN, O, K) with which the sides of the bayodar [or collected wheat or grain, or perhaps the place in which wheat or grain is trodden out,] are swept [to clear it of rubbish]: (O, TA:) so says IAar. (TA. [See also what next precedes.])

HinoTapN muSaw~alapN *
HinoTapN muSaw~alapN: see SuwlapN mino HinoTapK.

SawolajN *
SawolajN and SawolajapN: see what here follows.

SawolajaAnN *
SawolajaAnN (T, S, K) and SawolajaAnapN↓ (Sb, TA) and SawolajN↓ (T, TA) and SawolajapN↓, (TA,) as also Saw~ajaAnN, (L in art. Swj,) [A kind of goff-stick, or golf-stick, played with by men on horseback;] a stick with a curved, or crooked, end; syn. miHojanN; (S, K;) [or rather] a stick of which the end is curved [artificially] with which a ball is struck by men on horseback: a stick of which the end curves, or crooks, naturally, on its tree, is called miHojanN: (T, TA:) of Pers. origin, (S,) [i. e. from the Pers. JawoGaAno,] arabicized: (T, S:) pl. SawaAlijapN; (S, K;) the p being added in the pl. because of the foreign origin, (S, M, TA,) as is mostly the case in broken pls. of words of foreign origin. (M, TA.)

SawolajaAnapN *
SawolajaAnapN: see the next paragraph here preceding.

1 SaAma *
1. SaAma, (S, M, &c.,) aor. yaSuwmu, (Msb,) inf. n. SawomN, and SiyaAmN; (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) and AiSoTaAma↓; (M, K;) He abstained, (Msb, TA,) in an absolute sense: (Msb:) this is the primary signification: (TA:) [or] this is said to be the signification in the proper language of the Arabs: (Msb:) and in the language of the law, (Msb, TA,) he observed a particular kind of abstinence; (Msb;) i. e. (TA) he abstained from food (S, M, K, TA) and drink (M, K, TA) and coïtus: (M, K:) and (S, * M, &c.) by a tropical application, (TA,) (tropical:) from speech: (S, * M, Mgh, Msb, * K, TA:) or SawomN in the proper language of the Arabs signifies a man's abstaining from eating: and by a secondary application, a particular serving of God [by fasting]; (Mgh;) [i. e.] the abstaining from eating and drinking and coïtus from daybreak to sunset: (KT:) accord. to Kh, it signifies [properly] the standing without work. (S.) SAm Al$~ahora means SAm fiY Al$~ahori [He fasted during the month]: agreeably with what is said in the Kur ii. 181. (TA.) And it is said (S, M) by I'Ab (S) that the saying, in the Kur [xix. 27], (S, M,) A_in~iY na*arotu lilr~aHom`ni SawomFA means (assumed tropical:) [Verily I have vowed unto the Compassionate] an abstaining from speech. (S, M, Msb.) One says also, SAm Alfarasu, inf. n. SawomN (S, M) and SiyaAmN, (M,) (assumed tropical:) The horse stood without eating of fodder; (S;) or abstained from the eating of fodder. (M, A, Mgh.) And SAm Eani Als~ayori (tropical:) He abstained from going along, or journeying. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,]
SAmt Al$~amosu (assumed tropical:) The sun became [apparently] stationary [in the mid-heaven]: (T, TA:) or attained its full height. (M, TA.) ― -b3- And SAm Aln~ahaAru, (inf. n. SawomN, S,) (tropical:) The day reached its midpoint. (S, M, Mgh, K, TA.) ― -b4- And SAmt Alr~iyHu, (M, TA,) inf. n. SawomN, (S, K,) (tropical:) The wind became still, or calm. (S, M, K, TA.) ― -b5- And SAm AlmaA='u, [inf. n. SiyaAmN (see SulaAqapN) and probably SawomN also,] (assumed tropical:) The water became still, or motionless; syn. qaAma and daAma. (TA.) ― -b6- And SAm Aln~aEaAmu, (M, K,) inf. n. SawomN, (M,) (tropical:) The ostrich cast forth its dung; (M, K, TA;) and in the same sense the verb is used in relation to the domestic fowl; because each stands still in doing this, or because each becomes tranquil by reason of the passing forth of that which occasions annoyance: and accord. to [some one or more of the copies of] the M, SAm Aln~ahaAru, inf. n. SawomN, The nhAr, by which is here meant the young one of the karawaAn, [or rather of the bustard called HubaAraY,] cast forth what was in its belly. (TA.) ＝ -A2- SAm maniy~atahu i. q. *aAqahaA [He tasted, or experienced, his death]. (K.) ＝ -A3- And SaAma He (a man) shaded himself by means of the tree called Sawom. (K.)

8 A_iSotawama
8: see 1, first sentence.

SawomN *
SawomN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, M, &c.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlS~awomu [app. for waqotu AlS~awomi] means also (tropical:) [The month of] Ramadán: (K, TA:) whence the saying of Aboo-Zeyd, A^aqamotu biAlbaSorapi Sawomayoni, meaning [I remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in El-Basrah] two Ramadáns. (TA.) ― -b3- And [in like manner] SawomN also means (assumed tropical:) A Christian church; syn. biyEapN: (S, K, TA:) as though for maHal~u AlS~awomi i. e. Alwaqofi [the place of station: for, as Hooker says, speaking of the ancient usage of the Church, “ their manner was to stand at prayer, whereupon their meetings unto that purpose had the names of stations given them ”]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also SaAy^imN. ＝ -A3- Also (assumed tropical:) The dung of the ostrich. (S, M, K.) ＝ -A4- And, in the dial. of Hudheyl, (S,) Certain trees, (S, M,) or a certain tree, (K,) [but] the n. un. is with p, of the form of the figure of a human being, (M,) ugly in appearance, (M, K,) very much so, the fruits of which are called ruw^uwsu Al$~ayaATiyni, i. e. [the heads] of the serpents, [see $ayoTaAnN and zaq~uwmN,] not having leaves: AHn says that they have [what are termed] hadab [q. v.], their branches do not spread forth, they grow in the manner of the [species of tamarisk called] A^avol, but are not so tall, and mostly grow in the districts of Benoo-Shebábeh. (M.)

SaAmapN *
SaAmapN, for SawomapN, inf. n. of un. of SaAma: see a verse cited voce taAba, in art. twb.

SawomaAnu *
SawomaAnu: see SaAy^imN.

A^aroDN SawaAmN *
A^aroDN SawaAmN Dry land or ground, in which is no water. (K.)

Saw~aAmN *
Saw~aAmN is like SaAy^imN but having an intensive signification [i. e. meaning Abstaining, &c., much or often]. (Msb.) One says rajulN Saw~aAmN qaw~aAmN, meaning A man who fasts (yaSuwmu) [often] in the day, and who rises [often] in the night [to pray]. (TA.)

SaAy^imN *
SaAy^imN Abstaining, in an absolute sense: this is said to be the signification in the proper language of the Arabs: and in the language of the law, observing a particular kind of abstinence; (Msb;) [i. e.] abstaining from food (S, M, K) and drink and coïtus: and, [by a tropical application, (see 1, first sentence,)] (tropical:) from speech: (M, K:) it is applied to a man: (S, M, Msb:) and SawomaAnu↓ signifies the same, (S, K,) so applied; (S;) as also SawomN↓, (M, K,) applied to a man, (M,) and to a woman, and to two men, (TA,) and to a pl. number; (M, K;) being an inf. n. used as an epithet; (TA;) or it is a pl., [or rather quasi-pl. n.,] like zaworN: (M voce DayofN:) or, in the proper language of the Arabs, SaAy^imN signifies abstaining from eating: and by a secondary application, serving God in a particular manner [by fasting: see again 1, first sentence]: (Mgh:) accord. to AO, it signifies any creature abstaining from food, or (assumed tropical:) from speech, or (assumed tropical:) from going along or journeying: (S, Msb:) pl. SiyaAmN and Suw~amN (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and Suy~amN (S, M, Msb, K) and Siy~amN and Suw~aAmN and Suy~aAmN and SayaAmaY, (M, K,) the last of which [written in the CK SuyaAmaY] is extr. (M.) ― -b2- Applied to a horse, (assumed tropical:) Standing still (S, (M, Msb) without eating of fodder (S, Msb) or without eating anything: (M:) or abstaining from the eating of fodder: (Mgh:) or standing upon his four legs. (Az in art. Swn, and TA.) ― -b3- And bakorapN SaAy^imapN (assumed tropical:) A sheave of a pulley that remains still, (Mgh, TA,) that will not revolve. (S, Mgh, TA.) ― -b4- And maA='N SaAy^imN (assumed tropical:) Water that is still, or motionless; syn. qaAy^imN and daAy^imN. (Mgh, TA.)

maSaAmN *
maSaAmN (tropical:) The station, or standing-place, of a horse; as also maSaAmapN↓. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- And maSaAmu Aln~ajomi (assumed tropical:) The [imaginary] place of suspension of the asterism [meaning the Pleiades]. (M.) Imra-el-Keys says,
kaA^an~a Alv~uray~aA Eul~qato fiY maSaAmihaA
biA^amoraAsi kat~aAnK A_ilaY Sum~i janodali
[As though the Pleiades were hung, in their place of suspension, by means of ropes of flax, to hard and solid rocks: i. e. they seemed as though they were stationary: he means that the night was tedious to him]. (S. [See EM p. 36, where a reading of the former hemistich different from that above is given, with the same and another reading of the latter hemistich.]) ― -b3- One says also, jiy^otuhu waAl$~amosu fiY maSaAmihaA, meaning (assumed tropical:) [I came to him when the sun was] in the middle of the sky. (TA.)

maSaAmapN *
maSaAmapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

1 SaAnahu *
1. SaAnahu, (M, K,) first pers. Sunotuhu, (S, Msb,) aor. yaSuwnuhu, (TA,) inf. n. SawonN and SiyaAnN and SiyaAnapN, (S, M, Msb, K,) He preserved it, kept it, laid it up, took care of it, or reserved it, (Msb, K,) in its repository; (Msb;) and ADTAnhu↓ signifies the same: (M, K:) but one should not say ASAnhu, as the vulgar say. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence] one says, (M, Msb,) by way of comparison, (M,) SAn EiroDhu, (M, Msb,) inf. n. SiyaAnapN and SawonN, (M,) (assumed tropical:) [He preserved his honour, or reputation], Eani Ald~anasi [from pollution]. (Msb. [See also 6.]) And fulaAnN yaSuwnu diybaAjatayohi i. e. (tropical:) [Such a one preserves from disgrace] his cheeks; (A in art. dbj;) or diybaAjatahu his face. (Har p. 15.) ― -b3- And SAn Alfarasu Eadowahu (M, TA) and jaroyahu, (TA,) inf. n. SawonN, (tropical:) The horse reserved somewhat of his running for the time of need. (M, TA.) And farasN lahu SawonN waba*olN; and *uw SawonK waA@boti*aAlK: see 1 in art. b*l. ― -b4- And SAn Alfarasu, aor. yaSuwnu, inf. n. SawonN, means Saf~a bayona rijolayohi [app. the same as Saf~a rijolayohi He set his hind legs evenly, side by side]: (M:) or he stood upon the extremity of his hoof, (S, M, K,) by reason of [attenuation, or abrasion, such as is termed] wajFY or HafFA. (S, K.) ― -b5- And SAn, inf. n. SawonN, He (a horse) limped, or halted, much; (M;) or, as expl. by IB, slightly. (TA.) yaSun~a Alma$oYa occurs in a verse (S, M, TA) of En-Nábighah, (M, TA,) [referring to horses,] and J says that As knew it not, but that others expl. it as meaning Reserving somewhat of the rate of going, (TA,) or as meaning suffering pain in the hoofs from attenuation, or abrasion: (S:) accord. to IB, it means limping, or halting, and suffering pain in the hoofs, from fatigue. (TA.)

5 taSaw~ana
5: see the next paragraph.

6 taSaAwunN *
6. taSaAwunN is the contr. of Aiboti*aAlN, (Msb,) or of taba*~ulN: (S and Msb in art. b*l:) one says, of a man, taSaAwana and taSaw~ana↓, the latter on the authority of IJ, (M, TA,) and mentioned also by Z, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He preserved himself, or his honour, or reputation, (M, TA,) mina AlmaEaAyibi [from the things, or actions, for which he should be blamed], (TA. [See also 1, second sentence.])

8 A_iSotawana
8: see 1, first sentence.

SawonN *
SawonN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, M, &c.) See also SiynapN, below. ― -b2- And see maSuwnN.

SawonapN *
SawonapN [A receptacle for perfumes &c., such as is commonly called] an Eatiydap. (IAar, K.)

SiynapN *
SiynapN [originally SawonapN] i. q. SawonN↓: one says, h`*ihi viyaAbu AlS~iynapi i. e. AlS~awoni [These are the garments of reservation for wear on extraordinary occasions]: (M, TA:) contr. of bi*olapN. (TA.)

SiwaAnN *
SiwaAnN and SuwaAnN (S, M, Msb, K) and SawaAnN (K) and SiyaAnN (S, Msb, K) and SuyaAnN and SayaAnN, (K,) but the third and the last two are extr., (TA,) A thing, (M, Msb, K,) or receptacle, (S,) [or chest or the like,] used as a repository (S, M, Msb, K) for a garment, (S, K,) as also maSaAnN↓, (Skr, cited by Reiske in Abulf. Ann. ii. 614,) [or for clothes,] or for a thing: (M, Msb:) pl.
A^SownapN: (MA:) or maSaAnN↓ signifies any place in which one reposits a garment. (TA in art. Drs.)

SawaAniY~u *
SawaAniY~u pl. of SiyniY~N. (KL.) See art. Syn.

Saw~aAnN *
Saw~aAnN [Flint-stone; and flint-stones: thus in the present day:] a sort of stones, (S, Msb,) in which is hardness; (Msb;) hard stones, (M, K,) of a certain sort, (K,) with which fire is struck: or, as some say, certain black stones which are not hard: (M:) or a sort of hard stones, which, when fire smites it, crackles (yufaq~iEu) and cracks, and sometimes fire is struck with it, but it is not fit for [making] time, nor for heating for the purpose of roasting thereon: (Az, TA:) one thereof is called Saw~aAnapN↓. (S, M, Msb, K.)

AlS~aw~aAnapu *
AlS~aw~aAnapu The dubur [meaning anus]: (K, TA:) so called because it keeps [from escape] much, or often, what would issue from it. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also Saw~aAnN.

Say~inN *
Say~inN [thus app., like say~idN and jay~idN, written in my copy of the Msb Sayn] One who preserves his honour, or reputation. (Msb.)

maSaAnN *
maSaAnN: see SiwaAnN, in two places.

muSaAnN *
muSaAnN: see miSowaAnN.

maSuwnN *
maSuwnN and maSowuwnN↓, (S, M, Msb, K,) like maduwfN and madowuwfN, (S and Msb in art. dwf, q. v.,) the latter of the dial. of Temeem, (M,) Preserved, kept, laid up, taken care of, or reserved; (S, * M, * Msb, K;) applied to a garment [&c.]; (S, M;) as also SawonN↓, which is an inf. n. used. as an epithet: (M:) one should not say muSaAnN, (S, TA,) nor munoSaAnN, as the vulgar say. (TA.)

miSowaAnN *
miSowaAnN A bow-case; (K, TA;) as also muSaAnN↓. (TA.)

maSowuwnN *
maSowuwnN: see maSuwnN.

1 Sawati Aln~axolapu *
1. Sawati Aln~axolapu, (Lth, Az, S, M, K,) aor. taSowiY, (S, K,) inf. n. SuwiY~N; (Lth, Az, S, M, K;) and Sawiyat, (Az, M, K,) which is the form preferred by Az, [aor. taSowaY,] inf. n. SawFY; (TA;) The palm-tree needed irrigation, and became slender: (Az, TA:) or became dry, or dried up; (S, M, K;) as also A^aSowat↓, and Saw~at↓: (K:) and in like manner one says of other trees: and sometimes, of animals. (M.) And SawiYa AlD~aroEu The udder had no milk remaining in it. (Ham p. 661.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Sawati Al$~aApu The ewe, or she-goat, became fat, (S, TA,) in consequence of her udder's having been made to dry up. (S.) And SawiYa He became strong. (K.)

2 Sw~Y *
2. Sw~Y, (M,) inf. n. taSowiyapN, (K,) primarily, (M,) is used in relation to females, meaning He abstained from milking her, in order that she might become fat, (M, K,) and not be weak. (M.) You say, Saw~ayotu Aln~aAqapa I abstained from milking the she-camel for some days in order that the milk might collect in her udder so that she might become fat: or I made her milk to dry up, that she might become fatter. (M.) And Saw~ayotu Al$~aApa, inf. n. as above, I made the udder of the ewe, or goat, to become dry, that she might become fatter: (S:) or Sw~yt Alganama I made the milk of the ewes, or goats, to dry up, purposely, that they might become fatter; like as one says in relation to camels: the subst. from the verb thus used is SawFY↓; and this is said to mean The leaving an animal and not milking her. (M.) Some say that taSowiyapN is like taSoriyapN; and hence the trad., Alt~aSowiyapu xilaAbapN [i. e. The causing the milk to collect in the udder of an animal by abstaining from milking her for some days, when one desires to sell her, is an endeavouring to deceive: but I think that the right reading in this instance is probably Alt~aSoriyapu, with r]. (TA.) ― -b2- It is also used in relation to a stallion (S, M, K) of the camels: (S:) thus it is used by El-Fak'asee. (M.) One says, Saw~ayotu AlfaHola, (M,) inf. n. as above, (S, K,) I put no burden upon the stallion [camel], and did not bind him with a rope, in order that he might become more brisk in covering, and more strong; (S, * M, K; *) thus expl. by El-'Adebbes El-Kinánee: (S:) or I exempted him from work, and fed him, until his spirit returned to him, and he became fat. (M.) And Saw~ayotu liA_ibiliY faHolFA I chose for my camels a stallion, and fed and nourished him for the office of the stallion. (S.) ＝ -A2- See also 1. ＝ -A3- [And see art. Sw.]

4 A^aSowaYa
4: see 1. ― -b2- One says also ASwY Alqawomu, meaning The people's cattle became lean, or emaciated; like ADwY Alqwm. (IKtt, TA.) ＝ -A2- [See also art. Sw.]

SawFY *
SawFY a subst. from 2, q. v. (M.)

SawK *
SawK: see its fem., SawiyapN, voce SaAwK. ― -b2- [Also, app., Empty sunobul (or ears of corn): accord. to the TA (on the authority of Az): the word in this sense, and thus applied, is there written with the article, AlSwY, without any syll. sign.]

Sawiy~apN *
Sawiy~apN: see the following paragraph.

SaAwK *
SaAwK Dry, (S, K, TA,) by reason of thirst, or want of irrigation, or by reason of leanness, or emaciation. (TA.) You say naxolapN SaAwiyapN, (M, K,) and SawiyapN↓, (M, TA,) [agreeably with rule, as part. n. of Sawiyat,] or Sawiy~apN↓, (so in copies of the K, [app. a mistranscription,]) A dry, or driedup, palm-tree: (M, K:) and in like manner one terms other trees: and sometimes, animals: thus the poet Sá'ideh applies the epithet SAwyp to wild cows or wild oxen (baqar waHo$). (M.) ― -b2- And Strong. (TA.)

1 SaAba *
1. SaAba aor. yaSiybu, (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. SayobN, (S, Msb, K,) said of an arrow, (S, M, Msb,) i. q. A^aSaAba [expl. in art. Swb]; (S, * M, Msb, K;) like SAb having for its aor. yaSuwbu. (S, M, Msb.)

SayobaAnN *
SayobaAnN: see SawobN, in art. Swb.

SuyaAbN *
SuyaAbN: see Suy~aAbapN.

SayuwbN *
SayuwbN An arrow going right, or hitting the mark: pl. SuyubN (M, K) and SiyaAbN, (MF, TA,) or the latter is pl. of SaAy^ibN, which signifies the same. (M, in art. Swb.)

SuyaAbapN *
SuyaAbapN: see Suy~aAbapN.

Say~ibN *
Say~ibN: see art. Swb.

Suy~aAbN *
Suy~aAbN: see Suy~aAbapN, in four places.

Say~uwbN *
Say~uwbN: see art. Swb.

Sub~aAbapN *
Sub~aAbapN and Suy~aAbN↓ (M, A, K) and SubaAbapN↓ and SuyaAbN↓ (A, K) The A^aSol (M, A, K) [as meaning the original stock] of a people, (M,) or [as meaning the original, or the principal, or most essential, part,] of a thing: (A, K:) and the purest, or choice, or best, part or portion, (M, * A, K,) of a thing (M, K) of any kind, (M,) or of a people. (A.) One says, huwa fiY Suy~aAbapi qawomihi and Suy~aAbihimo↓ He is of the A^aSol [or original stock] of his people: (Fr, TA:) and mino Suy~aAbapi qawomihi and Suw~aAbapi qwmh (TA) and mino Suy~aAbihimo↓ (A) of the purest in race of his people. (A, * TA.) And qawomN Suy~aAbN↓ A choice, or an excellent, people. (TA.) ― -b2- Also the first, The collective body of a people; (Kr, M;) and so Suw~aAbapN. (M in art. Swb.) ― -b3- And A lord, master, or chief. (M, K.)

SiytN *
SiytN and SiytapN: and Say~itN: see art. Swt.

1 SaAHa *
1. SaAHa, (S, A, O, Msb, &c.,) aor. yaSiyHu, (S, O, Msb,) inf. n. SiyaAHN and SayoHapN (S, A, * O, Msb, K *) and SayoHN and SuyaAHN and SayaHaAnN, (S, O, K, *) He raised his voice, voiced, called or called out, cried or cried out: (S, A, O, Msb, K:) or did so vehemently, cried aloud, uttered a loud cry or crying, shouted, exclaimed, or vociferated: (T, S, * A, * O, * Msb, * TA:) or did so with his utmost force or power; (K, TA;) as also Sy~H↓: (A, * TA:) it is said of a man, and of other things: (TA:) or of anything: (T, TA:) originally, of an animal, and often of a bird of the crow-kind, but rarely of a bird unrestrictedly, and sometimes of a spear as being likened to an animal. (Ham p. 187.) One says, SaAHa SayoHapF $adiydapF [He called, or cried, &c., with a vehement calling or crying &c., or with a vehement call or cry &c.]. (A.) And SAj bihi He called or cried, or called out or cried out, to it [or to him]. (Msb.) And SiHo liY bifulaAnK Call thou to me such a one. (A, TA.) And bihi SaAyaHa↓ and SaAyaHahu, (A, TA,) and Say~aHa↓ bihi and Say~aHahu, (A,) He called, hailed, or summoned, him; called out, cried out, or shouted, to him. (A, TA.) ― -b2- And SiyHa bihimo (assumed tropical:) They were
frightened, or terrified. (K.) And SiyHa fiyhimo (assumed tropical:) They perished. (K.) ― -b3- One says also, laqiytuhu qabola kul~i SayoHK wanaforK I met him before every calling, or crying, and dispersing; meaning (assumed tropical:) I met him before daybreak: (S, TA:) so in the Proverbs of Meyd. (TA.) Or A^atayotuhu qabola SayoHK wanaforK (tropical:) I came to him before everything. (A.) And gaDiba mino gayori SayoHK walaA naforK (tropical:) He was angry for neither little nor much: (ISk, S, K:) or for nothing. (A.) ― -b4- And SaAHati Al$~ajarapu, (A, Msb,) or Aln~axolapu, (K,) (tropical:) The tree, (A, Msb,) or the palm-tree, (K,) became tall. (A, Msb, K.) And SAH AlEunoquwdu (tropical:) The raceme came forth completely from its envelope, and became long, and in a fresh and tender state. (K.) And SAH AlkaAfuwru (tropical:) [app. meaning The spathe of the palm-tree put forth its spadix, or its raceme, to its full length]. (A.)

2 Say~aHa
2: see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- Sy~Ht Albaqola said of the sun, (S, K,) and of the wind, (S,) i. q. Saw~aHatohu [q. v.]. (S, K.) ― -b2- And Say~aHotu Al$~aYo'a I broke and split the thing much. (TA in art. SwH.)

3 muSaAyaHapN *
3. muSaAyaHapN and taSaAyuHN↓ signify The calling or crying, or calling out or crying out, &c., of people, one to another. (S, K.) One says, SAyH Alqawomu (TK) and tSAyHwA↓ The people, or party, called or cried, &c., one to another. (A, TK.) ― -b2- See also 1.

5 tSy~H Albaqolu *
5. tSy~H Albaqolu i. q. tSw~H [q. v.]. (S, K.) ― -b2- And tSy~H Al$~aEaru i. q. tSw~H [q. v.]. (K in art. SwH.) ― -b3- And tSy~H Al$~aYo'u The thing became much broken and cloven or split or slit. (TA in this art. and art. SwH.) See also 7.

6 taSaAoyaHa
6: see 3, in two places. ― -b2- tSAyH said of the scabbard, or sheath, of a sword (A, K, TA) (tropical:) It became much split or slit: (K, TA:) it is like the phrase tadaAEaY AlbunoyaAnu [q. v.]. (A, TA.)

7 AnSAH *
7. AnSAH said of a garment, or piece of cloth, It became slit, or rent, or much slit or rent. (A, Msb. [See also 7 in art. SwH.]) And AnSAHt AlEaSaA The staff became much split or cracked; as also tSy~Ht↓. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AnSAH is also said of the dawn and of lightning (tropical:) [meaning It showed its light: originally, became cleft: as expl. in art. SwH]. (A.)

SayoHapN *
SayoHapN an inf. n. [and also an inf. n. un.] of SaAHa. (S, Msb, &c.) [Hence,] one says, maA yanotaZiruwna A_il~aA mivola SayoHapi AlHubolaY [They expect not, or wait not for, aught but the like of the cryingout, or cry, of the pregnant woman]; meaning, evil, or mischief, that shall come upon them suddenly. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence also (S) Punishment, castigation, or chastisement. (S, A, K.) ― -b3- And A hostile, or predatory, incursion, by which the tribe are surprised. (TA.)

SayoHaAnN *
SayoHaAnN: see what next follows.

SayoHaAniY~N *
SayoHaAniY~N, (T, S, A, Mgh, K,) or SayoHaAnN↓, (Msb,) A sort of dates of El-Medeeneh, (T, S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) black, and hard to chew: (T, Mgh, TA:) said to be so called in relation to a certain ram, named SayoHaAnu, that was tied to a palm-tree, (A, Msb, K, *) which was hence called naxolapN SayoHaAniy~apN: (A, Msb:) or the name of the ram was AlS~ay~aAHu, and SayoHaAniY~N is a rel. n. changed from its proper form, like SanoEaAniY~N, (K, TA,) from SanoEaA='u. (TA.)

Say~aAHN *
Say~aAHN A clamorous man: and anything noisy, or sounding much. (The Lexicons passim.) ― -b2- AlS~ay~aAHu is another name for AlEaw~aA='u [i. e. The constellation Bootes]. (Kzw.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) A certain perfume, or fragrant substance: (K, TA:) or a wash for the head, (A, K, *) consisting of xaluwq [q. v.], and the like. (A, TA.)

SaAy^iHapN *
SaAy^iHapN The crying, or clamour, of the place of the wailing of women. (K.)

1 SaAdahu *
1. SaAdahu, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) like baAEahu, (MF,) [first pers. Sidotu,] aor. yaSiydu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. SayodN; (S, M, Mgh, Msb;) and SaAdahu, (S, &c.,) like haAbahu, (MF,) [first pers. Sidotu, as above, but originally Sayidotu, whereas the first pers. of the former is originally Sayadotu,] aor. yaSaAdu; (IAar, S, Msb, K;) and ASTAdhu↓, (S, M, A, L, Msb, K,) also written and pronounced AiS~aAdahu; (L;) and tSy~dhu↓; (M, A, L;) He took, captured, or caught, it; (Mgh, L;) [made it his prey;] snared, or ensnared, it; trapped, or entrapped, it; (MF;) or sought to take, capture, catch, snare, or trap, it; hunted it, or chased it: namely, [game, i. e.] any kind of wild animals, or the like, (L,) fowl, &c., (Msb,) and fish. (L.) [And SaAda, and ASTAd↓, and tSy~d↓, without the mention of the object, this being understood, He took, captured, caught, snared or ensnared, trapped or entrapped, game, i. e. any kind of wild animals, or the like, fowl, &c., or fish; or he sought to take &c.; he hunted or chased, stalked, or lurked for game; he fowled; or he fished.] You say, xaraja yataSay~adu↓ [&c., meaning He went forth to take &c., or seeking to take &c., game, or wild animals or the like; to hunt or chase, to stalk, or lurk for game; to fowl; or to fish]. (S, K.) And AlwaHo$a xaraja yataSay~adu↓ He went forth [to take &c., or] seeking to take &c., the wild animals. (L.) And Sidotu fulaAnFA SayodFA i. q. Sidotu lahu [I took &c., or sought to take &c., for such a one, game, or a wild animal, or wild animals, or the like]. (M, * K.) And SAd AlmakaAna, and ASTAdhu↓, i. q. SAd fiyhi [He took &c., or sought to take &c., game, or wild animals, or the like, in the place]: Sb mentions, as a phrase of the Arabs, SidonaA qanawayoni meaning SidonaA waHo$a qanawayoni: qanawaAni being the name of a certain land [or of two mountains]. (M.) And AlS~aqoru yaSiydu [The hawk preys]. (Msb and K in art. Sqr.) *awaAtu AlS~ayodi is applied to beasts and to birds [That prey upon others; predatory]. (S and K in art. jrj, &c.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, huwa yaSiydu Aln~aAsa biAlmaEoruwfi (tropical:) [He captivates men by goodness, beneficence, or kindness]. (A.) ― -b3- And AiqotaSido taSido (tropical:) Aim thou at that which is right and just: thou shalt obtain that which thou wantest. (A.) ― -b4- xarajonaA naSiydu bayoDa Aln~aEaAmi (tropical:) [We went forth to take, or hunt after, the eggs of ostriches]. (T, TA.) ― -b5- And SidonaA AlkamaA^apa, (M, A, TA,) a good phrase of the Arabs, mentioned, but not expl., by IAar; app. meaning (tropical:) We drew forth truffles [from the ground] like as one draws forth wild animals [from their lurking-places]. (M, TA.) ― -b6- And SidonaA maA='a Als~amaA='i (tropical:) We took [or caught in vessels or collected] the water of the sky. (Th, M, A. *) ＝ -A2- Sayida, (Lth, S, M, L,) of the dial. of El- Hijáz, aor. yaSoyadu, (Lth, L,) inf. n. SayadN; (Lth, S, M, L;) and SaAda, (Lth, M, L,) [aor. yaSiydu;] He (a camel) had the disease termed SayadN [expl. below]: (Lth, S, M, L:) the Y in Sayida is preserved unchanged because it is so preserved in the original form, which is AiSoyad~a↓, (S,) though they may not have said AiSoyad~a; (Sb, M;) and the like is the case in Eawira: (Sb, * S, M: *) the augmentative letters are rejected for the purpose of alleviation: hence, one does not say, in the case of verbs of this class, maA A^afoEalahu, [i. e. maA A^aSoyadahu, and maA A^aEuwarahu, and the like,] forming thus verbs of wonder, because the original form is augmented, and a verb of four letters cannot be formed from a verb of four letters, for a measure can only be formed from a measure that is less. (S.) Also, both verbs, (the former accord. to the S and M, and ↓the latter likewise accord. to the M,) (assumed tropical:) He (a man) was unable to look aside, (S, M,) by reason of disease. (S.) And Sayida, inf. n. SayadN, (assumed tropical:) He raised his head, by reason of pride: and (assumed tropical:) he (a king) looked not aside, to the right or left. (S.) And Sayida (K, TA, in the CK [erroneously] Say^ida,) (tropical:) He (a man, TA) had an inclining, or a bending, neck. (K, TA.) ＝ -A3- And Sidotu fulaAnFA (tropical:) I made such a one to have an inclining, or a bending, neck. (K, TA. [See also 4.])

4 ASAdhu *
4. ASAdhu He made him, incited him, or induced him, to take &c., or to seek to take &c., wild animals, or the like, [fowl,] or fish. (L.) ＝ -A2- Also He, or it, [app. meaning the vein called SaAd, or the disease termed Sayad,] annoyed, or hurt, him; (K;) namely, a camel. (TK.) ― -b2- And He cured him (i. e. a camel, TK) of the disease termed Sayad, (K, TA,) by burning with a hot iron. (TA.) Thus it has two contr. significations. (K.) ― -b3- And A^aSoyada baEiyrahu He (God) caused his camel to have the disease termed Sayad. (M.)

5 taSay~ada
5: see 1, in four places.

8 A_iSotayada
8: see 1, in three places.

9 A_iSoyad~a
9: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph, in two places.

SaAdN *
SaAdN A certain vein (M, K) between the eyes of a camel, (K,) or between the eye and the nose; (M;) whence the disease termed Sayad: pl. A^aSoyaAdN and pl. pl. A^aSaAyidu [in the CK A^aSAy^idu]. (K.) ― -b2- See also SayadN, in two places. ― -b3- And see A^aSoyadu, likewise in two places. ＝ -A2- Also Brass; syn. SuforN:
and copper: (S, M, K:) or a species thereof: (K:) or cooking-pots made of Sufor, (A'Obeyd, TA,) or of copper: (A'Obeyd, M, TA:) pl. SiydaAnN, (M, TA,) like tiyjaAnN pl. of taAjN: and some say that SayodaAnN↓ [q. v., thus written with fet-h to the S,] signifies copper. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See also art. Swd.

SayodN *
SayodN an instance of faEolN in the sense of mafoEuwlN, (Msb,) or an inf. n. used as a subst. [properly so called, and therefore used in a sing. and in a pl. sense], (Msb, TA,) [i. e.] an inf. n. used in the place of the objective complement of its verb; (IJ, M;) [Game, chase, or prey; an object, or objects, of the chase or the like;] i. q. maSiydN↓ (S, Mgh, K, TA) used as a subst.; (TA;) meaning what is taken, captured, or caught; or sought to be taken or captured or caught; [by the chase, or by means of a snare or trap, or by artifice of any kind;] of wild animals or the like; (L;) of fowl &c.; (Msb;) and of fish: (L:) or what is repugnant, or difficult of approach, (Mgh, L, K,) wild, or shy, by nature, not to be taken but by means of artifice, whatever it be, (Mgh,) but lawful to be taken, (L,) having no owner: (L, K:) or any wild animal, or wild animals, whether, or not, taken or sought to be taken: (IAar, M:) but this last application of the word is a deviation from general usage: (M:) pl. SuyuwdN. (Mgh, Msb.) [Also The quarry of the hawk; the prey of any beast or bird &c.] Sayoduka laA tuHoramohu (Meyd, A, but in the latter Sayodaka, [for Ailozamo Sayodaka,]) is a prov. (Meyd, A) inciting one to seize an opportunity, (A,) applied to a man who seeks another to execute blood-revenge upon him, and lights upon him when he is inadvertent; meaning Thy prey has become within thy power, therefore be not thou neglectful of him [so as to suffer him to escape, or rather be not thou rendered hopeless of him]. (Meyd. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 712; where tuHoramuhu is put in the place of tuHoramohu.]) ＝ -A2- See also SayadN.

SiydN *
SiydN: see the next paragraph.

SayadN *
SayadN (S, M, A, L, K) and SiydN↓, with kesr, (K,) or SayodN↓, (L,) and SaAdN↓, (M, * L, K,) A certain disease in a camel's head, in consequence of which he raises it: (S:) a certain disease which causes a camel to raise his head: or a certain disease in a camel's head, which causes his neck to twist: (M:) or a certain disease which attacks camels in the head, in consequence of which there flows from their noses what resembles froth, or foam, and they raise their heads: (ISk, L, K: *) or a certain disease in a camel's neck, in consequence of which he is unable to turn his face aside: it is said that its cure is burning with a hot iron (A, TA) between the eyes: (TA:) [for] it arises from a vein between the eyes, called SaAd. (K.) [Hence,] also SayadN, (M, * A,) and SaAdN↓, (M,) Fixedness of the face of a king, so that it does not turn aside (M, A) to the right or left, by reason of pride. (A. [See also Sayida, of which it is the inf. n.]) [And the former, (tropical:) An inclination, or bending, of the neck: (see Sayida:) hence,] one says, laA^uqiyman~a Sayadaka (tropical:) [I will assuredly straighten the bending of thy neck: or I will assuredly rectify thy proud stiffness]. (A.)

SayidN *
SayidN: see A^aSoyadu.

SaAdiY~N *
SaAdiY~N [Of, or made of, brass or copper:] a rel. n. from SaAdN signifying “ brass ” and “ copper. ” (S.)

SayodaA='u *
SayodaA='u Stones, (S, A, L, K,) or stone, (M,) of a white colour, (M, L,) of which cooking-pots are made; (S, M, A, L, K;) as also SayodaAnN↓. (A, L.) See also SayodaAnN. ― -b2- And Rugged land or ground, (S, M, K,) containing stones: (M:) or land of which the earth is red, having rough stones even with the ground: (ISh:) or even, or level, ground, in which are pebbles: (AA:) or pebbles [themselves]. (Aboo-Wejreh, L.)

SayodaAnN *
SayodaAnN Copper: (L, K: see also SaAdN:) and gold: (K:) [but this seems to be taken from the following passage in the T:] in the stone-cookingpot (Alburomap) there is sometimes [what is termed] SayodaAnN and SayodaA='u↓, in which is an appearance like the glistening of gold and silver; and the best is that which is like gold: so says AA. (T, L.) See also art. Sdn. ― -b2- And Stone cookingpots: (S, L, K; and M in art. Sdn:) a coll. gen. n.: n. un. with p. (IB, L.) ― -b3- See also SayodaA='u. ― -b4- SayodaAnu AlHaSaY Small pebbles. (L. [See also art Sdn.])

SayodaAnapN *
SayodaAnapN [as a n. un.: see SayodaAnN, above. ― -b2- Also] A [demon of the kind called] guwl. (ISk, S, K.) ― -b3- And A woman of evil disposition, (ISk, S, K,) [and] so SayuwdN↓, (M,) and of much talk. (ISk, S, K.) ― -b4- See also art. Sdn.

SayuwdN *
SayuwdN: see Say~aAdN. ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A woman who takes, captures, or ensnares, something from her husband. (L, from a trad.) See also SayodaAnapN.

rajulN Say~aAdN *
rajulN Say~aAdN [A man accustomed to, or in the habit of, taking, capturing, catching, snaring, or trapping, game, i. e. any kind of wild animals, or the like, fowl, &c., or fish; a sportsman; a hunter, a fowler, or a fisherman: see 1, second sentence]: (Msb:) and SayuwdN↓ signifies the same as Say~aAdN: (K:) you say kalobN SayuwdN [A dog used for hunting]: (S, A:) and SaqorN SayuwdN [A hawk used for catching game]: and the same epithet is applied to a female: (M:) its pl. is SuyudN (S, M, A) and SiydN; (Yoo, Sb, S, M;) the latter of the dial. of those, (S, M,) namely, the tribe of Temeem, (M,) who say rusolN [for rusulN]; (S, M;) the S being with kesr in order that the Y may be preserved unchanged. (S.) ― -b2- See also A^aSoyadu, last sentence.

SaAy^idN *
SaAy^idN, applied to a man, Practising AlS~ayod [i. e. the taking, capturing, or catching, &c., of game, or any kind of wild animals, or the like, fowl, &c., or fish; hunting, fowling, or fishing: see 1, second sentence]. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- AlS~aAy^idu in the dial. of El-Yemen signifies The shank; syn. Als~aAqu. (M.)

Say~uwdN *
Say~uwdN, like tan~uwrN [in measure], An arrow going right, or hitting the mark. (K.)

A^aSoyadu *
A^aSoyadu [More, or most, wont, or able, to take, or capture, or catch, game, or prey]. A^aSoyadu mino layovi Eifir~iyna wamino DayowanK [More wont, or able, to capture prey than the lion of 'Ifirreen and than the he-cat] is a prov. (Meyd.) ＝ -A2- Also A camel having the disease termed Sayad; (S, M, A, L;) and so SaAdN↓, for *uw SaAdK, (L, K,) like maAlN for *uw maAlK, (L,) or for SayidN↓: (L:) pl. of the first SiydN. (L.) [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A man unable to look aside, (S, M,) by reason of disease. (S.) (assumed tropical:) A man who raises his head by reason of pride. (S.) (tropical:) A king who looks not aside, (M, A,) to the right or left, by reason of his pride. (A.) (assumed tropical:) A king: (K:) originally used in relation to a camel, and a king is so called because he raises his head by reason of pride, or because he does not look to the right or left. (S.) And A man having an inclining, or a bending, neck. (K, TA.) ― -b2- AlA^aSoyadu (assumed tropical:) The lion; (K;) because he walks proudly, not looking aside, as though he had the disease termed Sayad; (TA;) as also AlmuSoTaAdu↓ [as act. part. n. of 8]; and AlS~aAdu↓; (K, TA;) thus likened to a camel having the disease above mentioned; or, as in some copies of the K, not AlS~aAdu, but AlSay~aAdu↓. (TA.)

maSaAdN *
maSaAdN and muSoTaAdN↓ and mutaSay~adN↓ [A place of taking, capturing, or catching, &c., of game, or any kind of wild animals, or the like, fowl, &c., or fish; a place of hunting, fowling, or fishing]. (A. [The meaning is there indicated by the context, but not expressed.]) ＝ -A2- maSaAdN also signifies The upper, or highest, part of a mountain. (MF, from Aboo-'Alee El-Yoosee. [But this, accord. to the S &c., belongs to art. mSd.])

maSoyadN *
maSoyadN and miSoyadN: see miSoyadapN.

maSiydN *
maSiydN pass. part. n. of 1: (Mgh, Msb:) see SayodN.

miSoyadapN *
miSoyadapN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and maSoyadapN (M, and so in the handwriting of Az accord. to the L) and miSoyadN↓ (S, L, Msb, K) and maSoyadN↓ (so in the handwriting of Az accord. to the L) and maSiydapN↓ (M, Msb, K) A thing used for the purpose of AlS~ayod [or the taking, capturing, or catching, &c., of game, or any kind of wild animals, or the like, fowl, &c., or fish]; (T, S, M, A, Msb, K;) a snare, trap, gin, or net; (MA in explanation of the first and last;) [the first and third said by Golius, on the authority of Meyd, to be applied peculiarly to a net; but all signify also any kind of trap: see $ahomN:] pl. maSaAyidu, without '. (L, Msb.)

maSiydapN *
maSiydapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

muSoTaAdN *
muSoTaAdN: see A^aSoyadu: ― -b2- and see also maSaAdN.

mutaSay~adN *
mutaSay~adN: see maSaAdN.

1 SaAra ka*aA *
1. SaAra ka*aA, (T, S, Msb,) aor. yaSiyru, (S,) inf. n. SayoruwrapN (S, Msb) and SayorN, (S,) He, or it, attained to the state, or condition, of such a thing; (T;) became such a thing; (T, Msb;) in which sense the verb is like kaAna [in meaning, when the latter is non-attributive, and in having its subject
in the nom. case and its predicate in the accus.]. (T.) You say, SaAra zayodN rajulFA Zeyd became a man; or attained to the state, or condition, of a man. (TA.) And SaAra zayodN ganiy~FA Zeyd became rich, not having been so. (Msb.) And SaAra AlEaSiyru xamorFA The expressed juice became wine. (Msb.) [And SaAra laA $aYo'a Einodahu He became in a state, or condition, in which there was not anything in his possession. And SaAra yafoEalu ka*aA He became in the state, or condition, of doing such a thing; i. e. he became occupied, or engaged, in doing such a thing; or he set about, began, commenced, took to, or betook himself to, doing such a thing; like jaEala. And SaAra laA yafoEalu $ayoy^FA He became in the state, or condition, of not doing anything; or he became unoccupied in doing anything. And SaAra laA yatakal~amu He became in the state of not speaking; he became speechless. And SaAra yatafak~aru fiY ka*aA He became in a state of reflection upon such a thing; he began to reflect upon such a thing.] ― -b2- One says also, SaAra AlA^amoru A_ilaY ka*aA, (M, A, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. maSiyrN, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) which is anomalous, being regularly maSaArN, like maEaA$N, (S,) and SayorN and SayoruwrapN, (M, A, K,) i. e. rajaEa A_ilayohi: (Msb:) [but this is a loose explanation; the meaning being, The thing, or affair, or case, came eventually (see SiyrN) to such a state, or condition:] the difference between maSiyrN and marojiEN is, that the former word necessarily implies a difference [of the latter state or condition] from the former state or condition; but the latter word does not. (Bd in iii. 156.) [In this case, the ulterior state or condition is likened to a place: for] ― -b3- SaAra also signifies He, or it, attained in respect of place: so in the saying, SaAra zayodN A_ilaY EamorKw [Zeyd came, or went, or pursued a course that brought him, to 'Amr]. (TA.) Sirotu A_ilaY fulaAnK [I came, &c., to such a one] is similar to the phrase in the Kur [iii. 27] waA_ilaY A@ll~`hi A@lomaSiyru [And to God, as the ultimate object, is the transition, or course, of every human being]. (S.) [Hence, A^FlaA A_ilaY A@ll~`hi taSiyru A@loA^umuwru, in the Kur xlii. last verse, which Bd explains by adding the words biA@rotifaAEi AlwasaAy^iTi waAlt~aEal~uqaAti; the meaning being, Verily to God are things, or events, referrible, mediately and dependently: in the Expos. of the Jel expl. as meaning tarojiEu.] ― -b4- [And in like manner one says, SaAra lahu ka*aA Such a thing came to, betided, or befell, him, or it: and hence, he, or it, came to have, or became possessed of, such a thing.] ― -b5- And SaAra fiY A^aroDi falaApK [He became, or came to be, meaning he found himself, in a desert, or waterless, land]; i. q. waqaEa fiyhaA. (Msb in art. wqE.) And SaAra fiY Alr~abiyEi [He entered, lit. became in, the season called rbyE]; i. q. A^arobaEa [which is expl. in the S as signifying daxala fiY Alr~abiyEi]. (K in art. rbE.) ＝ -A2- SayorN signifies also The returning of seekers after herbage to the watering-places. (O, K.) And one says, SaAra Alr~ajulu, aor. yaSiyru, [inf. n. SayorN,] The man stayed, or abode, at the water. (TA.) And SaAra Aln~aAsu AlmaA='a The people stayed, or abode, at the water. (M, K, TA.) ＝ -A3- SaArahu, (S,) first pers. Sirotuhu, (M,) aor. as above, (S,) inf. n. SayorN, (K,) a dial. var. of SaArahu having for its aor. yaSuwruhu, [q. v.,] (S,) He cut it; (S, M, K;) and clave it, or split it. (M.) ― -b2- And in like manner, [i. e. as a dial. var. of SaArahu having for its aor. yaSuwruhu,] He made it to incline, or lean. (S.) You say, SaAra wajohahu, aor. yaSiyru, (M,) as also yaSuwru, (M and K in art. Swr,) He turned his face towards a person or thing. (M.) And Sirotu Eunuqahu I twisted his neck. (M.) [Respecting the phrase faSirohun~a A_ilayoka in the Kur ii. 262, accord. to one reading, see 1 in art. Swr.] ― -b3- SaArahu, aor. yaSiyru, inf. n. SayorN, signifies also Habasahu [He confined, restricted, &c., him, or it]. (Msb.)

2 Sy~rhu ka*aA *
2. Sy~rhu ka*aA He made him, or it, to be in such a state, or condition; or he made him, or it, to be such a thing; [as also A^aSaArahu↓;] syn. jaEalahu. (S.) You say, Say~araniY lahu EabodFA and A^FSaAraniY↓ [He made me to be to him a slave]. (A.) ― -b2- [And Say~arahu A_ilaY ka*aA and A^aSaArahu↓ He, or it, made, or caused, him, or it, to come, or to pursue a course that led, to such a state, or condition; brought, or reduced, him, or it, thereto.] 'Omeyleh El-Fezáree said to his paternal uncle Ibn-'Ankà, maA Al~a*iY A^aSaAraka↓ A_ilaY maA A^araY yaA Eam~i [What hath made thee to come, or brought thee, or reduced thee, to the state, or condition, that I see, O my paternal uncle?]. (M.) [In this case, the ulterior state or condition is likened to a place: for] you say, Say~arahu A_ilayohi and A^aSaArahu↓ [meaning He, or it, made him to come, or brought him, to him, or it; i. e., to a person, or place, or to a state, or condition:] (M, K:) and Say~aratoniY A_ilayohi AlHaAjapu and A^aSaAratoniY↓ [Want, or need, or necessity, made me to come, or brought me, to him, or it]. (A.) And [hence,] Say~ara A_ilayohi AlA^amora He committed to him the thing, or affair; syn. faw~aDahu Alyh. (M in art. fwD.) [And Say~ara lahu ka*aA He made such a thing to come to, betide, or befall, him, or it: and consequently, he made him, or it, to have, or become possessed of, such a thing.] ― -b3- taSoyiyrN is also by word, or covenant, as well as by deed. (Bd in ii. 20.) [You say, Say~arahu ka*aA meaning He asserted, or pronounced, him, or it, to be in such a state, or condition; or to be such a thing: in which case, also, it is syn. with jaEalahu, whereby it is expl. in the S. And Say~ara lahu ka*aA He asserted, or pronounced, such a thing to belong to him, or it; asserted, or pronounced, him, or it, to have such a thing; attributed to him, or it, such a thing: and appointed or assigned, to him, or it, such a thing.]

4 A^aSoyara
4: see 2, in six places.

5 tSy~r A^abaAhu *
5. tSy~r A^abaAhu He became like his father. (S, M, K.)

SayorN *
SayorN: see what next follows.

SiyrN *
SiyrN The ulterior or ultimate, latter or last, state, or condition; the end, conclusion, event, issue, or result; of a thing, an affair, or a case; (S, M, O, Msb, K;) as also SayorN↓ (O, K) and maSiyrN↓ (S, O, Msb, TA) and maSiyrapN↓ (TA) and Say~uwrN↓, (S, M, K,) of the measure fayoEuwlN, (S,) and Say~uwrapN↓. (K.) ― -b2- The verge, brink, or point, of an affair, or event. (M, K.) You say, A^anaA EalaY SiyrK mino A^amori ka*aA I am on the verge of such an affair, or event. (M.) And A^anaA EalaY SiyrK mino HaAjatiY I am at the point of [attaining] the object of my want. (M.) And A^anaA EalaY SiyrK mino qaDaA='i HaAjatiY I am at the point of accomplishing my want. (A.) And fulaAnN EalaY Siyri A^amorK Such a one is at the point of accomplishing an affair. (S.) ＝ -A2- A water at which people stay, or abide; (M, O, K;) as also SiyrapN↓. (TA.) ＝ -A3- A crevice of a door. (S, M, A, Msb, K.) It is said in a trad., mano naZara fiY Siyri baAbK fafuqiy^ato Eayonuhu fahiYa hadarN [Whosoever looks into the crevice of a door and has his eye put out, it is a thing for which no mulct is to be exacted]: (S, M:) A'Obeyd says that this is the only instance in which the word [in this sense] has been heard. (S.) ＝ -A4- [The condiment, made of small fish, called] SiHonaAp: (S, M, K:) or [a condiment, or the like,] resembling SHnAp: (M, K:) or what is called in Pers. maAhiY A=waho [jelly of salted fish]; as also SiHonaApN: (Mgh voce SHnAp:) and the small salted fish of which SHnAp is made: (Kr, M, K:) or the young ones of fish: [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p: (Msb:) thought by IDrd to be Syriac; (TA;) by IAth, to be Pers., as also SHnAp. (TA in art. SHn.) ＝ -A5- Also The A^usofuf~ [properly bishop] of the Jews. (O, K.) ＝ -A6- See also the next paragraph.

SiyrapN *
SiyrapN, (S, M, Msb, K,) accord. to A'Obeyd SiyorapN, with fet-h, but Az says that this is a mistake, (TA,) An enclosure (HaZiyrap) for sheep or goats (S, M, Msb, K) and for cows or bulls, (M, K,) constructed of wood and stones (M, TA) and of branches of trees; (TA;) as also SiyaArapN↓, (M, K,) which latter is said by IDrd to be of the dial. of the people of Baghdád: (TA:) pl. of the former SiyarN (S, M, Msb, K) and [coll. gen. n.] SiyrN↓. (M, K.) ＝ -A2- See also SiyrN.

SiyaArN *
SiyaArN The Sanoj; (O and TA in this art., and TS and K and TA in art. Sbr;) i. e. the stringed instrument thus called: (TS and TA in that art., and O and TA in the present art.:) [this is the right meaning, as is shown by the latter of the two verses cited voce SubaArapN: but,] accord. to AHeyth, (O,) the sound of the Sanoj. (O and K in the present art.) ＝ -A2- See also art. Swr.

SiyaArapN *
SiyaArapN: see SiyrapN. ＝ -A2- Also i. q. SubaArapN [q. v., signifying Stones, &c.]. (M in art. Sbr.)

Say~irN *
Say~irN A grave. (AA, O, K. [Perhaps so called as being the ulterior abode.]) One says, h`*aA Say~iru fulaAnK This is the grave of such a one. (O.) ＝ -A2- And A company (jamaAEap). (O, K.) ＝ -A3- See also art. Swr.

Say~irapN *
Say~irapN A thing, upon the head of a qaArap [or small isolated mountain or the like], resembling the [heap of stones, piled up as a sign of the way, called] A^amarap, except that it is cased, and the Amrp is
taller than it, and larger; or [in my originals “ and ”] they are both cased, but the Amrp is peaked and tall, and the Sy~rh is round and wide, and has angles [app. at the base]; and sometimes it is excavated, and gold and silver are found in it: it is of the work of 'Ád and Irem. (O, TA.)

SaAy^irN *
SaAy^irN Staying, or abiding, at a water. (TA.) And SaAy^irapN↓ A party, or people, staying, or abiding, at a water. (O, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A twister of men's necks. (TA.) ＝ -A3- [And The pivot at the top, and that at the heel, of a door; the former of which turns in a socket in the lintel, and the latter in a socket in the threshold:] see saAkifN.

SaAy^irapN *
SaAy^irapN: see the next preceding paragraph. ＝ -A2- Also Rain. (M, TA.) ― -b2- And Herbage, or pasture. (M.) See the next paragraph. ― -b3- Also The state of dryness to which herbage comes. (M.)

Say~uwrN *
Say~uwrN: see SiyrN. ― -b2- Also Judgment, or opinion, (S,) and understanding, or intellect, or intelligence; (S, M, K;) as in the saying, maA lahu Say~uwrN [He has not judgment nor understanding]: (S, M:) or a judgment, or an opinion, to which one eventually comes; as in the saying, maA lahu bado'N walaA Say~uwrN [He has not a first, nor a final, idea, thought, judgment, or opinion]. (A.) ＝ -A2- Also, (O, K;) as AHn says, on the authority of Aboo-Ziyád, (O;) and SaAy^irapN↓, (K,) Dry herbage or pasture, that is eaten long after its being green: (O, K:) and he adds that no herbs have Say~uwr except such as are of the kinds called Alv~agor and AlA^afaAniY. (O, TA.) ＝ -A3- A^um~u Say~uwrK signifies A confused and dubious affair, (M, K,) through which there is no way of passing; as in the phrase waqaEa fiY A^um~i Say~uwrK, mentioned by Yaakoob [ISk] in the “ Alfádh ” [accord. to some of the copies of that work]: originally meaning a [mountain, or hill, such as is termed] haDobap without a pass: but it is more probably Sab~uwr [q. v., in art. Sbr]. (M.)

Say~uwrapN *
Say~uwrapN: see SiyrN, first sentence.

maSiyrN *
maSiyrN an inf. n. of SaAra [q. v.]. (S, M, &c.) ＝ -A2- [Also A place, and hence a state or condition, to which a person, or thing, eventually comes: a place of destination.] See SiyrN. ― -b2- A place where people alight and abide: a good place where people alight and abide. (TA.) ― -b3- A place to which waters come, or take their course: (M, K:) [or a place of herbage, or pasture, and of water: pl. maSaAyiru: so in the saying,] xarajuwA A_ilaY maSaAyirihimo They went forth to their places of herbage, or pasture, and of water. (A.) ＝ -A3- See also art. mSr.

maSiyrapN *
maSiyrapN: see SiyrN, first sentence.

1 SaASati Aln~axolapu *
1. SaASati Aln~axolapu, [aor. taSiySu,] The palm-tree bore dates which had become such as are termed SiyS, i. e., $iyS; (K, * TA;) as also Sy~St↓, (K,) inf. n. taSoyiySN; (TA;) and ASASt↓, (K,) inf. n. A_iSaASapN; (TA;) all three on the authority of IAar, and the first mentioned by Sgh, in the O; and SaA^oSaA^at, from Siy^oSaA='N [a dial. var. of SiySaA='N, i. q. SiySN]. (TA.)

2 Say~aSa
2: see the preceding paragraph.

4 A^aSoyaSa
4: see the preceding paragraph.

SiySN *
SiySN, in the dial. of Belhárith Ibn-Kaab, The [bad] kind of dates called Ha$afN; (S;) i. q. $iySN; as also SiySaA='N↓; (K;) SiySN and SiySaA='N being dial. vars. of $iySN and $iySaA='N. (S.)

SiySapN *
SiySapN: see SiySiyapN, throughout.

SiySaA='N *
SiySaA='N: see SiySN. [It is also said to signify] Dates without stones. (L in art. lqH.) ― -b2- Also The pips of a colocynth that have no hearts, (AHn, S, K,) being husks only; (AHn;) to which a poet likens ticks that have been long left in a desolate place: (AHn, S: *) and so, accord. to some, of anything, such as the melon and the cucumber and the like. (AHn.)

SiySiyapN *
SiySiyapN, (S, IB, O,) or SiySapN↓, (K,) thus in all the copies of the K, but it is a mistake, or a contracted form, (TA,) The weaver's [implement called] $awokap, with which he makes the warp and the woof even: (S, IB, K:) but IB says that its last radical letter is Y, not S; so that it should be mentioned among the class of infirm words: (TA;) pl. SayaASK. (S.) ― -b2- Hence, (S,) The spur of the cock. (S, K.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] The horn of the bull or cow, and of the gazelle: (K:) pl. as above, (TA,) signifying the horns of bulls or cows; which were sometimes fixed upon spears, instead of the iron heads: (S:) and to such horns, called by this name, conflict and faction, or sedition, (fitonap,) is likened in a trad., because of its grievousness: some say that the sing. is SiySapN, [as in the K,] contracted. (TA.) ― -b4- And hence, (TA,) A wooden pin, or peg, with which dates are plucked out [when they are compacted in a mass, closely adhering together, in the receptacle of woven palm-leaves, or the like, in which they are packed]: (K:) likened to the horn of a bull or cow: in this sense, the word is written SiySapN: and a certain poet changes it to SiySaj~. (TA.) ― -b5- [Hence also,] Anything with which one defends himself: pl. as above, (K,) [in the CK erroneously written SayaASiY, as though it had the article Al prefixed to it, or were itself prefixed to another noun, for otherwise it is written and pronounced] with the [final] Y elided. (TA.) ― -b6- [Hence also,] A fortress: (K:) pl. in this sense as above. (S, TA.) ― -b7- [Hence also,] A pastor who manages [and protects] well his herds or flocks: (AA, K:) in this sense also written SiySapN. (AA, as in the TA.)

1 SiEotu *
1. SiEotu, aor. A^aSiyEu, inf. n. SayoEN: see 1 in art. SwE, in three places.

4 ASAE Alganama *
4. ASAE Alganama: see 1, in art. SwE, latter half.

5 tSy~E *
5. tSy~E: see 5 in art. SwE, last sentence. ― -b2- Also, said of water, It was, or became, in a state of commotion upon the surface of the ground: (IDrd, O, K, * TA:) but tsy~E is more approved [in this sense, or as meaning “ it ran upon the surface of the ground, ” as expl. in art. syE]. (TA.)

7 AnSAE *
7. AnSAE: see art. SwE. It belongs to this art. and to art. SwE. (K.)

A^aSoyaEu *
A^aSoyaEu [an epithet mentioned, but not expl., in the O and TA: it seems to be from SiEotuhu “ I dispersed it, or scattered it; ” and hence to be syn. with A^asoyaEu, signifying In a state of commotion, or of exceeding commotion]. Rubeh says,
faZal~a yakosuwhaA AlgubaAra AlA^aSoyaEaA
[app. meaning And he passed the day enveloping her, or it, or them, in the dust in a state of commotion, or of exceeding commotion]. (O, TA.)

2 Sy~g TaEaAmahu *
2. Sy~g TaEaAmahu, (ISh, O, K,) inf. n. taSoyiygN (K,) He soaked his food in sauce, or seasoning: (ISh, O, K:) and Sy~ghu biAls~amoni He soaked it with clarified butter. (ISh, O.) [Sabagahu has a similar meaning, and is better known.]

SiygapN *
SiygapN and other words in which Y is substituted for w, see in art. Swg.

1 SaAfa *
1. SaAfa, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) aor. yaSiyfu, inf. n. SayofN, (TA,) He, or it, (a company of men, M, Msb,) remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) during the [season called] Sayof, (S, O,) or during his, or their, Sayof, (O, Msb,) or during a Sayof, (K,) bihi in it, (S, M, O, K,) i. e. in a place; (S, M, O;) as also ASTAf↓, (S, O, * K, * TA,) and tSy~f↓; (S, * O, * K, * TA;) and biAlmakaAni AiS~ay~afa↓ is like Say~afa↓ [probably a mistranscription for taSay~afa, of which AiS~ay~afa is a var., and of which, together with one of this var., an ex. will be found in what follows]: (TA:) you say, Sifotu bimakaAni ka*aA [I remained during the Sayof in such a place], and in like manner Sifotuhu, and taSay~afotuhu↓, and Say~afotuhu↓ [probably a mistranscription for AiS~ay~afotuhu↓, as seems to be indicated by what here follows]: (M:) a Hudhalee says,
taSay~afotu nuEomaAna waA@S~ay~afato
[I remained during the Sayof in Noamán, and she remained during the Sayof]. (M, TA.) ― -b2- And Siyfati AlA^aroDu, (S, M, O, K,) a verb of the class of EuniYa, (K,) originally Suyifat, (TA,) The land was rained upon by the rain of the [season called] Sayof. (S, M, O. *) And SifonaA, of the measure fuEilonaA, like xurifonaA and rubiEonaA, We were rained upon by the rain of the Sayof: (S:) and in like manner Suy~ifonaA↓. (M, TA. *) ＝ -A2- SAf Als~ahomu Eani Alhadafi, (S, M, O, Msb, * K, *) aor. yaSiyfu, (S, O, K,) inf. n. SayofN (S, M, O, Msb, K) and SanyofuwfapN (S, M, O) and maSiyfN, (M,) The arrow turned aside from the butt: (S, M, O, Msb, K:) a dial. var. of SAf having for its aor. yaSuwfu and
inf. n. SawofN. (O, Msb, * K.) ― -b2- And SAf AlfaHolu Eano Taruwqatihi The stallion-camel turned away from covering the female that he had covered. (M.)

2 Say~afaniY *
2. Say~afaniY It (a thing, S, O, K) sufficed me for my [season termed] Sayofap, (S, O, K,) or for my Sayof: (Msb:) by the “ thing ” here spoken of is meant food, or a garment, or some other thing. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, in three places.

3 EaAmalahu muSaAyafapF *
3. EaAmalahu muSaAyafapF (S, M, O, Msb, K) and SiyaAfFA (Lh, M) is from AlS~ayofu, (M, O, Msb,) like mu$aAharapF (S, O, Msb, K) from Al$~ahoru, (O, Msb,) and muEaAwamapF (S, O) from AlEaAmu, (O,) i. e. [He made an engagement, or a contract, with him for work or the like] for the days of the Sayof. (S.) And in like manner, AisotaA^ojarahu muSaAyafapF and SiyaAfFA [He hired him, or took him as a hired man or hireling, for the period of the Sayof]. (M.)

4 ASAfwA *
4. ASAfwA They entered the [season called] Sayof: (S, M, O, Msb, K:) like A^a$otawoA meaning “ They entered the [season called] $itaA='. ” (TA.) ― -b2- And ASAft She (a camel) brought forth in the Sayof. (M.) ― -b3- [Hence,] ASAf said of a man, (tropical:) He had offspring born to him [in the summer of his age, i. e.] when he was old, or advanced in age: (S, M, O, K, TA:) or he had no offspring born to him until he was advanced in age, or old. (L, TA.) And (tropical:) He abstained from women while a young man, and then married when old, or advanced in age. (M, TA.) ＝ -A2- ASAf A@ll~`hu Ean~iY $ar~a fulaAnK God turned away, or may God turn away, from me the evil, or mischief, of such a one: (S, O, K: *) belonging to this art. and to art. Swf. (O, TA.)

5 taSay~afa *
5. taSay~afa, and its var. AiS~ay~afa: see 1, first sentence, in four places.

8 A_iSotayafa
8: see 1, first sentence.

SaAfN *
SaAfN: see SaAy^ifN: ＝ -A2- and see also art. Swf.

SayofN *
SayofN as signifying A certain portion of the year is said by ISk to be fem.: (TA, voce $itaA='N; q. v.:) [but by others I find it treated as masc.:] the Sayof as meaning one of the seasons is well known: (M:) Lth says, it is one of the quarters of the year; and is applied by the vulgar to a half of the year [i. e. to the half-year commencing at the vernal equinox; the other half-year being called by them the $itaA=']: Az says, it is, with the Arabs, the division which the vulgar in El-'Irák and Khurásán call the rabiyE [i. e. the spring]; it consists of three months; and the division that next follows it is with the Arabs the qayoZ; and in it is the jamorap [q. v.] of the qiyoZ; then, after this, is the division called the xariyf; and then, after this, the division called the $itaA=': (TA:) [i. e.] it is the quarter of the year vulgarly called the rabiyE, commencing when the sun enters Aries: but is applied by the vulgar to the qayoZ, which is the [summer, i. e.] the quarter commencing when the sun enters Cancer: (Msb in art. zmn; q. v.:) [F says,] the Sayof is the qayoZ [i. e. summer, or the hot season]; or [the season] after the rabiyE: (K:) and [Sgh says,] the Sayof is one of the divisions of the year; which is after the rabiyE: (O:) [but unless this explanation in the O denote only a vulgar meaning, and the latter of the two explanations in the K be virtually a repetition, we must suppose that, in each of them, by the rbyE is meant the season of rain thus termed, which ends in March: (see the latter of the two tables which I have inserted voce zamanN:) most probably, I think, both have been faultily transcribed from what here follows; for the S is largely copied in the O, and the S and O are among the principal sources of the K, which generally follows the O when it differs (rightly or wrongly) from the S:] the Sayof is one of the divisions of the year; which is after [that called] Alr~abiyEu AlA^aw~alu and before [that called] AlqayoZu: (S:) [this admits of two renderings, both of which are correct; namely, the quarter after the season of two months called AlrbyE AlAw~l (which ends in March) and before the quarter called AlqyZ (which is summer); and also the season of two months after that called AlrbyE AlAw~l and before the similar season called AlqyZ: (see the former of the two tables to which I have referred above:) but probably the latter only was meant by him who first gave. this explanation:] the pl. is A^aSoyaAfN (M, O, K) and SuyuwfN: (M, Msb:) SayofapN↓ is a more particular term [app. meaning A single Sayof; (see 2;)]; it is like $atowapN [q. v.]; (O, K;) and its pl. is SiyafN, like bidarN pl. of badorapN. (Fr, O, K.) AlS~ayofa Day~aEoti All~abana is a saying expl. in art. DyE [q. v.]. (O, K.) ― -b2- AlS~ayofu also signifies The rain that comes in the [season called] Sayof; (S, O, Msb, K;) [see, again, the second of the tables to which I have referred above, and see also nawoN;] and (O, K) so AlS~ay~ifu↓; (M, O, K;) also signifying the herbage thereof: (M:) or, (K,) accord. to Lth, (O,) the latter signifies the rain that falls after the division [a mistake for the rain] called the rabiyE; (O, K;) and so the former; (K;) and it is also called AlS~ayofiY~u↓; (O, K;) which likewise signifies the herbage thereof. (TA.) Hence the prov., relating to the completing of the performance of a needful affair, tamaAmu Alr~abiyEi AlS~ayofu [The completion of the rain called the rbyE is that called the Syf]: for the rain called the rbyE is the first rain, and the Syf is that which is [next] after it. (TA.) ― -b3- A=yapu AlS~ayofi is [A verse] in the end (A=xir) of suwrapu Aln~isaA='i [the 4th chapter of the Kur-án, but which verse I know not], mentioned in a tradition. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also The female of the buwm [or owl]. (Kr, M.)

SayofapN *
SayofapN: see the next preceding paragraph, latter half.

SayofiY~N *
SayofiY~N A thing of, or belonging to, the [season called] Sayof. (S, O.) ― -b2- A young camel born in the Sayof. (M.) [And in like manner a sheep or goat: see SafariY~N.] ― -b3- And [hence,] (assumed tropical:) A son born to a father [in the summer of his age, i. e.] old, or advanced in age. (S, M, O.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce riboEiY~N.] ― -b4- See also SayofN, near the end of the paragraph. ― -b5- Sayofiy~apN [used as a subst., or as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant, for miyrapN Sayofiy~apN,] and SaAy^ifapN↓ signify The miyrap [or provision of corn &c.] in the first part of the Sayof [here meaning spring]; i. e. the second myrp; for the first of the miyra is the riboEiy~ap, then the Sayofiy~ap, then the dafay^iy~ap, and then the ramaDiy~ap: (M:) or the SaAy^ifap↓ of a people is their miyrap in the Sayof. (S, O, K.) [See miyrapN.] ― -b6- [Sayofiy~apN is also applied to The latter, or last, season of the bringing forth of camels; so in an explanation of hubaEN in the S and TA.]

Sayofiy~apN *
Sayofiy~apN [fem. of SayofiY~N: and also used as a subst., or as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant: see the latter word].

SaAy^ifN *
SaAy^ifN is used as an imitative sequent in the phrase SayofN SaAy^ifN, (S, O, K,) meaning A warm, or hot, [spring or] summer: (PS:) a phrase like layolN laAy^ilN &c. (S, O.) And one says yawomN SaAy^ifN, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) meaning A hot day; (O, K;) and yawomN SaAfN↓ (S, O, K) was sometimes said, meaning SaAy^ifN; like yawomN raAHN [as meaning raAy^iHN]: (S:) and layolapN SaAy^ifapN [a hot night]. (S, O, Msb.) ― -b2- And maTarN SaAy^ifN [app. Rain coming in the Sayof, meaning spring; as also muSiyfN↓, occurring in a verse cited voce rasama, q. v.]. (M.) See also SaAfK in art. Sfw.

SaAy^ifapN *
SaAy^ifapN [fem. of SaAy^fN, q. v. ― -b2- Also, as a subst.,] A warring, or warring and plundering, expedition in the Sayof [i. e. either spring or summer]: (M, Mgh, and Ham p. 239:) pl. SawaAy^ifu. (Mgh, and Ham ib.) And [particularly] (Mgh) A warring, or warring and plundering, expedition against the Greeks (Alr~uwm): because they [i. e. the Arabs] used to go on expeditions of this kind in the Syf, (S, Mgh, O, K,) and to return in the winter, (Mgh,) on account of the cold and snow. (S, O, K.) And they said, waliYa fulaAnN AlS~aAy^ifapa, meaning Such a one was commander of the army going on a warring, or warring and plundering, expedition in the Sayof: (Ham ubi suprà:) [but Mtr says,] he who explains SaAy^ifapN as meaning the place [of], or the army [engaged in, such an expedition], errs: [adding that the Hanafee Imám] Mohammad has used the phrase AlS~awaAy^ifu wanaHowuhaA mina AlEasaAkiri AlEiZaAmi either by surmise or by extension of the [proper] meaning. (Mgh.) ― -b3- See also SayofiY~N, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also The time, or season of the Sayof. (M, TA.)

AlS~ay~ifu *
AlS~ay~ifu: see SayofN, last quarter of the paragraph.

Say~ifapN *
Say~ifapN, originally SayowifapN: see art. Swf.

maSiyfN *
maSiyfN A place of remaining, staying, dwelling, or abiding, during the [season called] Sayof; (S, O, TA;) as also muSoTaAfN↓ (S, K, TA) and mutaSay~afN↓: (TA:) and a time thereof: (Sb, M, TA:) pl. maSaAyifu. (Msb.) ― -b2- And A place in which dates are dried in the [season called] Sayof.
(Har p. 165.) ＝ -A2- [Also part. n. of the verb in the phrase Siyfati AlA^aroDu:] you say A^aroDN maSiyfapN and maSoyuwfapN↓ Land rained upon by the rain of the [season called] Sayof. (S, M, O, K.) ＝ -A3- Also, applied to a channel in which water flows, Winding, or tortuous: (S, M:) from SaAfa, like maDiyqN from DaAqa. (S.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce karabapN: and see also maDiyfN.]

muSiyfN *
muSiyfN: see SAy^ifN. ― -b2- Also, (M, O, K,) and muSiyfapN, (O, K,) [in the CK, erroneously, maSiyfN and maSiyfapN,] and miSoyaAfN↓, (M, O, K,) applied to a she-camel, (M, O, K,) That has brought forth in the [season called] Sayof: (M, L, TA:) or having with her her young one: (O, K, TA:) pl. of the last maSaAyiyfu. (TA in art. jr.) ― -b3- And [hence,] the first, (tropical:) A man having a child born to him [in the summer of his age, i. e.] when he is old, or advanced in age. (TA.)

miSoyaAfN *
miSoyaAfN, applied to land (A^aroDN), Having in it abundance of the rain of the [season called] Sayof. (O, K.) ― -b2- And, so applied, Late in producing herbage. (O, K.) ― -b3- See also muSiyfN. ― -b4- [Hence,] (tropical:) A man who does not take a wife until he has whiteness in the hair of his head mixed with the blackness thereof. (O, K.)

maSoyuwfap *
maSoyuwfap: see maSiyfN.

muSoTaAfN *
muSoTaAfN: see maSiyfN.

mataSay~afN *
mataSay~afN: see maSiyfN.

1 SaAka bihi *
1. SaAka bihi, aor. yaSiyku, inf. n. SayokN: see 1 in art. Swk.

3 Zal~a yuSaAyikuniY muno*u Alyawomi *
3. Zal~a yuSaAyikuniY muno*u Alyawomi a dial. var. of yuSaAy^ikuniY. (TA in art. Swk. See 3 in art. SA^k.)

1 SaAla *
1. SaAla, aor. yaSiylu, i. q. SAl having for its aor. yaSuwlu, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) i. e. He (a man) leaped or sprang [&c.]. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.) ＝ -A2- Siyla lahumo ka*aA, (S and K in art. Swl,) or lahu, (Ibn- 'Abbád and O and K in the present art.,) Such a thing was appointed, or ordained, or prepared, for them, or for him. (Ibn-'Abbád, S, O, K.) This is its proper place. (TA.)

SiylapN *
SiylapN The knot of the Ea*abap [i. e. of the end, or of the suspensory thong, of a whip]. (S and K in art. Swl, and O in the present art.)

SiyaAlN *
SiyaAlN and SiyaAlapN: see art. Swl.

Suy~amN *
Suy~amN and Siy~amN and Suy~aAmN and SayaAmaY pls. of SaAy^imN, expl. in art. Swm.

SiynapN *
SiynapN [originally SiwonapN]: see art. Swn.

SiyniY~N *
SiyniY~N Of, or relating to, AlS~iyn [i. e. China]. (TA.) [Hence,] A^awaAnK Siyniy~apN, (K, TA,) and [the pl.] SawaAniY~u, (S,) Vessels of AlS~iyn, (S, K, TA,) made in the country thus called [i. e. China]. (TA.)

SiyniynN *
SiyniynN A certain drug, [said to be] well known. (TA. [But what it is I have been unable to learn.])

SiyaAnN *
SiyaAnN and SiyaAnapN inf. n. of SaAna expl. in art. Swn. ＝ -A2- The former, of which SuyaAnN and SayaAnN are said to be vars., is also syn. with SiwaAnN, likewise expl. in art. Swn.

Say~inN *
Say~inN: see art. Swn.
